description: On 21 July 2008, Cambodian Defence Minister Gen Tea Banh and Thai Military Commander General Boonsang Niempradit met for a bilateral meeting in Thailand�s eastern border province of Sa Kaew. The goal of the talks was to lower tensions between the countries and to find a solution to the border dispute. However, no breakthrough was reached.

On 28 July 2008, both countries� foreign ministers agreed to pursue a withdrawal of troops from the contested temple. This agreement did not lead to any results however and clashes broke out in October of 2008.

On 13 November 2008, the two countries reached an agreement to start demarcating the border and withdraw troops from the contested area. Despite this agreement, armed fighting flared up again in 2009.

On 23 May 2009, Thai General Anupong spoke via mobile phone to Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen during a frontline visit. They both signaled their interest in reducing the amount of troops deployed at the border. However, the phone call did not result in any actual troop reductions.

On 15 November 2009, at the sideline of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) meeting, Indonesia met separately with both conflict parties and passed messages between them, thus conducting shuttle diplomacy. Indonesia tried to ease the tensions, but no significant results were reached.

On 4 February 2011, clashes broke out once again in the vicinity of Preah Vihear. Both sides made use of heavy weapons such as artillery, mortars, and multi-rocket launchers. On the same day, military leaders from both countries held phone calls and exchanged text messages to try arranging a ceasefire, but to no result.

Indonesia � which held the chairmanship of ASEAN at the time � tried to mediate between Cambodia and Thailand at an ASEAN Meeting in Jakarta on 22 February 2011. The two sides announced to allow Indonesian observers to be present at the contested temple site and monitor the disputed border territory. However, the Thai foreign ministry later backtracked and the decision about observers was therefore delayed.
On 28 April 2011 at a meeting of Thai and Cambodian field commanders, a ceasefire was agreed upon. However it was broken multiple times in the following days.

On 3 May 2011, just days before the 2011 ASEAN summit in Jakarta, Indonesia, the chairman of ASEAN, mediated between the two conflict parties. One topic of discussion was the deploying of observers in the contested area. However, Thailand refused to sign an agreement that would include a provision on observers.
On 4 May 2011, armies of both countries agreed on another ceasefire and borders were re-opened for trade.

On 7 May 2011, ASEAN, under the chairmanship of Indonesian Foreign Minister Marty Natalegawa, made a breakthrough in mediating the border conflict. Both sides formally agreed to let Indonesian observer teams enter the temple grounds and observe the implementation of the ceasefire. However, no observers did actually enter the temple ground after all. Nevertheless, the border conflict eased substantially from mid-2011 onwards. This was mostly due to the Thai general election in 2011, where the ultra-nationalist People Alliance for Democracy (PAD) lost against the pro-Thaksin Pheu Thai Party. Bilateral relations between the two countries have since improved greatly. There was another short exchange of gunfire on 15 December 2011, but no further armed clashes have been noted since then.
The newly elected Thai premier Yingluck Shinawatry met with Cambodian government officials in Phnom Penh on 15 September 2011. This meeting symbolized a thaw in Thai-Cambodian relations.
On 21 December 2011, the two countries met in Phnom Penh in Cambodia and agreed to set up a Joint Working Group (JWG) to plan the complete withdrawal of both armies from the conflict area.

On 13 July 2012, Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen met with Thai premier Yingluck Shinawatra in Siem Reap and they agreed on withdrawing their troops from the contested area. This withdrawal took place during the following days.
Bruno Delaye, a special adviser to President Francois Mitterrand of France, attempted to mediate negotiations between the parties beginning on 28 February 1994.

President Gnassingbe Eyadema of Togo mediated negotiations between the conflict parties in Kara on 4 July 1994. Cameroon submitted the dispute concerning the Bakassi peninsula to the International Court of Justice (ICJ) on 29 March 1994, as well as requested the mediation of the United Nations and the OAU. On 24 March 1994, the OAU appealed for the withdrawal of troops from the disputed region. An OAU fact-finding mission headed by OAU Deputy Secretary-General Tobias Mapuranga arrived in the region on 18 April 1994.

Cameroonian troops and Nigerian troops clashed on the Bakassi peninsula beginning on 3 February. Cameroonian troops captured 30 Nigerian civilians. UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali appealed for a troop withdrawal on 5 February 1996 and OAU Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim appealed for peaceful negotiations on 7 February 1996. President Gnassingbe Eyadema of Togo mediated a ceasefire agreement between the countries in Kara in Togo on 17 February 1996.
Lakhdar Brahimi, the special representative of the UN secretary-general, facilitated negotiations between the parties beginning on 14 May 1996.

The ICJ began hearings on the dispute on 2 March 1998. On 2 March 1998, Nigeria asked the ICJ to dismiss the case submitted by Cameroon, but the ICJ ruled that it had jurisdiction over the border dispute on 11 June 1998. In anticipation of the ICJ�s ruling, UN Secretary General Kofi Annan and French president Jaques Chirac mediated between the Nigerian and Cameroonian heads of state in Paris in September 2002. During this meeting, the two sides agreed to respect the court�s pronouncement. However, when the ICJ ruled that the Bakassi Peninsula fell under Cameroon�s jurisdiction, Nigeria quickly rejected the finding.

On 15 November 2002, the conflict parties met in Geneva for talks mediated by Kofi Annan. This meeting led to the Joint Cameroon-Nigeria Border Commission being tasked with overseeing the implementation of the court�s ruling.

UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan mediated talks between Cameroonian President Paul Biya and Nigerian President Olusegun Obasanjo in New York from 10 to 12 June 2006. This round of talks led to the signing of the Greentree Agreement on 12 June 2006. This agreement stipulated that Nigeria would pull back troops from the Peninsula. As part of the agreement, a follow-up committee � composed of both conflict parties, Germany, France, the UK, the US, and the UN � was established to oversee implementation. Nigerian troops completely withdrew in August 2006. Cameroon and Nigeria held a ceremony in Bakassi on 14 August 2006 to officially mark end of the conflict.

The EU appealed for negotiations on 15 May 1998. President Hassan Gouled Aptidon, who held the chair of IGAD at the time, attempted to initiate negotiations between the conflict parties on 15 May 1998. A first round of negotiations was mediated by Susan Rice of the US and Patrick Mazimhaka of Rwanda on 19 May 1998. France offered to mediate on 22 May 1998 and OAU Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim appealed for negotiations on 4 June 1998. On 9 June 1998, the OAU established a four-member conciliation commission � including Burkina Faso, Djibouti, Rwanda, and Zimbabwe � chaired by President Blaise Compaore of Burkina Faso.
President Mubarak of Egypt mediated negotiations between the countries between 12 and 14 June 1998.

The United States and Rwanda conducted a joint-mediation effort, led by Susan Rice and Paul Kagame, that shuttled between the conflict parties in June 1998. The team proposed a four-point plan for peace that focused on border demarcation.
The OAU conciliation commission mediated negotiations between Eritrea and Ethiopian representatives in Ouagadougou on 1 and 2 August 1998.
Anthony Lake, special envoy of the US, facilitated negotiations between the countries in October 1998.

The OAU conciliation commission, along with Lake�s team, mediated negotiations between Eritrean and Ethiopian representatives in Ouagadougou on 7 and 8 November 1998. During this round of negotiations, the OAU proposed a Framework Agreement and a Modalities of Implementation. These two agreements were accepted by Ethiopia, but rejected by Eritrea.
On 14 July 1999, Eritrea and Ethiopia both accepted the peace proposal outlined by the OAU. This was followed by an absence of fighting for eight months. Fighting resumed in February 2000.
UN special envoy Mohamed Sahnoun facilitated negotiations between the countries in February 2000.

Another round of negotiations took place in Algiers in May 2000. This round of negotiations was mediated by Algerian President Abdelaziz Bouteflika, who was the chairman of the OAU at the time. The UN Security Council imposed military sanctions in the form of an arms embargo against Eritrea and Ethiopia on 17 May 2000. Foreign Minister Mustafa Osman of Sudan offered to mediate negotiations between Eritrea and Ethiopia on 25 May 2000.

Another round of OAU-led negotiations was held in Algiers beginning on 29 May 2000. This round of peace talks ended with Eritrean representatives accepting a ceasefire proposal submitted by the OAU on 9 June 2000.
Ethiopia and Eritrea subsequently signed a ceasefire agreement on 18 June 2000.

OAU-led negotiations led to the conclusion of the Algiers Agreement on 12 December 2000. The agreement was also signed by UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan and US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright. The treaty established a permanent ceasefire and a process for the demarcation of the border between the countries. It was also agreed that a UN peacekeeping force would be deployed to help to implement the agreement. The treaty calls for the return of troops on both sides to positions prior to the conflict. The treaty also sets up a process for settling claims and compensation for damaged property on both sides.

An Eritrea-Ethiopia Boundary Commission established by the Algiers agreement was set up to demarcate the border. A decision was announced in April 2002 that the contested area belonged to Eritrea. Despite public acceptance of the conclusion, Ethiopian President Meles Zenawai offered an alternative five-point peace proposal. This proposal was rejected by Eritrea. In parallel, Eritrea�s relationship with the United Nations Mission in Ethiopia and Eritrea became strained and Eritrea tried to restrict the UN�s activities. On 6 and 7 September 2007, the Joint Commission convened the two sides in the Hague for reconciliation talks. Nevertheless, the two sides nearly came to a renewed conflict after Ethiopia threatened to renege on the Algiers Agreement in response to Eritrean encroachment on the Temporary Security Zone of 2007.
United States� Assistant Secretary of State for Africa Donald Yamamoto mediated indirect negotiations between Eritrea and Ethiopia between 22 and 24 April 2018.

In June 2018, Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed publicly announced that Ethiopia would move forward with fully implementing the Algiers Accord. In response, an Eritrean delegation convened for peace talks with Ethiopian representatives in Addis Ababa in late June 2018.

On 8 and 9 July 2018, the parties met in Eritrea for a round of discussions. This round of peace talks resulted in the signing the Joint Declaration of Peace and Friendship between Eritrea and Ethiopia on 9 July 2018.
agreement_name: Joint Declaration of Peace and Friendship between Eritrea and Ethiopia

description: The two sides met for another round of peace talks in Ethiopia from 14 to 16 July 2018.

On 16 September 2018, the two parties convened for a final round of peace talks in Jeddah in Saudi Arabia. This round of talks led to the signing of the Agreement on Peace, Friendship and Comprehensive Cooperation. The United Arab Emirates played an important role in a year of back-channel talks leading up to the conclusion of the peace agreement.
agreement_name: Agreement on Peace, Friendship and Comprehensive Cooperation

description: On 22 February 2019, Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed and Eritrean President Isaias Afwerki met in Addis Ababa to discuss the implementation of the Agreement on Peace, Friendship and Comprehensive Cooperation that had been concluded in September 2018. The talks focused on their shared border, which had been re-opened in September 2018, as well as focused on trade and transport and how to deepen cooperation.

On 18 July 2019, the Eritrean president met with the Ethiopian prime minister in Asmara to discuss how to deepen mutual cooperation in order to implement the Agreement on Peace, Friendship and Comprehensive Cooperation. No substantial results were reported. The countries of the region and the international community expressed their support of the process.

In March 2019, Eritrean President Afewerki hosted a tripartite meeting with the Kenyan and Ethiopian President to discuss bilateral and regional issues. The three leaders also discussed bilateral matters in separate meetings.

On 3 May 2020, Eritrean President Afewerki arrived in Addis Ababa for a two-day official visit. The two leaders discussed ways of strengthening the efforts in the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic, but also discussed the implementation of the Agreement on Peace, Friendship and Comprehensive Cooperation concluded in September 2018.

On 12 October 2020, Eritrean President Afewerki arrived in Ethiopia for a three-day official visit. The talks were aimed at enhancing bilateral ties, as well as to consolidate regional cooperation. Eritrea and Ethiopia did not engage in negotiations during 2021 and 2022 due to the armed conflict between the Ethiopian government and TPLF. Eritrea fought on the side of the Ethiopian government in this war.
In the early months of 2010, Qatar conducted shuttle diplomacy between Djibouti and Eritrea.

A round of negotiations between Djibouti and Eritrea, mediated by Qatar, led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in Doha on 6 June 2010. As part of its mediation effort, Qatar sent peacekeeping forces to the disputed area.

On 5 and 6 September 2018, Ethiopia, Eritrea, and Somalia held a summit to improve relations within the region. This led to the conclusion of an agreement between these three countries, after which they invited Djibouti to continue the talks. All four countries subsequently signed a peace agreement on 6 September 2018. This normalized the relations between Djibouti and Eritrea.
On 13 June 2011, the African Union High Implementation Panel (AUHIP) held a round of negotiations to tackle remaining contentious issues between Sudan and South Sudan
On 20 June 2011, the AUHIP facilitated an agreement between the parties on temporary arrangements for Abyei.
agreement_name: Agreement Between The Government of the Republic of Sudan and The Sudan People's Liberation Movement on Temporary Arrangements for the Administration and Security of the Abyei Area

description: On 29 June 2011, following mediation by the AUHIP, the two sides formally signed the Agreement on the Joint Political and Security Mechanism and the Joint Position Paper on Border Security. In July that year, the United Nations launched the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS).
agreement_name: Agreement on the Joint Political and Security Mechanism and the Joint Position Paper on Border Security

description: On 29 July 2011, the AUHIP mediated between Sudan and South Sudan on security arrangement regarding the shared border between the parties.

A series of meetings mediated by the AUHIP with both conflict parties was held from 30 July to 31 July 2011. Although no progress was made regarding the delineation of the Safe Demilitarized Border Zone, the parties reached the Agreement on the Border Monitoring Support Mission.
agreement_name: Agreement on the Border Monitoring Support Mission

description: From December 2011 onwards, tensions over oil payments exacerbated. Sudan took control of the oil flowing from South Sudan as payment for transporting the oil from South Sudan to Port Sudan. South Sudan subsequently unilaterally halted its oil production in January 2012. This escalatory succession of events prompted IGAD to hold a peace conference on 26 January 2012. IGAD Chair Meles Zenawai acted as the chief mediator at this conference. No progress was made at this conference.

Another round of negotiations, mediated by the AUHIP with support from the UN, led to the signing of the Memorandum of Understanding on Non-Aggression and Cooperation on 10 February 2012. However, fighting between Sudanese and South Sudanese security forces continued along their border.
agreement_name: Memorandum of Understanding on Non-Aggression and Cooperation

description: With support from the UN Special Envoy, the AUHIP mediated between the conflict parties in March 2012. With tensions remaining high, South Sudan surrounded Sudan�s largest oilfield in April 2012. A summit was planned on 3 April 2012 to convene the leaders from both sides, but the summit did not take place. Instead, the South Sudanese army occupied the Heglig region on 10 April 2012, but ultimately pulled back on 20 April 2012 following international pressure to do so.

A round of negotiations mediated by the AUHIP led to the signing of two initial framework agreements, one on the issue of nationality and another agreement on border demarcation in Addis Ababa on 10 April 2012. With tensions remaining high, South Sudan surrounded Sudan�s largest oilfield in April 2012.

The AU Peace and Security Council established a roadmap to peace between the parties on 24 April 2012. This plan officially placed the AUHIP in charge of mediation with the aim to resolve multiple issues of contention such as Abyei, the Safe Demilitarized Border Zone, and oil in the span of three months. The UN Security Council adopted this plan in Resolution 2046, adopted on 2 May 2012. The conflict parties subsequently engaged in negotiations mediated by AUHIP Chairman Thabo Mbeki in Addis Ababa on 29 May 2012.
Another round of negotiations led by the AU was held in Addis Ababa on 22 June 2012.
Another meeting was held on 4 September 2012. The AUHIP went on to propose its own draft agreement on 21 September 2012. South Sudan accepted this agreement, but Sudan rejected it.
The AUHIP went on to propose its own draft agreement on 21 September 2012. South Sudan accepted this agreement, but Sudan rejected it.

The Presidents of both countries attended a round of negotiations mediated by AUHIP in Addis Ababa from 23 to 27 September 2012. This culminated in the signing of the Cooperation Agreement and eight other agreements. This re-opened food trade between the countries and Sudan released 19 South Sudanese prisoners. On 27 September 2012, Sudan and South Sudan signed the Implementation Modalities for Security Arrangements, which was aimed at facilitating the implementation of the Agreement on Security Arrangements.
To implement the agreement signed in September 2012, the Joint Political and Security Mechanism convened in Juba from 5 to 7 November 2012.

The mechanism resulting from the September agreement met once again on 19 December 2012, with support from AUHIP and the UN. At this meeting, the countries worked with the Force Commander of the United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (UNISFA) to create an implementation matrix.

The African Union High Implementation Panel (AUHIP) mediated between South Sudan and Sudan in Addis Ababa from 3 to 5 January 2013. The conflict parties agreed that the implementation of previously concluded agreements needed to be sped up.

From 13 to 18 January 2013, the Presidents of both countries attended a summit facilitated by the AUHIP. This effort did not result in any peace agreement, but the parties agreed to the implementation matrix put together in December 2012.
Sudan and South Sudan engaged in negotiations mediated by the AUHIP on 12 March 2013. The conflict parties agreed to resume oil production and create the demilitarized zone.

A major milestone was reached the following month when Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir visited South Sudanese President Kiir Mayardit for the first time in the new country. During this visit, on 12 April 2013, the two sides agreed to create a joint high-level committee.

The conflict parties engaged in negotiations mediated by the AUHIP from 24 to 27 April 2013. Throughout May and July 2013, tensions over accusations between both sides concerning support for rebel groups began to increase. On 22 July 2013, the African Union established an ad hoc mechanism to investigate these claims. In late July 2013, Sudan halted oil transportation in response to South Sudanese support for the Sudan People�s Liberation Army/Movement � North (SPLM/A-N). The Sudan President had met with AUHIP delegates before announcing this decision.
The joint commission met in Khartoum on 23 August 2013.
The two Presidents convened for a peace meeting on 3 September 2013.
The earlier September meeting paved the way for a meeting between ministers from both sides in Juba on 23 September 2013, which led to the signing of an agreement on trade and border passage.

In order to hold a referendum on the status of Abyei, South Sudan asked for international support to implement the peace agreement on 7 October 2013. In relation to a remaining question of citizenship for the Misseriya and Ngok Dinka tribes of Abyei, Sudan proposed dual citizenship. The Presidents met once again on 22 October 2013 to try to find a solution to the Abyei question, but this ended without progress.

The Presidents met for another round of negotiations on 23 October 2013. Both sides agreed to establish a security zone and end their rebel support. South Sudan rejected the effort to hold a unilateral referendum on the disputed Abyei, which led to condemnation from the AU.

On 28 November 2013, Sudanese and South Sudanese security delegates met for negotiations mediated by the AUHIP in Khartoum. The AUHIP was unable to make progress on creating the demilitarized security zone during this round of negotiations. Armed fighting between Sudan and South Sudan resumed in mid-December.
On 4 April 2014, the Presidents of Sudan and South Sudan held their first round of peace talks following armed clashes in December 2013. This meeting took place in Khartoum.
Sudanese and South Sudanese representatives engaged in a bilateral round of negotiations regarding the demilitarized zone in Juba in September 2014.

Another round of bilateral round of negotiations regarding the demilitarized zone took place in Khartoum in September 2014. The AU invited the conflict parties to negotiations on the disputed border areas, but Sudan declined this offer of mediation.
Russia mediated peace talks between Sudan and South Sudan in Moscow on 10 September 2015.

On 14 October 2015, Sudan and South Sudan convened for peace talks in Addis Abba. At this round of talks, Sudan and South Sudan agreed to establish a buffer zone with join units deployed for monitoring.

Accusations of rebel support increased tensions between Sudan and South Sudan in 2017. In February 2017, the AU began to investigate whether South Sudan was housing Sudanese rebels. Sudan continued to accuse South Sudan of harboring rebels, but South Sudan continued to deny this charge. The Joint Political and Security Mechanism convened in Khartoum on 31 October 2017 in preparation for a meeting between Presidents Omar al-Bashir and President Salva Kiir. The two presidents met in Khartoum on 31 October 2017 to reaffirm their commitment to peace.
The Joint Border Commission met in November 2017. This meeting was the first meeting of this commission since 2016.
As part of the Joint Demarcation Committee, the AU mediated between representatives of Sudan and South Sudan between 10 and 13 September 2018. However, no progress was made.
On 2 October 2019, the Joint Political and Security Mechanism held a meeting in Juba.
Throughout 2019, the United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (UNSIFA) mediated meetings with officials from Sudan and South Sudan to promote peace in Abyei.
On 30 April 2021, the Government of Kyrgyzstan and the Government of Tajikistan agreed on an initial ceasefire.

On 1 May 2021, Russia mediated a round of negotiations between the Government of Kyrgyzstan and the Government of Tajikistan in Batken in Kyrgyzstan, resulting in the signing of a ceasefire. Government delegations from both sides met to discuss the delimitation and demarcation of their shared border. It was agreed that by 2 May 2021, all military units and equipment would be completely withdrawn from the entire Kyrgyz-Tajik State Border to their permanent bases.

On 29 June 2021, the Government of Kyrgyzstan and the Government of Tajikistan signed a Joint Statement on socio-economic bilateral relations in Dushanbe in Tajikistan. The presidents emphasized the importance of preventing border conflicts and urged both parties to adhere to international obligations and norms. They expressed a commitment to resolving issues peacefully through diplomatic means and mutual dialogue, particularly concerning the delimitation and demarcation of their shared border.
agreement_name: Joint Statement on socio-economic bilateral relations

description: On 16 September 2022, the Government of Kyrgyzstan and the Government of Tajikistan signed a ceasefire agreement. The ceasefire entered into force on 17 September 2022, but it was broken immediately after.
On 20 September 2022, the Government of Kyrgyzstan and the Government of Tajikistan signed a peace agreement, which led to the cessation of clashes.

On 29 January 2013, the government of Yemen and AQAP reached a ceasefire agreement that was brokered by tribal leaders in al-Bayda. This ceasefire was concluded to allow civilians to flee from the Radda region.

On 26 June 2004, a group of Yemeni mediators � including lawmakers and among them Yahia Badreddin al-Houthi, the brother of Ansarallah leader Hussein Badreddin al-Houthi � launched a mediation effort and met with Hussein Badreddin al-Houthi. This mediation attempt was launched at the request of President Ali Abdullah Saleh. The mediation effort failed and Ansarallah stated they were committed to continue the rebellion.
On 21 September 2004, the Government of Yemen (North Yemen) and Ansarallah reached a ceasefire agreement during a round of negotiations mediated by tribal leaders.
President Ali Abdullah Saleh announced on 14 May 2005 that a peace deal had been reached during negotiations with the Houthis.
Qatar emir Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani met with Yemeni President Ali Abdullah Saleh in May 2007 to discuss peace prospects with the Houthis.

In May 2007, following a peace meeting between Qatar and the Government of Yemen, a delegation from the Qatari foreign ministry met with the Houthi leadership. Shortly thereafter, Yahia Badreddin al-Houthi, the brother of Ansarallah leader Abdul-Malik Badruldeen al-Houthi, travelled to Qatar. Those meetings resulted in a list of general principles which paved the way for negotiations in June 2007.

On 16 June 2007, the Qatari emir Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani, with support from Yemeni parliamentarians, mediated a ceasefire agreement between the Government of Yemen and Ansarallah in Doha. The deal required rebels to lay down their weapons and included a temporary exile for their leaders. The ceasefire was the result of a series of rounds of peace talks mediated by Qatar.

Qatar mediated a round of negotiations between the conflict parties from 31 January to 1 February 2008. This led to the conclusion of the Doha Agreement on 1 February 2008. As part of the Doha Peace Process, Qatar pledged $300-500 million in reconstruction assistance for Saada province in exchange for the disarmament of the Houthis. Both sides agreed to cease military operations, release prisoners of war, accept and the extension of state authority into the region. The Houthis also agreed to adhere to the republican system, the constitution, and the laws in force in the country.

Following the signing of the Doha peace agreement, the Qatari committee overseeing its implementation arrived in Yemen and held discussion with the Ansarallah leader Abdul-Malik Badruldeen al-Houthi in the Tamrah area on 14 February 2008.

From 4 to 5 May 2008, Qatari mediators met with representatives of Yemeni government authorities and the Ansarallah rebels and began a new round of talks in Saada to revive the fragile agreement brokered in February.
Shaykhs, notables, and deputies of the Saada governorate mediated a round of negotiations between the Government of Yemen and Ansarallah that led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 17 July 2008.
third_party: traditional leaders, community leaders, local government

description: In mid-August 2009, President Saleh presented six conditions which the Houthis should respect for a ceasefire to be brokered, including the Houthi�s withdrawal, removal of checkpoints, and the clarification of the fate of kidnapped foreigners. In response, the Houthis submitted a message to the president on 19 August 2009, consisting of eleven points, which among others demanded the lifting of military blockades and the redeployment and return of military forces to their barracks, in exchange for which the al- Houthis commit to withdraw from the areas they occupy and declare their loyalty to the state, stipulating that the government should appoint directors and security and education officials from among the al- Houthis. Both sides rejected the conditions for a ceasefire put forward by the other party.

On 26 August 2009, the Government of Yemen and the Houthis reached a ceasefire agreement in the Saada province. This ceasefire was brokered by a local mediation and reconstruction committee. Ansarallah agreed to stop blocking roads and operating their strongholds in the mountains in exchange for an end to the military crackdown by government forces. On 4 September 2009, the Government of Yemen announced a unilateral ceasefire for humanitarian purposes. The Yemeni government announced a three-day ceasefire on 19 September 2009 for the Muslim holiday of Eid al-Fitr.

On 6 February 2010, on behalf of the Yemeni government, a group of local mediators handed over a timetable to implement the government�s six conditions for a ceasefire to Ansarallah. These conditions included the removal of checkpoints, the withdrawal of forces, clarification of the fate of kidnapped foreigners, handing over all captured military and civilian equipment, abide by law and order, and ending all attacks on Saudi Arabia�s military territory. Ansarallah agreed to these conditions on 11 February 2010 and the conflict parties concluded a ceasefire in Saada province.

On 21 June 2010, Yemeni Shaykh Ali Nasir Qirshah mediated a 22-point ceasefire agreement between the Government of Yemen and Ansarallah. The ceasefire was concluded in response to an escalation of the conflict and was aimed at ending the war.

On 13 July 2010, Qatar mediated a round of negotiations that led to a ceasefire agreement between the Government of Yemen and Ansarallah. The leaders decided to reactivate the Doha peace agreement. This agreement is a 22-point treaty containing, among others, a pledge to return internally displaced persons to their home villages and provide humanitarian aid to Sana?a.

In August 2010, follow-up meetings took place between negotiators from the Yemeni government and the Houthi rebels under the mediation of Qatar. On 16 August 2010, Qatari Prime Minister Sheikh Hamad bin Jassim al-Thani met with Yemeni President Ali Abdullah Saleh to discuss efforts to consolidate Yemen�s truce with Shiite rebels.

A round of peace talks mediated by Qatar began in Doha between representatives of the Yemeni government and the rebels took place between 23 and 26 August 2010. The two sides agreed on a peace agreement on 26 August 2010. The two parties agreed on the return of IDPs to their home villages, the release of all rebel detainees from government jails, and the provision of humanitarian aid including food and medicines to the residents of Saada. The agreement also stipulated a timetable for the implementation of the Doha agreement concluded in 2008 and the ceasefire concluded in February 2010.

In response to Arab Spring-inspired civil unrest, leading to key military commanders shifting to the opposition camp and encouraging mass desertion from the military, President Ali Abdullah Saleh sought to exit power. To this purpose, he turned to the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) for help. As part of a GCC initiative, President Abdullah Saleh and opposition leaders signed an agreement in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on 23 November 2011. Ansarallah and al-Hirak refused to take part and did not endorse the resulting agreement. The initiative, backed by the five permanent members of the UN Security Council and the European Union, ended President Ali Abdullah Saleh�s thirty-three-year term, and placed Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi, his then deputy, as interim president. The plan also included a six-month National Dialogue Conference (NDC) involving political parties, social groups, women, youth, and regional actors to draft a new constitution and prepare local, parliamentary, and presidential elections for 2014. The National Dialogue Conference foreseen by the GCC initiative took place from 18 March 2013 to 25 January 2014. On 25 January 2014, 565 participants - including representatives of youth, women, the General Congress Party, and the joint meeting parties, but also from Ansarallah and al-Hirak � signed a document on the outcomes of the National Dialogue Conference. The third parties involved in mediating this agreement were the GCC, the League of Arab States, the EU, the five permanent members of the UN Security Council, the Friends of Yemen and �other supporting states and organisations.� The signatories agreed on a roadmap for Yemen�s full transition to a democratic state that respects freedom, the rule of law, human rights, and good governance. A special committee also agreed that Yemen should be a federal state composed of six regions, with Aden and Saada given special status. Although the Houthis were not necessarily opposed to the idea of a federal state, they vehemently opposed the way the regions were demarcated and were dissatisfied with the region they had been allocated, as it did not give them access to the sea, which undermined their economic stability. On 26 February 2014, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 2140, which was the first Chapter VII resolution on Yemen, calling for financial and travel restrictions on anyone obstructing the transition in Yemen.
third_party: Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC), League of Arab States, EU, UN, Friends of Yemen
agreement_name: document on the outcomes of the National Dialogue Conference

description: On 3 June 2014, UN Special Envoy to Yemen Jamal Benomar brokered a ceasefire agreement between the Government of Yemen and Ansarallah. The ceasefire was aimed at ending clashes in the northern province of Amran.
On 22 June 2014, the two parties agreed on a ceasefire proposed by the Defence Ministry. This ceasefire is related to the GCC initiative and the National Dialogue Conference.

Following the ceasefire concluded on 22 June 2014, a field committee formed by the Defence Ministry resumed mediating negotiations between the Government of Yemen and the Houthis in Amran governorate and Hamdan district of Sana?a on 2 July 2014.

A presidential committee mediated a round of shuttle negotiations between Yemen�s army supported by Sunni tribe members and Houthi militants in the northern province of Al-Jawf between 19 July and 2 August 2014. The shuttle negotiations led to a ceasefire agreement on 2 August 2014.

From 21 to 24 August 2014, the ten-member presidential committee engaged in another round of peace talks with the Houthis in Saada. However, the committee interrupted the talks abruptly on 24 August 2014 �in reaction to the Houthis� continuous delay in responding to the committee�s suggestions.� President Hadi tasked the presidential committee to resume negotiations with the rebels on 30 August 2014.

From 17 to 19 September 2014, UN Special Envoy Jamal Benomar held talks in Saada with Houthi leader Adbel-Malek al-Houthi in order to find a peaceful solution to the crisis. The envoy failed to broker a ceasefire, but the Houthis agreed on a set of points to establish an agreement between the government and Houthi group. Those points were however not communicated to the press.

Following the talks with Houthi leaders that took place from 17 to 19 September and following the advance of Houthis on major state institutions in Sana?a, a round of negotiations involved the Government of Yemen, the Houthis, and political parties started on 21 September 2014 and resulted in the signing of the Peace and National Partnership Agreement on the same day. The agreement was mediated by UN Special Envoy Jamal Benomar and was based on the outcome of the national dialogue conference with the goal to form a more inclusive government. The agreement was signed at the presidential palace in Sana?a. The General People�s Congress (GPC) Party, the Islah Party, Houthi representatives, the Yemeni Socialist Party, the Rashad Party, the Development and Building Party, representatives of the Peaceful Southern Movement, the al-Haq Party, the Popular Forces Union, the National Democratic Alliance Parties, the Yemeni Unionist Coalition, and the Arab Socialist Ba�ath Party all signed the document. The Nasserist Unionist People�s Organization withheld its vote, objecting that the Houthis did not sign the appendix to the agreement. Although the agreement had the potential to boost the transition process because of its focus on inclusivity and transparency, it instead served as a cover for further Houthi territorial expansion. On 27 September 2014, after taking control of much of the capital Sana?a, the Houthi rebels signed the appendix of the Peace and National Partnership Agreement. Other political parties also signed it later in the day.

On 1 November 2014, the signatories to the Peace and National Partnership Agreement agreed on an implementation agreement. This was aimed to pave the way for the implementation of the National Dialogue Conference (NDC) outcomes and the Peace and National Partnership Agreement. The agreement led to the formation of a unity government under President Hadi and Prime Minister Khalid Bahah.

From 1 to 3 November 2014, representatives from the General People�s Congress (GPC), the Islah Party, the Houthis, the Southern Movement, the National Democratic Coalition, the Rashad Party, civil society institutions, and several businessmen met in Brussels. Sponsored by the Global Network for Rights and Development, in conjunction with the National Center for Human Rights and Democratic Developments in Yemen, the conference led to the signing of the Brussels Declaration for National Reconciliation. Other goals were to create a framework to end all armed conflicts in Yemen, prepare for a referendum on the constitution, hold parliamentary and presidential elections, and work to improve federal state infrastructure.
third_party: Global Network for Rights and Development, National Center for Human Rights and Democratic Development in Yemen

description: On 26 November 2014, UN Special Envoy Jamal Benomar held two meetings with Yemeni politicians who were signatories to the Peace and National Partnership Agreement to discuss the implementation of the agreement.

On 5 January 2015, Houthi leader Abdul-Malik al-Houthi held a meeting with a delegation of presidential advisors who came to Saada. According to local media reports, the two parties agreed to form a joint committee to implement and interpret the Peace and National Partnership Agreement and committed to implementing the agreement. The meeting took place in the context of the Houthis� rejection of the six-region federalist plan proposed by the new government.
On 19 January 2015, the Government of Yemen and Ansarallah agreed on a ceasefire in a round of direct negotiations.

Following the seizure of the presidential palace on 20 January 2015, transition president Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi and his advisors, met with Ansarallah representatives on 21 January 2015 to negotiate a solution to the political crisis. Following the meeting, the government agreed to amend the draft constitution to grant the Houthis more political power. In exchange, the Houthis agreed to release the President�s chief of staff and withdraw their militias from key government installations. The two parties also committed to maintain stability in Marib. However, as Ansarallah did not abide by the ceasefire agreement and kept President Hadi captive, the latter resigned on 22 January 2015. Based on the UCDP definition that focuses on control of the capital, Ansarallah is considered the Government of Yemen after capturing the presidential palace in Sana?a and taking full control of the capital in January 2015. It is thus important to note that while the government of Hadi was still the one internationally recognised as the Government of Yemen, the UCDP codes the Forces of Hadi as a rebel group. All negotiations between the conflict parties from 22 January onwards are therefore listed under this new dyad.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 23 January 2015, UN Special Envoy on Yemen, Jamal Benomar, mediated between Yemeni President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi and Houthi representatives in Sana?a to prepare for official negotiations.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: UN Special Envoy Jamal Benomar started a round of mediated peace talks between the political parties and the Houthis on 27 January 2015, but the talks collapsed on the same day and the three parties quit the negotiations.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 9 February 2015, UN Special Envoy Jamal Benomar resumed negotiations with Yemen�s political parties and the Houthi group to find a peaceful solution to the conflict.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: UN Special Envoy Jamal Benomar mediated another round of peace talks between the conflict parties on 20 February 2015, after which he publicly stated that the parties have taken a �very important step toward reaching a political deal.�

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 26 February 2015, UN Special Envoy Jamal Benomar visited President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi in Aden to prepare for peace talks with the Houthis. On 12 March, the Gulf Cooperation Council planned to invite the Houthis to peace talks in Riyadh, on the condition that they accept the legitimacy of President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi. Yet, the Houthis refused to comply with this demand. On 22 March 2015, the Houthis advanced on Aden, seized the international airport, and shelled Hadi�s headquarters. Hadi subsequently fled the country and called for outside intervention. In response, on 26 March 2015, Saudi Arabia, leading a coalition of eight Arab states � including Egypt, Bahrain, Kuwait, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates, Jordan, Sudan, and Morocco � intervened militarily in Yemen in defence of President Hadi and his internationally recognized government. Following this announcement, UN Special Envoy Jamal Benomar resigned his post, condemning �systematic acts of obstruction� and warning against �interference and coercion from outside forces.� Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed replaced him as UN special envoy to Yemen. On 14 April 2015, the UN Security Council passed a resolution (with Russia abstaining), unilaterally condemning the Houthis and calling on the group to immediately and unconditionally �a) end the use of violence, b) withdraw their forces from all areas they have seized, including the capital Sana?a�. On 24 April 2015, Oman � the only Gulf country which did not join the Saudi-led coalition � unveiled a seven-point peace plan initiated in coordination with Saudi Arabia and Iran. Among others, the plan called for the withdrawal of the Houthis and forces loyal to deposed president Ali Abdullah Saleh from all Yemeni cities, the restoration of President Hadi and the government of Khalid Bahah, and early parliamentary and presidential elections. While the Houthis supported the peace terms proposed by Oman, the Saudi-led coalition refused to negotiate.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 7 May 2015, Hadi�s Saudi-backed forces announced a five-day humanitarian ceasefire that would be effective on 12 May, on the sole condition that the Houthis agree to the ceasefire as well. The Houthis accepted the ceasefire shortly before the newly appointed UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed arrived in Sana?a.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 14 May 2015, UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed mediated pre-negotiations between the conflict parties, discussing arrangements with Yemeni factions for scheduled official peace talks in Riyadh on 17 May. All parties except the Houthis voiced their interest in participating in the negotiations sponsored by the GCC states. The Houthis eventually rejected their participation in the planned conference.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 23 May 2015, an Ansarallah delegation visited Oman to discuss a peaceful solution to the Yemeni conflict. Oman was undertaking considerable diplomatic efforts to persuade the Saudi-led coalition of Arab countries to stop its air strikes and return to dialogue.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: While UN-led negotiations should have been held on 14 June 2015, Houthi representatives refused to board the plane. On 15 June 2015, UN Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon opened peace talks in Geneva only in the presence of representatives of the exiled government. The Houthis eventually arrived on 16 June in Geneva, and UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed began to shuttle between the two parties that refused to sit at the same table. The talks ended on 19 June 2015 without an agreement.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 7 July 2015, UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed held talks with Ansarullah representatives in Sana?a to try to broker a humanitarian ceasefire.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 10 July 2015, the UN brokered a ceasefire agreement between the conflict parties. On 25 July 2015, the Forces of Hadi and the Saudi-led coalition declared a five-day humanitarian truce.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: UN-led peace talks were due to take place in mid-September. While the Houthis showed up for the peace talks, Yemen�s exiled president Hadi backed out before the talks began. The exiled president stated he would not participate in the negotiations unless the Houthis complied with UN Security Council resolution 2216 adopted in April 2015. Following talks mediated by the UN in Oman in September 2015, the Houthis and the party of the former president Saleh accepted, in a letter dated 3 October 2015, a seven-point peace plan proposed in April 2015, including ceasefire and the return of President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi�s government to Sana?a. On 18 October 2015, the exiled Yemeni government, referred to as the Forces of Hadi, in response agreed to participate to UN-sponsored peace talks.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: In preparation of the planned UN-led peace talks, UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed met the Houthis in Oman�s capital Muscat for consultations on 28 October 2015.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed consulted Yemeni Vice-President and Prime Minister Khaled Bahah in Riyadh on 25 November 2015 to prepare for negotiations between the exiled Yemeni government and the Houthis.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 5 December 2015, UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed arrived in Aden where he held talks with President Hadi, who had returned to the port city in September. The talks were aimed at preparing for peace talks with the Houthis scheduled for mid-December.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 7 and on 12 December 2015, the Forces of Hadi and the Government of Yemen, respectively agreed on a joint seven-day ceasefire brokered by UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed. The ceasefire would take effect on 15 December 2015 to coincide with the start of the scheduled UN-led peace talks in Switzerland.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: From 15 to 20 December 2015, Yemen�s ousted president Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi and representatives of the Houthis gathered in Biel, Switzerland for peace talks chaired by UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed. On 20 December 2015, despite no substantive agreement following the talks in Switzerland, the two sides agreed to extend the truce for seven more days. The talks were expected to resume in mid-January.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed met with several representatives of Hadi�s government in Riyadh on 9 January 2016. The UN mediator discussed the prospects for peace with Hadi�s representatives and the possibility of holding of peace talks in Geneva.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: From 10 to 14 January 2016, UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed conducted talks with Houthi representatives and their ally former President Ali Abdullah Saleh in Sana?a. This led to the release of a detained minister and four pro-Hadi political activists. Nevertheless, the new round of negotiations planned in Switzerland was postponed amid disputes over the venue and confidence-building measures.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: President Hadi met UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed in Riyadh on 5 March 2016 to discuss the prospects for peace and to prepare for official negotiations.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: At the invitation of Saudi Arabia, bilateral peace talks took place between the Saudi-led coalition supporting Hadi and representatives of the Houthis in Saudi Arabia on 7 March 2016. It was the first such visit since the start of Saudi Arabia�s intervention in Yemen in March 2015.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 9 March 2016, a tribal mediator negotiated a ceasefire between the Houthis and the Forces of Hadi. On 18 March 2016, the Houthis conducted a prisoner exchange with Saudi Arabia. In doing so, the Houthis tried to exclude President Hadi from the negotiations, thus delegitimising his internationally recognized government.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 19 March 2016, UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed arrived in Sana?a to discuss preparations with the Houthis for a new round of negotiations with the Forces of Hadi. The parties agreed to hold talks in Kuwait.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 23 March 2016, the conflict parties announced a joint ceasefire brokered by the UN which would enter into effect on 10 April 2016 ahead of a planned resumption of peace talks in Kuwait.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 2 April 2016, representatives of the Houthis and of the Forces of Hadi agreed on a ceasefire agreement for the governorate of Hajjah following mediation by the Saudi-led coalition in Dhahran al-Janoub. The ceasefire implementation agreement was signed two days later.
third_party: Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain, Kuwait, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates, Jordan, Sudan, Morocco

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 10 April 2016, the General People�s Congress, the Houthis, the Arab Coalition, and the Forces of Hadi signed the Dharan al-Janoub ceasefire agreements covering 6 governorates: Jawf, Marib, Taiz, al-Baydah, Shabwah and al-Dhalea. The agreement was brokered by the UN and endorsed by representatives of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. Monitor teams � composed of officers and tribal figures from the Houthis and from the Forces of Hadi � were deployed to the governorate to observe the ceasefire under UN supervision.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: The internationally recognized Yemeni President Hadi met with UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed in Riyadh on 12 April 2016 ahead of planned peace talks with the Houthis in Kuwait on 18 April.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 17 April 2016, the Forces of Hadi on one side and the Houthi government and the General People�s Congress on the other side agreed on a ceasefire in Marib. This ceasefire was mediated by Saudi Arabia and followed the conclusion of the ceasefire signed in Dharan al-Janoub in Saudi Arabia on 10 April 2016.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 20 April 2016, the Houthi government and the Forces of Hadi reached the Dhalea Ceasefire following mediation by Saudi Arabia.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: Peace talks between the Houthi government and its General People�s Congress party allies on the one side and the Saudi-backed government of President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi on the other side were held from 21 to 24 April 2016 in Kuwait. UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed acted as the mediator during these negotiations. The talks were delayed because the Houthis and the party of former president Saleh did not arrive on the due date and fighting continued between the conflict parties. The talks were then suspended by the UN envoy, as the two sides failed to make progress. While the Houthis demanded a halt the Saudi-led coalition�s air strikes, the internationally recognized Yemeni government wanted the Houthis to hand over their weapons and evacuate the main cities.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: From 26 April to 1 May 2016, the two sides engaged in negotiations mediated by the UN in Kuwait. The dialogue was suspended by the internationally recognised government of Hadi in protest at renewed violence conducted by the Houthis.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: Talks mediated by the UN resumed on 5 May 2016 in Kuwait. The two sides negotiated until 8 May 2016, when the Houthis pulled out of the peace talks in protest of an airstrike conducted by the Saudi-led coalition.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: After a day of suspension, the UN-led talks in Kuwait resumed on 9 May 2016. The Forces of Hadi interrupted their participation on 17 May 2016.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 21 May 2016, internationally recognised Yemeni President Hadi agreed to send a government delegation back to Kuwait to resume UN-led peace talks with the Houthis. This decision was taken following President Hadi�s meetings with UN Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon and the emir of Qatar in Doha. Talks were again suspended on 29 June 2016 in order to make it possible for the delegations to discuss the direction of the peace process with their leadership.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: UN-sponsored talks in Kuwait resumed on 16 July 2016. On 28 July 2016, the talks broke down when the Houthis and former President Ali Abdullah Saleh�s party declared that they would establish a presidential council. In response, the Saudi-led coalition and the Forces of Hadi announced on 30 July that they were leaving the Kuwaiti peace process.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: Just as the peace process seemed on the verge of collapse, the exiled Yemeni government of Hadi accepted a draft peace agreement proposed by UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed on 31 July 2016. The Houthis did not accept the peace plan, but welcomed the envoy�s proposal to extend the talks for another week. While the representatives of Hadi had already left Kuwait on 1 August, the talks were officially adjourned on 6 August 2016. The Kuwait talks addressed five main areas: the withdrawal of militias and armed groups, the handover of heavy weapons to the state, interim security arrangements, restoration of state institutions and the resumption of inclusive political dialogue, and the establishment of a committee on prisoners and detainees. While Saudi-led coalition and the Forces of Hadi were prepared to make significant concessions, the Houthi government was not and the peace talks collapsed. On 25 August 2016, US Secretary of State John Kerry announced a new initiative to restart peace talks in Yemen, resulting from consultations among the US, the UK, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates and with Oman occasionally attending the consultations. The plan proposed the participation of the Houthis in a unity government in exchange for the transfer of their heavy weapons to a third party. While the Houthis rejected Kerry�s call for the transfer of their ballistic missiles, the Yemeni government welcomed US plan.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: Houthi representatives met with US Undersecretary of State for Political Affairs Thomas Shannon and an Omani mediator on 8 and 9 September 2016. The US diplomat presented the peace plan proposed by US State Secretary John Kerry and the Houthi representatives agreed to resume peace talks.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 2 October 2016, UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed held talks with ousted president Hadi in Riyadh to make progress in finding a peaceful solution to the conflict and to prepare for official negotiations.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: The UN envoy discussed pathways for peace with Houthi government on 7 October 2016. The Houthi representatives expressed that a ceasefire was necessary. The special envoy was supposed to meet ousted Yemen President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi later the same day.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 17 and 18 October 2016 respectively, the Forces of Hadi and Houthi government committed to a joint 72-hour ceasefire called for by the UN, the UK, and the US. This ceasefire was to take effect on 19 October.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed met Houthi representatives and several representatives of former Yemeni president Ali Abdullah Saleh in Sana?a on 25 October 2016 and handed them a roadmap for peace. The UN peace plan called for the Houthis to hand over their heavy weapons to a third party and to withdraw from Sana?a and other cities. It also included the appointment of a new vice-president, to whom Hadi would hand over his powers and who would appoint a new prime minister to set up a government with equal representation from the north and south of Yemen.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: During a meeting with the UN envoy in the Saudi capital Riyadh on 29 October 2016, Yemen�s ousted president Hadi rejected the UN peace proposal that called for him to hand over his powers to a deputy acceptable to the warring parties Hadi argued that he refused the plan because it was not consistent with UN Security Council resolution 2216 adopted in 2015.

description: A Houthi delegation met with UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed in Sana?a from 4 to 7 November 2016 to negotiate on the UN-proposed peace plan.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: US State Secretary John Kerry held talks with Houthi representatives on 14 November 2016 in Oman, who agreed to a truce from 17 November onwards on the condition that the Forces of Hadi implemented it. Kerry stated that both sides had agreed to the ceasefire. The Saudi-led coalition supporting the Forces of Hadi announced a 48-hour unilateral ceasefire on 19 November 2016 �in response to UN and other international efforts to establish peace.�

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: The US mediated a round of talks between the conflict parties in Oman on 19 November 2016. The talks were aimed at concluding a ceasefire, but the Force of Hadi reportedly refused to conclude a ceasefire.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: Following up on the failed ceasefire talks held in November 2016, UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed discussed the UN peace plan with Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi in Aden on 16 January 2017.

description: The UN envoy held similar talks on 23 January 2017 with Houthi representatives in Sana?a.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: In an effort to get the Forces of Hadi and the Houthis resume UN-led talks and negotiate on the UN peace plan, representatives of Oman met with Hadi�s Foreign Minister Abdel-Malek al-Mekhlafi in May 2017. Oman told the Hadi representative that the Houthis were ready to agree to the UN peace plan.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council

description: On 16 February 2018, Martin Griffiths assumed the role of the UN Special Envoy. On 20 March 2018, he met with exiled president Hadi in Riyadh to discuss ways to resume peace talks with the Houthis.

description: On 4 June 2018, the Head of the Houthi-led Supreme Political Council met with UN Special Envoy Martin Griffiths in Sana?a. During these talks, the Houthi leader insisted that �the expulsion of all foreign presence� was a key condition for peace.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council

This declaration came ahead of UN-led peace talks between the two warring parties scheduled to take place in Geneva on 6 September.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council

The Houthis argued that they would not come because safe travel to and from the meeting could not be guaranteed. side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: Negotiations between the conflict parties were held in Sweden from 6 to 13 December 2018. The UN acted as the mediator during the talks. The UN mediation team shuttled between the two delegations for three days, after which the conflict parties engaged in direct talks on 9 December 2018. The negotiations led to the Stockholm Agreement on 13 December 2018. The parties also agreed to a ceasefire in Yemen port and aid hub Hodeida that would begin on 18 December. Furthermore, the two sides also agreed on the release of prisoners, missing or arbitrarily detained and forcibly disappeared persons, the establishment of humanitarian corridors in Taiz, and a handover of the three Red Sea ports (Hodeida, As Salif, and Ras Isa) to the United Nations Verification and Inspection Mechanism for Yemen. A Supervisory Committee, co-chaired by the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen (OSESGY) and the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), and whose members are the parties to the conflict in Yemen was established to monitor implementation of the agreement.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: From September 2019, following Houthis� claim of responsibility for drone attacks on Saudi Arabia�s oil processing facilities, Oman mediated indirect, �back-channel� peace talks between the Houthis and Saudi Arabia. The two parties discussed the reopening of Sana?a airport, as well as a buffer-zone along the Yemen-Saudi border.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 2 October 2019, UN Special Envoy Martin Griffiths conducted peace talks with Houthi representatives in Sana?a after the Forces of Hadi signalled to be ready for peace.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: The back-channel talks between Saudi Arabia and the Houthis mediated by Oman continued in November 2019.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 19 December 2019, the Forces of Hadi and the Houthis agreed to exchange 135 prisoners following tribal mediation in the province of Taiz.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: After two days of UN-mediated talks, on 19 December 2019, the Houthis and the Saudi-led coalition supporting Hadi agreed to create humanitarian corridors in Hodeida.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: UN Special Envoy Martin Griffiths held talks with ousted president Hadi in Riyadh on 14 January 2020 to revive the stalled peace talks between the warring parties.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: Back-channel talks between Saudi Arabia and the Houthis mediated by Oman continued through February 2020. Talks reportedly broke down in March when the Houthis withdrew from the talks. The Houthis cited a lack of implementation of provisions agreed in talks as the reason for their withdrawal. Saudi Arabian officials, on the other hand, suggested that the Houthis had not truly engaged in talks.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: Houthi representatives and representatives of the Forces of Hadi met in Amman from 10 to 16 February 2020. Through UN mediation, they agreed to implement a major and long-delayed prisoner exchange foreseen by the Stockholm agreement.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 6 March 2020, UN Special Envoy Martin Griffiths held talks with ousted Prime Minister Maeen Abdulmalik of the Forces of Hadi in Riyadh. On 8 April 2020, the government of Saudi Arabia supporting the Forces of Hadi announced a unilateral ceasefire in response to UN calls to halt hostilities amid the coronavirus pandemic. On 23 April 2020, the government of Saudi Arabia extended its unilateral ceasefire.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: UN Special Envoy Martin Griffiths met ousted but internationally recognised President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi in Riyadh on 30 June 2020 to discuss the prospects for peace with the Houthis.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 5 August 2020, a local mediator negotiated the exchange of 22 prisoners between the conflict parties in Taiz.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 13 August 2020, UN Special Envoy Martin Griffiths met with ousted Vice-President Ali Mohsen al-Ahmar of the Forces of Hadi in Riyadh to discuss a joint declaration regarding a ceasefire with the Houthis.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: From 18 to 27 September 2020, representatives of the Houthis and of the Forces of Hadi of the Supervisory Committee formed under the 2018 Stockholm Agreement met in Glion, Switzerland, and agreed on a prisoner-swap deal. The peace talks were co-chaired by the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and the Office of the UN Special Envoy.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: Ousted but internationally recognized president Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi met with UN Special Envoy Martin Griffiths in Riyadh on 13 October 2020 to discuss a national ceasefire.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: Back-channel talks between Saudi Arabia and the Houthis mediated by Oman resumed in November 2020. Saudi Arabia reportedly told the Houthis that it would sign a UN proposal for nationwide ceasefire if the Houthis would agree to a buffer-zone along Saudi Arabia and Yemen�s border. However, the Houthis refused this proposal by Saudi Arabia.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: UN Special Envoy Martin Griffiths and ousted but internationally recognised Yemeni President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi discussed a UN peace plan in Riyadh on 6 January 2021.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: In February 2021, the US began back-channel talks, reportedly with support from Oman and Qatar, with the Houthis in a bid to find a peaceful solution to the conflict.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: Further talks on the release of prisoners took place in Amman, Jordan, from 24 January to 21 February 2021 between the Forces of Hadi and Houthis under the auspices of the UN. These talks ended without a deal. On 9 April 2021, Iraq hosted the first direct peace talks between Iran and Saudi Arabia in Baghdad. Saudi Arabia had been embroiled in the conflict in Yemen since 2015, primarily supporting the ousted but internationally recognized government of Abdrabbuh Mansour Hadi and fighting against the Houthis. Iran, on the other hand, supported the Houthis. The two regional powers cut all diplomatic relations in 2016, when Iranian protesters stormed the Saudi embassy in Tehran following Riyadh�s execution of a Shia cleric on terrorist charges. Five rounds of behind-closed-doors talks between Saudi Arabia and Iran, mediated by Iraq, were held between April 2021 and April 2022. The discussion between Khalid al-Homaidan, head of Saudi intelligence, and Saeed Iravani, deputy secretary of Iran�s Supreme National Security Council, reportedly focused on the war in Yemen. Iraqi Prime Minister Mustafa al-Kadhimi reportedly drew on the deep relationships he built with the Iranian and Saudi governments during his years as Iraqi intelligence chief to make Iraq a venue for discussions between the two long-time rivals. The beginning of US President Joe Biden�s term in office was one of the key events that created an environment conducive to the Iranian-Saudi talks in Baghdad. His administration�s focus on ending the war in Yemen and potentially restoring the 2015 Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) changed the political calculus of both Tehran and Riyadh.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 2 May 2021, UN and US envoys to Yemen held talk with Houthi representatives in Muscat, Oman, focusing on reaching a ceasefire and opening seaports and airports to deliver necessary humanitarian aid to the Yemeni people. Oman was not involved as a mediator in this round of talks.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: From 5 to 11 June 2021, an Omani delegation held discussions with the Houthi movement in Sana?a and proposed a peaceful end to the war. The Omani delegation entered Yemen for the first time since the breakout of the civil war in 2014. The Houthis promised to start ceasefire talks immediately after the lifting of the blockade, in line with the latest proposal that had been made by UN Special Envoy Martin Griffiths. During these negotiations, the Houthis agreed to stop drone attacks on the border with neighbouring Saudi Arabia, while Saudi Arabia would allow the reopening of Sana'a airport and the port of Hodeidah.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 8 June 2021, the Omani Chairman of the State Council held talks with the ousted Yemeni Minister of Foreign Affairs Awad Mubarak in Muscat. The two state officials discussed the situation in Yemen and prospect for peace.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 28 August 2021, Iraq hosted a regional summit aimed at easing tensions in the Middle East. At this occasion, Iraq mediated between Iran and Saudi Arabia, whose rivalry has often played out in Yemen. Reportedly, the two countries agreed on a roadmap towards the resolution of the war in Yemen during the talks.
agreement_name: Roadmap Towards the Resolution of the War in Yemen

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: Newly appointed UN Special Envoy to Yemen Hans Grundberg met representatives of the Forces of Hadi in Aden on 7 November 2021 to discuss a UN-brokered peace plan.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: Following separate talks with the UN special envoy in March 2022 in Amman, Jordan, both the Saudi-led coalition and internationally recognized government of Yemen on one side and the Houthis on the other agreed on a two-month truce on 1 April 2022. This was the first nationwide truce since 2016 and also contained agreements to allow two commercial flights into Sana?a airport each week, to open Hodeidah port to 18 fuel ships, and to begin discussions on opening blocked roads in Taiz. On 7 April 2022, ousted but internationally recognized President Hadi handed over his powers to a presidential council formed of eight members composed of both political and armed group leaders, which would be responsible for implementing the truce. The eight-man Presidential Leadership Council was formally sworn in on 19 April in Aden. Although this nationwide truce and the government reshuffle came as a surprise to even long-time Yemen analyst, some factors contributed to this outcome. Firstly, the Saudi-led coalition increasingly recognised that a military victory was unlikely, as Houthis missile and drone attacks on Saudi and Emirati territory increased, posing economic risks, and damaging the international reputations of these Gulf states. Secondly, President Biden's shift in US policy towards the coalition, ending "offensive" support, prompted the US to support UN-led negotiations. This combination of pressure and diplomatic engagement encouraged Saudi and Emirati leadership to seek an end to their involvement in the war. The appointment of the new UN special envoy, Hans Grundberg, also injected new life into the stalled UN process. Furthermore, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates (UAE) may view their disengagement from Yemen as part of a broader effort to establish a more functional relationship with Iran amidst the ongoing nuclear deal negotiations. Finally, the Houthis, despite their previous gain in strategic ground, appeared to have lost momentum on the battlefield, diminishing their incentives to persist with fighting and making negotiations a more appealing option.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: From 11 to 13 April 2022, UN Special Envoy Hans Grundberg held talks with the Houthis in Sana?a to discuss the implementation of the truce. On 23 April 2022, Iraq resumed mediation and held the fifth round of talks between Saudi Arabia and Iran over Yemen. The two countries discussed the acceleration of re-establishment of diplomatic ties, the current ceasefire in Yemen, and the plans for national reconciliation in Yemen.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: After days of negotiations, the two parties agreed to extend the UN-brokered truce for another two months on 2 June 2022.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 5 June 2022, UN Special Envoy Hans Grundberg met with delegations of the ousted but internationally recognised Government of Yemen and the Houthis in Amman, Jordan, to discuss the reopening of roads in Taiz, as per the terms of the truce agreement. However, the Houthis still refused to reopen the roads to the besieged city of Taiz. The objective of the updated proposal was to alleviate civilian suffering and enhance the delivery of goods.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: In the week of 25 July 2022, UN Special Envoy Hans Grundberg shuttled between Aden, Oman and Riyadh for talks with Yemen ousted but internationally recognized government and Houthis negotiators.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: Once again, the two parties renewed the UN-brokered truce on 2 August 2022 for another two more months. Although UN Special Envoy Hans Grundberg proposed an expanded truce with provisions such as additional destinations for commercial flights and which would last six months instead of two, the truce was renewed in its existing streamlined form.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 26 and 27 September 2022, UN Special Envoy Hans Grundberg met with the President of the Presidential Council and the Houthis� chief negotiator respectively. The purpose of these meetings was to discuss the UN proposal to extend the truce beyond 2 October. However, the truce was not renewed and expired on 2 October 2022.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: Nevertheless, Houthis-Saudi backchannel talks through mediation by Oman reportedly revived in September 2022, which helped to maintain an informal truce between the warring parties. When the truce collapsed, Oman maintained contact between the Houthis and Saudi Arabia.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 21 December 2022, an Omani delegation held talks with Houthi representatives in Sana?a in a bid to revive peace negotiations between the conflict parties.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 10 March 2023, China helped broker a deal renewing diplomatic relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran. The two Middle Eastern powers met in Beijing from 6 March 2023 for five days of talks. This surprise rapprochement was welcomed by both warring parties who expected it to allow for a fresh start in the peace negotiations. In the agreement, Iran and Saudi Arabia thanked Iraq and Oman for their mediation role between 2021 and 2022. From 11 to 20 March 2023, the Supervisory Committee of the 2018 Stockholm Agreement met in Switzerland. The Supervisory Committee is co-chaired by the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen and the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), its members are the parties to the conflict in Yemen. The parties finalized the implementation plan for the release of 887 conflict-related detainees from all sides. They also agreed to meet again in May to discuss further releases.

side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 8 and 9 April 2023, Oman mediated between a Saudi delegation and Houthi representatives in Sana?a to negotiate a potential new truce. The aim of the talks was the reinstatement of the truce, the complete withdrawal of foreign forces from Yemen and the start of broader talks to resolve Yemen�s multifaceted political conflict. Yemen�s presidential leadership council was excluded from the discussions, but it had reportedly been consulted. These talks resulted in a draft agreement, stipulating a ceasefire for a period of six months in a first phase to build confidence, followed by a period of negotiations for three months on managing the transitional phase. This transitional phase was agreed to last for two years, during which a final solution will be negotiated between all parties. This Oman-led mediation process ran parallel to the UN peace efforts.

On 30 January 1989, the two rival prime ministers, General Michel Aoun and Selim Hoss, held separate talks with the Arab League committee in Tunis.
