This was the first attempt by the Arab League mediation committee, formed of six foreign ministers from Kuwait, Sudan, Jordan, Algeria, Tunisia, and the United Arab Emirates, to find a solution to the conflict between the two parties. In February 1989, the peace committee consulted with Lebanese religious leaders, who agreed on broad principles for national reconciliation.

On 29 March 1989, the Forces of Michel Aoun announced a unilateral ceasefire answering the call for a ceasefire by the Arab League at its biannual meeting on 28 March 1989 in Tunis. The ceasefire was aimed at paving the way for the Arab League to mediate an end to Lebanon�s crisis. On 28 March 1989, the Arab League also met with former Lebanese presidents, prime ministers, and a speaker of the parliament to hear their view on the conflict. These meetings served to collect information to prepare a comprehensive peace agreement for Lebanon.

Kuwaiti Foreign Minister Sheikh Sabah al-Ahmed, leader of the Arab League peace committee, and the League�s Secretary-General Chadli Kilibi held talks with pro-Syrian Muslim leftist leaders on 5 April 1989 in Damascus and proposed a three-point plan, calling for an immediate ceasefire. The Lebanese representatives included Druze leader Walid Jumblatt and Nabih Berri, head of the Shi'ite Muslim Amal militia. Both were also members of the Hoss cabinet. The plan called for a ceasefire, for a lift of the seaports blockade and for the reopening of all crossing points between Muslim west and Christian east Beirut. According to the plan, the Arab League committee would be responsible for the monitoring of the ceasefire. Aoun, commenting on the mediation efforts, said he was willing to lift the blockade of the harbours only if they would not be used to smuggle drugs.

On 5 April 1989, the French envoy Jean-Fran�ois Deniau shuttled between General Michel Aoun in east Beirut and acting Prime Minister Selim Hoss in west Beirut in an attempt to make peace between the two parties. This mediation effort was aimed at supporting the Arab League efforts.

From 13 to 14 April 1989, the Arab League peace committee held discussions with Christian leaders to find a peaceful solution to the conflict. The Christian representatives advocated the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon.

The Arab League held an emergency meeting on Lebanon on 26 April 1989 in Tunis at the request of the Arab League peace committee. The six Arab ministers that were part of the committee gave their approval for sending more than 300 ceasefire observers to Lebanon. General Aoun said he would accept the deployment of such a monitoring force, while also insisting on Syria�s withdrawal from Lebanon. The ceasefire proposed by the Arab League went into effect on 28 April 1989. The Arab League ceasefire and peace plan also received international support, with the UN Security Council and the UN Secretary General, as well as France, repeatedly publicly endorsing it.

On 3 May 1989, two Arab League envoys, Lakhdar Brahimi and Kuwait�s Ambassador to Syria Ahmed Abdel Aziz Jassem held separate talks with acting Prime Minister Selim Hoss and General Michel Aoun. This visit was aimed at implementing a call made by the Arab League for immediate ceasefire on 28 April 1989 and the deployment of the 300-men observer force. Following the meeting with the envoys, Aoun agreed to lift the blockade of illegal militia-run ports in a concession aimed at bolstering the Arab-mediated truce.

On 11 May 1989, following talks with Syrian Foreign Minister Farouq al-Shara, the Arab League peace delegation led by Lakhdar Brahimi went to Lebanon. During this visit, they managed to broker yet another ceasefire between the Syrian government and the Forces of Michel Aoun. The ceasefire was meant to calm the situation down in the lead up to more extensive negotiations on a peace plan for all Lebanese factions and areas.

On 12 May 1989, the Arab League mediation team led by Lakhdar Brahimi met separately with General Michel Aoun and acting Prime Minister Selim Hoss to stabilize the fragile truce brokered one day earlier. The mediatoion team then left Lebanon for Damascus to continue talk with Syria.

On 18 May 1989, the head of the Arab League mediation team met with Michel Aoun and asked him to �open all crossing points in divided Beirut and end a two-month-old blockade on Moslem militia-run ports.� On the same day, the peace envoy also talked to acting Prime Minister Selim Hoss with similar demands to bolster the fragile truce between the parties. The mediators reportedly discussed the deployment of more than 300 observers to monitor the ceasefire during their meeting with Hoss. Later in the month, the Arab League held a summit in Casablanca where Arab leaders discussed, among others, the crisis in Lebanon. Disagreements were voiced on whether the Syrian force should withdraw from the country. As a result, the proposed deployment of a 300-member observer force was ultimately abandoned. After four days of deliberation, the summit concluded on 26 May 1989, with the establishment of a tripartite committee. This committee comprised the heads of state from Saudi Arabia, Algeria, and Morocco. Tasked with a six-month mandate, its primary objectives were to oversee the implementation of a ceasefire and facilitate the search for a viable political resolution to the conflict within Lebanon.

On 9 June 1989, Arab League envoy Lakhdar Brahimi met with acting Prime Minister Selim Hoss and House Speaker Hussein Husseini to discuss a possible path towards peace. They discussed ways to end the sea and land blockades imposed on Christian enclaves and how to consolidate the fragile truce mediated on 11 May 1989. Before arriving in Beirut, Brahimi and the Arab League mediation team had visited Syrian President Hafez al-Assad in Damascus for consultations.

One day later, on 10 June 1989, the Arab league envoy continued his shuttle mediation effort and held talks with General Michel Aoun. The foreign ministers of Saudi Arabia, Algeria and Morocco did not come to Beirut themselves because of the deteriorating security situation. On the same day, Syria confirmed with the three Arab leaders of the peace committee that Syria supported their peace plan for Lebanon.

On 12 June 1989, the Arab League envoy Lakhdar Brahimi returned to Beirut to continue shuttle mediation between the warring parties. He met with parliamentary Speaker Hussein Husseini and acting Prime Minister Selim Hoss.

One day later, on 13 June 1989, Brahimi crossed the Green Line, separating the Muslim factions in predominantly Muslim West Beirut from the predominantly Christian East Beirut, to meet with General Michel Aoun in a bid to consolidate the existing ceasefire. Aoun reportedly refused to revive the disbanded ceasefire. After meeting in Algeria on 27 June 1989, the tripartite peace committee announced its intention to invite the Lebanese Parliament to meet outside Lebanon to find a political solution to the conflict. The committee composed by Saudi Arabia, Algeria, and Morocco decided �to move from the security phase to the political phase.� However, the mediators also stressed that a ceasefire, the lifting of naval blockades, and the reopening of roads between east and west Beirut should precede the external meeting of parliament. In addition, Arab leaders planned to send dozens � instead of hundreds � of peace observers. Following these announcements, the Soviet Union promised its support for the plan of the Arab mediation committee. Indeed, the Soviet Union used its influence with Presidents Hafez al-Assad of Syria and Saddam Hussein of Iraq, both close allies of Moscow, to urge them to show restraint in their support for the rival parties in Lebanon.

The tripartite Arab League peace committee continued its efforts and met with Iraqi and Syrian representatives in early July 1989. Iraq proclaimed its full commitment to stop sending weapon to Lebanon if foreign forces withdrew from the country and on 3 July 1989, while Syrian Muslim allies announced a unilateral ceasefire. On 4 July 1989, Syria and its Muslim allies reopened Beirut airport and lifted the land siege on the Christian enclave in the city. On 5 July 1989, Soviet leader Mikhael Gorbatchev and French President Fran�ois Mitterand issued a joint statement calling for an immediate ceasefire.

On 6 July 1989, amidst shelling across Beirut, Arab League peace envoy Lakhdar Brahimi held separate talks with General Michel Aoun and the acting Prime Minister Selim Hoss. While Syria reportedly asked Aoun to abandon the Frog-7 ground-to-ground missiles, which they feared could be fired at Damascus, General Aoun made it clear that the �missile issue� could only resolved in case of a complete withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon.

On 8 and 9 July 1989, Arab League mediator Lakhdar Brahimi again shuttled between General Michel Aoun and acting Prime Minister Selim Hoss, trying to bolster a fragile ceasefire. He stressed that Lebanese were responsible for their own peace and that �that recipe had to be Lebanese.� Yet, violence escalated only two days later when a Maltese oil tanker was reportedly hit by Syrian artillery in international waters, again fuelling the conflict in Beirut. On 31 July 1989, the three heads of state from Algeria, Saudi Arabia and Morocco issued a joint statement in Algiers after meeting with Arab League lead mediator Lakhdar Brahimi. This was a follow up to their meeting in Rabat from 29 to 30 July 1989, where they intended to find a solution to Lebanon�s war. In their statement, they pronounced their failure to achieve a ceasefire and the political reforms needed to end Lebanon's 14-year civil war and criticised the escalation of violence. They claimed their mediation efforts had reached an impasse. However, the US and the European commission appealed to the Arab mediators to continue their peace efforts. France also reacted to the news and attempted to secure wider international support by sending high-ranking emissaries to Damascus, Moscow, Washington, London, the Vatican, and the UN to discuss the rising violence in Beirut. French diplomats also met with the Arab League.

On 15 August 1989, the UN Security Council issued a presidential statement following an emergency session, called for by the UN secretary-General under article 99, on ending intensified fighting in Lebanon. While there was no formal response from the parties, General Michel Aoun affirmed he had accepted the ceasefire in a telephone interview with the media agency Reuters on 16 August 1989. Moreover, fighting around the Green Line ceased for some hours. The UN Security Council also reaffirmed its backing for the peacemaking efforts of the three-nation Arab League committee and urged it to resume its work. The Arab League peace committee also called for a ceasefire on the 16 August 1989. However, within less than 24 hours, violence flared up again. On 18 August 1989, the Arab League revived its peace process by producing a blueprint of a �national reconciliation charter� to end the civil war in Lebanon. The plan called for a ceasefire, the restoration of Lebanese sovereignty throughout the country, the renewal of constitutional authority, and a wide range of political reforms. The document was sent to ambassadors in Rabat, including to ambassadors of the permanent members of the UN Security Council.

On 17 and 18 August 1989, French envoy Alain Decaux separately met with General Michel Aoun and acting Prime Minister Selim Hoss in Beirut to find ways to enforce the UN ceasefire call. These meetings were in line with France�s diplomatic peace campaign. France also announced that it was ready to send the aircraft carrier Foch into Lebanese waters �to protect [the 7,000] French citizens [in Lebanon] if needed.�.

On 24 August 1989, as part of the international efforts to find a peaceful solution to the Lebanese protracted civil war, Deputy Soviet Foreign Minister Gennadi Terrosov met Acting Prime Minister Selim Hoss in Beirut after holding talks with Syrian officials a day earlier in Damascus.

Soviet envoy Gennadi Terrosov met with General Michel Aoun on 25 August 1989. Immediately following this meeting with the Soviet envoy, British ambassador Allan Ramsay also met with General Aoun to urge him and his forces to refrain from any military attacks and instead pursue a political solution. The US ambassador also reportedly met with Aoun with the same aim.

On 28 August 1989, France presented a three-step peace plan to Syria. The French peace plan proposed a ceasefire, a halt of arms deliveries to both sides, the introduction of political reforms to end the dominant role of the Christians, and the phased withdrawal of foreign forces from the country, beginning with the withdrawal of the Syrian troops from west Beirut. French envoy Fran�ois Scheer then travelled to Beirut on 30 August 1989 and met with several Muslim leaders, including Selim Hoss. cheer also held talks with General Aoun and other Christian representatives. It became clear that one obstacle to the war was that while Syria and its allies did not want to lift their blockade of the Christian enclave if Aoun did not end his �war of liberation Aoun and his allies insisted on the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanese soil as precondition for laying down their weapons.

On 13 and 14 September 1989, the tripartite Arab League peace committee � composed of Algeria, Morocco, and Saudi Arabia � met in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, to discuss the possibility of revival of the peace process and initiate formal negotiations. Following these talks, the Arab League announced in a communiqu� published on 16 September 1989, a seven-point peace plan for Lebanon. The plan called for an immediate ceasefire and an end to arms shipments. This peace plan was to be implemented by a special security committee headed by Lakhdar Brahimi. The peace plan also called the parliament to convey for a meeting aimed at national reconciliation on 30 September. However, the plan did not mention the withdrawal of Syrian troops. Syria and its allies immediately endorsed the plan, while General Michel Aoun claimed it was not containing anything new and asked for clarification.

On 17 September 1989, Lakhdar Brahimi, the Arab League envoy, held talks with the chief of the Shi�ite Muslim Amal Militia and the acting Minister of Justice. He briefed them on the latest Arab League peace plan. On the same day, Brahimi also met General Michel Aoun. During this meeting, Aoun stated that he needed written guarantees that Syria would withdraw its troops and clarifications before he could formally endorse the plan. Moreover, General Aoun, in a televised interview, rejected the all-Lebanese implementation committee and asked to include at least one Syrian member.
Lakhdar Brahimi again shuttled between Christian and Muslim representatives to discuss the peace plan on 18 September 1989.
On 19 September 1989, Lakhdar Brahimi held another round of separate talks with General Michel Aoun and Muslim leaders in west Beirut.

On 22 September 1989, following a third meeting with peace envoy Lakhdar Brahimi, General Michel Aoun eventually accepted the Arab League seven-point peace plan, which meant that the conflict parties could start the implementation of the previously concluded ceasefire. Phone calls from Arab leaders and influential officials from France and the US put pressure on Aoun to accept this seven-point peace plan.

On 23 September 1989, the security committee formed under the Arab League peace plan,including representatives of the Christian and of the Muslim community, declared a formal ceasefire. It was the first meeting of this committee , which was chaired by Arab League peace envoy Lakhdar Brahimi. The committee met again one day later to assess the effect of the ceasefire and noted that the it had held except for brief violations and welcomed the reopening of Beirut airport and sea port. During a meeting with Arab League envoy Lakhdar Brahimi on 25 September 1989, speaker of the parliament Hussein al-Husseini confirmed that Christian and Muslim members of parliament would meet on 30 September in Saudi Arabia in spite of serious violations of the ceasefire.

On September 30, 1989, a significant gathering took place in Taif, Saudi Arabia, involving 62 out of the 73 surviving Lebanese legislators from the 99-seat parliament. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the charter of national reconciliation proposed by the Arab League tripartite committee. Among the attendees, there were 32 Christian legislators and 30 Muslim legislators. The talks were mediated by Saudi Arabia, Algeria, and Morocco, with the assistance of Lakhdar Brahimi, the Arab League's assistant Secretary-General. During the negotiations, Saudi Arabia reportedly provided financial incentives to encourage the parties involved in the peace process. Notably absent from the discussions were General Michel Aoun, who was advising the Christian parliamentarians from Beirut, as well as the leader of the Druze community, the leader of the Druze militia, and the leaders of the two major Shi'ite militias, Amal and Hezbollah. Additionally, the four external powers operating on Lebanese soil � Syria, Israel, Iran, and the Palestinians (both PLO and non-PLO) � were not present. The negotiations focused on three major issues: political reforms based on the Constitutional Document of 1976, the election of a new president, and the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanese territory. The latter issue proved to be the most contentious and divisive. The meeting experienced a deadlock as Christian parliamentarians continued to insist on a specific commitment for the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon, with General Aoun advocating for an accelerated timetable. The Arab League committee finally proposed an amended plan on 21 October that stipulated that the Syrian and the Lebanese governments would decide �together� on Syrian troops redeployment, while the original plan stated that Syria would make this decision �in coordination� with Lebanon. The meeting held in Taif, Saudi Arabia, extended over a period of 23 days, culminating in the agreement known as the Taif Agreement on 22 October 1989. During the final vote, 59 deputies expressed their support for the agreement, one voted against it, and two chose to abstain. However, General Michel Aoun vehemently rejected the Taif agreement. His primary objection stemmed from the absence of a firm commitment to ensure the swift and complete withdrawal of Syrian armed forces from Lebanon, which he saw as a threat to Lebanon's sovereignty. Aoun further contended that the proposed political reforms within the agreement were inadequate, failing to address the fundamental political problems at hand and, therefore, deemed them unacceptable.
third_party: Arab League, Saudi Arabia, Algeria, marocco

description: On 22 October 1989, immediately after the Taif Agreement was reached, Lakhdar Brahimi met with General Aoun to persuade him to endorse the plan, but he did not succeed. Brahimi also held talks with Selim Hoss on the same day.

On 27 October 1989, Arab League envoy Lakhdar Brahimi met General Michel Aoun to try to clear the way for the Lebanese parliament to ratify the peace plan and hold a parliamentary session. However, the Christian leader showed no sign of cooperation and said he would oppose the election of a new head of state. Despite Aoun�s declaring the dissolution of the parliament on 4 November, the parliament met on 5 November 1989. It elected a moderate Maronite Christian president backed by Syria, Rene Muawad, and ratified the Arab League peace plan. General Aoun neither recognised the election nor the peace plan. Moreover, the newly elected President was killed in a car bomb explosion on 22 November 1989 and Elias Hrawi was elected as President two days later.

The Maronite Catholic Church was also involved in mediation efforts. Lebanon�s Maronite Patriarch, Nassrallah Butros Sfeir, who backed the Arab League peace plan, met on 27 October with Michel Aoun to seek a way out of the impasse. In addition, on 7 November 1989, Father Boulos Naaman met Aoun to offer to mediate between him and the president. Maronite Catholic clergymen eventually undertook mediation efforts and shuttled between General Aoun and President Hrawi in late November 1989. Those efforts were reportedly supported by France and the Vatican.

On 14 December 1989, in a bid to renew the peace effort in Lebanon, peace envoy Lakhdar Brahimi and the French deputy Gerard Bapt held talks with Prime Minister Selim Hoss and House Speaker Hussein Husseini. On 15 December 1989, the Arab League peace envoy then met with newly elected President Elias Hrawi.
On 18 March 1990, peace envoy Lakhdar Brahimi met with President Hrawi, Prime Minister Hoss, House Speaker Hussein Husseini, and several political and religious leaders in Beirut.

On 12 April 1990, Lakhdar Brahimi held further talks with Prime Minister Selim Hoss and Parliamentary Speaker Hussein Husseini in a bid to implement the Arab League plan. He then met with President Hrawi on 13 April 1990. On 29 May 1990, Arab League leaders agreed to extend by six months the mandate of the tripartite peace committee trying to end the civil war in Lebanon.

After Vatican envoy Pablo Puente held talks with General Michel Aoun, the French envoy Fran�ois Scheer presented a Vatican peace plan to end the inter-Christian conflict as well as the civil war to President Elias Hrawi in June 1990. The proposal entailed the inclusion of Aoun (Lebanese Army) and Geagea (Lebanese Forces) in the �national reconciliation� cabinet. Aoun accepted the plan, but President Hrawi rejected it since he opposed any change in the Arab peace plan of 22 October 1989. The French envoy tried to make Hrawi change his mind without conclusive results.

On 20 June 1990, Fran�ois Scheer, director-general of the French foreign ministry, held talks with General Aoun and militia leader Geagea, as well as with Maronite Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir. He wanted to seek Aoun�s acceptance of the Taif Agreement of October 1989 and the presidency of Elias Hrawi.

On 15 July 1990, yet another mediation attempt was led by Lakhdar Brahimi to implement the Taif Agreement. He met with President Elias Hrawi, Prime Minister Selim Hoss, and House Speaker Hussein Husseini in west Beirut before crossing the Green Line to discuss with General Michel Aoun.

On 23 July 1990, Arab peace envoy Lakhdar Brahimi again met with General Aoun to persuade him to accept a new peace plan to end the country�s civil war that had already been ongoing for 15 years. He tried to convince Aoun to accept the deployment of Hrawi�s army in Christian east Beirut. However, two days later, on 25 July 1990, Michel Aoun again rejected the new Arab-sponsored peace initiative and refused the deployment of troops loyal to Elias Hrawi in east Beirut. The Lebanese Civil War reached its climax on 13 October 1990, when the Syrian Army launched a decisive assault on Baabda Palace and other key positions held by General Aoun. This offensive resulted in the deaths of numerous Lebanese soldiers and civilians and ultimately led to the removal of Aoun from power, signifying the end of the Lebanese Civil War. Aoun surrendered and went into exile in France.

Kuwaiti Foreign Minister Sheikh Sabah al-Ahmed, leader of the Arab League peace committee, and Arab League Secretary-General Chadli Kilibi held talks with pro-Syrian Muslim leftist leaders on 5 April 1989 in Damascus and proposed a three-point plan, calling for an immediate ceasefire. The Lebanese government representatives included Druze leader Walid Jumblatt and Nabih Berri, head of the Shi�ite Muslim Amal militia. The plan called for a ceasefire, for a lift of the seaports blockade and for the reopening of all crossing points between Muslim west and Christian east Beirut. According to the plan, the Arab League committee would be responsible for the monitoring of the ceasefire.

From 13 to 14 April 1989, the Arab League peace committee held discussions with Muslim and Christian leaders to find a peaceful solution to the conflict. The Christian representatives advocated the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon, while Muslim leaders asked for a greater representation of Muslims in the political system. The Arab League held an emergency meeting on Lebanon on 26 April 1989 in Tunis at the request of the Arab League peace committee. The six Arab ministers that were part of the committee gave their approval for sending more than 300 ceasefire observers to Lebanon. The ceasefire proposed by the Arab League went into effect on 28 April 1989. The Arab League ceasefire and peace plan also received international support, with the UN Security Council and the UN Secretary General, as well as France, publicly endorsing it.

On 15 August 1989, the UN Security Council issued a presidential statement following an emergency session, called for by the UNSG under article 99, on ending intensified fighting in Lebanon. While there was no formal response from the parties, General Michel Aoun affirmed that he had accepted the ceasefire in a telephone interview with the media agency Reuters on 16 August 1989. Moreover, fighting around the Green Line ceased some hours. The UN Security Council also reaffirmed its backing for the peace-making efforts of the three-nation Arab League committee and urged it to resume its work. The Arab League peace committee also called for a ceasefire on the 16 August 1989. However, within less than 24 hours, violence flared up again. On 18 August 1989, the Arab League revived its peace process by producing a blueprint of a �national reconciliation charter� to end the civil war in Lebanon. The plan called for a ceasefire, the restoration of Lebanese sovereignty throughout the country, the renewal of constitutional authority, and a wide range of political reforms. The document was sent to ambassadors in Rabat, including to ambassadors of the permanent members of the UN Security Council.

On 28 August 1989, France presented a three-step peace plan to Syria. The French peace plan proposed a ceasefire, a halt of arms deliveries to both sides, the introduction of political reforms to end the dominant role of the Christians, and the phased withdrawal of foreign forces from the country, beginning with the withdrawal of the Syrian troops from west Beirut. French envoy Fran�ois Scheer then travelled to Beirut on 30 August 1989 and met with several Muslim leaders, including Selim Hoss. Scheer also held talks with General Aoun and further Christian representatives. It became clear that one obstacle to the war was that while Syria and its allies did not want to lift their blockade of the Christian enclave if Aoun did not end his �war of liberation�, Aoun and its allies insisted on the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanese soil as precondition for laying down their weapons.

On 13 and 14 September 1989, the tripartite Arab League peace committee � composed of Algeria, Morocco, and Saudi Arabia � met in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, to discuss the possibility of revival of the peace process and initiate formal negotiations. Following these talks, the Arab League announced in a communiqu� published on 16 September 1989, a seven-point peace plan for Lebanon. The plan called for an immediate ceasefire and an end to arms shipments. This peace plan was to be implemented by a special security committee headed by Lakhdar Brahimi. The peace plan also called the parliament to convey for a meeting at national reconciliation on 30 September. However, the plan did not mention the withdrawal of Syrian troops. Syria and its allies immediately endorsed the plan, while General Michel Aoun claimed it was not containing anything new and asked for clarification. On 18 September 1989, the Arab League peace envoy Lakhdar Brahimi met with General Aoun, the Christian Maronite Patriarch Nasrallah Boutros Sfeir, and the leader of the Lebanese Forces militia Samir Geagea, in a bid to discuss the peace plan. Samir Geagea ensured supporting the peace plan. The peace envoy subsequently met with Muslim government officials on the same day.

On 23 September 1989, the security committee formed under the Arab League peace plan, including representatives of the Christian and of the Muslim community (Lebanese Forces, Amal, and the mainly Druze Progressive Socialist Party), declared a formal ceasefire. It was the first meeting of this committee, which was chaired by Arab League peace envoy Lakhdar Brahimi. The committee met again one day later to assess the effect of the ceasefire and noted that the it had held except for brief violations and welcomed the reopening of Beirut airport and the seaport. During a meeting with Arab League envoy Lakhdar Brahimi on 25 September 1989, speaker of the parliament Hussein al-Husseini confirmed that Christian and Muslim members of parliament would meet on 30 September in Saudi Arabia in spite of serious violations of the ceasefire.
On 26 September 1989, the Arab League committee arranged a ceasefire between the Syrian, Druze, and Amal troops and the Lebanese Armed Forces, and the Lebanese Forces soldiers.

On 30 September 1989, a significant gathering took place in Taif, Saudi Arabia, involving 62 out of the 73 surviving Lebanese legislators from the 99-seat parliament. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the charter of national reconciliation proposed by the Arab League tripartite committee. Among the attendees, there were 32 Christian legislators and 30 Muslim legislators. The talks were mediated by Saudi Arabia, Algeria, and Morocco, with the assistance of Lakhdar Brahimi, the Arab League�s assistant Secretary-General. During the negotiations, Saudi Arabia reportedly provided financial incentives to encourage the parties involved in the peace process. Notably absent from the discussions were General Michel Aoun, who was advising the Christian parliamentarians from Beirut, as well as the leader of the Druze community, the leader of the Druze militia, and the leaders of the two major Shi'ite militias, Amal and Hezbollah. Additionally, the four external powers operating on Lebanese soil � Syria, Israel, Iran, and the Palestinians (both PLO and non-PLO) � were not present. The negotiations focused on three major issues: political reforms based on the Constitutional Document of 1976, the election of a new president, and the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanese territory. The latter issue proved to be the most contentious and divisive. The meeting experienced a deadlock as Christian parliamentarians continued to insist on a specific commitment for the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon, with General Aoun advocating for an accelerated timetable. The Arab League committee finally proposed an amended plan on 21 October 1989 that stipulated that the Syrian and the Lebanese governments would decide �together� on Syrian troops redeployment, while the original plan stated that Syria would make this decision �in coordination� with Lebanon. The meeting held in Taif, Saudi Arabia, extended over a period of 23 days, culminating in the agreement known as the Taif Agreement on October 22, 1989. During the final vote, 59 deputies expressed their support for the agreement, one voted against it, and two chose to abstain. However, General Michel Aoun vehemently rejected the Taif agreement. His primary objection stemmed from the absence of a firm commitment to ensure the swift and complete withdrawal of Syrian armed forces from Lebanon, which he saw as a threat to Lebanon�s sovereignty. Aoun further contended that the proposed political reforms within the agreement were inadequate, failing to address the fundamental political problems at hand and, therefore, deemed them unacceptable.

Having given up on their fight at the MONUSCO base, the rebels handed in their weapons to peacekeepers and agreed to take part in mediation talks with the local authorities. Following negotiations mediated by MONUSCO between the provincial authorities and the Kata Katanga fighters on 23 and 24 March 2013, the Kata Katanga fighters were transported by the Congolese authorities to Kinshasa on two flights. After the Lubumbashi incident in March 2013, military operations of the Congolese army against the Kata Katanga intensified. In 2014, the government took the headquarters of the group and Kata Katanga was pushed back further south in the direction of Lubumbashi and the Kundelungu and Upemba national parks. In May 2014, Kata Katanga fighters surrendered and, in June this same year, Kyungu offered his surrender if the UN mission would aid Mitwaba and Pweto. A few clashes took place during 2015, but the Kata Katanga fighters were scattered and the level of violence remained low. G�d�on Kyungu announced in 2015 that he would create a political party to stand in the anticipated elections in 2017.

After negotiations between G�d�on Kuyungu and the governor of Congo�s Haute-Katanga, Jean-Claude Kazembe in September and October 2016, Kyungu himself and several hundred rebels surrendered their weapons in a ceremony in Lubumbashi on 12 October 2016. When surrendering, Kyungu stated �I come to answer the call of the Head of State who wants peace.� He added that he was willing to face justice with regard to prosecution.

Following months of battles that forced the federal government army out of Tigray, the Government of Ethiopia announced a unilateral ceasefire in July 2021. The TPLF dismissed this ceasefire as a �joke� and vowed to continue fighting, stating that key conditions for peace had not been met. Nevertheless, a first round of pre-negotiations took place in November 2021. On 7 November 2021, former Nigerian president Olusegun Obasanjo who was appointed as the AU High Representative for the Horn of Africa region, with a specific mandate on Ethiopia, held a meeting with Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed in Addis Ababa. Obasanjo also visited Mekelle to talk to the TPLF leadership to explore the option of formal negotiations. However, Obasanjo faced challenges of gaining the trust of Tigrayans and did not manage to initiate formal peace negotiations between the conflict parties. Obasnjo�s effort was supported by the US Special Envoy Jeffrey Feltman.
On 14 November 2021, Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta landed in Ethiopia on a one-day visit to discuss with Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed the option of initiating formal negotiations.

In March 2022, the Ethiopian federal government declared a unilateral ceasefire. The TPLF indicated that it would observe the ceasefire if aid was speedily delivered, but fighting in the Afar region continued. This fighting undermined efforts to get the conflict parties to engage in official negotiations. However, Abiy reportedly sent senior officials to secretly meet the TPLF to discuss the option of formal negotiations.

In March 2022, Ethiopia�s government declared humanitarian truce to help hasten delivery of emergency aid into the Tigray region. In mid-June 2022, Ethiopia�s federal government established a committee to engage in peace negotiations with the TPLF. This move, publicly confirmed for the first time, marked a significant stride towards resolving the conflict in the northern region. Deputy Prime Minister Demeke Mekonnen was appointed to head the committee. In reaction, Debretsion Gebremichael, chairman of the TPLF, expressed readiness to join a �credible, impartial, and principled� peace process, committing to send a delegation. The conflict parties subsequently held preliminary peace talks in Djibouti on 13 June 2022. However, the talks were almost instantly aborted because the Ethiopian government claimed that contrary to what had been agreed, information about the process had been leaked. The meeting in Djibouti was mediated by the AU.

In late June 2022, the conflict parties requested the AU to mediate again. This led to a face-to-face meeting between senior political and military delegates from Addis Ababa and Mekelle in Seychelles in July 2022. The talks were mediated by the AU.
Another meeting mediated by the AU took place in Djibouti between 5 and 7 September 2022.

Additionally, there were ongoing indirect communications facilitated by the AU, the US, and the EU. These talks led to agreements on a number of key issues, including humanitarian access to the famine-struck population of Tigray, the lifting of the government-induced siege, and the framework for a formal ceasefire agreement.
In September 2022, after a series of failed ceasefires, the Tigrayan leadership committed to a ceasefire to pave the ground for negotiations mediated by the AU.

On 5 October 2022, following a round of shuttle talks mediated by the AU, the Ethiopian government and TPLF accepted to participate in peace talks mediated by the AU in South Africa. This was the first time the parties agreed to formal negotiations since the war broke out.

Negotiations took place in Pretoria, South Africa, from 24 October to 2 November 2022. The talks were jointly mediated by Olusegun Obasanjo along with the former President of Kenya, Uhuru Kenyatta, and former South African Deputy President Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka. Representatives of IGAD, the UN, and the US were participating as observers to this AU-led peace process. The US put a high degree of pressure on the conflict parties. On 2 November 2022, the Ethiopian federal government and the TPLF signed the Agreement for Lasting Peace through a Permanent Cessation of Hostilities, also known as the Pretoria Agreement. The agreement establishes a permanent cessation of hostilities, as well as stipulates the protection of civilians from various forms of violence and ensures humanitarian aid access. The agreement also facilitates the disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration of the TPLF.
third_party: AU, Kenya, South Africa, IGAD, UN, US

description: Following the agreement, military commanders from both sides held talks on the implementation of the agreement in Nairobi between 7 and 12 November. On 12 November 2022, a declaration of the senior commanders on the modalities for the implementation of the agreement was signed.
agreement_name: Declaration of the senior commanders on the modalities for the implementation of the agreement

description: On 26 December 2022, a high-level delegation from Ethiopia�s federal government visited the Mekelle for talks with a TPLF delegation to discuss the implementation of the Pretoria Agreement. This government delegation was led by Tagesse Chafo, the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The delegation included ministers and heads of key public enterprises. Getachew Reda, the TPLF spokesman, lauded this visit as a milestone in the peace process, highlighting important discussions and agreements, particularly regarding the restoration of services in Tigray.
A joint monitoring and verification team comprising representatives of the government, the TPLF, and IGAD began a new set of talks about disarmament of TPLF in Mekelle on 29 December 2022.
On 3 February 2023, Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed met senior leaders of the TPLF to discuss the implementation of the Pretoria Agreement.

On 10 February 2023, the Joint Committee for implementing and monitoring the Pretoria Agreement held its inaugural meeting at the African Union Commission Headquarters in Addis Ababa. The Committee also examined the functioning of the Monitoring Verification and Compliance Mechanism (MVCM). The committee was chaired by Ambassador Bankole Adeoye, the AU Commissioner for Political Affairs, Peace and Security. The Joint Committee comprised representatives of the conflict parties and IGAD. In March 2023, in line with the Pretoria Agreement, the Ethiopian government established an interim administration for the Tigray region, appointing TPLF spokesman Getachew Reda to head this interim administration. Moreover, in the same month, Ethiopia�s parliament agreed to remove the TPLF from a list of terrorist organizations.

On 25 May 2023, the AU hosted the Second Joint Committee Meeting for the MVCM of the Ethiopian peace process. This meeting was attended by representatives from the federal government and the TPLF, as well as representatives of the AU and IGAD.

The Joint Committee met for a third time to discuss the implementation of the Pretoria Agreement in Addis Ababa on 1 December 2023. The Joint Committee called for a scaled up Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration process, resettlement of internally displaced people, and the commencement of political dialogue. The mandate of the MVCM was extended for one more year. The parties agreed to the need for taking stock of the implementation so far and to the importance of engaging international partners. Moreover, they expressed their commitment to full implementation of the Pretoria Agreement.

On 4 November 1989, exploratory talks between representatives of the EPRDF and the Government of Ethiopia opened in Rome. Alberto Solerathe, the Italian ambassador to China and former ambassador to Ethiopia, chaired these talks. During the talks, that were supposed to be of a procedural kind to make way for future negotiations, the TPLF presented a peace plan adopted at its congress in March the same year. The plan called for a broad based provisional government including representatives from all political organisations. The Government, in turn, accused the rebel factions of wishing to secede, leading to �national disunity�. The talks were adjourned on 11 November and were scheduled to be reopened on 12 December, but instead of continued talks, the fighting intensified in December 1989.

Between 20 and 29 March 1990, talks between the EPRDF and the Government of Ethiopia were held in Rome, under chairmanship of Alberto Solerathe, but no substantial progress was made. The negotiations again ended in a stalemate due to disagreement about what the focus of the talks should be. While the Government of Ethiopia solely wanted to discuss local issues related to the area in which the EPRDF was operating, the EPRDF demanded that the discussions would focus on national issues.

In early May 1991, the conflict parties agreed to negotiations in London scheduled on 27 May 1991, where Herman Cohen, US Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, would act as the chief mediator. Prior to these talks, General Tesfaye Gebre Kidan, who had replaced the exiled Colonel Mengistu, had expressed his willingness to negotiate with the rebels through the United States. However, on 26 May, the EPRDF had surrounded the capital and seized the main military bases. The next day, on 27 May, the negotiations in London were opened, where the TPLF-leader Meles Zenawi negotiated on behalf of the EPRDF. The EPLF and OLF were participating with separate delegations. Simultaneously to the negotiations, on 27 May, the EPRDF entered Addis Ababa and took control of the country. After one and a half days of negotiations, on 28 May, the parties present in London agreed to let the EPRDF set up a transitional government and arrange democratic elections within a year. The US did not provide any material incentives to the conflict parties to resolve the conflict. The US provided famine relief, but this was not linked to the mediation effort. Indeed, congressional declarations clearly indicated that famine relief would not be withheld. EPRDF leader Meles Zenawi had pledged to not enter Addis Ababa until after the London conference. However, prior to the EPRDF taking control of Addis Ababa on 27 May, the EPRDF leadership had requested Cohen for permission to do so in order to restore stability, which was subsequently granted. In fact, Cohen promised Zenawi that he would make a statement on the BBC and the Voice of America that he had recommended this action. The US thus recognised the EPRDF as the legitimate Government of Ethiopia.

In the first half of 1989, former US President Jimmy Carter tried to mediate between the two parties in order to bring peace talks about. Between 7 and 19 September 1989, preliminary peace talks took place in Atlanta, Georgia, where Carter obtained his mandate to mediate talks without conditions and with the talks publicly and officially announced.

The talks resumed in Nairobi on 20 November 1989, again led by Carter. Although Carter was acting as a private citizen in the mediation, through the Carter Center, the initiative had the approval of the US Secretary of State James A. Baker. Moreover, the mediation effort itself was not entirely separate from US diplomatic engagement in the conflict. In a meeting, aimed at improving US-Ethiopian relations, with US Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs Herman Cohen on 4 August 1989, President Mengistu had promised Cohen to find a solution to the conflict by inviting Jimmy Carter to mediate. One option discussed during the preliminary talks mediated by Carter was the initiation of official negotiations mediated by the OAU and the UN, but it soon became apparent that the UN could not attend without explicit invitation of the Government of Ethiopia, while the Government was not willing to officially invite the UN. Another problem was that the Government refused to even discuss independence for Eritrea, which made the EPLF refuse to enter into mediated negotiations as well. The negotiations mediated by Jimmy Carter in Nairobi in November 1989 did not lead to an agreement, but at the end of the talks in Nairobi, on 20 November 1989, the two sides decided to hold formal negotiations in early 1990. However, these negotiations never came about. Although the Government of Ethiopia frequently expressed it was willing to resume negotiations mediated by Carter, the EPLF was reluctant to renew the Carter initiative.

In early May 1991, the conflict parties agreed to negotiations in London scheduled on 27 May 1991, where Herman Cohen, US Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, would act as the chief mediator. Prior to these talks, General Tesfaye Gebre Kidan, who had replaced the exiled Colonel Mengistu, had expressed his willingness to negotiate with the rebels through the United States. However, on 26 May, the EPRDF had surrounded the capital and seized the main military bases. The next day, on 27 May, the negotiations in London were opened, where the TPLF-leader Meles Zenawi negotiated on behalf of the EPRDF. The EPLF and OLF were participating with separate delegations. Simultaneously to the negotiations, on 27 May, the EPRDF entered Addis Ababa and took control of the country. After one and a half days of negotiations, on 28 May, the parties present in London agreed to let the EPRDF set up a transitional government and arrange democratic elections within a year. The US did not provide any material incentives to the conflict parties to resolve the conflict. The US provided famine relief, but this was not linked to the mediation effort. Indeed, congressional declarations clearly indicated that famine relief would not be withheld. EPRDF leader Meles Zenawi had pledged to not enter Addis Ababa until after the London conference. However, prior to the EPRDF taking control of Addis Ababa on 27 May, the EPRDF leadership had requested Cohen for permission to do so in order to restore stability, which was subsequently granted. In fact, Cohen promised Zenawi that he would make a statement on the BBC and the Voice of America that he had recommended this action. The US thus recognised the EPRDF as the legitimate Government of Ethiopia.

From February to May 1997, South Africa undertook various attempts to initiate negotiations between President Mobutu Sese Seko and AFDL leader Laurent-D�sir� Kabila. However, the AFDL had the upper hand in the fighting and therefore initially rejected formal talks. On 19 February 1997, South African President Nelson Mandela announced that he had invited Laurent-D�sir� Kabila, chairman of the ADFL, to visit South Africa and to engage in peace talks with Mobuto. On 26 February, it was announced that Mandela had persuaded Kabila to negotiate. On 4 May 1997, Mandela mediated the first direct negotiations between Kabila and Mobutu aboard a South African naval vessel. The talks did not lead to an agreement. Mobutu proposed to set up a mutually acceptable transitional government prior to open elections in which everyone could participate, while Kabila demanded Mobutu to step down and hand over power to the AFDL. In the meantime, the AFDL moved steadily from the east to the west. They met little resistance on their way to Kinshasa, with the exception of troops from the former Rwandan army and from the Angolan rebel group UNITA under Jonas Savimbi. In mid-May 1997, President Mobutu was defeated by the AFDL and its allies. AFDL leader Kabila claimed victory and subsequently assumed power on 16 May 1997.

At a summit in Windhoek on 18 January 1999, the delegations of Zimbabwe, Uganda, Rwanda, Angola, Namibia held discussions on troop withdrawal and mandated Zambian President Frederick Chiluba to convene a summit aimed at concluding a ceasefire. However, the Government of the DRC did not attend this summit.

Libyan President al-Gaddafi continued his mediating efforts between Kabila and Museveni in Sirte on 18 April 1999, but none of the rebel factions were involved in these talks. Nevertheless, progress was made. President Kabila promised to start negotiations with Congolese rebels, while President Museveni promised to withdraw Uganda�s troops.

Consequently, the Government of the DRC and the three rebel groups � the RCD, the RCD-ML, and the MLC � as well as Uganda, Rwanda, Angola, Namibia, Zambia, and Zimbabwe met in Lusaka in July 1999. This meeting led to the signing of the Lusaka Accord by the regional states on 10 July 1999, but RCD and MLC initially refuse to sign. The agreement outlined several key provisions to bring about peace. It called for an immediate cessation of hostilities, the halt of military movements, and the cessation of hostile propaganda. A crucial aspect was the complete withdrawal of foreign troops from the territory of the DRC within a nine-month timeframe. To ensure compliance with the ceasefire and the disarmament of militia groups, a joint military commission, consisting of the warring parties and a UN/OAU observer group, would be established. The agreement also entailed the deployment of UN peacekeepers and the formation of a national army comprising both government and rebel forces. Additionally, it included an amnesty provision, granting immunity to all rebel groups except those involved in acts of genocide. Furthermore, the peace agreement provided a roadmap for an Inter-Congolese Dialogue, which aimed at achieving a democratic transition through general elections. Participants in this dialogue would include the government, armed groups, as well as unarmed political forces within the country. The MLC signed the agreement on 1 August 1999. On 31 August, after intense diplomatic pressure, all 50 founding members of the fractious RCD signed. Rebel leader Emile Ilunga and 41 of his deputies signed on behalf of the RCD. This was a compromise following dispute between the two RCD factions about which group had the right to sign. The Lusaka Accord foresaw a ceasefire, retreat of foreign armies, and a national dialogue.

The Joint Military Commission (JMC) and the Political Committee that oversaw the former, both created by the Lusaka Accord, had their first meeting in Kampala on 11 and 12 October 1999. The RCD and the MLC were represented in the JMC, but both Uganda and Rwanda were also members of the JMC. The talks focused, among others, on the disengagement of Rwandan and Ugandan troops from the DRC. The OAU and UN acted as mediators.

The Joint Military Commission (JMC) and the Political Committee that oversaw the former, both created by the Lusaka Accord, had their second meeting in Lusaka on 15 October 1999. The RCD and the MLC were represented in the JMC, but both Uganda and Rwanda were also members of the JMC. The talks focused, among others, on the disengagement of Rwandan and Ugandan troops from the DRC. The OAU and UN acted as mediators.

Since Chiluba�s mediator position increasingly weakened throughout 1999, because of accusations that Zambia covertly was assisting UNITA in Angola, the Government and rebel parties met in the Ethiopian capital Addis Ababa to discuss disagreements about possible facilitators for the Inter-Congolese Dialogue, as stipulated in the Lusaka Accord. The meeting was successful. The OAU Secretary-General nominated the former President of Botswana, Ketumile Masire, as mediator in the DRC�s political dialogue on 15 December, two months after the deadline given to the participants to conclude the Inter-Congolese Dialogue.

On 24 and 25 January 2000, the UN Security Council discussed the Congo peace process, with the Congolese, Rwandan, and Ugandan presidents, as well as the OAU Secretary-General, all making statements. The MLC and the RCD were not involved in these talks. The OAU and UN acted as mediators on the sidelines of this meeting. The talks focused on the implementation of the Lusaka Accord and the disengagement of Rwandan and Ugandan troops.

On 23 February 2000, the Lusaka Accord signatories � including the Congolese, Rwandan, and Ugandan presidents, but also the RCD and MLC leadership � met in Lusaka and agreed on a new implementation schedule starting on 1 March 2000. The talks focused on the disengagement of foreign troops. The OAU and UN acted as mediators.

Several preparatory meetings for the Inter-Congolese Dialogue were held in early 2000. On 8 April 2000, the parties to the Lusaka agreement � including Angola, the DRC, Namibia, Uganda, Rwanda, and Zimbabwe � accepted a disengagement plan in Kampala in which they agreed to retreat their forces 15 km behind the frontlines.
On 4 May 2000, the three Congolese insurgent parties renewed their commitment to the Inter-Congolese Dialogue.

In June 2000, the JMC and the Political Committee met in Lusaka. The RCD and the MLC were represented in the JMC, but both Uganda and Rwanda were also members of the JMC. The talks focused, among others, on the disengagement of Rwandan and Ugandan troops from the DRC. The OAU and UN acted as mediators.

The preparatory committee of the Inter-Congolese Dialogue subsequently continued to work on finding consensus on how the peace talks would proceed. After it was decided which parties should participate in the Inter-Congolese Dialogue, the Government of the DRC suggested that the dialogue should be held in Kinshasa, but this suggestion was rejected by Masire. The Government became increasingly critical toward Masire, which eventually led to a declaration in which they stated to have lost their confidence in the OAU mediator. Kabila considered him persona non grata and reportedly closed his offices in Kinshasa. As a result, the Government boycotted a round of consultations organized by Masire in Benin in June. Nevertheless, by August, the parties had managed to agree on an agenda, the structure, the rules, the place, and the dates of the dialogue.
In August 2000, leaders of the countries involved in the Congo war met in Lusaka, but the summit broke down.

In mid-October 2000, a regional summit was held in Mozambique hosted by Mozambican President, Joaquim Chissano, where the agreement that all fighters should withdraw 15 km from their positions was reiterated. Within the same month, South African President Thabo Mbeki managed to secure agreement to this withdrawal plan from all the rebel parties.
The leaders of the countries involved in the Congo war held a meeting in Maputo in Mozambique on 28 November 2000. The meeting focused on the withdrawal of foreign forces.

On 6 December 2000, the he Defense chiefs from the DRC, Zimbabwe, Uganda, Rwanda, Angola, and Namibia committed to a ceasefire agreement, the so-called Harare disengagement plan. In it, they reiterated the observation of the ceasefire, the retreat of troops 15 km behind the frontlines, the deployment of a peacekeeping force, and the withdrawal of foreign troops. This allowed the UN Security Council to adopt resolution 1332.

In January 2001, President Kabila was assassinated by his bodyguard, and his son, Joseph Kabila, assumed power. In early February 2001, Joseph Kabila met Rwandan President Paul Kagame in Washington to discuss the Rwandan troop presence in the DRC, paving the way for further peace talks.

On 15 February 2001, all parties to the conflict met in Lusaka and agreed once again to disengage to positions occupied by their forces in May 2000. However, no timetable for the withdrawal was set. Moreover, Uganda and Rwanda insisted on maintaining a presence in the DRC until the ADF and Hutu militias were removed, while Kabila�s foreign allies refused to withdraw until Uganda, Rwanda and Burundi had moved out their troops from the DRC.

On 3 April 2001, DRC President Kabila met a Ugandan delegation led by Foreign Minister Eriya Kategaya in Kinshasa. The MLC and the RCD did not attend these talks, but the talks focused on the withdrawal of Ugandan troops, which were supporting both the MLC and the RCD. The next day, on 4 April 2001, Ugandan President Museveni announced that he would pull out two more battalions from the DRC.

When Laurent Kabila was assassinated on 16 January 2001, his son succeeded. He had a more welcoming attitude towards Masire. In early March 2001, Joseph Kabila invited Masire to Kinshasa and promised to resume discussions with the mediator in the Inter-Congolese Dialogue. On the initiative of South Africa, the conflict parties (including the Mayi-Mayi militias) met in a closed-door meeting at Shumba Village (between Pretoria and Johannesburg) in April 2001.

On 4 May 2001, representatives of the DRC Government and the principal rebel factions signed the Declaration of Fundamental Principles for the Inter-Congolese dialogue in Lusaka. The agreement confirmed the parties commitment to 14 principles, which included, among others respect for the provisions of the Lusaka agreement, the sovereignty and the territorial integrity of the country, national reconciliation and a new political order for peace and reconstruction of the DRC, the inclusion of the political opposition and civil society in the dialogue, consensus as the means for adopting all decisions discussed in the negotiations, the holding of elections after the transitional period, the formation of an integrated national army, the utilization of national resources and to halt all acts of violence against civilians.

On 3 and 4 June 2001, DRC National Security Minister Mwenze Kongolo met a Ugandan delegation in Kampala and delivered a message from President Kabila to President Museveni. The MLC and the RCD were not part of this meeting. The talks as part of this meeting focused on the disengagement of Ugandan troops.

In late August 2001, the parties met in Botswana and agreed that the official Inter-Congolese dialogue was to commence in mid-October in the Ethiopian capital Addis Ababa. Attempting to outline areas of agreement, the Congolese government, the RCD, and the MLC signed the Acte d�Engagement in Gaborone on 24 August with Botswanan president Ketumile Masire acting as the lead mediator.
A subsequent preparatory meeting was held in Abuja in September 2001 to prepare for peace talks in Addis Ababa.

Another round of talks took place in Addis Ababa on 15 October 2001. However, Kabila and MLC leader Bemba failed to attend these talks. Furthermore, the RCD boycotted the opening ceremony. Consequently, the talks at Addis Ababa only lasted for five days instead of the proposed 45 days. The mediation effort was also plagued by financial problems. Donors had pledged $5 million for Masire�s office, but only $250,000 had been forthcoming for the Addis Ababa meeting. This forced the mediation team to ask the conflict parties to reduce their delegations at the very last minute.

On 18 February 2002, Ugandan President Museveni reportedly met a Congolese delegation of seven officials led by the Director General of External Security Organisation, Didi Kazadi. The RCD and the MLC were not part of these talks. However, the talks focused on the disengagement of Ugandan troops, which were providing support to the RCD and the MLC.
In 2002, the Inter-Congolese Dialogue continued. Talks started in Sun City, South Africa, on 25 February 2002, but these broke down after one day, when the MLC boycotted the meeting.
third_party: Switzerland, South Africa, Zambia, Nigeria, Malawi, OAU, UN

description: However, talks including the MLC resumed on 5 March 2002, although accusations of ceasefire violations in Moliro overshadowed the talks. The 362 delegates in Sun City split into five different committees to negotiate on political and legal matters, security and defense, social, cultural, and humanitarian affairs, economy and finance, and finally, peace and reconciliation.
third_party: Switzerland, South Africa, Zambia, Nigeria, Malawi, OAU, UN

description: On 9 April 2002, the talks moved forward, among other due to MLC accepting Joseph Kabila as the President during the interim period, which was the result of bilateral talks between the two parties.
third_party: Switzerland, South Africa, Zambia, Nigeria, Malawi, OAU, UN

description: On 19 April 2002, a partial peace agreement was signed between the rebel factions and Kabila, referred to as the Political Agreement on Consensual Management of the Transition in the DRC or �Sun City Accord�, which was supported by more than 70 per cent of the delegates. The agreement outlined the creation of key institutions. These included a national assembly, a senate, a senior army council, and courts and tribunals. According to the agreement, Joseph Kabila was accepted as the president for the 30-month transitional period, while Jean Pierre Bemba, the leader of the MLC rebel group, would assume the position of prime minister. In terms of the distribution of roles, the presidency of the senate was offered to political parties representing the non-armed opposition, while civil society would take on the responsibility of organizing elections. Additionally, provisions were made for the establishment of a truth and reconciliation commission and a committee focused on human rights, ethics, and anti-corruption. The president would hold the position of supreme commander of the army, which would be overseen by a senior army council. It was the president's duty to safeguard national unity and territorial integrity. Meanwhile, the prime minister would serve as the head of government, exercising control over the Council of Ministers and possessing the authority to appoint ministers and civil servants. Yet, the Rwandan-supported RCD wing rejected the agreement insisting that they deserved the position of the prime minister, which the agreement accorded to MLC leader Bemba. As part of the Sun City Accord, Uganda promised to withdraw its troops. It was agreed that MONUC would monitor the Ugandan troop withdrawal.
third_party: Switzerland, South Africa, Zambia, Nigeria, Malawi, OAU, UN

description: On 6 June 2002, DRC Minister for Presidency Katumba Mwanke, accompanied by Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Musimwa Bisharhwa, met with Ugandan President Museveni, handing him a message from DRC President Kabila. The RCD and the MLC were not part of these talks. However, the talks focused on the disengagement of Ugandan troops, which were providing support to the RCD and the MLC.

To move the peace process forward, the UN Secretary-General mandated Moustapha Niasse as his Special Envoy to the DRC to mediate a comprehensive peace agreement. Niasse conducted three missions in the region between June and October during which he consulted with the main rebel leaders and the government officials.

On 30 July 2002, Rwandan and Congolese presidents, Kagame and Kabila, signed an accord in Pretoria under Mbeki�s watch. Kabila pledged to disarm and arrest Rwandan Hutu militias in return for Rwandan troops withdrawing.

On 14 and 15 August 2002, the DRC and Uganda held negotiations in Luanda under the mediation of Angolan Foreign Minister Joao Miranda. The RCD and the MLC were not part of these talks. However, the talks focused on the disengagement of Ugandan troops, which were providing support to the RCD and the MLC.

Moreover, on 6 September 2002, Uganda and the DRC signed the Luanda agreement hosted by President Dos Santos, which decided on the withdrawal of Ugandan forces from the Congolese territory within three months.

In November, another round of talks began, resulting in the conclusion of the Global and Inclusive Agreement on the transition in the Democratic Republic of Congo in Pretoria on 17 December 2002. In addition to the conflict parties, the political opposition and civil society, with the latter referred to as the forces vives, participated in the Inter-Congolese Dialogue. The parties involved in the agreement reaffirmed the ceasefire modalities established in the Lusaka Agreement, Kampala Withdrawal Plan, and Harare Sub-Agreement. These modalities aimed to halt hostilities and seek a peaceful resolution to the conflict. One of the key provisions was the formation of a restructured, integrated national army comprising fighters from different factions. A similar approach was applied to the police force, creating integrated units within the security sector. While no specific quotas were mentioned, the agreement emphasized the importance of equitable representation among the groups. The agreement specified the establishment of a Government of Unity for a transitional period lasting 24 months, followed by scheduled elections. Four vice presidents were appointed, representing the RCD, MLC, government, and political opposition. Joseph Kabila was allowed to remain in his position as president. The parties were also granted ministerial portfolios, with each group receiving seven ministries and four deputy minister positions. A power-sharing arrangement was implemented in the senate and national assembly, ensuring a specific number of seats for all parties participating in the Inter-Congolese Dialogue. Reforms were introduced to separate the executive, legislative, and judicial branches of government. Additionally, amnesty was granted to those who had not committed acts of genocide, and an extensive program for the resettlement of refugees and internally displaced persons was established.
third_party: Switzerland, South Africa, Zambia, Nigeria, Malawi, AU, UN
agreement_name: Global and Inclusive Agreement on the transition in the Democratic Republic of Congo

description: In 2003, South Africa hosted continued talks between the parties. Ketumile Masire acted as the chief mediator, but Thabo Mbeki, acting as the Chairman of the AU, and Moustapha Niasse, acting as the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General of the UN on the Inter-Congolese Dialogue, were also involved in the peace talks. On 6 March 2003, after 11 days of talks in Pretoria, a draft constitution and a memorandum on the military and security arrangements during the transition period was adopted.
agreement_name: Draft Constitution, Memorandum on the Military and Security Arrangements During the Transition Period

description: In late March 2003, talks were held on integrating rebels into the DRC armed forces and on security measures during the transition period.

On 2 April 2003, a peace agreement was concluded that confirmed all the previous agreements: the Inter-Congolese Political Negotiations - The Final Act. This agreement emphasizes the parties' commitment to adhere to 36 Resolutions that were adopted during the Inter-Congolese Dialogue, The Global and Inclusive Agreement, and the Constitution of the Transition. Additionally, the Lusaka Agreement was reaffirmed. The agreement specifically highlights the important role of MONUC in ensuring the security of the transitional institutions that emerged from the Inter-Congolese Dialogue.
agreement_name: Inter-Congolese Political Negotiations - The Final Act

description: Nelson Mandela, as the chairman of SADC, tried to broker peace talks at an emergency summit of SADC leaders that was convened in Pretoria on 23 August 1998, but without success. President Kabila stated that he doubted whether Mandela was neutral.

On 7 and 8 September 1998, the Presidents of Zimbabwe, Uganda, Rwanda, Angola, Namibia, and the DRC met in Victoria Falls, Zimbabwe, to discuss how to resolve the conflict. The actors present agreed on a ceasefire between Rwanda, Uganda, and the DRC. Zambian President Frederick Jacob Titus Chiluba was mandated as mediator at this meeting, after which he was formally authorized to act as mediator in the conflict at the annual SADC meeting on 15 September 1998. The RCD was not invited to participate in the talks at Victoria Falls. As a consequence, the RCD leadership immediately rejected the ceasefire agreed to in Victoria Falls.
The RCD was not invited to peace talks organized in Addis Ababa on 10 September by the OAU either.

Yet, a few weeks later, Libyan head of state al-Gaddafi, acting on his own, mediated talks in Libya between President Kabila and RCD officials. Ugandan President Museveni also participated in these talks. However, no real progress was made, as Kabila continued to insist on the withdrawal of Ugandan and Rwandan troops before he would consider signing a ceasefire.

Building on the draft ceasefire agreement introduced by the OAU and the UN in Addis Ababa in September 1998, the Presidents of Zimbabwe, Uganda, Rwanda, Angola, Namibia, and the DRC agreed to the ceasefire in principle at a meeting in Lusaka on 26 and 27 October 1998, pending on �further consultations with the parties concerned.� Rwanda and Uganda�s concerns were addressed in the revised ceasefire through adding a clause that a mechanism would be set up through which the RCD and the Government of the DRC could negotiate on how to implement the ceasefire.

On 27 October 1998, Chiluba was officially mandated to further press on with a peace initiative to end the war after consultations between regional foreign and defence ministers. At a summit in Windhoek on 18 January 1999, the delegations of Zimbabwe, Uganda, Rwanda, Angola, Namibia held discussions on troop withdrawal and mandated Zambian President Frederick Chiluba to convene a summit aimed at concluding a ceasefire. However, the Government of the DRC did not attend this summit.

Libyan President al-Gaddafi continued his mediating efforts between Kabila and Museveni in Sirte on 18 April 1999, but none of the rebel factions were involved in these talks. Nevertheless, progress was made. President Kabila promised to start negotiations with Congolese rebels, while President Museveni promised to withdraw Uganda�s troops.

Consequently, the Government of the DRC and the three rebel groups � the RCD, the RCD-ML, and the MLC � as well as Uganda, Rwanda, Angola, Namibia, Zambia, and Zimbabwe met in Lusaka in July 1999. This meeting led to the signing of the Lusaka Accord by the regional states on 10 July 1999, but RCD and MLC initially refuse to sign. The agreement outlined several key provisions to bring about peace. It called for an immediate cessation of hostilities, the halt of military movements, and the cessation of hostile propaganda. A crucial aspect was the complete withdrawal of foreign troops from the territory of the DRC within a nine-month timeframe. To ensure compliance with the ceasefire and the disarmament of militia groups, a joint military commission, consisting of the warring parties and a UN/OAU observer group, would be established. The agreement also entailed the deployment of UN peacekeepers and the formation of a national army comprising both government and rebel forces. Additionally, it included an amnesty provision, granting immunity to all rebel groups except those involved in acts of genocide. Furthermore, the peace agreement provided a roadmap for an Inter-Congolese Dialogue, which aimed at achieving a democratic transition through general elections. Participants in this dialogue would include the government, armed groups, as well as unarmed political forces within the country. The MLC signed the agreement on 1 August 1999. On 31 August, after intense diplomatic pressure, all 50 founding members of the fractious RCD signed. Rebel leader Emile Ilunga and 41 of his deputies signed on behalf of the RCD. This was a compromise following dispute between the two RCD factions about which group had the right to sign. The Lusaka Accord foresaw a ceasefire, retreat of foreign armies, and a national dialogue.

The Joint Military Commission (JMC) and the Political Committee that oversaw the former, both created by the Lusaka Accord, had their first meeting in Kampala on 11 and 12 October 1999. The RCD and the MLC were represented in the JMC, but both Uganda and Rwanda were also members of the JMC. The talks focused, among others, on the disengagement of Rwandan and Ugandan troops from the DRC. The OAU and UN acted as mediators.

The Joint Military Commission (JMC) and the Political Committee that oversaw the former, both created by the Lusaka Accord, had their second meeting in Lusaka on 15 October 1999. The RCD and the MLC were represented in the JMC, but both Uganda and Rwanda were also members of the JMC. The talks focused, among others, on the disengagement of Rwandan and Ugandan troops from the DRC. The OAU and UN acted as mediators.

Since Chiluba�s mediator position increasingly weakened throughout 1999, because of accusations that Zambia covertly was assisting UNITA in Angola, the Government and rebel parties met in the Ethiopian capital Addis Ababa to discuss disagreements about possible facilitators for the Inter-Congolese Dialogue, as stipulated in the Lusaka Accord. The meeting was successful. The OAU Secretary-General nominated the former President of Botswana, Ketumile Masire, as mediator in the DRC�s political dialogue on 15 December, two months after the deadline given to the participants to conclude the Inter-Congolese Dialogue.

On 24 and 25 January 2000, the UN Security Council discussed the Congo peace process, with the Congolese, Rwandan, and Ugandan presidents, as well as the OAU Secretary-General, all making statements. The MLC and the RCD were not involved in these talks. The OAU and UN acted as mediators on the sidelines of this meeting. The talks focused on the implementation of the Lusaka Accord and the disengagement of Rwandan and Ugandan troops.

On 23 February 2000, the Lusaka Accord signatories � including the Congolese, Rwandan, and Ugandan presidents, but also the RCD and MLC leadership � met in Lusaka and agreed on a new implementation schedule starting on 1 March 2000. The talks focused on the disengagement of foreign troops. The OAU and UN acted as mediators.

Several preparatory meetings for the Inter-Congolese Dialogue were held in early 2000. On 8 April 2000, the parties to the Lusaka agreement � including Angola, the DRC, Namibia, Uganda, Rwanda, and Zimbabwe � accepted a disengagement plan in Kampala in which they agreed to retreat their forces 15 km behind the frontlines.
On 4 May 2000, the three Congolese insurgent parties renewed their commitment to the Inter-Congolese Dialogue.

On 3 June 2000, negotiations took place between DRC President Kabila and Rwandan President Kagame in Eldoret in Kenya. The talks were mediated by Kenyan President arap Moi, with support from diplomats from the UN and the OAU. The RCD was not involved in these talks, which were aimed at ending the Congolese support to ALiR and ending the Rwandan support to the RCD.

In June 2000, the JMC and the Political Committee met in Lusaka. The RCD and the MLC were represented in the JMC, but both Uganda and Rwanda were also members of the JMC. The talks focused, among others, on the disengagement of Rwandan and Ugandan troops from the DRC. The OAU and UN acted as mediators.

The preparatory committee of the Inter-Congolese Dialogue subsequently continued to work on finding consensus on how the peace talks would proceed. After it was decided which parties should participate in the Inter-Congolese Dialogue, the Government of the DRC suggested that the dialogue should be held in Kinshasa, but this suggestion was rejected by Masire. The Government became increasingly critical toward Masire, which eventually led to a declaration in which they stated to have lost their confidence in the OAU mediator. Kabila considered him persona non grata and reportedly closed his offices in Kinshasa. As a result, the Government boycotted a round of consultations organized by Masire in Benin in June. Nevertheless, by August, the parties had managed to agree on an agenda, the structure, the rules, the place, and the dates of the dialogue.
In August 2000, leaders of the countries involved in the Congo war met in Lusaka, but the summit broke down.

In mid-October 2000, a regional summit was held in Mozambique hosted by Mozambican President, Joaquim Chissano, where the agreement that all fighters should withdraw 15 km from their positions was reiterated. Within the same month, South African President Thabo Mbeki managed to secure agreement to this withdrawal plan from all the rebel parties.
The leaders of the countries involved in the Congo war held a meeting in Maputo in Mozambique on 28 November 2000. The meeting focused on the withdrawal of foreign forces.

On 6 December 2000, RCD and the Congolese government both committed to a ceasefire agreement, the so-called Harare disengagement plan. In it, they reiterated the observation of the ceasefire, the retreat of troops 15 km behind the frontlines, the deployment of a peacekeeping force, and the withdrawal of foreign troops. The agreement was also signed by the he Defense chiefs from Zimbabwe, Uganda, Rwanda, Angola, and Namibia. This allowed the UN Security Council to adopt resolution 1332.

In January 2001, President Kabila was assassinated by his bodyguard, and his son, Joseph Kabila, assumed power. In early February 2001, Joseph Kabila met Rwandan President Paul Kagame in Washington to discuss the Rwandan troop presence in the DRC, paving the way for further peace talks.

On 15 February 2001, all parties to the conflict met in Lusaka and agreed once again to disengage to positions occupied by their forces in May 2000. However, no timetable for the withdrawal was set. Moreover, Uganda and Rwanda insisted on maintaining a presence in the DRC until the ADF and Hutu militias were removed, while Kabila�s foreign allies refused to withdraw until Uganda, Rwanda and Burundi had moved out their troops from the DRC.

On 3 April 2001, DRC President Kabila met a Ugandan delegation led by Foreign Minister Eriya Kategaya in Kinshasa. The MLC and the RCD did not attend these talks, but the talks focused on the withdrawal of Ugandan troops, which were supporting both the MLC and the RCD. The next day, on 4 April 2001, Ugandan President Museveni announced that he would pull out two more battalions from the DRC.

When Laurent Kabila was assassinated on 16 January 2001, his son succeeded. He had a more welcoming attitude towards Masire. In early March 2001, Joseph Kabila invited Masire to Kinshasa and promised to resume discussions with the mediator in the Inter-Congolese Dialogue. On the initiative of South Africa, the conflict parties (including the Mayi-Mayi militias) met in a closed-door meeting at Shumba Village (between Pretoria and Johannesburg) in April 2001.
