On 4 May 2001, representatives of the DRC Government and the principal rebel factions signed the Declaration of Fundamental Principles for the Inter-Congolese dialogue in Lusaka. The agreement confirmed the parties commitment to 14 principles, which included, among others respect for the provisions of the Lusaka agreement, the sovereignty and the territorial integrity of the country, national reconciliation and a new political order for peace and reconstruction of the DRC, the inclusion of the political opposition and civil society in the dialogue, consensus as the means for adopting all decisions discussed in the negotiations, the holding of elections after the transitional period, the formation of an integrated national army, the utilization of national resources and to halt all acts of violence against civilians.

On 3 and 4 June 2001, DRC National Security Minister Mwenze Kongolo met a Ugandan delegation in Kampala and delivered a message from President Kabila to President Museveni. The MLC and the RCD were not part of this meeting. The talks as part of this meeting focused on the disengagement of Ugandan troops.

On 9 July 2001, on the sidelines of an OAU summit in Lusaka, UN Secretary General Annan mediated talks between DRC President Kabila and Rwandan President Kagame. The talks focused on the disengagement of Rwandan troops from the DRC. These Rwandan troops were supporting the RCD.

In late August 2001, the parties met in Botswana and agreed that the official Inter-Congolese dialogue was to commence in mid-October in the Ethiopian capital Addis Ababa. Attempting to outline areas of agreement, the Congolese government, the RCD, and the MLC signed the Acte d�Engagement in Gaborone on 24 August with Botswanan president Ketumile Masire acting as the lead mediator.

On 31 August 2001, DRC President Kabila and Rwandan President Kagame held closed-door talks without their aides at a hotel in Durban in South Africa on the sidelines of a UN conference on racism. The talks focused on the disengagement of Rwandan troops from the DRC. These Rwandan troops were supporting the RCD.
A subsequent preparatory meeting was held in Abuja in September 2001 to prepare for peace talks in Addis Ababa.

On 26 September 2001, DRC President Kabila and Rwandan President Kagame held long talks in Blantyre in Malawi. The talks were chaired by President Muluzi of Malawi, the SADC chairman at the time. The talks focused on the disengagement of Rwandan troops from the DRC. These Rwandan troops were supporting the RCD.

Another round of talks took place in Addis Ababa on 15 October 2001. However, Kabila and MLC leader Bemba failed to attend these talks. Furthermore, the RCD boycotted the opening ceremony. Consequently, the talks at Addis Ababa only lasted for five days instead of the proposed 45 days. The mediation effort was also plagued by financial problems. Donors had pledged $5 million for Masire�s office, but only $250,000 had been forthcoming for the Addis Ababa meeting. This forced the mediation team to ask the conflict parties to reduce their delegations at the very last minute.

On 18 February 2002, Ugandan President Museveni reportedly met a Congolese delegation of seven officials led by the Director General of External Security Organisation, Didi Kazadi. The RCD and the MLC were not part of these talks. However, the talks focused on the disengagement of Ugandan troops, which were providing support to the RCD and the MLC.
In 2002, the Inter-Congolese Dialogue continued. Talks started in Sun City, South Africa, on 25 February 2002, but these broke down after one day, when the MLC boycotted the meeting.

On 12 September 2002, Presidents Kabila and Kagame met with US President Bush on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly meeting in New York. They were joined by chief mediator South African President Mbeki. The talks focused on the status of Rwandan troop withdrawal from the DRC and the disarmament and repatriation of armed Rwandan groups based in the DRC, most notably the FDLR.

On 18 September 2002, officials of the governments of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and Rwanda, and representatives of the third parties � South Africa and the UN � met in the Rwandan capital, Kigali, to discuss the status of Rwandan troop withdrawal from the DRC and the disarmament and repatriation of armed Rwandan groups based in the DRC, most notably the FDLR.

agreement_name: Inter-Congolese Political Negotiations - The Final Act

description: On 27 November 2003, Presidents Kabila and Kagame met in Pretoria for a round of talks mediated by President Mbeki. The talks focused on the implementation of the Pretoria Accord signed on 30 July 2002, which stipulated that the DRC would disarm and arrest Rwandan Hutu militias in return for Rwandan troops withdrawing from the DRC. The meeting was also attended by UN and AU representatives. Kabila and Kagame agreed to finish implementing the Pretoria Accord within 12 months.

In August 2004, the RCD left the Government of DRC for a short period after the Gatumba massacre of Congolese Tutsi refugees in Burundi in August 2004. On 1 September, they joined the Government again after South African President Thabo Mbeki held crisis talks with all parties.

In June 2004, the CNDP attacked the Congolese town of Bukavu. No negotiations between the CNDP and the Congolese government took place, but negotiations between the Congolese government and Rwanda did take place in response to the emergence of the CNDP. DRC president Joseph Kabila immediately accused Rwanda of supporting this new rebel group. Fearing the outbreak of full-scale war that could again drastically destabilize the region, the international community immediately expressed concern. Diplomats from the UN, AU, EU, and US called for both sides to show restraint. In an early effort to reduce the tensions, Nigerian president Olusegun Obasanjo, chairman of the AU, held talks in Abuja in June 2004 between Congolese President Joseph Kabila and Rwandan president Paul Kagame. Both sides agreed to adhere in the Pretoria agreement of July 2002 and to set up a verification team that would ensure the disarmament of Hutu militia groups and the absence of Rwandan troops on DRC soil.

On 20 and 21 April 2006, the Tripartite Plus Joint Commission met in Bujumbura. This meeting took place in the context of support provide by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. The meeting ended with a call for UN and AU sanctions to be imposed on rebel groups operating in the eastern DRC. The US acted as mediator.

On 26 and 27 May 2006, the Tripartite Plus Commission met in Kigali. This meeting took place in the context of support provide by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. The parties agreed on a provisional list of rebel chiefs on whom they wanted sanctions imposed for destabilizing the region. The meeting in Kigali, the third between the four countries in the space of two months, was facilitated by US Deputy Assistant Secretary for African Affairs Donald Yamamoto.

The DRC and Rwanda were among the signatories of the Pact on Security, Stability and Development in the Great Lakes Region at an international summit in Nairobi on 15 December 2006. This agreement, among others, included provisions on non-aggression and mutual defense. This makes the agreement relevant in relation to the support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda.
agreement_name: Pact on Security, Stability and Development in the Great Lakes Region

description: The UN called for talks between CNDP and the DRC government. The latter sent his interior minister, General Denis Kalume, to start the talks. On 29 December 2006, the United Nations Organization Mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (MONUC) negotiated a ceasefire between the two sides.

On 1 January 2007, Rwanda mediated talks in Kigali between Laurent Nkunda representing CNDP and General Denis Kalume Numbi representing the Government of the DRC. The talks led to an informal agreement to integrate Nkunda�s fighters into the government forces located in North Kivu to carry out operations against the Forces d�mocratiques de lib�ration du Rwanda (FDLR) (English: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda). They had agreed that Nkunda�s troops would be integrated into the national army with the system of Brassage, meaning that troops loyal to him would be mixed with troops loyal to the central government. However, rather than diluting Nkunda�s influence, this deal extended his influence beyond his original sphere of influence. It was agreed that if the FDLR would be defeated, the Banyamulenge refugees would be able to return to the DRC and Nkunda would go into exile. Yet, with armed violence escalating throughout the first half of 2007, the UN took a firmer stance and publicly called the CNDP as �the single most serious threat to stability in the DR Congo� in July 2007.

On 15 and 16 March 2007, the Tripartite Plus Commission met in Kigali. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. Ministers from the four countries reiterated their commitment to end rebel activities in the region.

On 18 April 2007, top military officials from Burundi, the DRC, Rwanda, and Uganda held a Tripartite Plus Commission meeting in Bujumbura. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support.

In early June 2007, the Tripartite Plus Commission met in Lubumbashi. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support.

On 27 and 28 August 2007, top military officials of the Tripartite Plus Commission met in Kigali. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. Opening the talks, Rwandan Foreign Affairs Minister Charles Murigande criticized the DRC for stopping military action against the FDLR.

MONUC mediated a new ceasefire on 6 September 2007, which prevented CNDP to take control over Sake. However, fighting resumed on 24 September, when the Government of the DRC launched an operation against the CNDP involving more than 20,000 soldiers after it became apparent that the CNDP had failed to meet the deadline to disarm and integrate its fighters into the national army. Nevertheless, on 23 October, only 200 CNDP soldiers were sent to assembly points for integration, which spurred renewed negotiations. It was agreed that a peace conference, involving most armed groups in the region, was to be held at the end of the year. However, the conference was rescheduled to take place in January 2008. On 15 October and 26 December 2007, CNDP declared unilateral ceasefires in anticipation of the peace talks.

DRC President Kabila and Rwandan President Kagame met on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly in New York in September 2007 and asked the UN for support in removing foreign rebel groups from the DRC. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending support they respectively provided to the FDLR and the CNDP.

The Tripartite Plus Commission met in Kampala between 15 and 17 September 2007. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support.

The Tripartite Plus Commission met in Kinshasa in late September 2007. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. Rwanda raised concerns about the lack of Congolese action against the FDLR during the meeting.

President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, President Paul Kagame of Rwanda, President Pierre Nkurunziza of Burundi, and Minister of State for Interior Denis Kalume, representing President Joseph Kabila of the DRC, met in Addis Ababa on 5 December 2007 for a Tripartite Plus Joint Commission meeting. US Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice acted as the mediator during this meeting. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. The parties agreed at the end of the meeting that �No member state will harbor any Negative Forces. Participants recommitted to deny safe haven or support to any Negative Forces.�

A peace conference, facilitated by the UN, was held in Goma in January 2008. Although the UN representatives participated in the conference, the two chief mediators were Abb� Appollinaire Malu Malu and Vital Kamerhe. These two Congolese politicians had been mandated to mediate by the Government. Prior to the actual conference, the chief mediators went on an extensive awareness-raising tour through North and South Kivu. On the basis of different consultations and meetings during this tour, a document specifying 15 objectives of the conference was produced. While the organizers of the conference expected 600 participants, around 1500 people showed up at Goma at the start of the conference on 6 January 2008. Neither the FDLR nor the Rwandan government participated in the talks. The role of the UN representatives was twofold. First, they served as observers in order to ensure the neutrality of the talks. Second, in addition to participating in the plenary meetings, the UN representatives held secret bilateral meetings with Government of the DRC and the CNDP leadership. The conference led to the conclusion of an immediate ceasefire under the Act d�Engagement, Nord Kivu on 23 January 2008, as well a promise by the CNDP to withdraw all of its fighters from the North Kivu province, and impunity for Nkunda�s forces. The agreement also enlisted the DRC government to remove FDLR forces from North Kivu, yet the CNDP remained dissatisfied with the results and they declared war on the FDLR. Consequently, the ceasefire did not hold and intense fighting took place throughout the rest of the year. Civilians blamed the UN, claiming that MONUC had done nothing to prevent the CNDP from advancing. The UN then prevented CNDP fighters from advancing on Goma. On 28 October 2008, fighting took place between CNDP and joint government-MONUC troops. The CNDP declared a unilateral ceasefire on 29 October 2008. Yet, they broke it and advanced further.

In late March 2008, the Tripartite Plus Commission met in Bujumbura to discuss efforts against rebel groups in the region. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending support to rebel groups.

Prior to the CNDP advance on Goma, on 8 May 2008, the Congolese government had agreed to negotiate with CNDP at the behest of Olusegun Obasanjo, the UN Secretary-General�s Special Envoy on the Great Lakes Region. Obasanjo had been mandated by the UN Secretary-General to facilitate dialogue between the leaders of Democratic Republic of Congo and Rwanda and assist the Governments of the sub-region to address the challenges to peace and security posed by the continued presence and activities of armed groups in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo. Negotiations began in Nairobi on 8 December of this same year. This round proved unsuccessful as it was suspended on 21 December.

Chiefs of defence staff of the Tripartite Plus Joint Commission member states approved an operational plan to be used in stopping rebel groups � including the FDLR and the CNDP � operating in the DRC at a meeting in Kigali on 20 June 2008.

On 28 October 2008, newly appointed DRC Foreign Minister Alexis Thambwe Mwamba met Rwandan President Kagame in Kigali and delivered a special message from President Kabila. The meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support.

On 4 December 2008, government representatives of the DRC and Rwanda signed the so-called �Four on Four Agreement� that specified that the Congolese government forces would end their military support of the FDLR and would, with support from the Rwandan government forces, forcefully disarm the FDLR. In the framework of the so-called �four plus four� mechanism in which four Rwandan officials met several times with their Congolese counterparts, the Rwandan and the DRC governments planned a joint military operation, called �Umoja Wetu� (English: Our Unity) to root out the FLDR. The joint operation lasted for one month in 2009 and ended with Rwanda withdrawing at the end of February 2009. In return for the Congolese support, Rwanda agreed to end its support for the CNDP and even helped the DRC to arrest CNDP leader Nkunda in Rwanda on 22 January 2009.

Negotiations between Rwanda and the DRC at the Ihusi Hotel in Goma in January 2009 led to a formal rapprochement in the form of the signing of the Ihusi Agreement on 16 January 2009. The agreement committed Rwanda to ending its support to the CNDP and arresting CNDP leader Nkunda, while it committed the DRC to end support to the FDLR and help the Rwanda attack the FDLR forces in the DRC.

Negotiations between the Government of the DRC and CNDP began in Nairobi on 7 January 2009. Olusegun Obasanjo and Benjamin William Mkapa, former President of Tanzania and representing the AU, acted as the joint chief mediators. On 16 January, a faction from CNDP signed a ceasefire agreement with the government. Another ceasefire was concluded on 4 February 2009. The ongoing negotiations led to the conclusion of the Ihussi Accord on 23 March 2009. The agreement referenced the ceasefires announced on 16 January and 4 February 2009. The CNDP reiterated their dedication to integrating their members into the police and armed forces. Both parties also reached a consensus on implementing extensive reforms in the army and security services. The agreement outlined the establishment of a community-based police force that would represent the diverse local population. The CNDP would undergo a transformation into a political party, allowing its officials to engage in national politics and participate in the political activities of the DRC. Furthermore, the agreement involved an assessment of the Electoral Act. Both parties reaffirmed their commitment to national sovereignty, territorial integrity, the inviolability of national borders, and the protection of human rights, fundamental freedoms, and citizens' duties. The agreement emphasized the apolitical nature of the armed forces and national police, emphasizing their allegiance to the Republic. The agreement also aimed to restore the authority of the State in the areas of Masisi, Rutshuru, and Nyiragongo. The government agreed to release all political prisoners and enact an Amnesty Act covering the period from June 2003 to 2009. However, it was clarified that this amnesty would comply with international law and not encompass war crimes, crimes against humanity, or genocide. Additionally, the government committed to establishing a ministerial body responsible for national security, local affairs, and reconciliation, as well as creating local conciliation committees. The agreement included provisions for the repatriation of displaced individuals and refugees to their respective countries, as well as the return of internally displaced persons to their communities. To oversee the agreement�s implementation, a government-CNDP Follow-up Committee and an International Follow-up Committee were to be established with specific mandates. Dr. D�sir� Kamanzi, Chairman of CNDP, signed the agreement on behalf of the CNDP and Raymond Tshibanda signed on behalf of the Government of the DRC.

Local leaders approached surrounding rebel groups to meet for negotiations. On 18 December 2012, the APCLS and the Congolese government met with other armed groups � including the Mayi-Mayi, Nyatura, and Raia Mutomboki � and negotiated a ceasefire, as well as an alliance between themselves.

In January 2013, attempts were made by the Government of the DRC to integrate APCLS into the national army. Government negotiators and APCLS leader Janvier Bwingo Karairi negotiated over the possible integration of APCLS forces into the national army in January 2013. Although a number of fighters from APCLS reported for integration, most rejected integration and continued to carry out attacks on civilians in parts of Masisi territory. According to UN Radio, discussions over integration broke down over the murder of an APCLS officer and attempts by the APCLS to attack ethnic Tutsi living in a displacement camp, who they alleged were hiding weapons.

Fighting escalated in February 2014, when government forces launched an operation targeting APCLS. On 17 March 2014, government forces took control of Lukweti, which had been used by APCLS as headquarters for six years. Clashes continued in April, May and June and forced the group to disperse further. After being dormant for some time, the APCLS made a resurgence in 2016. On 23 August 2016, APCLS and militia group Mai-Mai Nyatura concluded a peace agreement in the presence of Congolese government officials in Muhanga in which they agreed to hand over their weapons to national army on the condition that they would be provided guarantees for their security, including amnesty. Deputies from North Kiva, representing the Government of the DRC, were involved in these negotiations. The agreement was mediated by two elected officials of the Masisi, assisted by the police and the security services. On 7 February 2017, the APCLS joined the CMC alliance that aimed to unite armed groups in North and South Kivu in order to force President Joseph Kabila to stand down and reduce Rwandan influence in the eastern part of the DRC.

In April 2022, the Congolese government and various armed groups attended a peace conference in Nairobi. The peace conference was held under the auspices of the East African Community (EAC). Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta acted as the EAC mediator during the peace conference. The APCLS also participated in this conference.
Another peace conference organized by the EAC and mediated by Uhuru Kenyatta was held in Nairobi in June 2022.

A third peace conference organized by the EAC was held in Nairobi between 28 November 2022 and 6 December 2022. Former President of Kenya Uhuru Kenyatta acted as the chief mediator at this peace conference.

A peace conference, facilitated by the UN, was held in Goma in January 2008. Although the UN representatives participated in the conference, the two chief mediators were Abb� Appollinaire Malu Malu and Vital Kamerhe. These two Congolese politicians had been mandated to mediate by the Government. Prior to the actual conference, the chief mediators went on an extensive awareness-raising tour through North and South Kivu. On the basis of different consultations and meetings during this tour, a document specifying 15 objectives of the conference was produced. While the organizers of the conference expected 600 participants, around 1500 people showed up at Goma at the start of the conference on 6 January 2008. The conference led to the conclusion of an immediate ceasefire through the conclusion of the the Acte d�Engagement, Nord Kivu on 23 January 2008. This agreement was signed by Yakutumba, along with other Mayi Mayi movements.

In March 2012, the rebels sent a delegation to Bukavu to talk with the DRC Government, but the negotiations failed. In April 2012, a mutiny broke out among government troops in Fizi and Uvira territories, which proved to be the precursor to the M23 rebellion.

In late 2012, the Congolese government, intent on preventing the M23 from gaining allies, approached Yakutumba again to reconcile. During negotiations in December 2012, the CNSPC leadership and the government negotiators came to an agreement that CNSPC fighters would be integrated into the national army. On 5 February 2013, Yakutumba began sending some of his troops to an integration camp in Sebele, approximately 30 kilometres south of Baraka. Around 250 troops gathered there very soon, which amounted to well over half of the estimated numbers of the CNSPC. However, in spite of the government providing equipment and money to help regroup his troops, most of Yakutumba�s men left to take up positions in Ubwari and in nearby mining areas. The Congolese army subsequently declared the process a failure and terminated the integration process. In order to force the government to continue to negotiate on the integration of his fighters, Yakutumba and his fighters tried to take control of Kachemba, Misisi, and Lulimba localities in April 2014. Yet, no new negotiations were initiated. There was only little fighting between the CNPSC and the government forces in 2015 and no fighting in 2016. In late 2016, Yakutumba revived the CNPSC alliance. In the first half of 2017, the CNPSC successfully launched a series of attacks against the government forces, leading to a significant expansion of their influence in the Fizi area, extending their reach to the gold hub Misisi and to major towns such as Fizi and Baraka. In 2017 and 2018, the CNSPC continued to attack government bases, but it was not considered a threat to the stability of the state.

In December 2019, 32 armed groups attended a peace conference in Murhesa near the provincial capital Bukavu. The conference � often referred to as Murhesa I � led to the signing of a ceasefire. The Congolese government and the NGO Search for Common Ground acted as mediators during the peace conference. The CNPSC also attended this peace conference and signed the ceasefire.

Between 14 and 16 September 2020, 70 armed groups attended another peace conference in Murhesa � often referred to as Murhesa II � near the provincial capital Bukavu. The conference led to the signing of a ceasefire. The Interprovincial Commission for Support of the Community Awareness, Disarmament, Demobilisation and Reintegration (CIAP-DDRC) facilitated the dialogue in close partnership with the NGO Search for Common Ground, Consortium Maji ya Amani, the Initiative for Cohesive Leadership (ILC), and the Association for Integrated Community Development (ADCI). The Minister for National Defense acted as the chief mediator. The CNPSC also attend this peace conference. The conference ended with the signing of a declaration that included a ceasefire.
third_party: CIAP-DDRC, Search for Common Ground, Initiative for Cohesive Leadership, ICDA, Minister for National Defense
agreement_name: Declaration of Murhesa II for A Community Demobilisation, Disarmament, Reintegration and Reconciliation process in South Kivu province

description: In April 2022, the Congolese government and various armed groups attended a peace conference in Nairobi. The peace conference was held under the auspices of the East African Community (EAC). Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta acted as the EAC mediator during the peace conference. A CNPSC delegation led by the spokesperson of the group, rather than the CNPSC leader William Yakutumba, also participated in this conference.
Another peace conference organized by the EAC and mediated by Uhuru Kenyatta was held in Nairobi in June 2022.

A third peace conference organized by the EAC was held in Nairobi between 28 November 2022 and 6 December 2022. Former President of Kenya Uhuru Kenyatta acted as the chief mediator at this peace conference.

On 24 November 2012, the International Conference for the Great Lakes Region led by Uganda mediated a ceasefire between the two parties. Following M23 taking control of Goma, the Ugandan military, which was in communication with the M23 rebels, announced that the M23 leadership had agreed to a plan drawn up by regional heads of state for the rebels to leave Goma within 48 hours, with no conditions. However, the M23 leader in December 2012, Jean Marie Runiga, subsequently told reporters in Goma that his forces would only withdraw if President Kabila would hold national talks, release political prisoners, and dissolve the electoral commission, a body widely accused of delivering Kabila a second term in a flawed 2011 election. These demands were refused by the Congolese government. Nevertheless, on 1 December 2012, the M23 rebels left Goma.
third_party: International Conference for the Great Lakes Region, Uganda

description: Later in December 2012, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region (ICGLR), with the support of other international and regional partners, was successful in facilitating the opening of a dialogue between the DRC and M23. Holding ICGLR Presidency, Uganda facilitated negotiations between the Government of the DRC and M23 in Kampala between 9 and 21 December. The Ugandan Defence Minister, Crispus Kiyonga, acted as mediator during the talks. This round of negotiations would prove to be the first in a series of negotiations mediated by Uganda in which the ICGLR provided for the overall institutional framing for the peace process. On 20 December 2012, the peace talks stalled after the Government rejected M23�s demand for a ceasefire before continuing negotiations. The round ended with only rules of procedure and a provisional agenda agreed. The first round of talks did not lead to any agreement and were postponed until 4 January 2013. In addition, in December 2012, as a result of the UN expert report, M23 was listed for sanctions and a number of M23 leaders subjected to individual sanctions, including travel bans and asset freezes.
third_party: International Conference for the Great Lakes Region, Uganda

description: Scheduled for 4 January 2013, formal peace talks mediated by Uganda did not resume because of a disagreement on the issue of the conclusion of a formal ceasefire, which the Congolese government had rejected. On 8 January 2013, at the start of a second round of peace negotiations, M23 declared a unilateral ceasefire. On 16 January 2013, the Government and M23 formally adopted the agenda of the talks and a framework agreement was signed. On 18 January 2013, the DRC government rejected the groups� �unconstitutional� demands such as the formation of a transitional government, for the results of elections in 2011 to be scrapped, for the resignation of all provincial governors, provincial parliament and senate members, and for the introduction of a federal system of government. On 21 January 2013, both delegations completed their respective evaluations of the implementation of the 23 March 2009 agreement. A document was produced by the conflict parties in February 2013 that evaluated the agreement between the Government of the DRC and the CNDP concluded on 23 March 2009. This document concluded that twenty-three of the thirty-five points of the agreement had not been implemented as they should have been implemented and that twelve points had not been implemented at all.
third_party: International Conference for the Great Lakes Region, Uganda

description: On 28 March 2013, the United Nations Security Council authorized the deployment of an intervention brigade in its resolution 2098 within MONUSCO to carry out targeted offensive operations, with or without the Congolese national army, against armed groups such as M23 that threaten peace in eastern DRC. On 20 May 2013, M23 attacked government forces in an effort to block the deployment of the intervention brigade. On 23 May, M23 declared a unilateral ceasefire. M23 declared another ceasefire on 30 August 2013. On 5 September 2013, the ICGLR demanded that negotiations between the Congolese government and M23 resume within three days and conclude within 14 days. Talks resumed in Kampala on 10 September 2013, but broke down again on 21 October 2013. However, soon after these talks, the M23 leadership called upon their field commanders to lay down arms and discuss political solutions to the conflict.
third_party: International Conference for the Great Lakes Region, Uganda

description: On 11 November 2013, the conflict parties negotiated with the aim to sign a political agreement to put an end to the conflict, but Kinshasa refused to sign a peace agreement following the military victory and preferred to issue a declaration. Kinshasa rejected a general amnesty for pardons on an individual basis. Only M23 fighters that were not guilty of war crimes could rejoin the Congolese Army or police.

Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni subsequently mediated between the Government of the DRC and the M23 rebels. This mediation effort led to three separate declarations, of which neither carried both parties� signature. These three declarations were combined in an overall declaration � referred to as the Nairobi Declaration � signed in Nairobi by Yoweri Museveni, President of Uganda and chair of ICGLR, and Joyce Banda, the President of Malawi and Chair of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) on 12 December 2013. The three separate documents pertained to M23�s commitment to end the rebellion to become a political party, a partial amnesty for M23 members for the rebellion, but not for international war crimes, and demobilization of former M23 members. On 12 February 2014, President Joseph Kabila announced an amnesty for former members of the defeated M23 rebel group. On 9 November 2014, the new M23 leader, Bertrand Bisimwa, accused Kinshasa of not upholding its side of the deal, while Kinshasa complained that the M23 had not participated in follow-up meetings in Kinshasa and Nairobi and stated that the M23 were probably not interested in demobilizing.
third_party: International Conference for the Great Lakes Region, Uganda

description: The Congolese government and M23 started confidential negotiations in September 2020. These negotiations lasted for 14 months, eventually breaking down in November 2021.

In late March 2022, M23 initiated a new offensive in North Kivu, engaging in combat with the Congolese national army and MONUSCO. The M23 spokesmen stated that the movement took up arms because they believed the conditions of the 2013 peace agreement were not being honoured by the Congolese government. The new offensive by M23 resulted in the displacement of several hundred thousand local inhabitants. The Rwandan backed the offensive by M23. In response, Angolan President Jo�o Louren�o, in his role as chair of the International Conference for the Great Lakes Region (ICGLR) and mandated by the African Union, facilitated discussions between the Government of the DRC and Rwanda to address the M23 rebellion. The meeting took place in Luanda on 6 July 2022, bringing together Congolese President F�lix Tshisekedi and Rwandan President Paul Kagame to establish a plan for reducing tensions and de-escalating the conflict. Burundian President Evariste Ndayishimiye and Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta were present as mediators. The regional leaders called on the M23 Movement to cease hostilities and withdraw from occupied territories. The M23 subsequently confirmed its adherence to a ceasefire and expressed willingness to engage in dialogue with the Congolese government.

In April 2022, the Congolese government and various armed groups attended a peace conference in Nairobi. The peace conference was held under the auspices of the East African Community (EAC). Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta acted as the EAC mediator during the peace conference. Several representatives of the Bisimwa faction of M23 attended the conference, but they were expelled from the negotiations due to the ongoing attacks conducted by M23 in North Kivu.

Another peace conference organized by the EAC was held in Nairobi in June 2022, but the M23 did not participate in this conference. However, Rwanda, whose troops were supporting the M23 and even fighting alongside the M23, did participate in the peace conference. Rwandan and Congolese government officials engaged in negotiations at the peace conference to end the M23 rebellion. The EAC subsequently called on M23 to retreat from Bunagana as a precondition for a ceasefire, but the M23 leadership refused.

Rwandan President Paul Kagame and Congolese President F�lix Tshisekedi held a meeting on 6 July 2022. According to the Congolese side, the presidents agreed upon a ceasefire and the withdrawal of M23 from Congolese territory. However, instead of adhering to this agreement, the M23 rebels attacked Kanyabusoro and Rwanguba the next day.

On 20 and 21 July 2022, the Joint Permanent Commission of the DRC and Rwanda held a meeting in Luanda. Angola acted as a mediator at these talks, which were aimed at ending the M23 rebellion. The delegations from both countries, led by their respective Foreign Affairs Ministers, pledged to rebuild trust between them. They agreed to restart regular communication between their defence and security agencies and to organize meetings involving relevant institutions to review or renew existing bilateral agreements.

The intensity of the armed fighting was relatively low after the meeting between Rwanda and the DRC in Luanda in July, but fighting intensified again in late October 2022. In response, the Congolese government expelled the Rwandan ambassador from the country. Moreover, on 8 November, the Congolese National Assembly declared M23 a terrorist group and adopted a recommendation prohibiting negotiations. However, the Congolese government continued to negotiate with Rwandan counterparts. Rwanda supported the M23 and negotiated on its behalf. Indeed, in mid-November 2022, former President of Kenya Uhuru Kenyatta mediated between Rwanda and the DRC via telephone, convincing Rwanda to agree on an immediate ceasefire on behalf of M23.

On 23 November 2022, the Mini-Summit on Peace and Security in the Eastern Region of the DRC took place in Luanda, Angola. Hosted at the invitation of President Jo�o Manuel Gon�alves Louren�o of Angola, it aimed to address the ongoing dialogue between the DRC and Rwanda. Attended by President �variste Ndayishimiye of Burundi, President F�lix Tshisekedi of the DRC, and represented by Vincent Biruta, Rwanda participated in the discussions. The main objective was to establish a timetable for the implementation of priority actions for the cessation of hostilities and the withdrawal of the M23 from occupies Congolese localities.

A third peace conference organized by the EAC was held in Nairobi between 28 November 2022 and 6 December 2022. The M23 did not participate in this conference, but Rwandan and Congolese government officials again engaged in negotiations to end the M23 rebellion. Former President of Kenya Uhuru Kenyatta acted as the chief mediator at this peace conference.

On 12 January 2023, the president of Kenya Uhuru Kenyatta in his role as EAC mediator, held talks with representatives of the M23 rebel group in Mombasa. During the meeting, the M23 agreed to a ceasefire and committed to withdrawing their forces from the areas they had occupied by 15 January. Despite this promise, the M23 resumed their offensive operations and continued to expand their control over territories in Masisi and Rutshuru. In response, the Heads of State from the East African Community issued a call for an immediate ceasefire from all involved parties at an extraordinary summit held in Bujumbura on 4 February 2022.

Lawrence Kanyuka, the spokesperson of M23, announced a ceasefire to take effect on 7 March 2023. The ceasefire was aimed at preparing the ground for discussions between the M23 leadership and Angolan President Joao Lourenco, which took place in Luanda in the same month.

On 25 July 2016, a delegation was sent to Kamuina Nsapu to negotiate with Mpandi. This delegation was led by provincial minister of the interior, Simon Pierre Tshibuyi Kayembe. Tshibuyi�s report emphasized that Mpandi was upset that the provincial authorities had not acted on his request for official recognition of his customary title. He also rejected the notion that he was forming a militia.

On 8 August 2016, Mpandi and his forces attacked the police buildings in Tshimbulu. On 10 August 2017, another delegation arrived in Kananga, this time composed from the national association of customary chiefs, but this round of negotiations also failed. Immediately following this round, a prominent Congolese politician in the Kasai region �variste Boshab gave Mpandi an ultimatum: surrender or face a government attack. On 12 August 2016, Jean-Pierre Mpandi was killed by government soldiers. The governor publicly announced Mpandi�s death and his body was brought to Kananga.

From 18 to 21 September 2016, the Congolese government led a peace conference in Kananga with 800 government officials, traditional leaders from Kamuina Nspau, and representatives from the region. By the end of the conference, a peace agreement was signed.

Following Mpandi�s death, the Kamuina Nsapu intensified attacks on state targets. On 27 January 2017, the rebels protested a visit from Prime Minister Samy Badibanga and sought the removal of governor Alex Kande. In addition, the demands shifted to national issues in late February 2017, namely the stepping down of Joseph Kabila as president. On 12 March 2017, the Interior Minister Emmanuel Ramazani Shadari, whose delegation included opposition members of parliament, held talks with the Kamuina Nsapu�s family. A peace agreement between Mpandi�s family and the government was signed. On 16 March 2017, the parliamentarians published some recommendations, including the appointment of a new provincial administration and measures to manage conflicts with the customary authorities. On 17 March 2017, the government announced a less far-reaching compromise, including the burial of the Kamuina Nsapu, measures on detainees, and an agreement on the procedure to select Jacques Kabeya Ntumba as the new chief. In January 2019, following the election of Felix Tshisekedi, a group of Kamuina Nsapu leaders along with 100 soldiers surrendered to the Congolese government. Although more than a thousand surrendered eventually, some proved dissatisfied with the Tshisekedi government and fighting in the area reignited.

At the Tunis summit, Julius Nyerere was endorsed by the OAU and the UN to initiate negotiations and conclude a peace agreement between the Burundian conflict parties. Nyerere refused to be an official representative of the UN and the OAU, preferring instead a �freelancing� approach. Nyerere conducted discussions with political parties in Mwanza, Tanzania, in May 1996.

Nyerere mediated another round of negotiations in Mwanza in early June 1996. On 25 June 1996, a regional summit on Burundi was convened in Arusha. With the support of the UN and the OAU, Nyerere secured President Ntibantunganya�s agreement to foreign intervention in Burundi. The plan was to deploy a regional military force. However, Nyerere did not succeed in convincing the Burundian military about the planned action, as the country�s armed forces vehemently opposed any foreign military intervention. Nyerere blamed the military for breakdown of the preliminary talks in June 1996 and subsequently threatened the military leaders to use force against them. More specifically, Nyerere told the army leaders: �The time for you to run this country is over. [�] You�ll not solve the problem by military intervention, but you must not rule out military intervention. If there is an eruption of killings there, the international community must not sit again with its hands folded, as we did in Rwanda.� Nyerere also stated that the �Burundian leaders have to stick to the Arusha initiative. If they don�t then we will be talking about a peace enforcement mission and we don�t want to do that yet.� On 25 July 1996, a military coup took place, which brought former President Pierre Buyoya to power. In response to the coup, a meeting was held between the regional leaders within five days of the military�s seizure of power. The leaders of Tanzania, Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda, Zaire, and Ethiopia agreed to impose sanctions on Burundi, issuing a list of specific demands that the Government of Burundi had to meet before the sanctions would be lifted, including to unconditionally undertake negotiations and reinstitute constitutional order.

Nyerere�s mediation efforts concentrated on making the government accept negotiations without conditions. However, Nyerere appeared to lose credibility and confidence among the conflict parties, mainly due to the ineffectiveness of his initiative to impose economic sanctions on Burundi after the 1996 coup as an instrument for bringing the parties closer to agreement. Prenegotiations between the conflict, mediated by Nyerere, took place in Arusha in August 1997, but the Government withdrew from discussions when it was clear that the embargo towards Burundi would not be completely revoked. Nyerere was also accused of being pro-Hutu. As a response, Nyerere offered to resign if the regional leaders decided that his efforts were impeding the peace process.

In spite of some dissatisfaction with Nyerere as a mediator, the regional heads of state decided that Nyerere should continue to mediate at a summit in Arusha on 4 September 1997. The OAU Secretary-General, Salim Ahmed Salim, attended the meetings that Nyerere held with the Government. The UN also organised joint conferences, which were aimed at supporting a dialogue between the warring parties.
Between March and April 1998, Nyerere held separate talks with all the conflict parties to prepare for comprehensive peace talks. All parties agreed to negotiations without conditions by May.

Accordingly, comprehensive talks facilitated by Nyerere began in Arusha, Tanzania, in June 1998. Although the parties which participated announced on 20 June 1998 their agreement to suspend the hostilities by 20 July and begin peace talks, the Government of Burundi almost immediately distanced itself from the agreement.
In October 1998, a new round of talks were held in Arusha.

In January 1999, the sanctions imposed against Burundi by the countries in the region were lifted. This created some momentum and the Arusha commissions continued their work in mid-March 1999. In early July 1999, a fifth round of negotiations took place. However, little progress was made.

In September, Nyerere�s health worsened and the Arusha process was suspended. However, the main negotiating parties met in the Tanzanian capital the same month, and good progress was reported. A degree of consensus on the integration of rebel forces into the military and on Buyoya�s transition programme was reached. Nyerere died in October, after which the regional heads of state unanimously endorsed Nelson Mandela as the new mediator at the Eighth Arusha regional summit on Burundi on 1 December 1999. Point 11 of the joint communique of this summit states that �The Regional Summit urged all the parties to the Burundi conflict including the Government of Burundi to genuinely extend maximum co-operation to the new Facilitator so as to enable him accomplish his mission.�

The Arusha multiparty talks continued during 2000, with Nelson Mandela as a new mediator. He mediated a first round of negotiations on 21 February. Key issues, such as the leadership of the transition, the future electoral system, and the equal ethnic representation of the armed forces were discussed but not agreed on. Mandela had strong support from the UN Security Council, the European Union and the Regional Peace Initiative in his efforts to bring the 19 parties together.
third_party: Nelson Mandela, South Africa, UN, OAU, Regional peace initiative (members: Burundi, DR Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia)

description: From early 2000 onwards, simultaneously to the Arusha talks, South African Deputy President Jacob Zuma engaged in shuttle diplomacy with the objective to secure a ceasefire, but without success.
The eighth round of Arusha negotiations started on 27 March. The talks focused on the issue of army integration, despite the continued absence of the CNDD-FDD and the Palipehutu-FNL.
third_party: Nelson Mandela, South Africa, UN, OAU, Regional peace initiative (members: Burundi, DR Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia)

description: During talks in July 2000, the parties mainly discussed who should lead the transition, the nature of the electoral system and how to achieve a ceasefire. However, no agreements could be made by the parties on the main issues.
third_party: Nelson Mandela, South Africa, UN, OAU, Regional peace initiative (members: Burundi, DR Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia)

description: A further round of negotiations was planned for August, prior to which Mandela conducted a series of bilateral discussions with the heads of party delegations at Arusha, to persuade them to commit themselves to signing an accord. To increase the pressure, Mandela invited a number of Heads of State, including the US President Bill Clinton, and other senior international political figures to the August discussions. On the 28 August 2000, a peace agreement was signed: the Arusha Peace and Reconciliation Agreement for Burundi. The agreement outlined several key provisions. Firstly, it established a ceasefire and required all troops to either remain in their current positions or be stationed in designated sites, where they would await demobilization or integration into the new armed forces. To monitor and supervise the ceasefire, a joint ceasefire commission was established, consisting of government delegates, representatives from the warring parties, as well as members from the UN, the OAU, and the Regional Peace Initiative for Burundi. The parties also agreed on the reform of the armed forces, with a 50-50 ethnic quota, ensuring equal representation of Hutus and Tutsis. The agreement included provisions for a pre-transition and transition period, followed by democratic elections. It was determined that a Senate would be elected based on ethnic representation to maintain balance in higher levels of government. Procedures for the assembly and the senate were agreed upon to prevent any single political or ethnic group from dominating the political system. Additionally, an Implementation Verification Commission was established to oversee and supervise the implementation of the agreement's provisions. The transitional period would conclude with elections for the National Assembly, Presidency, and Senate. The agreement also included a general amnesty for individuals who did not commit crimes against humanity or crimes related to the genocide. Furthermore, provisions were made for the repatriation of refugees and displaced persons, along with extensive reconstruction programs aimed at economic and social development.
third_party: Nelson Mandela, South Africa, UN, OAU, Regional peace initiative (members: Burundi, DR Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia)
agreement_name: Arusha Peace and Reconciliation Agreement for Burundi

description: On 27 and 28 February 2001, a further round of discussions arranged by Mandela was held in Arusha. The aim was to resolve the main remaining issues of disagreement. The regional Heads of States attended the meeting.

Accordingly, comprehensive talks facilitated by Nyerere began in Arusha, Tanzania, in June 1998. Although the participating parties announced on 20 June 1998 their agreement to suspend the hostilities by 20 July and begin peace talks, the Government almost immediately distanced itself from the agreement.

A degree of consensus on the integration of rebel forces into the military and on Buyoya�s transition programme was reached.

Nyerere died in October, after which the regional heads of state unanimously endorsed Nelson Mandela as the new mediator at the Eight Arusha regional summit on Burundi on 1 December 1999. Point 11 of the joint communique of this summit states that �The Regional Summit urged all the parties to the Burundi conflict including the Government of Burundi to genuinely extend maximum co-operation to the new Facilitator so as to enable him accomplish his mission.� Furthermore, the Regional Summit underscored the importance of urgently concluding the negotiations and called upon all the parties to �accelerate the momentum of the Burundi Peace Negotiations until the conclusion of a final peace agreement that will ensure lasting peace, genuine democracy and security for all.� Mandela adopted a more urgent and outspoken approach from the outset.
