This round of negotiations led to the signing of the �Declaration of Principles� on 5 July 2005, after more than three weeks of negotiating. The declaration included provisions for refugees to return home and new security arrangements. It also committed the signatories to respect the different ethnic and religious groups in Sudan and work towards an equitable distribution of national wealth.
A sixth round of AU-sponsored peace talks began in September. Yet, these negotiations were plagued by rebel divisions and violence on the ground. The sixth round ended 20 October 2005.

The seventh and final round of talks mediated by the AU started in Abuja on 29 November 2005. From the start of the seventh round of talks, the pressure on the conflict parties to sign a peace agreement steadily increased. The Western governments funding the peace process warned the parties that funding for the peace process could dry up in the absence of progress during the talks. The meetings of the seventh round of negotiations were held at different locations, but finished again in Abuja. The negotiations took place within three categories: power sharing, wealth sharing, and security arrangements. On the basis of the bilateral consultations and plenary sessions on these three categories which had been ongoing for more than five months, the AU mediation team submitted to the parties a draft peace agreement for the parties to sign in late April 2006. The rebel parties requested three more weeks to review the draft peace agreement, but this request was rejected. Instead, a number of high-profile diplomats arrived on 2 May 2006 in order to force a breakthrough in the negotiations. US Deputy Secretary of State Robert Zoellick and British Secretary of State for International Development Hilary Benn took over the mediation process in this final stage of the seventh round of the Abuja peace talks. Only two 48-hour extensions to the talks� deadline were subsequently allowed. The US mediation team promised the rebel leaders that if they signed the Darfur Peace Agreement (DPA), the US would guarantee its implementation. To back-up this promise, Zoellick carried personal letters with him from President George W. Bush assuring the rebel leaders of the US�s commitment to the DPA. In addition, the UN Security Council had imposed an arms embargo on all non-governmental entities operating in Darfur in July 2004. This sanctions regime was strengthened with the adoption of resolution 1591 in March 2005, which expanded the scope of arms embargo to also include all the parties to the N�djamena Ceasefire Agreement and any other belligerents, as well as imposed a travel ban and assets freeze on individuals designated by the UN Sanctions Committee. In spite of the pressure put on the conflict parties to sign the peace agreement, the JEM and the SLM/A refused to sign the agreement, leaving the SLM/A faction led by Minni Minnawi as the only rebel party that signed the DPA on 5 May 2006.

The Organization of the Islamic Conference (OIC) mediate a round of indirect negotiations between Chad and Sudan in late January 2006. This round of negotiations, which involved an OIC envoy shuttling between the parties, was aimed at ending the military support both countries were simultaneously providing to each other�s rebel groups. This round of negotiations aimed at ending military support was held in parallel to the seventh and final round of talks of the Abuja peace processes, which was held between 29 November 2005 and 5 May 2006.

On 8 February 2006, the African Union hosted a mini-summit in Tripoli, which was aimed at improving relations between Chad and Sudan and ending military support both countries were providing to each other�s rebel groups. At this summit, Chad and Sudan signed an agreement which stipulated that each country would refrain from using each other�s territory for hostile activity directed against the other and prohibited each country from accepting rebels from the other. However, the agreement between Chad and Sudan concluded in February 2006 did not hold. A Sudan-supported attack by the FUCD on Chad�s capital took place on 13 April 2006. This round of negotiations aimed at ending military support was held in parallel to the seventh and final round of talks of the Abuja peace processes, which was held between 29 November 2005 and 5 May 2006.

On 16 April 2006, Libyan foreign minister made a brief visit to Chad and a Libyan envoy met with the Sudanese President on 17 April. These shuttle talks were aimed at ending the military support Sudan and Chad were providing to each other�s rebel groups. This round of negotiations aimed at ending military support was held in parallel to the seventh and final round of talks of the Abuja peace processes, which was held between 29 November 2005 and 5 May 2006.

From the signing of the DPA on 5 May 2006 onwards, AU mediators Alex de Waal and Sam Ibok met with SLM/A leader Abdul Wahid several times a day to get clarity on his objections to the DPA. They encouraged him to write to Salim Ahmed Salim a letter in which he could specify on what was needed in order for him to sign the DPA. In his letter send to Salim on 10 May, Abdul Wahid proposed to conclude a �supplementary agreement� to the DPA, demanding greater representation at the legislature and executive bodies of Darfur, as well as a larger compensation fund for Darfur. However, Salim knew that the chief government negotiator, Majzoub El Khalifa, would reject this option, instead insisting that Abdul Wahid had to sign the DPA first, after which some of the remaining issues could be negotiated. Consequently, on 13 May 2006, Salim replied to Wahid that the AU could not re-open negotiations on the DPA, but was willing to support the conflict parties in implementing the agreement. Sam Ibok subsequently tried to persuade Wahid that the AU�s insistence on implementation rather than concluding a supplementary agreement would still allow Wahid to get what he wanted. Ibok�s effort to persuade Wahid did not work. Wahid kept insisting on a supplementary agreement. The AU Peace and Security Council decided on 16 May 2006 that the non-signatory groups would have another two weeks to sign the DPA. A final mediation attempt was launched by the EU during the last week of May 2006, but Abdul Wahid in the end did not show up for negotiations. Instead, he flew to Asmara, Eritrea, at the invitation of JEM leader Khalil Ibrahim to discuss the founding of a rebel alliance.

The leaders of Sudan and Eritrea met in Khartoum on 12 June 2006. This was the first meeting between the two leaders in more than five years. The leaders discussed the prospects for peace in Sudan, but also agreed to end support for the armed opposition in each other's countries. While there were some talks on ending military support to the armed opposition groups in Darfur, the SLM/A did not engage in peace talks with the government between 2007 and 2011 in spite of some joint UN/AU mediation effort. In February 2007, a joint UN/AU mediation effort was initiated, headed by Jan Eliasson and Salim Ahmed Salim, who respectively represented the UN and the AU. The SLM/A faction led by Minni Minnawi lost power and the movement was now led by Abdul Wahid. The SLM/A refused to attend the UN/AU organised negotiations in Sirtre, Libya. Hence, they were not involved in any negotiations with the Government of Sudan in 2007, although the SLM/A leadership did consult with the UN/AU negotiation team. In the beginning of 2008, the joint UN/AU mediation effort continued. Yet, no substantial progress was made. As a result, Jan Eliasson and Salim Ahmed Salim resigned in July 2008, after which Djibril Bassol� assumed the role of chief mediator, the former foreign minister of Burkina Faso. In addition to the joint UN/AU initiative, Qatar conducted some effort to initiate negotiations. However, no real negotiations took place. Abdul Wahid, the leader of SLM/A, demanded that security had to be provided for the civilians in Darfur before he would enter negotiations. Djibril Bassol� continued his efforts as the chief mediator of the joint UN/AU mediation effort in 2009. SLM/A leader Abdul Wahid refused to leave his exile in Paris. Consequently, no negotiations were held between the SPLM/A and the Government of Sudan in 2009. In 2010, Djibril Bassol� continued his efforts as the chief mediator of the joint UN/AU mediation effort. In contrast to several of the other rebel groups based in Darfur, the SLM/A and its leader Abdul Wahid refused to negotiate with the Government of Sudan until the security situation in Darfur would improve. In November 2011, the SLM/A � together with the Sudan People�s Liberation Movement-North (SPLM/A-North), the Justice and Equality Movement (JEM), and the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army led by Minni Minnawi (SLM/A-MM) � formed a new rebel coalition: the Sudanese Revolutionary Army (SRF). The rebel groups declared to collectively fight to topple the Sudanese Government. All peace efforts involving the SLM/A from this point onwards took place under the banner of the SRF and are therefore listed under that dyad.
During the seventh AU Summit in Gambia, Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi arranged a tripartite meeting with Sudan and Chad on 2 and 3 July 2006.

As a follow up to the meeting at the AU summit, Chadian foreign minister went to Khartoum for several days in mid-July 2006 and met with the Sudanese government to discuss political and security matters as well as the possibility of resuming diplomatic relations. After the Chadian foreign minister's visit to Sudan in mid-July, which was an outcome of the Libyan initiative during the AU Summit, the two countries continued their negotiations that led to a peace deal. On 26 July 2006, Chad and Sudan signed a peace deal agreeing to take steps to normalize their relations and end military support to each other�s rebel groups. The agreement called for a joint military commission to monitor the border and forbade the presence of rebel elements in both countries.

On 8 August 2006, many African leaders, including the President of Sudan, were present in Ndjamena to attend President Deby's inauguration ceremony after his re-election as president. Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi persuaded Sudanese and Chadian Presidents to hold an impromptu mini-summit after the inauguration ceremony. The mini-summit was also attended by the head of the AU, and the leaders of the Republic of Congo and Gabon. At the end of this impromptu mini-summit, Chad and Sudan agreed to end military support to each other�s rebel groups, as well as immediately restore diplomatic ties by reopening their common border and respective embassies.
third_party: Libya, AU, Republic of Congo, Gabon

description: Khartoum's new national unity government, particularly Foreign Minister Lam Akol, attempted to normalize relations with Eritrea to end Eritrea�s military support to Darfurian rebel groups. In October 2006, an Eritrean delegation visited Khartoum for talks with a Sudanese government delegation led by Akol.
In December 2006, a Sudanese delegation led by Vice-President Salva Kiir visited Asmara for talks on normalizing relations and ending Eritrea�s military support to Darfurian rebel groups.

On 10 April 2007, Libyan leader President Muammar al-Gaddafi dispatched Abdel Salem Triki, his personal envoy, as part of a mediation effort between Chad and Sudan aimed at ending the military support both countries were providing to each other�s rebel groups. Eritrea joined the effort as well, and the two sides met with both mediators that same day. On 12 April 2007, Libyan mediators reached an agreement with Chad and Sudan to allow Eritrean and Libyan military observers to monitor the border region. On 17 April 2007, the mediation effort by Libya and Eritrea led to the creation of a joint military and high security committee.

On 3 May 2007, Saudi Arabia hosted another meeting between President al-Bashir and Chadian President Deby in which the leaders of state agreed on ending military support to each other�s rebel groups, as well as on measures to prevent cross-border attacks by these rebel groups.

On 27 January 2008, Sudan and Chad participated in a summit of African countries that was convened to try and defuse tensions between Chad and Sudan and resolve the crisis in Darfur through persuading Chad to stop supporting Darfurian rebel groups. In addition to Gabon in the role of chief mediator, Libya, Egypt, Eritrea, Senegal, and Mauritania also attended this summit.
third_party: Gabon, Libya, Egypt, Eritrea, Senegal, Mauritania

description: On 6 March 2008, Senegal announced that it had been conducting shuttle diplomacy between Chad and Sudan. Senegal also announced that the two sides had consented in principle to sign an agreement at an upcoming meeting of the Organization of the Islamic Conference (OIC) to be held in Dakar. Despite Chad's and Sudan's pledge to sign the agreement, both sides continued to accuse each other of supporting the other's rebel groups and questioning each other's prospective commitment to the agreement, blaming each other for breaking all previous agreements. Nevertheless, Chad and Sudan signed the Dakar Agreement on 13 March 2008 at the OIC summit. Both sides agreed to stop supporting each other's armed opposition movements and to stop allowing their respective territories to be used as bases from which rebels could launch border incursions. The agreement failed to end the crisis however, as Chad accused Sudan of sending Chadian rebels to attack only hours before the agreement was signed. This confirmed the fears expressed by many analysts, as well as Chadian and Sudanese opposition movements, that the agreement would not be signed in good faith and would have little effect on the overall conflict. What is more, the JEM was able to attack Khartoum on 10 May 2008. In response, Sudan immediately cut diplomatic ties with Chad. Chadian rebels started an offensive in early June 2008. Chadian government troops had repelled this offensive by 18 June 2008.

Libya met with Chad and Sudan in late July 2008 and made proposals that were accepted by both sides, including ending military support to rebel groups, the restoration and normalization of diplomatic relations, and resumption of cooperation between the two countries.

On 2 May 2009, Chad and Sudan signed a new reconciliation agreement in Doha in Qatar. This agreement stipulated an end to the military support Sudan was providing to the UFR and Chad was providing to the SLM/A and JEM. However, the next day, on 3 May 2009, the UFR launched a new major raid on Chadian territory.

In August 2009, Sudanese and Chadian government representatives held exploratory talks in Tripoli under Libyan auspices. These talks were aimed at ending the military support Chad was providing to the SLM/A and JEM and ending the military support Sudan was providing to the UFR.

Chadian President D�by sent his foreign minister to Khartoum in December 2009 in order to start a process of rapprochement between the two countries. Sudanese President Al-Bashir responded by sending his adviser, Ghazi Salah al-Din al-Atabani, to N�Djamena to discuss the details of a security pact and in order to start a process of rapprochement between the two countries. The efforts of the Chadian foreign minister and the Sudanese presidential adviser paved the way for the conclusion of an agreement on 25 December 2009. The agreement committed Sudan and Chad to previous protocols that addressed controlling the border between the two countries and end military support to each other�s rebel groups.
On 15 January 2010, another agreement was signed by Chad and Sudan, this time mediated by Libyan President Muammar Gaddafi.

Qatar began another mediation effort in early 2010, meeting with Sudan in late February and then Chad in early March. This mediation effort was led by Qatarese Emir Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani. The agreement between Chad and Sudan concluded on 25 December 2009 was confirmed on 9 February 2010, when Chadian President Idriss Deby visited Sudan and met with Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir. During the visit, Chad and Sudan signed a formal agreement in which they agreed that neither would support rebel organizations targeting the other. While there were some talks on ending military support to the armed opposition groups in Darfur, the SLM/A did not engage in peace talks with the government between 2007 and 2011 in spite of some joint UN/AU mediation effort. In February 2007, a joint UN/AU mediation effort was initiated, headed by Jan Eliasson and Salim Ahmed Salim, who respectively represented the UN and the AU. The SLM/A faction led by Minni Minnawi lost power and the movement was now led by Abdul Wahid. The SLM/A refused to attend the UN/AU organised negotiations in Sirtre, Libya. Hence, they were not involved in any negotiations with the Government of Sudan in 2007, although the SLM/A leadership did consult with the UN/AU negotiation team. In the beginning of 2008, the joint UN/AU mediation effort continued. Yet, no substantial progress was made. As a result, Jan Eliasson and Salim Ahmed Salim resigned in July 2008, after which Djibril Bassol� assumed the role of chief mediator, the former foreign minister of Burkina Faso. In addition to the joint UN/AU initiative, Qatar conducted some effort to initiate negotiations. However, no real negotiations took place. Abdul Wahid, the leader of SLM/A, demanded that security had to be provided for the civilians in Darfur before he would enter negotiations. Djibril Bassol� continued his efforts as the chief mediator of the joint UN/AU mediation effort in 2009. SLM/A leader Abdul Wahid refused to leave his exile in Paris. Consequently, no negotiations were held between the SPLM/A and the Government of Sudan in 2009. In 2010, Djibril Bassol� continued his efforts as the chief mediator of the joint UN/AU mediation effort. In contrast to several of the other rebel groups based in Darfur, the SLM/A and its leader Abdul Wahid refused to negotiate with the Government of Sudan until the security situation in Darfur would improve. In November 2011, the SLM/A � together with the Sudan People�s Liberation Movement-North (SPLM/A-North), the Justice and Equality Movement (JEM), and the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army led by Minni Minnawi (SLM/A-MM) � formed a new rebel coalition: the Sudanese Revolutionary Army (SRF). The rebel groups declared to collectively fight to topple the Sudanese Government. All peace efforts involving the SLM/A from this point onwards took place under the banner of the SRF and are therefore listed under that dyad.

The SLM/A-MM was part of the seventh and final round of the Darfur peace talks mediated by the AU. This round started in Abuja on 29 November 2005. The negotiations took place within three categories: power sharing, wealth sharing, and security arrangements. On the basis of the bilateral consultations and plenary sessions on these three categories, which had been ongoing for more than five months, the AU mediation team submitted to the parties a draft peace agreement for the parties to sign in late April 2006. The rebel parties requested three more weeks to review the draft peace agreement, but this request was rejected. Instead, a number of high-profile diplomats arrived on 2 May 2006 in order to force a breakthrough in the negotiations. US Deputy Secretary of State Robert Zoellick and British Secretary of State for International Development Hilary Benn took over the mediation process in this final stage of the seventh round of the Abuja peace talks. Only two 48-hour extensions to the talks� deadline were subsequently allowed. The US mediation team promised the rebel leaders that if they signed the Darfur Peace Agreement (DPA), the US would guarantee its implementation. To back-up this promise, Zoellick carried personal letters with him from President George W. Bush assuring the rebel leaders of the US�s commitment to the DPA. In addition, the UN Security Council had imposed an arms embargo on all non-governmental entities operating in Darfur in July 2004. This sanctions regime was strengthened with the adoption of resolution 1591 in March 2005, which expanded the scope of arms embargo to also include all the parties to the N�djamena Ceasefire Agreement and any other belligerents, as well as imposed a travel ban and assets freeze on individuals designated by the UN Sanctions Committee. Zoellick also threatened Minni Minawi with possible UN sanctions or an International Criminal Court indictment if he did not sign the agreement. In addition, Zoellick threatened that an attack on Minawi�s forces in South Darfur by Sudanese troops would be executed if he failed to sign the DPA. Despite these threats, Minawi still had reservations when the final stretch of the Abuja talks started on 4 May, which were hosted by Nigerian President Olusegun Obasanjo at his state house in Abuja. During a break of the plenary peace talks on 4 May, Zoellick allegedly told Minawi privately, �Have no doubt where I stand. I am a good friend and I am a fearsome enemy.� Minawi signed the DPA the next day, on 5 May 2006. However, the JEM and the SLM/A led by Abdul Wahid refused to sign the agreement, leaving the SLM/A led by Minni Minnawi as the only rebel party that signed the peace agreement. The agreement included a comprehensive ceasefire agreement, reaffirming the N�Dajema Agreement of April 2004. It aimed to integrate the forces of SLM/A and JEM into Sudan's security institutions, with 4000 soldiers joining the armed forces, 1000 joining the police, and 3000 receiving professional and educational training for civilian reintegration. The agreement covered both political representation and the future status of Darfur. In the political aspect, it focused on power-sharing at the national and state levels, establishing the Transitional Darfur Regional Authority (TDRA), and ensuring fair representation of Darfurians in Sudanese affairs. During the interim period until elections, SLM/A and JEM would be represented at the national level by a Senior Assistant to the President, chosen from a list of nominees provided by these two movements.
UNAMID mediated between Sudanese Vice-President Ali Osman Taha and Minni Minawi in al-Fasher in September 2008. The mediation effort led to an agreement that committed both sides to the DPA.

In August 2009, UNAMID convened a Round Table meeting of the Parties and Partners of the DPA on the implementation of the DPA. The meeting was chaired by UNAMID Joint Special representative (JSR), Mr. Rodolphe Adada.

In November 2011, the SLM/A-MM � together with the Sudan People�s Liberation Movement-North (SPLM/A-North), the Justice and Equality Movement (JEM), and the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A) � formed a new rebel coalition: the Sudanese Revolutionary Army (SRF). The rebel groups declared to collectively fight to topple the Sudanese Government. Accordingly, any peace efforts only involving the SLM/A-MM from this point onwards are listed here, while peace efforts involving the SRF are listed under that dyad. The JEM and the SLM/A-MM on the one side and the government on the other side held informal discussions, mediated by the AU, in the Ethiopian town of Debre Zeit on 23 January 2016. These talks did not take place under the SRF banner.
A round of secret negotiations between the SLFA, referred to as the SLM/A-Unity at that time, and the Sudanese government in February 2011 led to the signing of a ceasefire on 15 February 2011.

On 7 October 2010, the President of South Sudan Salva Kiir Mayardit issued a pardon for George Athor and his men. George Athor responded by declaring a ceasefire and indicating his willingness to negotiate: �We have accepted the amnesty as a step in the right direction. We have announced also on our side a ceasefire and we have sent a small delegation to Juba so that we can prepare for negotiations.� Negotiations started in October 2010, but no agreement was reached in 2010.
Another round of negotiations starting in early January 2011 led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 5 January 2011. The Episcopal Church of Sudan moderated these talks.

In early June 2011, the AU High-Level Implementation Panel on Sudan (AUHIP) led by former South African president Thabo Mbeki initiated mediated negotiations to end the fighting. SPLM/A-North chairman Malik Agar negotiated for the SPLM/A-North and Ali Nafi for the Sudanese government. This mediation effort led to the signing of a ceasefire on 16 June 2011.

Although the conflict parties had signed the ceasefire agreement and were engaged in negotiations, fighting continued throughout June 2011. Negotiations in Addis Ababa, mediated by Mbeki, led to the conclusion of an agreement for comprehensive political and security arrangements in the border states of Blue Nile and South Kordofan on 28 June 2011, referred to as the Addis Ababa Agreement. This agreement was signed by Presidential Bashir�s aide Nafie Ali Nafie and SPLM/A-North leader Malik Agar. The peace agreement stipulated that a joint political committee would be formed, tasked to resolve the issue of governance in the contested states. The agreement also includes a ceasefire and provisions with regard to disarmament. In spite of the conclusion of this agreement, fighting continued. On 7 July 2011, the government backed out of the agreement with SPLM/A-North.

By the end of August 2011, Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi mediated talks between President Bashir and Agar. However, the talks did not produce any tangible results. The government announced a unilateral ceasefire for South Kordofan on 23 August 2011, but fighting continued. In November 2011, the SPLM/A-North � together with the Justice and Equality Movement (JEM), the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A), and the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army led by Minni Minnawi (SLM/A-MM) � formed a new rebel coalition: the Sudanese Revolutionary Army (SRF). The rebel groups declared to collectively fight to topple the Sudanese Government. Accordingly, any peace efforts only involving the SPLM/A-North from this point onwards are listed here, while peace efforts involving the SRF are listed under that dyad.

In 2012, the African Union (AU) Peace and Security Council mandated the African Union�s High Level Implementation Panel (AUHIP) led by former South African President Thabo Mbeki to mediate between the Sudanese government and the Sudanese armed opposition. A first round of negotiations mediated by the AUHIP took solely place between the SPLM/A-North and the Government of the Sudan in Addis Ababa on 26 July 2012. These negotiations focused on political and security issues underlying the continuing conflict in Blue Nile and Southern Kordofan States. The talks were conducted indirectly via the AUHIP, with both sides setting preconditions for engaging in direct talks. The Government of the Sudan insisted that the SPLM/A-North would disengage from South Sudan, as well made it clear that it opposed the return to the Agreement of 28 June 2011. On 16 September 2012, the AUHIP submitted a draft proposal for a political solution based on the Agreement of 28 June 2011, reflecting views of the conflict parties and the �changed circumstances and current realities on the ground.� Neither party accepted this agreement.
The AU mediated a round of peace talks between the SPLM-North and the Sudanese government on a political solution to the conflict from 23 to 27 April 2013, but these talks ended without agreement.

At the start of a round of negotiations on 25 February 2014, the Sudanese government accepted the draft framework agreement put forward by AUHIP to cease hostilities and deliver humanitarian aid to civilians in Sudan�s �Two Areas� of Blue Nile and South Kordofan, but negotiations between the SPLM/A-N and the government were suspended on 2 March 2014 because the conflict parties disagreed on how the resolve the conflict.
The AU mediated another round of negotiations between the SPLM-North and the Government of Sudan on 22 April 2014, but this round of negotiations also failed.

On 7 July 2015, Secretary�General of the SPLM/A-N Yasir Arman stated that the SPLM/A-North would not continue peace negotiations from where the last round of AU-led peace talks stopped. On 3 August 2015, President Omar al-Bashir met with AU chief mediator Thabo Mbeki to discuss peace in Blue Nile and South Kordofan states. The meeting between Mbeki and al-Bashir did not lead to a new date for the resumption of negotiations on the two areas. The Government of Sudan and the SPLM-North engaged in direct negotiations mediated by the AU between 19 and 23 November 2015. This round of negotiations focused on security arrangements.

In December 2015, the Sudanese government and SPLM/A-North expressed to the AUHIP their willingness to sign a comprehensive agreement. An informal round of peace talks was subsequently held in Addis Ababa from 16 to 18 December 2015. However, this round of talks did not lead to an agreement, as the parties disagreed about whether the SPLM/A-North should be allowed to keep its troops. The conflict parties and the mediation team agreed to resume discussions in January 2016. A government attack on the SPLM/A-North in Aroum on 23 January 2016 led SPLM/A-North officials to publicly question the government�s commitment to establishing peace. In late 2016, the AUHIP called upon the SPLM/A-North to review their positions on the talks on the Two Areas. The SPLM/A-N insisted on a provision allowing humanitarian access through Asosa in Ethiopia, but the Sudanese government rejected such a provision. In March 2017, the SPLM/A-North split into two factions, resulting in several clashes. While there were many calls to engage in negotiations throughout 2017 and 2018, the conflict parties did not engage in peace talks. The split was a result of long-simmering ethnic and political�military tensions within the SPLM/A-North in Blue Nile. While the Uduk, Berta, and Burun had made up the majority of the SPLM/A�s 10th Division during war between the SPLM/A and the Sudanese government between 1983 and 2005, members of the Ingessana tribe assumed increasingly more power within the rebel group from 2012 onwards. This led to widespread dissatisfaction among the non-Ingessana tribes. Tensions were temporarily put on hold due to intense fighting between the SPLM/A-North and government forces throughout 2015-2016, but following a unilateral ceasefire issued by the Sudanese government on 18 June 2016 tensions escalated. In March 2017, SPLM/A-North deputy chairman Abdelaziz al-Hilu publicly released a resignation letter. Abdelaziz al-Hilu accused Agar of not fully representing the entire SPLM/A-North movement in the peace process led by the AU, particularly with regard to the issue of self-determination of the Nuba Mountains. Al-Hilu�s letter essentially forced the members of the SPLM/A-North to choose between himself and chairman Malik Agar of the Ingessana tribe. The Nuba Mountains Liberation Council (NMLC) subsequently passed resolutions that removed Arman as the SPLM/A-North�s lead negotiator with the AUHIP, as well as put the NMLC in power of both South Kordofan and Blue Nile. Moreover, many senior non-Ingessana leaders began to publicly voice support for al-Hilu and the NMLC. In April 2017, almost all of the non-Ingessana Blue Nile Liberation Council (BNLC) members declared their support for the NMLC decision to dismiss Arman as the SPLM/A-North AUHIP lead negotiator. Accordingly, although the deputy chairman Abdelaziz al-Hilu broke away from the rebel group led by chairman Malik Agar, the UCDP codes the SPLM/A-North led by Malik Agar (SPLM/A-N-MA) as the splinter faction because the dismissal of Agar was endorsed by the NMLC and most of the BNLC.

Preparations for official negotiations between the SPLM/A-North and the Sudanese government continued in spite of this split. SPLM/A-North representatives met with mediators from the AUHIP in Addis Ababa in late August 2017 to prepare for formal negotiations.

In late September 2017, Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) special envoy for Sudan, Lesane Johannes, discussed details for the resumption of formal peace talks between the SPLM-North and the government with Sudanese Presidential adviser Ibrahim Mahmoud. However, these pre-negotiations did not lead to formal negotiations between the SPLM-North and the Government of Sudan.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: On 30 January 2018, the SPLM/A-North announced an extension of the unilateral ceasefire at South Kordofan and Blue Nile areas for four months starting on 1 February 2018. Pre-negotiations resumed in Addis Ababa on 3 February 2018, but the talks broke down on 4 February because the government refused the SPLM/A-North�s demand for greater autonomy.

Another round of exploratory peace talks was held between the Sudanese government and the SPLM/A-North in Addis Ababa and Johannesburg between 19 and 30 October 2018, but both sides continued to disagree on the terms of resuming official peace talks.

Nevertheless, on 3 November 2018, the Sudanese government agreed to the proposal of SPLM/A-North to appoint South Sudanese President Salva Kiir as the chief mediator of future negotiations. AU representatives met with different factions of the SPLM/A-North in Addis Ababa on 17 and 26 November respectively to prepare for official peace talks.

Following a massive popular uprising, President Omar al-Bashir was ousted from power in April 2019. The transitional government that was put in place continued to negotiate with the SPLM/A-North. Both the SRF and the SPLM/A-North participated in negotiations in Juba in September 2019, which led to the signing of the Juba Declaration for Confidence Building Procedures and the Preparation for Negotiation on 11 September 2019.
agreement_name: Juba Declaration for Confidence Building Procedures and the Preparation for Negotiation

description: A second round of negotiations in Juba between 14 and 21 October led to the signing of a political declaration between the transitional Government and SRF, but the SPLM/A refused to sign this declaration.

A third round of negotiations in Juba took place between 10 December and early January 2020. This round of negotiations consisted of five separate tracks covering Darfur, the Two Areas of Blue Nile and Southern Kordofan, and central, east and north Sudan. While the SPLM/A-North led by Malik Agar signed a ceasefire with the Sudanese government during these peace talks, the SPLM/A-North refused to sign an agreement.

Negotiations between the Sudanese government and the SPLM/A-N led by al-Hilu on the Two Areas resumed on 21 January 2020 after a two week suspension. The talks would last until 14 February 2020. The talks saw advancement on six key points of a framework agreement However, there was still contention over al-Hilu's demands for establishing a secular state in South Kordofan and Nuba Mountains, as well as for self-determination in the Blue Nile region.

From 2 to 5 September 2020, Abdallah Hamok and Abdel Aziz of the SPLM/A-N held a meeting in Addis Ababa to discuss how they can include the separation between religion and politics in the peace process, in a way to satisfy the positions of the two sides. The negotiations led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 3 September 2020. The agreement stated that �Sudan is a multi-racial, multi-ethnic, multi-religious and multi-cultural society. Full recognition and accommodation of these diversities must be affirmed. [...] The state shall not establish an official religion. No citizen shall be discriminated against based on their religion.�

On 28 March 2021, Sudan�s government and SPLM-N concluded an agreement in Juba. The �declaration of principles� outlines priorities including the unification of armed forces and the establishment of a democratic, secular state with freedom of religion.

On 25 May 2021, discussions between the Government of Sudan and the SPLM/ A-N took place in Juba. The talks were mediated by South Sudan, but were also attended by the Special Representative of the UN.

The declaration of principles signed between Sudan and the SPLM-North in March paved the way for peace talks in Juba on 15 June 2021. The talks focused on reaching a framework peace deal to address Sudan's internal conflicts. Unlike the SPLM/A-North-MA that was part of the SRF, the SPLM/A-North did not sign an agreement.

In 2012, the African Union (AU) Peace and Security Council mandated the African Union�s High Level Implementation Panel (AUHIP) led by former South African President Thabo Mbeki to mediate between the Government of Sudan and the SRF. Indirect negotiations between the SRF and the Government of Sudan were mediated by the AUHIP. These negotiations led to the signing of an agreement to allow humanitarian assistance in rebel-controlled areas of South Kordofan and Blue Nile on 4 August 2012. Yet, the agreement did not address the conflict issues.

On 27 January 2014, President al-Bashir announced the creation of a national dialogue to address Sudan�s political instability. On 31 January 2014, Sudan and Chad agreed to send special envoys to meet and encourage Darfur rebel groups that refused to sign a peace agreement with the Sudanese government, to engage in peace talks. Several meetings were held throughout 2014 aimed at initiating a formal peace process between the Sudanese government and the SRF. The joint AU-UN Special Envoy, Mohamed Ibn Chambas, met with the SRF leadership in Kampala on 12 February 2014 to discuss the possibility of formal negotiations. To prepare for the national dialogue, the leaders of the SRF and the Umma Party, a Sudanese opposition party, decided to form an alliance at a meeting in Paris on 8 August 2014. They signed the Paris Declaration, calling for national dialogue.

On 1 September 2014, leaders of the SRF met with the chairman of the AU High Level Implementation Panel (AUHIP), Thabo Mbeki, in Addis Ababa to discuss the format of future negotiations. On the basis of this discussion, the African Union�s Peace and Security Council issued Communique 456 on 15 September 2014, which stipulated that government�s talks with the Darfuris and SPLM-North should be conducted in a synchronized manner, referred to as the �one process, two tracks� approach. This effectively focused the negotiations on reaching a ceasefire in Darfur and South Kordofan and Blue Nile, while simultaneously implementing the national dialogue that al-Bashir had announced in January 2014. The alliance between the SRF and the Umma Party forged in Paris in August was reiterated and extended to include other traditional political party leaders and civil society representatives on 3 December 2014, with the signing of the Sudan Call.

A round of AUHIP-mediated negotiations between the SRF and the Sudanese government started in Addis Abba on 12 November 2014. This round of negotiations consisted of two track. The SLM/A-MM and the JEM negotiated with the government on a ceasefire in Darfur (the SLM/A boycotted this round of talks with the government), while the SPLM/A-North negotiated on a ceasefire in the two areas. This round of negotiations ended with the AU mediation team announcing on 9 December 2014 that the government delegation and the SPLM-North failed to agree on a ceasefire. The reason for this deadlock was that the SPLM/A-North had insisted on a comprehensive solution for Sudan entirely, while Khartoum insisted on a cessation of hostilities for the Blue Nile and South Kordofan only. What is more, the Sudanese government had already initiated what it referred to as a deceive summer campaign in South Kordofan on 1 December 2014. The government�s military summer campaign in South Kordofan continued until mid-January 2015 and was extended to Blue Nile in February 2015. In addition, the Sudanese government refused to attend a preparatory meeting for the national dialogue that the AUHIP had wanted to facilitate in Addis Ababa on 29 and 30 March 2015. This effectively ended the SRF�s participation in the national dialogue.

On 24 August 2015, the Sudanese government announced a two-month ceasefire with the SRF, which could be extended if progress is made in negotiations. The ceasefire applied to both Darfur and the Blue Nile and South Kordofan. The SRF agreed to the ceasefire and also indicated it was ready resume negotiations with the government without further delay. On 14 September 2015, the SRF leadership announced that it was ready to sign a six-month cessation of hostilities agreement with the Sudanese government. The SRF further called on the government to �engage in a comprehensive dialogue.� However, no direct negotiations between the Sudanese government and the SRF were held in 2015.
In January 2016, the SRF leadership met with the Qatari deputy prime minister in Paris to discuss the possibility of official peace negotiations.
In addition, informal negotiations between the SRF and the Sudanese government were held in Berlin between 22 and 24 January 2016.

Another round of negotiations between the Sudanese government and the SRF took place in Addis Ababa between 19 and 21 March 2016. Based on this round of talks, the AU mediators drew up a roadmap agreement for the conflict parties� consideration. The Sudanese government signed the roadmap agreement on 21 March 2016, but the SRF refused to sign the roadmap. Subsequent third party efforts were aimed at making the SRF accept the roadmap.

On 17 June 2016, Donald Booth, the US special envoy to Sudan and South Sudan, met with representatives of the JEM and the SLM/A-MM, as well as representatives from the National Umma Party, in Addis Ababa. Booth tried to persuade the JEM and the SLM/A-MM representatives to sign the roadmap agreement.

Another round of negotiations between the Government of Sudan and the SRF in Addis Abba in early August 2016 made some progress. On 8 August 2016, the SRF accepted and signed the roadmap agreement put forward by the AU on 21 March 2016. The roadmap stipulates a ceasefire, as well as outlined a framework for negotiations on the conflicts in Darfur and the two areas of Southern Kordofan and Blue Nile.

The conflict parties started another round of AU-mediated negotiations in mid-August 2016. These negotiations were supposed to focus on implementing the roadmap agreement, but the AUHIP declared the collapse of Darfur and Two Areas Ceasefire talks on 15 August 2016, blaming the JEM and the SLM/A-MM for introducing new demands on issues that had previously been agreed and which contradicted the roadmap agreement.

Several rounds of informal negotiations were held in Berlin throughout 2018. The German Foreign Ministry and the Berghof Foundation acted as mediators at these exploratory talks. These negotiations were aimed at initiating formal negotiations between the SRF alliance and the Sudanese government. Representatives of the JEM and the SLM/A-MM, representing the SRF, and the Sudanese government conducted pre-negotiations in Berlin on 16 and 17 April 2018. The Joint Special Representative for Darfur and representatives of Norway, the UK, and the US also participated in these pre-negotiations.
third_party: Germany, Berghof Foundation, Norway, UK, US

description: Another such round of negotiations was held in Berlin on 28 June 2018, this time with involvement from the SPLM/A-North as well. Both of these informal negotiations failed to reach an agreement on official negotiations.
third_party: Germany, Berghof Foundation, Norway, UK, US

description: Another round of negotiations in Berlin on 6 and 7 December 2018, attended by the JEM and the SLM/A-MM, representing the SRF, and the Sudanese government, led to the signing of a pre-negotiation agreement, committing the parties to resume official negotiations.
third_party: Germany, Berghof Foundation, Norway, UK, US

description: A third round of negotiations in Juba took place between 10 December 2019 and 14 February 2020. This round of negotiations consisted of five separate tracks covering Darfur, the Two Areas of Blue Nile and Southern Kordofan, and central, east and north Sudan. The talks between the Sudanese government and the SRF in the Darfur track led to the signing of a framework agreement on 28 December 2019.

Following a massive popular uprising, President Omar al-Bashir was ousted from power in April 2019. The transitional government that was put in place continued to negotiate with the SRF. Negotiations in Juba in September 2019 led to the signing of the Juba Declaration for Confidence Building Procedures and the Preparation for Negotiation on 11 September 2019.
agreement_name: Juba Declaration for Confidence Building Procedures and the Preparation for Negotiation

description: A second round of negotiations in Juba between 14 and 21 October 2019 led to the signing of a political declaration between the transitional Government and SRF.

On 24 January 2020, the Sudanese government and the SPLM-N led by Malik Agar, which was part of the SRF, signed a framework peace agreement in Juba. This agreement was concluded ahead of an effort to conclude a comprehensive peace deal with various armed groups in mid-February 2020.

On 21 February 2020, the transitional government and eastern Sudan groups signed an agreement to address the development issues in the region and ensure their political participation in the federal government. The deal was reached within the framework of the Juba hosted negotiations between the government and the armed and political groups members of the SRF.

On 10 June 2020, the head of the Sudanese government negotiating team Mohamed Haman Daglo �Hemetti� and the Sudanese rebel negotiators took part in a teleconference session of talks on national issues. The parties all committed to sign a peace agreement on 20 June. The parties agreed on the entire document except for the question of power-sharing, which they agreed would be tackled later. However, no peace agreement was concluded on 20 June 2020.

On 25 June 2020, a South Sudanese delegation led by chairman Tut Galuak visited Khartoum for two days. The South Sudanese delegation mediated between the SRF delegation � including Yasir Arman (SPLM-North-MA), Ahmed Tugud (JEM), and Mohamed Bashir (SLM/A-MM) � and the Sudanese government delegation to address unresolved issues in the peace negotiations.

The Sudanese government and the SRF started another round of negotiations in Juba in August 2020. The negotiated were mediated by South Sudan. A critical issue during the negotiations was that of demobilization and reintegration. On 15 August 2020, the Sudanese government delegation discussed the DDR process with the SPLM-N led by Malik Agar, who was part of the SRF alliance. The conflict parties reached two agreements during the negotiations. The first agreement was a security agreement to integrate the SRF into the Sudanese Armed Forces and was reached on 17 August 2020. Ahmed El Omda, a member of the SPLM/A-N initialed the peace document on behalf of the entire SRF. Talks on political issues subsequently continued. Another agreement was reached on 31 August 2020. This agreement addressed critical topics such as security, land rights, transitional justice, the distribution of power, and the resettlement of individuals displaced by conflict. It also outlined plans for disbanding rebel groups and assimilating their members into the national military. The negotiations involved the leaders of both Sudan and South Sudan. One day before the second agreement was reached, Sudanese Prime Minister Abdalla Hamdok and several ministers flew to Juba to have a private meeting with South Sudan President Salva Kiir. The signing ceremony of the Juba Peace Agreement (JPA) took place on 3 October 2020. The transitional Government of Sudan, the SRF, the SLM/MM and the SPLM-North-MA signed the peace agreement in Juba. The Juba Peace Agreement stipulated the integration of the rebels into the security forces, as well as well as grant the rebel groups political representation and economic and land rights. In addition, the agreement committed the Sudanese government to a 10-year plan to invest $750 million to develop southern and western regions and to guarantee the return for displaced people.

From 5 to 6 September 2021, UNITAMS convened a technical consultative meeting of the Permanent Ceasefire Committee of the Darfur Permanent Ceasefire and Final Security Arrangement of the Juba Agreement for Peace in Sudan. The meeting discussed the implementation modalities of the Permanent Ceasefire Committee and its subsidiary mechanisms. It included participants who were members of these entities and stakeholders.
On 17 March 2014, President Omar al-Bashir sent a delegation to Darfur to negotiate with Musa Hilal.

In late March 2014, Chad hosted peace talks between the conflict parties in the Chadian border town of Um Jaras, but this did not lead to an agreement. By late 2014, Hilal was running his own administration in North Darfur, with his troops controlling Saraf Umra town, Kutum town, Kabkabiya town, and the El Waha area. To this purpose, Hilal set up a council composed of native leaders to perform administrative and judicial functions in these areas. A tax system with various fees for vehicles travelling in their areas of control was also set up. SARC also profited from artisan gold mining in Jabal Amer.

In response to armed clashes between the government forces and the SARC, President Omar al-Bashir sent a delegation to Darfur to negotiate with Musa Hilal on 12 January 2015, which led to the conclusion of an agreement and the reintegration of SARC fighters into the Border Guard. SARC even supported the Sudanese government during the elections that were held in this year. However, the Sudanese government had strong financial incentives to take back control of the area controlled by SARC. A UN Panel of Experts estimated that the SARC earned around $54 million a year from taxing and gold mining. Clashes resumed again in 2016 following efforts by the government forces to disarm SARC fighters. Following a clash between the SARC and government forces, Hilal was arrested in November 2017.
In April 2018, Omda Hasoun Mangali negotiated with the Sudanese government on behalf of SARC to release Musa Hilal, but Mangali was kidnapped by unknown gunmen while in Khartoum for negotiations.

Between 2 and 4 June 2016, US and Chadian diplomats held shuttle talks with representatives from the SLMJ and Sudanese government representatives in Chad. The shuttle talks were aimed at finding a way in which SLMJ could join the Doha Document for Peace in Darfur (DDPD).

Between 6 and 12 May 2023, delegates from the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the RSF met directly for the first time in Jeddah in Saudi Arabia. Saudi Arabia and the US acted as mediators. The talks were described as pre-negotiation talks.

During negotiations in May 2023, the conflict parties signed the Treaty of Jeddah on 20 May 2023, committing to a short-term ceasefire, as well as vowing to ensure the safe passage of civilians, protect relief workers, and prohibit the use of civilians as human shield. The agreement included a remote monitoring mechanism executed by the US. US secretary of state Antony Blinken stated in this regard: �If the ceasefire is violated, we'll know, and we will hold violators accountable through our sanctions and other tools at our disposal.�

Between 26 October and 3 December 2023, the SAF and RSF engaged in another round of negotiations in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia. Saudi Arabia and the US acted as mediators. The talks ended without any of the side wanting to commit to a ceasefire.

On 13 November 2023, President William Ruto of Kenya welcomed President Gen. Abdel-Fattah Al Burhan of the Transitional Sovereignty Council of Sudan in Nairobi. The leaders engaged in bilateral discussions focusing on the current security situation in Sudan and the broader region. Additionally, they assessed the possibility of IGAD organizing a peace summit. IGAD hosted this peace summit in early December 2023. One outcome of this peace summit was that Hemedti and al-Burhan agreed to meet in person at some point in the future. A meeting between the two leaders, mediated by IGAD, was scheduled for the last week of December 2023, but this meeting was postponed because of �technical reasons�.

The Ugandan Minister for the North, Betty Bigombe, initiated contacts with the LRA in mid-1993. This was done through Kony�s close friend Yusuf Okwonga Adek, a northerner residing in Gulu, who delivered a letter from Bigombe to Kony. Adek continued his work as an intermediary between June and November 1993, shuttling between the conflict parties and laying the groundwork for future talks. This led to the first face-to-face peace meeting ever between government representatives and the LRA rebels on 25 November 1993. The talks were held at Pagik in the Gulu district. The Government delegation was led by Bigombe and included Acholi elders, the Director of Military Intelligence Lieutenant Colonel Fred Toolit, and Colonel Samuel Wasswa. Joseph Kony did not attend the meeting, but sent a tape-recorded message. The parties agreed that they would stop fighting. The LRA promised they would gather in a gazetted area where they would be able to move freely. During the talks, the LRA negotiators demanded an amnesty for all their fighters. A LRA Commander, Cirilo Jurukadri Odego, emphasised that in order for talks to succeed �old wounds should not be reopened.� Bigombe responded by assuring the LRA delegation that the LRA fighters would all be covered by the already existing general amnesty. However, in the weeks after the meeting at Pagik, Bigombe came under increasing pressure. For instance, Brigadier Mugume and Lieutenant Colonel Toolit accused Bigombe of having �caved in too much� to LRA demands. Moreover, Kony kept on refusing to show up for peace talks.

On 10 January 1994, the negotiators met again in Pagik, but the parties were unable to agree security arrangement for the initiation of official negotiations. Although Kony still refused to participate in peace talks, he showed up at Pagik the next day to have a one-to-one meeting with Bigombe.

A third round of pre-negotiations was held at Lakwatimer Primary School on 24 January 1994, but Kony did not show up for this meeting. Relations between the Government and Uganda and the LRA started to deteriorate from this meeting onwards, with the LRA representatives accusing the negotiators of the government side behaving arrogantly. An example of this behaviour might be that Brigadier Mugume told LRA commander Otti-Lagony that he �thought you had come here to negotiate your surrender.� In spite of these misgivings, negotiations continued.

A ceasefire agreement was concluded at a peace meeting at Tegot-Atto on 2 February 1994. Yet, soon after this meeting, the national Ugandan army claimed that LRA fighters had made contact with the Government of Sudan. This was unacceptable to the government delegation and on 6 February 1994, President Museveni announced that the LRA had a week to surrender, otherwise the government would defeat them. The LRA did not take up this ultimatum, after which most of its troops crossed the border into Sudan, only to return in a few months conducting attacks with more sophisticated weapons and landmines. Fighting continued during the rest of 1994.

Libya mediated a round of negotiations between Sudanese and Ugandan representatives in Tripoli in early April 1995. The LRA and the SPLM/A were excluded from the talks. The negotiations focused on Uganda ending military support to the SPLM/A and Sudan ending military support to the LRA. The Sudanese and Ugandan representatives signed an agreement in Tripoli in Libya on 5 April 1995, which called for the end of military assistance to rebel groups in both countries. The agreement stipulated, among others, a �commitment to noninterference in either side's internal affairs, pledging to refrain from providing aid to any opposing gang in either country and barring the use of either side�s territory for attacks against the other side.� However, the agreement failed. Uganda severed diplomatic relations with Sudan on 23 April 1995, and expelled eleven Sudanese diplomats from the country on 24 April 1995. Sudanese troops and Ugandan troops clashed near the border on 29 October 1995.

President Museveni stated in a speech on 3 June 1996 amnesty would be given to ordinary fighters of the LRA, but not to the LRA leaders. In September 1996, several members of the LRA called for peace talks. A �Kacoke Madit� � which is a big meeting of the Acholi � was subsequently convened in London during October and November 1996. This meeting brought together Acholi communities from Uganda, the diaspora, the Government of Uganda, and the LRA. The Ugandan Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Martin Aliker, stated that he had been mandated by the government to talk to the LRA on its behalf. The LRA was represented by James Alfred Obita, the Secretary for External Affairs and Mobilisation. Both parties expressed their desire to initiate peace negotiations.

After the Kacoke Madit in London ended, the Community of Sant�Egidio contacted its organisers to discuss the possibility of mediation. An initial meeting between the Community of Sant�Egidio and LRA representatives was held in London in November 1996.

Iran mediated negotiations between the countries between September and November 1996. The LRA and the SPLM/A were excluded from the talks. The negotiations focused on Uganda ending military support to the SPLM/A and Sudan ending military support to the LRA. Sudanese and Ugandan representatives signed a draft peace agreement in Tehran in November 1996.

The LRA leadership made another call for peace talks in April 1997. The Community of Sant�Egidio mediated secret pre-negotiations in Rome in May 1997, which James Alfred Obita attended on behalf of the LRA. It was agreed that official negotiations would be initiated, in which the LRA would send two representatives of its military wing and two representatives of its political wing.
The LRA leadership approved mediated negotiations during another round of pre-negotiations mediated by the Community of Sant�Egidio in Khartoum in May 1997.

The Community of Sant�Egidio organised another round of talks with the LRA in Khartoum in June 1997 in order to prepare for official negotiations with the Government of Uganda. After this meeting, the Government of Uganda informed the Community of Sant�Egidio that they were ready to meet the LRA delegation. Moreover, in October 1997, President Museveni accepted the idea of granting LRA leader Kony amnesty. On 22 November 1997, President Museveni replied to a letter of James Alfred Obita, in which agreed to mediation, writing that �our delegation is ready to discuss with your representatives anywhere and we are ready to reach a peaceful settlement within the confines of the 1995 Constitution of the Republic of Uganda.�

On 12 December 1997, the Community of Sant�Egidio mediated negotiations between the conflict parties in Rome. Andrea Riccardi and Matteo Zuppi acted as the chief mediators. The Government of Uganda was represented by Amama Mbabazi, the State Minister of Foreign Affairs, and David Pulkol, Director of the External Security Organisation. Charles Laroker and James Alfred Obita negotiated on behalf of the LRA. No agreement was reached, but the conflict parties agreed to meet again in January 1998.

During the talks in Rome in mid-December 1997, the parties had scheduled another round of negotiations on 18 January 1998. While the Government of Uganda attended this meeting, the LRA delegation never showed up. In mid-May 1998, the district military commanders of the Ugandan states of Gulu and Kitgum entered into secrete negotiations with eight representatives of the LRA. The secret talks were hosted by Kenya in Nairobi and lasted until early July 1998. Taking progress made during these secret talks into account, Museveni announced on 21 July 1998 that he was ready to accept a ceasefire, on the condition that the LRA fighters would remain in defined bases and not move around. In addition, later in 1998, the Kacoke Madit � which is an umbrella organisation of Acholi parliamentarians, religious and opinion leaders � offered to organise roundtable talks between the conflict parties, but the LRA refused this offer.

The Community of Sant�Egidio succeeded in initiating talks between the conflict parties on 13 May 1999. This led to a promise by President Museveni that an amnesty to all LRA rebels would be granted and that Joseph Kony would get a cabinet post should he be democratically elected.

In August 1999, the Carter Center mediated a round of negotiations between Sudan and Uganda. The LRA and the SPLM/A were excluded from the talks. The negotiations focused on Uganda ending military support to the SPLM/A and Sudan ending military support to the LRA.

In early December 1999, Jimmy Carter, representing the Carter Center, mediated negotiations between Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir and Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni in Nairobi in Kenya. The leaders of Sudan and Uganda signed an eleven-point agreement in Nairobi on 8 December 1999, which provided, among others, for the resumption of diplomatic relations and the end to military assistance to rebel groups. The Nairobi Agreement stipulated an end to the support of Uganda to the SPLM/A and the support of Sudan to the LRA. More specifically, in the agreement the conflict parties pledged that �1. Each of us will respect the sovereignty and territorial integrity of each other, in accordance with the charters of the United Nations and the Organization for African Unity. 2. We renounce the use of force to resolve differences, and will take steps to prevent any hostile acts against each other. 3. We will make every effort to disband and disarm terrorist groups and to prevent any acts of terrorism or hostile actions that might originate in our territory that might endanger the security of the other nation. 4. We agree not to harbor, sponsor, or give military or logistical support to any rebel groups, opposition groups, or hostile elements from each other�s territories.�

In January 2000, the US Department for African Affairs and the Carter Centre mediated talks between the conflict parties. Not much is known about this mediation effort, other than that Jimmy Carter acted as the chief mediator.

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. Negotiations aimed at implementing the Nairobi Agreement therefore continued. The first Nairobi Agreement implementation meeting between Uganda and Sudan was held in Nairobi in January 2000.

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. Negotiations aimed at implementing the Nairobi Agreement therefore continued. A second Nairobi Agreement implementation meeting was held in Nairobi in March 2000. Following a bilateral meeting on 20 March 2000, Uganda and Sudan issued a joint statement to the United Nations Security Council, emphasizing their commitment to �further foster and maintain security across their common border.�

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. Negotiations aimed at implementing the Nairobi Agreement therefore continued. The Carter Center hosted a joint ministerial meeting in Atlanta on 18 and 19 July 2000 where the Atlanta Joint Action Plan for the Nairobi Agreement was drawn up.

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. The foreign ministers of Sudan and Uganda attended a round of talks mediated by Egypt and Libya in Kampala on 26 and 27 September 2000. It was announced following this round of negotiations that Sudan had agreed to move the LRA 1,000 miles north of the Ugandan border. Both sides also agreed to a partial restoration of relations.

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. The Carter Center mediated a Nairobi Agreement implementation meeting at the ministerial level of the governments of Uganda and Sudan in Khartoum on 6-7 October.

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. A Nairobi Agreement implementation meeting was held in Nairobi in November 2000.

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. Representatives of Sudan and Uganda engaged in negotiations mediated by the Carter Center in Nairobi on 19 and 21 January 2001.

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. A Nairobi Agreement implementation meeting was held in Nairobi on 3 June 2001.

In June 2001, the Gulu District Chairman Walter Ochorra met a local LRA leader of the Gulu district, Oneu Kandulu. The talks concerned the peaceful resolution of the insurgency, the LRA abductions of civilians, and an amnesty for LRA rebels.

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. A Nairobi Agreement implementation meeting was held in Nairobi in November 2001. This meeting was successful. Sudan committed to fully ending its support for the LRA and it allowed Uganda to enter its territory to pursue the LRA in Operation Iron Fist in February 2002.

Following a meeting in Kampala on 13 March 2002, Ugandan and Sudanese government officials issued a statement on the improvement of relations between the two countries. The statement reconfirmed the commitments and obligations of both Governments under the Nairobi Agreement of December 1999.

On 23 February 2003, the LRA declared an immediate ceasefire to pave the way for peace talks. The Government of Uganda accepted this ceasefire in early March 2003. Yet, the Government of Uganda reneged on the ceasefire in late April.

In August 2004, officials from a British-based charity called Africa Relief Trust tried to initiate talks between the LRA and the Government of Uganda, after having been in contact with the rebels since December 2003. Head of the team was Joseph Ocwet, Uganda�s ambassador to the African Union. On 30 August 2004, the Africa Relief Trust mediation team met with three LRA commanders at Abuga village, conducting talks to prepare the ground for formal negotiations. However, the initiative came to an abrupt halt when questions of the authenticity of the LRA commanders arose and the national army attacked a group of rebels that had reportedly been a part of the process, killing a LRA emissary. The LRA came under military pressure during the second half of 2004 when the Government of Sudan struck a deal with the Ugandan Government, allowing Ugandan forces to move further into Sudan to attack LRA forces. The LRA was severely weakened by November 2004. Accordingly, LRA spokesman Sam Kolo announced that the LRA was willing to enter negotiations. The Ugandan government also wished to negotiate, which led President Museveni to request Betty Bigombe, a former minister in the Ugandan Government, to put together a peace team, consisting of international observers of non-African nationalities, UN representatives, Acholi elders, and members of parliament. The team initially conducted informal talks with rebel officers, attempting to find out what the rebel�s demands were. As this became increasingly clear, Bigombe arranged a meeting between LRA officers and Acholi elders, which was one of the rebel�s pre-conditions for holding formal peace talks. All these efforts eventually led to a first direct meeting between the rebels and a government delegation, led by Ugandan Minister of Internal Affairs, Ruhakana Rugunda, on 29 December 2004. The conflict parties reached agreement on a total ceasefire and a signing ceremony was scheduled for 31 December 2004. However, the mediation team failed to finalise the accord, which resulted in the indefinite postponement of the signing ceremony. In addition to having representatives in Bigombe�s mediation team, Norway, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom financially sponsored the peace initiative.

Bigombe tried to make the conflict parties sign an improved draft of the ceasefire proposal during negotiations in January 2005, but the conflict parties did not sign this agreement. The conflict escalated again in February 2005. After Bigombe communicated with Kony over the phone in April 2005, Kony attempted to set up a face-to-face meeting with Bigombe. Yet, this meeting never materialized due to logistical and security obstacles. In September 2005, Bigombe prepared a draft peace proposal, which President Museveni accepted as the starting point for further negotiations. However, the International Criminal Court (ICC) issued an arrest warrant for LRA�s top five leaders before Bigombe had a chance to deliver it to Kony. Nevertheless, after discussions with President Museveni, Bigombe indicated that the door was still open for negotiations and Bigombe stayed in contact with the rebels throughout the rest of the year. The old troika of engaged countries � Norway, the UK, and the Netherlands � was joined by the US in April 2005. The four countries supported the peace team with personnel and financial means. Moreover, in July 2005, in an unprecedented move, the countries issued a direct appeal to LRA to urgently re-establish contact with Bigombe. The message was broadcasted on radio throughout northern Uganda 18 times a day.

In 2006, a new peace process was imitated. Several third parties were involved in the peace process in Uganda at different levels and at different stages during the year. Pax Christi, a Catholic peace movement from the Netherlands, managed to establish channels for contact between the LRA and the Government of Uganda, thus initiating pre-negotiations. Pax Christi also approached vice-President of the autonomous Southern Sudan, Riek Machar, as a potential mediator for negotiations. Machar had offered the conflict parties to mediate as early as November 2005. Instrumental in these initial efforts of Pax Christi was Leonzio Angole Onek, a Sudanses Acholi and former colleague of Riek Machar, who was provided with financial and logistical support by Pax Christi to set up negotiations between the conflict parties. Moreover, Machar was in a good position to initiate negotiations. Determined to get the LRA out of South Sudan, Machar gave the LRA three options: an ultimatum to either leave Sudanese territory peacefully, accept mediation with the Government of Uganda, or face military action. The threat of military action against the LRA remained implicit throughout the Juba peace talks. After a round of pre-negotiations in May 2006, the conflict parties officially agreed to mediation by Riek Machar and it was decided that the negotiations would start in Juba on 14 July 2006.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, Netherlands, Switzerland, UN

description: Prior to the start of negotiations in Juba in July 2006, President Museveni announced that he guaranteed Joseph Kony�s safety if an agreement was signed. This announcement received widespread attention, since Kony and four of his deputies had been indicted by the International Criminal Court for crimes against humanity. At Juba, Machar was supported both by a mediation team within his vice-Presidential office and by a mediation group that included delegates of Pax Christi, the Netherlands, and Switzerland. Switzerland provided a professional negotiator that assisted Machar during the talks, while Pax Christi provided the LRA delegates with training in negotiating. The Community of Sant�Egidio, who had been invited by the LRA, also attended the negotiations. UN representatives from the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs and the Department of Political Affairs were also involved in the process to advice on issues related to the protection of internally displaced persons political aspects of the process respectively. The UN had initially been ambivalent regarding the Juba process being more supportive of the ICC position. Jan Egeland, the UN Emergency Relief Coordinator, faulted the Sudanese and Ugandan government for agreeing to talks to those indicted, stating that �Those who are indicted have been indicted because they are responsible for mass murder of the worst possible kind, and so those who are indicted should go and face justice in The Hague.� However, the UN became increasingly involved in the process over time and in October statements were made saying that the world body was firmly behind the process. The UN subsequently contributed 4.8 million US Dollars to sponsor the peace talks. In addition, in early December UN Secretary-general Kofi Annan named former Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano his special envoy for LRA-affected areas. Chissano was mandated to develop a cohesive policy approach among all external actors in the peace process and to liaise with the ICC on questions regarding the indicted leadership of LRA. Neither Kony nor his top commanders attended the talks at Juba. Instead, the LRA delegation consisted of 14 negotiators, who had been appointed by Kony. Almost all of these 14 negotiators were Acholis from the Diaspora. The negotiation teams at Juba soon managed to agree on the issues that needed to be addressed in order to resolve the armed conflict: the cessation of hostilities, comprehensive solutions addressing the underlying issues of the conflict, reconciliation and accountability, the conclusion of a formal ceasefire, and disarmament, demobilization and reintegration of the fighters. Yet, the parties were unable to agree in which order these issues needed to be addressed and talks were adjourned on 24 July. In the meantime, the two negotiation teams consulted with their seniors.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, Netherlands, Switzerland, UN

description: On 18 August, negotiations resumed. The focus in this round of talks was particularly on the cessation of hostilities and demobilisation. After eight days, on 26 August 2006, the parties signed a cessation of hostilities agreement. The Cessation of Hostilities Agreement, among others, called upon all rebels to assemble at two designation points in Southern Sudan within three weeks. These assembly points were to be supervised and protected by SPLM forces.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, Netherlands, Switzerland, UN

description: In late September 2006, the Juba process resumed for a third round of talks, but this time the talks focused on finding a comprehensive solution to the conflict. As the progress made during these talks stalled, Ugandan president Museveni flew in to meet the LRA negotiation team in October 2006. This did not produce any results. In addition, while many rebels had assembled in the two camps by the deadline, the LRA leadership did not turn up and rebels started to move away from the camps again. The two sides continued to accuse each other of violations of the truce during the rest of the year. On 1 November 2006 and later again on 16 December 2006, the two sides recommitted to their ceasefire.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, Netherlands, Switzerland, UN

description: In November 2006, Jan Egeland met LRA leader Joseph Kony in a mediation effort to support the Juba peace talks.

On 12 January 2007, three days before the Juba talks would resume, the LRA leadership announced that they withdrew from the peace process, stating that they would not resume talks unless Machar was replaced as the chief mediator and a new venue would be found. A plausible reason for this is that Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir had pledged to force the LRA out of Sudan. Efforts were aimed at getting the LRA back to the negotiation table during the following two months, in which UN Special Envoy Joaquim Chissano and Pax Christi played an instrumental role. In early March 2007, Chissano met Kony somewhere along the Congo-Sudan border in yet another round of pre-negotiations aimed at resuming official negotiations.

In a second visit in late March 2007, Rugunda, the government negotiator, accompanied Chissano, which resulted in the first face-to face meeting between Rugunda and Kony, paving the way for a resumption of peace talks at Juba.

In addition, Pax Christi hosted talks between an LRA delegation and a Government of Uganda delegation led by General Salim Saleh in Mombasa in early April 2007. Hizkias Assefa and Simon Simonse mediated the talks on behalf of Pax Christi.

In preparation of another round of peace talks between the LRA and Ugandan government, UN Special Envoy Joaquim Chissano mediated negotiations between the conflict parties between 14 and 16 April 2007. These negotiations led to a ceasefire agreement 16 April 2007. This agreement was based on a previous ceasefire from August 2006 and was set to last two months.

On 26 April, the Juba process resumed, leading to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 2 May 2007: the Agreement on Comprehensive Solutions. The agreement outlines comprehensive principles to tackle the persistent economic, political, and social challenges affecting the region of northern Uganda. It emphasizes the importance of promoting equal opportunities, fostering diversity within government institutions, revitalizing the North�s economic and educational infrastructure, and facilitating the resettlement of internally displaced persons. These crucial measures are identified as indispensable prerequisites to establish a lasting and sustainable peace in the region. Regional observers from Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo and South Africa were also present at the Juba talks in 2007, serving as informal mediators by promoting communication, confidence, and compromise.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa

description: After the conclusion of the Agreement on Comprehensive Solutions, talks focused on issues related to reconciliation and accountability.
