A round of negotiations in June 2007 led to the signing of the Agreement on Accountability and Reconciliation on 29 June 2007. This agreement addresses how the conflict parties aim to establish a viable national alternative to ICC indictments against five top-LRA leaders, including Kony. The agreement provided for the establishment of a domestic legal framework that would function as a substitute for the ICC prosecutions. This was complemented by alternative processes like traditional justice. Under the accord, rebel commanders accused of serious crimes were to face formal criminal and civil justice proceedings in courts, which could impose �alternative penalties and sanctions� to replace existing punitive measures. However, the specifics of these alternative penalties and sanctions were not specified. Additionally, the agreement stipulated that abuses by the national army were to be pursued in the criminal justice system. Although another round of negotiations was scheduled in August 2007, no other peace talks were held during the rest of 2007. However, on 1 November, a LRA delegation went on a historic first trip to Kampala, where it released a white dove as a symbolic gesture of peace. They then visited President Museveni and signed an addendum to the cessation of hostilities agreement that extended the pact for another three months. Martin Ojul, the LRA delegation leader, then led the group up to Gulu and appeared on a local radio station asking for forgiveness from the local population.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa

description: Two events resulted in uncertainty with regard to whether the Juba talks would continue in 2008. First, the LRA�s second in command, Vincent Otti had died in October 2007. Second, on 22 January 2008, LRA leader Joseph Kony sacked the head of LRA�s negotiating delegation, Martin Ojul, together with three others, accusing them of making money from the peace talks. Nevertheless, the Juba talks resumed on 30 January 2008 with the two sides extending the ceasefire the day before. The LRA team was now led by David Matsanga. Riek Machar continued to act as the chief mediator. In addition to the third parties already present in 2007, the US, the EU, Canada and Norway joined the talks. The conflict parties reached agreement on a number of issues. On 22 February 2008, the Implementation protocol to the Agreement on Comprehensive Solutions was signed. The protocol laid out the framework for the implementation of the Agreement on Comprehensive Solutions signed on 2 May 2007. According to the accord, the armed forces and security agencies were required to ensure that their recruitment and composition reflected the ethnic diversity of Uganda. Additionally, the agreement mandated the creation of an �Equal Opportunities Commission� shortly after the Final Peace Agreement�s signing. The primary responsibility of this commission was to investigate any regional or ethnic disparities and imbalances in government departments and institutions� participation. Furthermore, the agreement made provisions for the establishment of a �diaspora desk� within the Foreign Ministry. The purpose of this desk was to facilitate the repatriation and return of Ugandans residing abroad to their home country. On 23 February 2008, the Agreement on a Permanent ceasefire was signed. This agreement provided for an immediate truce, which was set to take effect 24 hours after the Final Peace Agreement's signing. As per the terms of the accord, all forces belonging to the LRA were required to be stationed within the Ri-Kwang-Ba assembly area, and a buffer zone surrounding it was to be respected. To monitor the cessation of hostilities, the existing Cessation of Hostilities Monitoring Team underwent transformation into a Ceasefire Monitoring Team. This new team consisted of five representatives from each of the parties involved in the agreement, five members from each of the AU observer countries participating in the peace talks, and a five-person liaison team from the UN. Additionally, it was specified that the Ceasefire Monitoring Team would be led by two senior officers from the SPLA. This arrangement aimed to ensure effective oversight and implementation of the ceasefire provisions outlined in the agreement. On 28 February 2008, the Agreement on Disarmament, Demobilisation and Reintegration was signed. This agreement established the Ceasefire Monitoring Team, which was created under the Agreement on a Permanent Ceasefire, with the primary responsibility of overseeing the disarmament and demobilization process. The accord specified that the Ceasefire Monitoring Team would develop a Disarmament Operations Plan, outlining the establishment of disarmament sites, among other details. Moreover, the Ceasefire Monitoring Team took on the task of facilitating the repatriation of ex-fighters from Ri-Kwan-Ba back to Uganda. The Government of Uganda was entrusted with the duty of identifying and preparing reception points for these returning individuals. Furthermore, the agreement granted former fighters the right to make a choice between joining the army or receiving reintegration support aimed at assisting them in their transition to civilian life. This provision aimed to offer these individuals the opportunity to pursue a path that best suited their aspirations and reintegration needs after leaving the armed forces. On 29 February 2008, the conflict parties signed the Agreement on Implementation and Monitoring Mechanisms. This agreement confirmed all the previous accords signed in the Juba process. It called for a transitional period of one month, commencing immediately after the Final Peace Agreement's signing, during which the Government of Uganda and the LRA were to prepare for the implementation of the Final Peace Agreement. As part of the accord, the parties agreed to develop an Implementation Schedule, which would be appended to the Final Peace Agreement, outlining all pertinent dates and timeframes for various actions and measures. Additionally, the Agreement on Implementation and Monitoring Mechanisms established an �Oversight Forum� responsible for overseeing and monitoring the implementation of the Final Peace Agreement. The forum would also offer advice and support to the parties and any relevant institutions created under the Final Peace Agreement. The Chief Mediator of the Juba process, Riek Machar, was designated as the chair of this forum, while the UN Secretary-General�s Special Envoy for LRA-affected areas, Joaquim Chissano, assumed the role of its spokesperson. Moreover, the agreement outlined the creation of a Joint Liaison Group, tasked with on-the-ground monitoring of the Final Peace Agreement's implementation in accordance with the Implementation Schedule. The Joint Liaison Group was further responsible for providing the Oversight Forum with progress reports on the implementation process.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa
agreement_name: Implementation protocol to the Agreement on Comprehensive Solutions, Agreement on a Permanent Ceasefire, Agreement on Disarmament, Demobilisation and Reintegration, Agreement on Implementation and Monitoring Mechanisms

description: After an agreement had been reached on these issues, the LRA team travelled to Joseph Kony�s base in Garamba National Park in early March for a new round of negotiations on the text of a proposed Final Peace Agreement before signing. The focus in the negotiations subsequently shifted to the provisions for a final ceasefire, followed by talks on disarmament, demobilization and reintegration. It is unclear whether Kony was briefed, but plans for the signing ceremony continued. On 3 March 2008, the LRA and Government of Uganda signed an agreement that included provisions for not only a ceasefire, but also disarmament and demobilization. On 10 April, all actors that had been involved in the Juba talks assembled at Ri-Kwangba to witness the signing of the final agreement. However, Kony did not show up, stating he wanted clarification on the issues of the Mato Oput (traditional judicial system) and the Special Division of the High Court. Kony stated he no longer trusted the mediators, claiming that they were in favour of the Government of Uganda. Kony also fired Matsanga, replacing him with James Obita. The legitimacy of LRA�s negotiation team was thus seriously hampered. This problem became even become worse when Matsanga reappeared in June 2008 and claimed to have been reinstated by Kony as the chief negotiator, which has remained unclear whether this was the case.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa

description: UN Secretary-General�s special envoy Joaquim Chissano worked to get the negotiations process back on track after Kony had failed to turn up for the signing ceremony on 10 April 2008. To this purpose, Chissano held a series of separate meetings with President Museveni and Kony between April and July 2008. While the LRA continued to request further mediated negotiations, Uganda�s president Museveni stated in July 2008 that his government would not hold further negotiations with Kony. Instead, the Government of Uganda would wait for Kony to sign the Final Peace Agreement. On 11 September 2008, Machar declared the peace process over. Another signing ceremony was prepared in November 2008, but Kony again failed to show up. The LRA called for a ceasefire in January, March, and June 2009. However, the LRA was only willing to resume peace talks provided that another mediator would lead the process and that talks would be held at another venue. In October 2009, Matsanga stated that talks should be held on �neutral ground� such as in Kenya or Tanzania. Matsanga also claimed that Kony would prefer Nigerian ex-president Olusegun Obasanjo to act as the chief mediator. Machar conducted yet a final attempt at restarting negotiations at Juba by the end of September 2009. Prior to Machar�s attempt, Chissano had made several attempts to find a credible negotiator of the LRA, but concluded that this was impossible and ended his role as Special Envoy to the Secretary-General on 29 May 2009. The Government of Uganda rejected calls for peace talks, regardless of the venue and chief mediator, stating that an agreement had already been reached and that the only thing missing was Kony�s signature on the final accord.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa

description: It was not until 1999 that negotiations between the conflict parties took place for the first time, though some one-sided peace initiatives took place before. In August 1997, President Museveni publicly stated that he was willing to pardon fighters from the ADF who turned themselves in. In October 1997, the ADF sent a list of preconditions for peace talks to President Museveni. These included power-sharing with the rebel groups, suspension of the country�s 1995 constitution that bans all political parties, and the release of all captured rebels. The Ugandan government did not respond to these demands. In May 1999, Roman Catholic leaders of the Ruwenzori region offered to mediate between the Ugandan Government and the ADF, but this offer was not accepted. In November 1999, the Chairman of the Ugandan district of Kasese, Yokas Mikande, and the Busongora South Minister of Parliament, Christopher Kibanzanga, held seven peace meetings with the commanders of the ADF in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. The talks concerned the possibility of peace in the Ruwenzovi region in western Uganda. The peace talks were the result of a letter sent by the ADF leadership to the Ugandan army saying that they were ready to stop fighting. Commenting on the letter, a senior army commander stated that the Government of Uganda was willing to negotiate with the ADF.

Throughout 2005, Ugandan government representatives attempted to convince the ADF rebels to embrace the amnesty law and return from their camps in the Democratic Republic of Congo. This was done via radio messages and the distribution of leaflets. In September 2005, plans were revealed for a meeting to be held between the government and the ADF in the near future. However, the meeting never took place. In early December 2005, Adams Lwanga, in charge of the ADF negotiations desk, stated that negotiations would only be considered after the release of some ADF members. In December 2007, it was the ADF leadership that tried to initiate negotiations. The head of MONUC, the UN peacekeeping force in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Olamide Adedeji, stated that MONUC�s political section had been in contact with the ADF leadership, who reportedly wanted to negotiate peace and go home. Confidential negotiations between the government of Uganda and the ADF, without the involvement of a third party, were held in Nairobi starting in May 2008. The negotiations were aimed at reaching a ceasefire and amnesty, but the talks failed because the negotiations were complicated as a result of the fragmentation of the ADF�s leadership. In mid-December 2008, it was reported that both sides expected that formal peace talks would be initiated in early 2009, but these talks never materialised.

In December 1998, the Government of Uganda sent UNRF II a letter asking for a dialogue with the movement. UNRF II did not immediately respond to the offer of peace negotiations issued by the Government of Uganda in December 1998, but UNRF II commanders and a government delegation met for pre-negotiations in January 1999.
The UNRF II and the Government of Uganda conducted another round of pre-negotiations in June 2000, but the talks did not lead to any tangible results.

The Government of Uganda formed the Aringa-Obongi Peace Initiative Committee (AROPIC) in 2001 to act as the government negotiation team. A round of negotiations between the government delegation and the UNRF II leadership was subsequently held in Khartoum in November 2001. While this round of negotiations took place abroad, no third party was involved in these negotiations.
Another round of negotiations was held in Nairobi later in November 2001. While this round of negotiations took place abroad, no third party was involved in these negotiations.
Another round of negotiations between the UNRF II and the Government of Uganda took place in early 2002.
Several days of negotiations in Arua State Lodge in June 2002 led to the signing of a formal ceasefire agreement on 15 June 2002.

Negotiations in December 2002 led to signing of the Yumbe Peace Agreement on 24 December 2002. The Chairman for the Uganda Amnesty Commission, Justice Onega, mediated the negotiations, but no international third parties were involved. The accord stipulated a ceasefire. It also provided for the integration of around 700 rebels into the national army, while the remainder would be given resettlement packages. All UNRF II commanders would retain their ranks. Furthermore, it was agreed that the movement would receive ten government posts.

No negotiations have taken place between Eritrea and the EIJM - AS, but Eritrea has engaged in negotiations with Sudan about the latter ending military support to the EIJM - AS. When the border dispute between Ethiopia and Eritrea escalated into an armed conflict in May 1998, the leadership of Eritrea wanted to improve relations with Sudan. Consequently, Eritrean Foreign Minister Haile Woldensae and Sudanese Foreign Minister Mustafa Osman Ismail of Sudan engaged in negotiations mediated by Qatari Foreign Minister Sheikh Hamad bin Jassim bin Jabr al-Thani in Doha. These negotiations began on 9 November 1998 and ended on 2 February 1999 with the signing of a peace agreement. This peace agreement stipulates that both Eritrea and Sudan should abstain from supporting groups that undermine the security and stability of neighboring countries.

President Muammar Qaddafi of Libya mediated negotiations between the presidents of Eritrea and Sudan in Tripoli on 16 and 17 April 1999. These negotiations were aimed at ending the military support Eritrea and Sudan were providing to each other�s rebel groups.

The presidents of Eritrea and Sudan held another round of negotiations mediated by Qatar in Doha in Qatar on 2 and 3 May 1999. The Sudanese and Eritrean delegations agreed to abstain from supporting groups that undermine the security and stability of neighboring countries, as well as agreed to restore diplomatic ties. Eritrean authorities subsequently forced Sudanese opposition figures to leave Eritrea by the end of May 1999. Eritrea and Sudan resumed diplomatic relations on 4 January 2000.

A unilateral victory by either side was increasingly perceived as unlikely in the civil war in Angola by the end of the 1980s. This explains why both President dos Santos and Savimbi, attended a conference organised by Zairian President Mobutu Sese Seko in Gbadolite, Zaire, in June 1989, that involved 20 African countries. Prior to this meeting, Mobutu had obtained a mandate to mediate from the conflict parties through separate meetings on two occasions with Savimbi and Angolan President Eduardo dos Santos to �restore peace and National Reconciliation in Angola.� He had also consulted the regional heads of state at a summit in Tokyo on 22 February 1989 and a conference of regional leaders in Luanda on 16 May 1989. According to some observers, Mobuto wanted to portray himself as a regional peacemaker, since he lost some influence due to the end of the Cold War. The Gbadolite Peace Agreement was signed on 22 June 1989. The heads of states of the following countries attended the conference in Gbadolite: Zambia, Botswana, Burundi, Cameroon, Cape Verde, Chad, Congo, Gabon, Guinea-Bissau, Mozambique, Niger, Rwanda, Sao Tome and Principe, Tanzania, Zanzibar, Zimbabwe and the king of Morocco. Only a few days after President dos Santos and UNITA leader Savimbi signed the agreement, fighting erupted again with both parties disagreeing about the content of the agreement.

Mobutu undertook mediation efforts to follow up on the Gbadolite Peace Agreement. At a mini summit in Harare at the end of August, Mobutu and six other African Presidents endorsed the MPLA�s interpretation of the agreement in an attempt to save the peace process.
Mobutu also directly met with representatives of the conflict parties to rescue the peace process, including at meetings in France at the end of October.

A series of clashes at Mavinga in early 1990 cost the MPLA government between 400 and 800 million US Dollars and between 4,000 and 6,000 lives. Consequently, President dos Santos started looking for a third party and invited Portugal to mediate. Portugal�s Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, Jose Durao Barroso, convened the first round of negotiations between the two sides in Evora, Portugal, on 24-25 April 1990. The peace talks initiated by Portugal continued for 18 months and involved six rounds of negotiations.
Savimbi withdrew the UNITA delegation at the second round of talks in June 1990.
Nevertheless, a third round of negotiations was held in Evora in July 1990.

A breakthrough occurred in the summer of 1990 when the MPLA government abandoned its Marxist inspired ideology and compromised to the principle of �evolution to a multi-party state�, two points which the US had repeatedly emphasized as essential for their support to the peace process. These concessions allowed the US and the Soviet Union to become directly involved in the negotiations for the first time in the fourth round of talks in September 1990. The conflict parties agreed at this fourth round of negotiations that once a schedule for a ceasefire and elections had been negotiated, military support from the US and the Soviet Union to the conflict parties would end.

The negotiations gained further momentum during the fifth round of negotiations in December 1990, when United States Secretary of State James Baker held several meetings with Angolan Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi in Washington, which led to what became known as the Washington Concepts Paper. The meeting in Washington was also attended by the Portuguese intermediaries and Soviet diplomats. The Washington Concepts Paper stipulated that once a ceasefire would be concluded the conflict parties would organize free and fair elections, and that the parties would create a national army between the time of the conclusion of the ceasefire and the elections. The Washington Concept Paper further specified that the restructuring of the army and holding of elections were to be overseen by a UN monitoring force.

As a result of the Washington Concepts Paper, most of the underlying issues had been resolved by the time the sixth round of negotiations that started on 4 April 1991. This allowed the conflict parties to focus on the remaining key issues, which were the formulation of a unified national army, the setting of dates for a ceasefire and multiparty elections, and the international monitoring of implementation of an agreement. Of these remaining issues, the election date proved to be the most contentious point. While the MPLA government demanded the election to be held three years after the ceasefire date, UNITA proposed the elections to be held as early as nine months after the ceasefire. It was only after the US and the Soviet Union agreed to take part in the implementation process of the agreement that the conflict parties agreed to the elections taking place 18 months after the ceasefire would take effect, which was set for 15 May 1991. On 31 May 1991, the Bicesse Agreement was signed. The agreement established a ceasefire to be monitored by a joint commission, comprised of the two warring parties and a number of third parties. Furthermore, the agreement stipulated reforms of the military and security sector, creating an integrated army and a new police force. The agreement stipulated that both parties would contribute 20000 troops each to the new armed forces. The forces that were not integrated into the new army were to be demobilized and reintegrated into civilian life. The agreement allowed UNITA to become a legal political party. The agreement committed the parties to a multi-party democracy. An elections process was to be held in which the people would vote for a new President and a National Assembly. Political rights were extended, such as the freedom of expression and freedom of association. The authority of the central administration was extended to include the entire Angolan territory. The implementation of the peace agreement became the responsibility of the joint political-military commission. All civilian and military prisoners were to be released as a consequence of the agreement. The question of the return of exiles was to be discussed in the joint political-military commission. A variety of different mediation methods were used by the third parties to move the conflict parties towards the Bicesse Accords. First, the Bush administration made negotiations more attractive to the MPLA Government by promising that if the conflict parties would reach a negotiated settlement, then Washington would normalise relations with the MPLA Government and recognise it. Second, the third parties used military inducements, both through extending and refusing to extend military assistance. Seeking to maintain their position in Southern Africa, the US had been supporting UNITA, while the Soviet Union had been supporting the MPLA government. However, as the Cold War waned by the end of the 1980s, the conflict parties could no longer depend on unqualified support from their clients. Besides scaling back their support, both Washington and Moscow became increasingly willing to apply pressure to the conflict parties in favour of a peaceful solution to the conflict. The US drew on its patron client relationship with UNITA by urging the latter to make public statements calling for national reconciliation, making it easier for the MPLA government to reach out. The US had also tacitly assured dos Santos that with national reconciliation, the military aid to UNITA would be ended. In addition, the third parties guaranteed the implementation of the Bicesse Accords. The agreement stipulated that representatives of Portugal, the USA and the USSR, together with sub-groups and members of the government and UNITA, were to take part in the joint Politico-Military Commission (CCPM), with the task of overseeing the political and ceasefire process. It was also agreed that around 30 observer states would be involved in the implementation process, as well as a UN force of 800 people financed by a US grant of 40 million US Dollars. Moreover, President dos Santos was promised by US Secretary of State James Baker that �the USA had all the means to guarantee the implementation of the accords and also to prevent the accords being violated.�

However, the concluded peace was unstable. Several minor confrontations took place between soldiers and police loyal to the MPLA and supporters of the UNITA after the signing of the Bicesse Accords. On 6 February 1992, the UN Secretary-General appointed Miss Margaret Joan Anstee as his Special Representative to coordinate all United Nations activities in connection with the Angola Peace Accords. Although no large-scale fighting took place until after the elections in the last week of September 1992, the security situation deteriorated as the elections came closer. Representatives from Portugal, the US and Russia continued their efforts in the CCPM, set up under the Bicesse accord, with the task of overseeing the political and ceasefire process. It was stipulated in this peace agreement that the CCPM was mandated to ensure the �implementation and functioning of the mechanisms instituted to verify and exercise control over the ceasefire, provided for in the [Bicesse Accords] documents signed on this subject.� The UN Angola Verification Mission II (UNAVEM II) also continued its work and in addition to the monitoring of the military aspects of the agreement, it oversaw the elections in late 1992. On 31 October, the United Nations brokered a truce between the Angolan government and UNITA in Huambo.

In another round of negotiations mediated by the UN, the two sides reaffirmed commitment to the 1991 peace agreement and a ceasefire on 26 November. The MPLA won both the parliamentary and presidential elections, although the presidential elections required a second round of elections since dos Santos did not receive more than the required 50 percent of the votes. In spite of the UN describing the elections to be free and fair, UNITA leader Savimbi claimed fraud, left Luanda and resumed UNITA�s fight against the government.

When UNITA took up arms again after the elections, the UN Security Council imposed sanctions against UNITA�s war effort. UN Security Council Resolution 864 issued on 15 September 1993 stipulated that all countries were prohibited from selling arms, petroleum, and related products to UNITA. Later resolutions also imposed travel restrictions and trade measures. In addition to imposing sanctions, the UN sponsored negotiations. In January 1993, government and UNITA delegations met in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, to discuss both political and military matters. However, the talks broke down without an agreement on a ceasefire.

A second round of negotiations was due to take place the following week, but was postponed indefinitely when UNITA withdrew their support. In April 1993, UN-sponsored peace talks were held in Abidjan, Ivory Coast. The negotiations continued for 6 weeks, and revolved around issues like national reconciliation, UNITA enhanced participation in national, provincial and local government, and the respect for the Bicesse Accord. However, the parties failed to reach an agreement on a ceasefire and the talks broke down in late May.

Following a series of setbacks on the battlefield, UNITA agreed to preliminary talks aimed at discussing the details of formal peace negotiations. This peace initiative was led by the new UN special envoy to Angola, Alione Blondin Beye, who was mandated to implement the Bicesse Accords. American, Russian, and Portuguese diplomats also took part in the mediation effort led by Beye. These exploratory talks started in Lusaka in October. These exploratory talks ended with UNITA issuing a communiqu� reaffirming the validity of the Bicesse Accords, opening the way for new peace talks.

As a result, in December 1993, a new round of peace talks was launched in Lusaka, Zambia, by the new UN�s special envoy to Angola, Alione Blondin Beye, who was mandated to implement the Bicesse Accords. On 24 March 1992, this mandate had been confirmed by the UN Security Council, which stated in Resolution 747 that it welcomed Beye�s appointment and that he would be �in charge of all current and projected activities of the United Nations in connection with the [Bicesse] Accords.� UN SC Resolution 747. On 15 December 1993, the UN Security Council issued Resolution 890, in which it stated mandated Bye to conduct mediation �with the goal of restoring a cease-fire and reinstating the peace process for the full implementation of the Acordos de Paz [Bicesse Accords] and relevant Security Council resolutions.�

The negotiations launched in Lusaka in November 1993, at which Beye acted as the chief mediator, continued throughout 1994. American, Russian and Portuguese diplomats also took part, including US President Bill Clinton�s special envoy, Paul Hare. On 16 November 1994, the two sides signed a truce in order to support the ongoing peace talks. The Lusaka Accord was signed on 20 November 1994. The agreement reinstated the ceasefire from 1991, but contained some important amendments. Among other things this ceasefire agreement included the withdrawal of UNITA forces from specific locations to allow for a UN monitoring and verification presence in these areas. UNITA forces would withdraw to encampment areas, while government forces, in turn, would remain �in situ�. The agreement stipulated a proportionate integration of UNITA forces into the new national army. The agreement amended the earlier deal on the police forces, stipulating a specific number of UNITA troops that would become police officers in the new police force. A demobilization program was created under which military forces were to be demobilized and integrated into civilian society. The implementation of the agreement would be monitored and verified by a joint commission and the UN. The agreement stipulated that UNITA was to participate in all levels of Government, and that the movement was given certain ministerial portfolios, diplomatic missions, governorships and assured participation in the National Assembly. The agreement also provided UNITA with a formal amnesty for crimes committed during the conflict, and supplied the UNITA party and political leaders with �appropriate� housing. The agreement also stipulated that a Joint Commission would oversee the peace agreement. This was to be composed of government and UNITA representatives and chaired by the Alioune Blondin Beye, while representatives of Portugal, Russia and the USA were to be observers. On 8 December 1994, the UN Security Council mandated Beye and the Joint Commission to �continue their efforts aimed at the full implementation of the �Acordos de Paz� [Bicesse Accords], the Lusaka Protocol and relevant Security Council resolutions.�

Due to repeated crises in the peace process � both as a result of and resulting in � severe delays in the implementation of the Lusaka Accord, the Secretary-General�s special envoy to Angola was active in a number of mediation efforts from 1995 until early 1999, together with US, Portuguese and Russian representatives in the Joint Commission and in other contexts. UNITA and the Government of Angola held a round of negotiations, mediated by the UN, in February 1995 to discuss violations of the Lusaka Protocol.

On 6 May 1995, UN-brokered negotiations in Lusaka brought together dos Santos and Savimbi for the first time in 3 years. They both reaffirmed their commitment to implement the accord. This summit meeting was expected to facilitate the task of the UN Peacekeeping force, which was to be deployed in the country.
In July 1995, further talks were held in Lusaka, focusing this time on the implementation of the military aspect of the accord.

In August 1995, dos Santos and Savimbi met at the Franceville summit in Gabon. Negotiations did not reach any concrete results. The key stumbling block was the disarmament of UNITA, the confinement to barracks of government security forces and the formation of a single national army.

Another meeting was held in Libreville, Gabon, on 1 March 1996, where dos Santos and Savimbi managed to reach an agreement on the formation of a government of national unity within the following four months. Savimbi also committed himself to complete the quartering of UNITA forces by June 1996 and both leaders agreed that the formation of the unified armed forces should be concluded by the same date. President dos Santos repeated his invitation for Savimbi to become a vice-president, but the latter failed to respond. The creation of a government of national unity was never realised.

In mid-March 1997, the Joint Commission finally managed to meet after five successive postponements. Agreement was reached on some, including the granting of �special status� to Savimbi, following his rejection of the title of vice-president in late 1996. It was agreed at the same meeting that several UNITA leaders would become members of Parliament, providing the first parliamentary opposition to the MPLA since Angola gained independence in 1975. Dos Santos dissolved his government and subsequently formed a government of national unity in April 1997, with four UNITA cabinet ministers and seven deputy ministers.

Negotiations aimed at implementing the Lusaka Declaration continued following the establishment of a government of national unity. On 9 January 1998, negotiations took place in Luanda, attended by dos Santos together with a delegation from the government and UNITA. A new schedule was agreed for the implementation of the accord, stipulating that the terms of the protocol was to be fulfilled by 28 February. However, this failed to materialise. Since this deadline was yet again not met, the UN Security Council imposed new sanctions on UNITA on 25 June 1998, which stipulated the freezing of UNITA�s foreign bank accounts and a ban on the purchase of Angolan diamonds without a certificate of origin, as well as prohibited all air and water transport in and out of the territories controlled by UNITA. Savimbi had indicated on 6 June 1998 that if the UN would impose new sanctions, UNITA would regard this as an attack on UNITA to which it was ready to respond. Indeed, following the imposition of new UN sanctions, UNITA immediately seized control in some of the localities in which it had transferred power to the central government. By the end of 1998, the Government of Angola had lost patience with the lack of implementation of the Lusaka Protocol and resumed the civil war. At an MPLA congress held in early December 1998, President dos Santos stated that �the only path to lasting peace is the total isolation of Jonas Savimbi and his movement.� Large-scale armed fighting subsequently resumed. Following the resumption of war in late 1998, the UN Security Council terminated MONUA in February 1999 and replaced it with a small political mission in Luanda � the United Nations Office in Angola (UNOA) � which was mandated to watch political developments and promote human rights. However, the new set of UN sanctions, imposed against UNITA in June 1998, made a third party peacemaking role for the UN problematic. Unable to initiate new peace talks, the UN officially terminated its mediation effort in March 1999. The secretary-General�s special envoy to Angola, Issa Diallo, who had replaced Beye after Beye had died in a plane crash in June 1998, left the country in March 1999, stating that �the UN did what it could.� President Dos Santos stated that the Government of Angola would never negotiate with Savimbi again.

It was not until 2002 that the conflict parties engaged in negotiations again. These talks followed the death of UNITA leader Savimbi, who was killed by government forces on 22 February 2002, after which plans were immediately made to initiate peace talks. The Government of Angola initially indicated that its counter-insurgency campaign against UNITA would continue in spite of Savimbi�s death, but following a series of meetings President dos Santos held with the Portuguese Government in Lisbon, President George W. Bush in Washington, and UN Under Secretary for African Affairs Ibrahim Gambari in New York, the Government of Angola announced on 2 March that it would contact UNITA to prepare the ground for a ceasefire. The Secretary-General of UNITA, Paulo Lukamba, subsequently formed the so-called Management Committee which was to negotiate with the Government of Angola. The conflict parties engaged in informal discussions, which led the Government of Angola to declare a unilateral ceasefire on 13 March.

The Government of Angola also presented a peace plan, which called for negotiations on the outstanding military and political issues in accordance with the Bicesse Accords and Lusaka Protocol. No third parties were involved in the peace process, but the UN endorsed the peace plan. The UN Special Representative in Angola, Mussagy Jeichande, expressed satisfaction with the peace plan, describing it as �conciliatory.� Crucially, UNITA�s breakaway factions, which had challenged Savimbi�s leadership in 1998, also supported the peace talks. UNITA-Renavado leader Eugenio Manuvakola publicly declared not to interfere with the peace negotiations, reportedly allowing �UNITA to represent UNITA.� Preliminary talks between the conflict parties subsequently started on 15 March in the town of Cassamba in Moxico province. It was agreed at these talks that official negotiations would mainly focus technical military matters. The conflict parties also decided that the provincial capital Luena would be the venue of the peace talks, because the Government of Angola had the necessary facilities in this town to host talks, but the town was also close to the battlefield. The conflict parties signed a ceasefire at Cassamba on 18 March. In spite of the ceasefire, some low-level fighting continued throughout Angola. Yet, the negotiators kept the positive momentum, insisting that this fighting was only the result of a lack of information getting to the fighting elements.

Official peace talks started on 20 March in Luena. The UNITA delegation was headed by UNITA�s Information Secretary Marcial Dachala and by UNITA�s Secretary for Foreign Affairs Alcides Sakala. The negotiations focused mainly on the technicalities of a ceasefire and the DDR process. The negotiators agreed that the Lusaka Protocol would be taken as the basis for the political resolution of the conflict. On 30 March 2002, the parties agreed on a ceasefire agreement, referred to as the Luena Memorandum. The Luena Memorandum was formally signed in Luanda on 4 April 2002. The agreement essentially provides for the implementation of a ceasefire and the signatories� compliance with the outstanding clauses of the Lusaka peace agreement from 1994. In contrast to the peace agreements previously concluded to end Angola�s civil war, the security provisions in the Luena Memorandum were quickly implemented. No armed fighting took place following the signing of the agreement and UNITA troops began to move towards the assembly points designated by the Luena Agreement on the same day the agreement was signed. UNITA officially gave up its armed wing on 2 August 2002, declaring it would from this moment onwards solely be a political party.

No negotiations have taken place between the Ethiopian government and AIAI, but the Ethiopian government has engaged in negotiations with Sudan about the latter ending military support to the AIAI. When the border dispute between Ethiopia and Eritrea escalated into an armed conflict in May 1998, the leadership of Eritrea wanted to improve relations with Sudan. In a round of negotiations on 31 March 1999, the leaders of Sudan and Ethiopia restored diplomatic relations and concluded an agreement in which they committed to abstain from activities that undermine peace and security in each other�s countries. Specifically, the Government of Ethiopia committed to end support to the SPLM/A, while the Government of Sudan committed to end support to the OLF and the AIAI.

Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir and Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi engaged in negotiations in Addis Ababa on 18 and 19 November 1999, confirming the March 1999 agreement that committed both states to abstain from activities that undermine peace and security in each other�s countries.

In June 2004, the Government of Ethiopia and the ONLF agreed to mediation by Kenya and the United Kingdom. Representatives of ONLF held talks with the Ethiopian government in both Nairobi and London. The Nairobi talks in June 2004 involved ONLF chairman, Muhammad Umar Usman, and an official from the Ethiopian Foreign Affairs Ministry. The government delegation offered political positions to the ONLF leadership on the condition that the group be disbanded during the Nairobi talks, but no agreement was reached.
The London talks in June 2004 were held between ONLF secretary-general, Muhammad Sirad Dolal, and officials from the Ethiopian embassy.

By the end of 2011, President Meles Zenawi confidentially encouraged the resumption of ONLF-government talks. In order to bring about talks, Meles also requested Kenya to mediate. The presence of a third party was tantamount to the ONLF, after the killing of its negotiator in 1998. Talks mediated by Kenya were scheduled to take place in August 2012, but were postponed due to the death of President Meles. A first meeting was subsequently held between 6 and 7 September 2012, when a delegation from the Ethiopian government, led by Defence Minister Siraj Fegisa, met an ONLF delegation under the leadership of the group�s foreign secretary Abd-al-Rahman Mahdi. A Kenyan team under the leadership of Yusuf Haji, the Defence and a Kenyan Ogaadeni, functioned as the mediators during the process that aimed to start up official negotiations between the Ethiopian government and ONLF. At this initial meeting, the parties focused mainly on the modalities for future talks and at the end of it, they had agreed on principles to end the conflict. It was announced by the ONLF that the two sides were committed to holding formal negotiations to solve the conflict, that the goal of the process was to attain just and lasting peace, that the negotiations were to be comprehensive, addressing the root causes of the conflict, that no preconditions were to be made of either party, that the substantive agenda was to include issues that would facilitate the implementation of a future agreement, and, finally, that both parties were to agree to specific measure of good-will and confidence-building in order to create a favourable climate for the negotiations.

The Nairobi talks resumed in October 2012, but soon ran into difficulties as the government delegation insisted that the continuation of the talks depended on the ONLF first accepting the Ethiopian constitution, thereby accepting Ogaden as being part of Ethiopia.

On 12 August 2018, the Ogaden National Liberation Front (ONLF) declared a unilateral ceasefire. The leadership of the group publicly stated that it declared the ceasefire in response to call for peace by the Ethiopian government led by Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed. The improvement in relations between Ethiopia and Eritrea in July 2018 gave further impetus to the peace process between the Government of Ethiopia on the one hand and the OLF and the ONLF on the other hand. In spite of Eritrea hosting both groups on its territory, it initiated a mediation effort between the Ethiopian government and these two rebel groups. A round of negotiations in Asmara mediated by Eritrea led to the signing of a peace agreement between the government and the ONLF on 21 October 2018. Many ONLF leaders subsequently returned to Ogaden to transform the group into a political party ahead of 2020 elections.
agreement_name: Joint Declaration Between the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia And The Ogaden National Liberation Front

description: A POLISARIO delegation, led by Mahfoud Ali Beiba, held negotiations with King Hassan II in Marrakesh on 4 and 5 January 1989, although the King described the meeting as �discussions� rather than �negotiations�. The talks took place without the involvement of any third party and was instead chaired by King Hassan II himself. However, the UN Secretary-General remained involved in the conflict throughout the year, particularly with regard to the implementation of the in 1988 presented peace plan, which aimed to end the war by holding a referendum to decide on the future status of the disputed territory.

In June 1990, the Secretary-General presented a more elaborate plan, including a timetable for the process. This plan was approved by the UN Security Council, calling on both Morocco and POLISARIO to �co-operate fully� with the Secretary-General. On the basis of the new mandate, P�rez de Cuellar arranged a meeting with the conflict parties in Geneva held in late June 1990, but he failed to convince the Moroccan side to engage in official negotiations during five days of pre-negotiations under the auspices of the UN.

In 1991, P�rez de Cuellar mediated between the conflict parties throughout the entire year regarding updating the administrative aspects of his peace plan. On 28 June 1991, during a round of peace talks mediated by the UN, the government of Morocco and POLISARIO agreed to a ceasefire starting on 6 September. On 19 December 1991, less than two weeks before he would leave office, the UN Secretary-General submitted a final report to the UN Security Council, recommending extending the eligibility of potential voters in the referendum. However, the proposal was only �welcomed� by the UN Security Council. Nevertheless, Morocco began moving around 170,000 individuals to the Western Sahara who were supposedly allowed to vote on the basis of P�rez de Cuellar�s proposed criteria.

On 26 January 1992, Boutros-Ghali issued an update report on the situation in the Western Sahara, outlining different options to resolve the conflict. The Security Council chose to pursue the resolution of the conflict on the basis of intensification of talks and mandated the UN Secretary-General and his Special Representative �to intensify their efforts, with the parties, in order to resolve the issues ... in particular those relating to the interpretation and application of the criteria for voter eligibility.� On the basis of this mandate, the UN Secretary-General travelled to the region in June 1992 and consulted with both the Moroccan Government and representatives of POLISARIO in a round of pre-negotiations.

The visit by the UN Secretary-General in June 1992 led to initiation of official negotiations between the adversaries in the Sahrawi capital of Al-Ayounby in mid-July 1992. These negotiations took place under UN auspices.
Another meeting took place in New York in October 1993. This round of talks failed because the government sent Sahrawi defectors to negotiate instead of government officials.

In January 1994, Boutros-Ghali attempted to initiate a new round of direct negotiations. Although both sides initially agreed, official peace talks never materialised due to POLISARIO�s objections against General Abdelhak Kadiri, head of the Moroccan secret services, acting as Morocco�s chief negotiator. In 1997, the UN succeeded in mediating four rounds of direct negotiations. James Baker, who had been appointed by UN Secretary-General by Kofi Annan as his Personal Envoy on 18 March 1997, acted as the chief mediator during these peace talks. The first round of negotiations mediated by the UN took place in London in June 1997.

The second round of negotiations mediated by the UN took place in London in July 1997. The second round resulted in a compromise proposal concerning the identification process of people eligible to vote in the planned referendum.

The third round of negotiations mediated by the UN took place in Lisbon in August 1997. The third round resulted in an agreement regarding how to deal with the prisoners of war and political detainees.

The fourth round of negotiations mediated by the UN took place in Houston September 1997. The four rounds of negotiations were referred to as a �breakthrough� by POLISARIO. As a result of these talks, the identification process was restarted in December 1997.

In 2000, James Baker mediated another three rounds of talks. The first round of negotiations mediated by the UN took place in London on 14 May 2000. These talks were also attended by neighbouring Algeria and Mauritania. No progress was made, and the meeting ended with Baker inviting the parties to come forward at the next meeting with concrete suggestions on how to resolve the multiple problems facing the settlement plan launched by the UN in 1988 and discussed ever since, or else, to be prepared to discuss alternative options.

The second round of negotiations mediated by the UN was held in London on 28 June 2000. The parties both presented areas of difficulties with the settlement plan, but neither offered specific proposals to resolve these problematic areas, which both could agree to.

On 28 September 2000, the third and final round of negotiations mediated by the UN of the year was held in Berlin. Since no progress was made and neither party seemed open to discuss their position, Baker suggested that new options should be explored. However, both POLISARIO and the Moroccan representatives reiterated their commitment to the settlement plan, while disagreeing on how to implement it.

In 2001, Baker formulated a blueprint to resolve the conflict titled the Personal Envoy�s Draft Framework Agreement, also known as Baker Plan I. The document was immediately rejected by representatives of POLISARIO, who stated that it aimed at �the precipitous integration of the Saharan Territory into Morocco.� POLISARIO continued to oppose the Baker plan between 2001 and 2002. Consequently, in January 2003, Baker presented a new peace plan to the parties, named the �Peace plan for self-determination of the people of Western Sahara�, also known as the Baker Plan II. This plan provided for a referendum to take place within four to five years. The final vote would offer the inhabitants of the territory a choice between independence, autonomy within Morocco or complete integration with Morocco. The plan also proposed that, in the run-up to the referendum, an autonomous Western Sahara Authority would be made responsible for running key parts of the administration, taking control of local government, taxation, economic development, internal security and other dossiers. Yet, Morocco would retain control over foreign relations, national security, external defence and all matters relating to the production, sale, ownership and use of weapons during the interim period.

Following a round of negotiations in July 2003, POLISARIO accepted the plan, but the Government of Morocco rejected it. The main obstacle for the government was that one of the ballot choices was independence.

On 29 July 2005, the UN Secretary-General appointed a new Personal Envoy for Western Sahara, Peter van Walsum. The UN Security Council, and Secretary-General Kofi Annan, urged POLISARIO to enter into new negotiations with the Government of Morocco in 2006. In spite of various efforts to initiate direct talks by van Walsum, the POLISARIO movement stated it was interested in the promised referendum, not in new talks. In April 2006, the Moroccan king offered to grant Western Sahara autonomy within Moroccan territorial sovereignty, but the POLISARIO leadership firmly refuted this proposal, stating that only a referendum on independence would satisfy his people.

On 30 April 2007, the UN Security Council adopted resolution 1754, in which it called upon the parties to enter negotiations. A round of negotiations under UN auspices was subsequently held in June 2007, in which Van Walsum acted as the chief mediator.

Another round of negotiations mediated by Van Walsum took place in August 2007. However, no agreement was reached as the government continued to stick to its proposal for limited autonomy under Moroccan sovereignty for Western Sahara, while POLISARIO maintained its demand for a referendum with a choice of autonomy or independence. In December, POLISARIO threatened that they would consider going back to armed conflict to �speed up the process.�
Between 7 and 9 January 2008, Van Walsum mediated negotiations in Manhasset, near New York City. The talks ended without the parties reaching further agreement than to resume talks in March 2008.

As a result, another round of mediated negotiations in Manhasset took place on 18 and 19 March 2008, but again without success. In May 2008, POLISARIO again expressed their scepticism regarding the possibility of a political solution and again threatened to resume violence. POLISARIO further demanded that Peter Van Walsum had to be replaced, since he had expressed that independence for Western Sahara was unrealistic.

Van Walsum was replaced on 14 January 2009 by Christopher Ross, as the UN Secretary-General for Western Sahara. In February 2009, Ross began a series of separate meetings with the concerned parties in the conflict.

Ross mediated direct talks between the parties in Duernstein, Austria, on 10 and 11 August 2009. Although the parties appeared satisfied with the talks and promised continued negotiations in the near future, no progress towards an agreement appeared to have been made, as Morocco continued to propose autonomy while POLISARIO demanded a referendum and possible independence.

Ross mediated three rounds of negotiations between the government of Morocco and POLISARIO in 2010. He first mediated informal talks near New York in February 2010, but these broke down after two days without reaching any progress.

The two parties met again for talks mediated by UN Special Representative Ross in New York on 8 and 9 November 2010. Yet, these talks were overshadowed by the Moroccan military entering a camp near Laayoune just days before the talks, resulting in a small number of fatalities.
New talks mediated by the UN were held in New York between 16 and 18 December 2010. While each party continued to reject the proposals of the other, they agreed to meet again for talks in 2011.
UN Special Representative Ross mediated a round of negotiations in Malta in March 2011.
Another round of UN-mediated negotiations was held in New York in May 2011.
Another round of UN-mediated negotiations was held in New York in June 2011.
Another round of UN-mediated negotiations was held in New York in July 2011. However, the parties continued to reject each other�s proposals.

The Government of Morocco and POLISARIO engaged in negotiations outside of New York in March 2012. The talks were mediated by Christopher Ross, the personal of the UN Secretary-General for Western Sahara. Mauritania and Algeria also participated in the mediation efforts at this meeting.
UN Special Representative Christopher Ross mediated a round of shuttle negotiations between the conflict parties in February 2016.
Another round of shuttle negotiations mediated by Ross took place in September 2016.
Another round of shuttle negotiations mediated by the UN took place from late November 2016 to early 2017.
In October 2017, Horst K�hler replaced Christopher Ross as the UN Special Representative. K�hler managed to initiate face-to-face negotiations between the conflict parties on 5 and 6 December 2018.
Another round of negotiations mediated by K�hler took place in Geneva on 21 and 22 March 2019.

In September 1988, President Chissano met South African President Pieter Willem Botha at Songo in the Tete province, where they promised to commit to the in 1984 concluded Nkomati accord. In addition, Chissano gave permission to senior leaders of the Roman Catholic, Anglican, and Protestant Churches to open direct contacts with Renamo leaders. Exploratory talks between church leaders in Mozambique and a delegation from Renamo were held in Nairobi in August in 1989. The goal of these talks was to prepare for direct talks between the Government of Mozambique and the rebel movement. The talks were chaired by President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya and President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, who had been officially requested to mediate by the Government of Mozambique on 21 July. The mediation efforts of Moi and Mugabe continued throughout the rest of the year, but they did not succeed in initiating direct negotiations because of disagreements about the who should be the mediator. Renamo demanded Kenya, its supporting nation, to act as the mediator. However, the Frelimo government agreed to this on the condition that Zimbabwe, its own ally, also played a role as a co-mediator. This condition was not acceptable to Renamo, which also dismissed Frelimo�s suggestion to proceed without any mediators, citing a lack of mutual trust. The conflict parties eventually consented to elevate Sant�Egidio from a mere observer to the role of a mediator.

The first direct talks between the conflict parties were held in Rome between 8 and 12 July 1990. This was the starting point of what came to be known as the Rome process, brokered by two members of the Catholic Community of Sant�Egidio, as well as the Archbishop of Beira Jaime Gon�alves, and Italian government representative Mario Raffaelli. From the start of the Rome talks onwards, the Government of Italy constantly provided extensive financial incentives to Renamo in particular in order to keep it engaged in the peace processes. Vines claims that premier seats at the opening World Cup football match in June 1990 between Argentina and Cameroon were an initial incentive for both delegations to commit to talks. Mugabe and Moi participated in the first round of talks in Rome, but due to accusations of being biased they ended their mediation efforts after this round of negotiations. Zimbabwe was considered as biased towards the Government by Renamo because of its military support, while the Government perceived Kenya to be biased towards Renamo because of a Renamo presence on Kenyan territory.
third_party: Community of Sant�Egidio, Italy, Kenya, Zimbabwe

description: The second round of negotiations of the Rome process took place between 11 and 14 August 1990, but ended in deadlock. It was reported that Renamo was reluctant to address substantial issues.

The parties came together for a third round of talks from 8 November to 1 December 1990, which led to a partial ceasefire. The conflict parties agreed to stop fighting in the Beira and Maputu corridors, which link Zimbabwe and other landlocked countries with the ocean. It was also decided that the number of Zimbabwean troops would be reduced by half and confined to the corridors.

In late December 1990, during the fourth round of negotiations, a Joint Verification Committee � consisting of members of the government, Renamo, and eight countries � was set up to monitor the ceasefire, ensuring non-defection. Of the eight countries serving on the committee, Renamo chose Kenya, Portugal, the US, and Zambia, while the Government of Mozambique selected Congo, France, the UK, and the Soviet Union.

The fifth round of talks in the framework of the Rome negotiations � which were mediated by the Roman Catholic Community of Sant�Egidio, the Archbishop of Beira, and the Italian government � took place from 23 January to early February 1991. The talks were supposed to address the major disagreements, including issues related to electoral procedures, but no progress was made.
During the sixth round of talks, held in May 1991, an agenda for negotiations was agreed upon and the Protocol on the Agreed Agenda was signed on 28 May 1991.
The seventh round of negotiations in July 1991 broke down as Renamo introduced new demands.

However, during the eighth round of talks, held in October 1991, substantial progress was made. On 18 October, a protocol on Fundamental Principles was signed, where Renamo recognised the legitimacy of the Government during a transitional period between a formal ceasefire and elections. The protocol confirmed the May agenda and cleared the ground for a general peace agreement once a protocol for each agenda item had been negotiated.

On 13 November, a partial peace agreement, dealing with criteria for political parties was signed: the Agreement on Establishment and Recognition of Political Parties. In this partial peace agreement, the parties reached consensus on certain aspects of the future multi-party democracy by defining the general principles, rights, and responsibilities of political parties. Additionally, it was agreed that RENAMO would undergo a transformation into a political party once a final peace agreement was signed.
agreement_name: Agreement on Establishment and Recognition of Political Parties

description: On the ninth round of negotiations in December 1991, a joint communiqu� confirming consensus on simultaneous presidential and parliamentary elections supervised by the UN and the OAU and held within a year of the signing of a general peace agreement, was issued. Throughout the Rome talks, the Government of Italy constantly provided extensive financial incentives to Renamo in particular in order to keep it engaged in the peace processes.

Round ten of the Rome negotiations � which were mediated by the Roman Catholic Community of Sant�Egidio, the Archbishop of Beira, and the Italian government � took place between 21 January and 12 March 1992. The tenth round resulted in the signing of a protocol, which supplemented the earlier agreements on electoral issues. The agreement ensured several fundamental rights, including freedom of the press, access to the media, freedom of association, expression, and political engagement, freedom of movement and residence, the right of refugees to return, and the right to vote. It also specified that national elections would be conducted within one year of the final peace agreement's signing, with a detailed process outlined for the elections. The elections would include direct voting for a national assembly based on proportional representation and a president overseen by a National Elections Commission. The agreement established that a political party would need a minimum of 5% and a maximum of 20% of votes to obtain seats, while a presidential candidate would require 10,000 signatures. Furthermore, the agreement encouraged the return of refugees and internally displaced persons to participate in the forthcoming elections in Mozambique.

In mid-June 1992, round eleven of the negotiations started. They were supposed to focus on military issues, but instead revolved around famine relief due to the worst drought in 30 years. British businessman Tiny Rowland together with Zimbabwean president Robert Mugabe managed to convince Renamo leader Dhlakama and President Chissano to meet face to face for negotiations in Dhlakama, Botswana, on 5 July 1992. As a result of this meeting, the parties signed, on 7 August 1992, a declaration of intent to sign a ceasefire in early October 1992. Tiny Rowland had already become involved in the peace process in 1990, when he and President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia launched a separate initiative in parallel to the Rome process. Rowland was the chairman of Lonroho, a company based in the United Kingdom which was the first major transnational corporation to make major investments in Mozambique. Rowland regarded the civil war as a serous hindrance to expansion of his business interests, which is why he worked to initiate a face-to-face meeting between President Chissano and Renamo leader Dhlakama.
On 16 July 1992, representatives from the government of Mozambique and Renamo reached a ceasefire agreement in Rome to allow for humanitarian aid to reach rebel areas.

The 7 August declaration of intent was signed at the twelfth and final round of the Rome process, which was initiated on 5 August 1992. Finally, the Acordo General de Paz (English: General Peace Agreement), also known as the Rome Accord, was signed on 4 October 1992. The Acordo Geral de Paz consolidated various previous protocols signed by the government and RENAMO. Upon assembly ratification, a ceasefire would be implemented. Both forces would then withdraw from their current positions and relocate to designated sites for integration into a new armed unit or demobilization. The agreement outlined the establishment of a new army comprising 30,000 men, with each party contributing 15,000. Remaining forces would be disarmed and demobilized under UN supervision within six months. RENAMO would transform into a political party, and free multi-party elections would be held. Under UN supervision, presidential and legislative elections were scheduled one year after the signing of the General Peace Agreement, contingent upon full implementation and completion of the demobilization process. Additionally, all prisoners were to be released, and refugees and internally displaced persons were granted the right to return freely and voluntarily to the country. Lastly, UN peacekeepers would monitor the ceasefire and oversee the elections. The Government of Italy constantly provided extensive financial incentives to Renamo in particular to keep it engaged in the peace processes, in fact, by the time of the signing of the Rome Accord, the Government of Italy had spent around 20 million US Dollars on purchases to promote cooperation in the peace process.
Negotiations on military issues continued until the end of September 1992.
On 15 April 2012, Renamo leader Afonso Dhlakama met with the Mozambican president in Maputo to discuss issues of security and defense. These negotiations did not lead to a peace agreement.

In response to several armed attacks conducted by Renamo in October 2012, the Government of Mozambique agreed in November 2012 to meet and negotiate with the organization. The two sides subsequently convened at a hotel in Maputo on 3 December 2012.

On 17 April 2013, the government invited Renamo to a round of negotiations in Maputo on 22 April, but this invitation was rejected by Renamo on the basis of preferring a different location. Ultimately, the two sides met for bilateral peace talks at the Joaquim Chissano Conference Centre in Maputo on 2 May 2013.
Another peace meeting was held in Maputo on 13 May 2013.
The parties also met for negotiations in Maputo on 20 May 2013.
Another round of negotiations was held in early June.
The conflict parties also met in mid-June for negotiations.
Negotiations in early September 2013 were terminated because Renamo demanded a third-party mediator to be involved.

The Community of Sant�Egidio, which had also been heavily involved in mediation during the first civil war, subsequently started to play a leading role in mediation. Community of Sant�Egidio mediator Matteo Zuppi mediated a round of negotiations in late September 2013. The negotiations did not lead to any tangible results. While the government side demanded that all Renamo troops would lay down their weapons, Renamo demanded the withdrawal of government troops from the main Renamo stronghold, the Gorongosa area. Renamo also demanded a better representation within the armed forces, a share of the mineral revenues, and a new electoral law.

Negotiations mediated by the Community of Sant�Egidio in October 2013 broke down, after which the government forces managed to capture the main Renamo bases at Satunjira and Maringue in October 2013. Renamo subsequently retreated to the bush and engaged in small scale attacks. The government ultimately agreed in December 2013 to involve local observers in future discussions with Renamo.
During a round of negotiations on 1 February 2014, the conflict parties agreed on a list of national observers to attend future rounds of negotiations.
A round of negotiations on 10 February 2014 led to an agreement that called for the restructuring of the National Electoral Commission.
On 15 February 2014, another round of negotiations was held.
The government conceded to international mediation during a round of negotiations on 17 March 2014.
On 24 March 2014, during another round negotiations, the two sides agreed to the Southern African Development Community (SADC) being an observer.
Following another round of negotiations on 14 April 2014, Renamo agreed to disarm and reintegrate its members into the national army.
From 22 April to 23 April, the government and Renamo engaged in negotiations that ended with the former agreeing to let the Renamo leadership potentially run in forthcoming presidential elections.

A round of negotiations that started on 21 July 2014 led to a full draft of a peace agreement on 28 July 2014. This draft agreement included provisions for a ceasefire and the reintegration of rebel members. However, the agreement was neither formally signed nor implemented.

The conflict parties continued to negotiate in 2014, but without the involvement of a third party. Ahead of elections on 15 October 2014, the conflict parties agreed to a ceasefire in Maputo on 24 August 2014. As part of the negotiations, the government began to release Renamo prisoners a week prior to the conclusion of the ceasefire. The ceasefire was signed by Renamo�s chief negotiator Saimon Macuiane and government representatives. The ceasefire was seen as part of a wider attempt to bring peace to the country ahead of elections scheduled for October 2014. Saimon Macuiane, the Renamo� chief negotiator, called the ceasefire an �important step towards national reconciliation... and a durable peace.�

A round of negotiations in September led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 5 September 2014. The agreement was signed by Mozambican President Arnando Guebuza Renamo leader Afonso Dhlakama. The latter emerged from two years in hiding to sign the deal in the capital, Maputo. Foreign military observers under the Military Group for the Observation of the Military Hostilities (EMOCHM) would later arrive to oversee the implementation of this agreement. It was intended to last 135 days, but would be extended.
From 7 to 9 February 2015, the Government of Mozambique and Renamo convened in Maputo for negotiations.
Between 4 and 12 May, the two sides engaged in negotiations. This did not lead to a peace agreement.
On 26 May 2015, another round of negotiations was held once again in Maputo.
In early June 2015, the EMOCHM foreign observers left the country. Another round of negotiations took place on 29 June 2015.
On 27 July 2015, a round of negotiations respectively took place in Maputo.

In August 2015, Renamo unilaterally suspended talks with the government. Nevertheless, the conflict parties resumed negotiations in October 2015. Mozambican religious leaders and academic figures acted as mediators of these peace talks.

In mid-June 2016, the conflict parties agreed to the involvement of international mediators in their negotiations. The subsequent mediation process was led by Community of Sant�Egidio, but mediators from the European Union were also involved. Mario Raffaeli from the Community of Sant�Egidio acted as the coordinator of the international mediation team. These third parties mediated a round of negotiations in July 2016, only to terminate the negotiations in late July in the wake of escalating violence and an impasse over the status of the six northern and central provinces, which Dhlakama insisted were under Renamo�s control. The mediation process subsequently stalled and the international mediation team left Mozambique in mid-December 2016.
On 26 December, the parties reached a 7-day ceasefire agreement through bilateral negotiations over the phone.

The previously agreed upon ceasefire was extended for two months during a round of negotiations on 3 January 2017. In February 2017, Switzerland was announced as a lead mediator in an international team intended to mediate between the rebels and government. However, in early March 2017, the Government of Mozambique announced that a further round of negotiations would be held, but without the involvement of international mediators.
The ceasefire was extended once again in early May and the parties met 11 May 2017 for a round of negotiations.

At the start of August 2017, President Nyusi met with Dhlakama in the Gorongosa forest. No peace agreement came out this particular bilateral effort. It was also announced that mediated negotiations would be held in the future. Switzerland took the lead in mediating these peace talks. The mediation effort was led by the Swiss Ambassador Mirko Manzoni. The mediating team included also Neha Sanghrajka of Kenya, Jonathan Powell of the UK, and Eduardo Namburete, a Mozambican member of parliament trusted by Dhlakama.
Switzerland mediated a round of negotiations in October 2017.
Another round of negotiations was mediated by Switzerland in December 2017. Ultimately, the peace process did not move forward significantly in 2017.

On 3 May 2018, Afonso Dhlakama, the long-time and influential leader of RENAMO, died after suffering a heart attack. Peace talks between the rebel group and Mozambican government continued in May 2018.
On 11 July 2018, leadership from both sides met for a peace talk in which progress was made regarding integration of former rebels.

A round of negotiations in August 2018 led to the signing of a memorandum of understanding on 6 August 2018 that outlined terms for disarmament. Later that year, in December 2018, several of Renamo officials were announced as new members of the Mozambican government.

The Ambassador of Switzerland and Chairman of Contact Group, Mirko Manzoni, mediated another meeting between President Filipe Nyusi and the Renamo leader President Ossufo Momade on 2 June 2019. The meeting focused on disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration (DDR) provisions.
third_party: UN, Contact Group (Switzerland, Botswana, China, EU, Great Britain, Norway, US)

description: Swiss diplomats led the international mediation team that was involved in the peace efforts during 2019. On 1 August 2019, on Swiss National Day, the conflict parties signed the final cessation of hostilities agreement in the rebel stronghold of Gorongosa Park. This date was chosen on purpose in honour of Switzerland. The ceasefire agreement was signed by President Filipe Nyusi and Renamo leader Ossufo Momade at Renamo�s remote military base in the Gorongosa mountains.
third_party: UN, Contact Group (Switzerland, Botswana, China, EU, Great Britain, Norway, US)

description: This ceasefire paved the way for the signing of the Maputo Accord for Peace and National Reconciliation on 6 August 2019. The new RENAMO leader Ossufo Momade signed the peace accord with President Nyusi.
third_party: UN, Contact Group (Switzerland, Botswana, China, EU, Great Britain, Norway, US)
agreement_name: Maputo Accord for Peace and National Reconciliation

description: On 11 October 2019, Mozambican President Filipe Nyusi had a phone call with the Renamo leadership about the implementation of the peace agreement.

Several rounds of peace negotiations aimed at implementing the Maputo Accord have taken place. These negotiations mainly focused on the disarmament, demobilization and reintegration (DDR) process and life pensions to demobilized Renamo fighters. This issue of life pensions for demobilized Renamo fighters became particularly a point of contentions as it had already been agreed between the conflict parties as part of the DDR, but it had not been written in the 2019 peace agreement. The negotiations addressing these issues took place on the highest political level between President Nyusi and Renamo leader Ossufo Momade through mediation by the Personal Envoy of the Secretary-General for Mozambique Mirko Manzoni, but many meetings also took place in the Military Affairs Commission (MAC), the Joint Technical Group for DDR (JTGDDR), the Joint Technical Group for Placement (JTGP) and the Joint Technical Group for Monitoring and Verification (JTGMV). As a result of a commitment by the parties to keep the deliberations secret, much is unknown about the locations and dates of the meetings aimed at implementing the Maputo Accord. However, the occurrence of a few high-level meetings between President Nyusi and Renamo leader Ossufo Momade are public knowledge. On 16 April 2020, a meeting took place between President Nyusi and Renamo leader Ossufo Momade. Few details are known about this meeting other than that the two sides discussed some �pertinent issues� related to the Maputo Accord and that Mirko Manzoni, the personal envoy of the UN Secretary-General for Mozambique and President of the Contact Group, mediated between the parties.
third_party: UN, Contact Group (Switzerland, Botswana, China, EU, Great Britain, Norway, US)

description: On 5 September 2020, Mirko Manzoni, the personal envoy of the UN Secretary-General for Mozambique and President of the Contact Group, met with President Filipe Nyusi and Renamo leader Ossufo Momade to discuss progress made with regard to DDR. The meeting took place in the context of a meeting at a Renamo base located in Gorongosa where a DDR process took place.
third_party: UN, Contact Group (Switzerland, Botswana, China, EU, Great Britain, Norway, US)

description: In December 2020, Mirko Manzoni, the personal envoy of the UN Secretary-General for Mozambique and President of the Contact Group, met with the leader of the Renamo Military Junta (RMJ), General Mariano Nhongo. The RMJ was a faction within Renamo refusing to disarm and demobilize, occasionally even launching armed attacks in the centre of Mozambique. This meeting was a round of pre-negotiations during which Nhongo sent his representatives to initiate dialogue on joining the DDR process. The next month, on 6 January 2021, the RMJ leadership announced a unilateral ceasefire. Intermittent fighting continued in spite of this unilateral ceasefire. On 11 October 2021, RMJ leader Nhongo died in a clash with the Mozambican police. The remaining RMJ fighters subsequently either fled or joined the DDR program.
third_party: UN, Contact Group (Switzerland, Botswana, China, EU, Great Britain, Norway, US)

description: On 22 June 2021, President Filipe Nyusi and Renamo Leader Ossufo Momade met to discuss the progress made with regard to the implementation of the Maputo Accord. Several topics were discussed, including the DDR process. Mirko Manzoni, the personal envoy of the UN Secretary-General for Mozambique and President of the Contact Group, acted as a mediator during these talks.
third_party: UN, Contact Group (Switzerland, Botswana, China, EU, Great Britain, Norway, US)
