Negotiations, mediated by Algeria, on 5 and 6 January 1991 led to the conclusion of the Tamanrasset Agreement. The Minister of Interior Department of Algeria acted as the chief mediator at these negotiations. The first point of the agreement called for a ceasefire and an end to hostilities. The ceasefire did not involve giving up any territory, instead, the opposing forces would remain in their current locations. This meant that the rebels would continue occupying northern Mali for the time being. Later on, a phased withdrawal would demilitarize the North. The agreement also included the demobilization of rebel forces, with the option of integrating them into the armed forces. It was agreed that Mali�s armed forces would not interfere in internal political activities. A joint commission, including Algeria as the mediator, would monitor the ceasefire. The agreement granted internal autonomy to the Adrar region (Gao and Timbuktu), and additional state funds were allocated for its development. Finally, the agreement stipulated the release of all prisoners.
Another round of talks mediated by Algeria was held in January 1992.

Another round of talks mediated by Algeria was held in March 1992. At the rounds of negotiations in January and March 1992, the Azawad Unified Movements and Fronts (MFUA), which was a newly formed umbrella-organization for the FIAA and several other rebel groups, negotiated on behalf of these groups.

Another round of negotiations in April 1992 led to the signing of the National Pact on 11 April 1992. Ahmed Baba Miske, a representative from Mauritania, and Edgar Pisani, a representative from France, also played a role in the mediation leading up to the National Pact. The National Pact was signed in Bamako, Mali, as a finalization of the Mopti Accord in 1991. The agreement established a new ceasefire, preventing any further troop movements and freezing the armed forces in their current locations. A military pact was formed, allowing voluntary integration of the Tuareg rebels into various branches of the armed forces, such as the military, police, or gendarmerie. Complete demilitarization of the North was planned. The agreement also modified Mali�s political structure by decentralizing authority to regional and sub-regional assemblies with executive powers. These assemblies had control over socio-economic, cultural, and budgetary aspects of governance. Special administrative structures were established for the Adrar region. To enhance representation, four seats in the assembly were designated for delegates from the Northern peoples of Mali. Efforts were made to integrate ex-rebels into different levels of government institutions, aiming for fuller inclusion of the Tuareg in the country�s political and economic spheres.

In 1994, Algeria mediated three rounds of negotiations between the Government of Mali on the one side and the MPA and the FIAA on the other side. The first round of negotiations mediated by Algeria in 1994 was held in Tamanrasset in April.
The second round of negotiations mediated by Algeria in 1994 was held in Algiers in May.

The third round of negotiations mediated by Algeria in 1994 was held in Tamanrasset in June. Instead of concluding a new peace agreement, Algeria offered to implement the 1992 National Pact peace agreement. Although negotiations took place throughout 1994, the role of Algeria as mediator in the conflict was officially confirmed at the Bamako Conference taking place in August 1994, which was attended by Algeria, Mali, Mauritania, Burkina Faso, Libya and Niger. The final document produced at this conference makes provision for security measures along the border and greater coordination among the countries of the region, but also stressed that Algeria is playing the role of mediator in the Tuareg conflict. The conflict ended when the FIAA declared a unilateral, permanent ceasefire via Algeria on 7 January 1995.

The first negotiations between the conflict parties took place in Tripoli in April 2007 and were mediated by the Gaddafi Foundation, which was a charitable organization chaired by Libyan leader Muammar al-Gaddafi�s son Saif al Islam. These talks led to a ceasefire, which also stipulated that the rebels were to release any soldiers being held hostage, while the Malian army was to partly withdraw from the Kidal area. The parties expressed in a joint statement that the ceasefire would create a climate of appeasement which would open the way for a dialogue to forge a final settlement. However, the ceasefire soon broke down with both parties accusing each other of not implementing it.
Negotiations without the involvement of a third party on 11 May 2007 did not lead to any tangible outcome.

In June 2007, the Malian Foreign Minister Moctar Ouane went to Algeria to meet with President Abdelaziz Bouteflika to request mediation by Algeria. Bouteflika agreed, after which Abdelkrim Ghrieb, the Algerian Ambassador to Mali, acted as the main mediator in peace talks in July 2007, which led to a new ceasefire on 21 July 2007.
On 31 August 2007, the conflict parties engaged in negotiations without the involvement of a third party. This led to a ceasefire, but this ceasefire did not appear to last.
On 19 September 2007, a temporary ceasefire was concluded in negotiations in which elected Tuareg officials served as mediators.
The Libyan government became involved in mediation in 2008. A round of preliminary negotiations took place in March 2008. The two sides agreed to negotiations in the first week of April.
During a round of negotiations in the first week of April, the conflict parties agreed to a ceasefire agreement in Tripoli on 3 April 2008.
Another ceasefire agreement was negotiated in Algiers on 21 July 2008, but this ceasefire failed to bring peace.
The Malian government engaged in another round of negotiations with the rebels in November 2008, but this round of negotiations failed. The government side defeated the insurgents by January 2009.

The FPLA took part in the Mouvements et Fronts Unifi�s de l�Azawad (MFUA) (English: United Movements and Fronts of Azawad), a rebel umbrella organization set up to form a united front during negotiations with the government. Algeria mediated between the government and the MFUA in a round of negotiations in January 1992.
Algeria mediated between the government and the MFUA in a round of negotiations in March 1992.

Another round of negotiations mediated by Algeria in April 1992 led to the signing of the National Pact on 11 April 1992. Ahmed Baba Miske, a representative from Mauritania, and Edgar Pisani, a representative from France, also played a role in the mediation leading up to the National Pact. The National Pact was signed in Bamako, Mali, as a finalization of the Mopti Accord in 1991. The agreement established a new ceasefire, preventing any further troop movements and freezing the armed forces in their current locations. A military pact was formed, allowing voluntary integration of the Tuareg rebels into various branches of the armed forces, such as the military, police, or gendarmerie. Complete demilitarization of the North was planned. The agreement also modified Mali�s political structure by decentralizing authority to regional and sub-regional assemblies with executive powers. These assemblies had control over socio-economic, cultural, and budgetary aspects of governance. Special administrative structures were established for the Adrar region. To enhance representation, four seats in the assembly were designated for delegates from the Northern peoples of Mali. Efforts were made to integrate ex-rebels into different levels of government institutions, aiming for fuller inclusion of the Tuareg in the country�s political and economic spheres. FPLA�s representative in MFUA was Zeidane ag Sidi Alamine, who was a relative of FPLA leader Rhissa ag Sidi Mohamed. Rhissa and Zeidane disagreed about whether or not to sign the National Pact when it was on the table. Rhissa continued to refuse to sign, but Zeidane travelled to Bamako to sign it on behalf of the FPLA. However, with Zeidane unable to exert influence over the fighters on the ground at this point in time, attacks on government targets continued. On 27 March 1996, the so-called Flame of Peace ceremony was held in Timbuktu to symbolically mark the end of the armed conflict. Around 3,000 decommissioned weapons were destroyed in a giant fire. Furthermore, Zeidane ag Sidalamine, representing not only FPLA, but the entire rebel movement in northeren Mali, announced the formal dissolution of all major rebel groups.
Algeria opened an unofficial process, bringing together the conflict parties several times during the first half of the year.

The MNLA met in Algiers with Malian Foreign Minister Soumeylou Boubeye Maiga on 2 February 2012, but this did not lead to an agreement. In early 2012, ECOWAS appointed Blaise Compaor�, president of Burkina Faso, as chief mediator in the Mali crisis in order to find a diplomatic solution to the conflict between the Government of Mali on the one side and Ansar Dine and the MNLA on the other side.

The MNLA had concluded an alliance with the Islamist insurgent group, Ansar Dine, which resulted in military successes and the MNLA had announced the creation of the independent state of Azawad on 6 April 2012. However, soon thereafter the tactical alliance broke down and Ansar Dine evicted MNLA from the towns in the region. By late 2012, most MNLA fighters were based in the countryside, attempting to regroup. On 4 December 2012, MNLA and Ansar Dine again met for a round of talks with Compaor� in Ouagadougou. The conflict parties agreed during this round of negotiations to end hostilities with the government.

In late 2012, Islamist groups started moving south towards Bamako. This prompted the Government of Mali to request French military support. On 11 January 2013, France launched Operation Serval. The peace process between the Government of Mali and the MNLA continued in spite of this intervention, with a round of negotiations taking place in Bamako on 13 February 2013.

Another round of mediated talks mediated by Blaise Compaor� was held in Ouagadougou between 8 and 10 June 2013 and brought together MNLA and Ansar Dine representatives. This round of negotiations focused on establishing an agenda for peace talks and led to the Ouagadougou Accord on 18 June 2013, which was a preliminary agreement that stipulated an immediate ceasefire, as well as commits the conflict parties to create the conditions for holding presidential elections and outlined the principles for future inclusive peace talks. The full name of this agreement is the Accord pr�liminaire � l��lection pr�sidentielle et aux pourparlers inclusifs de paix au Mali (English: Preliminary agreement for the presidential election and inclusive peace talks in Mali).

Between February and June 2014, consultations were held in Algeria, intended to bring together the many disparate groupings of the North under one unified front. MINUSMA facilitated three short workshops with representatives of the Government of Mali, local authorities, armed groups, and civil society in Algiers between 3 February and early March 2014. The conflict parties reaffirmed their willingness during these workshops to take part in an inclusive dialogue to reach a comprehensive settlement of the armed conflict. These workshops also resulted in the signing of a technical document on 18 February by all present. This document outlined the steps that needed to be taken to further the cantonment process. UN Security Council Resolution 2100 (2013), a February visit by its members, as well as the Ouagadougou Agreement informed the agreement�s timeframe for the cantonment process.
On 18 May 2014, a MINUSMA delegation led by mediator Major General Jean Bosco Kazura attempted to mediate a ceasefire between MNLA and the government in response to a recent episode of fighting.

UN envoy Albert Koenders and AU chairman President Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz of Mauritania managed to mediate a ceasefire between the rebels and government � the Accord de cessez-le-feu � in another round of negotiations in Kidal on 23 May 2014. This agreement committed the Government of Mali and the MNLA to immediately cease hostilities throughout Mali, as well as reconfirmed the preliminary agreement of Ouagadougou that had been signed on 18 June 2013. On 9 June 2014, the MNLA signed the Algiers Declaration in Algiers, stating their interest in collaborating with the government in a peace process.

On 16 June 2014, a high-level consultation on Mali attended by government representatives from the Sahel region mandated Algeria as the official mediator between the Malian government and the armed opposition groups in northern Mali. Concerted efforts by Algeria, the UN, the AU, ECOWAS, and other regional governments besides Algeria subsequently led to the launch of formal peace negotiations between the armed groups and the Government of Mali. The first round of official negotiations in what came to be known as the Algiers peace process between the Government of Mali and MNLA took place from 14 to 24 July 2014 in Algiers. The talks were supported by a mediation team led by Algeria � comprising the UN, ECOWAS, the AU, the OIC, the EU, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, and Chad. This round of negotiations focused on the security situation in northern Mali and the formulation of a road map for negotiations. The first round of negotiations led to the signing of the Feuille de route des negotiations dans le cadre du processus d�Alger, which includes a ceasefire and a road map for negotiations in the context of the Algiers peace process. The road map reaffirmed the need to respect Mali�s territorial integrity and secularism. The road map also provided a framework for future negotiations. Negotiations would focus on four distinct thematic areas: political and institutional issues, defence and security issues, economic development, social, and cultural issues, and reconciliation, justice and humanitarian issues. In the subsequent rounds of negotiations, the parties negotiated on the basis of this road map.
third_party: Algeria, AU, Burkina Faso, Chad, ECOWAS, EU, Mauritania, Niger, OIC, UN
agreement_name: Feuille de route des negotiations dans le cadre du processus d�Alger

description: A second round of negotiations mediated by Algeria and the wider mediation team took place in Algiers between 1 September and 23 September 2014. The mediation team shuttled between government representatives and the MNLA negotiation team during this round of negotiations. Both the conflict parties agreed on the territorial integrity of Mali, but the government delegation was only willing to consider �enhanced regionalization�, while the MNLA called for the establishment of a federal system in Mali.
third_party: Algeria, AU, Burkina Faso, Chad, ECOWAS, EU, Mauritania, Niger, OIC, UN

description: On 18 October 2014, the mediation team and government representatives from the region engaged in another round of negotiations with a high-level meeting to review and validate a document that had been drafted based on discussions during the second round of negotiations, entitled Elements for a Peace and Reconciliation Agreement in Mali.
third_party: Algeria, AU, Burkina Faso, Chad, ECOWAS, EU, Mauritania, Niger, OIC, UN

description: The third round of negotiations in Algiers was held between 21 and 23 October 2014. The conflict parties discussed the draft document of principles during this round of talks.
third_party: Algeria, AU, Burkina Faso, Chad, ECOWAS, EU, Mauritania, Niger, OIC, UN

description: The MNLA transformed into CMA in late October 2014, serving as a coalition of pro-independence groups. The fourth round of negotiations was held between 4 and 27 November 2014. The mediation team met separately with the parties to discuss the draft document of principles.
third_party: Algeria, AU, Burkina Faso, Chad, ECOWAS, EU, Mauritania, Niger, OIC, UN

description: From 22 to 24 November 2014, the mediation team organized another round of interactive dialogues between the government delegation and the CMA negotiators. On 26 November 2014, the mediation team presented the parties with a slightly revised text that included three annexes and was renamed the Draft Peace and Reconciliation Agreement in Mali. On 27 November 2014, the negotiation teams returned to Mali for consultation with their respective constituencies, with the understanding that their senior leaders would reconvene in Algiers in January 2015.
third_party: Algeria, AU, Burkina Faso, Chad, ECOWAS, EU, Mauritania, Niger, OIC, UN

description: The fifth round of peace talks, which was supposed to start in January 2015, was stalled due to military clashes. On 9 February, the CMA and the government agreed to a ceasefire as they prepared for this round.
third_party: Algeria, AU, Burkina Faso, Chad, ECOWAS, EU, Mauritania, Niger, OIC, UN

description: Negotiations eventually were held between 11 February and 1 March 2015 in Algiers. This round of talks led to drafting of a peace agreement, but the CMA negotiation team requested additional time to consult with its constituency before signing the agreement.
third_party: Algeria, AU, Burkina Faso, Chad, ECOWAS, EU, Mauritania, Niger, OIC, UN

description: Algerian Minister of Foreign Affairs Ramtane Lamamra subsequently shuttled between the Government of Mali and the CMA from 31 March to 5 April 2015.
A government delegation met with the CMA negotiation team in Algiers on 6 April 2015, but this meeting mediated by Lamamra did not lead to any tangible results.

Between 14 and 19 April 2015, the CMA delegation in Algiers maintained that it would sign the draft peace agreement if the mediator could guarantee that some outstanding issues would be addressed during the implementation process.

The Government of Mali and the CMA subsequently met in Algiers on 30 May 2015 for a new round of negotiations, while fighting continued in the north despite the previously concluded ceasefire. This round ended with the conflict parties signing the Relev� de Conclusions des Consultations Pr�paratoires � la mise en �uvre de l�Accord pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali Issu du Procesus d�Alger (English: Statement of Conclusions of the Preparatory Consultations for the Implementation of the Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation in Mali Arising from the Algiers Process) on 5 June, which addressed stipulated the creation of two regions in Mali, the integration of rebel fighters into the national army, and several arrangements to promote regional economic development. On the same day, the conflict parties also signed another ceasefire, the Arrangement s�curitaire pour une cessation des hostilit�s (English: Security Arrangements for a Cessation of Hostilities).
agreement_name: Relev� de Conclusions des Consultations Pr�paratoires a la mise en �uvre de l�Accord pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali Issu du Procesus d�Alger, Ceasefire (Arrangement s�curitaire pour une cessation des hostilit�s)

description: This paved the way for the CMA finally signing a comprehensive peace agreement in Bamako on 20 June 2015: the Accord Pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali - Issu du Processus d�Alger (English: Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation in Mali - Resulting from the Algiers Process), also referred to as the Bamako Agreement.
agreement_name: Accord Pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali - Issu du Processus d�Alger (Bamako Agreement)

description: A monitoring committee � the Comit� de Suivi du present Accord (CSA) � to oversee the implementation of the agreement was set up under the terms of the Bamako Agreement. The CSA comprises the Government of Mali, the CMA, Platform, as well as the mediation team chaired by Algeria and further including Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the United Nations, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, the African Union, and the European Union. The CSA met for negotiations on the implementation in Bamako between 3 and 5 July 2015.
third_party: Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU

description: Another round of negotiations between the members of the monitoring committee � the Comit� du Suivi du present Accord (CSA) � was held in late July 2015 to discuss the implementation process, but the members of the committee disagreed on certain stipulations of the implementation process, such as representation and responsibility sharing.
third_party: Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU

description: The CSA also met in August 2015.
third_party: Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU

description: The CSA�s efforts to implement the Bamako Peace Agreement continued in 2016. The CMA and the other non-state signatory to the agreement, Platform, were both unhappy with the slow pace of the implementation of the agreement. Hence, the signatories met in Bamako on 19-26 February 2016, but no progress was made. While the Government of Mali presented the measures that it had taken, including the creation of the M�naka and Taoudenni regions and the review of the Code des collectivit�s territoriales, the signatory armed groups, in a joint letter, deplored the lack of progress on the establishment of the interim administrations, reiterating the need for further efforts on institutional issues before moving forward on security and defense aspects.
third_party: Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU

description: Another meeting to discuss the implementation of the Bamako Agreement was held in New York on 23 September 2016, on the margins of the general debate of the seventy-first session of the UN General Assembly. The opening session of the meeting was chaired by the UN Secretary-General together with the President of Mali, Ibrahim Boubacar Keita. The goal of the meeting was to mitigate the tensions that had arisen surrounding the implementation of the Bamako Agreement between July and September 2016. Following the opening session, a meeting was co-chaired by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, International Cooperation and African Integration of Mali, Abdoulaye Diop, and the Minister of State, Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation of Algeria, Ramtane Lamamra, together with the UN Under-Secretary-General for Peacekeeping Operations. In the Co-Chairs� summary of the meeting, the signatories of the Bamako Agreement were urged to fully and sincerely maintain their commitments under the agreement and encouraged to take specific steps to swiftly implement the agreement.
third_party: Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU

description: Another meeting on the implementation of the agreement took place on 23 October 2016. During this meeting it was decided to start implementation of the agreement in November 2016, but this did not happen.
third_party: Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU

description: Another CSA meeting on the implementation of the agreement took place on 28 November 2016.
third_party: Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU

description: At another CSA meeting on 20 December 2016, the CMA representatives announced the suspension of its participation in the CSA because of a lack of progress in the implementation of the Bamako Agreement.
third_party: Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU

description: On 16 January 2017, MINUSMA mediated between government representatives and CMA leaders in Kidal to discuss a return of the CMA to the CSA.
third_party: Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU

description: Following a deadly terrorist attack in Gao on 18 January 2017 � which killed 54 members of a mixed patrol including forces from the government, Platform, and the CMA � the mediators tried to prevent a collapse of the peace process. An international mediation team, including ministers from the Governments of Algeria, Mauritania, and the Niger continued to urge CMA to continue its participation in the CSA. While a CSA meeting was held on 30 January in Bamako without the presence of CMA, the CMA remained involved in trying to set up mixed patrols in Gao. On 23 February, the signatory parties launched the first mixed patrols in Gao.
third_party: Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU

description: A conference for national harmony, the conf�rence d�entente nationale, was held in Bamako from 27 March to 2 April 2017. This conference adopted several recommendations, including, among others, the need to address governance and security issues in the central regions and a lack of inclusiveness in the peace process.
third_party: Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU

description: In June 2018, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 2423, calling for the signing of a �Pact for Peace� by the Malian parties. At a meeting in October 2018, the Malians parties signed this Pact for Peace, emphasizing the urgency of taking steps to �accelerate the full and inclusive implementation� of the agreement.

On 16 January 2018, a CSA meeting also attended by the CMA led to the endorsement of a timeline to accelerate the implementation of key provisions of the Bamako Agreement. By September 2018, signatory parties made some progress in the implementation of the Agreement, including the nomination of interim authorities at the district level, the creation of municipalities for the M�naka and Taoudenni regions, and the adoption of the national security sector reform strategy.
third_party: Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU

description: On 22 August 2019, the signatories to the 2015 peace agreement held a working session in Bamako. This meeting was chaired by the Minister of Social Cohesion, with support from the Carter Center, to examine in detail the progress made with regard to implementing the peace agreement.

A political crisis and the COVID-19 pandemic brought the implementation of the 2015 peace agreement to a standstill. The CSA held its first-ever meetings outside of Bamako, namely in Kidal, in February 2021. The CSA comprises the Government of Mali, the CMA, Platform, as well as the mediation team chaired by Algeria and further including Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the United Nations, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, the African Union, and the European Union.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Another CSA meeting was held in Kayes in March 2021. However, shortly after this meeting, two specific events further stymied the implementation process during the first half of 2021. First, on 13 April 2021, CMA leader Sidi Brahim Ould Sidat was assassinated. Second, a second coup d��tat took place on 24 May 2021.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: According to the Carter Center, which acted as the official observer of the implementation process of the Agreement on Peace and Reconciliation in Mali concluded in 2015, the implementation had reached a state of unprecedented impasse in its seventh year. The CSA met in October 2021, but this meeting ended when intense disagreements broke out among the signatories. After this meeting, the work of the CSA and its various subgroups was suspended.

From 30 January to 3 February 2022, Ara Pacis Initiatives for Peace, an Italian non-profit organization, mediated peace talks between the CMA, Platform, and representatives from the transitional Government, with the Minister for National Reconciliation being part of the government team. The purpose of these talks was to address ongoing tensions between the signatory parties to the Algiers Accord. The talks also focused on disagreement surrounding the Cadre strat�gique permanent (CSP) (English: Permanent strategic coalition).

The signatories to the 2015 peace agreement held a working session in Bamako on 16-17 February 2022. The working session was chaired by the Minister of Social Cohesion, with support from the Carter Center, to examine in detail the progress made with regard to implementing the peace agreement.

On 16 March 2022, the signatories to the Algiers Accord met in Gao to address their ongoing disagreements, particularly regarding the creation and mission of the Cadre strat�gique permanent (CSP) (English: Permanent strategic coalition), which was formed by the CMA and Platform to strengthen the relations between them, but was also envisioned as a key security provider in the northern regions. The Government of Mali insisted that security matters should remain under the state�s authority and that any concerns raised by the movements should be resolved within the framework of the peace agreement. However, there was no concrete resolution reached.

Although the CSA did no longer meet, the Technical Security Commission (CTS) � tasked with monitoring the ceasefire, investigating potential violations, and monitoring security arrangements � met on 31 March 2022.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Although the CSA did no longer meet, the Technical Security Commission (CTS) � tasked with monitoring the ceasefire, investigating potential violations, and monitoring security arrangements � met on 16 June 2022.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: A high-level decision-making meeting was held in Bamako from 1 to 5 August 2022, attended by the Prime Minister, ministers, the High Representative of the transitional President for the implementation of the Agreement, and leaders of the signatory movements. The members of the international mediation team and the Carter Center, acting as the Independent Observer, were also present at this meeting. During this meeting, the Malian parties reached an agreement on the integration of ex-combatants into the national defense and security forces and the public administration in two phases.
The CSA, having been inactive since October 2021, restarted by initiating a ministerial meeting on 2 September 2022.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Consultations were held among the signatories of the Algiers Accord in Bamako on 9 and 10 January 2023 to discuss the way forward regarding the peace agreement. The former Minister for Foreign Affairs of Algeria, Ramtane Lamamra acted as the mediator.

The international mediation team � including Algeria, the UN, ECOWAS, the AU, the EU, France, and the US � shuttled between the conflict parties in February 2023. On 1 February 2023, the international mediation team met with the CMA leadership in Kidal to discuss the viability of the Algiers Accord concluded in 2015. On 13 February 2023, the international mediation team held discussions with the Platform and the Mouvements de l�inclusivit� in Bamako. The international mediation team conducted a meeting with government officials on 14 February 2023. Following these meetings, the international mediation team called on the parties on 20 February 2023, to demonstrate renewed commitment and to refrain from any statements or actions that could further complicate the situation and efforts for the early holding of a high-level session of the CSA.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: The Minister for Foreign Affairs of Algeria, Ahmed Attaf, visited Bamako from 23 to 25 April 2023 to urge the signatory parties to fully adhere to the proposals made by the international mediation team.

The Minister for Reconciliation, Peace, and National Cohesion, Colonel-Major Isma�l Wagu�, met with representatives of the CMA and Platform in Kidal on 12 May 2023 to rebuild confidence and facilitate the resumption of the work of the monitoring mechanisms. However, tensions increased and the Platform movements left the CSP in September 2023.

On 21 November 2023, the Minister for Reconciliation, Colonel-Major Isma�l Wagu�, travelled to Kidal for consultations with relevant CMA stakeholders and visited the reconstituted battalion. However, tensions continued to increase. On 25 January 2024, Mali�s governing junta announced the abrupt end of the 2015 Algiers Accord. The junta attributed this sudden decision to a �shift in stance among some of the agreement�s signatory groups� and �acts of aggression and manipulation of the accord by the Algerian government.�

In June 1994, negotiations between the CRA and the Government of Niger began in Paris. France served as mediator, together with Algeria and Burkina Faso. After the talks, the government agreed to meet the CRA demands for autonomy for Tuareg regions, which would be governed by elected assemblies and governors. The government agreed, in principle, to the carving out of a new administrative map, taking account of �cultural and social homogeneity.� The agreement also included a quota system which would guarantee Tuaregs a fair share of government jobs and military positions.

In October 1994, the negotiations resumed in Ouagadougou, where Burkina Faso initially solely hosted the meetings with no external mediators involved in the talks, but later mediators from France and Algeria joined and participated in the talks. The talks led to the signing of the Ouagadougou Accord on 9 October 1994. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire, but also stated that the issues of defence and internal security would be dealt with at a later stage of the negotiations. The agreement emphasized that Niger was unitary and indivisible, but also contained amendments to the political-territorial structure of Niger, rearranging the country into smaller entities of political control. Finally, the accord included provisions with regard the facilitation of the return and resettlement of refugees.

The CRA experienced internal tensions in early 1995, which resulted in Front de lib�ration de Tamoust (FLT) (English: Tamoust Liberation Front) leaving the umbrella organisation in June 1995. Nevertheless, negotiations took place between the CRA and the Government of Niger in March 1995. These negotiations were mediated by Laala Mohamed and Alain Deschamps, an Algerian and a French mediator respectively, as well as the Foreign Minister of Burkina Faso, Ablass� Ouedraogo.

Another round of negotiations mediated by these third parties took place in April 1995. This led to the signing of a comprehensive peace agreement in Niamey on 24 April 1995. The agreement had several key points. First, it declared a ceasefire and confirmed the previous ceasefire established in 1994. Second, it required the restructuring of Niger�s armed forces by integrating rebel fighters into the government army. Third, it included measures for decentralizing Niger�s political system. The agreement specifically focused on promoting the economic, social, and cultural development of the Tuareg areas. To oversee the agreement�s implementation, a peace committee was established. Additionally, the government announced a general amnesty and initiated a resettlement program to assist those who were displaced, both within the country and externally.

Negotiations and third party involvement with regard to the implementation of the agreement continued throughout the year. On 25 May 1995, the Special Peace Committee set up to implement the peace agreement signed in Niamey met for the first time to discuss issues related to the implementation of the agreement.

During another meeting of the Special Peace Committee on 9 September 1995, CRA leaders threatened to resume armed struggle of the government if it did not meet its commitments stipulated in the peace agreement signed in April 1995.

At another meeting in November 1995, following a clash in which one Tuareg was killed, both the government and the CRA reaffirmed their commitment to peace agreement. This meeting came after the most serious clash since the April Peace Accord was signed.

In late 1995, the Burkinabe Prime Minister Roch Marc Christian Kabor� called on the Tuareg factions to hold the peace after new clashes had occurred in December 1995. The French co-operation minister Jacques Godfrain subsequently held talks with officials of the Government of Niger on the Tuareg peace-process in December, after which France gave a 40,000 US Dollar grant for policing the Tuareg. On 28 December 1995, France, together with Burkina Faso and Algeria, announced that they ended their involvement in the peace process on 31 December 1995, but that they would still respond to any requests of peace negotiations.

On 18 March 1996, the transitional government recognized the CRA as a political party. On 17 December 1996, the government held some peace talks with the CRA and other Tuareg groups. This led to the signing of an agreement providing for the return to barracks of former Tuareg fighters, which was agreed to precede the integration of the former Tuareg rebels back into the regular army.

As early as 14 October 1990, the Belgium Prime Minister Wilfried Martens, aided by his Foreign Minister and Defence Minister, travelled to Kigali to �halt the offensive and seek a peaceful solution within the framework of the OAU.� Martens discussed the conflict with Rwandan President Habyarimana, Ugandan President Museveni, Zairian President Mobuto, and Tanzanian President Mwinyi. Belgium also tried to initiate negotiations between the conflict parties, yet as the Government of Rwanda claimed that the conflict was an interstate conflict with the FPR being Uganda�s proxy army rather than an independent insurgent group supported by Uganda, the Government of Rwanda refused to engage in mediated negotiate with the FPR. Moreover, the FPR demanded the direct resignation of President Habyarimana.

The Belgian peace initiative was followed by several ad hoc summits organised by both the Communaut� �conomique des Pays des Grand Lacs (CEPGL) (English: Economic Community of the Great Lakes Countries) and the OAU. The first ad-hoc summit was the Mwanza summit on 17 October attended by the Presidents of Tanzania, Rwanda, and Uganda.
The second ad-hoc summit was the Gbadolite summit on 26 October attended by the Presidents of Zaire, Rwanda, and Burundi.
To signal their respect of the ongoing peace efforts, Rwanda and FPR concluded a ceasefire agreement, without any direct negotiations between them, on 24 October 1990.

The third ad-hoc summit was the Goma summit on 20 November attended by the Presidents of Zaire, Rwanda, and Burundi, as well as the third deputy Prime Minister of Uganda. The Zairian President Mobutu Sese Seko acted as the chief mediator of the countries in the region during these three summits. Mobutu�s appointment was in large part based on the idea that he could prevail over Habyarimana, thus delivering the agreement of the conflict party that the mediator favoured. Although no real attempts to bring the FPR in seemed to be made, talks were held between Ugandan President Museveni and Habyarimana, where the former promised to put pressure on the FPR to commit to a ceasefire. In addition, most of the regional conferences focused on the refugee problem, which was at least in part due to the perception that the refugee problem forced the FPR into Rwanda.

Meetings between countries in the region continued to be held in early 1991 through the efforts of both the CEPGL and the OAU, in which the participants discussed the refugee situation, as well as the possibility of the deployment of a neutral peacekeeping force in Rwanda. A summit was held in Zanzibar on 17 February 1991.
Another summit was held in Dar-es-Salaam on 19 February.

While little effort was made to include the FPR in negotiations during the summits in 1990, the regional leaders persuaded President Habyarimana to engage in peace talks with the FPR leadership during the summits in early 1991. At the Dar-es-Salaam summit on 19 February, a declaration was drafted in which President Mobutu was thanked �for his efforts in instituting a dialogue between the Rwandan government and the armed opposition� and urged him to �maintain the momentum of the dialogue.� The Declaration further committed the conflict parties to �find a definitive and durable solution to the problem.� Accordingly, the Government of Rwanda and the FPR met for the first time in March 1991. Under Mobutu�s mediation, the conflict parties agreed to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 17 March 1991, which was signed by Rwandan Foreign Minister Casimir Bizimugu and FPR vice-Chairman Paul Kagame in N�Sele on 29 March 1991. This agreement stipulated a ceasefire and the deployment of a Neutral Military Observer Group, comprised of personnel from Nigeria, Senegal, Zimbabwe, the OAU, and representatives of the warring parties. The agreement � referred to as the N�Sele Ceasefire Agreement � did not include provisions on how to resolve the conflict issues. Instead, the document included a short agenda for future talks, specifying that rule of law and democracy should be created, that the formation of a new national army should commence, and that power-sharing arrangements need to be established. The ceasefire did not hold, with government forces attacking FPR forces almost immediately after the Neutral Military Observer Group was deployed on 7 May 1991.

At the OAU�s annual summit in June 1991, it was decided to reactivate the peace process, after which an OAU summit aimed at finding a solution to the crisis was organised in Gbadolite, Zaire, on 7 September.

Direct talks between the Rwandan Government and the FPR continued in Gbadolite between 15 and 17 September 1991. Zairian President Mobutu acted as mediator at these talks, which ended with the parties expressing their commitment to the N�Sele Ceasefire Agreement. The Gbadolite Ceasefire did not hold.

On 7 April 1992, a coalition Government was set up, which was a result of a compromise President Habyarimana made with the political opposition in Rwanda. The new Government of Rwanda was mandated to directly negotiate with the FPR. In 1992, the US Assistant Secretary of State for Africa, Herman Cohen, undertook a round of shuttle negotiations to push for mediated negotiations. The first meeting took place in Kampala on 8 and 9 May with Ugandan President Museveni and the FPR leadership.
The second meeting took place in Kigali on 10 and 11 May with Rwandan Government officials and political opposition leaders.

On his trip to Rwanda, Cohen reportedly persuaded Rwandan Foreign Minister Boniface Ngulinzira to explore the option of negotiations by pointing out that these could be held without any preconditions. Consequently, Ngulinzira met with the FPR vice-chairman Patrick Mazimpaka for a round of negotiations mediated by the US in Kampala on 24 May 1992.

This led to a round of pre-negotiations between the Rwandan government and the FPR in Paris between 3 and 6 June 1992. After the pre-negotiations in Paris it was agreed that comprehensive negotiations would start on 10 July 1992 under Tanzania�s mediation. At the invitation of the Director of African Affairs at the French Foreign Ministry, Henri Dijoud, Herman Cohen had been present in Paris too. Cohen put significant pressure on the conflict parties to start official negotiations. Crucially, he put pressure on Uganda to push the FPR to accept negotiations. Cohen expressed to Ugandan Foreign Minister Paul Ssemmogere that the continuing civil war in Rwanda is not without costs and that the United States and the donor community are �devoting considerable resources to the care of hundreds of thousands of displace Rwandans�, he then continued by pointing out that Uganda was the recipient of major bilateral aid and that if the Rwandan negotiations did not move forward soon, it would �be necessary to finance continued assistance to the internally displaced by reducing assistance to Uganda.�

Parallel to the talks in Paris in early June 1992, several representatives of the FPR met with a delegation of the Rwandan political opposition parties in Brussels, under the auspices of Belgian representatives.
Prior to the OAU�s annual summit in June the conflict parties met in Dakar, Senegal, and confirmed their commitment to comprehensive negotiations in Arusha, as agreed in Paris.
third_party: US, France, Belgium, DR Congo (Zaire), Tanzania, Burundi, Uganda

description: The first round of negotiations in Arusha started on 10 July 1992. This led to the signing of a temporary ceasefire agreement. This followed three more days of peace talks. Although Zairian President Mobutu was present at the first round of the negotiations in Arusha, the Tanzanian mediation team was most actively involved in the negotiations. In fact, at the meeting in Gbadolite in September 1991, the Tanzanian President Ali Hassan Mwinyi had been mandated by the regional countries to mediate. While Mobuto officially continued to be the mediator, Mwinyi officially was appointed the chief facilitator. Hence, although Mobutu continued to be the chief mediator on paper, Miwinyi in reality assumed the role of chief mediator. Mobutu became increasingly less active from the second round of the Arusha talks onwards and the first three rounds of negotiations in June, July, and August were primarily led by the Tanzanian Minister of Foreign Affairs Hassan Ahmed, aided by Ami Mpungwe, who worked for the Tanzanian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The first three rounds focused on the implementation of the new ceasefire, as well as the integration of the FPR in the army and the issues of democracy and national unity.
The second round of negotiations in late July led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 31 July 1992.
The third round of negotiations in Arusha took place in August 1992, but did not lead to any results.
In October 1992, during a fourth round of negotiations, a partial accord on power sharing was signed in Arusha.

However, during peace talks in November 1992, the parties failed to agree on the creation of a neutral zone for the OAU observers, as well as on the issue of repatriation of refugees, the participation of the FPR in the transitional government, and the final incorporation of the FPR in the Rwandan army.

Another round of negotiations started in January 1993. This led to the signing of a protocol on power sharing in Arusha. However, President Habyarimana�s political party the Mouvement r�publicain national pour la d�mocratie et le d�velopement (MRND) (English: National Republican Movement for Democracy and Development) immediately rejected the agreement. This round of negotiations subsequently broke down in early February 1993.

A month later, in March 1993, new peace talks were convened in Arusha, in which the Tanzanian President Ali Hassan Mwinyi acted as the chief mediator. The talks focused on the structure of the Rwandan armed forces, but the parties could not reach an agreement on this issue. Nevertheless, the conflict parties signed a ceasefire on 7 March 1993.
Another round of negotiations mediated by Mwinyi in Arusha in April also failed to resolve the issue of the structure of the future Rwandan armed forces.

A new round of negotiations started in Kinihira in May 1993. During this round of peace talks, progress was made. A timetable for the demobilisation of the 19,000 troops of security forces was agreed upon. Consensus was also reached on the creation of a neutral zone to be observed by the OAU observer group. Moreover, an agreement was signed for the establishment of transitional structures and the demilitarisation of Kigali.
Negotiations mediated by Tanzania in Arusha in June 1993 led to the conclusion of a protocol for the repatriation of all Rwandan refugees resident in Uganda, Tanzania, and Zaire.

The final round of negotiations in Arusha took place in August 1993 and led to the signing of the Arusha Accord on 4 August 1993. This agreement included all the provisions agreed upon during the Arusha talks from July 1992 onwards.

In 1994, the UN and the OAU initiated several attempts to negotiate ceasefires during the ongoing genocide. On 8 April 1994, the two sides reached a 48-hour ceasefire agreement during negotiations in Kigali.
Two other ceasefire agreements were reached during negotiations between 12 and 13 April 1994.
On 5 May 1994, General Rom�o Dallaire, the Force Commander of the UN peacekeeping mission in Rwanda, brokered a ceasefire between the FPR and Rwandan government.
On 6 May 1994, the two sides reached a ceasefire in Gbadolite, as well as agreed on another round of peace talks two days later.
The negotiations on 8 May 1994 were without results.
Ahead of the arrival of the UN special envoy, a temporary truce was brokered between the conflict parties on 22 May.

Another round of negotiations between representatives of the Government of Rwanda and the FPR was held at the UNAMIR headquarters on 30 May 1994. Force Commander of UNAMIR, Rom�o Dallaire, acted as the mediator during these talks. The UN Security Council had earlier in May imposed an arms embargo on Rwanda.
In June 1994, the OAU organised a meeting on situation in Rwanda in Tunis, but the FPR did not attend. Instead, Uganda represented the FPR.
On 13 June 1994, the Government of Rwanda and the FPR attended a round of ceasefire talks mediated by the UN in Kigali.
A day later, on 14 June 1994, a round of negotiations mediated by Zaire led to the signing of another ceasefire agreement.

No negotiations have taken place between the Government of Rwanda and ALiR. However, on 3 June 2000, negotiations took place between DRC President Kabila and Rwandan President Kagame in Eldoret in Kenya. The talks were mediated by Kenyan President arap Moi, with support from diplomats from the UN and the OAU. The talks were aimed at ending the Congolese support to ALiR and ending the Rwandan support to the RCD.

The FDLR repeatedly called for an inter-Rwandan dialogue, but the Government of Rwanda continued to refuse to talk to any group connected to the genocide. However, talks occasionally did take place between Rwanda and Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). On 30 July 2002, Rwandan and Congolese presidents, Kagame and Kabila signed an accord in Pretoria under Mbeki�s watch. Kabila pledged to disarm and arrest Rwandan Hutu militias in return for Rwandan troops withdrawing.

On 12 September 2002, Presidents Kabila and Kagame met with US President Bush on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly meeting in New York. They were joined by chief mediator South African President Mbeki. The talks focused on the status of Rwandan troop withdrawal from the DRC and the disarmament and repatriation of armed Rwandan groups based in the DRC, most notably the FDLR.

On 18 September 2002, officials of the governments of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and Rwanda, and representatives of the third parties � South Africa and the UN � met in the Rwandan capital, Kigali, to discuss the status of Rwandan troop withdrawal from the DRC and the disarmament and repatriation of armed Rwandan groups based in the DRC, most notably the FDLR.

On 1 November 2002, Presidents Kabila and Kagame met in Pretoria for talks mediated by President Mbeki of South Africa. The talks focused on the implementation of the Pretoria Accord signed on 30 July 2002, which stipulated that the DRC would disarm and arrest Rwandan Hutu militias in return for Rwandan troops withdrawing from the DRC. Kabila and Kagame agreed to give each other another 90 days to implement the peace deal.

On 20 October 2003, Rwandan Foreign Minister Charles Murigande arrived in Kinshasa for talks with the Congolese government. The talks were aimed at restoring normal ties and ending Congolese support to the FDLR.

On 27 November 2003, Presidents Kabila and Kagame met in Pretoria for a round of talks mediated by President Mbeki. The talks focused on the implementation of the Pretoria Accord signed on 30 July 2002, which stipulated that the DRC would disarm and arrest Rwandan Hutu militias in return for Rwandan troops withdrawing from the DRC. The meeting was also attended by UN and AU representatives. Kabila and Kagame agreed to finish implementing the Pretoria Accord within 12 months.

On 6 July 2004, on the sidelines of an AU summit, a mini-summit was held in Addis Ababa to ease tensions between the DRC and Rwanda. It was attended by President Kagame and the DRC Foreign Minister representing President Kabila, who did not attend after the AU published a report critical of him. Presidents Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, Domitien Ndayizeye of Burundi and Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique, who was also the outgoing chairman of the AU, acted as mediators. The talks focused, among others, on the DRC ending its support to the FDLR.

On 25 August 2004, the foreign ministers of the DRC and Rwanda met in Munyonyo in Uganda. The negotiations were mediated by Uganda�s defense minister, with support from US diplomats. The DRC delegation agreed to end support to the FDLR rebels and disarm them. The talks were sponsored by the US.

On 22 and 23 September 2004, meetings involving senior DRC and Rwandan officials, including President Kabila, were held at the UN Headquarters in New York. UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan was involved as a mediator in these talks, alongside US diplomats. The talks resulted in the signing of the Joint Verification Mechanism (JVM) on 22 September 2004 and the Memorandum of Intent (MOI) on Regional Security in the Great Lakes of Africa on 23 September 2004 by the Foreign Ministers of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and Rwanda, and the Defense Minister of Uganda. The Joint Verification Mechanism (JVM) was established to create a cooperative framework for monitoring and verifying allegations of cross-border incursions and the presence of hostile forces in the eastern DRC and along the borders with Rwanda and Uganda. The primary objective of the JVM was to build trust between the DRC, Rwanda, and Uganda by providing a transparent mechanism to investigate claims of military activity or support for rebel groups across their borders. The JVM was composed of representatives from the DRC, Rwanda, and Uganda, as well as observers from the international community, including the UN, the AU, and other regional organizations. The mechanism allowed for joint inspections and verification missions to investigate reported incidents or movements of armed groups in the border areas. The parties agreed to share information and cooperate in addressing any violations or security threats identified through the JVM. The Memorandum of Intent (MOI) on Regional Security in the Great Lakes of Africa was a broader agreement aimed at enhancing regional cooperation on security matters. The MOI aimed to foster collaboration among the DRC, Rwanda, and Uganda to combat armed groups, including foreign and domestic militias operating in the eastern DRC, such as the FDLR and the LRA.
agreement_name: Joint Verification Mechanism (JVM), Memorandum of Intent (MOI) on Regional Security in the Great Lakes of Africa

description: On 5 October 2004, DRC and Rwandan delegations led by senior government officials met in Kigali to set up the Joint Verification Mechanism (JVM) that had been agreed upon the previous month in New York. Ambassador William Swing, head of the UN peacekeeping mission in the DRC, attended the meeting.

At a meeting in Kigali on 26 October 2004, the DRC, Rwanda, and Uganda signed the Tripartite Commission Agreement. This agreement deals with security issues and calls for cooperation in neutralizing armed groups, including the FDLR.  The US and the UN were involved as mediators in this initiative.

On 19 and 20 November 2004, Presidents Kabila and Kagame attended the Conference on the Great Lakes Region in Dar es Salaam, hosted by the Tanzanian President, with support from the UN and the AU. The final document signed at the conference � the Dar-es-Salaam Declaration on Peace, Security, Democracy and Development in the Great Lakes Region � obliged its signatories to �halt all direct and indirect� support to armed groups in the region. The document thus stipulated an end to the Congolese support to the FDLR.
agreement_name: Dar-es-Salaam Declaration on Peace, Security, Democracy and Development in the Great Lakes Region

description: Tensions between Rwanda and the DRC increased after Rwanda claimed that the FDLR had launched a rocket attacks from the DRC into Rwanda on 15 November 2004. In mid-December 2004, EU cooperation and development commissioner Louis Michael mediated a round of shuttle talks between the DRC and Rwanda, visiting the DRC on 18 December 2004 and Rwanda on 19 December 2004. Michael focused on ending Congolese support to the FDLR during his talks with Congolese government representatives. Michael managed to convince Rwanda to withdraw its threat to invade the DRC.

At a two-day AU summit in January 2005, the AU Peace and Security Council discussed the conflict between Rwanda and the DRC and urged the DRC to end their support to the FDLR and disarm FDLR forces. The AU also decided to send troops to the region in order to help the DRC disarm the FDLR.

The US mediated between the foreign ministers of Rwanda, Uganda and the DRC in Washington in late January 2005. The negotiations that took place in Washington were aimed at ending Congolese support to the FDLR and promote cooperation and trust between the countries. As a result of these negotiations, the Rwanda-DRC Joint Border Verification Mechanisms was launched on 8 February 2005.

On 2 February 2005, the US hosted a meeting of the Tripartite Joint Commission in Washington, DC. The Tripartite Commission was formed to implement previous agreements on ending support to rebel groups, including Congolese support to the FDLR. Foreign ministers of Rwanda and Uganda, Congo�s minister of regional cooperation, and the defense minister of Uganda participated meeting. The meeting was mediated by Assistant US Secretary of State Constance Newman. Representatives of the EU, the AU, and the UN supported the US mediation effort.

The FDLR repeatedly called for an inter-Rwandan dialogue, but the Government of Rwanda continued to refuse to talk to any group connected to the genocide. Although the Government of Rwanda did not participate in these talks, a FDLR delegation went to Rome in March 2005 to discuss their disarmament with the Community of Sant�Egidio as a mediator. While Rwanda did not participate in these one-sided negotiations, the Democratic Republic of Congo did participate in the meeting. At the end of the meeting, the FDLR leadership issued a declaration that it would disarm and demobilize in May 2005 and transform into a political party. It was further agreed that it would repatriate to Rwanda in June 2005. In August 2005, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Rwanda, and Uganda gave the FDLR until 30 September to disarm or face possible military action. FDLR reaffirmed their commitment to the Rome Declaration in September 2005, but they again pressed the necessity of accompanying measures to be taken by Rwanda. However, the Government of Rwanda rejected any direct negotiations involving the FDLR. From this moment onwards, no more negotiations involving the FDLR have taken place. In fact, Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo began to cooperate militarily from late 2008 onwards to attack the FDLR.

On 21 and 22 April 2005, Congolese, Rwandan, and Ugandan ministers met in Lubumbashi for a US-sponsored Tripartite Commission meeting. The Tripartite Commission was formed to implement previous agreements on ending support to rebel groups, including Congolese support to the FDLR. The Congolese delegation confirmed its commitment to end support to the FDLR and facilitate the repatriation of the FDLR to Rwanda.

On 25 and 26 August 2005, the DRC, Rwanda, and Uganda met in Kigali for a US-facilitated Tripartite Commission meeting. The Tripartite Commission was formed to implement previous agreements on ending support to rebel groups, including Congolese support to the FDLR. The Congolese delegation confirmed its commitment to end support to the FDLR and facilitate the repatriation of the FDLR to Rwanda.

On 16 September 2005, at a meeting held in New York, Burundi was included in the Tripartite Joint Commission, which previously consisted solely of Rwanda, the DRC, and Uganda. The renamed Tripartite Plus Joint Commission continued to serve as a platform for implementing previous agreements on ending support to rebel groups in the region. The commission representatives agreed that military and diplomatic pressure on all militias on the member States� territories would be continued to ensure their disarmament and repatriation or reintegration, and that sanctions would be imposed on such armed groups should they refuse to disarm voluntarily before 30 September 2005.

On 20 and 21 October 2005, the Tripartite Plus Commission met in Kampala. This commission served as a platform for implementing previous agreements on ending support to rebel groups in the region. In the presence of US Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs Donald Yamamoto, ministers and senior officials from Burundi, the DRC, Rwanda, and Uganda agreed to seek from foreign states punitive measures, including financial restrictions and visa bans, against members of nine rebel groups operating in the region.

On 20 and 21 April 2006, the Tripartite Plus Joint Commission met in Bujumbura. This meeting took place in the context of support provide by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. The meeting ended with a call for UN and AU sanctions to be imposed on rebel groups operating in the eastern DRC. The US acted as mediator.

On 26 and 27 May 2006, the Tripartite Plus Commission met in Kigali. This meeting took place in the context of support provide by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. The parties agreed on a provisional list of rebel chiefs on whom they wanted sanctions imposed for destabilizing the region. The meeting in Kigali, the third between the four countries in the space of two months, was facilitated by US Deputy Assistant Secretary for African Affairs Donald Yamamoto.

The DRC and Rwanda were among the signatories of the Pact on Security, Stability and Development in the Great Lakes Region at an international summit in Nairobi on 15 December 2006. This agreement, among others, included provisions on non-aggression and mutual defense. This makes the agreement relevant in relation to the support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda.
agreement_name: Pact on Security, Stability and Development in the Great Lakes Region

description: On 15 and 16 March 2007, the Tripartite Plus Commission met in Kigali. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. Ministers from the four countries reiterated their commitment to end rebel activities in the region.

On 18 April 2007, top military officials from Burundi, the DRC, Rwanda, and Uganda held a Tripartite Plus Commission meeting in Bujumbura. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support.

In early June 2007, the Tripartite Plus Commission met in Lubumbashi. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support.

On 27 and 28 August 2007, top military officials of the Tripartite Plus Commission met in Kigali. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. Opening the talks, Rwandan Foreign Affairs Minister Charles Murigande criticized the DRC for stopping military action against the FDLR.

DRC President Kabila and Rwandan President Kagame met on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly in New York in September 2007 and asked the UN for support in removing foreign rebel groups from the DRC. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending support they respectively provided to the FDLR and the CNDP.

The Tripartite Plus Commission met in Kampala between 15 and 17 September 2007. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support.

The Tripartite Plus Commission met in Kinshasa in late September 2007. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. Rwanda raised concerns about the lack of Congolese action against the FDLR during the meeting.

Following a round of negotiations mediated by the UN, Rwanda and the DRC signed the Nairobi Communiqu� on 9 November 2007. The agreement specified a common approach to deal with the FDLR. The Government of the DRC agreed to end support to the FDLR and design a plan to disarm the FDLR.

President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, President Paul Kagame of Rwanda, President Pierre Nkurunziza of Burundi, and Minister of State for Interior Denis Kalume, representing President Joseph Kabila of the DRC, met in Addis Ababa on 5 December 2007 for a Tripartite Plus Joint Commission meeting. US Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice acted as the mediator during this meeting. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. The parties agreed at the end of the meeting that �No member state will harbor any Negative Forces. Participants recommitted to deny safe haven or support to any Negative Forces.�

In late March 2008, the Tripartite Plus Commission met in Bujumbura to discuss efforts against rebel groups in the region. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending support to rebel groups.

Chiefs of defence staff of the Tripartite Plus Joint Commission member states approved an operational plan to be used in stopping rebel groups � including the FDLR and the CNDP � operating in the DRC at a meeting in Kigali on 20 June 2008.

On 28 October 2008, newly appointed DRC Foreign Minister Alexis Thambwe Mwamba met Rwandan President Kagame in Kigali and delivered a special message from President Kabila. The meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support.

On 4 December 2008, government representatives of the DRC and Rwanda signed the so-called �Four on Four Agreement� that specified that the Congolese government forces would end their military support of the FDLR and would, with support from the Rwandan government forces, forcefully disarm the FDLR. In the framework of the so-called �four plus four� mechanism in which four Rwandan officials met several times with their Congolese counterparts, the Rwandan and the DRC governments planned a joint military operation, called �Umoja Wetu� (English: Our Unity) to root out the FDLR. The joint operation lasted for one month in 2009 and ended with Rwanda withdrawing at the end of February 2009. In return for the Congolese support, Rwanda agreed to end its support for the CNDP and even helped the DRC to arrest CNDP leader Nkunda in Rwanda on 22 January 2009.

Negotiations between Rwanda and the DRC at the Ihusi Hotel in Goma in January 2009 led to a formal rapprochement in the form of the signing of the Ihusi Agreement on 16 January 2009. The agreement committed Rwanda to ending its support to the CNDP and arresting CNDP leader Nkunda, while it committed the DRC to end support to the FDLR and help the Rwanda attack the FDLR forces in the DRC.
Negotiations between the Senegalese government and the MFDC led to a ceasefire on 29 March 1991.

In May 1991, negotiations, mediated by Guinea-Bissau, led to the signing of the Bissau Accord. This accord called for a ceasefire, as well as the release of hundreds of Casaman�e detainees, among them the political leaders of MFDC. However, the accord mainly focused on a ceasefire and failed to address any of the conflict issues, including the status of Casamance.

A peace commission was established in January 1992. The commission comprised representatives of the Government and the MFDC, but mediators from Guinea-Bissau were also active in the commission throughout 1992.

On 8 April 1993, the leader of the MFDC, Diamacounce Senghor, called for a ceasefire between the parties to take effect on 10 April 1993, while calling for negotiations with France as mediator. However, the government responded with heavy clashes on 18 and 19 April 1993, after which it also called for a ceasefire with the rebels on 27 April 1993. Senegal�s Minister of Defence, Madieng Khary Dieng, and the leader of MFDC, Diamacoune Senghor, conducted a round of negotiations in early July 1993 and signed a ceasefire agreement on 8 July 1993. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire, the release of Casaman�e prisoners, the non-reinforcement of government troops in Casaman�e, and the free return of refugees.

In September 1995, a new peace commission was established, the Commission nationale de paix, which sought dialogue with the MFDC. The commission engaged in some preliminary talks in September 1995. It was proposed that more preliminary discussions would take place in January 1996 to be followed by formal peace negotiations.

The proposed preliminary discussions within the context of the Commission nationale de paix took place on 8 January 1996, but the peace negotiations were postponed indefinitely. A first meeting between MFDC leader Abbe Diamacoune Senghor, the Secretary-General of the MFDC, and several members of this commission was held the day before. At this meeting, Senghor handed over a proposal which demanded immunity for the delegates who are assigned to the negotiations. The proposal also includes an MFDC demand that negotiations take place in a neutral country. The government did not accept these conditions.

Negotiations between the Government of Senegal and MFDC took place in Ziguinchor in late August 1997. On 27 November 1997, MFDC leader Augustin Diamacoune Senghor called on the Catholic clergymen in Ziguinchor to help them resume the suspended negotiations. A round of negotiations was scheduled for Christmas, but the negotiations were cancelled because of a flare up of armed fighting a few days before.

On 3 January 1998, the Senegalese president, Abdou Diouf, confirmed his willingness for talks mediated by Gambia. Gambian President Yahya Jammeh subsequently started hosting regular meetings between the MFDC and the Senegalese Government. In a round of negotiations mediated by Gambian President Yahya Jammeh on 28 January 1998, MFDC leader Augustin Diamacoune Senghor asserted that he is ready to give up the demand for Casaman�e�s independence, but on condition that the government take measures towards greater economic and social development of this region.
President Abdou Diouf held talks with MFDC leader Diamacounce Senghor on 22 January 1999, which led to a call for an end to hostilities and a peaceful settlement.
The MFDC and the Senegalese government conducted another round of negotiations in Banjul, in Gambia, in April 1999.
Another round of talks was held in Banjul in July 1999.

On 26 December 1999, new negotiations commenced in Banjul, where the conflict parties agreed to an immediate ceasefire in the Casamance. They also agreed to meet face to face at least once a month to negotiate. In addition to representatives of the Gambian government, representatives of Guinea Bissau also mediated in this round of negotiations in December.

After his inauguration in April 2000, Senegalese President Abdoulaye Wade, immediately dismissed all those persons who mediated in the Casamance crisis before his election to the presidency. A round of negotiations between the Senegalese government and the MFDC in November 2000 led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement on 30 November 2000.
With the Bishop of Ziguinchor serving as mediator, a round of negotiations between the conflict parties let to the signing of a truce on 16 March 2001 in Ziguinchor.
The conflict parties conducted unofficial talks in Dakar in January 2002.

Following these unofficial talks, negotiations between the Senegalese Government and the MFDC resumed in Banjul on 25 March 2002. Both parties expressed their willingness to find a solution to the conflict in the Casamance region. In early July and early September, the government offered negotiations to the MFDC. On 22 October 2002, the MFDC leadership announced its readiness to accept negotiations. The adversaries also recognised Gambia and Guinea Bissau as mediators.

In early 2003, there was an upsurge in fighting between the Senegalese army and MFDC forces. The former claimed that the string of operations it conducted were a result of MFDC�s mine laying efforts throughout the region. Nevertheless, negotiations did take place in 2003. On 4 May 2003, President Wade met with MFDC leader Senghor without the involvement of a mediator. These negotiations did not lead to an agreement, but President Wade promised an amnesty for all MFDC fighters, a reintegration program for former combatants, funding for economic recovery of the Casamance region, resettlement of refugees and displaced people.

Peace talks between the Government of Senegal and the political leadership of MFDC continued in 2004. In January 2004, France provided good offices for talks between the external wing of the MFDC and a Senegalese government delegation. The talks ended without any results and did not lead to a breakthrough.

Secret negotiations without the involvement of any third party between October and December 2004 led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. During these negotiations, the Senegalese Government was represented by Interior Minister Ousmane Ngom and the MFDC was represented by Augustin Diamacoune Senghor. The Accord general de paix entre le gouvernement de la republique du Senegal et le Mouvement des forces democratique de la Casamace was signed on 30 December 2004. The agreement established a ceasefire between the conflict parties. Senegal�s Government granted amnesty to rebels and offers voluntary integration into paramilitary units. A peace management committee, comprising Government representatives, Senegalese army, MFDC fighters, and MFDC's political wing, would monitor compliance. International Red Cross and African Assembly for the Defence of Human Rights would oversee fighter disarmament. The agreement also covered economic reconstruction, country de-mining, aid for returning refugees.
agreement_name: Accord general de paix entre le gouvernement de la republique du Senegal el le Mouvement des forces democratique de la Casamace

description: On 1 February 2005, negotiations on the implementation of the 2004 accord were launched in the central town of Foundiougne. The Government�s delegation was led by Interior Minister Ousmane Ngom, while the rebels were led by MFDC leader Augustin Diamacoune Senghor. After a day of talks, the two sides agreed to set up four 10-member technical committees consisting of five people from each side. The committees were to address political issues, economic and social development, as well as disarmament, demobilisation, and demining. Yet, the talks were suspended two days later. New talks, scheduled to take place in late March 2005, were postponed due to divergences within the MFDC. Groups within the rebel movement opposed the peace deal and the rebel leadership wanted to arrange consultations between the various factions in order to include more factions in the peace process. The peace process was postponed yet again in December 2005.

In January 2012, Salif Sadio, one of MFDC�s military chiefs, announced that he was willing to negotiate with the Government of Senegal on the condition that these peace talks would be mediated by the Community of Sant�Egidio and would be held in a foreign country. Not responding directly to this proposal, President Wade announced a new peace proposal for Casamance while being on a campaign trail in the region on 12 and 13 February 2012. Although this plan was immediately rejected by the MFDC, they stated that they demanded �frank and sincere� negotiations in a neutral setting and brokered by a neutral third party as their precondition for working towards peace. In April 2012, Macky Sall was elected as the new Senegalese president, stating that resolving the Casamance conflict was one of the first national priorities and that he was willing to work with neighbouring Gambia and Guinea-Bissau in the search for lasting peace. Yet, Salif Sadio maintained his demands for the process to take place under the auspices of the Community of Sant�Egidio to which President Sall then agreed. The Sadio faction of MFDC subsequently met with a Government delegation in Rome in October 2012 under the auspices of the Community of Sant�Egidio. Don Angelo Romano and Mauro Garofalo mediated the talks.

Another round of negotiations mediated by the Community of Sant�Edgidio took place in December 2012. On 14 December, President Sall announced that Casamance would be a test case for advanced decentralization policy.

Both the Community of Sant�Egidio and Humanitarian Dialogue were involved in mediation between 2014 and 2016. There is, however, limited information available about these mediation efforts. On 29 April 2014, the leaders of MFDC, Salif Sadio, declared a unilateral ceasefire. The ceasefire was announced after a government delegation and a MFDC delegation met in Rome in April 2014 under the facilitation of the Community of Sant�Egidio.
third_party: Community of Sant�Egidio, Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue

description: A round of negotiations mediated by the Community of Sant�Egidio took place in October 2017.
