Gabon�s efforts to resolve the conflict were aided by the International Negotiation Network (INN), which had been involved consultations with the conflict parties since August 1999, when Professor William Zartman and Joyce Neu had travelled to Brazzaville. On the basis of these consultations, the representatives of the INN drafted an eight-point document outlining a framework for a transition to free and fair elections. Although the INN launched its mediation attempt separately from Omar Bongo�s efforts, President Sassou-Nguessou made it clear that he would only accept mediation by the INN if they would coordinate with Bongo. Peace talks mediated by Bongo opened in Libreville on 18 December 1999. During the negotiations, Bongo built on the eight-point document that had been produced by the INN. The peace talks led to the signing of the Accord de Cessez-le-Feu et de Cessation des Hostilit�s in Brazzaville on 29 December 1999. This agreement stipulates an immediate ceasefire and the creation of a committee to implement the accord. This committee was tasked to oversee the disarmament of the militias, the integration of former fighters into the armed forces, and collection of weapons from these groups. The accord also guaranteed the free circulation of people and their goods throughout the country and allowed for former civil servants to resume their posts. Furthermore, the agreement stipulated the launching of a national dialogue aimed at drafting a new constitution and a return to a multiparty political system through holding elections.

description: In 2002, armed fighting between the government and the Ntsiloulou militia erupted again. Secret negotiations mediated by Omar Bongo were held between the government and the Ntsiloulou militia, starting in January 2002. Isidore Mvouba, the government�s coordinator and Adelaide Moundele-Ngollo, the Minister of Trade, led the government side.

Due to the secretive nature of the Bongo-led talk, not much is known about the proceedings, but a peace agreement was concluded on 17 March 2002, which was referred to as the accords of reaffirmation of the 1999 accords. This agreement serves as a reaffirmation of the previous 1999 agreement. It includes provisions for granting amnesty and integrating Ntsiloulou�s professional soldiers into the national armed forces. In return, the Ntsiloulous committed to surrender their weapons, cease all activities aimed at undermining the state�s authority, and ensure the unrestricted movement of people and goods within the Pool region, which is the stronghold of the movement. However, it is important to note that the agreement does not specifically address the main demands of the rebels. These demands included the reopening of the national dialogue and the return of political leaders who were in exile.

On 28 December 2009, Ntoumi finally arrived in Brazzaville to take up his post as the General Delegate in Charge of the Promotion of Peace and Post-Conflict Reconstruction. However, tensions between Ntoumi and President Sassou increased again in the run up to the 2016 elections, in which Sassou sought a third term as president. In early April 2016, the Ntsiloulous militia attacked government targets in the wake of the contested elections won by Sassou. The government conducted bombings and attacks in the Pool area in retaliation, targeting Ntoumi and his Ntsiloulous militia. France tried to mediate negotiations between the conflict parties, but failed to initiate face-to-face talks.

Jean Gustave Ntondo, a representative of Ntoumi and the Ntsiloulous militia, momentarily withdrew from Brazzaville to take shelter following the armed violence in April 2016, but he was invited back to enter into negotiations by the Minister of the Interior and Territorial Administration, Raymond Z�phyrin Mboulou. Jean Gustave Ntondo subsequently came to Brazzaville with a delegation of 12 people to begin negotiations with the government on 6 May 2016.

A round of negotiations without the involvement of any third party in December 2017 led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 24 December 2017. The ceasefire agreement stipulates that the Ntsiloulous militia led by Ntoumi would facilitate the collection of weapons held by its fighters and not create any obstacles to the reestablishment of state authority in the department of Pool. The ceasefire agreement further stipulated that for its part, the government should guarantee �the process of demobilization, as well as professional, social, and economic reintegration of ex-combatants after the collection of weapons.�

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: In June 1998, President Vieira accepted Gambia�s President Yahya Jammeh�s offer of Gambian mediation, after which Sedath Jobe, the Foreign Minister of Gambia, began its efforts to try to bring peace to Guinea-Bissau. A round of negotiations mediated by Gambia led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 10 June 1998. The two sides also agreed to further talks.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: The Ambassadors of Portugal and Angola launched a joint mediation effort and scheduled the first meeting between the conflicting parties aboard a Portuguese frigate anchored off the coast on 28 June 1998, but no government representatives showed up. Francisco Henriques da Silva, the Portuguese ambassador, who acted as the official go-between for this planned meeting, was waiting on board of the Vasco da Gama with the rebel delegation.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: On 3 July, ECOWAS Foreign and Defence Ministers met to discuss the situation in Guinea-Bissau and it was decided to support the military intervention of Senegal and Guinea and to broaden ECOMOG�s mandate beyond Sierra Leone to include Guinea-Bissau. Another effort to end the conflict through mediation was initiated in July 1998 by the Community of Portuguese-speaking countries (CPLP), leading to the conclusion of a ceasefire and a Memorandum of Understanding on 26 July 1998. Portugal provided the good offices of these negotiations on board of a naval vessel called the Corte-Real.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: Another round of negotiations mediated by the CPLP led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 8 August 1998.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: Later that month, on 25 August 1998, the parties met for negotiations in Cape Verde under the auspices of both CPLP and ECOWAS.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: Another round of negotiations was held in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, in September 1998, where the conflict parties agreed on the need of a peacekeeping force to ensure a ceasefire.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: Two rounds of negotiations were held in October 1998. The first took place in Banjul, Gambia, which was mediated by the Gambian Foreign Minister Sadat Jobe.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: The second round of negotiations in October 1998 took place in Portugal, where Portugal mediated the first face-to-face meeting between Vieira and Mane. France and Sweden were also present at the talks in Portugal.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: On 21 October 1998, the government of Guinea-Bissau announced a unilateral ceasefire. Two days later, the rebels announced their own ceasefire.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: Negotiations mediated by ECOWAS � led by Presidents Abdulsalam Abubakar of Nigeria and Yahya Jammeh of Gambia, as well as Foreign Ministers from Ghana, Niger, Senegal and Togo � started again in Abuja on 31 October 1998. During the peace talks, the mediators made it clear that if a peace agreement would be concluded, ECOMOG would ensure the implementation. The peace talks at Abuja led to the signing of the Abuja Peace Agreement on 1 November 1998. The agreement confirmed the existing ceasefire and outlined the simultaneous withdrawal of Senegalese and Guinean troops along with the deployment of an ECOMOG interposition force. It also specified the establishment of a government of national unity, consisting of both rebel representatives and members of the current government. The agreement further mandated that elections would be conducted no later than March 1999.
third_party: ECOWAS, Ghana, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, Togo

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: Following up on the Abuja Peace Agreement, the conflict parties engaged in another round of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS on 15 December 1998. This led to the signing of an additional protocol to the Abuja Peace Agreement. This protocol detailed the composition of the Government of National Unity. Guinea-Bissau�s government was to nominate five ministers and three secretaries of state, while the Military Junta would nominate three ministers and four secretaries of state.
third_party: ECOWAS, Ghana, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, Togo
agreement_name: additional protocol to the Abuja Peace Agreement

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: Fighting erupted again along the front line in the north of Guinea-Bissau on 31 January 1999, just when around 300 ECOMOG soldiers from Benin and Niger aboard the French warship Sirrocco were about to arrive in the port of Bissau. As a response to renewed fighting, the President of Togo and then Chairman of ECOWAS, Gnassingb� Eyad�ma, dispatched his Foreign Minister, Joseph Kokou Koffigoh, to present the conflict parties with a ceasefire, which Viera and Mane signed on 3 February 1999.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: Further negotiations mediated by ECOWAS were held on a number of occasions throughout February 1999, resulting in the announcement of a government of national unity and the complete withdrawal of the Senegalese and Guinean troops. The government of national unity was officially inaugurated on 20 February, with five cabinet ministers nominated by Viera and four by Mane. As stipulated in the Abuja Agreement, the Senegalese and Guinean troops had withdrawn their forces by the end of March 1999, while an ECOMOG force of around 700 soldiers was deployed simultaneously.

side_b: Military Junta for the Consolidation of Democracy, Peace and Justice
description: The ECOMOG force had to defuse tensions by mediating between the conflict parties throughout April 1999. With tensions increasing, fighting erupted again in late April, which led to defeat of the government forces and the unconditional surrender of President Viera on 7 May.

It was not until early May 1991, that the OLF became active in negotiations for the first time, when it agreed to negotiations in London on 27 May, where Herman Cohen, US Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, acted as the chief mediator. Prior to these talks, General Tesfaye Gebre Kidan, who had replaced the exiled Colonel Mengistu, had expressed his willingness to negotiate with the rebels through the United States. However, on 26 May, the EPRDF had surrounded the capital and seized the main military bases. The next day, on 27 May, the negotiations in London were opened, where the TPLF-leader Meles Zenawi negotiated on behalf of the EPRDF. The EPLF and OLF were participating with separate delegations. Simultaneous to the negotiations, the EPRDF entered Addis Ababa and took control of the country on 27 May. After one and a half days of negotiations, on 28 May, the parties present in London agreed to let the EPRDF set up a transitional government and arrange democratic elections within a year. The US did not provide any material incentives to the conflict parties to resolve the conflict. The US provided famine relief, but this was not linked to the mediation effort. Indeed, congressional declarations clearly indicated that famine relief would not be withheld. EPRDF leader Meles Zenawi had pledged not enter Addis Ababa until after the London conference. However, prior to the EPRDF taking control of Addis Ababa on 27 May, the EPRDF leadership had requested Cohen for permission to do so in order to restore stability, which was subsequently granted. In fact, Cohen promised Zenawi that he would make a statement on the BBC and the Voice of America that he had recommend this action. The US thus recognised the EPRDF as the legitimate Government of Ethiopia.

In early October 1992, the EPLF, one of the main rebel groups that had fought against the in 1991 ousted Derg regime, initiated talks between OLF and the newly installed EPRDF government. The talks � in which mediators from the US, UK, and Sweden actively participated � were held in Asmara on 28-29 October 1992. These Western countries had steadily increased pressure on the Ethiopian Government from early 1992 onwards to engage in peace talks. For example, in July 1992, the chairman of the US House of Representatives� subcommittee on Africa, Mervyn Dymally, urged Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi to �continue to dialogue with the OLF.� During the October negotiations, the OLF demanded the June elections to be annulled, as well as a restructuring of the army, which was exclusively under EPRDF control. This was not acceptable for the EPRDF, who encouraged the OLF to join the Government.

In January 1994, the Carter Center launched a new mediation attempt. In early 1994, OLF representatives met with Jimmy Carter and subsequently sent him a letter, dated 4 March, agreeing to discuss in a conference or bilaterally �issues of rectification of violations of the Charter.� After having passed along this message to the Ethiopian Government, the latter replied that it was only willing to hold discussions with those who had first renounced violence, as well as that any discussions would only concern the modalities of participation in the political process as it was already structured. Consequently, no direct negotiations were held based on these shuttle talks.

In February 1995, the US Congress established a Task Force, headed by Congressman Harry Johnston, to work towards getting the Ethiopian opposition to participate in the upcoming May elections. The Task Force managed to convene a meeting in Washington between representatives of the Government of Ethiopia and the OLF, as well as some other opposition groups. The talks mainly focused on Ethiopia�s democratisation process. No agreement was reached during the negotiations.

In 1996, Germany became involved in the conflict as a third party. A delegation headed by former German Ambassador to Ethiopia, H. Winkelmann, aimed to initiate official negotiations between the conflict parties, but was unsuccessful.

In February 1997, Germany managed to initiate negotiations in Bonn, where Winkelmann served as the mediator. The Government delegation suggested that the OLF join the political process, either as a government partner or as opposition, on the precondition that the group accepted the constitution and renounced violence. Since accepting the constitution would entail accepting the territorial integrity of Ethiopia, thereby giving up the demand for an independent Oromiya, the OLF rejected this suggestion.

In addition to negotiations between the Ethiopian government and the OLF, some negotiations have taken place between Ethiopia and Sudan, focusing on ending military support to each other�s rebel groups. The border dispute between Ethiopia and Eritrea that escalated into an armed conflict in May 1998 motivated the Ethiopian leadership to improve relations with Sudan. In late September and early November 1998, a high-level Ethiopian delegation was in Khartoum for discrete talks with a Sudanese delegation on reconciliation between the two countries. The talks concerned the ending of Ethiopian military support to the SPLM/A and Sudanese military support to the OLF. The negotiations were successful and the Ethiopian government shut down offices of the SPLM/A in Gambela in western Ethiopia near the Ethiopia-Sudan border, though the SPLM/A maintained a presence in the frontier zone. The Sudanese authorities, in turn, closed the OLF offices in Khartoum and suburbs.

In a round of negotiations on 31 March 1999, the leaders of Sudan and Ethiopia restored diplomatic relations and concluded an agreement in which they committed to abstain from activities that undermine peace and security in each other�s countries. Specifically, the Government of Ethiopia committed to end support to the SPLM/A, while the Government of Sudan committed to end support to the OLF and the AIAI.

Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir and Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi engaged in negotiations in Addis Ababa on 18 and 19 November 1999, confirming the March 1999 agreement that committed both states to abstain from activities that undermine peace and security in each other�s countries.

Norway tried to initiate official negotiations between the conflict parties from 1999 onwards. However, Norway struggled to initiate negotiations, which, according to Chairman of the Oromo Liberation Front Dawud Ibsa Ayana, was due to the government avoiding direct talks. Nevertheless, in 2004, representatives of Norway�s ministry of foreign affairs acted as go-between between the Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi and OLF leaders Galassa Dilbo and Abiyou Geleta. The Norwegian delegation did not manage to make the two sides meet face to face. Various subsequent attempts to initiate negotiations occurred between September 2004 and 2008, but none of these attempts resulted in either shuttle or direct negotiations. From 27 September to 1 October 2004, Norway sponsored a conference of Oromo dignitaries in Bergen. According to OLF chairman, Ato Daud Ibsa, the Ethiopian government was approached to attend the conference, but refused the idea of any dialogue that includes the presence of a third party. Furthermore, the conference led to a diplomatic dispute when Prime Minister Meles Zenawi asked the Norwegian foreign minister why Norway allowed the OLF, which the Ethiopian government considers to be as a terrorist organization, to hold a conference in Norway, after which the Norwegian minister told the Ethiopian Prime Minster that Norway does not view the OLF the way the Ethiopian government views it. In September 2005, Prime Minister Meles Zenawi announced that he was willing to engage in an unconditional dialogue with OLF. However, when street protests in Oromiya were met by harsh government repression in November, the prospects for negotiations disappeared. In 2006, the OLF indicated its willingness to engage in negotiations on several occasions, but the government responded by describing the situation in Oromiya as a law-and-order issue. Norway had stopped trying to initiate direct negotiations between the conflict parties after 2005, but the Fafo Institute for Applied International Studies organised a seminar in Oslo in March 2007, gathering members of the OLF � including Lencho Letta, Dime Neggewo, Raha Abdi, and Hussein Hassan � to discuss a way out of crisis in Ethiopia. Later in 2007, on 15 August, the Government of Ethiopia ordered six Norwegian diplomats to leave the country, stating that Norway�s peace and reconciliation efforts, both between Ethiopia and Eritrea and between Ethiopia and various opposition groups, in the Horn of Africa were undermining Ethiopia�s security interests. In 2008, it was the Ethiopian Government who tried to initiate negotiations, but the rebels refused to enter negotiations and stated the government was actually calling for the group to submit and surrender.

The improvement in relations between Ethiopia and Eritrea in July 2018 gave new impetus to the peace process between the Government of Ethiopia on the one hand and the OLF and the ONLF on the other hand. In spite of Eritrea hosting both groups on its territory, it initiated a mediation effort between the Ethiopian government and these two rebel groups. A round of negotiations mediated by Eritrea led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement between the government and the OLF in August 2018. Eritrean minister of information, Yemane Gebremeskel, called the agreement a �Reconciliation Agreement.�
The Government of Ethiopia and the OLA engaged in negotiations in Zanzibar between 24 April and 3 May 2023. The talks were mediated by Kenya and Norway. The talks did not result in an agreement.

On 7 November 2023, talks between the Ethiopian government and the OLA were hosted by Tanzania, with support from Norway and the Centre for Humanitiarian Dialogue (HD). The negotiations were conducted by high-ranking military representatives. Negotiations broke down on 6 December 2023.

The UN condemned the coup, but stressed that there must not be a witch-hunt of the Yakoma tribe. UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan mandated former Malian President Amadou Tour� as the UN peace envoy to the Central African Republic on 5 June 2001. Annan stated that in response to the violence that continues to plague the Central African Republic, following the attempted coup on 27 and 28 May 2001, he decided to �dispatch to Bangui, as his Special Envoy, General Amadou Toumani Tour� of Mali, for urgent talks with President Patass� and other authorities and actors. The Special Envoy will hold discussions with his interlocutors with a view to ending the fighting that reportedly continues in parts of Bangui between forces loyal to the Government and the rebels, and restoring peaceful political dialogue within the framework of respect for the country�s democratic institutions.� UN peace envoy and former Malian President Amadou Tour� subsequently mediated peace talks in Bangui in June 2001, involving the government, the opposition, and civil society.

Armed violence had stopped by November 2001, but when unrest resurged, third party efforts were intensified. The new UN peace envoy, Lamine Cisse, a Senegalese retired army general, led this mediation effort between November and December 2001. Chadian Ambassador, Maitimo Njumbe, also played an active role. In addition, an OAU mediation team, led by OAU Secretary-General Mahamat Habib Doutoum, was involved in the mediation effort. However, neither the mediation effort by the UN after the coup, nor the mediation effort of the UN, Chad, and the OAU from November onwards succeeded in initiating face-to-face negotiations between the conflict parties or in concluding a peace agreement.

On 18 March 2003, three days after Francois Bozize�s coup, the Gabonese foreign minister Jean Ping and the foreign minister of the Republic of Congo Rodolphe Adada came to Bangui for peace talks. Although direct, face-to-face negotiations never took off, a reconciliation process did take place on the country level. In September and October 2003, a national dialogue of one month brought almost all the country�s political actors and all of civil society together. The delegates discussed issues with regard to truth and reconciliation, politics and diplomacy, economy and finances, defence and security, education, social affairs, and culture.

Libya, together with Chad and CEN-SAD, initiated a mediated round of negotiations in Syrte in February 2007. In addition to the UFDR, the Front d�mocratique du peuple centrafricain (FDPC) (English: Democratic Front of the Central African People) was also part of the negotiations. The negotiations led to the Syrte agreement on 2 February 2007.

Another round of negotiations between the Government of the Central African Republic and the UFDR led to the signing of the Birao Agreement on 13 April 2007. The agreement outlined a ceasefire between the government and the UFDR, with its immediate implementation. Additionally, the agreement acknowledged the UFDR's status as a political party, granting it political recognition. Furthermore, the agreement specified that UFDR troops would undergo demobilization and later be integrated into the national army. However, it did not provide a specific quota for the integration process. In a significant development, rebel fighters were granted a blanket amnesty, meaning they would be exempt from prosecution or punishment for their past actions. This amnesty aimed to promote reconciliation and create an environment conducive to long-lasting peace. No third parties were involved in the negotiations leading up to the signing of this peace agreement, though the UN witnessed the signing of the peace agreement.

During the first three months of 2008, President Bozize held a political dialogue, facilitated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD). The dialogue involved the ruling party Kwa Na Kwa, the political opposition alliance Forces vives de la nation, civil society representatives, and several rebel groups. This paved the way for direct negotiations between the government and armed opposition groups.

Between May and July 2008, Omar Bongo, President of Gabon, acted as mediator for negotiations in Libreville that were attended by the UFDR, as well as the Arm�e Populaire pour la Restauration de la D�mocratie (APRD) and the Front D�mocratique du Peuple Centrafricain (FDPC). Bongo�s mandate was based on his role as the Chairman of the ad-hoc Committee within the CEMAC on Central African issues. Michel Djotodia led the UFDR during the talks in Libreville. The government signed a ceasefire with only the APRD on 9 May 2008.
Another round of negotiations led to the conclusion of a comprehensive peace agreement on 21 June 2008, signed by all three rebel groups.

In December 2012, a new rebel group called Seleka started a rebellion in the northern part of the country. Seleka was an alliance of the former rebel groups, including the UFDR. The AU and FOMAC (the Central African Multinational Force) both tried to initiate negotiations in response to the Seleka rebellion, but did not succeed. The Seleka announced a unilateral ceasefire on 20 December, claiming that had stopped its offensive on the capital in order to give peace a chance. However, fighting continued the next day. ECCAS mediator, Congolese President Sassou Nguesso, invited the conflict parties to Libreville in early 2013. This led to the signing of the Libreville Agreement on 11 January 2013. This agreement stipulated a ceasefire and defined the modalities for power sharing and a political transition. The ceasefire agreement provides for a cessation of all hostilities between the Central African Republic�s government and the Seleka coalition within 72 hours. The ceasefire agreement also contains provisions on political prisoners, disarmament and demobilization, and the establishment of an oversight commission supervising the implementation of the ceasefire agreement.

However, the ceasefire soon broke down and the Seleka managed to take over control of Bangui by March 2013. The Seleka subsequently deposed Boziz�, while installing Michel Djotodia as President. On 10 January 2014, a conference in N�Djamena brought about the end of the regime of Djotodia, paving the way for a political transition. Chadian President Idriss D�by convinced Djotodia to step down, after which former mayor of Bangui Catherine Samba-Panza was elected as the new president by the new transitional government. The Seleka alliance subsequently rebranded itself as ex-Seleka. Several negotiations took place between the ex-Seleka alliance and the government. In June 2014, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) initiated the first peace initiative following the crisis in 2013. A discussion on possible mechanisms to resolve the armed conflict at a workshop that brought together 30 Central African participants from varying backgrounds � including representatives from government, anti-Balaka, and ex-Seleka � led to the idea of organizing a forum.

Furthermore, on the side-lines of the 23rd Ordinary Summit of the African Union in Malabo, Equatorial Guinea, in June 2014, the leaders of the Economic Community of Central African States (ECCAS) agreed to organize a ceasefire conference in Brazzaville in July 2014. The leaders also agreed to organizing popular consultations and to implement the idea of the HD workshop to organize a forum, which would later lead to the Bangui National Forum. Congolese President Sassou Nguesso, in his capacity as the ECCAS chief mediator, mediated the ceasefire negotiations between the anti-Balaka and the FPRC � as well as several other armed groups, though not the UPC led by Ali Darassa) � in Brazzaville in late July 2014. The Government of the Central African Republic was also involved in the negotiations. These negotiations led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement on 23 July 2014. However, clashes continued between the non-state armed groups.

Several of the non-state armed groups operating in the Central African Republic participated in a mediation process led by the Kenyan government in Nairobi, with negotiations taking place in early 2015. Building on these ceasefire negotiations, the mediation effort in Nairobi was subsequently replaced by the Bangui Forum in which the government also participated. The United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (MINUSCA) provided political and logistical support to Bangui Forum. Abdoulaye Bathily, the UN Special Representative for Central Africa, chaired the Forum. Special Representatives were also sent by the African Union and the Republic of Congo to support the negotiations. Technical support and expertise were given to the mediations by HD and the EU. Around 600 representatives from the Central African Republic participated. The Bangui Forum was held between 4 and 11 May 2015 and led to the conclusion of two negotiated settlements. First, the parties concluded the Agreement between the Transitional Government and the armed groups on the principles of disarmament, demobilization, reintegration and repatriation and integration into the uniformed State forces of the Central African Republic on 10 May 2015. This agreement included provisions on a ceasefire, as well as on the disarmament, demobilisation, and reintegration for all the armed groups that signed the agreement, including the Front populaire pour la renaissance de la Centrafrique, Rassemblement patriotique pour le renouveau de la Centrafrique, Union des forces r�publicaines fondamentales, Seleka r�nov�e, Mouvement des lib�rateurs centrafricains pour la justice, Front d�mocratique pour le progr�s de la Centrafrique, Coordination des ex-combattants anti-Balaka, Unit� du peuple centrafricain, R�volution et justice, and the Union des forces r�publicaines. Second, the Bangui Forum resulted in the conclusion of the Republican Pact � or in full the Pacte r�publicain pour la paix, la reconciliation, et la reconstruction en R�publique centrafricaine � which, among others, established a local and national mechanism for reconciliation. This agreement was signed by the government and nine out of the ten armed groups operating in CAR.
agreement_name: Agreement between the Transitional Government and the armed groups on the principles of disarmament, demobilization, reintegration and repatriation and of integration into the uniformed State forces of the Central African Republic, Republican Pact

description: In February 2016, the AU mandated Mohamed El Hacen Lebatt as its special representative. Lebatt launched what was referred to as the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation. Angola, Chad, the DRC, and ECCAS supported this AU-led mediation effort. Talks mediated by Lebatt in February 2016 did not lead to an agreement.

In late 2016, Angola, which had been mandated by the International Conference on the Great Lakes region, mediated between the transitional government and several armed groups � including the anti-Balaka, the FPRC, and the MPC - in Luanda in December 2016. Andr� de Oliveira Jo�o Sango, director general of the secret services, acted as the chief mediator. The Angolan mediators proposed a general amnesty, which was widely condemned in Bangui. The negotiations in Luanda ended without an agreement.
third_party: International Conference on the Great Lakes, Angola

description: In March 2017, the Community of Sant�Egidio started a mediation process mainly involving the non-state armed groups operating in the Central African Republic. This led to an agreement, referred to as the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic. The agreement reaffirmed the 2016 elections. In addition, the agreement called for the integration of all �politico-military groups� into the peace process and a restoration of state authority. The agreement also included an immediate countrywide ceasefire. The ceasefire did not hold. Armed clashes between several armed groups already took place in the Bria area already one day after the signing of the ceasefire. The government was not involved in the negotiations in Rome, but the government could nevertheless build on these negotiations. On 28 June 2017, President Faustin Archange Touad�ra held meetings with the representatives of the 14 armed groups that had signed the peace agreement in Rome on 19 June.
agreement_name: Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic

description: With it being clear that the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic of June 2017 did not succeed, the AU presented its roadmap for peace in Libreville on 17 July 2017. The roadmap agreement assigns the responsibility for leading peace negotiations in the Central African Republic to the AU, while pledging to take into account the achievements of previous peace initiatives including the peace agreement mediated by Sant�Egidio in June 2017. The Roadmap created an African Panel of Facilitators, with panel members from the AU, ECCAS, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, Angola, Chad, the Republic of Congo, and Gabon. MINUSCA was granted observer status. The African Panel of Facilitators mediated for the first time in Bangui between 11 and 12 September 2017.

On 28 August 2018, Russia � which had begun supplying the Government of the Central African Republic with arms and military instructors in February 2018 � and Sudan mediated negotiations between the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the one side and the anti-Balaka (represented by Maxime Mokom) on the other side. The government was not part of this peace initiative as it expressed its support to the AU-led peace process. The negotiations led to the signing of declaration of understanding and a pledge to support the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation in the Central African Republic led by the AU and regional states with the support of the UN. The UPC and MPC expressed that they were no longer committed to this declaration in October 2018, but they made it clear that they still supported the African Initiative. While the government was not part of the negotiations held in Khartoum in August 2018, these negotiations paved the road for subsequent peace talks in Khartoum in which the government was involved. Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The APPR was signed by 14 non-state armed groups and the Government of the Central African Republic. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements, making the agreement essentially an elite-level pact to buy off armed group leaders.
agreement_name: Accord politique la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: In early June 2011, the government and CPJP were involved in negotiations. No third party was involved in these talks. The negotiations, which were held in the northern town of N�dele, led to the signing of a ceasefire on 12 June 2011. The CPJP agreed to confine their soldiers to barracks while the talks on a final peace deal would take place. The CPJP also agreed to an immediate cessation of all hostility, the abstention from all military action and other forms of violence and to join the DDR campaign that several other opposition groups had already joined.

Another round of peace talks resulted in the signing of a peace agreement in Bangui on 25 August 2012. The agreement recommitted the government and the CPJP to the Libreville Global Peace Agreement of 21 June 2008 and to the ceasefire agreement of 12 June 2011. By taking the peace agreement concluded in Libreville in 2008 between the Government and UFDR as the basis for the peace between the Government and the CPJP, the conflict parties agreed that the forces of the CPJP would be integrated into the national army and that political leaders of the movement would participate in state affairs.

In June 2014, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) initiated the first peace initiative following the crisis in 2013. A discussion on possible mechanisms to resolve the armed conflict at a workshop that brought together 30 Central African participants from varying backgrounds � including representatives from government, anti-Balaka, and ex-Seleka � led to the idea of organizing a forum.

Furthermore, on the side-lines of the 23rd Ordinary Summit of the African Union in Malabo, Equatorial Guinea, in June 2014, the leaders of the Economic Community of Central African States (ECCAS) agreed to organize a ceasefire conference in Brazzaville in July 2014. The leaders also agreed to organizing popular consultations and to implement the idea of the HD workshop to organize a forum, which would later lead to the Bangui National Forum. Congolese President Sassou Nguesso, in his capacity as the ECCAS chief mediator, mediated the ceasefire negotiations between the anti-Balaka and the FPRC � as well as several other armed groups, though not the UPC led by Ali Darassa) � in Brazzaville in late July 2014. The Government of the Central African Republic was also involved in the negotiations. These negotiations led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement on 23 July 2014. This ceasefire agreement is referred to as the Accord de cessation des hostilit�s en R�publique Centrafricaine (Brazzaville Agreement on Cessation of Hostilities). However, clashes continued between the non-state armed groups.
agreement_name: Accord de cessation des hostilit�s en R�publique Centrafricaine (Brazzaville Agreement on Cessation of Hostilities)

description: On 17 April 2020, the Prime Minister of the CAR, Firmin Ngr�bada invited the leader of the UPC, Ali Darassa, to Bangui to discuss restoring state authority, preparations for disarmament and demobilization, and the establishment of special mixed security units in the south-east of the country.

On 30 July 2020, the Prime Minister held a meeting with Ali Darassa in Bangui. Darassa made a commitment to uphold the reinstatement of state authority, participate in disarmament and demobilization efforts, and facilitate the unrestricted movement of electoral agents. In return, he was granted permission to re-establish his presence in Bambari and maintain a direct communication channel with the Prime Minister.

The Government of the Central African Republic and the CPC allegedly engaged in a secret round of negotiations in the town of Moundou in southern Chad in mid-2021. The talks were mediated by Chadian and Angolan diplomates. The government refused talks had taken place.

On 16 September 2021, Angola, Rwanda, the International Conference on the Great Lakes region (ICGLR), the Economic Community of Central African States (CEEAC), and the African Union (AU) mediated peace talks between the Government of the Central African Republic and the main leaders of the CPC, with the exception of FPRC leader Nourredine Adam and UPC leader Ali Darassa, during the ICGLR third mini-summit. Negotiations culminated in the endorsement of the Joint Roadmap for Peace in the Central African Republic, which was signed with the commitment to cease armed action throughout the country and to engage in peace dialogue rather than violence. A significant outcome of the Joint Roadmap was the declaration of a unilateral ceasefire by President Faustin Archange Touadera on 15 October 2021. Subsequently, a republican dialogue was convened in Bangui from 21 to 27 March 2022, but the CPC did not participate in this republican dialogue and it was also boycotted by key figures of the political opposition.
agreement_name: Joint Roadmap for Peace in the Central African Republic

description: Third party efforts aimed at ending the fighting between the Government and the MPCI were initiated at early stage in the conflict. On 31 September 2002, a team of diplomats from several West African nations � including Ghana, Mali, Nigeria, Niger, Togo, and Guinea-Bissau � arrived in Abidjan to meet President Gbago and the armed opposition. This group of countries was known as the contact group which had been established at an ECOWAS meeting in Accra on 29 September 2002. The parties were close to concluding a ceasefire agreement in early October 2002, but President Gbagbo refused to sign a ceasefire at the last moment, as according to him this would legitimise the rebel movement and partition the country. Hence, the official signing ceremony did not take place.
third_party: ECOWAS, Ghana, Guinea-Bissau, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Togo

description: A new attempt was made in mid-October 2002, when Senegal�s Foreign Minister Cheikh Tidiane Gadio, on behalf of the ECOWAS contact group, held talks with the rebels, presenting a peace proposal from ECOWAS. This led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement in Abijan on 17 October.

Formal peace negotiations started subsequently in Lom�, Togo, on 30 October 2002, where the Togolese President Gnassingb� Eyad�ma, who held the ECOWAS Chairmanship at the time, was appointed coordinator of the mediating efforts. After two days of talks, on 1 November 2002, a joint statement was issued. This statement was referred to as the Lom� Ceasefire Agreement, outlining a basic agenda of future discussions. The Lom� ceasefire agreement together with the Abidjan agreement provided the basis for military intervention by ECOWAS and France. In spite of these third party peacemaking efforts, negotiations stalled, as rebels continued to demand the resignation of president Gbago, which was unacceptable to the Government of the Ivory Coast. The Government, in turn, insisted on the immediate disarmament of the rebels, which MPCI refused. Furthermore, the negotiations became increasingly complicated, as two new rebel groups � the MPIGO and the MJP � appeared in the west of the country. This negatively affected the level of trust between the Government and MPCI, resulting in the breaching of the truce on several occasions. On 23 December 2002, the MPCI spokesman called for the UN and France to take over negotiations, as the rebels had lost confidence in the African mediators due to a lack of progress.

On 3 January 2003, the Ivoirian government committed to a unilateral ceasefire at the behest of France�s foreign minister. Subsequently, between 15 and 24 January 2003, France mediated between the conflict parties and the Government of Ivory Coast in a southern suburbs of Paris, Marcoussis. Ten delegations and 32 representatives were present, including representatives of Gbagbo�s government, Guillaume Soro of the MPCI, representatives of western rebel groups MPIGO and MJP, as well as the major Ivorian political parties and Alassane Ouattara. During the negotiations, the mediators promised that a monitoring committee would be set up to guarantee the implementation of the agreement. This committee would include representatives of France, the EU, the AU, ECOWAS, the UN, la Francophphonie, the IMF, the World Bank, and the G8. On 23 January 2003, the parties signed the Linas-Marcoussis Peace Accords. The agreement reasserts the importance of the Lom� Ceasefire Agreement. It outlines the establishment of a Government of National Reconciliation, which would be formed through a power-sharing arrangement among the conflicting parties. The composition of this government would involve individuals selected by the participating parties during the Round Table discussions. To ensure credible and transparent elections, the agreement requires the preparation of an electoral timetable. Additionally, upon assuming office, the Government of National Reconciliation would immediately commence the process of regrouping its forces under the supervision of French and ECOWAS authorities. Subsequently, steps would be taken to disarm and demobilize all forces involved in the conflict. The responsibility of the Government of National Reconciliation also includes the reconstruction of a national army and a national security force. A plan for the country's reconstruction is proposed, alongside the release and amnesty of detained military personnel who have not committed severe human rights violations. After the singing of the Linas-Marcoussis Peace Accords, the mediation mandate of France was reinforced through UN Security Council Resolution 1464 (4 February 2003), which welcomed French mediation and backed the French military intervention, referred to as Op�ration Licorne, with a Chapter Seven mandate. The UN Security Council thus conferred the main political and military responsibility to France and ECOWAS, which were given an UN mandate to monitor the ceasefire and protect civilians.

To ensure the implementation of the Linas-Marcoussis Peace Accords, another round of negotiations, mediated by ECOWAS and Ghana was initiated at Accra. The President of Ghana and Chairman of ECOWAS, John Agyekum Kufuor, acted as the chief mediator at these peace talks. On 7 March 2003, the Accra II Agreement was concluded. The parties involved in the agreement expressed their unwavering commitment to the Linas-Marcoussis agreement and addressed new urgent issues. They emphasized their belief in democracy and the upcoming democratic election process. To facilitate the formation of a Government of National Reconciliation, the agreement established the creation of a National Security Council (NSC). The NSC would consist of a representative from each signatory of the Linas-Marcoussis Agreement. This council would be responsible for appointing a Minister of Defence and a Minister of National Security. Furthermore, the agreement provided specific details regarding certain aspects of the power-sharing arrangements. It explicitly stated that the Ministry of Territorial Administration and the Ministry of Communication would be assigned to the MPCI. The parties agreed to respect the choices made by other political parties when appointing representatives to the Reconciliation Government.

On 3 May 2003, the conflict parties as well as forces from the Liberian government would sign a peace agreement in Abidjan with the intent of resolving remaining conflict in the western shared border region.
Negotiations between the conflict parties and the Ivorian security forces led to a Joint Declaration on 4 July 2003, reaffirming their commitment to the ceasefire.
Another round of negotiations was mediated by the International Organization of Francophonie (OIF) between 1 and 4 October 2003.
ECOWAS negotiated a round of negotiations on 19 November 2003.
France�s Foreign Minister Dominique de Villepin negotiated a round of negotiations on 21 November 2003.

On 3 January 2003, the Ivoirian government committed to a unilateral ceasefire at the behest of France�s foreign minister. Subsequent negotiations in Lome in January 2003, mediated by ECOWAS mediator Mohamed Ibn Chambas, between the MPIGO and the Mouvement pour la justice et la paix (MJP) (English: Movement for Justice and Peace) led to a ceasefire agreement with the Ivorian government on 13 January 2003.

Between 15 and 24 January 2003, France mediated between the conflict parties and the Government of Ivory Coast in a southern suburbs of Paris, Marcoussis. Ten delegations and 32 representatives were present, including representatives of Gbagbo�s government, Guillaume Soro of the MPCI, representatives of western rebel groups MPIGO and MJP, as well as the major Ivorian political parties and Alassane Ouattara. During the negotiations, the mediators promised that a monitoring committee would be set up to guarantee the implementation of the agreement. This committee would include representatives of France, the EU, the AU, ECOWAS, the UN, la Francophonie, the IMF, the World Bank, and the G8. Subsequently, steps would be taken to disarm and demobilize all forces involved in the conflict. The responsibility of the Government of National Reconciliation also includes the reconstruction of a national army and a national security force. A plan for the country's reconstruction is proposed, alongside the release and amnesty of detained military personnel who have not committed severe human rights violations. After the singing of the Linas-Marcoussis Peace Accords, the mediation mandate of France was reinforced through UN Security Council Resolution 1464 (4 February 2003), which welcomed French mediation and backed the French military intervention, referred to as Op�ration Licorne, with a Chapter Seven mandate. The UN Security Council thus conferred the main political and military responsibility to France and ECOWAS, which were given an UN mandate to monitor the ceasefire and protect civilians.

They emphasized their belief in democracy and the upcoming democratic election process. To facilitate the formation of a Government of National Reconciliation, the agreement established the creation of a National Security Council (NSC). The NSC would consist of a representative from each signatory of the Linas-Marcoussis Agreement. This council would be responsible for appointing a Minister of Defence and a Minister of National Security. Furthermore, the agreement provided specific details regarding certain aspects of the power-sharing arrangements. It explicitly stated that the Ministry of Territorial Administration and the Ministry of Communication would be assigned to the MPCI. The parties agreed to respect the choices made by other political parties when appointing representatives to the Reconciliation Government.

Negotiations between the conflict parties and the Ivorian security forces led to a Joint Declaration on 4 July 2003, reaffirming their commitment to the ceasefire.

ECOWAS negotiated a round of negotiations on 19 November 2003.
France�s Foreign Minister Dominique de Villepin negotiated a round of negotiations on 21 November 2003.

The parties agreed to respect the choices made by other political parties when appointing representatives to the Reconciliation Government.

On 3 May 2003, the conflict parties as well as forces from the Liberian government would sign a peace agreement in Abidjan with the intent of resolving remaining conflict in the western shared border region.
Negotiations between the conflict parties and the Ivorian security forces led to a Joint Declaration on 4 July 2003, reaffirming their commitment to the ceasefire.
agreement_name: Joint Declaration on Commitment to Ceasefire

description: Another round of negotiations was mediated by the International Organization of Francophonie (OIF) between 1 and 4 October 2003.
ECOWAS negotiated a round of negotiations on 19 November 2003.
France�s Foreign Minister Dominique de Villepin negotiated a round of negotiations on 21 November 2003.
In late June 2004, the FN held talks with President Gbagbo to discuss the implementation of the Linas-Marcoussis peace plan.

In July 2004, John Agyekum Kufuor, the President of Ghana and Chairman of ECOWAS, mediated peace talks in Accra. The presence of 17 African Heads of State and government representatives, as well as the presence of UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan and AU Chairman Olusegun Obasanjo, showed the international commitment to resolve the conflict. The negotiations led to the conclusion of the Accra III agreement on 30 July 2004. The agreement restated the significance of the Marcoussis and Accra II agreements. It included a commitment to resume meetings and activities of the Reconciliation Government and empower the Prime Minister to establish effective governance throughout the entire national territory, thereby preventing the division of the country into separate entities. Furthermore, the parties agreed to initiate the demobilization process starting on 15 October 2004. Elections were scheduled to take place in October 2005. A National Human Rights Commission was planned to be established to address human rights concerns. Lastly, the parties reached an agreement to create a tripartite monitoring mechanism comprising ECOWAS, the African Union, and the United Nations. This mechanism would oversee the implementation of the agreement and ensure its compliance by all parties involved. The agreement set a timetable for political reform and disarmament. While it was stipulated that the parties would start to disarm on 15 October, the rebels made it clear on 14 October that they refused to comply as a result of the slow implementation of agreed reforms.

On 28 October 2004, Lansana Kouyate, the Special Envoy of la Francophonie, held talks with the leaders of the rebel movements in a bid to break a deadlock in the peace process. The discussions were held on disarmament and review of political reform. On 15 November 2004, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1572, which imposed an arms embargo, but also threatened the conflict parties with a 12-month travel ban and an asset freeze imposed on those who were attempting to obstruct the peace process.

After being appointed as official mediator by the African Union in November 2004, South African President Thabo Mbeki travelled to Ivory Coast for three hours of talks with President Gbagbo in mid-November. According to Mbeki, Gbagbo was committed to full implementation to previously concluded peace agreements.
In late November 2004, President Mbeki hosted the conflict parties in Pretoria to discuss the resumption of negations.
Between 2 and 6 December 2004, Mbeki visited Ivory Coast to mediate between the adversaries, after which the conflict parties indicated that they were willing to resume official negotiations.
In spite of several attempts by Mbeki, the adversaries refused to engage in direct negotiations during the first months of 2005. Accordingly, Mbeki shuttled between the different sides.

It was not until early April 2005 that face-to-face negotiations were held between NF leader Guillaume Soros and President Gbagbo in Pretoria. During the negotiations, Mbeki threatened the conflict parties that the AU would impose sanctions, as specified in UN Security Council Resolution 1572, against those obstructing the peace process. The negotiations resulted in the Pretoria Agreement on the Peace Process in the Cote d�Ivoire on 6 April. The agreement declares an immediate and definitive end to hostilities. It reiterates the importance of previous agreements, namely the Linas-Marcoussis, Accra II, and Accra III agreements. The parties involved also made a commitment to uphold the sovereignty, independence, integrity, and unity of Ivory Coast. Additionally, the parties pledged to disarm militias across the entire territory, implement the agreed-upon Disarmament, Demobilization, and Reintegration (DDR) plan, and establish a restructured national army. The FN, having previously withdrawn from the Government of National Unity in 2004, agreed to rejoin it as part of this agreement. Reforms were outlined for the Independent Elections Commission and the Central Commission to ensure the participation of the FN in these institutions. Furthermore, the parties agreed to conduct presidential elections in October 2005, with oversight from the United Nations.
agreement_name: Pretoria Agreement on the Peace Process in the Cote d�Ivoire

description: The Pretoria Agreement did not include a timeframe of the issues addressed, which is why the conflict parties met again several times during the year. These meetings focused mainly on issues related to disarmament and upcoming elections. The parties met for negotiations in Bouake on 14 April 2005.
The parties also met for negotiations in Pretoria on 28 and 29 June 2005. This led to the Declaration on the Implementation of the Pretoria Agreement, which is referred to as Pretoria II.
agreement_name: Declaration on the Implementation of the Pretoria Agreement (Pretoria II)

description: Another round of negotiations took place in Yamoussoukro in early July 2005. It became increasingly clear that free, democratic, and transparent elections could not be held, resulting in a call by the AU and the UN Security Council for an extension of President Gbagbo�s mandate for a maximum 12 months.

Negotiations appeared to be back on track in early 2006, when Prime Minister Charles Konan Banny, appointed in December 2005, managed to take major steps in addressing issues central to the implementation of the peace agreements. Several negotiations were held during the first half of 2006, of which most focused on the issue of voter eligibility. The Chairman of the AU, President of the Republic of Congo, Denis Sassou-Nguessou, mediated three rounds of negotiations. The first round of these negotiations took place in February.
The second round of negotiations took place in March 2006.
The third round of negotiations took place in June 2006.

On 5 July 2006, the conflict parties participated in consultations with UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan. Progress was made, but due to disagreements concerning voter�s eligibility, it soon became evident that the elections, scheduled to place on 31 October, would have to be postponed yet again. At an ECOWAS summit held in Nigeria in early October 2006, a new framework for the political transition was outlined. After the meeting, the ECOWAS leaders forwarded their recommendations to the AU Peace and Security Council meeting in Addis Ababa, where the recommendations were accepted and sent to the UN Security Council meeting, which then accepted the peace plan on 1 November. Rejecting the UN and its role in the conflict, Gbagbo presented a peace plan of his own as an alternative. In this plan he called for the abolishment of the buffer zone between rebels and government forces and for direct talks with the rebels. However, the insurgent movements rejected the offer of direct talks, stating that they would not sidestep the process laid out by the UN Security Council. Although Sassou-Nguessou had already assumed the role of chief mediator on a number of occasions during 2006, he officially replaced Mbeki by the end of 2006. The President of Niger and chairman of ECOWAS, Mamadou Tandja, and African Union Commission Chairman Alpha Oumar Konare, were also mandated to participate in the negotiations. Supplementing the arms embargo as laid down in UN Security Council Resolution 1572, the UN Security council adopted Resolution 1727, which called upon all of the member states to prevent the direct or indirect import of all rough diamonds from Ivory Coast to their territory, as well as imposed a travel ban and an asset freeze on those obstructing the peace process.

The rebel parties initially rejected the alternative peace plan presented by President Gbagbo in December 2006, but in January 2007 they eventually accepted to take part in the negotiations. ECOWAS, the AU, and the UN also gave their backing to proceed with Gbagbo�s peace plan. The president of Burkina Faso, Blaise Compaor�, who became the chairman of ECOWAS in January 2007, mediated the subsequent negotiations between Ivorian president Gbagbo and the three rebel movements. Mario Giro from the Community of Sant�Egidio was also involved in the mediation effort. While the mediation efforts in previous years had been characterised by external pressure and the threat of sanctions, the third parties mediating at Ouagadougou did not exert any pressure on the conflict parties. The talks led to conclusion of the Ouagadougou Political Accord on 4 March 2007. The agreement reinforced the commitment of the FN and the Ivorian government to the Linas-Marcoussis, Accra, and Pretoria agreements. It outlined several key provisions, including the merging of government and FN forces, as well as the deployment of joint patrols in the former "zone of confidence" that previously divided the government-controlled south from the FN-controlled north. Additionally, the agreement addressed the disarmament of militias and their reintegration through civic service programs. It granted amnesty for crimes committed since September 2000. The agreement also specified that presidential elections would be held once the identification and registration process of eligible voters was completed. Until the elections were conducted, a transitional government would govern the country. The agreement aimed for full implementation by 4 January 2008. To ensure compliance, a monitoring mechanism was established, comprising the signatories of the agreement, including Burkinabe President Compaor�, Henri Konan B�die, and Alassane Dramane Ouattara, two Ivorian opposition politicians.
third_party: Burkina Faso, Community of Sant' Egidio, ECOWAS

description: After the signing of the agreement, Compaor� remained involved in the peace process through participating in the monitoring mechanisms for the implementation of the agreement, as well as though brokering supplementary accords to the agreement. Other Burkinabe officials, including Djibril Bassolet, Burkina Faso�s security minister, were also actively participating in the peace process. Subsequent negotiations led to four complementary agreements. The First Complementary Agreement to the Ouagadougou Political Agreement was concluded on 27 March 2007. This agreement established that Guillaume Soro, Secretary-General of the FN, would assume the role of prime minister in the transitional government. As per the agreement, he would hold office until the upcoming presidential elections but would not be eligible to run as a candidate.
agreement_name: First Complementary Agreement to the Ouagadougou Political Agreement

description: The Second Complementary Agreement to the Ouagadougou Political Agreement and the Third Complementary Agreement to the Ouagadougou Political Agreement were both concluded on 28 November 2007. In the second complementary agreement, the former warring parties reached an understanding that the French Societ� SAGEM Securit� would serve as the technical operator responsible for printing new Ivorian identity and voter cards. This step was crucial for updating the electoral roll. The third complementary agreement outlined specific deadlines and procedures for implementing certain provisions of the agreement. This primarily focused on the disarmament and demobilization process, which had to be completed by 22 December 2007, and the presidential elections, which were to be concluded no later than the end of June 2008. Additionally, it addressed matters such as public administration and voter registration.
agreement_name: Second Complementary Agreement to the Ouagadougou Political Agreement, Third Complementary Agreement to the Ouagadougou Political Agreement

description: The Fourth Complementary Agreement to the Ouagadougou Political Agreement was concluded on 22 December 2008. This agreement dealt with the integration of approximately 5,000 former FN rebels into the Ivorian security forces. This integration process was to be completed within a two-year timeframe.
agreement_name: Fourth Complementary Agreement to the Ouagadougou Political Agreement

description: On 1 October 2004, the NDPVF and the government conducted a round of negotiations. This led to a ceasefire. The Niger Delta Vigilante (NDV) was also involved in these negotiations and also signed the ceasefire. NDPVF leader Moujahid Asari Dokubo and NDV leader Ateke Tom promised �the disbandment of all militias and militant groups as well as total disarmament.�

Following increasing tensions between the NDPVF and the government, the NDPVF issued a threat in September 2005 to attack Nigerian government forces and destroy foreign-owned oil facilities. Nevertheless, the NDPVF issued a unilateral ceasefire on 26 September 2005. The NDPVF and the Government of Nigeria conducted a round of negotiations in Yenagoa, the capital of Bayelsa state, in December 2007. This led to the signing of a ceasefire on 6 December 2007.

On 5 January 1992, Transitional Prime Minister Cheiffou called on the FLAA to disarm and enter into negotiations. On 7 January 1992, the FLAA leadership replied that they were willing to enter into negotiations, but on the condition that the army would return to the barracks and that an independent inquiry on the armed violence with international observers would be set up. The conflict parties entered pre-negotiations without the involvement of any third party in May 1992. This led to the signing of a joint communique on 12 May 1992, which committed the parties to the creation of a favourable climate for effective negotiations, beginning with a temporary ceasefire. It was also agreed that both Algeria and France would act as mediators. France subsequently helped to obtain both sides� commitment to peace talks.
A round of preliminary talks in March 1993, mediated by France, aimed at concluding a ceasefire and establishing an agenda for negotiations led to the signing of a ceasefire on 20 March 1993.

During subsequent secret talks between the rebels and the Government of Niger in Paris in June 1993, the government and the FLAA renewed, for another three months, the ceasefire reached in March. This round of secret negotiations continued and led to the signing of the Paris Agreement on 10 June 1993. Under the Paris Agreement, several important actions were outlined. Firstly, a three-month truce was mandated, and combatants were to be redeployed to barracks and defensive positions. Additionally, the state of emergency in northern areas of Niger was set to be lifted. Moreover, agreements were made to facilitate the return of Tuareg refugees from Algeria, create development funds for the northern regions, and plan for future negotiations concerning FLAA�s political demands. However, one day later, on 11 June 1993, the Algerian-based military command of the FLAA issued a statement that it opposed the agreement concluded by the FLAA�s political wing. The FLAA factionalized between June and September 1993 into several splinter groups as a result of disagreements about the Paris Agreement. The ceasefire was largely adhered to between June and September 1993, although FLAA splinter groups occasionally attacked government targets. France withdrew as mediator in November 1993, citing the deadlock created by the rivalry between the FLAA and several of its splinter groups.

During the first half of 1997, Chad met UFRA representatives and convinced them to join the ongoing peace process with the FDR. As a result, the UFRA participated in peace talks, mediated by Algeria, Burkina Faso, Chad, France, and Libya.
third_party: France, Algeria, Burkina Faso, Chad, Libya

description: Another round of talks in which the UFRA participated took place during the last two weeks of November 1997. Algerian, French, and Burkinabe diplomats mediated these talks. The talks led to the signing of a ceasefire accord on 29 November 1997. On 8 June 1998, the UFRA handed over their last military equipment to the military authorities.

While MNJ repeatedly asked for a dialogue with the Government of Niger, the latter refused any mediation in 2008, describing the rebels as mere criminals and bandits. Yet, in mid-February 2009, Nigerien president Mamadou Tandja requested Libyan leader, Colonel Muammar al-Gaddafi, chairman of the AU in 2009, to help find a settlement. Muammar al-Gaddafi accepted this request and in March mediated the release of five Niger soldiers and a gendarme who had been held by the MNJ. He subsequently mediated in a number of talks between government delegations and MNJ.
On 4 April 2009, another meeting was held in Tripoli, mediated by the Libyan ambassador to Niger.
After the Tripoli meeting of 4 April 2009, al-Gaddafi met with both the Government delegation and the MNJ delegation separately.

On 3 May 2009, Nigerien President Mamadou Tandja visited northern Niger for the first time in two years. During his visit to northern Mali in early May 2009, Nigerien President Mamadou Tandja held talks with the MNJ, mediated by al-Gaddafi. After the first meeting Tandja promised amnesty to all Tuareg rebels if they disarmed. The MNJ did not respond to this offer.
Talks subsequently continued in Agadez in early May 2009 and it was reported that issues such as the disarmament and reintegration of Touareg fighters were discussed.

MNJ and government representatives engaged in another round of peace talks in Niamey, the capital of Niger, in mid-May 2009. Before the launch of the talks, MNJ published a statement saying that the group would not disarm until talks were held on its political demands. The announcement went on to say that it found the government�s proposed scenario of �confining rebel combatants, disarming them and later granting them a general amnesty� as �incredible and unacceptable.� MNJ then went on to call for a clearly defined timetable for the negotiations. At the talks, it was reported that the parties had agreed to set up a technical committee to continue working on some of the core issues, including the rebels� demands and how to go about disarming the rebel fighters. The negotiations between the MNJ and the government of Niger led to a ceasefire agreement on 15 May 2009. In June 2009, a MNJ splinter group announced that it had agreed for its fighters to be disarmed. However, this deal did not involve the MNJ.

New talks between the conflict parties, without the involvement of a third party, were held in Niamey in July 2009. Following confusion in MNJ ranks in September 2009, a number of MNJ fighters, together with MNJ leader Agaly Alambo, participated in a peace ceremony in Sabha in southern Libya, at which dozens of MNJ fighters officially lay down their arms. The ceremony was initially rejected by one faction of MNJ, but by the end of the month it appeared as if the whole group stood behind the decision to end the armed struggle. A couple of weeks later the state of emergency in northern Niger was formally withdrawn by a presidential decree. The peace process continued in January 2010, when MNJ officially surrendered its weapons during a ceremony near Arlit in northern Niger.

The Sudanese federal Minister of Interior and the Minister of Interior of the Republic of South Sudan engaged in a round of negotiations on Abyei in January 2011, which led to the conclusion of the Agreement of the Minister of Interior on Security Arrangements in Abyei on 17 January 2011. The agreement allowed the return of displaced people under the protection of Joint Integrated Units of north-south law enforcement and supervised by the United Nations Mission in Sudan (UNMIS). The agreement also stipulated the opening of corridors for cattle and regulated the carrying of arms among misseriya herdsmen.
agreement_name: Agreement of the Minister of Interior on Security Arrangements in Abyei

description: Another round of negotiations in March 2011 led to the signing of another agreement on Abyei on 4 March 2011. This agreement � the Follow-up to the Kadugli Agreements Agreement between the Republic of the Sudan and the Republic of South Sudan on the Demarcation of the Boundary � reconfirmed the parties� commitment to the Kadguli agreements. The agreement requested the UN to ensure implementation of the agreement. However, on 27 of April 2011, President Bashir stated that �Abyei is part of north Sudan and will remain of the north. We do not say this just here. We say it in many forums and occasions.� Bashir also threatened to wage war against the Republic of South Sudan if they attempted to annex Abyei to the South Sudan. On 1 May 2011, a heavily armed Sudanese army convoy entered Abyei in a clear breach of what was agreed upon in the Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA) signed in 2005. SPLM/A forces subsequently ambushed this convoy. This triggered renewed fighting between the Sudanese forces and the SPLM/A.

The AU High-Level Implementation Panel for Sudan (AUHIP), led by former South African President Thabo Mbeki, mediated a round of negotiations between the Sudanese government and the SPLM/A in May 2011. This led to the drafting of a Joint Position Paper on Border Security, which forms the basis for a Common Border Zone and creates a Joint Political and Security Mechanism.
The AUHIP mediated another round of negotiations between the conflict parties on post-referendum issues on 13 June 2011.

Another round of negotiations on the status of Abyei, mediated by the AUHIP, resulted in the conclusion of the Temporary Arrangements for the Administration and Security of Abyei Area on 20 June 2011. The agreement stipulated a devolution of power to the Abyei Area Administration, with oversight from the Abyei Joint Oversight Committee. In addition, the agreement called for the demilitarization of the Area with the exception of the UN-authorized and Ethiopian-provided Interim Security Force for Abyei (ISFA). The parties also reaffirmed their commitment to resolve the final status of Abyei peacefully, with mediation support from the AUHIP. Although the Temporary Arrangements for the Administration and Security of Abyei Area stipulated, among others that both the SAF and the SPLA needed to be withdrawn from the Abyei Area, the SAF did not give up their control over Abyei.
agreement_name: Temporary Arrangements for the Administration and Security of Abyei Area

description: During a round of negotiations, mediated by the AUHIP, on 29 June 2011, the conflict parties formally signed an agreement that drew on the Joint Position Paper on Border Security. South Sudan gained its independence on 9 July 2011. All peace efforts after this date are coded as negotiations in the interstate conflict between Sudan and South Sudan.

Yau Yau and his Murle fighters objected to mediation by the South Sudan Council of Churches because Archbishop Daniel Deng being a Dinka Bor. In the first half of 2013, a mediation effort was instead conducted by a British defense contractor of AEGIS Defense Services (UK), James Ellery, hired by the South Sudanese government. This mediation effort was conducted in the first three months of 2013 and was aimed at initiating formal negotiations, but the mediation effort failed. UNMISS engaged the government, but also supported Ellery�s effort, providing both logistics and security. Ellery met with Yau Yau six time at various place in Pibor county, but Yau Yau did not agree to official negotiations.

Governments forces launched a military operation on 5 March 2013 in spite of efforts by the UNMISS leadership to persuade the government to refrain from such an operation. In addition, UNMISS flew Ellery to Pibor county on 13 March 2013 to get Yau Yau�s consent to a 48-hour ceasefire, but this effort failed.
A mediation attempt to initiate official negotiations by local Murle elites and interlocutors close to the Juba government on 19 and 20 May 2013 also failed.

A mediation team of three nationally respected church officials from Equatoria � namely Catholic bishop Paride Taban, along with Bishop Paul Benjamin Yugusuk of the Episcopal Church and Bishop Arkanjelo Wani Lemi of the African Inland Church � was initiated at a meeting in Addis Ababa in August 2013. This mediation effort, dubbed the Church Leaders� Mediation Initiative (CLMI), was supported by the Dutch NGO PAX and also received logistical support from Norwegian Church Aid and UNMISS. During the meeting in Addis Ababa in August 2013, the bishops agreed with representatives of the SSDM/A-Cobra Faction to enter into negotiations with the government. With President Kiir�s blessing, the bishops and the Presbyterian Murle pastor Orozu Lokine subsequently met with Yau Yau in Kongor in September 2013. The onset of the civil war between the South Sudanese government and the Sudan People�s Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition (SPLM/A-IO) strengthened the government�s commitment to a deal with Yau Yau as the government needed soldiers to fight the SPLM/A-IO, pushing the government to make concessions in favour of Yau Yau at the expense of key government actors in Jonglei state.

The peace process between the government and the SSDM/A-Cobra Faction was brought to Addis Ababa in January 2014. This mediation effort was conducted by the South Sudanese Church Leaders Mediation Initiative (CLMI). Hizkias Assefa, an Ethiopian professor and mediator, acted as the chief mediator during this peace process. The conflict parties signed a ceasefire on 7 January 2014.
Another ceasefire agreement was signed on 30 January 2014.

A peace agreement was concluded on 9 May 2014. This peace agreement, often referred to as the Greater Pibor Administrative Area (GPAA) Peace Agreement, established a special �Greater Pibor� region for the Murle people in the state.
agreement_name: Greater Pibor Administrative Area (GPAA) Peace Agreement

description: A round of negotiations between George Athor and South Sudanese President Salva Kiir on 20 November in Kenya, mediated by the South Sudan Council of Churches, led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. In spite of this agreement, Athor stepped up the SSDM/A�s armed attacks on government targets in early December 2011. Athor was killed on 19 December 2011, reportedly while entering South Sudan from Uganda. Peter Kuol Chol Awan became the new leader of the SSDM/A.

Awan entered secret negotiations in January 2012. This resulted in the signing of a peace agreement on 27 February 2012, after which Awan travelled to Juba and surrendered to the SPLA. The GoSS/SSLM Peace Agreement contained provisions providing the rebels an opportunity to be represented in the national government, as well as the state level governments in Jonglei and Upper Nile. The agreement further provided for a disarmament and reintegration process of the rebel fighters, stipulating assembly points in agreed areas where processes of integration of their forces into the Sudan People�s Liberation Army (SPLA) would be conducted. However, Johnson Olony, the leader of the SSDM/A-Upper Nile faction, rejected the agreement and kept fighting the Government of South Sudan.
The SSDM/A led by Olony accepted a ceasefire and an amnesty by the government following mediation by the Shilluk reth (King) in June 2013.
Negotiations on the terms of integrating the SSDM/A fighters into the national army subsequently continued in July and August 2013.

Following another round of negotiations in November 2013, President Kiir issued a decree on 25 November 2013 that confirmed the reintegration and commissioning of Major General Johnson Olony into the government forces. The SSDM/A remained loyal to the government until early 2015, when they defected to the SPLM/A-IO.
