Following South Sudan�s independence, President Salva Kiir offered an amnesty to various armed groups fighting in the south, including the SSLM/A. This led to a round of secret negotiations between the new South Sudanese government and the SSLM/A in late July 2011. On 3 August 2011, SSLM/A spokesperson Bol Gatkouth announced: �We are declaring a ceasefire and we are also accepting the amnesty offered by the president as the basis of talks with the Government of South Sudan.�

When it became clear that few Nuer fighters would join his rebellion and that overthrowing the state government of Tabang Deng in Unity province seemed unlikely, Peter Gadet, until then the leader of SSLM/A, negotiated his way back in and joined the Government of South Sudan. Following negotiations in early January 2012, President Kiir issued a decree on 6 January 2012, reinstating Peter Gadet to his position in the Sudan People�s Liberation Army (SPLA). The SPLA functions as the government forces of South Sudan. On 15 February 2012, the registration of the SSLM/A into the SPLA was completed.

In spite of Gadet joining the government, many SSLM/A fighters led by Bapiny Monytuiel continued their rebellion with the support from Khartoum. The SSLM/A led by Bapiny Monytuiel signed an agreement with the government in April 2013.

Following another round of negotiations in November 2013, President Kiir issued a decree on 25 November 2013 that confirmed the reintegration and commissioning of Lieutenant General Bapiny Monytuil of the SSLM/A into the government army. The leadership council of the SSLM/A issued a statement on 27 November 2013 expressing support for the President�s announcement.

A delegation from the Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD), which had mediated an end to the civil war in Sudan in 2005, visited Juba between 19 to 21 December 2013 for pre-negotiations with President Kiir and other relevant stakeholders to obtain a first-hand understanding of the crisis, to explore possible ways to resolve the crisis, and to make the conflict parties agree on official negotiations. This IGAD delegation was supported by the UN and the AU.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: On 26 December, a second IGAD delegation � led by the President of Kenya, Uhuru Kenyatta, and the Prime Minister of Ethiopia, Hailemariam Dessalegn � visited Juba for peace talks with the President of South Sudan, members of the Cabinet, and the detained a group of eleven high-profile individuals. The IGAD delegation also tried to further probe into the root causes of the conflict and discuss how best to address it.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: IGAD held an extraordinary summit in Nairobi on 27 December 2013, where three special envoys � Ambassador Seyoum Mesfin of Ethiopia, General Lazaro Sumbeiywo of Kenya, and General Mohamed Ahmed Mustapha al-Dabi of the Sudan � were appointed to support a resolution of the crisis. IGAD began to mediate direct negotiations between the conflict parties in early 2014. Seyoum Mesfin, who had been the Ethiopian Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1991 until September 2010, was the chief mediator of the peace process. A first round of negotiations took place in Addis Ababa between 2 and 23 January 2014. These negotiations mainly focused on the conclusion of a ceasefire, as well as on the release of some political prisoners taken by the government. The mediation team led by Mesfin considered a ceasefire unlikely to hold unless underlying political grievances were addressed, but they deemed that a reduction in violence was necessary to create the space for substantial negotiations. Hence, the negotiations first focused on the conclusion of a ceasefire. The conflict parties signed a ceasefire on 23 January 2014, which took effect the next day. The ceasefire committed the conflict parties to end offensive operations, freeze their forces in place, and refrain from attacks against civilians. The ceasefire also established a monitoring and verification mechanism.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: With each side accusing the other side of violating the ceasefire, a second round of IGAD-led negotiations in Addis Ababa took place between 10 February and 3 March 2014. From this round of negotiations onwards, the peace process began to focus on concluding a comprehensive political settlement. The mediation team put forward a framework for negotiations and an agenda for political dialogue on 21 February 2014. In addition to discussing this framework for negotiations, the conflict parties agreed to a monitoring and verification mechanism to ensure compliance with the ceasefire. The second round of negotiations ended on 3 March 2014 with the signing of implementation modalities for the cessation of hostilities agreement. Although some progress had been made on the framework for negotiations, the conflict parties did not sign a declaration of principles.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: The conflict parties finally agreed to a declaration of principles on 27 March 2014, following the start of the third round of negotiations in Addis Ababa on 25 March 2014. The third round of negotiations was suspended on 31 March 2014.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: The fourth round of peace talks started in Addis Ababa on 28 April 2014 and ended on 9 May 2014 with the signing of another ceasefire. With negotiations in Addis Abba ongoing, US President Barack Obama imposed economic sanctions on 7 May, including a freeze of assets and a travel ban, against General Peter Gadet and Major General Marial Chanuong, with the former loyal to Machar and the latter loyal to Kiir. The agreement signed on 9 May 2014 � referred to as the Agreement to Resolve the Crisis in South Sudan � also called for broadening the negotiations to include Former Detainees, other opposition political parties, civil society, and faith-based groups. The negotiations that led to the ceasefire on 9 May were the first negotiations in which both President Kiir and SPLM/A-IO leader Machar participated, though the two leaders did not meet face-to-face or shake hand upon signing the ceasefire.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan
agreement_name: Agreement to Resolve the Crisis in South Sudan

description: On 6 and 7 June 2014, the IGAD mediation team conducted a round of talks with the conflict parties and other relevant actors, including political parties, the formerly detained SPLM/A members, and civil society groups. These talks were aimed at preparing for negotiations involving a broad-based group of actors.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: At the IGAD summit on 10 June 2014, a fifth round of negotiations took place. Kiir and Machar agreed on forming a transitional government within 60 days. However, the SPLM/A-IO refused to take part in the subsequent round of negotiations, which would start in Addis Ababa on 20 June. The SPLM/A-IO was opposed to the framework for inclusive negotiations, instead demanding that negotiations should solely be conducted between the SPLM/A-IO and the government.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: The sixth round of negotiations started in Addis Abba on 6 August 2014. The South Sudanese government signed the Protocol on Agreed Principles on Transitional Arrangements Towards Resolution of the Crises in South Sudan on 25 August 2014, but Machar refused to sign at that moment in time. The IGAD Heads of States subsequently extend South Sudan�s peace talks by 45 days. The conflict parties did sign a ceasefire on 26 August 2014.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: On 14 September, the IGAD mediation team moved the South Sudan peace talks to Bahir Dar, the capital of the Amhara region of Ethiopia. This round of negotiations officially started on 22 September. By the end of this round of negotiations, on 3 October 2014, there was still limited consensus on the provisions of a peace agreement to end the conflict.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: In parallel to the IGAD mediation process, another mediation effort emerged which was specifically aimed at reconciling the different factions within the SPLM/A. This mediation effort was led by Tanzania. The conflict parties acknowledged their collective responsibility for the crisis during a round of talks in Arusha between 15 and 20 October 2014, as well as expressed a commitment to three SPLM/A factions to work together.

IGAD-led negotiations between Kiir and Machar were held at the 28th extraordinary summit of heads of state and government of IGAD in Addis Ababa on 6 and 7 November 2014. These negotiations did not lead to a peace agreement, but both sides agreed to continue to look for a power-sharing formula to establish a transitional government. Both Kiir and Machar also called on their troops to honor the ceasefire in anticipation of a final peace agreement. The IGAD leaders warned the conflict parties that whoever violates the ceasefire would face sanctions, including a travel ban, an arms embargo and asset freezes. The IGAD leaders also set a deadline to reach an agreement within 15 days.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: A workshop on the implementation of the ceasefire was held in Addis Ababa on 16 November 2014.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: Another round of negotiations between the conflict parties was held in Addis Ababa between 18 and 22 December 2014. The parties agreed on the creation of 27 ministries, but continued to disagree over two ministries as well as the deputies of the prime minister. The conflict parties also continued to disagree over security matters, such as the structure of the armed forces. The negotiations were subsequently adjourned until 2015. On 23 December, Ethiopian Prime Minister Haliemariam Desalegn announced that IGAD would not implement sanctions against South Sudan yet.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: On 12 January 2015, the conflict parties signed another ceasefire in the IGAD-led mediation process, as well committed themselves to accelerate efforts to reach an agreement based on the formation of a transitional government.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: Negotiations in Arusha between 9 to 19 January 2015 brought together President Salva Kiir representing the SPLM/A-In Government, Rick Riek Machar representing the SPLM/A-IO, and Deng Alor Kuol representing the SPLM/A-Former Detainees. John Samuel Malecela, the Vice Chairman of Tanzania�s ruling party the Chama Cha Mapinduzi (CCM), and Abdulrahman Kinana, the CCM General-Secretary, acted as the chief mediators at this round of negotiations in Arusha. The negotiations led to the signing of the Agreement on the Reunification of the Sudan People�s Liberation Movement (Arusha Agreement) on 21 January 2015.

The South Sudanese government and the SPLM/A-IO met in Addis Ababa on 27 and 28 January 2015 for two days of IGAD-mediated negotiations prior to the IGAD Head of States Summit on 29 January. These negotiations focused on power-sharing. The IGAD mediation team proposed to make Riek Machar vice-president again, while keeping James Wani Igga as a second vice-president. Politicians from Equatoria expressed opposition to this proposal, asserting that Igga should hold a more senior position to Riek Machar in a future power-sharing agreement.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: The conflict parties signed another ceasefire on 1 February 2015.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: Another round of IGAD-led negotiations in Addis Abba started on 23 February 2015. Prior to the start of this round of negotiations, both the AU and IGAD threatened sanctions against South Sudan if a comprehensive power sharing deal would not be reached by 5 March 2015. One major disagreement during the negotiations was that the SPLM/A-IO demanded the creation of two separate armies in the country during the transitional period, with the SPLM/A-IO fighters being officially recognized as a separate army. The negotiations broke down on 6 March 2015.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: The IGAD mediation effort resumed in June 2015, but was officially reconfigured as �IGAD Plus� in June 2015, expanding the mediation team to also include representatives from five African Union member states, the UN, the Troika (US, UK, and Norway), the EU, and China. A new round of negotiations was initiated in Addis Ababa on 9 June 2015. This round of negotiations ended on 25 June, with an agreement that the IGAD mediation would circulate a �compromise agreement� in July, which was the product of negotiations and consultations since January 2014.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: On 27 June 2015, President Salva Kiir and SPLM/A-IO leader Riek Machar conducted a consultative meeting in Nairobi under the auspices of President Kenyatta of Kenya to review elements of the proposed peace agreement.

The mediation team indeed circulated the draft of this agreement after another round of negotiations in Addis Ababa from 21 to 23 July 2015. The third parties subsequently put a lot of pressure on the conflict parties to accept this agreement.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: At a new round of negotiations that had started with a summit in Addis Ababa on 27 July chaired by President Barack Obama, it was decided that the conflict parties would have until 17 August 2015 to sign a final peace agreement. Several amendments were subsequently negotiated on the basis of the draft agreement. For instance, the conflict parties agreed that the deadline for the complete integration of the SPLM/A-IO forces into the national army would be within 30 months of signing of the agreement, instead of the 18 months proposed by the mediators. The ARCSS included chapters on a transitional government, a permanent cease-fire and transitional security arrangements, humanitarian assistance and reconstruction, economic and financial management, transitional justice, a permanent constitution, and joint monitoring and evaluation. Both Riek Machar and a representative of the former detainees signed the Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan (ARCSS) in Addis Ababa on 17 August 2015. However, Salva Kiir indicated he was not ready to sign the agreement. The mediation team subsequently gave him and his negotiation team two additional weeks to return to Juba and secure support for the deal. Following this decision, the US introduced a draft resolution in the UN Security Council which threatened an arms embargo and targeted sanctions against South Sudan if the government failed to sign the agreement deal. Nine days later, Kiir signed the agreement at a ceremony in Juba in the presence of IGAD leaders. In October 2015, a Joint Monitoring and Evaluation Commission (JMEC), consisting of members of the conflict parties and IGAD Plus, was set up to oversee the implementation of the agreement. IGAD appointed the former president of Botswana Festus Mogae to head JMEC. In late October, the top military commanders of the government forces and the SPLM/A-IO attended a five-day workshop held in Addis Ababa to discuss security arrangements associated with the implementation of the peace agreement.

Another round of IGAD-led negotiations led to the signing of the Outcome of the Meeting of the Principal Signatory Parties to the Agreement on Planning Implementation of the provisions in Chapter II of the Agreement on 3 November 2015. This Agreement concerns the details on the implementation of the Transitional Government of National Unity (TGONU) and the Transitional National Assembly (TNA), as well as the adoption of the transitional constitution. The agreement also specified that the SPLM/A-IO was allowed to deploy 1,410 security personnel in Juba and the government could deploy 3,420 security personnel. The ARCSS included a political power-sharing provision. To this purpose, Machar returned to Juba in April 2016. However, problems with the implementation of the ARCSS were already apparent prior to Machar�s return. Kiir had cast aside the power-sharing formula of the ARCSS in October 2015 by creating 28 states instead of ten states. In addition, in violation to the agreement, Chief of Staff Paul Malong had secretly brought a Dinka militia to Juba. With tensions increasing, fighting between the conflict parties eventually resumed in July 2016. This effectively suspended the peace process. Following the clashes, President Kiir issued a decree on an immediate ceasefire in the country on 11 July 2016. Yet, fighting continued. Riek Machar subsequently fled to the Democratic Republic of Congo while under attack of ground forces and helicopter gunships. Taban Deng Gai sought the support of some disgruntled SPLM/A-IO generals, after which Kiir appointed Taban Deng Gai as the vice president, replacing Machar. Riek Machar was later put under house arrest in South Africa. However, most of the SPLM/A-IO remained loyal to Machar. JMEC chairman Festus Mogae reported in October 2016 �near-daily violations� of the ceasefire by both parties, warning that these could �trigger an uncontrolled escalation of violence.�
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan
agreement_name: Outcome of the Meeting of the Principal Signatory Parties to the Agreement on Planning Implementation of the provisions in Chapter II of the Agreement

description: Building on the Arusha Agreement that had been concluded in January 2015, Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni mediated a round of negotiations between the three factions with the SPLM/A in July 2017. This round of negotiations involving the SPLM/A-In Government, the SPLM/A-IO, and the SPLM/A-Former Detainees led to the signing of the Entebbe Declaration on the Operationalization of the Arusha Agreement on the Reunification of the SPLM on 27 July 2017. This agreement established a working group to revitalize and operationalize the implementation of the Arusha Agreement, trying to reunify the SPLM/A.
agreement_name: Entebbe Declaration on the Operationalization of the Arusha Agreement on the Reunification of the SPLM

description: Egypt and Uganda mediated a round of negotiations in Cairo in November 2017 aimed at reunifying the SPLM/A. On 16 November 2017, representatives of the SPLM/A-In Government, the SPLM/A-IO, and the SPLM/A-Former Detainees signed the Cairo Declaration on the Reunification of the Sudan People�s Liberation Movement (SPLM).
agreement_name: Cairo Declaration on the Reunification of the Sudan People�s Liberation Movement (SPLM)

description: IGAD tried �revitalize� the peace process from mid-2017 onwards. The IGAD leaders endorsed a plan to kick-start the peace process at the 31st Extra-ordinary Summit of IGAD Assembly of Heads of State on 12 June 2017. IGAD announced on 1 October 2017 that it would resume the formal peace process to bring peace to South Sudan. The revitalization forum, aimed at restarting peace talks, began in Addis Ababa on 18 December. This round of negotiations led to the conclusion of the Agreement on Cessation of Hostilities, Protection of Civilians and Humanitarian Access on 21 December 2017.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan
agreement_name: Agreement on Cessation of Hostilities, Protection of Civilians and Humanitarian Access

description: Building on the conclusion of the Cairo agreement, another round of negotiations involving the three factions within the SPLM/A was held in Entebbe in December 2017. These negotiations led to the conclusion of the Arusha Agreement on the SPLM Reunification Implementation Matrix on 15 December 2017.
agreement_name: Arusha Agreement on the SPLM Reunification Implementation Matrix

description: On 2 January 2018, the Troika � comprising of the US, the UK, and Norway � called on the conflict parties to end their military operations and threatened to impose sanctions on those who would not comply with this call. The IGAD-led mediation process continued in 2018. The second round of the IGAD revitalization forum was held in Addis Ababa between 5 and 16 February 2018, but no agreement was reached.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: A round of proximity talks was held between the conflict parties in Addis Ababa on 11 and 12 May 2018.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: This round of indirect talks was followed by the resumption of the revitalization forum in Addis Ababa from 17 to 23 May 2018. The South Sudan Council of Churches supported this IGAD-led round of negotiations by facilitating dialogue sessions to bridge their differences on the outstanding governance and security issues identified as critical to revitalize the Agreement. The conflict parties recommitted to the implementation of the cessation of hostilities agreement, but little substantial progress was made. Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed initially led the effort to revitalize the peace process following his election in April 2018.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan, South Sudan Council of Churches

description: The conflict parties engaged in shuttle negotiations in Addis Ababa from 18 to 20 June 2018, but Abiy Ahmed mediated a face-to-face meeting between President Salva Kiir and Riek Machar on the final day of this round of negotiations. This was the first meeting of Kiir and Machar since the resumption of hostilities in July 2016.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: The following day, on 21 June 2018, the IGAD Assembly of Heads of State and Government mandated Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir to mediate the negotiations. President al-Bashir was supported by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni. Face-to-face talks between President Kiir and Machar resumed in Khartoum on 25 June 2018 and concluded with the Khartoum Declaration of Agreement between Parties of the Conflict of South Sudan on 27 June 2018. This agreement was also signed by the representatives of the South Sudan Opposition Alliance, the �Former Detainees�, and the other political parties. In the Declaration, the signatories announced a permanent ceasefire, set objectives for transitional security arrangements and signatories to reach an agreement on the IGAD revised bridging proposal, improve infrastructure and basic services in South Sudan and restore oil fields in Unity. The agreement also stipulates a comprehensive ceasefire. This agreement commits the conflict parties to a permanent ceasefire and to finalize a deal on the pending issues in the governance chapter of the 2015 peace agreement. The agreement stipulated a �revised bridging proposal� that listed the details of a pre-transitional period. The agreement also includes provisions with regard to the oil, elections, and reconstruction. The agreement thus was meant to pave the way for the formation of an inclusive transitional cabinet. The agreement also called upon the AU and IGAD to deploy protection forces and ceasefire monitors to observe the ceasefire implementation. In addition, the conflict parties agreed to open the humanitarian corridors, release detainees, withdraw troops and militarily disengage.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan
agreement_name: Khartoum Declaration of Agreement between Parties of the Conflict of South Sudan

description: On 6 July 2018, following a round of negotiations mediated by Sudan and Uganda in Khartoum, the conflict parties signed the Agreement on Outstanding Issues of Security Arrangements, which included additional provisions on the ceasefire and the Disarmament, Demobilization, and Reintegration (DDR) process.
agreement_name: Agreement on Outstanding Issues of Security Arrangements

description: Another meeting between Kiir and Machar, mediated by Sudan and Uganda, took place in Entebbe on 7 July 2018.

The conflict parties signed the Agreement on Outstanding issues of Governance on 5 August 2018. This agreement supplemented and/or amended previously agreed provisions on political power-sharing through specifying who will hold the key government ministries and positions.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan
agreement_name: Agreement on Outstanding issues of Governance

description: Building on progress made through the signing of the Agreement on Outstanding issues of Governance, another round of negotiations was held in Khartoum between 13 and 19 August 2018. These talks mainly focused on the status and incorporation of the documents agreed upon in Addis Ababa and in Khartoum in the preceding months. On 18 August 2018, the mediators circulated a draft revitalized text of the peace agreement to the parties for comment before adjourning for the Eid holidays.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: Another round of negotiations in Khartoum started on 25 August 2018 and led to the signing of a draft revitalized peace agreement between 28 and 30 August.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: The conflict parties signed a final agreement in Addis Ababa on 12 September 2018, referred to as the Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan (R-ARCSS). While the Troika had been involved in most of the IGAD-led negotiations in 2018, they were excluded from the final rounds of negotiations. The Troika therefore refused to co-sign the R-ARCSS. The agreement outlined a revised comprehensive framework for the transition from conflict. The agreement stipulated the reinstatement of Machar as First Vice President and the establishment of a transitional government in May 2019. In addition, in line with the agreement, Kiir ordered the release of all prisoners of war and detainees in September 2018. Kiir and Machar jointly attended peace celebrations in the capital Juba on 31 October 2018, together with the presidents of Sudan, Uganda, Somalia, and Ethiopia, as well as Egypt�s prime minister. Nevertheless, fighting between government forces and the SPLM/A-IO continued throughout the year, though at a lower intensity.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan
agreement_name: Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in South Sudan

description: The R-ARCSS stipulated that Salva Kiir and Riek Machar had to form a unity government by May 2019. On 2 May 2019, IGAD mediated a round of negotiations in Addis Ababa where the conflict parties and the IGAD mediation team agreed to extend the deadline to 12 November 2019. The conflict parties indicated that this extension was needed to complete the necessary transitional security arrangements, including protection for senior government officials, to form the transitional Government. However, follow-up mediation was also needed to address more substantial issues. The International Crisis Group reported on the need for follow-up mediation on the R-ARCSS, stating that �The accord, brokered by Sudan�s Omar al-Bashir and Uganda�s Yoweri Museveni, is not a finished product and requires revision� and that �Additional political deals are necessary on two crucial matters � unifying a national army and resolving bitter disagreements over local boundaries and administration inside South Sudan. Absent such deals, the Kiir-Machar truce may fail its first major test in May 2019, when the two South Sudanese leaders are scheduled to form a unity government.� On 18 October, in a communiqu�, the Peace and Security Council of the AU called for the parties� adherence to the deadline of 12 November. During its visit to South Sudan on 20 October 2019, the UN Security Council also called for adhering to the deadline, but also stressed the need to address outstanding issues. While the Government of South Sudan intended to form the Revitalized Transitional Government of National Unity on 12 November, the SPLM/A-IO called for an extension.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: President Kiir and SPLM/A-IO leader Machar engaged in a face-to-face meeting mediated by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni on 7 November 2019. The Chair of the Sovereign Council of the Sudan, Lieutenant General Abdel Fattah Abdelrahman Al-Burhan, and the Special Envoy of Kenya to South Sudan were also involved in these talks. The meeting focused on outstanding pre-transitional tasks: transitional security arrangements, the issue of states and their boundaries, and the formation of the Revitalized Transitional Government of National Unity. In order to address these issues, Kiir and Machar agreed on an extension of the pre-transitional period for an additional 100 days, commencing on 12 November 2019.

Another face-to-face meeting between Kiir and Machar, which also involved other signatories of the R-ARCSS, took place on 9 November 2019. These talks were mediated by IGAD. The talks led to the endorsement of the plan to extend the deadline with 100 days in order to facilitate the resolution of the outstanding issues.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda, Sudan

description: On 6 January 2020, President Salva Kiir and SPLM-IO leader Riek Machar held a meeting to form a government of national unity by the February deadline.

On 12 January 2020, under the auspices of the Community of Sant'Egidio in Rome, and witnessed by IGAD, the government of South Sudan, the South Sudan Opposition Movements Alliance (SSOMA), the SPLM/A-IO, and the National Democratic Movement (NDM) signed a peace declaration in which they recommitted to the Cessation of Hostilities Agreement of December 2017 to avoid confrontation between the signatories and non-signatories parties of the South Sudan peace agreement.

On 15 January 2020, Sudanese General Mohamed Hamdan Daglo, a member of Sudan�s Sovereign Council, mediated between Kiir and Machar in a closed-door meeting in a bid to resolve the dispute and evaluate the possibility of forming a unity government the following month.

On 29 February 2020, during the field mission to South Sudan conducted by the AU Peace and Security Council (PSC), the PSC delegation engaged in consultations with SPLM/A-IO chairman Riek Machar. The one-sided consultations were aimed at contributing to the implementation of the Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan (R-ARCSS).

On 11 December 2020, South Sudanese leaders agreed on the formation of the Transitional National Legislative Assembly (TNLA). This decision was reached at a meeting between President Salva Kiir and First Vice President Riek Machar in Juba.

Another round of negotiations as part of the Rome Initiative for Political Dialogue in South Sudan resulted in the signing of the Declaration of Principles in Naivasha, Kenya, on 10 March 2021. This agreement was signed by representatives from the Revitalized Transitional Government of National Unity (R-RGoNU), including both the SPLM/A and the SPLMA-IO, and members of the SSOMA. The community of Sant�Egidio and Kenya acted as mediators.

From 15 to 18 July 2021, representatives from the RTGoNU, including both the SPLM/A and the SPLMA-IO, as well as the SSOMA, convened for a round of negotiations mediated by the community of Sant�Egidio in Rome. The talks were aimed the implementation of previous peace agreements and resulted in a Declaration of Recommitment.

On 19 August 2021, Prime Minister Abdallah Hamdok met separately with President Salva Kiir and First Deputy President Riek Machar to discuss the stalled implementation of the revitalized peace agreement, regional relations, and key issues in the peace process. In his meeting with Machar, Hamdok also deliberated on security arrangements, particularly addressing the share of signatory groups in the unified national army. Additionally, they discussed power-sharing agreements regarding administrative areas and the appointment of an SPLM/A-IO nominee to the Deputy Minister of Interior position, emphasizing the need for its fulfillment, as per the agreement terms.

On 2 March 2022, South Sudanese leaders in the transitional government have been invited by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni to attend a retreat aimed at reviewing the progress of implementing the revitalized peace agreement. Invitations were extended to President Salva Kiir, First Vice President Riek Machar, and all other deputy leaders in the presidency. The retreat aimed to assess the current status of the peace agreement�s implementation. In September 2022, the transitional period and term of the Revitalized Transitional Government of National Unity (RTGoNU) was extended by two years, from 23 February 2023 to 22 February 2025.

On 12 January 2020, under the auspices of the Community of Sant�Egidio in Rome, and witnessed by IGAD, the government of South Sudan, the South Sudan Opposition Movements Alliance (SSOMA), the SPLM/A-IO, and the National Democratic Movement (NDM) signed a peace declaration in which they recommitted to the Cessation of Hostilities Agreement of December 2017 to avoid confrontation between the signatories and non-signatories parties of South Sudan peace agreement. NAS was part of the SSOMA. On 12 April 2020, SSOMA committed itself to align with the UN Secretary General�s call for a global ceasefire in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. In doing so, SSOMA recommitted itself also to the peace declaration signed in Rome.

The SSOMA, which includes the NAS, recommitted to the Cessation of Hostilities agreement during talks between the government and the SSOMA in Rome on 9 November 2020. The Rome talks were mediated by the Community of Sant�Egidio.

Another round of negotiations as part of the Rome Initiative for Political Dialogue in South Sudan resulted in the signing of the Declaration of Principles in Naivasha, Kenya, on 10 March 2021. This agreement was signed by representatives from the Revitalized Transitional Government of National Unity (R-RGoNU) and members of the SSOMA, including delegates from the NAS. The community of Sant�Egidio and Kenya acted as mediators.

From 15 to 18 July 2021, representatives from the RTGoNU and the SSOMA, of which NAS was part, convened for a round of negotiations mediated by the community of Sant�Egidio in Rome. The talks resulted in a Declaration of Recommitment.

In November 2022, the South Sudanese government announced it had withdrawn from negotiations with SSOMA, accusing the rebel alliance to stall for time in order to prepare for war. On 30 January 2022, the South Sudanese government announced the lifting of the suspension of the Rome peace talks. Following this announcement, in February 2022, the Community of Sant�Egidio subsequently mediated a round of pre-negotiations, shuttling between the parties to prepare for formal negotiations.

The first round of official negotiations in the Rome peace process after the suspension of the process took place in Rome in March 2023. In addition to the NAS led by General Thomas Cirilo Swaka, the South Sudan United Front led by General Paul Malong Awan and the Real Sudan People�s Liberation Movement led by Pagan Amum attended the talks. South Sudan�s Minister for Presidential Affairs Barnaba Marial Benjamin headed the government delegation. The talks were mediated by the Community of Sant�Egidio. In December 2023, it was announced that Kenya would take over the peace process from the Community of Sant�Egidio.

Sudan mediated negotiations in Khartoum on 16 January 2022. The negotiations took place on two different tracks. The first track concerned negotiations between the Government of South Sudan and the SPLM/A-IO-Kitgwang and the second track concerned negotiations between the Government of South Sudan and the SPLM/A-IO-Olony. Both tracks led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. The agreement between the Sudanese government and the Olony faction is generally referred to as the Khartoum Agreement. The agreement concluded between Government of South Sudan and the SPLM/A-IO-Kitgwang is formally called the Agreement between the Sudan Peoples� Liberation Movement in Government (SPLM-IG) and the Sudan Peoples� Liberation Movement/Army-In Opposition (SPLM/A-IO) Regarding the Status of Forces. This agreement stipulated a permanent ceasefire, an amnesty of to the leadership and the forces of the SPLM/A-IO Kitgwang, and the creation of coordination offices in Juba, Malakal, and Bor to assist the process of assembling and reintegration of the forces of the SPLM/A-IO-Kitgwang into the South Sudan People�s Defence Forces (SSPDF).
agreement_name: Agreement between the Sudan Peoples� Liberation Movement in Government (SPLM-IG) and the Sudan Peoples� Liberation Movement/Army-In Opposition (SPLM/A-IO) Regarding the Status of Forces

description: The Libyan government announced a ceasefire in response to the international intervention. The Libyan government would later recommit to a unilateral ceasefire on 20 and 25 March 2011, but government forces continued to conduct offensive operations. On 28 March 2011, the government also declared a cessation of hostilities in response to fighting in Misrata with NTC, but this ceasefire did not lead to any changes on the ground. Jacob Zuma headed an AU mission to Tripoli on 10 April 2011 to talk to President Gaddafi and present him with a peace plan. The next day, the AU mission consulted with the NTC leadership in Benghazi. Since the AU peace proposal did not include Gaddafi�s departure, the NTC rejected the peace plan and rejected to participate in direct peace talks to discuss the proposal. The AU mission to Libya had received its mandate at the 265th meeting of the AU Peace and Security Council, held in Addis Ababa on 10 March 2011, when the AU established a High-Level ad hoc Committee on Libya. The Committee consisted of the AU Commission Chairperson, Jean Ping, as well as five countries represented by their respective presidents: South Africa (Jacob Zuma), Mauritania (Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz), Mali (then under Amadou Toumani Toure), Congo Brazzavile (Denis Sassou Nguesso) and Uganda (Yoweri Museveni). The Committee was mandated to �to engage with all the parties in Libya and continuously assess the evolution of the situation on the ground� and �to facilitate an all-inclusive dialogue between the Libyan parties on the appropriate reforms to be carried.� On 17 March 2011, a week after the creation of the AU High Level ad hoc Committee on Libya, the United Nations Security Council gave the go-ahead for military intervention into Libya. The Libyan government announced a ceasefire the next day in response to the international intervention. The Libyan government would later recommit to a unilateral ceasefire on 20 and 25 March 2011, but government forces continued to conduct offensive operations. On 28 March 2011, the government also declared a cessation of hostilities in response to fighting in Misrata with NTC, but this ceasefire did not lead to any changes on the ground. Jacob Zuma headed an AU mission to Tripoli on 10 April 2011 to talk to President Gaddafi and present him with a peace plan. The next day, the AU mission consulted with the NTC leadership in Benghazi. Since the AU peace proposal did not include Gaddafi�s departure, the NTC rejected the peace plan and rejected to participate in direct peace talks to discuss the proposal.
third_party: AU, Congo Brazzavile, Mali, Mauritania, Uganda, South Africa

description: The AU convened an extraordinary meeting on 25 May 2011, at which the leaders called for a ceasefire followed by mediation. Five days later, South African President Zuma flew to Tripoli to consult with al-Gaddafi, but the Libyan leader refused to step down from power.

In June 2011, the Russian chess master and chairman of the international chess federation, Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, was sent on several official missions to Libya by Russia. He met with both President Gaddafi and with the rebels, but did not manage to conclude an agreement or initiate official negotiations.
Russia�s Special Envoy Mikhail Margelov tried to initiate talks a week after Ilymzihinov�s visit, but did not manage to talk to al-Gaddafi.
Meanwhile, on 7 July 2011, a Chinese representative Chen Xiaodong met with NTC in Benghazi to discuss the conclusion of a ceasefire.

From 13 to 14 July 2011, the International Contact Group met in Istanbul with NTC representatives and recognized the movement as the legitimate authority in Libya. Another round of negotiations in the week of 16 July 2011 was conducted in Tunisia between the Libyan government and the United States, but these talks proved unsuccessful as the latter demanded al-Gaddafi�s resignation and the former rejected this.

In August 2011, the Libyan capital Tripoli came under control of the TNC. In parallel to fighting in Bani Walid and Sirte, the NTC proposed a ceasefire during negotiations with Gaddafi�s representatives in early September 2011. However, Gaddafi�s forces continued to fight. One month later, in October 2011, Gaddafi was found and executed in Sirte.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: The conflict parties agreed to a temporary humanitarian ceasefire on 19 November 2014.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: After two unsuccessful attempts to initiate negotiations in the autumn of 2014, the United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) managed to initiate negotiations in Geneva in late January 2015. UN Special-Representative Bernadino Leon acted as the chief mediator at these talks. The negotiations were aimed at concluding a Libyan Political Agreement, which would establish a new governmental structure. The first round of negotiations was held in Geneva on 14-15 January 2015. Following these talks, the GNC government declared a unilateral ceasefire on 18 January 2015, which was reciprocated by the Forces of the HOR.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: The second round of negotiations was held in Geneva on 26-27 January 2015. Another track of negotiations with consultation from the UN Special Representative was being led by Algeria and Tunisia. Tunisian President Beji Caid Essebsi and Sheikh Rached Ghannouchi met with the conflict parties for negotiations in Algiers in March 2015, which led to a framework for the negotiations on 19 March 2015.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Another track of negotiations with consultation from the UN Special Representative was being led by Algeria and Tunisia. Tunisian President Beji Caid Essebsi and Sheikh Rached Ghannouchi met with the conflict parties for negotiations in Algiers in March 2015, which led to a framework for the negotiations on 19 March 2015.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: UNSMIL mediated another round of negotiations on 8 June 2015.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 11 July 2015, following mediation by the UN, a framework called the Libyan Political Agreement was signed by most of the relevant political actors, except the GNC. The framework agreement focused on the basic terms for the Libyan state-building process and outlined the steps to get to a Government of National Accord (GNA).

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Progress was made in the following months. During negotiations mediated by the UN, the parties agreed to annexes of the accord on 21 September 2015.
agreement_name: Annexes to the Libyan Political Agreement

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Another round of UN-mediated negotiations in Sikhat, Morocco, focused on reaching agreement on the membership of the proposed Presidency Council on 7 October 2015.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: UN-mediated negotiations in Skhirat in December 2015 led to the signing of the Libyan Political Agreement on 17 December 2015. This comprehensive peace agreement created a Presidency Council with Fayiz al-Serraj as Prime Minister. The HOR lost its status as the internationally recognized government following the creation of the GNA.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 2 January 2016, the Presidency Council convened its first meeting in Tunis. That same month, it released a proposal for a Government of National Accord (GNA) for the HOR to accept, which the HOR did on 25 January. However, there was a faction within the HOR that rejected the GNA. Those HOR members that endorsed the agreement attempted to meet with the breakaway group between 18 and 21 April, but they were unsuccessful. It was not until 30 March 2016 that the Presidency Council of the GNA was officially set-up in Tripoli. Following the formation of the GNA, efforts continued to obtain unified and full support from the HOR for the GNA. UN-mediated negotiations on the inclusivity of the GNA were held in Tunis between 16 and 18 July 2016.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Prime Minister Fayiz al-Serraj convened with members of the HOR on 22 August 2016 to discuss a new proposal, but this proposal was rejected. In response, the new Libyan government publicly stated that it intended to function with or without HOR support.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: UN-mediated negotiations on the inclusivity of the GNA were held in Tunis on 5 and 6 September 2016.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: The UN also mediated negotiations on the inclusivity of the GNA in Malta on 10 and 11 November 2016.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: UNSMIL continued its active role in supporting the peace process, but Egypt took over as a key mediator in late 2016. In December 2016, Egypt hosted negotiations between GNA and HOR representatives in Cairo, although these negotiations would shift later in the month to focusing on the forces of General Haftar and his rivals in the West and South of the country.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: UNSMIL staff held a meeting with HOR President Agila Saleh on 5 January 2017 in an attempt to continue to work towards an inclusive government. A consultation meeting regarding implementation of the Libyan Political Agreement and to get the HOR on board was held in Ghadames on 17 January 2017. No third party was involved in this meeting.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Another consultation meeting was held in Tunis between 22-24 January 2017. These meetings led to the signing of the Hammamet Agreement on 24 January 2017. This agreement addresses structural issues of the Presidency Council and other governmental bodies, as well as the implementation of the Libyan Political Agreement by the HOR.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Prime Minister Fayiz al-Serraj and General Khalifa Haftar, leader of the Libyan National Army, engaged in negotiations in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) from 2 to 3 May to discuss an end to armed fighting.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: The HOR created a committee of 24 representatives on 24 April to implement the Hammamet Agreement, while the government created a committee of 13 representative to this purpose on 9 May 2017. The committees met for negotiations, mediated by the Minister for Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands, in The Hague on 23 May 2017.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 29 May 2017, France unilaterally held a summit with Serraj, Haftar, Saleh and Khaled Mishri of HOR. This produced a plan for 2018 elections.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Another round of negotiations involving the HOR and government committees tasked to implement the Hammamet Agreement took place in The Hague on 7 July 2017.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: France mediated between Serraj and Haftar in Paris in July 2017, which led to a ceasefire on 25 July 2017. This ceasefire was sporadically violated throughout the year.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: The UN Special Representative introduced an Action Plan in Tunis in September 2017 that focused on institutional development and elections. The HOR and government committees met again in Tunis on 26 September 2017. This meeting was mediated by UNSMIL and led agreement on the restructuring of the Presidency Council and other institutions. A formal proposal was released on 10 November 2017.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: UNSMIL mediated a round of negotiations between Serraj and Haftar, as well as several members of the High Council of State, in Paris on 29 May 2018. This led to an agreement on holding elections.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: From 12 to 13 November 2018, a peace conference was hosted by Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte in Palermo in order to discuss elections and stabilization in Libya. Representatives from HOR and GNA as well as 38 UN-members states were in attendance, producing a document summarizing their efforts on the final day of the conference.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Along with the US, France, and the UAE, the UN mediated between Haftar and Serraj for another round of peace talks in Abu-Dhabi. This meeting was held near the end of February 2019. While the parties verbally agreed to uniting the government and preparing for elections, no formal agreement came out of this effort. The UN prepared a National Conference to further the political dialogue, but this conference never materialized because of renewed attacks led by Haftar.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: The Moscow Conference took place in January 2020 and was aimed at achieving a ceasefire in the Libyan conflict. Russian President Vladimir Putin called on Egypt and the UAE to press General Khalifa Haftar to halt military operations and support efforts for a political solution ahead of this conference. The context of this appeal by Putin was that Haftar received substantial military support from other countries besides Russia, such as France, Egypt, and the UAE, diminishing Russia�s leverage.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 6 January 2020, UNSMIL facilitated the first meeting of the economic track of the intra-Libyan dialogue in Tunis.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 9 and 10 February 2020, UNSMIL facilitated the second meeting of the economic track of the intra-Libyan dialogue. This second meeting was held in Cairo. It involved 28 representatives of Libyan economic institutions and economic experts. The participants agreed to a draft term of reference for a Libyan expert economic commission and the creation of three working groups to refine specific policy recommendations.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: In the context of the western, Tripoli-based government receiving military support from Turkey, Qatar, and Italy and the HoR receiving military support from the United Arab Emirates, Egypt, France, and Russia, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and Russian President Vladimir Putin met in Istanbul on 8 January 2020 to discuss the war in Libya. The meeting ended with both Erdogan and Putin calling for a ceasefire to go in effect on 12 January 2020.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 19 January 2020, the UN and the German government organized the Berlin Conference. During the conference, Serraj and Haftar designated their representatives for the UNSMIL-facilitated 5+5 Joint Military Commission. This committee was compiled by five senior military officers chosen by the Libyan government led by Serraj and five senior military officers chosen by the HoR led by Haftar. The committee was chaired by UNSMIL.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: From 3 to 8 February 2020, the 5+5 Joint Military Commission, made up of five representatives from each of the Libyan sides, held their first meeting in Geneva. The meeting was held under the auspices of UNSMIL with the aim of reaching a lasting ceasefire and restoring security to civilian areas.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 16 February 2020, the international follow-up committee to the Berlin Conference convened its first meeting in Munich, Germany. The committee was co-chaired by the German government and UNSMIL, with support from South Africa and Tunisia.
third_party: Germany, International Follow-Up Committee (AU, France, Italy, Turkey, UK, UNSMIL)

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: During a round of negotiations held from 18 to 23 February 2020, UNSMIL mediators prepared a draft ceasefire agreement with provisions for the safe return of civilians to their areas of residence.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 26 February 2020, UNSMIL convened a meeting of the Libyan Political Forum in Geneva. It was attended by 50 members of the HoR and the High Council of State, as well as other political representatives, women leaders and civil society representatives were invited to attend.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 2 April 2020, UNSMIL organized the second meeting of the follow-up committee to the Berlin Conference, conducted via closed-circuit television. During the meeting, both conflict parties were urged to halt military actions and implement a humanitarian pause. This pause would enable a collective focus on addressing the challenges posed by COVID-19.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Between 9 April and 25 August 2020, the security working group, co-chaired by France, Italy, Turkey, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, and the African Union, held 11 meetings. Their efforts were focused on ensuring the commitment of the Government of National Accord and the Libyan National Army to the 5+5 Joint Military Commission talks, contributing to the maintenance of security and dialogue between these parties. In addition, within the same time window, between 9 April and 25 August 2020, the political working group, co-chaired by Algeria, Germany, and the League of Arab States, convened four times with the aim of supporting a political solution to the conflict. Their focus was on facilitating the resumption of the intra-Libyan dialogue. Within the same time window, between 27 April and 25 August 2020, the economic working group, co-chaired by Egypt, the UN, and the EU, has met four times to solidify policy recommendations stemming from discussions within the intra-Libyan economic track. Finally, again within the same time window, between 8 May and 25 August 2020, the international humanitarian law and human rights working group, co-chaired by the Netherlands and Switzerland, has held two meetings. Their focus has been on determining key priorities to promote human rights and ensure adherence to international humanitarian law, particularly in the context of advancing towards a ceasefire.
third_party: France, Italy, Turkey, UK, Northern Ireland, AU, Algeria, Germany, League of Arab States, Egypt, EU, UN, Netherlands, Switzerland

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 6 June 2020, the President of Egypt, Abdel Fattah Al Sisi, mediated between Haftar and Saleh. This led to the signing of the Cairo Declaration. This declaration called for a ceasefire in Libya, set to begin on 8 June 2020. On 9 June 2020, France, Germany, Italy, and the EU issued a joint statement, calling on both Libyan and international parties to cease all military operations in Libya and actively participate in UN-led security-track talks.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 23 July 2020, the international follow-up committee to the Berlin Conference met online. The conflict parties did not meet for negotiations in August, but they declared a ceasefire on 21 August 2020.
third_party: International Follow-Up Committee (AU, France, Italy, Turkey, UK, UNSMIL)

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Negotiations were resumed in September. These negotiations brought together key Libyan stakeholders under the auspices of the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) and UNSMIL in Montreux from 7 to 9 September 2020. The meeting was aimed at addressing the aspirations of Libyans for stability, as well as tackling the country�s critical economic, social, and health challenges. Following the ceasefire declarations on 21 August 2020, the meeting�s objective was to reinvigorate the political process, initiating what the participants termed the Preparatory Phase for a Comprehensive Settlement. The group agreed to forward their recommendations to the forthcoming Libyan Political Dialogue, to be convened under UNSMIL. The recommendations from the meeting on Libyan stakeholders in Montreux, Switzerland, encompass a range of initiatives aimed at stabilizing and democratizing Libya. Central to these is the Preparatory Phase for a Comprehensive Settlement, a time-limited phase dedicated to establishing the necessary conditions for parliamentary and presidential elections within eighteen months, based on a mutually agreed constitutional framework. A significant restructuring of the executive authority was proposed, including the formation of a Presidency Council consisting of a president and two deputies, as well as a separate Government of National Unity. The selection of members for these bodies would be conducted through the Libyan Political Dialogue, with the Head of the Government of National Unity responsible for proposing the government and ensuring it reflects Libya�s diverse geographic, political, and social makeup. The Libyan Political Dialogue would also play a crucial role in periodically evaluating the performance of the executive authority. Concurrently, the House of Representatives and the High Council of State were charged with appointing individuals to key sovereign positions and delineating the electoral process within established timelines. Additionally, a relocation of the executive institutions and the House of Representatives to Sirte was proposed, contingent on the fulfillment of security and logistical requirements. A strong emphasis was placed on national and social reconciliation efforts, including ending unlawful detentions, enacting amnesty laws for political prisoners, supporting the return of deported and displaced individuals, and offering reparations for damages while preserving rights to legal action.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 11 September 2020, delegates from Libya�s rival administrations, the GNA and the HoR, held discussions in Morocco known as the �Libyan Dialogue.� They reached an agreement on the criteria for appointments to key institutions in their country.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 16 September 2020, Turkey and Russia met for another round of negotiations on their military support to Libya�s internationally-recognized Government of National Accord (GNA) and the HoR respectively. The meeting took place in Ankara.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 23 September 2020, the Egyptian President Abdel Fattah Al-Sisi met with Khalifa Haftar and Speaker of the HoR, Aqila Saleh, in Cairo.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Ahead of a peace meeting in Tangiers, Morocco, a round of pre-negotiations, referred to by the parties as a �preliminary session� was attended by 75 deputies from Tripoli and Tobruk on 3 October 2020. This round of pre-negotiations also took place in Tangiers.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 5 October 2020, parties involved in the conflict held a meeting in Tangiers, Morocco, to unify the parliaments in Tripoli and Tobruk.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 9 October 2020, delegations from the Libyan Supreme Council of State and the HoR met in Malta as part of ongoing Libyan talks.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 12 October 2020, meetings between representatives of the High State Council and the HoR were taking place in Cairo.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Between 19 and 23 October 2020, the fourth round of in-person meetings of the 5+5 Joint Military Commission took place in Geneva, under the UN supervision. At the last day of this round of peace talks, on October 23, the parties signed a ceasefire agreement that was meant to be a �permanent� ceasefire.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: In November 2020, the 5+5 Joint Military Commission held meetings in Ghadamis, Sirte, and Marsa al-Burayqah to focus on implementing the ceasefire agreement and working on the unification and restructuring of the Petroleum Facilities Guard.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: From 7 to 15 November 2020, the UNSMIL facilitated the first round of the Libyan Political Dialogue Forum (LPDF) in Tunis. The LPDF was a platform for inclusive discussions among various Libyan constituencies, mediated by UNSMIL and the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), including international working groups on the economic, political and security aspects of the conflict. Out of 75 participants, 13 members were nominated by each of the HoR and the High State Council, while the remaining participants were selected by UNSMIL to create geographical and political counterweights to the legislative members. On 15 November 2020, the Forum agreed upon a political roadmap that included holding presidential and parliamentary elections on 24 December 2021. The first round of negotiations produced a document entitled �The Preparatory Phase for a Comprehensive Solution�, which had been adopted based on consensus.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: A round of negotiations was held in Tangier, Morocco, from 23 to 28 November 2020.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 30 November 2020, delegations from Libya�s High Council of State and HoR held a coordination meeting in Morocco to prepare for formal negotiations.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 6 December 2020, another coordination meeting was held in Ghadamis in Libya.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 21 December 2020, the acting Special Representative initiated the virtual launch of the legal committee of the Libyan Political Dialogue Forum (LPDF). The committee followed up on the discussions of the constitutional committee established by the HoR and the High State Council. It was mandated to provide recommendations, including proposals, for a suitable constitutional framework and electoral arrangements for the national elections.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: From 13 to 16 January 2021, the UN Acting Special Representative Stephanie Williams held a meeting in Geneva with a smaller group of eighteen forum delegates called the Advisory Committee to establish consensus on a voting mechanism for the Libyan Political Dialogue Forum (LPDF). The LPDF adopted �The Selection Mechanism for the Unified Executive Authority Adopted by LPDF Members� on 19 January 2021.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 21 January 2021, the economic working group � co-chaired by Egypt, the United States, and the European Union � organized a plenary meeting with the Governor of the Central Bank of Libya and the two ministers of finance. The aim was to reach an agreement on unifying the budget with UNSMIL�s facilitation. The following week, UNSMIL conducted meetings with the ministers of finance and the Central Bank of Libya, leading to an agreement on a consolidated two-month interim budget for January and February.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: From 1 to 5 February 2021, UNSMIL convened the Libyan Political Dialogue Forum (LPDF) in Geneva, with the support from the Government of Switzerland. On 5 February 2021, Libyan delegates nominated a new unified interim executive for the country. Mohamed Mnefi from eastern Libya was selected to lead a new three-person Presidency Council and Abdulhamid Dabaiba, a businessman from Misrata in western Libya, was nominated as the prime minister-designate. This executive was expected to serve until the scheduled late-2021 elections.
third_party: UNSMIL, Switzerland, Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD)

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: From 8 to 12 February 2021, the Constitutional Committee, initiated by the HoR and the High State Council in Libya to establish a constitutional basis for national elections, held a meeting in Hurghada, Egypt.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 11 February 2021, UNSMIL convened a plenary session of the Libyan economic dialogue to seek the views of economic experts on recent economic reforms and receive recommendations on the way forward. Representatives of both sides in the conflict also attended the talks.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 25 February 2021, the International Follow-up Committee on Libya conducted a virtual meeting. The participants expressed their commitment to finding a solution to the conflict. The next month, on 10 March 2021, the HoR endorsed the new Government of National Unity in Sirte. Garnering significant support, the new government led by Prime Minister Abdulhamid Dabaiba secured the vote of confidence with 132 votes in favor and only two against. Both rival governments agreed to an orderly transfer of power. The primary responsibility of the new Government of National Unity was to oversee the organization of elections that were scheduled for 24 December 2021.
third_party: International Follow-Up Committee (AU, France, Italy, Turkey, UK, UNSMIL)

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 26 March 2021, UNSMIL convened a virtual meeting of the Libyan Political Dialogue Forum (LPDF).

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: From 7 to 9 April 2021, UNSMIL convened a meeting of the legal committee of the LPDF in Tunis. The committee advanced in completing a draft constitutional framework that outlines how legislative and executive powers will function after the elections.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: From 8 to 10 March 2021, the 5+5 Joint Military Commission, consisting of five senior miliary officers from both sides, engaged in negotiations in Sirte. During this period, they also met with the security working group of the International Follow-up Committee on Libya.
third_party: International Follow-Up Committee (AU, France, Italy, Turkey, UK, UNSMIL)

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: The UN Special Envoy mediated a round of peace talks attended by the 5+5 Joint Military Commission in Sirte on 27 April 2021. The talks focused on discussing progress in the ceasefire implementation and the remaining steps required to reopen the coastal road.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: The political working group � co-chaired by Algeria, Germany, and the League of Arab States � held a plenary session on 18 March 2021. The Chair of the High National Elections Commission provided an update on preparations for the national elections.
third_party: Algeria, Germany, League of Arab States

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Between March and May 2021, the international humanitarian law and human rights working group � co-chaired by the Netherlands and Switzerland � held three plenary sessions. The sessions focused on the issue of arbitrary detention and its consequences, including its impact on the political process and local and national reconciliation activities. In addition, the importance of maintaining and expanding humanitarian space was discussed. Finally, the meetings focused on the need to ensure that the ceasefire led to tangible benefits for civilians, such as freedom of movement and access to essential services and markets.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: The two sides engaged in discussions in Ankara on 1 August 2022. These talks focused on the constitutional framework for elections and how to address the deadlock concerning the executive.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 5 August 2022, Turkish and Russian Presidents held talks in Sochi. The Sochi meeting between Turkey and Russia primarily focused on cooperation in Syria and Libya. The talks took place in the context of Russia and Turkey supporting opposing sides in both the war in Libya and the war in Syria. In the context of Libya, the two leaders emphasized their strong commitment to Libya�s sovereignty, territorial integrity, and national unity. They underlined the importance of holding free, fair, and credible elections with broad consensus and reiterated their support for the ongoing Libyan-led political process.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 9 August 2022, the 5+5 Joint Military Commission and UNSMIL met in Sirte, with the participation of eight Libyan ceasefire monitors and representatives of the 5+5 Joint Military Commission subcommittees. During this meeting, they reviewed the readiness of the Libyan ceasefire monitoring mechanism, activated a joint operations room in Sirte, and finalized the modalities for the planned withdrawal of foreign forces, foreign fighters, and mercenaries from Libya.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: The conflict parties held a meeting regarding the constitutional framework for elections and the executive deadlock in Alamayn in Egypt on 14 August 2022.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 11 October 2022, a delegation from the HSC travelled to Bayda to discuss political issues with members of the HoR.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 27 October 2022, the Special Representative of the UN for Libya mediated a meeting of the 5+5 Joint Military Commission in Sirte. side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: The security working group � co-chaired by the UN, France, Italy, Turkey, the United Kingdom, and the AU � met in Tunis on 8 December 2022.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: Following a meeting on 5 January 2023, Speaker of the HoR Aguila Saleh and President of the HSC Khaled Mishri announced in Cairo that they would task a joint committee composed of members of the two chambers with submitting a draft constitutional basis to the two houses for consideration and that they would later set out a road map for the holding of elections.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 15 and 16 January 2023, the UNSMIL ceasefire monitoring team engaged in discussions with the 5+5 Joint Military Commission in Sirte. The primary focus of this meeting was establishing the working procedures for the monitors. They deliberated on how to integrate the monitors� activities into plans aimed at withdrawing foreign fighters, foreign forces, and mercenaries from Libya. The Commission also approved the terms of reference of a subcommittee on disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration. Moreover, as part of the ceasefire agreement�s Article 2, the 5+5 Joint Military Commission reached an agreement to establish a swift and agile joint military force. The UNSMIL actively supported the 5+5 Joint Military Commission in evaluating the structure, makeup, responsibilities, and positioning of this force, taking into account developments following the ceasefire agreement�s signing.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: The UN Special Representative chaired a meeting with the 5+5 Joint Military Commission and the liaison committees of Libya, Niger and Sudan in Cairo on 7 and 8 February 2023. They agreed to establish an integrated mechanism for joint coordination and data exchange to facilitate the full withdrawal of foreign fighters and mercenaries from Libya.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 26 February 2023, the leaders of the HoR and HSC agreed to establish a joint committee referred to as the �6+6� committee to finalize the necessary constitutional and legislative framework for the holding of elections. The HoR elected its six representatives to the committee. The HSC had not yet convened a session to formally nominate its six representatives.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 15 March 2023, the UNSMIL facilitated a meeting of the 5+5 Joint Military Commission and leaders of armed groups from eastern and western Libya. The meeting was held in Tunis and discussed efforts to ensure a conducive security environment for elections and the protection of civilians.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 16 March 2023, a meeting of the security working group took place in Tunis. The meeting involved the Chiefs of Staff from both western and eastern regions of Libya, along with the presence of the 5+5 Joint Military Commission. This session encompassed discussions at both ambassadorial and technical levels. The technical session focused on reviewing the list of necessary equipment for a joint military force proposed by the Commission. Participants also examined the projected roles this force would undertake within Libya.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 27 March 2023, the UN Special Representative held a meeting in Tripoli with the 5+5 Joint Military Commission alongside armed group leaders representing various regions of Libya. The meeting�s outcome was a public statement wherein all participants pledged their support for the upcoming 2023 elections in Libya.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 7 April 2023, the UN Special Representative mediated a meeting in Benghazi, uniting the 5+5 Joint Military Commission with leaders from armed groups representing eastern, western, and southern regions of Libya. This gathering aimed to build trust among military and security leaders in support of the political process. The primary goal was to foster a secure environment that would facilitate the upcoming free and fair elections.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 9 April 2023, the UNSMIL organized a meeting in Sabha involving security and military actors operating in the southern region. The meeting�s conclusion saw participants commit to establishing a secure environment conducive to peaceful elections in Libya. They also made public commitments to reject any form of violence in the country, address challenges concerning internally displaced persons, and support national reconciliation.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 24 May 2023, a hybrid plenary meeting of the security working group was held. The meeting was co-chaired by Turkey and the UN and attended by the 5+5 Joint Military Commission and members of the International Follow-Up Committee on Libya.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: The 6+6 committee met on 6 June 2023. Following this meeting, it was announced that they had finalized the draft laws on presidential and parliamentary elections.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: From 17 to 18 July 2023, facilitated by UNSMIL, the 5+5 Joint Military Commission and two Chiefs of Staff held a meeting in Paris.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 25 July 2023, a plenary session of the security working group took place in Benghazi. The meeting brought together the 5+5 Joint Military Commission and members of the working group to review the advancements in implementing the ceasefire agreement from October 2020. Their discussion primarily focused on the progress concerning the withdrawal of foreign mercenaries, fighters, and forces from Libyan territory, as well as the establishment of a unified joint military force within the country.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: On 26 July 2023, the newly formed high committee on financial oversight convened for a second meeting in Tripoli.

After clashes during the first half of March 2016, the conflict parties entered into negotiations. This led to an agreement on 16 March 2016 that stipulated that Khalifa�s forces along with other opposition groups would withdraw from Tripoli.
Algeria opened an unofficial process, bringing together the conflict parties several times during the first half of the year.

Blaise Compaor�, acting as ECOWAS mediator, met with Ansar Dine in an attempt to get the group to end its relationship with Al-Qaeda. On 11 December 2012, MNLA and Ansar Dine again met for a second round of talks with Compaor� in Ouagadougou, where they agreed to end hostilities with the government. The peace process involving Ansar Dine initiated in 2012 came to an abrupt end when the Islamist groups started moving south, possibly towards Bamako. This prompted the Government of Mali to request French military support. On 11 January 2013, France launched Operation Serval.
Another round of mediated talks mediated by Blaise Compaor� was held in Ouagadougou between 8 and 10 June 2013 and brought together MNLA and Ansar Dine representatives.

In February 2020, former Malian President Ibrahim Boubacar Ke�ta expressed a willingness to engage in dialogue with Malian jihadist leaders, which was seen as a significant development. His high representative for central Mali, Dioncounda Traor�, had also mentioned sending emissaries to initiate talks with jihadist leaders like Iyad ag Ghaly and Amadou Koufa. However, the specifics of these discussions were never made public. On 8 March 2020, JNIM released a communique indicating its willingness to negotiate with the Malian government, on the precondition that the French military �occupation� would end. While no formal negotiations between the national-level government and the JNIM took place following these statements, a local peace process subsequently took place between the JNIM and local state authorities. At a meeting on 18 April 2020 in Bin�dama, local Fulani and Dogon leaders agreed to work towards peace in the Koro circle through engaging with the JNIM. Local state authorities subsequently established contact with JNIM representatives in June 2020 through an exchange of prisoners. During a meeting the local state authorities and the JNIM agreed to a truce, covering sixteen villages.
