Local state authorities and the JNIM held another meeting in a corner of the bush between the villages of Dinangourou and Dioungani in July 2020. JNIM imposed restrictive demands during this meeting, demanding that the local population is forbidden from carrying weapons, drinking alcohol, and smoking cigarettes. It was also agreed during this meeting that the question of stole animals would not be addressed in the future in order to avoid further violence. The negotiations led to an agreement on 27 July 2020 to which 108 villages in Koro circle and Bandiagara circle.

On 26 August 2020, Abyei businessmen organized a lunch for the chairman of the Sudanese government negotiating team Mohamed Hamdan Daglo, also know as Hemetti, and South Sudanese Vice-President Hussein Abdelbagi. The event was organized to discuss tensions between Sudan and South Sudan in Abyei.

By the end of the ordinary session of the Joint Political and Security Mechanism (JPSM) meeting held on 18 January 2023 in Juba, co-chaired by Sudanese Minister of Defence Lieutenant General Yassin Ibrahim Yassin and South Sudan Minister of Defence and Veterans Affairs Hon. Angelina Teny, the Sudanese and South Sudanese representatives emphasized their commitment to fully implement the Cooperation Agreements and the Agreement on Security Arrangements signed by Sudan and South Sudan in 2012. This meeting involved high-level delegations and was aimed at operationalizing the commitments made by President Salva Kiir Mayardit of South Sudan and General Abdel Fattah Al Burhan of Sudan during their meeting in Juba on 12 January 2023, focusing on bolstering bilateral relations between the two countries.

From 2 to 5 August 2014, the Lebanese Committee of Muslim Scholars (Hay�at al-Ulemaa al-Muslimin) mediated peace talks between the Lebanese government and Islamist fighters belonging to the Al-Nusra Front and the Islamic State. The two parties eventually reached a 24-hour ceasefire on 5 August 2014. The aim of the ceasefire was to allow time for �a mediator� to investigate the fate of 25 missing soldiers.

On 5 September 2014, a Qatari envoy mediated between IS and al-Nusra militants to negotiate a solution to the hostage crisis and relay their demands back to the government, since the conflict parties were not ready to negotiate directly.

On 30 September 2014, a Qatari envoy accompanied by elements of the Lebanese General Security negotiated the release of Lebanese soldier Kamal al-Hujayri in Arsal, where IS and the al-Nusra Front fought Lebanese troops in August. While the IS and the al-Nusra Front withdrew after the ceasefire concluded in August 2014, they took about 20 soldiers and police officers hostage.

In late November 2014, following months of talks with intermediaries, the government declared that it was meeting directly with militants from IS and al-Nusra to negotiate a prisoner swap deal. Qatar formally ended its mediation in December 2014, after the al-Nusra Front executed a hostage, the Lebanese policemen Ali Bazzal.

In January 2015, negotiations between the Government of Lebanon and IS and al-Nusra continued for the release of the remaining soldiers and policemen taken hostage by the terrorist groups in August 2014. Arsal Deputy Mayor Ahmad Fliti was appointed as mediator by Progressive Socialist Party leader Walid Jumblatt to negotiate with IS and al-Nusra. In February 2015, mediation was resumed by Qatar between the government and al-Nusra, while negotiation with IS was suspended. Ransom money was reportedly the key demand for the release of the prisoners.

In April and May 2015, the government of Lebanon resumed negotiations with IS over the release of Lebanese servicemen captured in August 2014 in Arsal. While the process stalled with IS, the Qatari mediator manage to negotiate the long-awaited prisoner swap deal between al-Nusra militants and the Lebanese government on 1 December 2015. In January 2016, IS, which was holding eight Lebanese hostages, announced that it was ready to resume prisoner exchange negotiations. The reasons given for this shift were the jihadist group�s rivalries with the Nusra Front for control of Arsal and the desire for official recognition of its organisation by the Lebanese state.

On 27 August 2017, the government of Lebanon announced a unilateral ceasefire. The ceasefire allowed for negotiations on the same day related to the fate of nine Lebanese soldiers abducted in August 2014 in Arsal. The Lebanese Officer Abbas Ibrahim mediated the talks between the army and IS. The ceasefire led to the surrendering of IS fighters, who left the region with their family.

From the moment the UCDP considered this conflict an intrastate conflict, the UCDP recorded the first fighting in 2016. Yet, the two sides had already met for peace talks mediated by Ethiopia in Addis Ababa in early April 2013.

The conflict parties also engaged in a round of negotiations, mediated by Turkey, in Ankara on 13 April 2013. This round of negotiations led to the signing of the Ankara Communique, which stipulated, among others, intelligence-sharing, cooperation in fighting terrorism, extremism and piracy, and in combatting the illegal dumping of poisonous materials in Somali waters. The conflict parties also committed themselves to further negotiations.

Another round of negotiations mediated by Turkey took place from 7 to 9 July 2013 in Istanbul. The talks in Istanbul did not discuss the contested issue of Somaliland�s sovereignty, but did result in an agreement allowing Somaliland to receive international aid directly from donors and to enjoy full control of its airspace.
Another round of negotiations mediated by Turkey was held in Istanbul from 16 to 19 January 2014.

A new round of negotiations was held in Djibouti on 21 December 2014. The conflict parties reaffirmed all the points of agreement reached in earlier negotiations. A round of negotiations scheduled to take place in Istanbul in early 2015 was cancelled and the peace process broke down. The reason for this breakdown was that the Somaliland leadership was upset about Somalia�s intention to send a negotiating team that included individuals who trace their roots to Somaliland.

At the initiative of the President of Djibouti, Isma�l Omar Guelleh, Mr. Farmajo and the President of Somaliland, Muse Bihi Abdi, held a consultative meeting in Djibouti on 14 June 2020, aimed at facilitating the resumption of dialogue between Somalia and Somaliland. Besides the President of Djibouti, the Prime Minister of Ethiopia, Abiy Ahmed, also attended the meeting as a mediator. During this round of pre-negotiations, the two sides agreed to form a joint committee. The meeting took place in Djibouti and had the support of the US and the EU. At the end of this meeting, the parties agreed to form a joint committee that would meet in Djibouti on 15-17 June 2020.

The joint committee met in Djibouti from 15 to 17 June 2020, under the mediation of the Minister for Foreign Affairs of Djibouti and facilitators from the US and the EU. The committee deliberated on the way forward for the talks, established three technical subcommittees on aid coordination, airspace management and security cooperation, and agreed to resume its work in Djibouti.

On 28 and 19 December 2023, Somalia and of Somaliland held a conference to resume dialogue, marking the first such negotiation since 2020. The talks, mediated by Djibouti President Ismail Omar Guelleh, involved key actors such as Somali President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud and Somaliland leader Muse Bihi Abdi. The parties agreed on a roadmap for the following 30 days, collaboration on security and fighting organized crime, and a pledge to work together for peace and stability in conflict zones.

Switzerland and the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) conducted pre-negotiations between the conflict parties in Saint-Luc, a small village in the canton of Valais, on 25 and 27 June 2019. These negotiations were aimed at initiating formal negotiations. However, the mediation process ended in failure due to distrust from certain factions within the secessionist movement.
A round of negotiations was held in Geneva in early July 2019.

Another round of negotiations was held in Geneva on 20 July 2019. The Swiss Process, as it was later referred to, did not result in any formal agreement or end the conflict. The effort was ended in December that year.

From 30 September to 4 October 2019, the Cameroonian government hosted the Major National Dialogue in Yaounde. This was intended to unite the country and bring an end to the crisis of Ambazonia. A majority of insurgents refused to participate, with the exception of a faction from Fako.
In April 2020, Ambazonian separatist leader Sisiku Julius Ayuk Tabe met with government representatives to explore the possibility of a ceasefire.

Ceasefire talks between the government and separatist leaders, including Sisiku Julius Ayuk Tabe, resumed in July 2020. During this meeting, both sides reached a mutual understanding on key points, which included a commitment to confine security forces to their barracks, the release of all prisoners, and the acceptance of a third-party mediator for future talks.

From 29 October to 1 November 2021, Canada played a facilitating role by bringing together various groups in Toronto for pre-negotiations. Among the participants were separatist political-military leaders, civil society representatives, traditional authorities, religious leaders, women�s and youth groups. No government representatives participated in this meeting. The meeting was rather aimed at finding common ground and to prepare for possible talks with the government.

On 13 September 2022, representatives from the separatist coalition ACT, comprising political-military factions and civil society organizations, met with Swiss special envoy Ambassador Gunther Bachler in another round of pre-negotiations. The Cameroonian President Paul Biya reportedly informed Swiss President Ignazio Cassis in the same month that they were contemplating a military solution, leading to the rejection of the Swiss mediation effort aimed at initiating negotiations.

During a meeting in March 2022, the Swiss mediation team raised a request for the Cameroonian government to provide clarity regarding its mandate. However, Yaound� declined the Swiss initiative and instead urged Switzerland to endorse the negotiation process based on the National Dialogue that had been held between September and October 2019.

In July 2022, French President Emmanuel Macron held discussions with President Paul Biya. Macron conveyed the idea that a decentralization process and enhanced dialogue had the potential to bring a resolution to the conflict in the English-speaking regions.
On 4 August 2022, the Cameroonian government convened the follow-up committee of the National Dialogue in Yaound�.

Following Switzerland�s withdrawal from its mediating role, delegates from the government and different Anglophone separatist groups convened for a round of pre-negotiations in Toronto from 10 to 14 October 2022. This meeting marked the commencement of a new initiative aimed at revitalizing peace negotiations between the involved parties.

In October 2022, the government initiated preliminary discussions with Anglophone leaders residing in the diaspora. This paved the way for government officials in Yaound� to participate at higher levels in pre-negotiation discussions mediated by Canada.

In January 2023, following a round of shuttle talks between the conflict parties, mediated by Canada, the parties agreed to initiate a formal peace process. This involved the forming of technical committees to begin work on confidence-building measures through mediation by Canada. However, no other negotiations mediated by Cananda were held throughout the rest of 2023.

However, the ceasefire soon broke down and the Seleka managed to take over control of Bangui by March 2013. The Seleka subsequently deposed Boziz�, while installing Michel Djotodia as President. On January 10, 2014, a conference in N�Djamena brought about the end of the regime of Djotodia, paving the way for a political transition. Chadian President Idriss D�by convinced Djotodia to step down, after which former mayor of Bangui Catherine Samba-Panza was elected as the new president by the new transitional government. The Seleka alliance subsequently rebranded itself as ex-Seleka. Several negotiations took place between the ex-Seleka alliance and the government. In June 2014, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) initiated the first peace initiative following the crisis in 2013. A discussion on possible mechanisms to resolve the armed conflict at a workshop that brought together 30 Central African participants from varying backgrounds � including representatives from government, anti-Balaka, and ex-Seleka � led to the idea of organizing a forum.

Furthermore, on the side-lines of the 23rd Ordinary Summit of the African Union in Malabo, Equatorial Guinea, in June 2014, the leaders of the Economic Community of Central African States (ECCAS) agreed to organize a ceasefire conference in Brazzaville in July 2014. The leaders also agreed to organizing popular consultations and to implement the idea of the HD workshop to organize a forum, which would later lead to the Bangui National Forum. Congolese President Sassou Nguesso, in his capacity as the ECCAS chief mediator, mediated the ceasefire negotiations between the anti-Balaka and the FPRC in Brazzaville in late July 2014. The Government of the Central African Republic was also involved in the negotiations. These negotiations led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement on 23 July 2014. However, clashes continued between the non-state armed groups.
agreement_name: Accord de cessation des hostilit�s en R�publique Centrafricaine (Brazzaville Agreement on Cessation of Hostilities)

description: Several of the non-state armed groups operating in the Central African Republic participated in a mediation process led by the Kenyan government in Nairobi, with negotiations taking place in early 2015. Building on these ceasefire negotiations, the mediation effort in Nairobi was subsequently replaced by the Bangui Forum in which the government also participated. The United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (MINUSCA) provided political and logistical support to Bangui Forum. Abdoulaye Bathily, the UN Special Representative for Central Africa, chaired the Forum. Special Representatives were also sent by the African Union and the Republic of Congo to support the negotiations. Technical support and expertise were given to the mediations by HD and the EU. Around 600 representatives from the Central African Republic participated. The Bangui Forum was held between 4 and 11 May 2015 and led to the conclusion of two negotiated settlements. First, the parties concluded the Agreement between the Transitional Government and the armed groups on the principles of disarmament, demobilization, reintegration and repatriation and integration into the uniformed State forces of the Central African Republic on 10 May 2015. This agreement included provisions on a ceasefire, as well as on the disarmament, demobilisation, and reintegration for all the armed groups that signed the agreement, including the Front populaire pour la renaissance de la Centrafrique, Rassemblement patriotique pour le renouveau de la Centrafrique, Union des forces r�publicaines fondamentales, Seleka r�nov�e, Mouvement des lib�rateurs centrafricains pour la justice, Front d�mocratique pour le progr�s de la Centrafrique, Coordination des ex-combattants anti-Balaka, Unit� du peuple centrafricain, R�volution et justice, and the Union des forces r�publicaines. Second, the Bangui Forum resulted in the conclusion of the Republican Pact � or in full the Pacte r�publicain pour la paix, la reconciliation, et la reconstruction en R�publique centrafricaine � which, among others, established a local and national mechanism for reconciliation. This agreement was signed by the government and nine out of the ten armed groups operating in CAR. In addition to the ECCAS-led mediation effort and the mediation effort as part of the Bangui Forum, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) mediated a unilateral ceasefire agreement with the FPRC in N�Djamena on 20 December 2015. Cheikh Tidiane Gadio acted as the chief mediator of the OIC. Noureddine Adam promised to refrain from seeking independence from the Central African Republic, issued a unilateral ceasefire, and stated that the ceasefire would make it possible to hold elections. Legislative and presidential elections were held without significant armed fighting in late 2015.
third_party: MINUSCA, Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), EU
agreement_name: Agreement between the Transitional Government and the armed groups on the principles of disarmament, demobilization, reintegration and repatriation and of integration into the uniformed State forces of the Central African Republic, Republican Pact

description: In February 2016, the AU mandated Mohamed El Hacen Lebatt as its special representative. Lebatt launched what was referred to as the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation. Angola, Chad, the DRC, and ECCAS supported this AU-led mediation effort. Talks mediated by Lebatt in February 2016 did not lead to an agreement.
third_party: AU, Angola, Chad, Democratic Republic of Congo, ECCAS

description: In late 2016, Angola, which had been mandated by the International Conference on the Great Lakes region, mediated between the transitional government and several armed groups � including the anti-Balaka, the FPRC, and the MPC - in Luanda in December 2016. Andr� de Oliveira Jo�o Sango, director general of the secret services, acted as the chief mediator. The Angolan mediators proposed a general amnesty, which was widely condemned in Bangui. The negotiations in Luanda ended without an agreement.
third_party: Angola, International Conference on the Great Lakes Region

description: In March 2017, the Community of Sant�Egidio started a mediation process mainly involving the non-state armed groups operating in the Central African Republic. This led to an agreement, referred to as the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic. The agreement reaffirmed the 2016 elections. In addition, the agreement called for the integration of all �politico-military groups� into the peace process and a restoration of state authority. The agreement also included an immediate countrywide ceasefire. The ceasefire did not hold. Armed clashes between several armed groups already took place in the Bria area already one day after the signing of the ceasefire. The government was not involved in the negotiations in Rome, but the government could nevertheless build on these negotiations. On 28 June 2017, President Faustin Archange Touad�ra held meetings with the representatives of the 14 armed groups that had signed the peace agreement in Rome on 19 June.
agreement_name: Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic

description: With it being clear that the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic of June 2017 did not succeed, the AU presented its roadmap for peace in Libreville on 17 July 2017. The roadmap agreement assigns the responsibility for leading peace negotiations in the Central African Republic to the AU, while pledging to take into account the achievements of previous peace initiatives including the peace agreement mediated by Sant�Egidio in June 2017. The Roadmap created an African Panel of Facilitators, with panel members from the AU, ECCAS, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, Angola, Chad, the Republic of Congo, and Gabon. MINUSCA was granted observer status. The African Panel of Facilitators mediated for the first time in Bangui between 11 and 12 September 2017.
third_party: African Panel of Facilitators, AU, ECCAS, International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, Angola, Chad, Congo, Gabon, MINUSCA

description: On 28 August 2018, Russia � which had begun supplying the Government of the Central African Republic with arms and military instructors in February 2018 � and Sudan mediated negotiations between the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the one side and the anti-Balaka (represented by Maxime Mokom) on the other side. The government was not part of this peace initiative as it expressed its support to the AU-led peace process. The negotiations led to the signing of declaration of understanding and a pledge to support the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation in the Central African Republic led by the AU and regional states with the support of the UN. The UPC and MPC expressed that they were no longer committed to this declaration in October 2018, but they made it clear that they still supported the African Initiative. While the government was not part of the negotiations held in Khartoum in August 2018, these negotiations paved the road for subsequent peace talks in Khartoum in which the government was involved. Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The APPR was signed by 14 non-state armed groups and the Government of the Central African Republic. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements, making the agreement essentially an elite-level pact to buy off armed group leaders.
agreement_name: Accord politique la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: On 20 February 2008, elders from the Xawaadle and Abgal clans mediated between the conflict parties in Beled Weyne.
When violence broke out again on 11 September 2008, clan elders from the area once again immediately mediated between the conflict parties.

A round of negotiations mediated by representatives of the Islamic Administration and clan elders led to the conclusion of a preliminary peace agreement on 24 February 2009, which among other things stipulated a ceasefire. Islamic Administration forces were subsequently deployed in the area in order to sustain the ceasefire while reconciliation talks continued.

On 26 October 2009, mediation by local leaders and Harakat Al-shabab Mujahideen (also known as Al-Shabaab) led to the conclusion of a final peace agreement. In addition to stipulating a ceasefire, this agreement stipulated that future disputes would be resolved according to Sharia law.

Quickly after the clashes between the Ghana Abudu and Andani began, the Ghanian government stepped in and created a specialized committee to support peace efforts. Led by Professor Adzei Bekoe, this group was composed of six members and collaborated with religious groups and the Northern Regional Security Council. The mediation committee mediated between the leaders of the conflict parties in Tamale and Yendi in early April 2002. Additionally, on 25 April 2002, the government created a three-person commission of inquiry called the Wuaku Commission in order to help reconcile the communities.
third_party: government, religious leaders, Northern Regional Security Council, local peace committee

description: In April 2002, the Coalition of Muslim Organizations (CMO) facilitated a peace meeting between the Ghana Abudu and Andani.

In 2003, the Ghanian government formed the Otumfuo Committee of Eminent Chiefs, tasked with resolving the conflict. This team was headed by Asantehene Otumfuo Osei Tutu II, chief Nayiri-Na Bohugu Shirigu of the Mamprugu, and chief Yagbonwura Bawa Dosie of the Gonja. This mediation team collaborated with the Ministries of Interior and Chieftaincy and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP). Negotiations mediated by these third parties led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in Dagbon on 14 April 2003.
The Otumfuo Committee of Eminent Chiefs continued mediating between the conflict parties throughout 2004.

The Otumfuo Committee of Eminent Chiefs continued mediating between the conflict parties throughout 2005. This led to the signing of a roadmap to peace that called to establish an interim regent from the Andani.

The Otumfuo Committee of Eminent Chiefs mediated peace talks between the conflict parties in 2006. Consequnetly, the conflict parties signed the Roadmap to Peace in Dagbon in Kumasi on the 30 March 2006. In early April 2006, the tribes agreed that Kamakuya NaaAbudali Yakubu Andani would be the regent.
Fighting began again on 25 August 2006. On 29 August 2006, Otumfuo Osei Tutu II, mediated between the tribal leaders from both sides.
A mediation effort by the Otumfuo Committee of Eminent Chiefs from 16 to 18 November 2007 led to the conclusion of a final peace agreement on 18 November 2007.

The leaders of the political parties took part in the inter-party Peace and Security Committee�s meeting held at Transcorp Hilton Hotel on 17 January 2008 in response to this outbreak of violence. Negotiations mediated by the Honourable Ado Moses Okino led to the signing of a ceasefire on behalf of their supporters.

In early September 2011, after renewed clashes between the supporters of the PDP and ACN, the Oyo State Police Commissioner invited the executive committee of the PDP and ACN to a peace meeting aimed at ending the violence.

A new round of peace talks between supporters of the PDP and the ACN was held in Afon Allaye in Ekiti State in July 2013 in response to renewed fighting. The traditional chief of Afon Allaye, Oba Emmanuel Aladejare, the Allaye-in-Council, and the Efon Development League acted as the mediators.

On 11 March 2003, President Obasanjo convened the leaders of the AD and PDP to a peace meeting at Ibadan Airport lounge in view of the April elections. The leaders signed a pact guaranteeing efforts towards peaceful elections.

On 17 June 2003, after violence erupted between supporters of the AD and PDP in Effurun, Divisional Police Officer Umar Mohammed summoned the leaders of the supporters of the PDP and AD to a peace meeting at Ekpan Police Station in the Uvwie Local Government Area in Delta State. This mediation effort did not result in a written peace agreement.
Ethiopian government officials and a local peace committee called Araaraa mediated between the Afar and Kereyou on 8 January 2003. It is unclear whether this effort was successful.

In response to heavy clashes in May 2000, the Ethiopian government created Integrated Security and Peace Committees that comprised security officials and leaders from both sides. These committees were established at the district, zonal and regional levels. The committees helped to mitigate tensions, among others through overseeing the return of stolen cattle and mediating disputes over use of shared land. Armed violence reignited in March 2002. Minister of Federal Affairs Seyoum Mesfin mediated a reconciliation meeting in Awash and in March 2002.
Mesfin mediated another reconciliation meeting in Dire Dawa in March 2002. This meeting did not lead to the conclusion of an agreement.
Prime Minister Meles Zenawi mediated a peace meeting in Addis Ababa in March 2002. This meeting did not lead to the conclusion of an agreement.

The armed conflict reignited in January 2004, following a land dispute on the west bank of Belet Weyne. Elders mediated between the conflict parties during January 2004, but this effort did not lead to an agreement.
A mediation effort by Elders in June 2004 led to the conclusion of an agreement in which both sides promised to avoid civilian causalities. However, both sides violated this agreement.

A peace conference was held in Buqda-Aqable village in January 2005 to reconcile the two subclans, which led to the signing of a peace agreement. This peace conference was mediated by Haji Hussein Ugaases.
Negotiations began at night on 27 October 1999. These talks would end on 28 October with the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement.

Armed fighting reignited in June 2002. The conflict was this time about control over Middle Shabelle, an area controlled by Somali Restoration and Reconciliation Council (SRRC). The Agon-Yar were aligned with the SRRC, while the Warsangeli allied with the Transitional National Government (TNG), which was fighting the SRRC at that time. In response to the new outbreak of armed fighting in June 2002, some elders from Mogadishu and Jowhar mediated negotiations between the conflict parties, but without any results.

A delegation of five ministers of the TNG was subsequently sent to mediate between the clan elders, Sharif Hussein Jilaow and Omar Fiasco, in July 2002. These negotiations did not result in an agreement either.

Heavy fighting took place between the clans on 3 and 4 September 2002. Negotiations following these clashes mediated by Hussein Haji Bod, an Abgal politician, led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 5 September 2002.

Armed fighting between the Ali-Galif and Mahadade subclans started in August 2002. Clan elders, including Hassan Fidow Asir, mediated between the two subclans of the Hawiye between August and September 2002. This led to the conclusion of a ceasefire by September 2002, which terminated the conflict.

Ugandan Colonel Peter Kerim mediated a round of peace talks between the Alur and the Lendu in Mahagi on 15 January 2002. Local leaders from the Warr-Palara, Panduru, and Jukot tribes as well as the district commissioner, were also in attendance at this round of peace talks. Fighting had by and large stopped by January in 2002, but resumed in February 2003, when timber theft by a Lendu sparked renewed violence between the groups, this time in the Nebbi District in Northern Uganda. The United Nations pushed for the Ugandan government to intervene in the fighting.
In December 2003, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and Ethiopian government organized a peace meeting directly between the Anuak and Dinka.

In November 2011, a meeting in Juba was held between a Murle parliament member and a chief to consider conflict resolution methods for the Anuak, Dinka-Bor, Murle and Nuer communities. In late March and April 2012, a disarmament campaign for Jonglei state gathered more than 10,000 arms. Following this effort, on 1 May 2012, a peace conference was held in Bor with the aim to bring peace to the area. Leaders from the Anuak and Nuer participated alongside the Dinka-Bor, Jie, Kachipo, and Murle. Archbishop Daniel Deng acted as the mediator. This peace effort proved successful. On 6 May, with the president of the respective peace committee as witness, the tribal representatives signed a peace agreement. The agreement�s implementation process was moderated by a mixed team of tribal leaders, peace committee members and a civil society group involved in a previous implementation process in Pibor County.

On 23 and 24 May, an inclusive peace meeting was held once again in Bor Town. More than 250 people attended the conference, with participants ranging from government officials to youths. Anuak and Dikna representatives also attended the conference. This conference did not end in a peace agreement.
In early December 2013, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and Ethiopian government mediated a peace meeting between the Anuak and Dinka.
Furthermore, the Prime Minister�s office also mediated between the conflict parties in December 2013.

On 15 November 2003, the Anuak and Nuer attended a peace meeting in Gambella in Ethiopia. This round of negotiations was mediated by a delegation from the Ethiopian government. The peace meeting did not lead to a peace agreement.
In 2004, the Anuak and Nuer participated in a round of mediated negotiations in Ethiopia, but this did not end the conflict.

In November 2011, traditional and government delegates convened in Juba in South Sudan to discuss conflict resolution for the Anuak, Dinka-Bor, Murle, and Nuer communities. Beginning in mid-March 2012, a disarmament program was implemented for Jonglei State in South Sudan. With thousands of guns collected, the next step was a peace conference between multiple tribal groups � including the Anuak, Dinka Bor, Jie, Kachipo and Nuer � that was held at South Sudan Hotel in Bor on 1 May 2012. The talks were mediated by Archbishop Daniel Deng along with members of a peace committee and culminated with the signing of a peace agreement by all those present on 6 May 2012. The implementation of the agreement was overseen by tribal leaders, civil society, and the members of the peace committee.

On 23 and 24 May 2012, another round of peace negotiations took place South Sudan Hotel in Bor. More than 250 representatives of different tribes and the government discussed ending conflict in Jonglei in South Sudan.

The Jonglei Women�s Association (JWA) and USAID organized a women�s peace conference in the state from 12 to 17 March 2013. Although no peace agreement was reached, the participants discussed pathways to peace among all the different tribes in Jonglei, including the Annuak and Nuer.

A team of local elders and civil societies immediately intervened to mediate an informal ceasefire on 22 February. On 22 March, fighting resumed following a dispute between two businessmen associated with each side.

On 26 March, another round of negotiations mediated by local clan leaders and religious leaders succeeded in creating a formal ceasefire. This ceasefire was concluded in order to pave the way for negotiations in Mogadishu aimed at concluding a formal peace agreement. However, the ceasefire did not hold, and a third round of fighting took place from 7 to 14 May.

On 13 May, a mediation team made up of the Mudulood clan mediated a temporary ceasefire. This ceasefire collapsed the same month. The ARS/UIC defeated the ARPCT forces in June 2006, which terminated the conflict.

In September 2007, a conflict erupted between these communities over fertile farmland situated in the Katanda Territorie of Tshilenge in the Baluba Shankadi sector. A police force was sent to the villages to restore order. In addition, a government delegation donated 20,000 US dollars in favor of the victims of the fighting a week following the armed clash between the two communities. The police left the villages in early 2008. In April 2008, the Bena Nshimba launched some new attacks on the crops of Bena Kapuya. As a response, a committee of elders from both communities came together to discuss peaceful co-existence.

On 28 September 2007, government officials, including the inspector general of the police and various ministers, visited the conflict zone of Mbuji Mayi to meditate, but this did not lead an agreement.

A round of negotiations between community leaders of Bena Nshimba, Bena Kapuya, and Bena Mwembia, mediated by the provincial government, led to the signing of a peace agreement in Katanda territory on 11 September 2020.
The Catholic Diocese mediated a truce between the Bokora Karimojong and Jie in March 2001.

Another round of peace talks between the Bokora Karimojong and Jie was held in Nakithikilet in August 2002. This led to a truce on 20 August 2002, which was adopted through traditional rituals rather than the signing of a document.
Terrence Achia, the chairman of the Local Council responsible for the entire district (LC5) of Moroto, mediated a peace agreement between the Bokora Karimojong and Jie clans on 21 October 2005.
The Bokora Karimojong, Jie, and Matheniko engaged in negotiations that led to the signing of a peace agreement in July 2009.
A peace meeting between the Bokora Karimojong and Pian Karimojong took place in late October 2005.

Several peace meetings took place between the Bor Dinka and the Murle in 2016. Baba Medan and Philip Aguer Panyang, the governors of Boma and Jonglei States respectively, organized a peace meeting at Gumuruk, in Boma State, on 19 August 2016. The conference ended without the conclusion of an agreement.

On 30 August 2016, Jonglei state governor Philip Aguer and deputy minister for Defense David Yau Yau mediated between Murle and Bor Dinka representatives. This peace conference was co-facilitated by UNMISS.

Another peace conference was held between the Bor Dinka and the Murle in Bor on 20 September 2016. This conference was mediated by local state officials and ended without the conclusion of an agreement.

On 4 December 2016, Jonglei State Peace Advisor Deng Aguer mediated between the Bor Dinka and Murle at a peace conference in Pibor State. The conference was co-organized by the governments of Jonglei and Boma states, with assistance from UNMISS and ZOA International. The mediation effort led to the conclusion of a peace agreement which stipulated a ceasefire, as well as an end to child abductions, cattle raiding, revenge killings, and hate speech. The agreement also called for the promotion of peace and reconciliation between the communities involved, establishing a secure and safe environment to facilitate free movement of people, goods, and services, and respect for rule of law, human rights and traditional cultures. The peace agreement also stipulates the creation of a joint police force consisting of 1,000 officers. The joint force is to patrol the borders, arrest criminals and ensure the safety of movement and trading activities between Boma and Jonglei.

In February 2017, the UN declared famine in Unity State. This famine triggered cattle raids between Dinka groups and Murle and a series of revenge attacks from both sides. On 11 May 2017, the head of UNMISS, David Shearer, expressed concerns over rising tensions in the Bor-Pibor area, especially tensions between youths from the Dinka Bor and Murle communities. He confirmed UNMISS� commitment to providing support to peace efforts on the ground between these communities. On 13 May 2017, Murle tribesmen carried out a major cattle raid in Jonglei state. UNMISS tried to facilitate peace talks in response. At a peace conference in Juba on 23 May, facilitated by UNMISS, Dinka Bor and Murle representatives signed a ceasefire agreement. Chuol Rambang, Chairperson of the South Sudan Peace and Reconciliation Commission, acted as the chief mediator. The stated objective of the agreement concluded was to �commit and obligate the two communities to immediately cease hostilities and create conducive atmosphere to a comprehensive and inclusive dialogue.� This ceasefire succeeded in preventing any further large-scale violence between these communities in the subsequent months.

In September 2020, UNMISS hosted a peace conference to address the prolonged violence in the Jonglei region involving Dinka, Nuer, and Murle groups. The meeting involved political leaders at national and state levels, community elders, civil society representatives, and other stakeholders engaging in peace talks. The conference led to the signing of the Bor Communiqu� on 9 September 2020, which highlighted a commitment to a bottom-up approach for peace involving youth and local leaders in conflict areas.

From 14 to 18 January 2021, Murle and Bor Dinka armed youth leaders from Jonglei State met in Rumbek in Lakes State for a peace meeting. Galweng leaders acted as mediators during this peace meeting. The meeting led to the signing of the Rumbek Commitment to Peace.

From 15 to 25 March 2021, delegates from Dinka Bor, Murle, and Lou Nuer communities � including women, youth leaders, and traditional leaders � met in Pieri. The negotiations were mediated by the NGO Peace Canal, a NGO financed by UK Aid. Peace Canal worked with a local mediator in each of the three communities. UNMISS provided some logistical support to the process, but UNMISS staff were not present at the conference. The conference was held under the guidance of Nuer Spiritual Leader Gok Deng Dak Kueth. The participants discussed the conflict�s impact and practical steps forward, focusing on issues such as abductions, cattle raiding, and civilian killings, aiming to build confidence in the peace process. The conference led to the signing of the Pieri Agreement by all parties. In this agreement, the communities pledged to support peace efforts, and develop modalities for punishment of perpetrators, return of abducted women and children, and return of stolen cattle.
A Jonglei-GPAA Inter-Communal Governance Structures meeting was held in December 2021 to follow up on the Pieri Agreement.
A Jonglei-GPAA Inter-Communal Governance Structures meeting was held in Juba in late July 2023 to follow up on the Pieri Agreement.
A Jonglei-GPAA Inter-Communal Governance Structures meeting was held Ayod from 2-6 November 2023 to follow up on the Pieri Agreement.

A peace conference attended by participants Bor Dinka, Murle, and Lou Nuer leaders from Bor County from Jonglei State and Gumuruk County from GPAA took place in Juba from 14 to 15 November 2022. The NGO Peace Canal and UNMISS Civil Affairs supported the conference. The conference led to the signing of the Agreement of Peace Dialogue. However, soon after the signing of this agreement, the Lou Nuer and Bor Dinka mobilized to conduct a large-scale attack on the Murle in the GPAA over the course of December 2022 and January 2023. This attack was allegedly in retaliation for the Murle raids into Lou Nuer and Dinka territory, which the Pieri process had failed to stop.

Fighting in 2006 was sparked over the government�s 2003 land policy, which re-assigned portions of the Borana district to the Guji. A cross-country peace conference was mediated by the Ethiopian government in the Yabello woreda from 11 to 18 July 2006. Government officials from the participating groups, regional NGOs and diplomats from the United States and United Kingdom joined the forum. With over 300 pastoralist groups from 19 different countries in attendance, special attention was given to the conflicts involving the Borana, Gabra, and Guji. The special session was led by the Gada councils of the communities. By the end of the conference, the three groups signed a peace agreement.
The Borana Aba Gadaa (traditional leader) mediated between the conflict parties in 2008, but there is no information on the outcome of this mediation effort.
On 15 May 2018, the Borana and Konso attended a peace meeting mediated by the Borena district administrator Abdel Kedir Abdinur. This round of peace talks did not lead to an agreement.
In 1997, the Ethiopian People�s Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF) mediated a round of peace talks between the Borana, Gabra and Garre.

On 5 and 6 January 2010, the tribes took part in a cross-border peace meeting. This meeting was organized by the Dire CEWERU LPC with ACCORD. There were 111 attendees from both countries. The conflict parties reached an agreement regarding resource sharing. To implement this, 14 joint committees were established (9 in Ethiopia and 5 in Kenya) for oversight.

In September 2010, the Borana and Gabra communities participated in locally organized peace caravans. The tribal delegates of the Borana and the Gabra � as well as the Meru, Pokot, Rendile, Samburu, Somali and Turkana � engaged in reconciliation talks as part of these peace caravans.
The Ethiopian Evangelical Church Mekane Yesus mediated between the Burji and the Guji at a peace conference in Doqonnu on 28 March 2010.

On 27 January 2023, a traditional conflict resolution ceremony was held between the two communities. Traditional leaders agreed to reopen a road connecting the Burji and Guji areas, which had been closed in 2022 to limit interactions between the ethnic groups.

On 25 January 2003, Burundian President Pierre Buyoya held talks with CNDD-FDD leader Jean-Bosco Ndayikengurukiye and the leader of a splinter of the Palipehutu-FNL led by Alain Mugabarabona. At this meeting, the leaders signed a memorandum of understanding with regards to the 7 October 2002 agreement. This memorandum established a joint ceasefire commission comprising six members each from the two rebel groups and the government, under the direction of a UN official. However, fighting continued, which ended more or less with a victory for the CNDD-FDD and its government ally. The Palipehutu-FNL nevertheless survived as a rebel group, although having been severely weakened by the fighting.

A peace conference, facilitated by the UN, was held between 6 and 23 January 2008. During this conference, a meeting was held between the CNDP, PARECO, the Government of the DRC, and the Government of Rwanda at the Ihusi Hotel in Goma on 16 January 2008. Although the UN representatives participated in the conference, the two chief mediators were Abb� Appollinaire Malu Malu and Vital Kamerhe. These two Congolese politicians had been mandated to mediate by the Government. Prior to the actual conference the chief mediators went on an extensive awareness-raising tour through North and South Kivu. On the basis of different consultations and meetings during this tour, they drafted a document specifying 15 objectives of the conference. While the organizers of the conference expected 600 participants, around 1500 people showed up at Goma at the start of the conference on 6 January 2008. The role of the UN representatives was twofold. First, the served as observers in order to ensure the neutrality of the talks. Second, in addition to participating in the plenary meetings, the UN representatives held secret bilateral meetings with Government of the DRC and the CNDP leadership. This led to PARECO ending its conflict with the CNDP on 17 January and the conclusion of a peace agreement between CNDP and the Government of the DRC on 23 January. In addition, the Congolese government and 22 armed groups signed a peace agreement � the Acte d�engagement � in Goma on 23 January 2008, committing all parties to an immediate ceasefire and the disengagement of forces from frontline positions. However, soon after the conclusion of this agreement, the CNDP launched a military offensive to dislodge PARECO and Mayi Mayi Mongol fighters from the Bukombo area. Fighting between these parties continued between February and April 2008.
The two sides reached a temporary ceasefire agreement in late June, but this agreement did not address the underlying conflict issues.

Fighting began again on 13 August 2004. Once the fighting stopped on 16 August 2004, neutral clan leaders from Baidao attempted to reconcile the two sides. While this mediation did not lead to an agreement, it reduced tensions between the conflict parties.

In 2005, leaders from the Dabare and Luway convened at the Togaar Hoos peace conference that was funded by the community. Without any third party involvement, this effort led to the signing of a peace agreement.
A government commission traveled to the conflict area to mediate between the chiefs of the two communities in November 2006.
On 30 May 2004, local elders mediated negotiations between the Da�ud and Warsangeli, which led to a ceasefire agreement.
A round of negotiations between the conflict parties on 11 May 2005 failed.
The next day, on 12 May 2005, a chief named Muhamoud Ali mediated between the conflict parties. His efforts resulted in a ceasefire between them.
The Didinga and Toposa reached a peace agreement in 2013 in which the leaders of the tribes vowed to end hostility.

In March 2014 a second peace conference, facilitated by the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) and the East Equatorian State Government, led to another agreement. This agreement stipulated a ceasefire, as well as condemned cattle raids and requested the state government to deploy police personnel into the area.

side_b: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: Clan elders arrived from Galkayo and managed to broker a ceasefire between the two clans on 28 January 2002.

side_b: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: The elders negotiated another peace agreement in July 2002. The two ceasefires of January and July 2002 halted the fighting until 2003.

side_b: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: Another round of negotiations began in 2003, and a peace agreement was produced that allowed for the return of those displaced by the clans� violence. This agreement terminated the conflict. However, the conflict would reignite again in 2019.

side_b: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: Between 18 and 19 December 2019, a team of local authorities from Puntland met with Dir and Sa�ad leaders in Towfiiq to quell tensions. The group met with traditional leaders, but no formal agreement came out of the effort.

The Ethiopian People�s Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF) mediated between the two groups, as well as representatives of the Me�en, in Maji on 6 December 1991. This peace meeting did not result in an agreement.

Another round of negotiations � in which 80 Me�en, 350 Dizi and 20 Suri participated � was held on 11 December 1991. This meeting ended with the conclusion of an agreement that stipulated a ceasefire and a pledge to disarm. The disarmament was scheduled for 15 February 1992. Local elders from the three tribes were selected to oversee implementation.

On 15 February 1992, the EPRDF mediated talks between the Me�en, Dizi, and Suri and oversaw their disarmament. When the Suri did not turn in all their weapons, the EPRDF sought to keep the peace and responded by sending troops to Maji and Turn.
By 2003, the conflict between the Dizi and Suri reignited. The Ethiopian government mediated between the communities various times during 2003.
In 1998, Nyangatom elders visited Turkana elders to perform reconciliation rituals.
The two sides performed traditional rituals at a peace meeting in Kibish in 2004, as well as promised to respect a cessation of hostilities.
In May 2005, bilateral peace talks between the Turkana and Nyangatom led to a pledge to normalize relations.

Later in May 2005, a peace conference, with support from the Kuraz wereda administration, led to the signing of a peace agreement outlining plans for shared grazing resources. However, renewed violence during the second half of May terminated the peace process.

Another peace conference was held with 20 participants in Lokichogio in August 2005. Aimed at reconciling the Dassantech, Nyangatom, and Turkana, this conference was facilitated by the African Union � Interafrican Bureau for Animal Resources (AU-IBAR). This peace conference did not result in a peace agreement.

In the first half of 2006, Ethiopian and Kenyan government officials organized a peace meeting that brought together 120 Dassantech, Nyangatom, and Turkana delegates. Although no peace agreement was reached, the participants indicated interest in a second peace conference in Kenya.
From 5 to 8 April 2006, Development Alternative, the Turkana Peace Initiative, and Oxfam collaborated and facilitated a peace meeting in Turkana North. This meeting did not lead to a peace agreement.
third_party: community leaders, local peace committee, Oxfam

description: After a flare-up of violence on 14 March 2007, district representatives from the Nyangatom administration in Ethiopia convened in Lokitang in Kenya with their Kenyan counterparts to discuss plans for organizing a peace meeting.

This meeting was followed up with a peace meeting between Nyangatom and Turkana representatives, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 6 April 2007. Despite this agreement, there were some violent incidences in June 2007.

In August 2007, the Ethiopian Pastoralist Research and Development Association (EPARDA), Riam Riam, and USAID mediated between the conflict parties. These talks did not lead to an agreement, but both conflict parties agreed to continue peace talks.

The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) mediated a four-day peace meeting between the conflict parties and some other tribes in early December 2007, which led to a peace agreement.
The Conflict Early Warning and Response Mechanism (CEWARN) collaborated with Ethiopian and Kenyan Conflict Early Warning Response Units (CEWERU) to hold peace talks that started in March 2008.

On 11 and 12 July 2008, at another round of talks mediated by CEWARN, attendees agreed on long term strategies to sustain and enhance peace, as well as to establish local peace committees in Nyangatom Wereda of Ethiopia and Kibish division, Turkana North District in Kenya.

On 12 August, the Turkana stole around 13,000 cattle from the Nyangatom. Government delegates from Ethiopia and Kenya mediated between community representatives from the Nyangatom and the Turkana in Nakuru on 10 October 2009.

A second peace meeting mediated by Ethiopian and Kenyan government officials was held in Hawassa on 2 November 2009. During this second meeting the conflict parties agreed on the establishment of a joint cross border administrators committee, to strengthen joint cross border peace structures, and to issue monthly reports on the implementation of the peace process. The Ethiopian delegation was led by the president of the Southern Nations Nationalities and People Region (SNNPNR) and the Provincial Commissioner of the Rift Valley Province led the Kenyan delegation.

A peace meeting was mediated by government representatives and district leaders from Ethiopia and Kenya in Arba-Minch on 6 October 2016. The participants discussed how to resolve conflict between the Dassanech, Nyangatom, and Turkana and reached the Arba-Minch Resolution at the end of the talk.
In 2017, multiple women�s dialogue sessions took place. Women from both tribes attended the Women Intra-healing Dialogue in Omorate from 1 to 2 March 2017.
Women from both tribes also attended the Women-Led Intra-Community Healing Dialogue in Kangaten from 3 to 4 March 2017.

The Peace and Development Center (PCD) and Saint Peter�s Community Network (SAPCONE) started the East Karamoja Cross-border Conflict Mitigation project in March 2017 to promote peaceful coexistence between the Nyangatom, the Dassanech, and the Turkana tribes. The Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD)�s CEWARN supported this project financially. The implementation period started at the beginning of March 2017 and ended by the end of September 2017. The project was focused on the South-Omo-Turkana corridor of the Karamoja cluster. During the implementation period, several peace meetings, forums, and cross-border committees were organized. On 12 and 13 May 2017, PDC and SAPCONE organized an event to form and train Joint Cross-border Peace Committees at Todonyang police station in Kenya. This event gathered local peace committee representatives, influential leaders and community members, women, youth, and local government representatives of Kenya and Ethiopia. The aim was to train participants on how to mitigate conflict and to improve peacebuilding efforts to achieve peaceful co-existence between the Dassanech, the Nyangatom, and the Turkana communities.
On 12 June 2017, the Joint Women Forum was held in Lowaregnak, Turkana County. This initiative was facilitated by PDC and SAPCONE.

A Chief�s Led Inter-Community Dialogue took place in Omorate on 12 June 2017. During this dialogue, attendees discussed past peace efforts, including the Arba Minch Resolution from 2016. The session�s main conclusion was that relations between the Dassanech, Turkana, and Nyangatom had to be further improved and that to this purpose further peace initiatives would take place in the second half of the year.

A joint cross-border peace caravan was organized from 15 to 17 July 2017 to enhance reconciliation, peace-building, and conflict resolution between the Dassanech, the Nyangatom, and the Turkana. At this event at Omorate, 75 people from Turkana County and 75 people from South Omo Zone, as well as local government representatives from Kenya and Ethiopia participated.

On 30 August 2017, the Joint Cross-Border Lower Level Government Official�s Meeting was held at Turmi, Ethiopia in order to prioritize mitigating the conflict between the Nyangatom, the Turkana, and the Dassanech.

On 24 and 25 September 2017, the Joint Cross-border Chiefs� Led Inter-Community Dialogue was held in Omorate, Ethiopia. The peace meeting was facilitated by PCD and SAPCONE. A total of 26 participants attended the peace meeting, including Ethiopian delegates, representatives of local governments in both countries, as well as the Dassanech, Nyangatom and Turkana representatives. During this meeting, participants agreed to conflict resolution mechanisms.
third_party: local NGO, local government, government, Kenya

description: In January 2019, the communities met at a peace conference organized by SAPCONE in the Illemi Triangle. Representatives from South Sudan and Uganda also participated. The conflict parties reached a peace agreement. On 6 April 2019, the Ateker Economic Summit convened tribal youth (from the Jie, Karamojong, Nyangatom, Teso, Toposa, and Turkana communities) in Teso North Sub County. Although this summit did not engage in direct negotiations, it was aimed at promoting peaceful relations.
On 28 April 2019, the governor of Turkana county met in Kibish with representatives from the Nyangatom Woreda District to promote peace between the communities.
In May 2019, Nyangatom and Turkana governors and tribal leaders met for peace talks to further mitigate cattle raiding and tensions.

In July 2019, Kenya and South Sudan decided to establish a joint border commission to stop conflict and promote peace between the Toposa, the Turkana, and the Nyangatom in Elemi Triangle. The Commission was mainly focused on resolving border issues between those communities.

side_b: Suleiman subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: When conflict between the clans over land and water rights reignited on 1 December 2012, Al-Shabaab and local clan elders immediately started to mediate between the leaders of the conflict parties. This led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 2 December, which was officially signed on 14 December.
The FAPC and FNI concluded a non-aggression pact in 2003, as well as an agreement to split taxes earned on trade in the region.

In addition, the FNI and the FAPC both signed the Acte d�Engagement de Kinshasa (English: Kinshasa Act of Engagement) on 14 May 2004, along other armed groups such as the Revolutionary Front for Ituri (FPRI), the Popular Front for Democracy in Congo (FPDC), the Party for Unity and Safeguarding the Integrity of Congo (PUSIC), the Union of Congolese Patriots (Thomas Lubanga) (UPC-L), and the Union of Congolese Patriots (Floribert Kisembo) (UPC-K). In September 2004, the Iturian DDR process officially started.

In addition, President Joseph Kabila attempted to reach a ceasefire agreement at Dar es Salaam in June 2004 with all the non-state armed groups operating in the Ituri region, but was unsuccessful. One of the reasons this round of negotiations failed was that the UPC remained deeply suspicious of the government as mediator, since the government had allied with Nyamwisi�s RCD-KML, which, in turn, had sided with Lendu militias. While direct clashes between the different armed groups had significantly decreased by mid-2004, the armed groups nevertheless continued to harass the local population, collect tax revenues, exploit natural resources, and engage in arms trafficking.

When the FAPC signed a mining deal with a Ugandan-based company to mine gold in the Zani river in Djalasiga, the FAPC and the FNI clashed on 15 June 2004, with both parties trying to control the goldmine and the wider region. MONUC mediated between the conflict parties in July 2004, since the fighting was seen as violating the terms of the Acte d�Engagement de Kinshasa (English: Kinshasa Act of Engagement) which had been concluded on 14 May 2004. Both the FAPC and the FNI were signatories of this agreement, which committed seven militias active in Ituri to end hostilities. MONUC�s mediation effort led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 5 July 2004. However, this ceasefire was already violated on 9 July 2004.

Fighting continued despite combined peace efforts by local business and clan leaders throughout August 2001. The Supreme Court organized a conference between 26 August and 14 November to select a successor to Abdullahi Yusuf. At this conference, clan elders selected Jama Ali Jama as President of Puntland. This led to armed clashes between the forces of Abdullahi Yusuf and Jama Ali Jama in November 2001, with both sides trying to take control of Puntland.

Heavy fighting took place in January 2002. Local clan elders subsequently mediated between the conflict parties in Garowe on 11 January 2002. This effort did not bring peace and on 26 January, they requested Jama and Yusuf demilitarize the city. Abdullahi Yusuf managed to defeat the forces of Jama Ali Jama. As such, Abdullahi Yusuf remained in power throughout his second term as president of Puntland until October 2004. He subsequently became the President of the Transitional Federal Government (TFG).
Both Abdullahi Yusuf and Jama Ali Jama attended the national reconciliation conference in Eldoret, Kenya, in October and November 2002.

Building on the Eldoret conference, Abdullahi Yusuf and Jama Ali Jama signed a peace agreement, which stipulated a formal power-sharing formula, on 17 May 2003. This peacemaking effort was independent of the national process.

In June 2004, the Nigerian government collaborated with the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA), Taraba State government, and UN agencies to repatriate displaced Nigerians. The Institute for Peace and Conflict Resolution (IPCR) and United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNCHR) attempted to facilitate peace talks between the two tribes, but did not manage to initiate direct negotiations.The UN engaged in shuttle talks between the conflict parties in April 2006.

In June 2017, Deputy Haruna Manu, on the orders of Governor Darius Ishaku, held a security meeting with the various tribes of the Mambila Plateau, including the Mambila and Fulani. Yet, violence broke out again soon after this meeting.
After the crisis re-erupted in June 2017, the police commissioner, Mr. Yakubu Babas, summoned the tribal chiefs to a meeting in order to avoid an escalation of the crisis.

Another meeting between the Mambila and Fulani communities took place at the Nigeria Union of Teacher�s hall in Gembu in early July 2017. The chairman, Rev. Ben Ube of the Taraba State chapter of the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN) spoke on behalf of the Mambila tribe, while Alhaji Ahmadu Bello, chairman of the Sardauna chapter of the Miyetti Allah Cattle Breeders Association of Nigeria, was representing the Fulani. This meeting was aimed at ending violence and finding a solution to the crisis.

On 5 March 2018, President Buhari mediated between Mambila and Fulani leaders at the government house in Jalingo. He appealed for justice and peace in the area. However, armed fighting resumed shortly after.

side_b: Ma'alin Weyne subclan of Mirifle clan (Digil-Mirifle)
description: Local administration and neutral clan leaders mediated between the two sides in March 2008, but this did not lead to an agreement.

A cross-country peace conference was mediated by the Ethiopian government in the Yabello woreda from 11 to 18 July 2006. Government officials from the participating groups, regional NGOs and diplomats from the United States and United Kingdom joined the forum. With over 300 pastoralist groups from 19 different countries in attendance, special attention was given to the conflicts involving the Borana, Gabra, and Guji. The special session was led by the Gada councils of the communities. By the end of the conference, the three groups signed a peace agreement.

A mediation team consisting of clan elders and local scholars was quickly formed to mediate between the conflict parties. This led to the conclusion of a temporary ceasefire on 7 June 2005, but the conflict reignited the next day.
third_party: traditional leaders, community leaders, local peace committee

description: The Hiran Council of Elders held talks among each other between 10 and 11 June 2005 in order to determine how to best find a solution to the ongoing conflict. It was decided that a set of elders from the Xawaadle clan would mediate between the conflict parties. Following an intervention executed by a disengagement force on 12 June, the fighters on both sides respected a ceasefire. The Xawaalde team mediated negotiations in Beledweyne between 13 and 14 June. The conflict parties signed a peace agreement on 17 June and a standing committee was set to monitor the implementation of this agreement.

Following armed clashes between Gamai and Pan tribes over land ownership in Namu in Plateau State, Governor Joshua Dariye established a committee for inquiry into the conflict as well as implemented a curfew. Governor Joshua Dariye mediated between the conflict parties in the last week of April 2006, which led to a white paper on resolving the conflict.

From 17 to 19 July 2006, Gamai and Pan leaders attended a peace meeting mediated by the International Foundation for Education and Self Help (IFESH) and the Inter-Faith Mediation Center (IMC). This peace meeting culminated in the signing of a peace agreement.
third_party: International Foundation for Education and Self Help (IFESH), local NGO

description: In June 2016, Gamai and Pan representatives began to participate in an inter-community dialogue process mediated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, along with several other community representatives from South Plateau. This led to the signing of the South Plateau Peace Declaration on 22 December 2016.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), community leaders

description: A subsequent mediation effort was led by Shaikh Ali Gure, a Somali-Kenyan religious leader from the Ogaden clan that had participated in a peace process for a Kenyan conflict involving the Garre. Shaikh Ali Gure mediated between the clan elders of both conflict parties between July and August 2005. This mediation effort led to the conclusion of a power-sharing agreement, but the conflict issue of ownership over the town was left for further peace efforts.
In August 2005, several NGOs from Beled Hawa and the Mandera District Peace Committee mediated between the conflict parties in El Wak, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire.

In June 2006, representatives of the Garre and Marehan attended the El Wak peace conference. This conference was convened by the Somali and Kenyan government representatives, as well as the Mandera District Commissioner. The Juba Valley Alliance (JVA) funded the event. The El Wak peace conference did not end in a written agreement, but the conflict parties agreed to postpone the establishment of an El Wak district administration and instead set up a committee of 15 members to manage the affairs of the district.
third_party: government, Kenya, local government, local NGO

description: Already in December 2004 before the violence had escalated into armed conflict, a team of women mediators led by Dekha Ibrahim Abdi started to held consultations regarding the violence in Mandera in response to the growing tensions. In December 2004, the Malaqyo of the two clans convened for a peace meeting, along around 100 community and religious representatives. The tribes reached a 15-day ceasefire by the end of the talk, but the ceasefire soon broke down.
third_party: traditional leaders, community leaders, religious leaders

description: In December 2004, another round of negotiations led to a verbal 15-day ceasefire, but this ceasefire also broke down.

Dekha Ibrahim Abdi mediated between members of the Garre and Murule communities in a round of peace talks on 11 January 2005. Kenyan government officials were also involved in these talks. These talks led to the establishment of an internal policing system.
On 17 January 2005, Garre and Murule elders attended a round of peace talks mediated by the provincial government. This meeting led to the signing of a ceasefire.

A round of negotiations mediated by Muslim and Christian religious leaders in April 2005 led to the Umal Accord. The Kenyan government served as a guarantor of this agreement and the District Peace Committee was tasked to oversee its implementation.

The Kenyan government dispatched a 40-elder peace team to the Mandera district to foster continued reconciliation in February 2006. This led to the conclusion of another peace agreement between the Garre and Murule.
In 2007, the Ministry for Northern Kenya convened a peace meeting between 50 representatives from the Garre, Murule, and surrounding tribes. This meeting was held in Nairobi.
Peace talks between the two tribes led to the signing of a peace agreement in Mandera on 14 February 2008.

From 28 to 29 April 2008, 15 leaders from the two tribes met for another round of negotiations in Mandera. The negotiations began with separate meetings with each tribe before the two presented their positions in front of the Mandera Mediation Council led by chief mediator Sheikh Ahmed Sudan. The mediation effort led to a peace agreement that included a provision for a task force to monitor the implementation of the February agreement. The federal and local government jointly established a peace committee in 2015 � which included local tribal, religious and political leadership along with delegates from outside the Mandera district � to mediate between the conflict parties.

From 13 to 15 August 2020, the Garre and Murulle communities engaged in a dialogue process to address the escalating tensions. Facilitated by Interpeace and the NCIC, in collaboration with the Mandera County government, the dialogue brought together a committee of 20 members representing both communities, County government officials, and peace stakeholders. The culmination of this process was the signing of the Granada I peace agreement on 15 August 2020, signaling a commitment to harmony and stability between the Garre and Murulle communities in Mandera County.

On 8 February 2021, a peace agreement, known as Sheikh Umal II, was signed. It involved political leaders, elders, religious leaders, civil society members, and security teams of Murulle and Garre clans. The negotiations leading up to this agreement were mediated by Interpeace, NCIC, and the Mandera County government. The agreement outlined directives for immediate cessation of hostilities, reparations led by local peace infrastructure, and the resolution of the territorial dispute by the government.
The Ethiopian government mediated between the conflict parties in June 2008.

In May 2022, a peace conference was held in Enijbara town, in the Ahmara region. Representatives from all of Metekel�s woredas and Awi zone participated. This included Gumuz, Sinasha, Oromo, Ahmara and Agaw.

In June 2022, a traditional peace and reconciliation ceremony was held in Wemebera woreda, in the Metekel zone, in which Gumuz, Sinasha, Oromo, Amhara, Agaw cohabitate. Elders from 11 kebeles of Wemebera woreda participated.

In August 2022, elders from Metekel visited Dangur Woreda Aysika Kebel center and held peace discussions. The Metekel region is diverse, with Gumuz, Sinasha, Oromo, Amhara, Agaw cohabitating in this region.
In an attempt to end the fighting, a government reconciliation mission met with conflict parties on 13 January 2007.

Following a series of retaliatory attacks throughout the first half of December 2008, both tribes agreed to attend reconciliatory talks in Nyala on 20 December 2008, but this was postponed to 25 December. This peace conference was mediated by the Sudanese government with support from UNAMID. The conference would take until 20 February, but failed because the decision on the boundary demarcation between the tribes was unacceptable to the Fulani. Fighting resumed on 9 March 2009.

UNAMID Civil Affairs subsequently mediated between the leaders of the conflicts parties on 19 March 2009. Local authorities also attempted to mediate between the leaders of the conflict parties at a peace meeting between the conflict parties on 30 and 31 March 2009.

Cattle rustling resulted in renewed clashes between the Habaniya and Fulani in early September 2014. In response, UNAMID held meetings with tribal leaders and state authorities to encourage dialogue between the two communities. This resulted in the creation of a mediation committee to further dialogue and peace. UNAMID also met with South Darfur state officials to urge that the underlying and unresolved issue of border demarcation be addressed, which contributed to the defusing of a potentially volatile situation between the two tribes.
In 2006, the local administration organized a reconciliation conference. There, both parties signed a reconciliation document.

Fighting resumed in Sunta locality in March and again in July 2015. No mediation or military intervention took place immediately following the outbreak of clashes in March and early July, but the Sudanese Armed Forces reinforced buffer zones between the two communities in late July. In addition, a �taskforce� including local authorities and representatives of both tribes met in late July to find a sustainable solution to the conflict.

In 2000, the violence broke out in the town of Kaduna, leading to more than 200 casualties. Following this violent confrontation, the conflict leaders entered into a round of negotiations mediated by President Olusegun Obasanjo, which led to an informal agreement on 29 February 2000 in Abuja. Hausa leaders agreed to stop pursuing strict Islamic law.
On 1 March, the Hausa and Igbo met with local and military leaders. This meeting produced a camp for people displaced by the fighting.

On 17 October 2000, during an emergency meeting mediated by the Governor of Lagos, Bola Tinubu, at the state government secretariat auditorium, the Igbo, Hausa and Yoruba leaders reached a peace agreement. However, new clashes broke out the next day.
On 17 October 2001, the Igbo and Hausa engaged in peace talk mediated by the police in Kano. The peace meeting led to the reopening of the Sabon Gari market, where Hausa and Igbo had fought.

Fighting between the conflict parties resumed in February 2002. Representatives of the Igbo and Hausa met in early March 2002 in Lagos at a peace forum inaugurated by the Igbo Eze-Ndi of Lagos, Eze Nwabueze Ohazulike. Alhaji. Hammed Yusuf represented the Hausa community. Both parties expressed their will to end the ethnic conflict and urged the state government to participate in the peace process and to strengthen equity between the two groups.

In mid-March 2002, the peace forum was held again, this time with representatives of the Yoruba communities in addition to the Igbo and Hausa leaders in the Eze-Ndi Igbo � Eze Nwabueze Ohazulike � palace in Lagos, in Ifako. Alhaji Ahmed Arewa led once again the Hausa delegation. The peace talks did not lead to a written agreement.

On 28 June 2004, representatives of 13 communities of the Jos North Local Government Area of Plateau � Afisare, Anaguta, Berom, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Ebira, Tiv, Sayawa, Southern Kaduna, South-South, and Yoruba � signed a peace agreement in Jos in which they pledged not to mix politics and religion and promised to live in peace.

The Center for Humanitarian Dialogue facilitated a series of peace meetings between the Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, and Yoruba between August 2013 and June 2014. Umaru Sani and Barr Zacch O. Nwankpa represented the Hausa and Igbo communities respectively during these negotiations. These meetings were part of the Jos Forum in which in addition to the community leaders, the Federal Government of Nigeria and the Government of Plateau State also participated.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), government, local government, community leaders

description: The Dialogue, Reconciliation and Peace Center (DREP) facilitated a meeting with eight religious leaders and six community leaders from the Hausa, Afisare, Berom, Igbo, Anaguta, and Yoruba communities in Jos on 19 June 2014. The meeting was aimed at working towards peaceful coexistence between Christian and Muslim communities.

The Center for Humanitarian Dialogue facilitated another meeting as part of the Jos Forum in December 2014. This led to the signing of the Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation on 11 December 2014. The agreement represents a public commitment to achieve peace among all signatories.
agreement_name: Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation

description: Following armed clashes in Jos in July 2015, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue mediated a round of negotiations between leaders of the Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, and Yoruba communities in Jos. This led to the signing of a joint declaration to end fighting in Jos.

Representatives of five Local Government Areas � including Sanga, Kachia, Kaura, Zangon Kataf, and Jema�a � were brought together by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue in Kafachan on 23 March 2016 for a peace meeting. Inter-community fighting, including between the Hausa and Igbo, was on the agenda of this peace meeting. The meeting led to the signing of the Kafanchan Peace Declaration, which guarantees the fostering of peace in Kaduna State and was signed by a wide range of actors, including representatives of development and cultural associations, traditional councils, elders, youth, women, and religious leaders.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), community leaders, traditional leaders, religious leaders

description: Peace talks initiated in June 2016 and involving community representatives from six Local Government Areas in the Southern Plateau, including representatives of the Hausa and Igbo communities, led to the signing of the South Plateau Peace Declaration on 22 December 2016. The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue mediated the talks leading up this agreement.

In August and September 2016, Alhaji Kabir Kasim, Deputy Chief Imam of the Jema�a Local Government Area facilitated a meeting between Hausa and Igbo representatives at the Igbo community town hall in Kafanchan. The meeting resulted in the partnership of the security agencies of the two communities to prevent violence from erupting in Kafanchan.

In mid-June 2017, President Yemi Osinbajo met separately with Hausa and Igbo leaders. The purpose of these shuttle talks was to avoid secessionist claims by Igbo leaders, but conflict between the Hausa and Igbo was also discussed. However, the conflict did not subside after these meetings.

On 4 August 2017, a 10-man peace committee equally composed of Hausa and Igbo was set up to find solution to the conflict. A meeting of the committee was held in Kano on 8 August 2017. Isa Tijani acted as the mediator of this meeting, which was aimed at reaching a peace agreement between the two tribes. However, both sides wanted further consultations before committing to an agreement.

In October 2017, the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue brought together several Plateau community leaders in Jos to discuss the recent armed clashes in the state and ways to achieve lasting peace. Among the participants were leaders from the Berom, Hausa, Afisare, Anaguta, Fulani, Igbo, and Yoruba communities. Alhaji Ibrahim Baba Hassan represented the Hausa Community, while Barr. Zacch O. Nwankpa spoke on behalf of the Igbo people.
