This peace meeting resulted in an appeal to all communities, religious groups, and to the Plateau State government to seek lasting peace in the region, but the talks did not lead to a written agreement.

On 26 March 2020, a joint communique was issued by the chairs of ten communities involved in the mediation process facilitated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) in Benue State. The communities included Agatu, Etulo, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Igede, Jukun, Tiv, and Yoruba ethnic groups. The communique focused on upholding peaceful co-existence during and after the COVID-19 pandemic.

Both conflict parties participated in the Plateau State Peace Summit in early August 2002, which led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. Former Plateau State governor Dariye acted as the mediator at this summit.
Four smaller follow-up meetings of the Plateau State Peace Summit were held in September 2002.

Several communities in the Wase Local Government Area, including Hausa and Tarok, took part in a peace meeting in the conference room of Rayfield Government House in Jos on 24 June 2004. The participants concluded the conference with issuing a communiqu� that was signed by the communities at the end of the peace meeting.

In June 2016, Hausa and Tarok representatives began to participate in an inter-community dialogue process mediated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, along with several other community representatives from South Plateau. This led to the signing of the South Plateau Peace Declaration on 22 December 2016.

The violence erupted again in July 1999 in Shagamu, following the murder of a Hausa woman observing a Yoruba traditional ceremony. Some Hausa subsequently fled to Kano, resulting in the spread of violence in that city, where some Hausas attacked Yorubas in retaliation for the Shagamu events. Following the clashes in Kano, Governor and Police Commissioner Abubakar Mairamri visited the affected areas to try to ease the tension and ensure state support. A curfew was imposed and the Emir of Kano, Alhaji Ado Bayero, the Governors of Kano and Lagos as well as the police commissioner appealed for peace in separated broadcasts. In late July 1999, Bola Tinubu, the Governor of Lagos, held a meeting with Hausa and Yoruba leaders in Lagos to encourage peaceful cooperation. Negotiations between both sides in the palace of the Akarigbo led to the signing of a peace agreement on 24 July 1999. The peace pact led to a few months of peace in the region.
The newly elected President of Nigeria, Olusegun Obasanjo, also met with the warring leaders in Kano on 10 August 1999.

Representatives of the conflict parties met again in Ajegunle in the Ajeromi/Ifelodun council of Lagos State on 3 November 1999 and agreed to an immediate cessation of hostilities in Lagos. The signatories were representatives of the Ijaw, the Ilaje, the Hausa and the Oodua People�s Congress (OPC � a Yoruba militia). Dele Alake, the Information Commissioner, along with other members of the State Executive Council acted as mediators.

On 28 November 1999, in reaction to renewed fighting between Hausa and Yoruba over the control over the Ketu / Mile 12 market in Lagos, the Governor of Lagos, Bola Tinubu, mediated negotiations between the leaders of the Hausa and Yoruba communities. This led to a peace agreement in early December.

However, the armed conflict continued in 2000. In October 2000, the government banned the OPC and imposed a curfew on the city of Lagos. Several members of the OPC went to court. On 17 October 2000, the Governor of Lagos, Bola Tinubu, mediated between Igbo, Hausa, and Yoruba leaders during an emergency meeting at the state government secretariat auditorium. This led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. However, armed fighting resumed the next day.

Violent clashes erupting in Idi-Araba on 2 to 4 February 2002 led to the deployment of the Nigerian army in the area and several meetings between government officials and leaders of the Hausa and Yoruba communities. On 5 February 2002, a meeting between the Governor of Lagos State, Bola Tinubu, and the Hausa and Yoruba leaders took place in Lagos. The Governor encouraged the two ethnic groups to achieve peace and reconciliation.

Furthermore, the Chairman of the Lagos Mainland Local Government, Alhaji Bashir Omolaja Bolarinwa, also mediated between Hausa and Yoruba community leaders in February 2002, but this did not lead to a written agreement.

A further meeting was organized by the new Director of the State Security Service (SSS) in the second half of February in Abeokuta, Ogun State, with Yoruba and Hausa leaders to prevent a crisis like the one in Lagos State from recurring. This meeting was aimed at ensuring peaceful coexistence between the communities, but did not result in a peace agreement.
In March 2002, representatives of the Hausa, Yoruba, and Igbo communities gathered at a peace meeting hosted by Igwe H.N. Ohazulike, who himself led the Igbo delegation, in his palace in Ifako.

Violent clashes resumed in the Idi-Araba region of the Mushin local government in October 2002. In response, the Inter-Ethnic Forum brought together Hausa, Yoruba, and Igbo representatives on 11 December 2002 for a peace meeting. This did not result in a written agreement.

A peace meeting hosted by the Inter-Ethnic Forum in Lagos in January 2003 gathered ethnic leaders from the Yoruba and Hausa communities from Idi-Araba. The leaders pledged to cease hostilities. The meeting led to the establishment of several committees � for example elders and youth committees composed of both Yoruba and Hausa � that were to ensure a lasting peace.

On 20 November 2003, in response to a dispute between Yoruba and Hausa traders at the Bodija market (Ibadan North, Oyo State), state police commissioner Felix Ogbandu mediated between representatives of the Bodija market in order to maintain peace in the area.

On 28 June 2004, representatives of 13 communities of the Jos North Local Government Area of Plateau � the Afisare, Anaguta, Berom, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Ebira, Tiv, Sayawa, Southern Kaduna, South-South, and Yoruba � signed a peace agreement in Jos. They pledged not to mix politics and religion and promised to live in peace. The peace meeing was not mediated by an external third party.

On 20 March 2012, following renewed violence in the Mile 12 market in Lagos between youth from the two communities, the local police organized a peace meeting between community leaders at the State Command Headquarters, Ikeja. The Lagos State Police Commissioner, Mr. Umaru Manko, mediated between the conflict parties. The conflict parties agreed to set up a 12-person peace committee. Alhaji Haruna Mohammed represented the Hausa, while Mr. Ashowade Adesina headed the Yoruba delegates. The two groups pledge to stop armed fighting, but did not conclude a written agreement.

The Center for Humanitarian Dialogue facilitated a series of peace meetings between the Afisare, Anaguta, Berom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, and Yoruba between August 2013 and June 2014. These meetings were part of the Jos Forum in which in addition to the community leaders, the Federal Government of Nigeria and the Government of Plateau State also participated.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), community leaders, government, local government

description: The Center for Humanitarian Dialogue facilitated another meeting as part of the Jos Forum in December 2014. This led to the signing of the Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation on 11 December 2014. Umaru Sani and Bankole Falade signed on behalf of the Hausa and Yoruba communities respectively. The agreement represents a public commitment to achieve peace among all signatories.
agreement_name: Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation

description: Following armed clashes in Jos in July 2015, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue mediated a round of negotiations between leaders of the Afisare, Anaguta, Berom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, and Yoruba communities in Jos. This led to the signing of a joint declaration to end fighting in Jos.

However, this joint declaration did not prevent new clashes that started in Mile 12 market and the Kosofe Local Government Area of Lagos on 3 March 2016. While Governor Akinwunmi Ambode immediately shut the market, Police Commissioner initiated peace talks with market leaders to ease tensions.

On 6 March 2016, following the armed violence in Mile 12, the secretary to the state government representing Governor Akinwunmi Ambode, Mr. Tunji Bello, met with market stakeholders including Yoruba and Hausa traditional leaders at the Alausa Secretariat, Ikeja. This meeting led to a peace agreement signed by the stakeholders and the 12 Mile market reopened. Oba Akiolu of Lagos also held a stakeholders� and residents� meeting in at the Iga-Idugaran, Lagos Island at the beginning of March 2016. He supported the relocation of the market as a path to peace. Finally, on 16 March 2016, community leaders and market traders followed the plan of the state government and accepted the relocation of the market.

Five Local Government Areas � including Sanga, Kachia, Kaura, Zangon Kataf, and Jema�a � were brought together by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue in Kafachan on 23 March 2016 for a peace meeting. Both the Yoruba and Hausa were residing in these areas. The peace meeting led to the signing of the Kafanchan Peace Declaration, which guarantees the fostering of peace in Kaduna State and was signed by a wide range of actors, including representatives of development and cultural associations, traditional councils, elders, youth, women, and religious leaders.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), community leaders, traditional leaders, religious leaders

description: Senior police officers and leaders from the Hausa and the Yoruba gathered at a peace meeting in Ibadan on 18 May 2016. This meeting, which was mediated by Oyo State Governor Senator Abiola Ajimobi, was aimed at reinforcing and ensuring peace in the state, especially between herders and farmers.

On 7 March 2017, Yoruba and Hausa traders clashed in the commercial district of Sabo Ile-Ife of Osun State. The clashes escalated, triggering a curfew and the deployment of a team of heavily armed soldiers and officers from the Nigerian Security and Civil Defence Corps (NSCDC) to maintain the peace. In addition, a truth and reconciliation committee was set up by the Ooni of Ife. The committee was inaugurated in Ogunwusi palace in Ile-Ife in early March 2017 and was chaired by the Obalufe of Ifeland. On 23 March 2017, the Deputy Inspector General of Police in charge of Lagos and Ogun, Mr Kayode Aderanti organized a security meeting with representatives of several ethnic groups in Ogun State. The aim of the meeting was to prevent the Yoruba-Hausa crisis from happening again. Furthermore, the Governor of Osun State, Rauf Aregbesola, inaugurated a judicial panel to investigate the remote and immediate causes of the crisis between the Yoruba and Hausa communities on 25 March 2017 in Osogbo.

On 29 March 2017, the Yoruba socio-cultural organization, Afenifere, together with representatives of the Hausa and the Yoruba communities met for peace talks mediated by the Ooni of Ife, Oba Adeyeye Ogunwusi.

In October 2017, the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue brought together several Plateau community leaders in Jos to discuss the recent armed clashes in the state and ways to achieve lasting peace. Among the participants were leaders from the Berom, Hausa, Afisare, Anaguta, Fulani, Igbo, and Yoruba communities. Alhaji Ibrahim Baba Hassan represented the Hausa Community, while Chief Bankole Falade spoke on behalf of the Yoruba people. This peace meeting resulted in an appeal to all communities, religious groups, and to the Plateau State government to seek lasting peace in the region, but the talks did not lead to a written agreement.

Tensions rose again in Akure in May 2018. In response, the state government brought the leaders of the two communities together in the Cocoa Conference Hall for a peace meeting. The meeting resulted in the conclusion of a peace agreement.

On 15 August 2019, after a year of shuttle diplomacy and pre-mediation meetings, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) launched the Benue Mediation Process to find a lasting solution to the farmer-herder conflicts in the region. The meeting took place at the Benue Hotel in Makurdi and brought together representatives of the Agatu, Etulo, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Egede, Jukun, Tiv, and Yoruba communities of Benue State. On this occasion, HD pledged to help the communities achieve lasting peace, while the attending communities pledged to support and actively participate in the mediation process. During this first meeting, it was announced that the mediation process would take place in a joint meeting between tribes from the same senatorial zones.

Clashes erupted between traders of the two ethnic groups at the Oke-Odo market in Lagos on 17 and 18 August 2019, injuring several people and destroying entire food stalls. Immediately after the turmoil, the army, the divisional police officers of the Oke Odo station, and officials of the Lagos State Waste Management Authority mediated between Hausa and Yoruba traders and market stakeholders in an attempt to calm the situation and bring peace to the market. No written agreement was signed but market activities quickly returned to normal.

HD convened a peace meeting with representatives of the Tiv, Idoma, Igede, Agatu, Etulo, Jukun, Fulani, Igbo, Yoruba, Hausa communities in Makurdi in Benue State in early November 2019. Traditional leaders, religious leaders, civil society groups, and security agencies, and state officials were also involved in the peace meeting. This meeting was part of the ongoing mediation dialogue between the conflict parties in the region. Stakeholders stressed the need for peace, but no written agreement resulted from the meeting.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), traditional leaders, religious leaders, government forces, local government

description: On 26 March 2020, a joint communique was issued by the chairs of ten communities involved in the mediation process facilitated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) in Benue State. The communities included Agatu, Etulo, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Igede, Jukun, Tiv, and Yoruba ethnic groups. The communique focused on upholding peaceful co-existence during and after the COVID-19 pandemic.

On 19 June 1999, Christian Nganga Lolo, the administrator of the territoire in which the conflict broke out, organized a conference inviting representatives of the Hema and Lendu elites to settle their dispute. However, the mediation effort did not lead to an agreement.
On 29 July 1999, a reconciliation meeting began in CCI-Nyakasanza and 451 people attended. It continued on 30 July, but did not result in a peace agreement.

Throughout the year, the Ugandan army and rebels aided in mediating the conflict. Wamba dia Wamba who had fled to Bunia in Ituri from Kisangani in August 1999 after the RCD�s split between RCD-Goma and RCD-ML (the latter being thereafter led by Wamba) also tried to mediate between the ethnic groups in 1999 and initially had a pacifying influence as he initiated peace talks and promoted ceremonies of mutual forgiveness. Two initiatives were established by the end of the year to pacify the conflict. The first initiative was the establishment of the Committee of Pacification and Follow-Up in August 1999 by Ad�le Lotsove to investigate the outbreak of violence. The second initiative was the creation of the Commission for Security and Peace in the Djugu Zone by RCD-ML leader Wamba dia Wamba. This commission was led by Jacques Depelchin. Negotiations mediated by Depelchin between November and December 1999 resulted in a brief pause in the fighting, but the conflict reignited in mid-December 1999.

In December 1999, Ugandan president Museveni invited representatives of the Hema, Lendu, and other Iturian communities to Kampala. As a result of this meeting, he replaced some of the Ugandan soldiers which had taken sides and deployed more UPDF troops. In addition, during the negotiations in Kampala, Wamba dia Wamba had asked Uganda to revoke Lotsove�s appointment as governor. She was subsequently replaced with a less controversial figure, Ernest Uringi Pa Ndolo, an ethnic Alur. The violence decreased temporarily.

The year 2000 was characterized by leadership struggles in the RCD-ML. Wamba�s power in the RCD-ML was being questioned by RCD-ML�s prime minister and member of an influential Nande family in North Kivu, Mbusa Nyamwisi and RCD-ML�s minister of mining, finance and budget and former head of the Kilo Moto gold mines in Ituri, John Tibasima, himself from Ituri and the Hema ethnic community. Their forces clashed in Ituri and ended with Wamba�s evacuation by the Ugandans in November 2000. This led to a lack of leadership in Ituri and a militarization of the communal conflict. Both Nyamwisi and Tibasima had trained and recruited soldiers for the RCD-ML from both Lendu and Hema communities and provided them with arms and training. With the lack of leadership, these soldiers now dispersed in their communities, which led to an intensification of the conflict between Hema and Lendu towards the end of 2000. A second round of heavy fighting erupted at the beginning of 2001. Lendu militias attacked Bunia for the first time, especially targeting UPDF headquarters and the airport. From 14 to 17 February 2001, the Front de Lib�ration du Congo (FLC) (English: Front for the Liberation of Congo), specifically via Jean-Pierre Bemba, mediated negotiations between the two groups. A peace agreement was signed by more than 150 local chiefs and notables on 17 February 2001. This agreement stipulated an end to hostilities, as well as included a provision for the new governor to be from neither ethnic group and two vice-governors, one from each ethnic group. The agreement also tasked the FLC �with closing ethnic militia training camps, disarming civilians, deploying security forces, setting up peace tribunals throughout the region, rehabilitating prisons, and creating a special provincial follow-up committee.� The eminent persons present thereafter buried their machetes as a sign of reconciliation. Yet, the agreement was not fully implemented as Bemba lost control over Ituri in November 2001 after the disintegration of the FLC in June 2001 and several violent confrontations took place between RCD-ML and MLC. Ituri was subsequently almost fully controlled by RCD-ML.

The RCD-ML appointed a new governor and chief of staff in Ituri in early 2002, Jean-Pierre Mulondo Lonpondo. Many Hema perceived Jean-Pierre Mulondo Lonpondo as biased in favor of the Lendu, although he was from the Nande ethnic group. This further exacerbated local tensions and violence escalated again throughout Ituri, including in Bunia. In August 2002, the Union des Patriotes Congolais (UPC) (English: Union of Congolese Patriotes), a militia predominately made of Hema fighters, formed a government in Bunia and temporarily managed to rule over most of Ituri. In July and August 2002, informal talks were held between Hema and Lendu representatives in Kinshasa. These talks were facilitated by the Congolese Government with human rights minister, Ntumba Luaba, in the lead. The negotiations did not lead to the conclusion of an agreement. Direct negotiations between the Government of the DRC and the Government of Uganda, mediated by Angolan President Jos� Eduardo Dos Santos, led to the conclusion of the Luanda Peace Agreement on 6 September 2002. This agreement not only put forward a timetable of three months for the Uganda forces to leave Ituri, it also established the Ituri Pacification Commission (IPC). The IPC was tasked, with support from MONUC, to bring together the leaders of all armed groups and representatives of civil society in Ituri in an effort to create an administrative authority for the region acceptable to all parties. However, it would not be until April 2003 before the first meeting of the IPC finally took place.

In the final days of December 2002, Ugandan Lt. General Salim Saleh and Ugandan gender, labour and social affairs minister, Zoe Bakoko Bakoru started to mediate a round of negotiations between the ethnic groups in Arua. The negotiations were aimed at concluding a peace agreement that would commit the Hema and the Lendu to halt hostilities.

The representatives of the UPC and the Front des Nationalistes et Int�grationnistes (FNI) (English: Nationalist and Integrationist Front), representing the Hema and Lendu respectively, were supposed to finalize the agreement in Arua on 1 January 2003, but the UPC refused to sign the agreement last minute. However, five days later, Ugandan Lt. General Salim Saleh succeeded in persuading UPC to sign the accord on behalf of the Hema.

The MONUC leadership sent an exploratory committee to Ituri to secure a local ceasefire and start building confidence among the members of the IPC from 22 to 29 January 2003. The MONUC team met all the actors in the Ituri crisis, including the Hema and the Lendu leaders. All agreed in principle to sign a peace agreement in Bunia. However, the UPC remained reluctant to support the IPC, stating that it was dominated by the government that had sided with Lendu ethnic groups through Mbusa Nyamwisi and wanted to pursue its own peace process so it could recuperate Ituri from the Ugandans.

On 11 February 2003, there was a summit in Dar-es-Salaam, Tanzania between Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni, Hema leader Thomas Lubanga, Congolese President Joseph Kabila, and representatives from Rwanda. This meeting served to relaunch the peace process. It was decided that the IPC would meet for the first time on 25 February 2003 and that the Ugandan troop withdrawal from Ituri would start on 20 March 2003. A ceasefire was scheduled to take effect in February 2003, before the first meeting of the IPC, but this ceasefire was postponed because the UPC questioned the good faith of the governments of Uganda and the DRC and MONUC. This stalled the process once again.

On 3 March 2003, the UN Special Representative Namanga Ngongi, with help from P�tronile Vaweka of the Alur tribe and founder and president of the association Fondation pour la Paix Durable, negotiated a ceasefire in Ituri. On 18 March 2003, Ngongi finally succeeded in creating a ceasefire at a round of negotiations in Bunia: the Ituri Cessation of Hostilities Agreement. However, the UPC, claiming to represent the Hema, refused to sign the ceasefire. The ceasefire also included a provision that stipulated the Ugandan troops to leave the DRC by 24 April 2003.

From 4 to 14 April 2003, the IPC held a meeting with 32 delegations representing all socio-professional categories and armed movements, the governments of the DRC and Uganda. The meeting took place under the aegis of MONUC, represented by deputy special representative Behrooz Sadry. The IPC worked in three sub-commissions on security and cessation of hostilities, reestablishment of public services and rule of law, and humanitarian assistance and rehabilitation. Questions of reconciliation were addressed in bilateral meetings initiated by MONUC. The meeting led to the conclusion of another ceasefire, but also to the creation of an interim administration, the Administration Sp�ciale et Int�rimaire de l�Ituri (ASII) (English: Ituri Special and Interim Administration). The ASII was presided over by an Alur women, P�tronile Vaweka and consisted of a General Assembly with 32 members, an interim executive organ with 5 members, a prevention and verification commission with 18 members, a committee for armed groups concertation with 9 members, and an interim human rights observatory with 17 members. The ASII was eventually relinked to Kinshasa and integrated into the national structure to consolidate the government�s control over its entire territory. When the final act to the Global and Inclusive Agreement at the national level was signed on 2 April 2003 in South Africa, Ituri was not pacified yet. Accordingly, Thabo Mbeki, in his capacity as chairperson of the African Union, invited the presidents of the DRC, Uganda, Rwanda and Tanzania to a meeting in Cape Town on 11 April 2003. In this meeting, Uganda reiterated its willingness to withdraw its forces from Ituri by 24 April 2003. Yet, this withdrawal led to intensified fighting.

On 26 April 2003 the Ugandan army handed over command of Ituri to MONUC. MONUC deployed 700 peacekeepers, while the DRC government deployed 700 Special Forces. Yet, one week later, violence completely escalated with the government forces overwhelmed and MONUC losing control over Bunia in May 2003. In only two days, 562 civilians were killed by militias. In response, the Government of Tanzania and MONUC facilitated a round of negotiations between the Government of the DRC and leaders of the main Iturian militias on 17 May 2003. This round of negotiations led to the conclusion of the Dar-Es-Salaam Agreement on 17 May 2003, which stipulated a ceasefire and the rights of the militias to be eligible for either integration into the national army or civilian reinsertion. On 30 May 2003, the Security Council adopted Resolution 1484, which authorized an interim emergency multinational force to restore peace and aid in humanitarian relief. This force, called Operation Artemis, consisted of 1,800 French troops and a small 80-man Swedish special forces unit. On 12 June 2003, the EU-led mission was launched in Bunia, the main town of Ituri region. The mission was mandated to last until 1 September 2003. In June 2003, the peacekeepers managed to restore security in the town, although massacres continued in the countryside.

On 1 August 2003, three Ministers of the new transitional government, set up in April and May 2003 and coming into being on 18 July 2003, visited Bunia to support the Ituri Interim Administration. With the exception of UPC, the armed groups expressed their willingness to be incorporated into the new armed forces. The new government mediated a round of negotiations between the Ituri militias in Kinshasa on 22 August 2003, which led to a memorandum of understanding in which the militias agree to work with the government to restore state authority across the region.

On 16 September 2003, an agreement to make Bunia a weapons free zone was reached between the conflict parties. Members of the Interim Administration regularly participated in information-gathering missions outside Bunia, where meetings were held with local authorities and populations to inform them of the existing peace process. The Interim Administration also organized successful peace marches in the town and was solving problems related to illegally occupied houses in Bunia. Yet, between 2003 and 2005, Bunia remained divided into two parts: one controlled by FNI and dominated by Lendu ethnic groups and one controlled by UPC and dominated by Hema ethnic groups. All aspects of public life were separated.

On 14 May 2004, the Dar-Es-Salaam Agreement was reiterated in the Acte d�Engagement de Kinshasa (English: Kinshasa Act of Engagement). This agreement, among others, stipulated a ceasefire. The militias that signed this agreement were the Popular Armed Forces for the Congo (FAPC), the Nationalist and Integrationist Front (FNI), the Revolutionary Front for Ituri (FPRI), the Popular Front for Democracy in Congo (FPDC), the Party for Unity and Safeguarding the Integrity of Congo (PUSIC), the Union of Congolese Patriots (Thomas Lubanga) (UPC-L), and the Union of Congolese Patriots (Floribert Kisembo) (UPC-K).

In September 2004, the Iturian DDR process officially started. In addition, President Joseph Kabila attempted to reach another ceasefire agreement at Dar es Salaam in June 2004 with all the non-state armed groups operating in the Ituri region, but was unsuccessful. One of the reasons this round of negotiations failed was that the UPC remained deeply suspicious of the government as mediator, since the government had allied with Nyamwisi�s RCD-KML, which, in turn, had sided with Lendu militias. While direct clashes between the different armed groups had significantly decreased by mid-2004, the armed groups nevertheless continued to harass the local population, collect tax revenues, exploit natural resources, and engage in arms trafficking. The International Committee in Support of the Transition in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (CIAT) gave an ultimatum to all militia groups in Ituri to voluntarily disarm by the end of March 2005 or face major consequences. In early April 2005, CIAT requested that the Government of the DRC launch both national and international arrest orders against leaders of militia groups in Ituri accused of crimes against humanity. Most militia chiefs subsequently stepped down from power or were arrested between March and April 2005.

Fighting resumed in 2016. In March 2016, MONUSCO and provincial authorities helped to facilitate negotiations between the Hema and Lendu in the Irumu territory. This led to a pledge to cease hostilities and a subsequent reduction in violence. However, violence increased not long after.

On 14 July 2017, a commission with Hema and Lendu leaders was formed. Negotiations as part of this commission were mediated by MONUSCO and the regional authorities. Yet, another upsurge in violence took place in December 2017.

Following a series of armed clashes between the Hema and Lendu communities in Djugu territory, MONUSCO staff from Bunia co-mediated a round of peace talks on 29 December 2017, along with the Territorial Administrator of Djugu territory and the president of Committee of Customary Chiefs of Ituri (COCCI). The traditional chiefs from both communities concluded a local agreement. It was also decided to set up local peace committees between neighbouring Hema and Lendu communities in order to enhance mutual trust.
In response to renewed fighting in late 2017, Ramazani Shadary, the Minister of the Interior, came to the region to mediate between Hema and Lendu representatives on 12 February 2018.
From 1 to 22 June 2018, Hema and Lendu community members came to together in Bunia for dialogue facilitated by MONUSCO.
The territory administrator and the traditional chiefs mediated another round of talks between between Hema and Lendu in Djugu in Ituri in July 2018.
Representatives of the Hema and Lendu engaged in peace talks in the week of 10 March 2019. The peace talks were mediated by a government delegation led by the country�s deputy prime minister.
The provincial government of Ituri facilitated a three-day intercommunity dialogue between the Hema and the Lendu in Tchomia between 19 and 21 November 2019.

From 19 to 21 November 2019, tribal and administrative leadership from different communities from Ituri, including the Hema and the Lendu convened for a peace conference. This conference was facilitated by MONUSCO.

On 30 March 2008, during its summit in Damascus, the Arab League formulated an Arab Initiative for the Resolution of the Lebanese crisis. This initiative called for the election of the Commander in Chief of the Army, Michel Sleiman, as the consensus candidate for President, the establishment of a unity government, and the normalization of Syrian-Lebanese relations. From 1 to 3 May 2008, the League�s Secretary General Amr Moussa held talks with Parliament Speaker Nabih Berri, Prime Minister Fouad Siniora, Michel Suleiman, Saad Hariri, Michel Aoun, Hezbollah member of parliament Haj Hassan Khalil, member of parliament Michel al-Murr, and Defense Minister Elias al-Murr to discuss the implementation of the Arab initiative. Since the PSP is a party on the side of the government, these shuttle talks are considered mediated negotiations.

On 11 May 2008, Talal Arslan, a Druze leader and ally of Hezbollah, brokered a ceasefire between the two sides following a request by PSP leader Walid Jumblatt. The two parties were heavily fighting in the mountainous area of Aley, when Jumblatt urged Arslan to secure the redeployment of the Lebanese Army there. However, the ceasefire did not hold.

On 11 May 2008, the Arab League held an emergency meeting and established a Ministerial Committee, led by Qatari Prime Minister Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani and Secretary General Amr Moussa, to intervene in the Lebanese crisis. On 14 May 2008, the government announced the repeal of some of the contentious decisions it had previously made concerning the airport security department and Hezbollah�s communication network. On the same day, the Arab League mediation team led by Qatari Prime Minister Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani visited Beirut to present a six-point agreement aimed at resolving the political crisis in the country. This visit preceded the national dialogue scheduled to take place two days later in Doha. The Lebanese parties agreed on the proposed deal and to engage in new talks.

To resolve the 18-month political crisis in Lebanon, the Arab league committee, headed by Emir Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani of Qatar, organized the Lebanese National Dialogue Conference in Doha from 16 to 21 May 2008. Parties present included Hezbollah, the Amal Movement, the Syrian Social Nationalist Party, the Lebanese Democrat Party, the Progressive Socialist Party, the Future Movement, and the Lebanese Government. Through bilateral and collective meetings, the parties reached the Doha Agreement, which established a power-sharing government and appointed the Commander of the Armed Forces, Michel Suleiman, as president. This agreement also committed the parties to abstain from �resuming the use of weapons and violence in order to record political gains.� Moreover, Hezbollah�s demands were addressed, granting them veto power in the new national unity government and an electoral law was adopted dividing Lebanon into smaller-sized districts.

The trigger for a full-scale armed conflict was the rape of a Newiba girl by a member of the Hotiya in Serif Omra locality. The Hotiya Baggara financially compensated the Newiba during a customary conflict resolution process in October 2005, but this reconciliation process collapsed following an insult by someone from the Newiba delegation. The Hotiya subsequently killed the entire seven-man delegation, which, in turn, prompted a massive counter-attack by the Newiba with support from the Mahariba and Mahamid. The fighting took mainly place in the Nyangadoula area in the Abaata locality.
A reconciliation conference facilitated by the local authorities led to an agreement in March 2006. This agreement successfully terminated the armed conflict.
The Digil and Mirifle Malaqyo peace initiative took place in Xagar village in December 2004.
A parliamentarians-led peace initiative was conducted in Xawaale Barbaar village on 1 January 2005.

The Inter-Riverine Development Agency (IRDA) initiated a peace process between the Hubeer and Yantaar communities on 20 January 2005. A Project Community Committee (PCC) was formed with representatives from both sub-clans and Asharaf elders from Dinsoo, along with three IRDA members to facilitate the process. The first phase of the peace conference took place in Hawaala Barbaar from 3-5 March 2005, with 120 attendees from both sides. They agreed to prioritize implementing points in the accord, including the ceasefire, postponing the core issue. The second phase was scheduled for June 2006 but was delayed due to lack of funds. The emergence of the Islamic Courts Union (ICU) further impacted the process, and in November 2006, the peace accord was broken when a Hubeer militia killed a Yantaar member, leading to revenge killings.
third_party: Inter-Riverine Development Agency, local peace committee

description: On 2 April 2005, the Elay-led peace initiative took place in Qansaxdhere.
In response to several armed clashes on 12 and 13 August 2005, local clan elders mediated between the conflict parties on 20 August 2005.
Local elders mediated between the two subclans at a peace meeting in Idale in February 2006, which led to the confirmation of a peace agreement from 2005.

The Transitional Federal Government (TFG) established the National Reconciliation Commission (NRC) in late 2005 with the task of facilitating reconciliation throughout the country. On 23 November 2006, the NRC arrived in Idale to help find a solution to the conflict between the Huber and Yantar. The NRC brokered a 15-day ceasefire, which was extended for another ten days following another armed clash by the end of the 15-day period.

The ceasefire of November 2006 held, and the NRC facilitated a peace conference in Baidoa on 15 January 2007, which led to the signing of a peace agreement on 15 January 2007. This agreement stipulated that the conflict parties would forgive past actions, that the land, including Idale village, belongs to Allah but that the state would manage it through the municipality, and that the water catchments that triggered the conflict would be managed by the municipality of the village.

The Nigerian government played a central role in mediating between the Ijaw and Isteriki. On 23 April 1997, military authorities announced that they have sent military troop to Warri to restore order. At the beginning of May 1997, youths and leaders from the Ijaw and Itsekiri communities gathered in Effon, near Warri, for a peace meeting chaired by the state administrator, Colonel David Dang, and the General Officer Commanding the 82nd Division of the Nigerian Army, Major General Felix Mojapero. At this occasion, the warring parties agreed to end hostilities. However, there is no public information available on the signing of a written agreement. Furthermore, the Delta State government, under the leadership of the military administrator, Colonel J. Dang, set up a Commission of Inquiry into the violence, chaired by Judge Alhassan Idoko. The commission, composed of Itsekiri, Ijaw, and Urhobo first met in June and July 1997, but the report never went public. As violence erupted again in Warri on 15 June 1997, Itsekiri leaders withdrew from the government commission of inquiry, fearing that the outcome would be unfavorable to them.

As violence between the two communities erupted again in Orgubo on 23 October 1998, the Nigerian government asked the two tribes to meet and negotiate an end to the conflict and instituted a public curfew on 24 October 1998. The leaders of Ijaw and Itsekiri subsequently met at a peace meeting in Asaba, capital of Delta State, on 26 October 1998. This peace meeting was mediated by Commander Walter Feghabor, military administrator, and resulted in a ten-point communiqu� calling for an immediate cessation of the ongoing hostilities. Feghabor, Ijaw, and Isteriki representatives were set to meet with General Abdulsalami Abubaka for follow-up.

At the end of May and June 1999, as Nigeria transitioned from a military to a civilian government, violence erupted again in Warri. As during previous episode of armed fighting, the government quickly sent soldiers to restore order. The governor of Delta State, James Ibori, announced a new curfew on 7 June 1999. Newly elected President Olusegun Obasanjo met leaders of Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Urhobo communities on 9 June 1999 in Abuja to show his commitment to peace in the Warri Delta region and encourage the stakeholders to respect each other and find a peaceful solution to the crisis.

On 9 June 1999, Chief James Onanefe Ibori, Governor of Delta State, held a peace meeting with leaders of the Urhobo, Ijaw, and Itsekiri communities in Warri to prepare the visit of President Obasanjo to Warri.

President Obasanjo then visited Warri on 11 June 1999, held a peace meeting with the leaders and representatives of the conflict parties. On the same day, the National Assembly of Nigeria set up a 12-person committee to investigate the Warri crisis.

Itsekiri, Ijaw, and Urhobo representatives met for two days of negotiations in Asaba on 16 and 17 June 1999. The negotiations were mediated by Governor James Ibori of Delta State. With no progress made, another round of negotiations was scheduled for the next week.

The negotiations mediated by Governor James Ibori one week later, in Asaba on 24 June 1999, were successful and led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement. The agreement was signed by Justice Franklin Atake for the Itsekiris, Chief Edwin Clark for the Ijaws, and Chief Benjamin Okumagba for the Urhobos. On 10 October 1999, representatives of young activists from the Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Urhobo communities announced the creation of a new association: the Warri Peace Vanguard. This association had the aim to help the communities to put an end to the conflict that has ravaged Warri for decades. Government, religious groups, traditional leaders, and private agencies were present at the first meeting of the newly founded association. A six-point peace plan was formed that included supporting government peace programs, mobilizing community development, and promoting a peaceful way of life.

Following negotiations, the Ijaw and Itsekiri signed a peace agreement on 1 February 2000. The Delta State Government mediated this round of negotiations. On 17 March, Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Isoko leaders visited President Obasanjo in Abuja to announce the return of peace to Warri.

In the run-up to Nigeria�s 2003 legislative and presidential elections, fighting broke out again in February between the Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Urhobo ethnic groups in the Niger Delta. Violent clashes between the Federated Niger Delta Ijaw Communities (FNDIC) and Itsekiri militias reached a peak in mid-March. The government sent more than 1,000 troops to the Niger Delta to contain the fighting. On 24 March 2003, James Ibori held an emergency meeting with the leaders of the Ijaws, the Urhobos, and the Itsekiris in Warri. No agreement was signed on this occasion.

The Governor of Delta State eventually agreed to renegotiate the electoral boundaries during peace talks in Warri in the end of March 2003. These peace talks between the Ijaw and Itsekiri leaders and the Delta State government led to the signing of a ceasefire between the two communities on 26 March 2003.
Another ceasefire agreement was reached on 26 March 2003 between the Ijaw youth (FNDIC) and the Itsekiri in the presence of state officials.

On 7 April 2003, Obasanjo met with Urhobo, Itsekiri, and Ijaw leaders in Abuja along with the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC), and security chiefs to further talk about peaceful solutions in Warri. At this meeting, the warring tribes reached a ceasefire agreement. Following this meeting, Obasanjo set up a committee headed by General Theophilus Y. Danjuma, the former Minister of defense. This committee was tasked with investigating the Warri Crisis and proposing ways to solve it. The report of this committee has not been made public.
On 15 May 2003, the national leader of Nigeria�s Ijaw ethnic communities reported that the youth of the Ijaw militia agreed to a ceasefire.

In July 2003, Delta State governor, James Ibori, moved the seat of his government to Warri to personally undertake the peace talks. On 20 July 2003, the Delta State Governor announced that leaders of the two tribes declared a ceasefire in Warri.

Concerned about a possible offensive by the Ijaw and Itsekiri youths, the Deputy Inspector General of Police in charge of Zone 5, Mr. Gazali Lawal, and the Delta State Police Commissioner, Mr. Jonathan Akaya, held peace meetings with the leaders of the two communities in the Police Zone Command Office in Warri on the night of 9 to 10 August 2003. The meeting culminated in a communiqu� signed by Mr. Justice Rewane for the Itsekiri, Chief Bare Etobor and Chief Tunde Smooth for the Ijaws, and by Akaya on behalf of the police. He urged the warring youth to support the government�s peace efforts. However, armed violence still erupted in spite of this effort and Nigerian authorities imposed a curfew on the town of Warri on 15 August 2003.

Nigerian troops were deployed in Warri after some 100 people were killed between 15 and 20 August. In addition, the federal government deployed a joint security force in Delta State: �Operation Restore Hope�, which would be maintained in the following years. On 20 August 2003, the leaders of the two ethnic groups met in Warri and signed a ceasefire mediated by Delta State governor, James Ibori. Chief Edwin Clark, the Ijaw leader, and Bob Mene-Afejeiku, the leader of the Itsekiri, announced, in separate interviews on 27 August 2003, that they agreed with Obasanjo�s proposal to end the crisis in Warri. This proposal involved separating political issues from criminal acts in order to facilitate the resolution of the conflict.

On 28 August 2003, James Ibori, Governor of Delta State, addressed the members of the Delta State Assembly in Asaba and proposed a peace plan for the Warri crisis. The plan called for each of the three warring ethnic groups � the Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Urhobo � to have its own local government area. While Ijaw and Urhobo leaders endorsed it, Itsekiri referred to the plan as �illegal� and �unconstitutional� and expressed their dissatisfaction with it.

On 19 September 2003, Nigerian President Obasanjo attended a meeting with Ijaw, Urhobo, and Itsekiri leaders in Warri in order to promote reconciliation. The meeting was chaired by the state administrator, Colonel David Dang, and the General Officer Commanding the 82nd Division of the Nigerian Army, Major General Felix Mojapero. The Ijaws and Urhobos deplored Itsekiri�s unjust domination of political power and supported Obori�s proposal to create local government areas. Itsekiri representatives once again rejected this proposal.

Governor James Ibori called a security meeting on 10 November 2003 in Warri to prevent a resurgence of fighting in Warri. State officials as well as representatives of the Ijaw, Urhobo, and Itsekiri tribes took part in the discussion.

In late November 2003, President Obasanjo set up a new committee to resolve the Warri crisis, headed by Delta State governor James Ibori. The latter mediated several rounds of negotiations with Itsekiri, Urhobo, and Ijaw leaders.

New clashes began in January 2004 between the two rival ethnic groups in the swamps surrounding the port of Warri. A 28-member peace committee, consisting of 14 Itsekiri and 14 Ijaws, met on 18 February 2004 in Warri. James Ibori and the Commissioner for Special Missions, Inter-Ethnic Relations, and Conflict Resolution, Ovuozorie Macaulay, acted as the mediators. The peace committee meeting led to approval of a six-point agreement aimed at peaceful coexistence between the rival groups. Among the main points are the establishment of a joint peace vanguard composed of members of both groups and an agreement that would allow people displaced by the conflict to return to their homes of origin without fear of attack.

On 1 June 2004, leaders of ethnic Ijaw and Itsekiri youth activist groups signed a ceasefire through the platform of the Warri Ijaw/Itsekiri Grassroots Peace Front (WIIGPF) moderated by Pastor Power Ziakede Aginighan.

Three weeks after the ceasefire concluded by the militias and after more than six months of peace negotiations, the Ijaw and the Istekiri leaders signed a peace agreement on 23 June 2004 at the senior officers� mess, NNS Delta Navy base, in Warri. Delta State Commissioner for Inter-Ethnic Relation and Conflict Resolution, Comrade Ovuzuorie Macauley was chief mediator of the negotiations. On 6 July 2004, three Ijaws chiefs � Wellington Okrika, Jonathan Ari, and Clark Gbenewei � from the 14-member delegation to the 28-member peace committee set up in February 2004 withdrew from the agreement, saying they were no longer satisfied with it. Some Ijaws argued that the agreement failed to address some of the contentious issues that had pitted the other two ethnic groups against Itsekiris, in particular the issue of separate local government for each Warri community.

The ceasefires concluded of June 2004 led to a fragile peace. However, tensions in the Delta North remained. Between 18 and 19 June 2005, Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Isoko (Urhobo) traditional rulers launched a traditional leaders� forum in Ozoro. This forum was initially headed by Ijaw retired Brigadier General Cletus Emein, retired Senator Francis Okpozo, and Itsekiri Chief Isaac Jemide. This forum had the goal to minimize the tensions between the ethnic groups. The meeting resulted in a covenant that recognizes the need to build the capacities of different communities. After renewed violence in the Delta region, President Obasanjo convened a stakeholders� meeting on 6 April 2006. The participants included Senator Fred Brume, Itsekiri leader Chief Isaac Jemide, gubernatorial aspirant Chief Kenneth Gbagi, national president of the Federated Niger Delta Ijaw Communities (FNDIC) Chief Bello Oboko, and leader of the Warri National Congress Mr. Collins Eselomo. The Stakeholders adopted a vote of confidence in the Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC) and called for an increase in its funding.

The fighting took mainly place at the border between the states of Cross River and Ebonyi and lasted two weeks in April 2005. On 23 April 2005, the authorities of Ebonyi and Cross River States met in Calabar to discuss the armed conflict. The governors of Ebonyi and Cross River States subsequently mediated between the Izzi and Ukele leaders in Abakaliki on 15 May 2005. However, fighting continued.

After renewed clashes between the Izzi and Ukele communities, the deputy governors of Ebonyi and Cross Rive States mediated between the conflict parties on 3 July 2018. This led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. The agreement stipulated that both sides would lay down their weapons, as well as establish a peace committee that would investigate the causes of the crisis.

In early December 2019, after repeated attacks between the Izzi and the Ukele, youth from both communities reached a peace agreement after failed efforts from the local state authorities. However, violence resumed in December 2019, which led to the death of a 17-year-old student in the Local Government Area of Izzi.

The Kapoeta, Jie, Dodoth, Turkana, Toposa and Didinga convened for a peace meeting on 13 May 2008. This meeting was organized by Riam Riam Turkana and the Karamoja Agro-pastoral Development Program (KADP).

In June 2008, the East African Safari Air Express, IKV Pax Christi, Intervida World Alliance, and Wilde Ganzen organized a four-day peace conference in Kapoeta in Southern Sudan. Seeds of Peace in Africa (SOPA) acted as the mediator at this conference. Representatives of the Acholi, Buya, Dodoth, Dongiro (Ethiopia), Jie, Kachipo, Lokir (Sudan), Lotuko, Matheniko (Uganda), Murile, Theuso, Toposa, and Turkana (Kenya) attended the peace conference. The conference did not lead to the conclusion of an agreement.
third_party: East African Safari Air Express, IKV Pax Chrsti, Intervida World Alliance, Wilde Ganzen, Seeds of Peace Africa

description: On 7 July 2008, the Jie and Turkana reached a peace agreement in the Kotido district during a round of peace talks mediated by Kenyan and Ugandan government officials.

The leaders of the Jie and Turkana engaged in peace talks in Turkana West district in December 2013. This led to the signing of a peace agreement in which both sides promised to end cattle raiding. This peace effort took place in Turkana West district.

Conflict over cattle raiding continued in 2016. The two tribes met for peace talks in Kotido. This round of talks was initiated by the Jie peace committee and mediated by KOPEIN. The meeting led to the formation of a taskforce to find the stolen cattle. Several community-level meetings were organized by the taskforce afterward to keep the peace.

The Somali Reconciliation Conference in Eldoret, which was mediated by the Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD), started on 15 October 2002 and led to the conclusion of a temporary ceasefire signed by 22 armed groups on 27 October. The conference was attended by most supporters of the TNG, including the JVA. While General Morgan refused to participate in this peace conference, General Morgan and the JVA signed the Eldoret Agreement in December 2002.

The resumption of armed conflict between the Forces of General Morgan and the JVA in 2004 should be seen in the context of the broader national-level power struggle between the TNG and the opposition. In early 2004, General Morgan resumed attacks against JVA. IGAD condemned this military campaign and called for sanctions on 27 July. Morgan was subsequently also denied entry into IGAD member states. Morgan was defeated, and he fled to Nairobi following heavy fighting in Juba in September 2004. General Morgan subsequently declared a unilateral ceasefire and began to participate in negotiations at the conference on 25 September 2004. In November 2004, the Transnational Federal Government (TFG) was established, with support from JVA. With the TFG in place, IGAD stopped its mediation effort to try and reach a formal ceasefire agreement.

In February 2008, five representatives of the Kalenjin and the Kikyyu each engaged in peace talks mediated by the Bishop of Korir and the Catholic Diocese of Eldoret. The meetings were held in a Catholic church in Yamumbi. Local peace committees from the Burnt Forest, Ilula, Kabiemit, Kiambaa, Kimuri, Kimumu, and Munyaka also intermittently participated in the talks.
In August 2008, the Burnt Forest peace committee mediated between Kalenjin, Kikuyu, Kisii, Luhya and Luo elders. The UN Development Programme supported these peace talks.

In April 2011, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) that had been established through the National Cohesion and Integration Act of 2008, the National Steering Committee on Conflict Management and Peace Building (NSC) invited all communities of Nakuru County to participate in the peace talks. The Kikuyu and Kalenjin participated in these peace talks with 40 elders each. The negotiations in April 2011 first consisted of separate meetings for each tribe with the NCIC and NSC, after which the mediation team later facilitated joint meetings.
Another round of negotiations mediated by the NCIC and NSC was held in May 2011. The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) joined the mediation team for the round of negotiations in May 2011.
In March 2012, 24 elders from each tribe negotiated a draft agreement mediated by HD.

In order to gather social support for the agreement, the NCIC and HD met with representatives of Nakuru Business and Professional Women�s Club, religious leaders, and youth. A round of negotiations mediated by the NCIC and HD led to conclusion of the Nakuru County Peace Accord on 19 August 2012 in Nakuru, signed by the Kalenjin, Kikuyu, and other communities in Kakuru.
In August 2008, peace talks were held between the Kalenjin, Kisii as well as Luo and Luhya communities in Kaptembwo. These talks were facilitated by the UN Development Programme.

In June 2001, the West African Network for Peacebuilding (WANEP) mediated peace talks between the conflict parties. The talks, referred to as the Damango Peace Talks, resulted in the two sides signing the Bawku Peace Initiative. WANEP collaborated with several NGOs, including the Advocacy Peace Group, Action Aid Ghana, the Centre for Conflict Transformations and Peace Studies (CECOTAPS), the Christian Council of Ghana, the Bawku East Women�s Development Association (BEWDA), and the Catholic Relief Services (CRS).
third_party: local NGO, Action Aid Ghana, religious leaders, community leaders

description: The government attempted to mediate between the two groups and established a curfew in early December 2001. On 13 December, the government set up a 13-person committee to mediate between the conflict parties and compensate victims of violence. In 2007, fighting reignited between the Ghana Kusai and Mamprusi.
A round of peace talks mediated by the Upper East Regional Coordinating Council (RCC) led to the signing of a ceasefire on 20 February 2008.
Ghanian President John Kufuor mediated between the conflict parties in Accra on 13 March 2008.
President Kufuor mediated a second round of talks in May 2008. However, this did not end the clashes.
The Ghanian Vice President John Mahama mediated between the conflict parties in March 2009.

President Atta Mills mediated between the conflict parties in Bolgatanga on 28 May 2009. This led to the establishment of the Bawku Inter-Ethnic Peace Committee (BIEPC) formed as a dialogue platform. The Mamprusi left the BIEPIC in September 2009.

The Ghana Kusasi and Mamprusi engaged in a round of negotiations mediated by World Vision-Ghana, WANEP, and the Northern Development Forum (NDF). This round of talks led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 12 May 2010. Following this agreement, the Mamprusi joined the BIEPC again in June 2010.
third_party: World Vision Ghana, WANEP, Northern Development Forum

description: The Regional Security Council (REGSEC) mediated a BIEPIC peace meeting on 16 October 2010.

President Salva Kiir initiated negotiations with SSDF leader Paulino Matip. This led to the Juba Declaration on Unity and Integration on 8 January 2006. The Declaration primarily laid the basis for unifying rival military forces in South Sudan, but also initiated a disarmament process. In the context of a disarmament process which also targeted the Murle and the Nuer, the SPLM/A mediated between the two tribes in June 2006. This mediation effort reportedly led to a decrease in tensions between the Murle and the Nuer.

The conflict between the Lou Nuer and the Murle escalated in 2009, with violence not only involving cattle raids, but also attacks on civilians and communities as a whole in the Greater Akobo, the greater Pibor, the Greater Bor areas. The Sudanese government, with support from the United Nations Mission in Sudan (UNMIS), facilitated a reconciliation meeting between the Nuer and the Murle in early May 2009, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire. A Joint Lou Nuer/Murle ceasefire committee was subsequently mandated to help implement this ceasefire. This reportedly reduced tensions in Akobo and Pibor counties of Jonglei State. On 13 May, the UN Mission in Sudan (UNMIS) announced it would temporarily deploy around 120 civilian, military and police personnel to Akobo and Pibor to assist local communities to engage in dialogue to prevent further violence. In June 2009, the Southern Sudan Peace Commission worked with state authorities, traditional authorities, UNMIS, UN Development Programme, and PACT to organize a peace conference to resolve the conflict between the Murle and the Nuer, but this conference was postponed several times, until the governor delayed it indefinitely in December 2009.

In February 2011, a Murle milita killed three Nuer chiefs in Thiam Payam. The Southern government authorities and UNMIS mediated a peace agreement between the conflict parties, which was signed on 10 April 2011. However, the Lou Nuer conducted a coordinated, retaliatory attack on Murle cattle camps in the eastern part of Pibor county in late April 2011 and launched a large-scale attack killing hundreds of Murle in June 2011. Armed violence between the Nuer and the Murle continued following South Sudan gaining independence on 9 July 2011. On 18 August 2011, Murle youths conducted a massive attack on Nuer civilians in Pieri in Uror county, which resulted in around 740 people killed and the theft of 38,00 heads of cattle. David Yau Yau and his fighters, who had signed an amnesty agreement with the South Sudanese government in June 2011, allegedly had provided some Murle with weapons prior to this attack.

Jonglei state governor Kuol Manyang Juuk and Jonglei state Minister of Parliamentary Affairs Gabriel Gai Riem repeatedly attempted to organize an all-Jonglei peace conference aimed at resolving the conflict between the Murle and the Nuer, but such a conference failed to materialize in August 2011. However, the Sudan Council of Churches (SCC) managed to initiate peace talks between the Murle and the Lou Nuer at a peace conference on 7 and 8 October 2011. Archbishop of the Episcopal Church of Sudan Daniel Deng Bul acted as the chief mediator. The conference brought together representatives of the Nuer and the Murle, as well as around 100 politicians from both the South Sudan national assembly and Jonglei state legislature. However, the peace conference did not produce a tangible outcome. Instead, the mediation team and the conflict parties agreed upon a four-step process, including (1) the delegations of the conflict parties consulting with their communities how to end the violence and address their grievances, (2) joint delegations with chiefs, women, and youth from both sides visiting communities to show that the peace process is a collective responsibility, (3) consultations with the communities on how to peace process could be taken forward, and (4) a peace conference aimed at an agreement on ending the violence and the return of abducted women and children prior to the start of the dry season in mid-December 2011. UNMISS provided logistical support to the peace process between August and December 2011, supporting key leaders with authority in the communities to advocate for peace.
third_party: religious leaders, local government, government, UNMISS

description: Up until December 2011, the SCC continued consultations with all communities, trying to design a framework for peace. However, the SCC failed to initiate official negotiations because the Lou Nuer and Murle could not agree on where to hold a peace conference. The SCC proposed a neutral area, such as Juba or Rumbek, but the Lou Nuer insisted the conference be held in Waat, which is centrally located in Nuer territory. The Lou Nuer leaders set a deadline of 1 December for action by the Murle community to prevent further cattle raids and for the return of their stolen cattle and women and children. Between October and December 2011, UNMISS representatives, government officials, and church leaders all repeatedly tried to convince the Nuer prophet Dak Kueth Deng to not call for an attack.
third_party: religious leaders, local government, government, UNMISS

description: Nevertheless, following a Murle attack on Bor Dinka in the Jalle area, Dak Kueth Deng decided to a mobilize a large group of Nuer fighters, known as the White Army, to launch a revenge attack on the Murle in Pibor county in December 2011. The SCC called off a peace conference that was set for 12 December when it became apparent that the Lou Nuer would conduct an attack in revenge of the Murle attack in August 2011. In addition to deploying a battalion to the main centers of Pibor county, UNMISS flew Vice-President Riek Machar to Lekwangole town on 28 and 29 December for him to persuade the Nuer militia leaders to withdraw, but with no success. The Nuer militia proceeded towards Pibor county.

When the Lou Nuer attack Pibor town on 2 January 2012, the South Sudanese government forces stationed there opened fire and managed to fend off the attack. This was the first time South Sudanese government forces opened fire to end communal violence. Two armored UN vehicles deterred the Lou Nuer on the eastern side of Pibor town. The Lou Nuer fighters withdrew from Pibor town on 4 January 2011, but moved deeper into Murle territory. The peace conference between Murle and Lou Nuer which had been scheduled for mid-December was held in January 2012, amidst the Nuer attack on the Murle in Pibor. The South Sudanese government deployed more than 12,000 soldiers in Jonglei to stop the fighting between Nuer and Murle in March 2012. Government forces in Jonglei were also tasked with a general disarmament campaign in what was called Operation Restore Peace.
third_party: religious leaders, local government, government, UNMISS

description: In addition, a Presidential Committee for Peace, Reconciliation, and Tolerance in Jonglei led by Anglican Archbishop Daniel Deng Bul Yak was set up in April 2012. However, because the mediation effort by Daniel Deng Bul Yak (as part of the mediation by the Sudan Council of Churches in October 2011) had failed to prevent the Nuer attack on Pibor, the Murle felt that Yak was biased against them. Vice-President Riek Machar launched the Presidential Committee for Peace, Reconciliation, and Tolerance with a three-day meeting on 2 April 2012 after a two-week tour of Jonglei, where he met community leaders in 11 counties.
third_party: local peace committee, religious leaders, government

description: In addition, the committee began with the facilitation of four smaller peace conferences on 25 April 2012, talking to the conflict parties in Bor, Ayod, Pibor, and Waat.

Between 1 and 5 May 2012, the leaders of the conflict parties met in Bor for the All Jonglei Peace Conference. While a series of resolutions and recommendations were adopted on strategies for reducing inter-communal tensions, abduction, livestock theft, and disputes over common grazing areas, the resolutions did not detail how these measures might be put into practice and the conflict parties did not agree on a ceasefire.
third_party: local peace committee, religious leaders, government

description: The Lou Nuer leaders and politicians of Greater Akobo held a reconciliation conference from 23 to 25 May 2012, which was supported by UNMISS.

The Jonglei Women�s Association (JWA) and USAID organized a women�s peace conference in the state from 12 to 17 March 2013. Although no peace agreement was reached, the participants discussed pathways to peace among all the different tribes in Jonglei, including the Murle and Lou Nuer.

In 2017, UNMISS facilitated several workshops between the Lou Nuer and Murle in Jonglei state in response to tensions between the two communities. These workshops were aimed at preventing a future resumption of previous hostilities.

In September 2020, UNMISS hosted a peace conference to address the prolonged violence in the Jonglei region involving Dinka, Nuer, and Murle groups. The meeting involved political leaders at national and state levels, community elders, civil society representatives, and other stakeholders engaging in peace talks. The conference led to the signing of the Bor Communiqu� on 9 September 2020, which highlighted a commitment to a bottom-up approach for peace involving youth and local leaders in conflict areas.

On 10 December 2020, Lou Nuer and Murle armed youth leaders met in Pieri. They engaged in peace talks and made a resolution for peace, as well as engaged in a spear ceremony guided by Spiritual Leader Gok Deng Dak Kueth.

From 14 to 18 January 2021, Murle and Bor Dinka armed youth leaders from Jonglei State met in Rumbek in Lakes State for a peace meeting. Galweng leaders acted as mediators during this peace meeting. The meeting led to the signing of a mutual commitment to peace witnessed by galweng leaders.

From 15 to 25 March 2021, delegates from Dinka Bor, Murle, and Lou Nuer communities � including women, youth leaders, and traditional leaders � met in Pieri. The negotiations were mediated by the NGO Peace Canal, a NGO financed by UK Aid. Peace Canal worked with a local mediator in each of the three communities. UNMISS provided some logistical support to the process, but UNMISS staff were not present at the conference. The conference was held under the guidance of Nuer Spiritual Leader Gok Deng Dak Kueth. The participants discussed the conflict�s impact and practical steps forward, focusing on issues such as abductions, cattle raiding, and civilian killings, aiming to build confidence in the peace process. The conference led to the signing of the Pieri Agreement by all parties. In this agreement, the communities pledged to support peace efforts, and develop modalities for punishment of perpetrators, return of abducted women and children, and return of stolen cattle.
A Jonglei-GPAA Inter-Communal Governance Structures meeting was held in December 2021 to follow up on the Pieri Agreement.
A Jonglei-GPAA Inter-Communal Governance Structures meeting was held in Juba in late July 2023 to follow up on the Pieri Agreement.

A peace conference attended by participants Bor Dinka, Murle, and Lou Nuer leaders from Bor County from Jonglei State and Gumuruk County from GPAA took place in Juba from 14 to 15 November 2022. The NGO Peace Canal and UNMISS Civil Affairs supported the conference. The conference led to the signing of the Agreement of Peace Dialogue. However, soon after the signing of this agreement, the Lou Nuer and Bor Dinka mobilized to conduct a large-scale attack on the Murle in the GPAA over the course of December 2022 and January 2023. This attack was allegedly in retaliation for the Murle raids into Lou Nuer and Dinka territory, which the Pieri process had failed to stop.

On 28 March 2018, the United Nations Peacekeeping Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) organized a two-day pre-migration conference in Duk Padiet in Jonglei. The conference was attended by 30 youth representatives of the Hol Dinka and Lou Nuer. These representatives agreed refrain from using violence during the migration season in the greater Jonglei area.
In August 2008, the Burnt Forest peace committee mediated between Kalenjin, Kikuyu, Kisii, Luhya and Luo elders. The UN Development Programme supported these peace talks.

A Peace Committee organized a reconciliation meeting between the tribal leaders in Nyala in October 2004 in response to the outbreak of armed fighting. The conflict parties agreed to resolve the conflict through the paying of double �dia� blood money for all those killed on both sides, the return of looted money and assets to each other, and the pardoning the perpetrators of violence. In addition, although not part of the official negotiations to end the tribal violence, the Ma�aliyah were granted a separate native administration headed by Nazir A.H. El Basha in 2004.

Renewed fighting broke out in August 2013. The Ma�aliyah accused East Darfur governor Abdel-Hamid Musa Kasha, who is a Rizeigat, of supporting his kin with government-issued vehicles and weapons. A mediation effort by governor of North Darfur Osman Mohamed Youssef Kibir, with support from UNAMID, led to agreement on signing a ceasefire on 14 August 2013. The abduction of 24 Ma�aliyah by Rizeigat led to a delay in signing the ceasefire, but after their release the conflict parties signed a ceasefire in al-Tawisha on 22 August 2013. The ceasefire was supposed to pave the way for a reconciliation conference.

President of Chad, Idriss D�by Itno, acted as the chief mediator at tribal mediation forum in Um Jaras from 26 to 29 March 2014. The forum was attended by tribal leaders from Darfur, including the Zaghawa, Rizeigat, Massalit, Ma�alia, Salamat and Ta�isha tribes. Sudanese Vice-President Hassabo Mohamed Abdul Rahman acted as the Joint Chief Mediator. Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir joined the forum on 29 March. The forum ended with the participants� announcement of their full support for peace and peaceful coexistence in Darfur.

Another peace conference was organized by a mediation committee with solely members of the Ma�aliya and Rizeigat in June 2014, but failing to reach an agreement the conference was suspended indefinitely on 20 June 2014.

On 22 August 2014, another mediation effort between the Rizeigat and Ma�aliya tribes was held in East Darfur, this time with the support from UNAMID Civil Affairs. This mediation effort led to the signing of a ceasefire by the leaders of the Rizeigat and Ma�aliya tribes on 29 August 2014. Prior to this conference, UNAMID had �engaged leaders of both communities at the state and Khartoum levels, including their respective Shura Councils.�

The theft of 320 sheep belonging to the Southern Rizeigat by the Ma�aliyah in Birghit on 13 January 2015 nearly trigged armed clashes between the tribes, but with support from government officials, leaders from both tribes intervened to stem tensions.

In mid-February 2015, a peace conference, facilitated by government officials, was held between Ma�aliyah and the Rizeigat Baggara in reaction to the previous year�s deadly clashes, but this conference ended without an agreement.

Another peace conference, mediated by Sudan�s first Vice-President Bakri Hassan Salih, was held in the locality of Merowe in March 2015, but the negotiations stalled over the right of land ownership known as Hakura (traditional land grant). Although the conflict parties did not reach an agreement, both sides released one captive on 4 May 2015. The armed fighting continued. Fighting stopped by 13 May, following an intervention by reinforcements from the central government as well as an intervention by the Sudanese Air Force.

On 14 May 2015, a high-ranking government delegation led by the Minister of Interior, Ismat Abdelrahman, arrived to mediate between the conflict parties. After shuttling between the conflict parties, the government decided on a package of measures to be taken by the government to stop the tribal clashes and defuse the tension. Yet, the conflict parties did not sign an agreement.

UNAMID helped to facilitate another peace conference on 2 September 2015. UNAMID facilitated the travel of a government delegation comprised of senior officials including the Governor of East Darfur and the Minster of Humanitarian Affairs. Staff from the UNAMID Civil Affairs Section were also involved in the mediation effort.

Fighting between the conflict parties resumed on 20 September, when some Rizeigat stole camels from Ma�aliyah in the Adola Mountain area. The Wali of East Darfur subsequently deployed troops to the area. Following a mediation effort by the Wali, with support from UNAMID, the conflict parties reached a settlement on 27 September.

Clashes between the Ma�aliyah and the Rizeigat as a result of cattle theft erupted again in Yassin locality on 17 April 2016, resulting in at least 20 deaths. In negotiations, facilitated by UNAMID, the conflict parties signed a peace agreement on 6 June 2016, agreeing on financial compensation for the fatalities of the clashes on 17 April 2016. However, fighting continued between the two tribes in West Kordofan on 24 August 2016.

With UNAMID support, government officials mediated another agreement between the conflict parties in Muglad, West Kordofan, on 27 August 2016. However, Ma�aliyah representatives protested against this agreement in Adilla on 3 September 2016, claiming that it was not inclusive of the entire Ma�aliyah community and that it had not been signed by the actual representatives of the Agarba.

A peace conference organized by Sudanese government officials in Khartoum on 11 October 2016 ended without reaching agreement between the conflict parties and negotiations were postponed until 30 October 2016.

Fighting between the Ma�aliyah and the Rizeigat spread to East Darfur on 14 and 15 October 2016. In response to these clashes, UNAMID managed to mediate a peace agreement, stipulating a ceasefire, between the Ma�aliya and Rizeigat tribes in East Darfur on 17 October 2016. The peace agreement also included provisions for the release of two members from the Rizeigat tribe held by the Ma�aliya and the return of 134 cows by the Ma�aliya. The agreement also stipulated that the government of East Darfur had to pay compensation of 650,000 SDG (US$102,000) to the Ma�aliya in order to cover the costs of a local rescue team, over 200 looted cattle, weapons and the blood money for the murder of a member of the Ma�aliyah tribe. The deputy governor of East Darfur subsequently visited Abu Karinka locality to pay representatives of the Ma�aliyah tribe the first half of the compensation.

Armed clashes between the conflict parties resumed in April 2017, but were not immediately followed by any mediation efforts. UNAMID participated in a peace meeting in Abu Karinka on 26 June 2017 between the Ma�aliyah native administration and a Rizeigat delegation from Ed Daein. The Sudanese government deployed security forces in late July in response to another round of fighting. Sudanese Armed Forces arrived in Ed Daein in late July to confiscate weapons from the Rizeigat and the Ma�aliyah, as well as to arrest traditional leaders and civilians from both communities.
Representatives of the Ma�aliyah and the Rizeigat set up a mechanism at regulating farming activities during a peace meeting on 7 January 2018.

Another peace meeting was held at Adilla and Abu Karinka on 27 and 28 January 2018 respectively. The Sudanese Vice-President attended this reconciliatory meeting and made a commitment to implement several development projects related to health, education, and infrastructure in the area.
Another round of negotiations between the Ma�aliyah and the Rizeigat led to the signing of a peace agreement in Khartoum on 27 November 2018.
Leaders from neutral clans mediated between the two sides in December 2003 but were unsuccessful.
Reconciliation talks between the two clans were during September and October 1997. This led to a temporary stop in fighting. Armed conflict reignited in May 1998.

No direct negotiations took place between the conflict parties in 1997, but Kenyan and Ethiopian officials signed an agreement in Awassa on 5 July 1997 that emphasized the countries� shared aim for conflict resolution along the shared border, referring namely to the conflict between the Dassanetch and Turkana. On 10 September 2002, the conflict parties engaged in a peace meeting in Lodonyang. The peace talks were mediated by the East Africa Conflict Resolution Component and Intermediate Technology Development Group (ITDG). The meeting led to signing of a peace agreement in the presence of government officials from Kenya and Ethiopia.
third_party: East Africa Conflict Resolution Component, Intermediate Technology Development Group, government, Ethiopia, government officials

description: On 26 September 2002, the two sides re-convened for another peace meeting in Lodwar in which both government and communal leaders participated.
The African Union - Interafrican Bureau for Animal Resources (AU/IBAR) mediated peace talks in Lokichogio in August 2005 to resolve the conflict between the Dassantech, Nyangatom, and Turkana.
Another peace meeting between the Dassanetch and Turkana was held in the Turkana District in Kenya in August 2005. This peace meeting led to a peace agreement and a peace committee was established.

The Turkana-South Omo Conflict Mitigation Project was initiated in 2006. With financial support from USAID and Oxfam, the project itself was carried out with involvement from the Ethiopian Pastoralist Research and Development Association (EPaRDA) and Riam Riam Turkana (RRT).
third_party: Oxfam, USAID, community leaders, local NGO

description: The Catholic Church of North Kenya began to mediate between the conflict parties in Kenya 2007. There are few details about these efforts.
The Ethiopian Pastoralist Research and Development Association (EPARDA) mediated between the conflict parties in Ethiopia in 2007.
The Turkana-South Omo Conflict Mitigation Project organized a peace meeting between the Dassanetch and Turakana in Ethiopia in 2008.
District officials from the Dassanetch and North Turkana districts in Ethiopia met multiple times to try resolve conflict issues throughout 2008.
