Several national commissions were established during this process that were designed to support peaceful coexistence. The National Cohesion and Integration Act 2008 established the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) in 2009 as a permanent body for achieving this goal. In February 2010, the NCIC began to investigate the conflict and initiated the Nakuru peace process.

In April 2011, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC), the National Steering Committee on Conflict Management and Peace Building (NSC) and the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) invited all communities of Nakuru County to participate in the peace talks. Eighty elders, 40 from the Kikuyu and 40 from the Kalenjin, participated in the peacetalks. While these meetings were centered around the latter two�s conflict, other tribes such as the Luhya joined the peace talks in order to help resolve broader conflict in the area. The peace process started with separate meetings for each tribe that were mediated by the NCIC and NSC. The mediation team later facilitated joint meetings. The Provincial Administration also attended some of these meetings. HD officially joined the peace process at the third joint meeting that was held in May 2011.

A mediation effort by the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) between 24 elders from each tribe led to the conclusion of a draft agreement that was revised and agreed to in March 2012. To gather social support for the agreement, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) and HD met with representatives of Nakuru Business and Professional Women's Club, religious leaders, and youth.

The Kalenjin and Kikuyu leaders, along with other community leaders such as those from Luhya, engaged in another peace meeting in Nakuru on 19 August 2012, which led to the signing of the Nakuru County Peace Accord. The signing of the Accord was witnessed by the NCIC, the Truth Justice and Reconciliation Commission, the Provincial Commissioner�s Office, and HD.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), government, local government

description: Several peace meetings between Kalenjin, Kikuyu, Kisii, Luhya, and Luo elders took place in Kaptembwo in August 2008. The UN Development Programme supported the meetings and 52 conflict resolution experts were also involved. The Kenya National Dialogue and Reconciliation (KNDR) process led by Kofi Annan started in early 2008. The UN and the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) supported this peace initiative. Several national commissions were established during this process that were designed to support peaceful coexistence. The National Cohesion and Integration Act 2008 established the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) in 2009 as a permanent body for achieving this goal. In February 2010, the NCIC began to investigate the conflict and initiated the Nakuru peace process.

In April 2011, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC), the National Steering Committee on Conflict Management and Peace Building (NSC) and the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) invited all communities of Nakuru County to participate in the peace talks. Eighty elders, 40 from the Kikuyu and 40 from the Kalenjin, participated in the peace talks. While these meetings were centered around the latter two�s conflict, other tribes such as the Luo and the Kisii joined the peace talks in order to help resolve broader conflict in the area. The peace process started with separate meetings for each tribe that were mediated by the NCIC and NSC. The mediation team later facilitated joint meetings. The Provincial Administration also attended some of these meetings. HD officially joined the peace process at the third joint meeting that was held in May 2011.

A mediation effort by the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) between 24 elders from each tribe led to the conclusion of a draft agreement that was revised and agreed to in March 2012. To gather social support for the agreement, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) and HD met with representatives of Nakuru Business and Professional Women's Club, religious leaders, and youth.

The Kalenjin and Kikuyu leaders, along with other community leaders such as those from Kisii and the Luo, engaged in another peace meeting in Nakuru on 19 August 2012, which led to the signing of the Nakuru County Peace Accord. The signing of the agreement was witnessed by the NCIC, the Truth Justice and Reconciliation Commission, the Provincial Commissioner�s Office, and HD.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), government, local government

description: Following up on the Nakuru County Peace Accord concluded in 2015 that addressed many different inter-ethnic conflicts in the Nakuru County, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) conducted a specific mediation effort to facilitate an end to the conflict between the Kalenjin and Luo. In January 2016, the commission collaborated with the local administrative officials from Kisumu and Nandi Counties and began to mediate between the two tribes. NCIC Chair Hon. Francis Ole Kaparo acted as the chief mediator. Another round of peace talk was scheduled for June, but the mediation team was chased out of town by a mob of citizens who were angry that the mediation effort had not made any progress.
In August 2016, another round of negotiations resulted in the Chemelil Declaration in which both communities agreed to end hostilities.
On 3 June 2001, Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi mediated between the leaders of both tribes in Nairobi.
On 6 June 2001, the Kisii and Maasai participated in a reconciliation meeting mediated by district commissioners.
Another round of negotiations took place in Trans Mara in late June 2001. These talks were mediated by district leaders.

Nakuru district commissioner Aden Noor Aden led a reconciliation meeting between the Maasai and Kikuyu in Longonot on 17 January 1995. The meeting was attended by elders, religious leaders, and local authorities.
third_party: local government, religious leaders, traditional leaders

description: On 2 February 2005, after two-week long clashes over the water of the Ewaso Kedong River, a round of negotiations between the Kikuyu and Maasai was held at the Karima Catholic Church in Mai Mahiu. Internal Security Minister Chris Murungaru mediated these negotiations. Although the conflict parties agreed that a joint solution over the use of water had to be found, no peace agreement was concluded.

In April 2011, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) that had been established through the National Cohesion and Integration Act of 2008, the National Steering Committee on Conflict Management and Peace Building (NSC) invited all communities of Nakuru County to participate in the peace talks. While the peace talks focused mainly on the armed conflict between the Kikuyu and Kalenjin, other tribes such as the Maasai also joined the peace talks in order to mitigate all armed violence in the area. The negotiations in April 2011 first consisted of separate meetings for each tribe with the NCIC and NSC, after which the mediation team later facilitated joint meetings. Another round of negotiations mediated by the NCIC and NSC was held in May 2011. The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) joined the mediation team for the round of negotiations in May 2011.

HD mediated a round of negotiations between the Kikuyu and the Maasai in March 2012. This round of negotiations led to the signing of a peace agreement. In order to gather social support for the agreement, the NCIC and HD met with representatives of Nakuru Business and Professional Women�s Club, religious leaders, and youth.

A round of negotiations mediated by the NCIC and HD led to conclusion of the Nakuru County Peace Accord on 19 August 2012 in Nakuru, signed by the Kalenjin and the Kikuyu, but also other communities in Kakuru such as the Maasai.
The Catholic Justice and Peace Commission (CJPC), with government officials in attendance, mediated between the conflict parties in July 2002.
Another round of negotiations mediated by the CJPC led to signing of the Kolowa Declaration at Kolowa in October 2002.
In 2003, district commissioners from each tribe�s district attended a peace meeting in Chesegon. This peace meeting was interrupted by an attack.
On 28 March 2003, the Marakwet and Pokot convened for a peace effort led by the Pokot Education and Development Programme (PEDP).

In 2016, large-scale conflict between the tribes reignited. In response, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) organized and supported several peace meetings between representatives of the Marakwet and the Pokot. A round of peace talks led to the conclusion of the Nakuru Declaration in September 2016.
The NCIC mediated another round of peace talks between the Pokot and Marakwet, which led to the conclusion of a peace agreement at the Bontana Hotel on 4 November 2016.
Government officials from the West Pokot and Elgeyo Marakwet districts mediated between the conflict parties in January 2018.
On 31 July 2018, local officials from the Marakwet and Pokot districts met for a peace meeting at their shared border.
Elders from both the Marakwet and Pokot tried to mediate between the communities in April 2019, but this effort failed to resolve the conflict.

On 31 July 2019, Deputy President William Ruto mediated a round of peace talks in the Kerio Valley. This mediation effort led to the signing of an agreement between communities of the the Baringo, Elgeyo-Marakwet, and West Pokot counties in which these communities committed to disarmament.
In late October 2023, Pokot and Marakwet community members held discussions to bring peace in the Cheptulel, Chesogon, and Tot border areas.

On 26 August 1998, the Nandi and Pokot � as well as the Luhya, Sabaot and Sengwe � convened for a peace meeting in Kitale. These tribes created a 15-person committee to advocate for an end to raiding and help from the District Commissioner.

In January 2002, the National Council of the Churches of Kenya (NCCK), Oxfam, the Office of the President, and the Department for International Co-operation and Development mediated a round of peace talks between the Nandi and Pokot. The actors established an early warning system and conflict resolution mechanisms during these peace talks.

In January 2013, tribal representatives of the Nandi and Pokot � as well as the Elgeyo Marakwet, Turkana, and Baringo � engaged in a peace meeting. The meeting ended with the signing of a statement that committed them to a later meeting in Eldoret to negotiate a peace coalition.

The Orma and Pokomo engaged in peace talks mediated by the Council of Imams and Preachers of Kenya on 21 July 2001. The chief mediator was Sheikh Ali Shee. An Imam, a priest, and tribal representatives from the Ngao, Sailoni, and Simi Karo were also present. This effort resulted in the Orma and Pokomo signing a ceasefire agreement. In October, the Kenyan government led a disarmament operation and suspended the land adjudication program in December 2001.

On 7 and 8 April 2011, the leaders from the counties of Marsabit, Isiolo, Mandera, Wajir, Garissa, Tana River, Samburu, Meru, and Nairobi met for a peace meeting at the Almond Resort in Garissa. Leaders of the Oma, Wardei, and Pokomo attended the meeting. All representatives renewed their commitment to the Modogashe Declaration in the presence of provincial Commissioners.
Hamisa Zaja and Sheikh Idriss, together with other religious leaders, mediated between the Orma and Pokomo communities in July 2012. Fighting flared up again in August 2012.

On 23 August 2012, the Orma and Pokomo convened for a round of negotiations mediated by Kenyan police officers. This round of talks did not lead to a peace agreement. After another bout of violence in September 2012, the Kenyan government sent 1,000 soldiers to stabilize the Tana River District and tried to organize another round of peace talks. However, neither community wished to participate in this mediation effort, preferring instead to engage in bilateral negotiations. In mid-September 2012, tribal elders from the Mijikenda signaled their intention to mediate between the Orma and Pokomo, but this did not lead to peace talks.

On 4 October 2012, 40 elders from the Orma, Pokomo, and Wardei attended a three-day peace conference in Malindi. Several different third parties acted as mediators during the conference, including the Consortium for the Empowerment and Development of Marginalised Communities, the National Commission and Integration Commission (NCIC), National Muslim Leadership Forum, and the Council of Imams and Preachers of Kenya. Although no peace agreement was concluded during this round of talks, the conflict parties agreed that peace was a priority.

The NCIC initiated a mediation effort in September 2014. The NCIC worked with religious and community leaders, civil societies, the National Steering Committee on Peacebuilding and Conflict Management (NSC), and the Kenya Red Cross Society (KRCS). The mediation effort focused on mitigating violence in the towns of Amu, Faza, Hindi, and Witu. On 17 September 2014, community leaders signed The Boma Commitment on the Promotion of Peace and Cohesion in Lamu County. President Uhuru Kenyatta attended the signing ceremony. To follow-up with the implementation, peace committees were created in Hindi, Lamu, and Mpeketoni.
third_party: government, religious leaders, community leaders, Red Cross
agreement_name: Boma Commitment on the Promotion of Peace and Cohesion in Lamu County

description: On 2 January 1989, Syria attempted to broker a ceasefire between the feuding Shia Muslim rivals in Beirut�s southern suburbs. However, it only took few hours after this mediation effort for the fighting to flare up again.
On 15 January 1989, the Lebanese Red Cross brokered a temporary humanitarian ceasefire in south Lebanon town of Jubah. This allowed the conflict parties to remove the dead from the battlefield.

From 23 to 25 January 1989, Foreign Ministers Farouk Sharaa of Syria and Ali Akbar Velayati of Iran mediated between Amal and Hezbollah leaders in Damascus. The talks were concluded with a preliminary peace agreement and a ceasefire, which lasted only few hours.

On 30 January 1989, Amal and Hezbollah signed the Damascus Agreement mediated by Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk Sharaa and his Iranian counterpart Ali Akbar Velayati in the Syrian capital. The agreement ensured compliance with the 25 January ceasefire, an end to media hostilities, the withdrawal of all militiamen from Jbaa and Ain Bouswar, the establishment of a common operations room to coordinate the �resistance� against Israel, and the freedom for UNIFIL and other international organizations to operate in Lebanon without harassment. However, the fate of numerous hostages was not addressed in the agreement.

On 3 April 1989, Syria held talks with the leaders of Amal and Hezbollah, during which the two sides vowed to join the campaign against General Michel Aoun. However, fighting between the two Shiite militias resumed in early July 1989.
On 8 July 1989, Amal and Hezbollah reportedly pledged to halt clashes at a meeting with foreign ministers Farouq Shaara of Syria and his Iranian counterpart Ali Akbar Velayati in Damascus.
Syrian troops brokered a one-hour ceasefire on 9 July 1989 to allow people to evacuate a beach as Amal and Hezbollah militias fought in southern Beirut.

On 12 July 1989, Iranian-backed Hezbollah and Syrian-backed Amal met separately with the Iranian Speaker of Parliament Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani in Tehran. The two militias were in Tehran to participate in a commemorative meeting marking the end of the 40-day mourning period for Iran�s late supreme leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

On 14 July 1989, Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati chaired talks between Amal and Hezbollah to try to resolve their dispute. His goal was to unify Shiite forces in the fight against General Michel Aoun. One day later, on 15 July 1989, the Druze Progressive Socialist Party (PSP) and the leaders of the Palestinian group Fatah Uprising and the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine also joined the discussions with the Iranian Foreign Minister. On 24 July 1989, Amal and Hezbollah issued a statement in Tehran in which they assured cooperation. Yet, in December 1989, clashes erupted again. Despite three calls for a ceasefire from a security committee composed of both Hezbollah and Amal representatives and Syrian officers, the parties continued to fight.
On 25 December 1989, Deputy Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammed Ali Besharati held talks in Beirut with Hezbollah and Amal leaders in an attempt to reach a ceasefire.

On 27 December 1989, Iran successfully mediated a ceasefire between its Shiite Muslim allies Hezbollah and the Syrian-backed Amal militia. This was the result of shuttle mediation aimed to end the violence in the Iqlim al-Tufah area, located 40km south of Beirut. On 3 January 1990, Hezbollah declared a unilateral ceasefire after 12 days of fighting against Amal in south Lebanon.

On 8 January 1990, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) brokered a 7-hour humanitarian ceasefire between the two Shiite rival militias to remove bodies from the battlefield south of Sidon.

From 8 to 9 January 1990, Iranian First Deputy Foreign Minister Besharati held separate talks with Amal and Hezbollah in Beirut. Besharati affirmed that the two Shiite militias had reaffirmed their commitment to abide by the Damascus Agreement signed in January 1989. However, both Amal and Hezbollah denied that a ceasefire had been reached after these meetings.
On 24 January 1990, an Algerian delegation mediated between the two warring militias. Yet, violence continued during the mediation effort.

On 27 January 1990, Amal declared a unilateral ceasefire in response to an ongoing mediation effort by Algerian envoy Mohammed Taher. This declaration followed a meeting with the Algerian peace envoy on the same day. Hezbollah negotiators, who talked to the mediator on the phone, stated that they were observing the ceasefire brokered by Iran.
On 5 June 1990, Syria�s chief intelligence officer in Lebanon, Brigadier Ghazi Kenaan, shuttled between Hezbollah and Amal officials in west Beirut to arrange direct talks between them.

On 7 June 1990, the two parties met for peace talks mediated by Syria�s chief of military intelligence in Lebanon, Brigadier Ghazi Kenaan, in the Syrian military headquarters in West Beirut. The Iranian Ambassador to Damascus, Mohammed Hassan Akhtari, was also involved as a mediator in these talks. The two sides discussed ways to implement the January 1989 Damascus Agreement. This meeting also had the goal to pave the way for another peace conference in Damascus.

On 30 June 1990, the Amal militia announced a unilateral ceasefire. This ceasefire was related to the holy feast of Eid al-Adha and also proposed to exchange prisoners with Hezbollah. One day later, on 1 July 1990, Hezbollah also declared it would observe the ceasefire called by Amal.
On 19 July 1990, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) brokered a humanitarian ceasefire to evacuate the wounded near Sidon.
On 22 July 1990, Allam Riza Walizadeh, a political officer of the Iranian embassy in Beirut, met with Hezbollah, Amal, and PLO fighters in the city of Sidon to find a way to end hostilities.

On 31 July 1990, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) mediated a ceasefire at a meeting between the two Lebanese Shiite militias and the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) in order to evacuate the dead from Iqlim al Tuffah. The ceasefire eventually took hold on 3 August 1990, allowing the ICRC to remove the bodies.
On 31 August 1990, as fighting continued in and around the ancient town of Baalbek (70km east of Beirut), Syrian officers brokered a ceasefire between Amal and Hezbollah militias.

Between 30 August and 2 September 1990, Hezbollah and Amal representatives held peace talks at the Syrian army headquarters in the eastern village of Anjar. Mediated by Iran�s ambassador to Damascus, Sheikh Mohammed Akhtari, and Brigadier Ghazi Kanaan, the intelligence chief, the talks resulted in a peace agreement between the two rival Shiite parties on 2 September 1990. During the talks, the parties reiterated their will to end their media campaign and work toward a peaceful solution of the conflict.

On 25 October 1990, Amal and Hezbollah representatives met in Anjar, in the Biqa valley, under the auspices of Iran and Syria. The parties discussed the deployment of the Lebanese army in the south and a solution to the situation in Iqlim al-Tuffah.

On 30 October 1990, the two parties reached a ceasefire mediated by Iran and Syria at the Syrian observer forces� headquarters in Beirut. The two sides indicated in a communiqu� that they expected future meetings to discuss possible prisoner exchanges and a comprehensive and final settlement of the conflict.

On 5 November 1990, Amal leader Nabih Berri and Hezbollah Secretary-General Sheik Subhi al-Tufeili signed a reconciliation agreement brokered by Syria and Iran in Damascus. Present for the signing of the agreement were Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa and his Iranian counterpart Ali Akbar Velayati. With this agreement, the two sides agreed to allow the Lebanese army assume order in Shiite Muslim areas of Lebanon. Moreover, the parties agreed that any future disputes would be mediated by Syria and Iran and that the latter would be responsible for overseeing the implementation of the agreement.

On 17 December 1990, Syria and Iran met with Amal and Hezbollah officials with the aim of facilitating the implementation of the peace agreement. Iran�s ambassador to Damascus, Sheikh Mohammed Akhtari, and Brigadier Ghazi Kanaan chaired the discussions. The mediators focused on resolving obstacles that were hindering the deployment of the Lebanese army in the Iqlim al-Toufah area.

Since 1990, Amal and Hezbollah maintained mostly peaceful relations, but violence erupted again in 2000. In an attempt to restore and maintain peace between the two groups, commanders from Hezbollah and Amal in the southern region met at the Syrian intelligence Beirut headquarters on 17 July 2000.

On 15 February 1989, the Forces of Michel Aoun and the Lebanese Forces reached a ceasefire agreement during negotiations that were mediated by Christian cleric Patriarch Nasrallah Boutros Sfeir. The ceasefire stipulated the withdrawal of the Lebanese Forces from the streets. Violence had spread throughout the Christian enclave, extending from East Beirut to the ancient coastal town of Byblos.

On 18 February 1989, Maronite Christian Church officials met with Lebanese Forces chief Samir Geagea to negotiate a solution to the conflict. On the same day, the Maronite Christian Church officials met General Michel Aoun. The talks were aimed at preparing for a more sustained negotiation process, but Michel Aoun rejected church mediation unless it met its demand.

On 20 February 1989, Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea met for the first time directly since the beginning of the armed fighting between their forces. As a gesture of goodwill to end the conflict with the Forces of Aoun, the Lebanese Forces promised to leave the fifth basin at Beirut port. In addition, Samir Geagea promised to put his militia at the disposal of Aoun�s troops in his fight against Syria and its allies.

Tensions rose again when Geagea implicitly recognized � meaning he did not recognize it officially � the National Agreement concluded on 22 October 1989. Another reason why tension rose is that Geagea refrained from condemning the election of President Rene Mouawad and later Hrawi. Aoun, on the other hand, rejected the Arab-sponsored peace agreement under which Hrawi was elected because it failed to ensure the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon. To address these tensions and prevent another violent confrontation, Aoun and Geagea held bilateral talks on 5 November 1989.

On the night of 30-31 January 1990, as conflict flared up in East Beirut, Church mediators held peace talks between Maronite Christian rivals. On 31 January 1990, Aoun and Geagea announced a ceasefire in a joint statement on the radio, but armed fighting continued.

On 1 February 1990, Papal Nuncio Pablo Puente, Vatican peace envoy, brokered a ceasefire between the Forces of Michel Aoun and the Lebanese Forces of Samir Geagea. The ceasefire was reportedly intended to allow both sides to evacuate their casualties and to facilitate the negotiation of a lasting peace by clergymen and politicians, but the ceasefire broke down already after few hours.

On the same day, on 1 February 1990, General Aoun and Samir Geagea agreed on another truce in a bilateral telephone call. This telephone call was the result of efforts made by the Papal Nuncio Pablo Puente. Yet, fighting continued after this phone call.

On 3 February 1990, the Forces of Michel Aoun and the Lebanese Forces announced that they would respect a ceasefire proposed by the Vatican through Papal Nuncio Pablo Puente and the Maronite Catholic Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir.

On 5 February 1990, Christian clerics, supported by the Vatican, mediated another ceasefire between the conflict parties. They also announced the formation of a ceasefire monitoring committee including representatives of the two warring sides.
On 8 February 1990, Christian mediators facilitated negotiations aimed at implementing the latest ceasefire. The conflict parties agreed upon another ceasefire to stabilize the latest ceasefire.
On 10 February 1990, yet another ceasefire was mediated by the Christian committee between the two rival forces.
On 11 February 1990, Christian mediators held hours of separate talks with representatives of the conflict parties, without making any concluding statement.
On 12 February 1990, Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea discussed the modalities of engaging in official peace negotiations during a telephone call.

In response to an appeal by Maronite Patriarch Nasrallah Boutros Sfeir, Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea declared a ceasefire on 17 February 1990. They allegedly accepted the ceasefire to give their forces some rest, strengthen positions, and prepare for new attacks.

On 19 February 1990, Chaker Abu Sleiman, a Maronite community leader part of the Christian committee mediating in the Maronite conflict, mediated a six-point peace agreement between the two Maronite rivals. The pact sought to consolidate a two-day-old ceasefire, provided for a council of Christian leaders to govern the enclave under Aoun�s command, and featured a commitment to avoid force to settle disputes.
In late February 1990, a series of meetings were held aimed at the implementation of the peace agreement concluded on 19 February.

On 2 March 1990, Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea promised to stick to the ceasefire during a telephone conversation with the head of Lebanon�s Maronite Church Nasrallah Boutros Sfeir. Nasrallah Boutros Sfeir put pressure on the conflict parties by threatening them and all those waging the inter-Christian war with excommunication if they were not to lay down their weapons.
On 3 and 4 March 1990, the Christian mediation team continued talks with the conflict parties to bolster the truce.

On 4 March 1990, the Vatican emissary Mgr. Alberto Sozzi shuttled between Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea. He reportedly wanted to avoid a Syrian military intervention in the Christian enclave, encouraging the two Maronite rivals to refrain from violence.

On 7 March 1990, French ambassador Rene Ala held talks with General Michel Aoun at the presidential palace in Beirut. In a coordinated effort, the charg� d�affaires of the Vatican Giovanni Daniello delegation held talks with Samir Geagea in Beirut on the same day.

On 29 March 1990, Boutros Nasrallah Sfeir hosted a meeting between Maronite deputies and political and religious leaders in Bkirki. Samir Geagea was present, but Michel Aoun was not. The meeting was aimed at finding ways to end the two-month long conflict among the Maronite community. Samir Geagea reportedly agreed to start a dialogue with President Hrawi, who had the backing of Syria, to isolate Michel Aoun and to restore a Muslim-Christian government.

On 1 April 1990, the three-man Christian committee backed by the Vatican mediated a ceasefire between the Forces of Michel Aoun and the Lebanese Forces. On 3 April 1990, Geagea officially recognized President Hrawi on Lebanese radio and accepted the Taif agreement, provoking a vehement response from Michel Aoun.
On 3 April 1990, the Christian mediation committee met again with the two Maronite leaders, but without achieving reconciliation.
Following a ceasefire call made by Nasrallah Boutros Sfeir on 4 April 1990, Aoun and Geagea ordered their troops to put down their weapons.

On 29 April 1990, a Maronite monk, Boulos Naaman, mediated a 36-hour truce in the district of Qlaiaat between the two rival forces, allowing residents to visit their houses and take away their belongings.

On 13 May 1990, Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz shuttled between representatives of the conflict parties in Baghdad. The President of Iraq, Saddam Hussein, allegedly wanted to resolve the inter-Christian conflict before hosting the special Arab League Summit on 28 May 1990 in Baghdad. Iraq was the main arms supplier of the two Christian forces, which should be seen in the context of the tensions between Iraq and Syria. In spite of the close relations with Iraq, the conflict parties refused to sit at the same table during the negotiations.

On 16 May 1990, a Maronite Christian monk, Father Bolous Na�aman, supported by the Vatican, mediated a ceasefire between Aoun and Geagea. The mediator engaged extensively with both sides, but the talks were held separately.
On 26 May 1990, Pablo Puente, the Apostolic Nuncio to Lebanon, mediated a permanent ceasefire between Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea, but their forces continued to fight.

After the ceasefire concluded on 26 May 1990 was announced, Pablo Puente shuttled between the two conflicting parties from 27 May until 6 June 1990. He tried to get both sides to agree on a Vatican peace initiative and stick to the ceasefire. The Vatican peace plan sought to include Aoun and Geagea in Hrawi�s cabinet and proposed revised political reforms. However, Hrawi opposed any amendments to the Taif agreement.
On 19 June 1990, Vatican envoy Pablo Puente held a three-hour discussion with General Michel Aoun to push him towards an end in fighting between his troops and the Lebanese Forces.

On 20 June 1990, director-general of the French foreign ministry Fran�ois Scheer mediated between Aoun and Geagea. Maronite Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir was also involved as a mediator in these talks. The mediators tried to obtain Aoun�s acceptance of the October 1989 Taif Agreement and the presidency of Elias Hrawi.
On 10 July 1990, Maronite Christian rivals agreed to end hostilities after a bilateral meeting.

On 15 July 1990, a mediation attempt was led by Lakhdar Brahimi to implement the Taif Agreement. He first met with President Elias Hrawi, Prime Minister Selim Hoss, and House Speaker Hussein Husseini in west Beirut. Next, he crossed the Green Line to hold discussions with Michel Aoun. The Arab peace envoy sought to persuade Aoun to recognize the Arab-sponsored peace agreement of October 1989 and the Hrawi administration. The next day, on 16 July 1990, Lakhdar Brahimi met with Samir Geagea, who expressed his approval of the Taif agreement, recognized President Hrawi, and indicated that he was willing to start talks with Hrawi�s administration.

On 23 July 1990, Arab peace envoy Lakhdar Brahimi met with General Aoun to propose a new peace plan to end the 15-year civil war. Brahimi sought to convince Aoun to accept the deployment of Hrawi�s army in Christian east Beirut. However, on 25 July 1990, Michel Aoun rejected the new Arab-sponsored peace initiative and refused the deployment of troops loyal to Elias Hrawi in east Beirut. In response, Hrawi�s cabinet imposed sanctions against Aoun on 28 July 1990, including a fuel ban, an embargo on military spare parts and ammunition, and a freeze on the salaries for government employees in Aoun-controlled territory. On 2 August 1990, Iraq invaded Kuwait, reshuffling the cards in the Middle East. As fighting resumed in the Christian enclave of Beirut, Syrian and Lebanese troops loyal to President Hrawi were deployed on 1 September 1990. In September, the constitutional reforms outlined in the Taif agreement were adopted by the Lebanese Parliament and then ratified by President Hrawi. On 13 October 1990, General Michel Aoun eventually surrendered after Syrian planes bombed his presidential palace. Aoun sought refuge in the French embassy and subsequently went into exile in France. Meanwhile, Geagea pledged allegiance to President Hrawi and promised to disband his 6,000-member militia and integrate them into Lahoud�s army.

Negotiations mediated by ECOWAS between the Government of Liberia, the NPFL, and the INPFL led to the signing of the Bamako Ceasefire Agreement on 28 November 1990. The agreement included a ceasefire provision, although the specific details of how it would be implemented were to be determined at a later time. ECOMOG was designated to oversee the monitoring of the ceasefire. Additionally, the parties agreed to address their disagreements concerning an Interim Government for Liberia, as outlined in the ECOWAS Peace Plan. This agreement is commonly interpreted as a sign of the NPFL accepting the ECOWAS Peace Plan.

Another round of talks between these conflict parties, mediated by ECOWAS, led to signing of the Banjul IV agreement on 21 December 1990. The agreement stipulated the extension of the existing ceasefire established in the Bamako agreement and the creation of an Interim government. Additionally, all seaports and airports were designated as military-free zones. Within a timeframe of 60 days, an All-Liberian National Conference was scheduled to convene, focusing on the details of establishing the interim regime. Upon its formation, the Interim government was responsible for disarming the warring factions.

Following two days of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS in the Togolese capital Lome, the INPFL and the NPFL, as well as the government forces, signed a ceasefire on 14 February 1991. The ceasefire was signed by NPFL leader Charles Taylor, INPFL leader Prince Yormie Johnson, and commander of Liberia�s armed forces General Hezekiah.

On 15 March 1991, the All-Liberia National Conference was held to discuss political power-sharing arrangements in Liberia until the upcoming elections. Taylor sent a NPFL delegation, but refused to attend the talks himself. The conference ended on 20 April 1991. The conflict parties agreed to form an Interim Government of National Unity to be led by Amos Sawyer. Elections were stipulated to be held as early as October 1991. Subsequent widespread infighting took place within the INPFL over disagreement about cooperating with the Interim Government. The infighting within the INPFL effectively ended the fighting between the INPFL and the NPFL.The INPFL was excluded from subsequent peace talks in 1991 between the Government of Liberia and the NPFL at Yamossoukro, which were mediated by ECOWAS and the INN.

Prince Johnson and Charles Taylor concluded a modus vivendi in 1992, under which their two militias agreed to cooperate in taking over Monrovia. In what the parties dubbed operation �Octopus�, the NPFL and INPFL were to launch a joint military assault against ECOMOG. However, Prince Johnson reneged on this agreement last minute. Consequently, the NPFL overran the INPFL�s Cadwell Base and killed some of its fighters. Prince Johnson surrendered to ECOMOG and was given sanctuary in Nigeria. The INPFL thus ceased to exist in October 1992.

In April 1994, the transitional government, UNOMIL and ECOMOG undertook efforts to bring about a ceasefire between NPFL and LPC as well as to bring LPC into the disarmament and demobilization process. However, in May 1994, LPC continued to attack NPFL.

In 1994, Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings was appointed ECOWAS chairman. Rawlings mediated negotiations in Akosombo in order to salvage the Cotonou agreement, which led to the conclusion of the Akosombo Peace Agreement in Ghana on 12 September 1994. Yet, the LPC was not included in this peace process either. Hence, the LPC rejected the Akosombo agreement. Consequently, the peace process continued, and another conference started in Accra on 22 November and led to a ceasefire agreement and a reaffirmation of the Akosombo agreement on 22 December 1994. The agreement set up a five-member Council of State. Seats were to be divided between the NPFL, ULIMO, the coalition of anti-NPFL factions which also included the LPC, the Liberian National Conference (LNC) consisting largely of civil society representatives, and a fifth member elected by the electoral college of the Liberian National Transitional Government (LNTG). The Accra Agreement stipulated that a ceasefire would come into effect by midnight on 28 December 1994. The Accra ceasefire lasted little more than a month.

From 15 to 19 August 1995, multiple conflict parties including the LPC and NPFL convened for a round of peace talks in Abuja. This effort was mediated by Ghanian representatives and supported by ECOWAS. A peace agreement was concluded in Abuja on 19 August 1995. The Abuja Accord successfully brought together leaders of all warring factions to form a transitional government in September 1995. This agreement amended and supplemented the Cotonou Accord, the Akosombo Agreement, and the Accra (Clarification) Agreement. Unlike previous agreements, the Abuja Agreement included most non-state armed groups, including the ULIMO, the United Liberation Front of Liberia for Democracy faction led by Roosevelt Johnson (ULIMO-J), LPC, NPFL, AFL, the National Patriotic Front of Liberia - Central Revolutionary Council (NPFL-CRC), and LNC. The Abuja Agreement gave sole authority for military enforcement to ECOMOG and removed the role that the Akosombo Agreement had assigned to the LNTG.
On 21 and 22 August 1995, a new round of negotiations aimed at ending the civil war in Liberia was mediated by Nigeria�s General Sani Abacha in Abuja, with support from the UN and the OAU.

A ceasefire was re-declared, which would take effect on 26 August 1995. The agreement also established a timeframe for the formation of an interim government and the distribution of positions within the interim government. All signatory rebel groups of the Abuja Agreement sent orders to their commanders to cease hostilities. The only exception was LPC, which continued fighting. Fighting continued in the south-east and west.

During a few weeks in the early summer of 1996, fierce battles raged in the Liberian capital Monrovia. These clashes, which are commonly referred to as the third battle for Monrovia, were fought between National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) and the United Liberation Movement of Liberia for Democracy faction led by Alhaji Kromah (ULIMO-K) on the one side and the United Liberation Front of Liberia for Democracy faction led by Roosevelt Johnson (ULIMO-J), the Liberian Peace Council (LPC), and the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) on the other side. The clashes took place in the context of a struggle over political power in the wake of the Abuja Accord concluded in December 1995. ULIMO-J fighters were among the first to violate the terms of this agreement, when they resisted the deployment of ECOMOG troops around the diamond mines near Tubmanburg. The leader of the ULIMO-J, Roosevelt Johnson, was dismissed from leadership in early 1996. Since he represented the ULIMO-J, Roosevelt Johnson was subsequently also removed from the transitional government. On 6 April, Charles Taylor tried to arrest Roosevelt Johnson, which led to heavy fighting between Taylor�s NPFL and ULIMO-J fighters loyal to Roosevelt Johnson. While the ULIMO-K fought alongside the NPFL, the ULIMO-J was supported by the AFL and the LPC. Mediation by ECOWAS � with support from the UN and the OAU � led to the restoration of a ceasefire in Monrovia on 26 May 1996.
Another round of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS, UN and OAU led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement between the factions on 4 July.

Subsequent peace talks, also mediated by ECOWAS, the UN, and the OAU, led to the conclusion of the Supplement to the Abuja Accord on 17 August 1996. The agreement is an amended version of the former Abuja accord with minor amendments to the Transitional Government and an extension of its lifespan. It confirmed the ceasefire and provided for elections to be held in May 1997. The signatories included the NPLF, AFL, LPC, ULIMO-J, and ULIMO-K.

The OAU appointed Reverend Cnaan Banna, the former President of Zimbabwe, as its eminent person to Liberia in January 1993. Together with Gordon-Sommers, Bannana was actively involved in peacemaking activities and discussed the establishment of a ceasefire with Charles Taylor in April 1993.

A UN-sponsored peace conference was held in the UN Palais des Nations in Geneva from 10 to 17 July 1993, under the joint chairmanship of the UN, ECOWAS, and the OAU. The Interim Government of National Unity (IGNU), the NPFL, and ULIMO attended this conference.

The early July effort paved the way for another round of negotiations that started on 22 July and led to the signing of a peace agreement between the conflict parties in Cotonou on 25 July 1993. The Cotonou Agreement established a monitored ceasefire and cessation of hostilities by ECOMOG. Troops were required to stay in their locations until encampment and demobilization. A transitional government with full authority over Liberia was agreed upon, including power-sharing arrangements in the executive, legislative, and judicial branches. The executive consisted of a five-member Council of State selected by prominent Liberians. The transitional Assembly comprised delegates from the government, NPFL, and ULIMO. ULIMO was given the right to nominate a delegate to the Supreme Court. Power-sharing extended to the elections commission, amnesty declaration, repatriation program for refugees and displaced persons, and release of prisoners of war. At this peace conference, Somers acted as the UN�s chief mediator, while the OAU�s eminent for Liberia person Canaan Banana acted as the OAU�s chief mediator. In addition, Nic�phore Soglo, President of Benin and chairman of ECOWAS, acted as the chief mediator of ECOWAS. According to the provisions of the agreement, which was signed in Cotonou, Benin, a ceasefire was to take effect on 1 August 1993, after which a provisional government was to be established by the end of September 1993. Elections were scheduled for 1994. In order to ensure compliance with the ceasefire, the agreement also set up a Joint Ceasefire Monitoring Committee, comprising representatives of the Interim Government, the NPFL, and ULIMO, as well as representatives of ECOWAS and the UN. However, the Cotonou ceasefire broke down almost as soon as it was signed. There was renewed fighting between the NPFL and ULIMO, while a new Krahn-dominated militia, the Liberian Peace Council (LPC), emerged in the south-east of the country where it was immediately at odds with the NPFL.

In 1994, Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings was appointed ECOWAS chairman. Progress in the peace process halted as heavy fighting took place between ULIMO and NPFL in April 1994. Consequently, with support from a mediation team consisting of UN, OAU, and ECOWAS diplomats, Rawlings mediated negotiations in Akosombo in April 1994.
On 9 September, NPFL announced a unilateral ceasefire and the next day ULIMO also announced a ceasefire.

The parties subsequently engaged in another round of negotiations and finalized the Akosombo Agreement in Ghana on 12 September 1994. The agreement was signed by the NPFL, ULIMO, and the Liberian Armed Forces. The Akosombo Peace Agreement served as a complement to the Cotonou agreement and introduced modifications to it. Alongside reaffirming the ceasefire, the agreement included amendments related to the armed forces of Liberia. It outlined the requirements for establishing a new military force. The agreement specified that demobilizing the troops and forming a new national army would fall under the responsibility of the Transitional Government. Furthermore, the agreement stated that the Transitional Government would exist for approximately 16 months, and elections were scheduled to take place on 10 October 1995. However, at the time of the signing of the Akosombo Peace Agreement, the fighting was still raging throughout Liberia. In fact, Charles Taylor and his forces were being expelled from their headquarters in Gbarnga simultaneously to the peace process in Akosombo.

The earlier peace process continued, and another conference started in Accra on 22 November and led to a ceasefire agreement and a reaffirmation of the Akosombo agreement on 22 December 1994. The Accra Agreements, also referred to as the Akosombo Clarification Agreement, reaffirmed and provided additional details to the Akosombo Agreement. Furthermore, the Accra Agreements compelled several non-signatories to adhere to the terms of the Akosombo Agreement. The agreement set up a five-member Council of State. Seats were to be divided between the NPFL, ULIMO, the coalition of anti-NPFL factions, the Liberian National Conference (LNC) consisting largely of civil society representatives, and a fifth member elected by the electoral college of the Liberian National Transitional Government (LNTG). The Accra Agreement stipulated that a ceasefire would come into effect by midnight on 28 December 1994. The Accra Agreement lasted little more than a month.

From 15 to 19 August 1995, multiple conflict parties including the LPC and NPFL convened for a round of peace talks in Abuja. This effort was mediated by Ghanian representatives and supported by ECOWAS. A peace agreement was concluded in Abuja on 19 August 1995. The Abuja Accord established a transitional government in September 1995, incorporating leaders from all warring factions. It amended and supplemented previous agreements including the Cotonou Accord, Akosombo Agreement, and Accra (Clarification) Agreement. A new ceasefire was declared, effective from August 26, 1995. The amendments mainly involved minor adjustments to power-sharing arrangements, such as replacing the five-member Council of State with a six-member council and granting ULIMO-J movement ministerial portfolios. Additionally, there were minor reallocations of other ministerial portfolios.

On 21 and 22 August 1995, a new round of negotiations between the NPFL and the ULIMO was mediated by Nigeria�s General Sani Abacha in Abuja, with support from the UN and the OAU. Prior to these talks, Abacha met with Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings. It became clear during this meeting that Nigeria would accept Ghana�s position that only the inclusion of the warlords in the government would bring peace to Liberia. Consequently, Abacha had also held private consultations with NPFL leader Taylor for four days prior to the negotiations in Abuja, which had led to a rapprochement between Nigeria and the NPFL. With Nigeria no long opposing his ambitions, Taylor became more amenable to a political solution to the conflict. The Abuja Agreement gave sole authority for military enforcement to ECOMOG and removed the role that the Akosombo Agreement had assigned to the LNTG. A ceasefire was re-declared, which would take effect on 26 August 1995. The agreement also established a time-frame for the formation of an interim government and the distribution of positions within the interim government. All signatory rebel groups of the Abuja Agreement � including the ULIMO, the United Liberation Front of Liberia for Democracy faction led by Roosevelt Johnson (ULIMO-J), NPFL, the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL), the National Patriotic Front of Liberia - Central Revolutionary Council (NPFL-CRC), and LNC � sent orders to their commanders to cease hostilities. The only exception was LPC, which continued fighting. Fighting continued in the south-east and west of Liberia.

ULIMO managed to advance and took control of the strategic Po-river Bridge in late 1992, which was located just fifteen kilometres outside the capital Monrovia. ECOMOG and the NPFL engaged in open combat from 1 November 1992 onwards, with ECOMOG being assisted by ULIMO. On 10 November 1992, ULIMO announced a unilateral ceasefire. On 20 November 1992, Trevor Gordon-Somers was appointed as the Special Representative of the UN Secretary-General to Liberia to coordinate the activities of the UN and support the peace process. Gordon-Somers subsequently began to shuttle between the conflict parties. Somers held separate consultations with the conflict parties, but he did not mediate any direct negotiations.
Mediation by ECOWAS � with support from the UN and the OAU � led to the restoration of a ceasefire in Monrovia on 26 May 1996.
Another round of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS, the UN and OAU led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement between the factions on 4 July 1996.

Subsequent peace talks, also mediated by ECOWAS, the UN, and the OAU, led to the conclusion of the Supplement to the Abuja Accord on 17 August 1996. The agreement is an amended version of the former Abuja accord with minor amendments to the Transitional Government and an extension of its life-span. It confirmed the ceasefire and provided for elections to be held in May 1997. The signatories included the NPLF, AFL, LPC, ULIMO-J, and ULIMO-K.
In April 1994, ECOMOG mediated negotiations between the two ULIMO factions, but without any results. Fighting broke out again between the two factions in May in Grand Cape Mount and Bomi Counties.

Mediation efforts conducted by UNOMIL and ECOMOG to resolve the dispute within ULIMO resulted on 6 May 1994 in a ceasefire and an agreement to hold further negotiations. However, the negotiations collapsed, and serious fighting resumed on 26 May 1994. Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings, who acted as the chairman of ECOWAS, mediated negotiations in Akosombo. These negotiations involved the Government of Liberia, the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL), the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), and the of ULIMO-K, but not ULIMO-J.
On 30 November, the ULIMO-J and the ULIMO-K signed a ceasefire agreement during a round of negotiations mediated by UNOMIL and ECOMOG.

In order to bring all major non-state armed groups in Liberia on board of the peace process, another round of negotiations was held in Accra in December 1994. The parties signed the Accra Agreement on 21 December 1994, which enabled the non-signatories to the Akosombo Agreement that had been concluded in September 1994, including ULIMO-J, to accept that agreement. The Accra Agreement stipulated that a ceasefire would come into effect by midnight on 28 December 1994. This ceasefire also entailed an obligation of ULIMO-K and ULIMO-J to stop fighting.

From 15 to 19 August 1995, multiple conflict parties including the LPC and NPFL convened for a round of peace talks in Abuja. This effort was mediated by Ghanian representatives and supported by ECOWAS. A peace agreement was concluded in Abuja on 19 August 1995. The Abuja Accord successfully brought together the leaders of all conflicting factions, establishing a transitional government in September 1995. This agreement served as an amendment and addition to the Cotonou Accord, the Akosombo Agreement, and the Accra (Clarification) Agreement. Both factions of the ULIMO were part of this agreement and both factions committed to a ceasefire that would take effect on 26 August 1995 and several power-sharing provisions included in the agreement. The Council of State, previously composed of five members, was replaced by a six-member council, and the ULIMO-J movement was granted several ministerial positions. Additionally, there were minor reassignments of ministerial portfolios agreed upon.
On 21 and 22 August 1995, a new round of negotiations aimed at ending the civil war in Liberia was mediated by Nigeria�s General Sani Abacha in Abuja, with support from the UN and the OAU.

During a few weeks in the early summer of 1996, fierce battles raged in the Liberian capital Monrovia. These clashes, which are commonly referred to as the third battle for Monrovia, were fought between the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) and the ULIMO-K on the one side and the ULIMO-J, the Liberian Peace Council (LPC), and the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) on the other side. The clashes took place in the context of a struggle over political power in the wake of the Abuja Accord concluded in December 1995. ULIMO-J fighters were among the first to violate the terms of this agreement, when they resisted the deployment of ECOMOG troops around the diamond mines near Tubmanburg. The leader of the ULIMO-J, Roosevelt Johnson, was dismissed from leadership in early 1996. Since he represented the ULIMO-J, Roosevelt Johnson was subsequently also removed from the transitional government. On 6 April, Charles Taylor tried to arrest Roosevelt Johnson, which led to heavy fighting between Taylor�s NPFL and ULIMO-J fighters loyal to Roosevelt Johnson. While the ULIMO-K fought alongside the NPFL, the ULIMO-J was supported by the AFL and the LPC. Mediation by ECOWAS � with support from the UN and the OAU � led to the restoration of a ceasefire in Monrovia on 26 May 1996.
Another round of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS, the UN and OAU led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement between the factions on 4 July 1996.

Subsequent peace talks, also mediated by ECOWAS, the UN, and the OAU, led to the conclusion of the Supplement to the Abuja Accord on 17 August 1996. This agreement is also known as the Abuja II peace agreement. The agreement is an amended version of the former Abuja accord with minor amendments to the Transitional Government and an extension of its life-span. It confirmed the ceasefire and provided for elections to be held in May 1997. The signatories included the NPLF, AFL, LPC, ULIMO-J, and ULIMO-K. Nevertheless, tensions between ULIMO-K and ULIMO-J remained.

On 6 September 1996, the two groups concluded another ceasefire during a round of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS, the OAU, and the UN. Hostilities subsequently ceased in Bomi county and both groups disengaged their forces.
On 24 September 1996, ECOWAS, the OAU, and the UN mediated another ceasefire after some fighting had resumed.

Negotiations between the ARLA and the MPA, without the involvement of a mediator, led to the conclusion of a treaty on 11 April 1994. The treaty was aimed to close the ranks between the two groups in preparation for a meeting in Tamanrasset between MFUA and the Government of Mali.

FPLA leader Zeidane ag Sidi Alamine initiated another round of negotiations between the MPA and ARLA, which led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 15 December 1994. The FPLA also signed the agreement. However, the FIAA was not part of this round of peace talks. On the contrary, the agreement signed by the MPA, ARLA, and FPLA on 15 December 1994 not only stipulated peace between the signatory groups, but also included a provision that the three groups would fight �renegade rebels�, referring to the FIAA. In the weeks prior to this formal treaty, the MPA and FPLA, together with the Mouvement Patriotique Ganda Koi (MPGK), had already reached an informal agreement to fight the FIAA together. As a result of being attacked by several armed groups, Zahaby ould Sidi Mohamed, the leader of the FIAA, finally conceded in June 1995 to adhere to the National Pact. This ended the fighting between the FIAA and the MPA, as well as the former allies of the FIAA: the PLA and ARLA.
Malian and Niger government officials met in Menaka in March 1997 to try and reconcile the two groups.

The government of Mali responded to the violence by inviting the Nigerian government to talks in the city of Menaka in Mali. These talks were held in mid-March 1997 in Menaka after the first outburst of violence. The talks were unsuccessful since violence flared up once again in July 1997. However, armed fighting did not continue after the summer of 1997.

After the start of the civil war in Mali in 2012, the Fulani became fearful that the Tuareg would dominate the inner delta of the Niger river. As a result, tensions between the two tribes increased. In February 2014, tensions between the Fulani and Tuareg escalated into violent clashes, resulting in some 30 Tuaregs killed by armed Fulani around 80 kilometres from Gao, allegedly in revenge for the kidnapping and killing of a member of their community. In March 2014, inter-communal violence between the Tuareg and the Fulani in Gao region further intensified. From 17 to 19 March 2014, the governments of Mali and Niger organized a peace meeting of Fulani and Tuareg community leaders of both countries in an effort to address long-standing intercommunal tensions and foster reconciliation.

Between 14 and 19 April 2015, MINUSMA, in line with its mandate concerning the protection of civilians, which includes the mitigation of intercommunal violence, supported a peace caravan to Goundam Cercle. To restore trust between the communities of Goundam, peaceful messages were disseminated to people in over 20 localities in the Cercle, including members of Arab, Fulani, Songhai and Tuareg communities, as well as representatives of the M�bera refugee camp in Mauritania. Activities included large public meetings in Bintagoungou, Dou�kir�, Goundam, Mbouna and Scale, as well as the facilitation of several focus group sessions aimed at promoting reconciliation. In addition, MINUSMA facilitated a number of intercommunal dialogues between the Tuareg and the Fulani communities in Bamako and the Gao, Kidal and Timbuktu regions between September to December 2015.

With support from MINUSMA, the Ministry of National Reconciliation organized two intercommunal dialogues between the Tuareg and the Fulani communities in Ansongo and Gao in the Gao region on 10 and 11 November 2015 respectively.

In the beginning of September 1993, Mr Saro-Wiwa, the founding member of the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (MOSOP), together with Senator Birabi and representatives of the Rivers State Security Council, went to the destroyed village of Kaa, and Ogoni town, and urged Governor Ada George to take steps to stop the violence between the Adoni and Ogoni. This led to several meetings between Adoni and Ogoni leaders mediated by government officials. In addition, a peace committee was created. This committee was led by headed by Professor Claude Ake. On 25 September 1993, the Nigerian government instructed the military to halt the fighting. Following the creation of the peace committee, Claude Ake went on to organize a peace conference, which was organized by the Rivers State Peace Conference Committee and National Council on Inter-Governmental Relation on 6 October 1993. After the conference, a joint resolution was issued, claiming that all parties accept the immediate resolution of the conflict. Ake dismissed this resolution as he suspected that the government played a role in the conflict. In addition, some of the Ogoni leaders, such as Saro-Wiwa, refused to sign the agreement, arguing that were still too many unanswered questions regarding the role of the government.

Negotiations in February 1995 led to the signing of a peace agreement by three Adoni and three Ogoni representatives in Port Harcourt. The agreement was signed in front of an audience of journalists, government commissioners, and elders from the concerned communities. They agreed to perform traditional rituals to complete the reconciliation and asked the government to devolve more authority, so local leaders could better keep the peace.

On 18 June 2001, the Nigerian government mediated peace talks between the conflict parties. This meeting did not lead to a written agreement, but it did result in the establishment of a commission of inquiry into the conflict.

In September 2001, clashes erupted in direct response to a dispute over a recent political appointment. Armed fighting led to several thousand deaths. A 10-man commission � referred to as the Niki Tobi Judicial Inquiry Commission � led by Joshua Dariye was set up to investigate the conflict. This commission subsequently mediated between the conflict parties at a peace conference. The Afisare, Anagura, and Birom agreed to the conclusion of a peace agreement, but the Hausa and the Fulani refused to sign it.
Tribal and religious figures representing the conflict parties engaged in peace talks mediated by state officials in early September 2001. These talks ended in a stalemate.

On 16 September 2001, President Obasanjo, reacting to the violence in Jos, met political, religious and community representatives at the government building of Plateau State and encouraged them to make peace.
The conflict parties attended the Plateau State Peace Summit in early August 2002. Plateau State governor Dariye acted as the mediator at this summit. The negotiations led to an agreement.

Four smaller follow-up meetings of the Plateau State Summit were held in September 2002. Furthermore, in 2002, the Nigerian government created a body to investigate the causes of the conflict, the Justice Opene Commission led by Justice C. Okpene. In June 2003, the Justice Dusu Commission, led by Justice Felicia K. Dusu, was established to provide recommendations for conflict resolution. Additionally, a 7-person committee was created by the Presidential Committee on Peace and Reconciliation for Southern Plateau in order to promote peace. Neither initiatives led to peace talks. Secretary to the state government Ezekiel Gomos and Governor Joshua Dariye continued to engage with the communities in order to initiate peace talks, but to no effect.

On 28 June 2004, representatives of 13 communities of the Jos North Local Government Area of Plateau � Afisare, Anaguta, Berom, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Ebira, Tiv, Sayawa, Southern Kaduna, South-South, and Yoruba � signed a peace agreement in Jos in which they pledged not to mix politics and religion and promised to live in peace.

In addition, local authorities organized a month-long peace conference aimed at bringing peace to Plateau State, which was inaugurated by President Obasanjo on 18 August 2004. This conference was conducted under a twelve-member steering committee and brought together several represenatives of the conflict parties. Government officials and traditional leaders acted as the mediators. All indigenous ethnic groups from Plateau State such as the Afisare, Anaguta, and Birom were allowed to send two representatives each to the conference, while �settlers� such as Fulani and Hausa were allowed only one representative each. The conference culminated in a draft agreement containing a number of resolutions. The draft agreement included a resolution stating that the Berom, Anaguta, and Afisare ethnic nationalities are the owners of Jos. The Hausa, unsatisfied with the conference report, refused to sign it. On 3 March 2010, the Gbong Gwom Jos set up the Stakeholder�s Consultative Committee � a multi-ethnic peace committee � together with ninety community leaders from Plateau State from Igalas, Idomas, Tivs, Afisare, Anaguta, Igbos, Yoruba, Shuwa Arab, Hausa, Fulani, Berom, and South South communities, as well as Youth groups, CAN, and JNI members. This committee had the task to restore peace in the state and met monthly in order to do so. The UN Development Program (UNDP) supported this committee.

On 10 July 2013, following consultations with each of the conflict parties, the conflict parties agreed to engage in peace talks in Jos. The Center for Humanitarian Dialogue subsequently facilitated a series of peace meetings between the Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, and Yoruba between August 2013 and June 2014. These meetings were part of the Jos Forum in which in addition to the community leaders, the Federal Government of Nigeria and the Government of Plateau State also participated.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), community leaders, government, local government

description: The Dialogue, Reconciliation and Peace Center (DREP) facilitated a meeting with eight religious leaders and six community leaders from the Hausa, Afisare, Birom, Igbo, Anaguta, and Yoruba communities in Jos on 19 June 2014. The meeting was aimed at working towards peaceful coexistence between Christian and Muslim communities.

The Center for Humanitarian Dialogue facilitated another meeting as part of the Jos Forum in December 2014. This led to the signing of the Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation on 11 December 2014. The agreement represents a public commitment to achieve peace among all signatories.
agreement_name: Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation

description: Following armed clashes in Jos in July 2015, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue mediated a round of negotiations between leaders of the Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, and Yoruba communities in Jos. This led to the signing of a joint declaration to end fighting in Jos.

In October 2017, the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue brought together several Plateau communities leaders in Jos to discuss the recent armed clashes in the state and ways to achieve lasting peace. Among the participants were leaders from the Berom, Hausa, Afisare, Anaguta, Fulani, Igbo, and Yoruba communities. This peace meeting resulted in an appeal to all communities, religious groups, and to the Plateau State government to seek lasting peace in the region, but the talks did not lead to a written agreement.

Following the clashes, on 25 August 1997, the Osun State Council of Obas and chiefs from both communities met in Oshogbo and established a seven-man committee to investigate the events. Directly after renewed violence, on 25 September 1997, the military governor of the state, Lieutenant-Colonel Anthony Obi, invited the leaders of the two communities to an emergency meeting at his headquarters in Oshogbo to end the fighting. However, no written agreement resulted from the meeting.
The Ife and Modakeke leaders agreed to peace following negotiations in Ife on 10 November 1997. However, on the same day, new clashes erupted.
On 8 December 1997, tribal leaders met with military representatives to discuss how to end the fighting in Ife Town.

Negotiations between the Modakeke and Ife leaders, mediated by the state government (led by the administrator, Lt-Col Assan Ubi), led to the signing of a peace agreement in Oshogbo on 9 December 1997.

Negotiations between the ibale (traditional ruler) of Modakeke Chief Francis Adedoyin and the asiwaju of Ife Chief Orayemi led to the signing of another peace agreement on 15 December 1997. Colonel Ubi, Osun State administrator, mediated this accord.

In response to the resurgence of violence between the two communities in September 1998, the state administrator, Col Theophilus Bamigboye, met separately Modakeke and Ife communities for shuttle negotiations on 7 September 1998. At this occasion, both communities vowed to end hostilities. However, no written agreement was agreed upon.

On 14 September 1998, Oba Okunade Sijuade and Oba Francis Adedoyin, respectively the Ooni of Ife and the Ogunsua of Modakeke met again separately with Col. Theophilus Bamgboye to negotiate an end to the fighting. Both agreed to commit to peace, but no written agreement was signed. On 14 October 1998, the Osun State Council of Obas selected Colonel Theophilus Bamigboye to create a six-person committee called the �reconciliation team� to find a solution to the ongoing ethnic conflict. Simultaneously, a committee was set up by traditional elders to attempt to mediate between the conflict parties.
Negotiations led to the signing of another peace agreement in 1999.

Violence erupted again in the beginning of March 2000. In reaction to this, the Governor of Osun State, Bisi Akande, imposed a curfew on 7 March 2000. On that same day, on 7 March 2000, Frederic Fasheun and Beko Ransome-Kuti � two officials of the Odua People�s Congress (OPC), a pan-Yoruba organization � met with leaders of the conflict parties to negotiate a solution. The following day, the two tribes agreed to a temporary ceasefire that was set to last until 10 March.

The Governor of Osun State, Bisi Akande, met with the Modakeke traditional Monarch, Oba Francis Adedoyin, to ease tensions on 9 March 2000. However, violence continued. In the same month, the Presidential Conflict Reconciliation Committee on Ife/Modakeke, Ife North Local Government Communities was established, headed by Commodore Olabode George, in order to put an end to the clashes.
On 17 March, the Ife and Modakeke leaders signed a peace agreement, after engaging in indirect negotiations mediated by the Osun Governor Bisi Akande in Oshogbo.

From 23 to 24 March, President Olusegun Obasanjo met with representatives of the Ife and Modakeke, as well as the Governor of Osun State, Bisi Akande and Commodore Olabode George to discuss lasting measures for peace. This led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement. Furthermore, President Olusegun Obasanjo also set up a new peace body with Bishop Gabriel Abegunrin (Osun State�s Catholic Diocese) serving as leader of a 27-person team: the Olabode George committee. The committee was composed of 12 members from Ife, seven from Modakeke, and eight government officials, including former external affairs minister, Professor Bolaji Akinyemi. Among the provisions included is the creation of liaison office, a police-training center and Sijuade�s recognition of Adedoyin�s authority.
On 14 April 2000, both sides reiterated their commitment to maintain peace at a peace meeting of the Olabode George committee � also known as the 27-man committee � in Oshogbo.
On 27 May 2000, President Obasanjo mediated peace talks between the two feuding communities in Abuja, while violence erupted again in the cities of Modakeke and Ife.

Following the recommendation of the Olabode George committee, the Ooni of Ife, Oba Okunade Sijuade and the Ogunsua of Modakeke Chief Francis Orafidiya reached a peace agreement at another round of negotiations mediated by President Olusegun Obasanjo in Abuja on 21 June 2000. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire and a power-sharing mechanism ensuring proportional representation of the two cities on the regional council. The US Agency for Internal Development (USAID) organized workshops and training program to key stakeholders of the Modakeke and Ife towns throughout 2000.

On 15 December 2000, after a two-day meeting with the country�s human rights panel, representatives of the two cities of Ife and Modakeke signed a �Memorandum of Understanding�, reiterating their commitment to peace.

Negotiations between Modakeke Chief Francis Adedoyin and the asiwaju of Ife Chief Orayemi, mediated by Prince Olagunsoye Oyinlola, took place on 6 February 2009. The talks resulted in Adedoyin being recognized as the Oba of Ifeland on 8 February. Furthermore, the agreement provided for the establishment of a unique local council that would be based in Modakeke. The agreement was concluded between the Osun State Government, the Ooni of Ife, the Oba Okunade Sijuwade, the Olubuse II and the Ogunsua of Modakeke, Francis Adedoyin.

Colonel Moses Fasanya tried to mediate between the conflict parties on 23 September 1998, but both parties refused to enter negotiations. In November 1998, Colonel Moses Fasanya conducted shuttle mediation between the tribal leaders in their respective Local Government Areas. Both sides expressed interest in finding a peaceful solution.
The general chief of staff Admiral Akhigbe mediated between the conflict parties in Azure in mid-February 1999. The Ijaws expressed their wish for a local government during these negotiations.

The Ijaw and Ilaje promised to establish a joint peace committee to move the reconciliation process forward during a round of negotiations in Akure on 4 August 1999. The conflict parties also agreed to a truce in the presence of federal security forces and the governor of Ondo State, Adebayo Adefarati.
In mid-August 1999, the two communities met with the Minister of Internal Affairs Chief Afolabi, who tried to negotiate an end to the clashes.
On 30 September 1999, Deputy Governor Afolabi Iyanta mediated negotiations between the conflict parties in Akure.

A round of negotiations in Ajegunle in the Ajeromi/Ifelodun council of Lagos State led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 3 November 1999. Governor Bola Ahmed Tinubu mediated these negotiations.
On 16 July 2003, the two conflict parties signed a peace agreement at a round of negotiations mediated by Ondo State governor Olusegun Agagu.

Following the violence of April 1997 in Warri, the Delta State government, under the leadership of the military administrator, Colonel J. Dang, set up a Commission of Inquiry into the violence, chaired by Judge Alhassan Idoko. The commission was composed of Itsekiri, Ijaw, and Urhobo. The commission first met in June and July 1997, but the report never went public. The violence in 1998 was limited to a single-day clash in late March and resulted in the death of thirty people. Local leaders mediated between the conflict parties in late March and early April, but this did not lead to an agreement.

Newly elected President Olusegun Obasanjo met leaders of Ijaw, Itsekiri and Urhobo communities on 9 June 1999 in Abuja. He then visited Warri on 11 June 1999, and said he was committed to finding a solution to the turmoil. On the same day, the National Assembly of Nigeria set up a 12-person committee to investigate the Warri crisis.

Itsekiri, Ijaw and Urhobo representatives met for two days of closed deliberations on 16 and 17 June 1999 to discuss the Warri crisis mediated by Governor James Ibori in the Delta State capital Asaba. This only resulted in the postponement of the peace meeting a week later.

Negotiations between the three communities one week later, mediated by Governor James Ibori of Delta State, led to the signing of a ceasefire on 24 June 1999 in Asaba. The agreement was signed by Justice Franklin Atake for the Itsekiris, Chief Edwin Clark for the Ijaws and Chief Benjamin Okumagba for the Urhobos.

In February 2003, in the run-up to Nigeria�s 2003 legislative and presidential elections, fighting broke out between the Ijaw, Itsekiri and Urhobo ethnic groups in the Niger Delta. The government sent more than 1,000 troops to the Niger Delta to contain the fighting. On 24 March 2003, James Ibori held an emergency meeting with the leaders of the three ethnic groups in conflict, the Ijaws, the Urhobo and the Itsekiri in Warri. No agreement was signed on this occasion.

On 7 April 2003, President Obasanjo met with Urhobo, Itsekiri and Ijaw leaders in Abuja, along with the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC), and security chiefs to further talk about peace solutions in Warri. At this meeting, the conflict parties reached a ceasefire agreement. Following this meeting, Obasanjo set up a committee tasked with resolving the Warri Crisis. This committee was headed by General Theophilus Y. Danjuma, who was the former Minister of Defense.

On 28 August 2003, James Ibori, the Governor of Delta State, addressed the members of the Delta State Assembly and proposed a peace plan for the Warri crisis. The plan calls for each of the three warring ethnic groups, Ijaw, Itsekiri and Urhobo, to have its own local government area. While Ijaw and Urhobo leaders endorsed it, Itsekiri claimed the plan to be �illegal� and �unconstitutional� and expressed to not be satisfied with the plan.

On 19 September 2003, Nigerian President Obasanjo attended a meeting with Ijaw, Urhobo, and Itsekiri leaders in Warri in order to promote reconciliation. The meeting was chaired by the state administrator, Colonel David Dungs, and the General Officer Commanding the 82nd Division of the Nigerian Army, Major General Felix Mojapero. The Ijaws and Urhobos deplored Itsekiri�s unjust domination of political power and supported Obori�s proposal to create local government areas. Itsekiri representatives once again rejected this proposal.

Governor James Ibori called a security meeting on 10 November 2003 in Warri to prevent a resurgence of crisis in Warri. State officials as well as representatives of the Ijaw, Urhobo and Itsekiri tribes took part in the discussion.

In the end of November 2003, President Obasanjo set up a new committee to resolve the Warri crisis, headed by Delta State governor James Ibori. James Ibori subsequently mediated several negotiations between the Itsekiri, Urhobo and Ijaw leaders in late November 2003.

Traditional rulers of the Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Urhobo participated in a traditional leaders� forum in Ozoro on the weekend between 18 and 19 June 2005. This forum was aimed at minimizing the tensions between feuding ethnic groups. Ijaw Brigadier General (retired) Cletus Emein, retired Senator Francis Okpozo, and Itsekiri Chief Isaac Jemide led the meeting. The meeting resulted in a covenant that recognizes the need to build the capacities of different communities
Mediation attempts by Taraba and Adamawa authorities were carried out during December 1991, but this did not ease the tensions.

The conflict intensified in early 1992. The Nigerian government convened peace meetings between the Jukun and Tiv on two separate occasions during February 1992. On 13 February, the leaders of the conflict parties � H.R.H. Dr. Shekarau Angyu Masa-Ili and H.R.H. Ochivirigh Alfred Akawa Torkula Tor Tiv for the Jukun and the Tiv respectively � signed a 10-point peace agreement in Wukari. Representatives from both Taraba and Benue governments, Reverend Jolly Nyame and Moses Adasu, were in attendance.
Earlier on 13 February 1992, the group had gathered at Aguda House in Abuja with Admiral Augustus Aikhomu in order to discuss the conflict issues and the potential for signing a ceasefire.

The UCDP does not record any armed clashes between the conflict parties between 1995 and 2000, though little progress was made with regard to the implementation of the 1992 agreement. This might explain why shortly after his election in May 1999, Rev. Jolly Nyame set up a peace committee that had the task to mediate between the two communities. Violence intensified again in Taraba in the second half of 2001. On 24 September 2001, Vice-President Atiku Abubakar, following the order of President Olusegun Obasanjo instructed the governments of Benue and Taraba to resolve the continued conflict during a reconciliation meeting in Abuja. Representatives of both warring groups were present. In addition, at the national level, the Federal Government and military authorities asserted that they sent soldiers to Tarabata State and the areas around the Tarabata-Benue border at the beginning of October 2001 in order to restore peace in the region. Meanwhile, on 10 October 2001, a Tiv armed group abducted 19 soldiers. Tiv elements claim that the soldiers were armed Jukuns and did not believe that these soldiers were coming to restore peace.
