Furthermore, militia fighters were not included in the negotiations and expressed resentment over the lack of consultation. As a result, the belligerents did not surrender their weapons following the agreement. The agreement however allowed the deployment of the army in the two adjacent neighbourhoods and the return of displaced persons. Although sporadic attacks between the two groups and against the army continued, the situation remained relatively calm in the following months.
third_party: Mufti of Tripoli and Northern Lebanon

description: The arrest of Sunni cleric Shadi al-Mawlawi reignited clashes between Alawites and Sunnis in Tripoli on 12 May 2012. The Lebanese army deployed in the Syria street demarcating the neighbourhoods of Bab al-Tabbaneh and Jabal Mohsen on 14 and 15 May 2012. On 15 May 2012, the two sides agreed on a ceasefire imposed by the Lebanese army.

Heavy fighting continued in the beginning of June 2012. On 3 June 2012, the Lebanese army intervened to stop the fighting and sent more troops to the area. On 20 August 2012, the Lebanese army enforced an end to fighting between Bab al-Tabbaneh Sunnis and Jabal Mohsen Alawites. Yet, clashes continued. Peace talks held on 22 August 2022 led to the signing of an agreement at the house of Deputy Mohammad Kabbara from the Future Movement. This agreement called for the army to redeploy units in the Syria street in Tripoli. The meeting also ended with the declaration of a unilateral ceasefire on the part of Bab al-Tabbaneh representatives. Despite the deal, casualties continued to be reported during the deployment of Lebanese government troops. Jabal Mohsen Alawite representatives reportedly also committed to the ceasefire agreement. However, clashes continued in the Tripolitan neighbourhoods.

On 23 October 2012, following two nights of fighting, the Lebanese army brokered a ceasefire between Tripoli Alawite and Sunni gunmen after talking to both parties. However, fighting already resumed the same evening. In December 2012, the Lebanese army sought to impose a security plan in Tripoli. It installed checkpoints in Jabal Mohsen and Bab al-Tabbaneh and expanded its deployment in the city. However, lacking a political mandate, the army neither seized weapons nor arrested fighters.
On 23 March 2013, after talks with the army, community representatives from Bab al-Tabbaneh and Jabal Mohsen separately announced a ceasefire.

A new round of violence erupted on 19 May 2013. In response to calls for a ceasefire, peace talks were held in the Harba Mosque in Bab al-Tabbaneh on 22 May 2013. Members of parliament, religious leaders, and other community leaders were among the negotiators present at this meeting. No ceasefire was reached.

On 26 May 2013, two meetings were held in different mosques in Tripoli between leaders of armed groups in the neighbourhoods of Qibbeh, Al-Shaarani, and Mankoubin. Sunni leaders insisted on the departure of head of the Arab Democratic Party, Refaat Eid, from Jabal Mohsen as a precondition for a ceasefire. One of the meetings was headed by Sheikh Khalid Sayyid, who managed to broker a truce between the Alawites and the Sunnis. This truce was reportedly aimed at facilitating the deployment of the army in Bab al-Tabbaneh. A new Tripoli security plan was set up in early October 2013, following a meeting of top security officials chaired by interim Interior Minister Marwan Charbel. On 2 December 2013, the government authorized the army to take charge of security in Tripoli for six months, even though the army had so far been unable to quell the violence.

On 22 January 2014, a ceasefire was agreed during an emergency meeting at the Tripoli residence of interim Prime Minister Najib Mikati, gathering members of parliament, religious leaders, other community leaders, and army representatives. The meeting was also attended by the head of the Army Intelligence in the north. On 1 April 2014, the Lebanese government launched a new security plan for Tripoli. The army deployed in the city, dismantling militia barrages, replacing them with army checkpoints. This ended armed fighting.

On 23 April 1999, the three tribes reached a peace agreement in Bukavu that outlined new access to markets and herding land. Armed clashes between the Bafulero and the Banyamulenge erupted again in 2014, this time with the involvement of the Barundi. On 6 June 2014, the Bafulero on the one side and the Banyamulenge and the Barundi on the other side clashed around Mutarule. The Banyamulenge claimed that a Bafulero militia had attacked Banyamulenge herders � and in revenge Banyamulenge and Barundi youths attacked and killed over 33 Bafulero that had gathered to attend an outdoor church service.
Hamisa Zaja and Sheikh Idriss, together with other religious leaders, mediated between the Orma and Pokomo communities in July 2012. Fighting flared up again in August.
On 23 August 2012, the Orma and Pokomo convened for a round of negotiations mediated by Kenyan police officers. This round of talks did not lead to a peace agreement.

After another bout of violence in September 2012, the Kenyan government sent 1,000 soldiers to stabilize the Tana River District and tried to organize another round of peace talks. However, neither community wished to participate in this mediation effort, preferring instead to engage in bilateral negotiations. In mid-September 2012, tribal elders from the Mijikenda signaled their intention to mediate between the Orma and Pokomo, but this did not lead to peace talks. On 4 October 2012, 40 elders from the Orma, Pokomo, and Wardei attended a three-day peace conference in Malindi. Several different third parties acted as mediators during the conference, including the Consortium for the Empowerment and Development of Marginalised Communities, the National Commission and Integration Commission (NCIC), National Muslim Leadership Forum, and the Council of Imams and Preachers of Kenya. Although no peace agreement was concluded during this round of talks, the conflict parties agreed that peace was a priority.

The NCIC initiated a mediation effort in September 2014. The NCIC worked with religious and community leaders, civil societies, the National Steering Committee on Peacebuilding and Conflict Management (NSC), and the Kenya Red Cross Society (KRCS). The mediation effort focused on mitigating violence in the towns of Amu, Faza, Hindi, and Witu. On 17 September 2014, community leaders signed The Boma Commitment on the Promotion of Peace and Cohesion in Lamu County. President Uhuru Kenyatta attended the signing ceremony. To follow-up with the implementation, peace committees were created in Hindi, Lamu, and Mpeketoni.
third_party: government, religious leaders, community leaders, Red Cross
agreement_name: Boma Commitment on the Promotion of Peace and Cohesion in Lamu County

description: Violence between the conflict parties resumed in 2017 with the Dan Nan Ambassagou armed group, belonging to the Dogon tribe, taking up arms in 2017, allegedly to defend itself against the Fulani community. The Fulani were perceived by the Dogon community as an accomplice of external, Jihadist armed groups who had also targeted the Dogon. In April 2017, the government established the Mission to Support National Reconciliation, which travelled to the Dogon areas and some areas of the Central Delta to meet with the Dogon and Fulani communities for dialogue.

From 7 to 9 September 2017, 140 community representatives � including village chiefs and religious leaders � from Bambara, Fulani and Dogon communities from the regions of Mopti and S�gou came together in the city of S�gou in order to promote reconciliation between communities in Central Mali. This peace initiative was complemented with several peace meetings between the different tribal communities organized at lower levels in the regions.

Heavy armed fighting broke out again in January 2018. The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue began a peace effort in early February 2018, involving continuous talks with the political bureau, the military staff, and the local representatives of Dan Nan Ambassagou.
The Malian Minister of National Reconciliation and Social Cohesion mediated between the leaders of the Dogon and Fulani of the Mopti region in Bamako on 16 March 2018.
On 24 March 2018, there was also a meeting between Dogon and Fulani in Koro, which was mediated by a delegation of the Ministry of National Reconciliation and Social Cohesion.
On 6 and 7 June 2018, MINUSMA provided logistical support for a mediation effort by a government delegation in Mopti. This led to a local ceasefire.

On 28 August 2018, following a mediation effort conducted by HD involving 34 Dogon and Fulani village chiefs from the Koro district that had begun in early June 2018, the conflict parties signed an intercommunal peace agreement to end violence in the Mopti region. The agreement stipulates a ceasefire, as well as stressed that all communities should have peaceful access to natural resources and calls for the use of traditional mediation mechanisms to prevent and manage disputes over land access. In order to link this agreement to the national-level peace process, HD tried to work together with the monitoring committee set up following the Bamako Agreement concluded in June 2015 � the Comit� de Suivi du present Accord (CSA) � to oversee the implementation of the peace agreement concluded between the Dogon and the Fulani, as well as the Bamako Agreement. However, the Bamako Agreement was rejected by the Dan Nan Ambassagou, which claimed that it had not been involved in the process. On 16 September, the militia group would agree to a unilateral ceasefire referred to as �Commitment to a unilateral ceasefire from Youssouf TOLOBA and his armed group, Dan Nan Ambassagou� in Mopti. The Fulani cultural association Tabital Pulaaku had denounced the Bamako Agreement because its leaders wanted to see Dana Nan Amassagou�s military leader, Youssouf Toloba, tried at the International Criminal Court (ICC). The HD effort to link the peace process between the Dogon and the Fulani to the national-level peace process failed.

In July 2018, MINUSMA started a reconciliation project in three villages in the Koro district of the Mopti region. The project was aimed at preventing further conflicts between the Dogon and Fulani communities.

A peacemaking effort by the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), mandated by the Government of Mali, led to the issuing of a unilateral ceasefire in Mopti on 2 July 2018 by a Dogon militia, called the Dan Nan Ambassagou. As part of this unilateral ceasefire, the Dan Nan Ambassagou armed group also mandated HD to mediate the conflict between them and the Fulani community armed groups actors in the areas of Koro, Bankass, Douentza, and Bandiagara in central Mali.

On 2 October 2018, the Malian Prime Minister chaired inter-community talks between the Dan Nan Ambassagou and Fulani representatives. This led to the conclusion of another ceasefire. However, the Dan Nan Ambassagou leaders denounced this ceasefire in November 2018, arguing that they needed to take up arms again to protect Dogon tribe members after several were Dogon were killed by Malian armed forces.

The Ogossagou massacre of Fulani herders on 23 March 2019 sent shockwaves throughout the region and led to the resignation of the prime minister and his government. In response, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) began to mediate peace talks between the Bozo, Dafi, Dogon, Fulani and Samoko in June 2019. This led to the signing of a peace agreement in Baye on 25 July 2019. The main commitments of the communities in this peace agreement were to urge their armed groups to cease violence, report any threats or attacks, strongly condemn future violence by their members, and help lift embargoes on villages and markets, facilitating the rapid return of displaced persons.

Local leaders and MINUSMA Civil Affairs mediated between the Fulani and Dogon in the the Bambara community in Macina, San, and Niono cercles in the Segou region and the Djenn� and Tenenkou cercles in the Mopti region. This led to the signing of peace agreement on 3 August 2019.

On 16 August 2019, MINUSMA Civil Affairs, supported by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue and the deputy mayor of Ouenkoro, Housseyni Sankar�, succeeded in mediating a peace agreement between the Dafing, Fulani and Dogon communities. The Agreement committed the parties to cease and prevent violence, aid the rapid return of displaced individuals, respect free movement of people and goods, ensure the return of lost herds to the authorities, help lift embargoes on Ouenkoro's villages and markets, oppose livestock theft irrespective of community ownership, promote peace among community leaders through cohesive messaging, and ensure the agreement's dissemination and ongoing communication regarding its implementation at the community level

Following a visit by the Malian Prime Minister, Dr. Boubou Ciss�, in early July 2019, local authorities initiated a mediation effort between Fulani and Dogon communities living in Sokoura and Tori in the Bankass cercle of the Mopti region. This mediation effort resulted in a round of peace talks in the chef-lieu of Sokoura commune on 18 September 2019. This round of negotiations was mediated by the Prefect of Bankass, with support from MINUSMA Civil Affairs. The peace talks led to the signing of a peace agreement.
MINUSMA and the Mayor of Youdiou mediated between between Dafing, Dogon, Fulani and Mossi communities on 24 November 2019. This led to a local peace agreement.

On 22 January 2021, a peace agreement between the Fulani and Dogon communities of Pel Maoud�, Dougout�n� 1, Dougout�n� 2, Koporo Kendi� Na, Koporo Pen, and Youdiou was signed after four months of mediation by HD.
agreement_name: Peace agreement between the Dogon & Peulh communities of Dougout�n� I, Dougout�n� II, Koporo Kendi� Na, Koporo Pen, Pel Maoud� and Youdiou

description: On 24 January 2021, a peace agreement between the Fulani and Dogon communities from Madougou and Barapir�li was signed after four months of mediation by HD.
agreement_name: Peace Agreement between the Dogon & Peulh communities of Madougou and Barapirely

description: On 7 February 2021, a peace agreement was concluded between the Dogon, Dafing, and Fulani communities in Mali. This accord pledges to uphold the physical safety and freedom of movement for individuals, goods, and livestock, and explicitly denounces the violence in the Bankass circle. The agreement was reached after an eight-month mediation effort conducted by HD.
agreement_name: Peace Agreement between Dogon, Dafing & Fulani communities in Diallassagou, Koulogon Hab�, Lessagou Hab�, S�gue, Soubala, Sokoura and Tori communes

description: In January 2021, HD mediated between the Fulani and Dogon communities in three different locations, each leading to the signing of a peace agreement. On 12 January 2021, the peace agreement between the Fulani and Dogon communities from Dagat�ne, Bondo, Diougani, and Koro was signed after four months of mediation by HD.
agreement_name: Peace Agreement between the Dogon & Peulh communities of Bondo, Dioungani, and Koro

description: On 26 February 2021, a peace agreement was reached between the Fulani and Dogon communities in Koro, Mali. The agreement followed a series of prior peace deals signed on 12, 22 and 24 January 2021, among various Fulani and Dogon communities in specific regions within Koro. The agreement was mediated by HD.

On 26 March 2021, a peace agreement was concluded between the Dogon, Bobo, Mossie, and Fulani communities residing in Timiniri and Bara Sara within Mali's Bandiagara circle, situated in the Bandiagara region. The agreement aimed to address and resolve a community conflict involving armed actors among these groups, fostering peace and reconciliation in the region. The agreement was mediated by HD.

On 10 July 2021, a peace agreement was concluded between the Fulani community from the municipalities of Ouenkoro, Sokoura, and Diallassagou in the Bankass circle, and the Bwa, Dafing, and Dogon communities from the municipalities of Timissa, Lanfiala, Koula, and Benena in the Tominian circle within Mali�s Mopti region. The agreement was facilitated by HD. On 18 September 2021, the municipality of Fangasso acceded to the peace agreement, joining the aforementioned communities in their commitment to peace and reconciliation.

On 28 June 2012, Iyad Ag Ghali, the leader of Ansar Dine, reportedly arrived in Gao at the head of a convoy of more than 60 vehicles to meet with the leaders of the various rebel groups operating in Gao to put an end to tensions between the different groups.

On 30 June 2012, Iyad Ag Ghaly met with some of the CMA leadership, including Colonels Mechkenani, Ntala, and Salat, to discuss the conclusion of a ceasefire between the CMA on the one hand and MUJAO, AQIM, Signed-in-Blood Battalion, and Jama�atu Ahlis Sunna Lidda�awati wal-Jihad on the other hand. The CMA agreed in principle to a ceasefire but the Jihadist groups in the end refrained from delivering a written pledge to formally endorse a ceasefire.
Negotiations between MUJAO and CMA led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 17 November 2012.
In response to clashes in January 2012, the deputy governor went to the conflict area to mediate.

In November 2006, the groups fought for five days. Interior Minister General Denis Kalume Numbi arrived in Bolobo on 19 November 2006 to mediate and encourage a settlement between the two communities. He called for various actions such as establishing community brazas and a community radio.

In the week of 27 November 2006, a community seminar on peace was held. Fighting resumed again in 2018. Large-scale attacks were organized and planned by members of the Batende community against members of the Banunu community between 16 and 18 December 2018. The attacks were in response to the burial of a deceased Banunu customary leader in Yumbi town on 14 December 2018. Members of the Batende community had warned the Banunu not to bury their chief in the town center and the local authorities had forbidden it, but the Banunu went ahead. Military and police reinforcements arrived in the area in response to the fighting and tried to restore a fragile order. Local officials were held responsible and fired for their alleged participation in fomenting the conflict.
Negotiations between the Habaniya and Salamat Baggara led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in 2009.

Large-scale fighting erupted again in April 2017, when tribesmen from the Habaniya and Salamat Baggara clashed over 150 stolen cows in En Nadeef area. The conflict between the two tribes escalated further in Buram locality between 8 and 10 May, resulting in more than 100 people killed or injured. Sudanese government forces separated the two tribes following these clashes. The two communities agreed a ceasefire at a peace meeting on 12 May 2017. A state-level mediation committee, as well as the Governor of South Darfur, community leaders, and UNAMID, mediated this meeting.
third_party: government, local government, community leaders, UNAMID

description: The same third parties (a state-level mediation committee, as well as the Governor of South Darfur, community leaders, and UNAMID) mediated a peace agreement on 29 May 2017.
third_party: government, local government, community leaders, UNAMID

description: In addition, the leaders of both tribes engaged in negotiations, with mediation by the same third parties, on 30 October 2017. This led to the signing of a peaceful coexistence agreement.
third_party: government, local government, community leaders, UNAMID

description: Both groups participated in the Interactive Peace Summit in Benin City on 12 and 13 October 2013, along with several other cult groups including the Green Circuit (Maphites), Norsemen (Vikings), Family Fraternity of Nigeria, and Avarian Organization of Nigeria. The summit focused on ending violence in Edo State. Several state officials were also present such as the Iyase (i.e., the traditional Prime Minister) of the Benin Kingdom, Chief Sam Igbe, and representatives of the Edo State police.

Both the Eiye and the Black Axe took part in the Ikorodu peace initiative in June 2017. Both sides promised to end fighting and stop all forms of criminality. In return, the Governor of Lagos State, Akinwunmi Ambode, granted them amnesty. Abdulazeez Sholebo was there to represent the Eyie brotherhood, while Seyi Ajasa led the Black Axe group.

Both groups participated in the Interactive Peace Summit in Benin City on 12 and 13 October 2013, along with several other cult groups including the Eyie, Norsemen (Vikings), Family Fraternity of Nigeria, and Avarian Organization of Nigeria. The summit focused on ending violence in Edo State. Several state officials were also present such as the Iyase (i.e., the traditional Prime Minister) of the Benin Kingdom, Chief Sam Igbe, and representatives of the Edo State police.
The conflict parties did not clash in 2013, but armed fighting resumed again in August 2014. One year later, on 9 August 2015, the two sides attended a peace meeting in Aynabo.
Another round of negotiations was held in Addis Ababa on 1 November 2015.

As a result of the Khatumo administration becoming disillusioned with ongoing talks with the Government of Somalia about the status of the Khatumo administration, its leaders started to engage with the Republic of Somaliland again. A peace conference attended by elders from both the Khatumo administration and the Republic of Somaliland was held in Aynaba on 8 August 2016.
On 17 November 2016, representatives from both sides met in Addis Ababa. Ethiopian Prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn acted as the mediator at this round of negotiations.

Another round of negotiations started in mid-December 2016, which led to the signing of a peace agreement on 23 December 2016. This agreement stipulated that the contested territory would be governed under shared institutions.

On 7 February 2017, Ali Khalif Galaydh, the leader of one of the two contesting administrations in Khatumo, came to Djibouti in order to meet with Somaliland representatives to discuss solutions to the conflict between the Khatumo administration and the Republic of Somaliland.

On 17 June 2017, representatives of the Khatumo administration and Somaliland signed a five-clause agreement that stipulated, among others, devolution and a quota system for political representation. However, the traditional leadership in Khatumo vocalized opposition to this agreement.
A follow-up agreement was signed in Hargeisa on 28 August 2017.

A peace conference in Ainaba between 20 and 22 October 2017 led to the signing of the Ainaba Agreement. This agreement stipulated a ceasefire, but also altered Somaliland�s constitution and stipulated the integration of the Khatumo administration�s army into that of Somaliland.
The Muslim Brotherhood negotiated with the Egyptian army to reinstate Morsi in July 2013.
Foreign Minister Khalid Al Attiyah from Qatar mediated between various players, including the Muslim Brotherhood and the Egyptian army in late July 2013.
Al-Azhar University mediated between the Muslim Brotherhood and the Egyptian army in early August 2013.

European Union special envoy Bernardino Leon collaborated with the United States assistance secretary of state William Burns and defense secretary Chuck Hagel mediated during the protests in 2013. The government instituted a curfew to curb the violence in August 2013.

A 10-man commission � referred to as the Niki Tobi Judicial Inquiry Commission � led by Joshua Dariye was set up to investigate armed fighting in Jos in September 2001. This commission subsequently mediated between the Afisare, Anagura, Birom, Hausa, and Fulani at a peace conference in early September 2001. The Afisare, Anagura, and Birom agreed to the conclusion of a peace agreement, but the Hausa and the Fulani refused to sign a peace agreement.
In an attempt to find a solution to the crisis, the state government organized another round of peace talks on 12 September 2001. However, this meeting also ended in an impasse.
The conflict parties attended the Plateau State Peace Summit in early August 2002. Former Plateau State governor Dariye acted as the mediator at this summit. The negotiations led to an agreement.
Four smaller follow-up meetings were held in September 2002.

In May 2004, Chris Alli was selected to be Interim Administrator by President Obasanjo. He organized multiple efforts to resolve the ongoing conflicts between Christians and Muslims, which included the conflict between Afisare, Anaguta, Birom and Fulani, and Hausa. During the state of emergency, Chris Alli launched a six-month Plateau Peace Program to bring lasting peace to the area. The plan included meetings between religious, ethnic and community leaders and the government. On 28 June 2004, representatives of 13 communities of the Jos North Local Government Area of Plateau � including Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Ebira, Tiv, Sayawa, Southern Kaduna, South-South, and Yoruba � signed a peace agreement in Jos. They pledged not to mix politics and religion and promised to live in peace.

Part of Alli�s Program was also a month-long peace conference that was inaugurated by President Obasanjo on 18 August 2004. This conference was mediated by a twelve-member steering committee and brought together government officials and traditional leaders to find compromises to bring peace to Plateau State. All indigenous ethnic groups from Plateau State (e.g., Afisare, Anaguta and Birom) were allowed to send two representatives each while �settlers� (i.e., Fulani and Hausa) were allowed only one representative each. It culminated in a report containing a number of resolutions. These included the resolution stating that �the Birom, Anaguta and Afisare ethnic nationalities are the owners of Jos.� However, the Hausa, unsatisfied with the conference report, refused to sign it. On 7 March 2010, more than 200 Birom civilians were reportedly killed by Hausa and Fulani in Birom villages 10 kilometers south of Jos, in retaliation for previous attacks against Muslims and cattle rustling by Fulani herders. No mediation or negotiation process took place between the three groups after this event.

No longer able to control the Seleka fighters or violence in the Central African Republic in general, Michel Djotodia stepped down on 10 January 2014. This trigged even greater reprisal killings of Muslims conducted by Christians. The French military � which had begun an intervention in the Central African Republic in late 2013, dubbed Operation Sangaris � mediated between the Christian and Muslim communities in the PK5 and Bimbo 3 neighbourhoods in Bangui on 11 and 12 January 2014, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire.

Intense communal violence between Christians and Muslims also took place in Boda, located 200 kilometer west of Bangui, after the ex-Seleka withdrew from this town when President Michel Djotodia resigned in early January 2014. Bilateral negotiations between Muslim and Christian leaders in Boda led to the conclusion of an agreement to end hostilities on 16 March 2014.

The Government of the Central African Republic facilitated a peace meeting aimed at reconciliation between Muslims and Christians in the PK5 neighbourhood in Bangui in early April 2014, but this did not lead to an agreement. In April 2014, the London-based NGO Conciliation Resources helped to set up the interfaith platform in Bangui, which was a forum where religious leaders in the Central African Republic could engage in dialogue to promote reconciliation between the Muslim and Christian communities. As part of this initiative, several local interfaith �peace committees� were set up. On 10 April 2014, the UN Security Council authorized the United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (MINUSCA).
Another peace meeting mediated by the government, this time with support from the UN, led to the singing of an agreement in PK5 on 17 May 2014.

The government of the Central African Republic, with the support from MINUSCA and various other partners working in the realm of social cohesion and development, mediated between the Muslim community of PK5 and the Christian community in Bimbo 3 between June and September 2015. As part of these negotiations, the UN developed a plan for a labor-intensive project, refereed toi as travail � haute intensit� de main d�oeuvre, in which members from both communities could participate to help reopen the cemetery. In August 2015, 200 youths, 100 from the Christian and 100 from the Muslim community, were mobilized and started working together to weed the grounds of the cemetery. Negotiations culminated into a planned signing ceremony of a non-aggression pact on 17 September 2015, but the conflict parties refused to sign last minute. Violence between the PK5 and Bimbo 3 communities resumed and Muslims were once again prevented from accessing the cemetery.
Negotiations mediated by MINUSCA between representatives of the Christian and Muslim communities in Batangafo led to the signing of the Batangafo Weapon Free Zone agreement on 12 December 2015.

On 6 January 2016, negotiations between the Muslim community of PK5 and the Christian community in Bimbo 3 in Bangui resumed. These negotiations, which were mediated by government officials with support from MINUSCA, resulted in the signing of the Pacte de non-agression et de r�conciliation intercommunautaire (English: the Non-Aggression and Community Reconciliation Pact) by the two communities on 11 February 2016. Signatories included the religious leaders, women, youth, civil society representatives, the mayors of the two localities, but also representatives of the anti-Balaka forces. The pact guaranteed the Muslims free access to their burial grounds, as well as stipulated an end to the use of armed violence and igniting intercommunity tensions. In addition, the agreement stipulated that the PK5 community would not carry weapons when accompanying funeral processions, while the community of Boeing would guarantee the security of the processions. The non-aggression pact signed on 11 February 2016 remained the only signed agreement between the Muslim community of PK5 and the Christian community in Bimbo 3 by the end of 2018, though the agreement has been frequently been violated when there are tensions between PK5 and Boeing.
agreement_name: Pacte de non-agression et de r�conciliation intercommunautaire

description: Negotiations between representatives of the Christian and Muslim communities in Batangafo led to the signing of a non-aggression pact on 29 March 2016. These negotiations were mediated by deputy prefect, Ngozila Deo-Bafounga, with support from MINUSCA. The agreement committed both sides to allow for the free movement of people.

The Berberati field office of MINUSCA supported community-led initiatives in Carnot to help displaced Muslims return. On 8 May 2017, MINUSCA organized a workshop to resolve disputes between Christian occupants who resided in the houses of Muslim returnees.

In June 2017, MINUSCA mediated between the internally displaced Muslim community living in Kaga Bandoro and the Christian community of Ndenga. In addition, MINUSCA involved anti-Balaka representatives in the talks. MINUSCA�s mediation effort took place in the context of a high level of tensions between the Muslims and Christian communities in this area in the wake of an ex-Seleka attack on an internally displaced people camp in Kaga Bandoro on 12 October 2016, which resulted in at least 37 deaths. The mediation effort was successful and led to the signing of a non-agression pact on 10 June 2017: the Pacte de non agression et de la libre circulation dans la commune de Ndenga entre les habitats de la commune de Ndenga et les deplaces de Ndenga vivant a Kaga Bandoro.
agreement_name: Pacte de non agression et de la libre circulation dans la commune de Ndenga entre les habitats de la commune de ndenga et les deplaces de ndenga vivant a kaga bandoro

description: Intercommunity dialogue aimed at promoting social cohesion and reconciliation between Christians and Muslims took place in the Haut-Mbomou prefecture in February 2018. This peace effort was led by religious and community leaders and the deputy-mayor of Zemio, but was also supported by the MINUSCA Civil Affairs section in Obo. The peace effort led to the signing of the Pacte de non-agression et de r�conciliation entre les communaut�s in February 2018. This agreement stipulated the non-violent resolution of disputes, freedom of movement, prohibition of carrying weapons, and a commitment to counter false rumours and misinformation. The agreement was successful in mitigating violence between the two communities in spite of clashes between the anti-Balaka and the UPC in the area.
third_party: religious leaders, community leaders, local government, MINUSCA
agreement_name: Pacte de non-agression et de r�conciliation entre les communaut�s

description: A joint mediation of Cardinal Dieudonn� Nzapalainga and Imam Omar Kobine Layam, with support from MINUSCA, led to the signing of the Bangassou Peace Agreement on 9 April 2018. MINUSCA supported the mediation effort. This mediation effort was a response to an escalation of armed violence in the Bangassou area starting in May 2017. As a result of this increase in violence, the whole Muslim community in the area sought shelter at the Bangassou Cathedral. This agreement stipulates an end to violence, the freedom of movement for humanitarians and the general population, opening of the humanitarian corridor, and dismantlement of checkpoints in Bangassou and on the axes. A local peace council subsequently worked to implement the agreement. This local peace council had been set up by the local abbot, Father Alain-Blaise Bissialo, to resolve the numerous conflicts between Christians and Muslims in Bangassou town. The local peace council consisted of both Christian and Muslim notables.

On 4 and 5 June 2018, Cardinal Dieudonn� Nzapalainga and Imam Omar Kobine Layama facilitated another round of dialogue to discuss the implementation of the Bangassou Peace Agreement that had been concluded in April 2018.

In October 2018, the MINUSCA Civil Affairs section convened a workshop between Christian and Muslim communities in the Haut-Mbomou prefecture to follow up on the Pacte de non-agression et de r�conciliation entre les communaut�s which had been concluded in February 2018. The agreement of February 2018 had held, but tensions between the communities were increasing again as a result of fighting between the anti-Balaka and the UPC in the area. The workshop convened by Civil Affairs led to the signing of another agreement on 27 October 2018. This follow-up agreement confirmed the previous agreement and explicitly stated that the communities are committed to the agreement in spite of armed clashes between the anti-Balaka and the UPC.

Another peace process involving Muslim and Christian communities also started in October 2018. On 18 October 2018, MINUSCA facilitated an exchange of letters between the two Mayors of Pombolo and Gambo. These letters were in response to at least five large-scale clashes between the Muslim inhabitants of Gambo and Christian inhabitants of Pombolo towns since August 2017. These letters requested the start of a reconciliation process and suggested the organization of a round table discussion. Following this initial exchange of letters between the two mayors MINUSCA helped to create a peace committee in Gambo and another one in Pombolo, each consisting of 12 members. On 6 November 2018, MINUSCA and the Prefect of Mbomou facilitated an initial peace meeting between the two mayors in Pombolo. During this meeting the mayors agreed to move forward with the Peace Process and mandated the peace committees to find a solution to the conflict.
A first meeting, mediated by the sub-prefect and with support from MINUSCA was held on 9 December 2018.

Another meeting was held on 23 December 2018. This meeting was also mediated by the sub-prefect, with support from MINUSCA. The peace committees from the two communities confirmed their commitment to a peaceful resolution of the conflict, as well as agreed on a joint plan for direct dialogue.

Peace talks between the Muslim inhabitants of Gambo and Christian inhabitants of Pombolo mediated by sub-prefect, with support from MINUSCA, continued in 2019. A peace and reconciliation agreement was signed on 20 March 2019.
On 13 June 2019, the agreement was extended to the village of Ngandou, which means the agreement covers the entire sub-prefecture.

On 24 May 2022, MINUSCA, the Local Peace and Reconciliation Committees (LPRC), and local authorities mediated between the Muslim and Christian communities in Obo. This led to the signing of the Agreement for Dialogue and Reconciliation for the Communities of Obo. The latter foresees peaceful coexistence and forgiveness of the violent events taking place in the Obo region in 2020. It encourages free movement and trade in Obo, with a particular note on respecting herders� rights and agricultural land plots. Included in the agreement is the return of displaced persons and the establishment of a follow up committee.
third_party: MIUSCA, Local Peace and Reconciliation Committees, Local Authorities
agreement_name: Agreement for Dialogue and Reconciliation for the Communities of Obo

description: Following armed clashes in a cattle camp 34 kilometers north-east of Rumbek in November 2012, the Minister of Local Government and Law Enforcement visited the area with Rumbek Central Commissioner Abraham Mayen Kuc to gather information and to mediate between the conflict parties near the cattle camp. The government of Lakes State�s also responded through deploying heavily armed police and military patrols to the area in and around the Luak-Makuer Gol cattle camp.
UNAMID, together with Meidob tribal leaders, conducted a mediation effort in Mellit on 21 August 2012. This led to signing of a ceasefire agreement.

Several cattle raids and a conflict over grazing areas triggered renewed conflict in the Mellit area in March 2015. This time, the Berti accused former Janjaweed leader Musa Hilal of supporting the Al-Zayadia and to instigate the armed conflict. Hilal and Osman Mohamed Youssef Kibir were political rivals. The use of heavy weapons in these clashes led to the death of 127 tribe members in 2015. The Zayadia, allegedly associated with paramilitary Border Guards and Central Reserve Police troops, continuously attacked the Berti in Mellit. UNAMID support traditional authorities in their peacemaking efforts. UNAMID was involved in seven meetings in March with key stakeholders both in Northern Darfur and Khartoum as part of efforts to reach a peaceful resolution of the conflict. The conflict parties subsequently signed a ceasefire on 24 March 2015, as well as agreed on forming a commission to investigate the recent clashes.

However, fighting resumed again already the next day. UNAMID was heavily involved in peacemaking throughout July 2015, engaging with community leaders, local authorities, influential tribal figures in Khartoum, the native administrations in Khartoum, and the Darfur Regional Authority. UNAMID also supported the Sudanese government�s mediation effort, which led to the conclusion of another ceasefire agreement on 13 July 2015, but fighting continued.

The Mayi Mayi consisted of many local armed group and several Mayi Mayi groups in North Kivu signed an agreement with the FLC on 21 March 2001. This agreement was endorsed by the Brigade Raisonneur Lafontaine of the Mayi Mayi, while the agreement also had the buy-in of Brigade Karisimbi represented by Kambale Maghulu, Brigade Rwenzori by Kiyungu, Brigade Vurondo by Kambale Tsongo, Brigade Rwenzori/Lubwe by Lakule Vulendi, and Brigade Mabanga by Sadamu Mindul. The Ugandan army, religious leaders, traditional chiefs, and civil society representatives witnessed the signing of the agreement. The agreement provided for an extension of the FLC�s area of control to cover North Kivu areas occupied by the Mayi-Mayi, where some Mayi Mayi groups had been fighting against the presence of the Ugandan army. In a letter dated on 23 March 2001 addressed to the UN Special Representative, Bemba spoke of an agreement that Mayi Mayi groups in North Kivu had allied themselves to FLC and would be forming a �Division speciale Mayi-Mayi� within the military forces of FLC. The March agreement also pointed out that, since it was difficult to know who was genuinely Mayi Mayi because the militia has a loose structure, it was a collective responsibility of all signatories to help make clear who committed to the newly concluded agreement. However, the agreement did not hold. However, on 25 April 2001, FLC clashed with Mayi Mayi warriors in Butembo. In June 2001, the FLC alliance broke down.

On 27 May 2012, the leaders of both sides tried to reconcile their differences through bilateral negotiations. This led to the conclusion of an agreement in late May 2012. Both groups agreed to merge and create the independent Islamic state of Azawad. CMA spokesman Moussa ag Assarid said the alliance marked a compromise. The conflict parties agreed to an Islamic state but one developed by their own imams and suited to local religious practices. However, the agreement broke down almost immediately and Ansar Dine turned again to their Islamist allies. In the summer of 2012, Ansar Dine allied with al-Qaida al-Jihad fi Bilad al-Maghrib al-Islami (AQIM) (English: al-Qaida Organisation in the Islamic Maghreb) against the CMA and captured the regional capitals of Kidal, Timbuktu, and Gao, destroying many Sufi shrines and enforcing sharia law.

On 21 December 2012, Ansar Dine and CMA agreed to a seven-point ceasefire agreement in Algiers. Representatives of Algeria and Burkina Faso mediated these negotiations in Algiers. On 15 November 2015, the leader of Ansar Dine, Iyad Ag Ghali, rejected the peace agreement that the CMA and the Government of Mali had signed on 20 June 2015. Ghaly called on the various militant groups to derail the peace agreement. Following an attack on the Radisson Blu Hotel that would host peace talks between the Government of Mali and the CMA, a representative of the CMA, Sidi Brahim Ould Sidati, stated: �The Jihadis are in different groups but their goal is the same, and that�s to hinder implementation of the peace accord.� Ansar Dine led another attack against a CMA location in December 2015, publicly justifying its attack by saying that the CMA works for the French military.

Mohammed Abubakar, the Inspector General of Police, mediated between the conflict parties in a peace meeting in Kaduna State in April 2014. The meeting brought together leaders of both conflict parties, as well as representatives of the Southern Kaduna Peoples Union (SOKAPU), leaders of the Miyetti Allah Cattle Breeders Association of Nigeria (MACBAN), the Mogbai Fulani Development Association, and the Atakar Community Development Association. The peace talks led to the signing of a peace agreement.

After clashes broke out again in 2017, the Global Peace Foundation (GPF) convened the Southern Kaduna Peace and Reconciliation Meeting for Southern Kaduna representatives on 13 July 2017 in Afachan. Leaders of several different associations such as the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN) and Jama�atu Nasril Islam (JNI), as well as representatives from different chiefdoms and communities in Southern Kaduna, participated in the meeting. The Atakar and Fulani also participated. The stakeholders present at the meeting promised to embrace peace and forgive each other. No written agreement was signed, but all parties encouraged the GPF to continue its peace efforts.

Tiv, Fulani, Jukun and Hausa leaders from Wukari, Ibi, Donga, and Takum enagaged in peace talks, mediated by Deputy Inspector General of Police Michael Zuokumor, in Jalingo in Taraba State on 5 April 2014. These peace talks led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement that appealed for peace between the four communities.

In June 2016, Hausa and Jukun representatives began to participate in an inter-community dialogue process mediated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, along with several other community representatives from South Plateau. This led to the signing of the South Plateau Peace Declaration on 22 December 2016.

On 26 March 2020, a joint communique was issued by the chairs of ten communities involved in the mediation process facilitated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) in Benue State. The communities included Agatu, Etulo, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Igede, Jukun, Tiv, and Yoruba ethnic groups. The communique focused on upholding peaceful co-existence during and after the COVID-19 pandemic.
The Governors of Nasarawa State and Benue State convened a peace meeting between the Tiv, Fulani, Idoma, Alago, Migli, and Agatu at the government house in Lafia on 11 July 2013.

A second peace meeting involving the Tiv, Fulani, Idoma, Alago, Migli, and Agatu, mediated by the Governors of Nasarawa State and Benue State, was held in Lafia in early August 2013. The conflict parties agreed on the need to investigate the crisis and work towards a cessation of hostilities, but did not conclude a peace agreement. Violence resumed soon after this round of peace talks.

Deputy Inspector General of Police, Mr. Michael Zoukomo, mediated a round of negotiations between Tiv, Fulani, and Agatu leaders at the government house in Makurdi in Benue State on 31 March 2014. This led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement. However, armed fighting already resumed one week later.

On 26 March 2020, a joint communique was issued by the chairs of ten communities involved in the mediation process facilitated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) in Benue State. The communities included Agatu, Etulo, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Igede, Jukun, Tiv, and Yoruba ethnic groups. The communique focused on upholding peaceful co-existence during and after the COVID-19 pandemic.
Between September to November 2014, several attempts were undertaken to reconcile the Bosco and Makenga factions within the M23.

In early July 2015, Hezbollah and the Syrian army launched an offensive against the rebel-held town of Zabadani, located 10 km from the Lebanese border. The pro-Syrian forces fought against an insurgent alliance that included the Sunni Islamist Ahrar al-Sham and the al Qaeda-linked al-Nusra Front, which put pressure on Hezbollah and the Syrian Government by attacking Kefraya and Fouah, the only remaining government-held villages in Idlib province. On 11 August 2015, both sides agreed to a ceasefire mediated by Turkey and Iran. These mediators had a stake in the conflict, as Turkey supported the rebels and Iran supported the Syrian government. The 48-hour ceasefire was set to take effect the following day in the rebel-held town of Zabadani and the two Shi�ite Muslim villages in Idlib province. Ahrar al-Sham represented the rebel alliance during the talks.

On 13 August 2015, the two coalitions agreed to prolong the truce until 15 August 2015, but the negotiators failed to reach a broader deal. The goal of the truce was to facilitate the withdrawal of rebel fighters from Zabadani and the evacuation of civilians from the two Shi�ite villages in Idlib province.
On 26 August 2015, Syria�s Tadamun (English: Solidarity) Party mediated between the conflict parties in Zabadani and the two towns of Idlib province to re-establish a ceasefire in these areas.

On 26 August 2015, the Syrian government backed by Hezbollah and the rebel alliance including the al-Nusra Front agreed to another 48-hour ceasefire in the town of Zabadani and in two Shi�ite villages of Idlib province following negotiations led by Iranian and Turkish mediators. The truce began on 28 August after disagreement between the Syrian government and Hezbollah. The ceasefire aimed at allowing access of humanitarian aid to the residents of the two Muslim towns of Idlib province, allowing rebels to evacuate wounded combatants from Zabadani, and encouraging peace talks between the warring parties to achieve a permanent ceasefire. However, the ceasefire collapsed on 29 August 2015 with clashes resuming in the concerned areas.

On 20 September 2015, rebels and pro-Syrian forces agreed on a draft 25-point agreement that included an immediate truce. The talks were held in Turkey, with Iran representing the Syrian government and Hezbollah. Accordingly, Iran cannot be seen as a mediator during this round of talks.

On 24 September 2015, under the auspices of the United Nations, Iran and Turkey mediated talks between insurgents and pro-Syrian fighters that resulted in the agreement of a six-month truce. The deal included the evacuation of armed and wounded persons from Zabadani to Idlib province in exchange for the evacuation of civilians from the villages of Al-Fou�aa and Kafraya to zones controlled by the regime. This resulted after �weeks� of talks held in Turkey. Trucks loaded with humanitarian aid entered the besieged towns one month later. Yet, in May 2016, the agreement began to break down amidst increasing level of violence.
In July 2017, Ahmad al-Fliti, former deputy mayor of Arsal, mediated between Jabhat Fateh al-Sham and Hezbollah. However, he succumbed to his wounds after his car was shelled on 22 July 2017.

On 27 July 2017, Jabhat Fateh al-Sham militants raised the white flag and negotiated a ceasefire agreement with Hezbollah. This ceasefire was mediated by Lebanese General Security Director, Major-General Abbas Ibrahim. The deal called for a cessation of hostilities and the return of captured Hezbollah fighters in exchange for allowing the militants and their families to leave Lebanon for Idlib in Syria.
third_party: Lebanese General Security Director, Major General Abbas Ibrahim

description: The Nasarawa state government mediated between the Fulani and Agatu representatives to find a solution to the crisis on 2 February 2013. This mediation effort did not result in an agreement.

In another mediation attempt to end the crisis, the Governors of Nasarawa State and Benue State convened a peace meeting between the Tiv, Fulani, Idoma, Alago, Migli, and Agatu at the government house in Lafia on 11 July 2013.

A second peace meeting involving the Tiv, Fulani, Idoma, Alago, Migli, and Agatu, mediated by the the Governors of Nasarawa State and Benue State, was held in Lafia in early August 2013. The conflict parties agreed on the need to investigate the crisis and work towards a cessation of hostilities, but did not conclude a peace agreement. Violence resumed soon after this round of peace talks.

Deputy Inspector General of Police, Mr. Michael Zoukomo, mediated a round of negotiations between Tiv, Fulani, and Agatu leaders at the government house in Makurdi in Benue State on 31 March 2014. This led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement. However, armed fighting already resumed one week later.

The Governors of Benue State and Nasarawa State, Samuel Ortom and Tanko Al-Makura respectively, mediated peace talks between Agatu and Fulani leaders at the government headquarters in Makurdi in Benue State in January 2016. The two-day peace meeting led to an agreement on grazing rights in Agatu ahead of the harvest season in February and gave the Fulani permission to let their cattle graze on Agatu land. Both sides also agreed stop fighting and forgive the other side. However, new clashes broke out between Agatu farmers and Fulani herders along the Benue River in early February 2016. In response to these clashes, Bishop Benson Abounu, on request by Benue State Governor Samuel Ortom, met with Agatu traditional leaders in Agatu in February 2016, who expressed their renewed committment to peace with the Fulani. In a separate statement, Alhaji Mohammed Useni, president of MACBAN in Nasarawa State, representing Fulani herders, encouraged his people to embrace peace.

The Idoma Initiative and the Miyetti Allah Cattle Breeders Association of Nigeria (MACBAN), representing the Agatu and Fulani communities respectively, engaged in peace talks in Abuja on 29 March 2016. The Idoma community of Agatu is a group of prominent Agatu farmers. The negotiations led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement. In addition, the Fulani herders guaranteed that they would withdraw their cattle from the Agatu area, while Agatu youths would stop patrolling along the river.

Negotiations between the Agatu people in Benue State and Fulani herders in Nasarawa State, mediated by local authorities, led to the conclusion of an agreement to ensure peaceful coexistence on 6 January 2017. The agreement stipulates that both communities have the right to access to land and ensures that the two groups do not carry arms and do not send armed groups to contested land.

The Governors of Benue State and Nasarawa State mediated a two-day peace meeing between traditional rulers of the Agatu and Fulani on 18 and 19 January 2017. The meeting led to the signing of a peace agreement that granted the Fulani to use part of Agatu�s land for herding their cattle.

On 15 August 2019, after a year of shuttle diplomacy and pre-mediation meetings, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) launched the Benue Mediation Process to find a lasting solution to the farmer-herder conflicts in the region. The meeting took place at the Benue Hotel in Makurdi and brought together representatives of the Agatu, Etulo, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Egede, Jukun, Tiv, and Yoruba communities of Benue State. On this occasion, HD pledged to help the communities achieve lasting peace, while the attending communities pledged to support and actively participate in the mediation process. During this first meeting, it was announced that the mediation process would take place in a joint meeting between tribes from the same senatorial zones.

HD convened a peace meeting with representatives of the Tiv, Idoma, Igede, Agatu, Etulo, Jukun, Fulani, Igbo, Yoruba, Hausa communities in Makurdi in Benue State in early November 2019. Traditional leaders, religious leaders, civil society groups, and security agencies, and state officials were also involved in the peace meeting. This meeting was part of the ongoing mediation dialogue between the conflict parties in the region. Stakeholders stressed the need for peace, but no written agreement resulted from the meeting.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), traditional leaders, religious leaders, government forces, local government

description: On 26 March 2020, a joint communique was issued by the chairs of ten communities involved in the mediation process facilitated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) in Benue State. The communities included Agatu, Etulo, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Igede, Jukun, Tiv, and Yoruba ethnic groups. The communique focused on upholding peaceful co-existence during and after the COVID-19 pandemic.

In June 2014, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) initiated the first peace initiative following the crisis in 2013. A discussion on possible mechanisms to resolve the armed conflict at a workshop that brought together 30 Central African participants from varying backgrounds � including representatives from government, anti-Balaka, and ex-Seleka � led to the idea of organizing a forum. Furthermore, on the sidelines of the 23rd Ordinary Summit of the African Union in Malabo, Equatorial Guinea, in June 2014, the leaders of the Economic Community of Central African States (ECCAS) agreed to organize a ceasefire conference in Brazzaville in July 2014. The leaders also agreed to organizing popular consultations and to implement the idea of the HD workshop to organize a forum, which would later lead to the Bangui National Forum.

Congolese President Sassou Nguesso, in his capacity as the ECCAS chief mediator, mediated the ceasefire negotiations between the anti-Balaka and the FPRC � as well as several other armed groups, though not the UPC led by Ali Darassa � in Brazzaville in late July 2014. The Government of the Central African Republic was also involved in the negotiations. These negotiations led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement on 23 July 2014. This ceasefire agreement is referred to as the Accord de cessation des hostilit�s en R�publique Centrafricaine (Brazzaville Agreement on Cessation of Hostilities). However, clashes continued between the conflict parties.
agreement_name: Accord de cessation des hostilit�s en R�publique Centrafricaine (Brazzaville Agreement on Cessation of Hostilities)

description: Sassou Nguesso resumed another round of negotiations with the FPRC and anti-Balaka in Nairobi in December 2014. Kenya acted as the mediator at these negotiations.

Negotiations mediated by Kenya that had started in Nairobi in December 2014 continued in January 2015. This round of negotiations led to the signing of an agreement between the FPRC and the anti-Balaka on 22 January 2015. The FPRC and anti-Balaka negotiators present at this round of negotiations were referred to as the �Nairobists�, they included Micheal Djotodia, Nouredine Adam and their top commanders, as well as the Francois Boziz� and his son, Jean-Francis Boziz�, Maxime Mokom, and Joachim Kokat�.

Negotiations mediated by Kenya resumed in Nairobi in April 2015. This led to the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on Ceasefire and Cessation of Hostilities, as well as the Nairobi Engagement Declaration Adherence to the Transition Roadmap in Central African Republic on 8 April 2015. Joachim Kokate signed the agreement on behalf of the anti-Balaka and ex-president Michel Djotodia signed on behalf of the ex-Seleka. The government of Interim President Samba-Panza rejected the ceasefires concluded in January and April 2015, claiming it had not been involved in the talks mediated by the Kenyan government in Nairobi.
agreement_name: Nairobi Agreement on Ceasefire and Cessation of Hostilities, Nairobi Engagement Declaration Adherence to the Transition Roadmap in Central African Republic

description: Nevertheless, building on these ceasefire negotiations, the mediation effort in Nairobi was subsequently replaced by the Bangui Forum. The United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (MINUSCA) provided political and logistical support to Bangui Forum. Abdoulaye Bathily, the UN Special Representative for Central Africa, chaired the Forum. Special Representatives were also sent by the African Union and the Republic of Congo to support the negotiations. Technical support and expertise was given to the mediations by HD and the EU. Around 600 representatives from the Central African Republic participated. The Bangui Forum was held between 4 and 11 May 2015 and led to the conclusion of two negotiated settlements. First, the parties concluded the Agreement between the Transitional Government and the armed groups on the principles of disarmament, demobilization, reintegration and repatriation and of integration into the uniformed State forces of the Central African Republic on 10 May 2015. This agreement included provisions on a ceasefire, as well as on the disarmament, demobilizaition, and reintegration for all the armed groups that signed the agreement, including the Front populaire pour la renaissance de la Centrafrique, Rassemblement patriotique pour le renouveau de la Centrafrique, Union des forces r�publicaines fondamentales, Seleka r�nov�e, Mouvement des lib�rateurs centrafricains pour la justice, Front d�mocratique pour le progr�s de la Centrafrique, Coordination des ex-combattants anti-Balaka, Unit� du peuple centrafricain, R�volution et justice, and the Union des forces r�publicaines.
third_party: government, MINUSCA, Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), EU
agreement_name: Agreement between the Transitional Government and the armed groups on the principles of disarmament, demobilization, reintegration and repatriation and of integration into the uniformed State forces of the Central African Republic, Republican Pact

description: Second, the Bangui Forum resulted in the conclusion of the Republican Pact � or in full the Pacte r�publicain pour la paix, la reconciliation, et la reconstruction en R�publique centrafricaine � which, among others, established a local and national mechanism for reconciliation. This agreement was signed by nine out of the ten armed groups operating in CAR. In addition to the ECCAS-led mediation effort and the mediation effort as part of the Bangui Forum, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) mediated a unilateral ceasefire agreement with the FPRC in N�Djamena on 20 December 2015. Cheikh Tidiane Gadio acted as the chief mediator of the OIC. Noureddine Adam promised to refrain from seeking independence from the Central African Republic issued a unilateral ceasefire and stated that the ceasefire would make it possible to hold elections. Legislative and presidential elections were held without significant armed fighting in late 2015.
third_party: government, MINUSCA, Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), EU

description: A local peace process in Batangafo, with support from the Bossangoa field office of MINUSCA, led to the conclusion of a weapon-free zone agreement in December 2015.

In February 2016, the AU mandated Mohamed El Hacen Lebatt as its special representative. Lebatt launched what was referred to as the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation. Angola, Chad, the DRC, and ECCAS supported this AU-led mediation effort. Talks mediated by Lebatt in February 2016 did not lead to an agreement. In addition, some local peace processes between the anti-Balaka and the FPRC took place in 2016.
third_party: AU, Angola, Chad, Democratic Republic of Congo, ECCAS

description: Building on the weapon-free zone agreement that had been concluded in Batangafo in December 2015, MINUSCA mediated a non-aggression pact between the anti-Balaka and the ex-S�l�ka, including the FPRC and MPC, in Batangafo on 29 March 2016.

Another local peace process took place in the Mbr�s sub-prefecture. The MINUSCA field office in Kaga-Bandoro � with the involvement of the Local Peace and Reconciliation Committee (CLPR), religious leaders, and local authorities � mediated between the anti-Balaka on the one hand and the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the other hand in the Mbr�s area. This led to the signing of a non-aggression pact on 8 June 2016.
third_party: MINUSCA, religious leaders, local government, local peace committee

description: In late 2016, a country-wide peace effort took place again. Angola, which had been mandated by the International Conference on the Great Lakes region, mediated between the transitional government and several armed groups � including the anti-Balaka, the FPRC, and the MPC - in Luanda in December 2016. Andr� de Oliveira Jo�o Sango, director general of the secret services, acted as the chief mediator. The Angolan mediators proposed a general amnesty, which was widely condemned in Bangui. The negotiations in Luanda ended without an agreement.
third_party: Angola, International Conference on the Great Lakes Region

description: A local peace initiative took place in the Ouham prefecture in 2017. Local state officials in Ouham prefecture engaged in shuttle diplomacy between the anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka leaders in Kouki and Nana-Bakassa between January and June 2017. The local peace committee and the bishop of Bossangoa were also involved in this peace effort. This paved the way for a few rounds of face-to-face negotiations in June 2017, alternating between Kouki and Nana-Bakassa. MINUSCA facilitated these negotiations in June. The head of MINUSCA�s Bossangoa office and the prefect of Ouham acted as the chairs of the negotiations. The negotiations led to the signing of the Acte d�engagement de non-violence et de paix (English: Act of Commitment to Nonviolence and Peace) on 15 June 2017.
third_party: local government, local peace committee, religious leaders, MINUSCA
agreement_name: Acte d�engagement de non-violence et de paix

description: In March 2017, the Community of Sant�Egidio started a mediation process, with Andrea Riccardi acting as the chief mediator. UN envoy Parfait Onanga-Anyanga, the European Union, and the Italian Government had an observer status during the negotiations. With peace talks ongoing in Rome, FPRC fighters launched an offensive against anti-Balaka elements in Bakouma on 6 June 2017, following an anti-Balaka attack on Nzako. This persuaded the conflict parties at the negotiations to sign a peace agreement on 19 June 2017, stipulating an immediate ceasefire. This agreement, referred to as the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic, was signed by the RPRC, FPRC, FDPC, UPC, RPRC, RJ BELANGA, UFR-F, UPC, RJ SAYO, UFR-F, FPRC, UFR, RJ SAYO, MPC, SELEKA Renovee, Coordination anti-Balaka, anti-Balaka Mokom, MLJC, RJ Belanga, FDPC, MLJC, and the UFR. The agreement reaffirmed the 2016 elections. In addition, the agreement called for the integration of all �politico-military groups� into the peace process and a restoration of state authority. The agreement also included an immediate countrywide ceasefire. The ceasefire did not hold. Armed clashes between several armed groups already took place in the Bria area already one day after the signing of the ceasefire.
third_party: Community of Sant�Egidio, UN, EU, Italy
agreement_name: Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic

description: On 28 June, President Faustin Archange Touad�ra held meetings with the representatives of the 14 armed groups that had signed a peace agreement in Rome on 19 June 2017.

With it being clear that the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic of June 2017 did not succeed, the AU presented its roadmap for peace in Libreville on 17 July 2017. The roadmap agreement assigns the responsibility for leading peace negotiations in CAR to the AU, while pledging to take into account the achievements of previous peace initiatives including the June 2017 Sant�Egidio Agreement. The Roadmap created an African Panel of Facilitators, with panel members from the AU, ECCAS, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, Angola, Chad, the Republic of Congo, and Gabon. MINUSCA was granted observer status. The African Panel of Facilitators mediated for the first time Bangui between 11 and 12 September 2017.
third_party: African Panel of Facilitators, AU, ECCAS, International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, Angola, Chad, Congo, Gabon, MINUSCA

description: A local mediation effort between the FPRC and the anti-Balaka led by the prefect of Haute-Kotto, with MINUSCA support, resulted in the conclusion of the feuille de route pour la Paix � Bria (English: Roadmap for Peace in Bria) on 19 December 2017. The agreement stipulates a cessation of hostilities and commits the parties to refrain from impeding the restoration of the state�s authority. Zakaria Damane, the leader of the Rassemblement Patriotique pour le Renouveau de la Centrafrique (RPRC) (English: Assembly for the Renaissance of Central Africa), signed the agreement. The RPRC separated from the FPRC in November 2014 but joined forces with the FPRC in October 2015 to combat the Union for Peace in the Central African Republic (UPC). Consequently, Zakaria Damane signed the agreement representing both the RPRC and the FPRC.
agreement_name: Feuille de route pour la Paix � Bria

description: Another local peace process took place in early 2018. Mediation by local authorities and MINUSCA led to the conclusion of the Accord entre les Groupes Arm�s de Batangafo on 24 February 2018. The signatories were the anti-Balaka and the ex-S�l�ka, including the FPRC and MPC.
agreement_name: Accord entre les Groupes Arm�s de Batangafo

description: The conflict parties also participated in the national-level peace process in 2018. On 28 August 2018, Russia � which had begun supplying the CAR government with arms and military instructors in February 2018 � and Sudan mediated negotiations between the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the one side and the anti-Balaka (represented by Maxime Mokom) on the other side. These negotiations led to the signing of declaration of understanding and a pledge to support the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation in CAR led by the AU and regional states with the support of the UN. The UPC and MPC expressed they were no longer committed to this declaration in October 2018, but they made it clear that they still supported the African Initiative. Furthermore, the AU, with support from MINUSCA, organized a meeting between 14 armed groups in Bouar between 28 and 30 August 2018. The meeting produced a document with demands to the government, signed by all 14 groups that participated in the meeting. The document was handed over to the government following the meeting.

Mediation by local authorities and MINUSCA led to the conclusion of the Accord entre les Groupes Arm�s de Batangafo on 12 January 2019. An agreement with exactly the same name had been signed in February 2018. The second agreement, signed in January 2019, was prompted by the failure of the February 2018 accord following violent incidents in late October 2018. The parties involved in the initial accord � the anti-Balaka and the ex-S�l�ka, including the FPRC and MPC � also signed this subsequent agreement, which encompasses the same provisions. However, notable additions were made, as the new agreement received endorsements from local authorities and representatives of civil society.
third_party: local government, MINUSCA, civil society leaders
agreement_name: Accord entre les Groupes Arm�s de Batangafo

description: Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Nga�ssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, S�l�ka R�nov�e, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) and MINUSCA, with support from local officials and traditional and religious leaders, mediated a round of negotiations between the UPC, MPC, RPRC, MLJC, anti-Balaka-Molokom, and FPRC in Bria from 1 to 9 April 2019. This led to the signing of the Bria Accord on 9 April 2019. This local agreement was aimed at reinforcing the implementation of the 6 February 2019 national agreement. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire to end to the violence in Haute-Kotto and Ouaka prefectures, as well as guaranteed the safe and free movement of persons, goods, and humanitarian aid on the main axis.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), MINUSCA, local government, traditional leaders, religious leaders

description: Local authorities and a council of elders immediately initiated a mediation effort in response to the violence, with support from UNAMID. This led to the signing of a ceasefire on 11 January 2013. However, fighting continued.

On 13 and 14 January, UNAMID transported state government officials to the towns of El Sireaf and Saraf Umra to mediate between the conflict parties. The peace talks in Saraf Umra, mediated by the Governor of Northern Darfur with support from UNAMID, led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement on 17 January, which stipulated an end to the fighting, the stop of mining activities in Jebel Amir until the dispute would be resolved, and the participation in another reconciliation conference.
A similar agreement was signed on the same day in Um Dukhun, between members of the Beni Hussein and Reizegat Abbala who had participated in the fighting when it spread to that area.

Sporadic, small-scale clashes between the militias continued, but heavy fighting broke out again on 21 February. On 1 March, representatives of the Aballa and Beni Hussein militias held a second reconciliation conference in Saraf Umra, again chaired by the Governor of Northern Darfur with support from UNAMID. That conference concluded again with a ceasefire agreement, stipulating and end to the hostilities and a withdrawal of roadblocks on the road between El Sireaf and Saraf Umra.
On 17 June 2013, the administrations of the Beni Hussein and the Abbala tribes met to discuss a possible ceasefire between the two tribes, but the meeting was unsuccessful.

Another round of negotiations led to the conclusion of an agreement on 25 July 2013. This agreement not only stipulated a ceasefire, it also stipulated the free movement of people, vehicles, cattle, and goods to the market. In addition, government forces were to take control of the mining area. The agreement stipulated the creation of a compensation fund financed with gold revenues to pay blood money for each victim of the conflict. The governor of North Darfur announced on 6 August 2013 that government troops would soon be deployed to the El Sareif locality to monitor the agreement between the conflict parties.

The Civil Affairs section of UNAMID facilitated a peace conference between the Beni Hussein and Reizegat Abbala between 5 and 7 June 2014. The conference, which was attended by more than 250 representatives, was aimed at addressing outstanding issues between the two tribes and diffuse tensions in the area. A government delegation and sheikh Musa Hilal initiated the meeting. The conference ended with a renewal of the ceasefire, the establishment of committees to strengthen existing reconciliation mechanisms, and a resolution on pending issues, and agreement to re-open the roads leading to El Serief. In addition, the conference led to release of seven Beni Hussein tribesmen on 7 June, who had been abducted by members of the Rizeigat tribe on 26 May 2014.

side_b: Awlad Metanin clan (Misseriya), Awlad Serur clan (Misseriya)
description: In response to the armed conflict a reconciliation conference between the three tribes was held. Minister of Decentralized Government Hasbu Muhammad Abd al-Rahman acted as the mediator at this conference. The conference ended with the signing of a peace agreement on 1 March 2013, the Final Communique of the Reconciliation Conference between the Misseriyya Tribes. The agreement specified the payment of blood money, as well as outlined punishments for transgressing the agreement and a mechanism for re-negotiation.
agreement_name: Final Communique of the Reconciliation Conference between the Misseriyya Tribes

description: The United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) undertook a reconciliation effort in response to the armed clash of February 2018.

A clash resulting in three Misseriya killed by the Nuer in the Marial Achak area on 11 May 2018 prompted the Abyei joint peace committee to invite representatives of the Nuer to attend one of their meetings on 17 May 2018.

On 16 March 2013, the leaders of the two tribes signed a ceasefire agreement at the house of the local commissioner. According to this agreement, the Gimr had to pay blood money to the Beni Halba for the four losses it suffered. The ceasefire was mediated by the governor of South Darfur Hammad Ismail Hammad and the locality�s �committee for goodwill�, with support from UNAMID. In addition to a commitment to �put an end to tribal gatherings, escalations of incidents and all forms of violence�, the conflict parties agreed to hold a reconciliation conference in April 2013. However, armed fighting continued.
third_party: local government, local peace committee, UNAMID

description: The governor of South Darfur, with support from UNAMID, therefore resumed its mediation effort in Nyala in early May 2013. This led to another ceasefire agreement on 4 May 2013. Yet, fighting continued.
third_party: local government, local peace committee, UNAMID

description: Negotiations continued in Nyala in June, but these negotiations broke down in June, with the Gimir leaders stating their unwillingness to continue to participate in any reconciliation initiatives because they lacked confidence in the neutrality of State authorities to mediate the dispute.

Heavy fighting erupted again in March 2014, so UNAMID initiated a mediation effort between the conflict parties. UNAMID staff, together with a leader from the Tama tribe, mediated between Beni Halba Baggara and Gimir representatives at UNAMID�s base in Saraf Omra on 12 March 2014. This led to the conclusion of a reconciliation agreement, stipulating a ceasefire. The signing ceremony was attended by 50 members from each of the communities.

The Nazirs (the native leaders of the tribes) signed a ceasefire in Umm Dukhun on 11 April 2013. This ceasefire stipulated the dismantling of soldiers� camps, the return of displaced to their villages, and the demilitarization of civilians. Local authorities mediated this ceasefire.

The conflict parties started an ajaweed reconciliation conference in early June 2013. UNAMID supported this reconciliation conference. The conference ended with the signing of a peace agreement. However, this agreement did not hold. However, this agreement did not hold.
Another ceasefire was reached on 31 July 2013.

On 13 September 2013, leaders of the Salamat and Misseriya tribes agree to open the roads linking Um Dukhun, Bindisi, Abugaradil, Nyala, Zalingei, and Foro Baranga, as well as to encourage the displaced people to return voluntarily to their areas.

UNAMID Civil Affairs facilitated the travel of the Governor of Central Darfur and the State Security Committee, accompanied by a team of UNAMID mediators, to Um Dukhun on 17 November 2013 to mediate between the two tribes. The mediation effort succeeded confirming the conflict parties� commitment to the peace agreement signed on 3 July 2013 and the conflict parties once more agreed on a cessation of hostilities.

On 16 June 2014, the Central Darfur governor dismissed leaders of the Salamat and Misseriya tribes from their administrative positions, claiming that they had put insufficient effort in trying to mediate between the conflict parties. Negotiations with support from UNAMID led to the signing of a ceasefire in Um in September 2014.
In response to renewed armed clashes between the Misseriya and the Salamat Baggara in July 2016, the reconciliation committee in Lagawa unsuccessfully tried to mediate between the conflict parties.

Following heavy clashes between the Misseriya and the Salamat Baggara in May 2017, UNAMID and Sudanese authorities mediated between the conflict parties. This led to the signing of a ceasefire on 27 May 2017. This ceasefire did not hold. Salamat tribesmen attacked the Misseriya in the Sure area on June 12, killing one Misseriya.

In collaboration with Sudanese authorities, UNAMID mediated between the conflict parties on 6, 12 and 28 June, with the goal to make them implement the ceasefire. These meetings were not successful. On 21 August, another two clashes took place in Um Dukhun, resulting in the death of two people.
Fighting ended following the deployment of government forces and negotiations between tribal leaders from both tribes, with mediation by local authorities. However, tensions remained high.
