Fighting resumed in March 2014. Following another armed clash on 24 May, local leaders mediated between the conflict parties. This initially stopped the fighting, but later on the day Hamar fighters attacked and burned a Ma�aliyah village, which re-started fighting between the conflict parties.
Direct negotiations between the leaders of the Hamar and the Ma�aliyah continued throughout July and August, but without any results.
On 27 September 2014, leaders of the Hamar and Ma�aliyah tribes signed a reconciliation agreement in El Fula, West Kordofan. UNAMID supported this peace meeting.

On 2 September 2014, the Governor of Nasarawa State, Tanko Al-Makura, mediated between the leaders of the conflict parties at the state house in Lafia. The conflict parties did not sign a peace agreement. The meeting only resulted in an eleven-point communiqu� guaranteeing the government�s support in resolving the crisis.

Joseph Haruna Kigbu � a member of the House of Representatives � mediated a round of negotiations between the Fulani and Eggon representatives in Lafia on 27 and 28 December 2014, which led to the conclusion of a peace agreement.

On 8 October 2017, the NGO Search for Common Ground mediated a peace meeting between representatives of several ethnic groups � including the Fulani, Tiv, Alago, Eggon, Mada, and Migili � in the Doma Local Government Area in Nasarawa State. The mediation effort did not lead to an agreement.

In 2007, the two communities clashed violently following the conflict that had already erupted in July 2006 on the borders of Benue and Taraba States. The Governor of Benue State, together with his Taraba counterpart, mediated between the leaders of the two communities in August 2007. Chief Thomas Degaa, representing the Tiv of Benue State, and Bawa Buki, speaking on behalf of the Kuteb people of Taraba State, condemned the crisis and pledged to end the violence.

The conflict flared up again in May 2015, resulting in more than 70 deaths in Takum town in Taraba State. In September 2015, Reverend Risae Yakubu Shamaki, in collaboration with other churches, chaired a peace and reconciliation meeting at the Secretariat of the Reformed Church of Christ for the Nations (RCCN) in Takum. During this peace meeting, the Governor of Taraba State, Darius Ishaku, appealed to the two communities stop fighting. The conflict parties vowed to do so, though no written agreement was signed.
In June 2017, the governor of Taraba State convened a peace meeting between Tiv, Junkun, Kuteb and Miyeti Allah leaders in Jalingo in Taraba State. The meeting did not result in a peace agreement.

In late 2016, a peace committee made up of neighbouring tribes � the Warfalla Bani Wali, Zintan, Tarhuna, Barqah � mediated negotiations in Sabha between the Awlad Suleiman and Qadhadhfa. This led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 25 November.

Another round of peace talks mediated by the peace committee led to the Agreement on Peaceful Coexistence Between the Tribes of Qadhadhfa and Awlad Suleiman on 4 December 2016. However, fighting would reignite in late December.
agreement_name: Agreement on Peaceful Coexistence Between the Tribes of Qadhadhfa and Awlad Suleiman

description: The United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) mediated negotiations between the Awlad Suleiman and Qadhahdfa in Malta from 24 to 26 May 2017.

On 6 November 2017, a follow-up round of dialogue for women-only, supported by UNSMIL, took place in Tripoli. Tribal representatives from the cities of Kabaw and Batin al-Jabal agreed on 26 November to establish an independent committee for an investigation of the conflict between the Awlad Suleiman and Qadhadhfa.

Burkina Faso�s president Blaise Compaor� mediated a round of negotiations between the CMA and the MAA in Ougadougou in June 2013. Yet, on 15 and 19 July 2013, clashes between MAA and CMA took place again, this time in Lerneb.

Between 6 and 11 August 2013, the Government of Mauritania mediated negotiations between CMA and MAA leaders in Nouakchott, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire and a joint statement on 9 August 2013, calling for collaboration among them to ensure the security of the northern regions.

On 3 September 2013, the MAA and CMA held their first meeting at the military level. Officers of the two groups met for bilateral negotiations on a neutral ground at Mishra, which was located in between their bases in the far north-eastern part of the country. The discussions centered on the implementation of the Nouakchott Agreement and an end to hostilities. The negotiation teams agreed to set up a permanent coordination mechanism between the heads of the Inhalil and Infara bases in order to guarantee security in the areas and avoid new clashes.

The CMA entered into a peace process with the Government of Mali in mid-2014. This peace process, which would become known as the Algiers peace process, was supported by a mediation team led by Algeria, including the UN, ECOWAS, the AU, the OIC, the EU, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, and Chad. The first round of official negotiations in the Algiers peace process took place from 14 to 24 July 2014 in Algiers. The Platform alliance � of which the CM-FPR, GATIA, MAA were members � took also part in the Algiers peace process, but the CMA and Platform refused to sit at the same table of negotiations. Talks took place on parallel tracks between the government and the CMA on the one side, and the government and the Platform on the other. The CMA refused to negotiate with the Platform because it saw the alliance as a �government militia,� thereby challenging its legitimacy as a full stakeholder in the process. However, CMA and the Platform alliance met in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, from 25 to 28 August 2014. These talks were mediated by Burkina Faso, whose president was the ECOWAS mediator in the Malian crisis, with support from the UN and the AU. This round of negotiations took place in between the first round of the Algiers process in July 2014 and the second round of negotiations that was planned to be held in Algiers in September 2014. After four days of discussions, the talks in Ouagadougou led to the D�claration finale on 28 August 2014. This peace agreement stipulates a ceasefire, but also describes how the CMA and Platform position themselves in talks with the Government of Mali.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: While the CMA and Platform were not engaged in direct negotiations during most of the Algiers process, this changed during the final phase of the process. The Government of Mali, the CMA, and Platform entered negotiations in Algiers on 30 May 2015. They signed the Relev� de Conclusions des Consultations Pr�paratoires � la mise en �uvre de l�Accord pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali Issu du Procesus d�Alger (English: Statement of Conclusions of the Preparatory Consultations for the Implementation of the Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation in Mali Arising from the Algiers Process) on 5 June 2015, which addressed the creation of two regions in Mali, the integration of rebel fighters into the national army, and several arrangements to promote regional economic development. On the same day, the conflict parties also signed another ceasefire agreement, the Arrangement s�curitaire pour une cessation des hostilit�s (English: Security Arrangements for a Cessation of Hostilities).
agreement_name: Relev� de Conclusions des Consultations Pr�paratoires � la mise en �uvre de l�Accord pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali Issu du Procesus d�Alger, Arrangement s�curitaire pour une cessation des hostilit�s

description: This paved the way for the Government of Mali, the CMA, and Platform signing a comprehensive peace agreement in Bamako on 20 June 2015: the Accord Pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali � Issu du Processus d�Alger (English: Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation in Mali � Resulting from the Algiers Process), also referred to as the Bamako Agreement.
agreement_name: Accord Pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali - Issu du Processus d�Alger

description: Another round of negotiations between the members of the monitoring committee � the Comit� du Suivi du present Accord (CSA) � was held in late July 2015 to discuss the implementation process, but the members of the committee disagreed on certain stipulations of the implementation process, such as representation and responsibility sharing. The CSA comprises the Government of Mali, the CMA, Platform, as well as the mediation team chaired by Algeria and further including Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the United Nations, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, the African Union, and the European Union.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: The CSA also met in August 2015.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: A monitoring committee � the Comit� de Suivi du present Accord (CSA) � to oversee the implementation of the agreement was set up under the terms of the Bamako Agreement. The CSA comprises the Government of Mali, the CMA, Platform, as well as the mediation team chaired by Algeria and further including Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the United Nations, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, the African Union, and the European Union.The CSA met for negotiations on the implementation in Bamako between 3 and 5 July 2015.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: The CSA�s efforts to implement the Bamako Peace Agreement continued in 2016. The CMA and Platform were both unhappy with the slow pace of the implementation of the agreement. Hence, the signatories met in Bamako on 19-26 February 2016, but no progress was made. While the Government of Mali presented the measures that it had taken, including the creation of the M�naka and Taoudenni regions and the review of the Code des collectivit�s territoriales, the signatory armed groups, in a joint letter, deplored the lack of progress on the establishment of the interim administrations, reiterating the need for further efforts on institutional issues before moving forward on security and defense aspects.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Another meeting to discuss the implementation of the Bamako Agreement was held in New York on 23 September 2016, on the margins of the general debate of the seventy-first session of the UN General Assembly. The opening session of the meeting was chaired by the UN Secretary-General together with the President of Mali, Ibrahim Boubacar Keita. The goal of the meeting was to mitigate the tensions that had arisen surrounding the implementation of the Bamako Agreement between July and September 2016. Following the opening session, a meeting was co-chaired by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, International Cooperation and African Integration of Mali, Abdoulaye Diop, and the Minister of State, Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation of Algeria, Ramtane Lamamra, together with the UN Under-Secretary-General for Peacekeeping Operations. In the Co-Chairs� summary of the meeting, the signatories of the Bamako Agreement were urged to fully and sincerely maintain their commitments under the agreement and encouraged to take specific steps to swiftly implement the agreement.

Another meeting on the implementation of the agreement took place on 23 October 2016. During this meeting it was decided to start implementation of the agreement in November 2016, but this did not happen.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Another CSA meeting on the implementation of the agreement took place on 28 November 2016.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: At another CSA meeting on 20 December 2016, the CMA representatives announced the suspension of its participation in the CSA because of a lack of progress in the implementation of the Bamako Agreement. On 16 January 2017, MINUSMA mediated between government representatives and CMA leaders in Kidal to discuss a return of the CMA to the CSA, but Platform representatives did not participate in this meeting. Following a deadly terrorist attack in Gao on 18 January 2017 � which killed 54 members of a mixed patrol including forces from the government, Platform, and the CMA � the mediators tried to prevent a collapse of the peace process. An international mediation team, including ministers from the Governments of Algeria, Mauritania, and the Niger continued to urge CMA to further participate in the CSA. While a CSA meeting was held on 30 January in Bamako without the presence of CMA, the CMA remained involved in trying to set up mixed patrols in Gao. On 23 February 2017, the signatory parties launched the first mixed patrols in Gao.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: A conference for national harmony, the conf�rence d�entente nationale, was held in Bamako from 27 March to 2 April 2017. This conference adopted several recommendations, including, among others, the need to address governance and security issues in the central regions and a lack of inclusiveness in the peace process.

On 16 January 2018, a CSA meeting, which was also attended by the CMA, led to the endorsement of a timeline to accelerate the implementation of key provisions of the Bamako Agreement. By September 2018, signatory parties made some progress in the implementation of the agreement, including the nomination of interim authorities at the district level, the creation of municipalities for the M�naka and Taoudenni regions, and the adoption of the national security sector reform strategy.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: In June 2018, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 2423, calling for the signing of a �Pact for Peace� by the Malian parties. At a meeting in October 2018, the Malians parties signed this Pact for Peace, emphasizing the urgency of taking steps to �accelerate the full and inclusive implementation� of the agreement.

On 22 August 2019, the signatories to the 2015 peace agreement held a working session in Bamako. This meeting was chaired by the Minister of Social Cohesion, with support from the Carter Center, to examine in detail the progress made with regard to implementing the peace agreement.
The CMA and MAA signed a peace agreement in June 2020.

A political crisis and the COVID-19 pandemic brought the implementation of the 2015 peace agreement to a standstill. The CSA held its first-ever meetings outside of Bamako, namely in Kidal, in February 2021.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Another CSA meeting was held in Kayes in March 2021. However, shortly after this meeting, two specific events further stymied the implementation process during the first half of 2021. First, on 13 April 2021, CMA leader Sidi Brahim Ould Sidat was assassinated. Second, a second coup d��tat took place on 24 May 2021.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: After two days of negotiations taking place in Bamako on 5 and 6 April 2021, CMA and of the Platform agreed on the formation of a Cadre Strat�gique Permanente (CSP) (English: Permanent Strategic Coalition). The CSP was aimed at strengthening the relations between the CMA and the Platform, but was also envisioned as a key security provider in the northern regions.
At another meeting between the CMA and Platform in Rome on 6 May 2021, the leaders of the two groups signed the Rome Declaration, confirming the creation of the CSP.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: According to the Carter Center, which acted as the official observer of the implementation process of the Agreement on Peace and Reconciliation in Mali concluded in 2015, the implementation had reached a state of unprecedented impasse in its seventh year. The CSA met in October 2021, but this meeting ended when intense disagreements broke out among the signatories. After this meeting, the work of the CSA and its various subgroups was suspended.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: From 30 January to 3 February 2022, Ara Pacis Initiatives for Peace, an Italian non-profit organization, mediated peace talks between the CMA, Platform, and representatives from the transitional Government, with the Minister for National Reconciliation being part of the government team. The purpose of these talks was to address ongoing tensions between the signatory parties to the Algiers Accord. The talks also focused on disagreement surrounding the Cadre strat�gique permanent (CSP) (English: Permanent strategic coalition).

The signatories to the 2015 peace agreement held a working session in Bamako on 16-17 February 2022. The working session was chaired by the Minister of Social Cohesion, with support from the Carter Center, to examine in detail the progress made with regard to implementing the peace agreement.

On 16 March 2022, the signatories to the Algiers Accord met in Gao to address their ongoing disagreements, particularly regarding the creation and mission of the Cadre strat�gique permanent (CSP) (English: Permanent strategic coalition), which was formed by the CMA and Platform to strengthen the relations between them, but was also envisioned as a key security provider in the northern regions. The Government of Mali insisted that security matters should remain under the state�s authority and that any concerns raised by the movements should be resolved within the framework of the peace agreement. However, there was no concrete resolution reached.

Although the CSA did no longer meet, the Technical Security Commission (CTS) � tasked with monitoring the ceasefire, investigating potential violations, and monitoring security arrangements � met on 31 March 2022.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Although the CSA did no longer meet, the Technical Security Commission (CTS) � tasked with monitoring the ceasefire, investigating potential violations, and monitoring security arrangements � met on 16 June 2022.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: A high-level decision-making meeting was held in Bamako from 1 to 5 August 2022, attended by the Prime Minister, ministers, the High Representative of the transitional President for the implementation of the Agreement, and leaders of the signatory movements. The members of the international mediation team and the Carter Center acting as the Independent Observer were also present at this meeting. During this meeting, the Malian parties reached an agreement on the integration of ex-combatants into the national defense and security forces and the public administration in two phases.
third_party: Carter Center, International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: The CSA, having been inactive since October 2021, restarted by initiating a ministerial meeting on 2 September 2022.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Consultations were held among the signatories of the Algiers Accord in Bamako on 9 and 10 January 2023 to discuss the way forward regarding the peace agreement. The former Minister for Foreign Affairs of Algeria, Ramtane Lamamra acted as the mediator.

The international mediation team � including Algeria, the UN, ECOWAS, the AU, the EU, France, and the US � shuttled between the conflict parties in February 2023. On 1 February 2023, the international mediation team met with the CMA leadership in Kidal to discuss the viability of the Algiers Accord concluded in 2015. On 13 February 2023, the international mediation team held discussions with the Platform and the Mouvements de l�inclusivit� in Bamako. The international mediation team conducted a meeting with government officials on 14 February 2023. Following these meetings, the international mediation team called on the parties on 20 February 2023, to demonstrate renewed commitment and to refrain from any statements or actions that could further complicate the situation and efforts for the early holding of a high-level session of the CSA.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: From 20 February to 3 March 2023, the CMA leadership and Platform visited Algeria for a round of negotiations. The former Minister for Foreign Affairs of Algeria Ramtane Lamamra acted as the mediator at these talks.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs of Algeria, Ahmed Attaf, visited Bamako from 23 to 25 April 2023 to urge the signatory parties to fully adhere to the proposals made by the international mediation team.

The Minister for Reconciliation, Peace, and National Cohesion, Colonel-Major Isma�l Wagu�, met with representatives of the CMA and Platform in Kidal on 12 May 2023 to rebuild confidence and facilitate the resumption of the work of the monitoring mechanisms. However, tensions increased and the Platform movements left the CSP in September 2023. Tensions between the signatories of the Algiers Accord continued to increase. On 25 January 2024, Mali�s governing junta announced the abrupt end of the 2015 Algiers Accord. The junta attributed this sudden decision to a �shift in stance among some of the agreement�s signatory groups� and �acts of aggression and manipulation of the accord by the Algerian government.�
The Marsabit Catholic Peace Justice Commission mediated a round of negotiations between the Borana, Burji, and Gabra on 24 March 2013.
The Kenyan government mediated an inter-tribal meeting between the Borana, Burji, and Gabra in Moyale on 28 August 2013.
Another round of peace talks between the Borana, Burji, and Gabra took place in Moyale in December 2013. Kenyan security forces mediated between the conflict parties at these peace talks.

Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta formed the Marsabit Peace Restoration Committee to reconcile the conflict parties. With support from the UN, this committee mediated between the Borana and Gabra. Francis ole Kaparo and Yusuf Haji, the former National Assembly speaker and county senator respectively, led the committee and acted as the chief mediators. This peace meeting led to the signing of the Boma Peace Agreement on 22 February 2014. However, fighting would continue.
third_party: UN, government, local government, local peace committee

description: On 23 March 2015, 35 elders from the Borana and Gabra, and the Burji, Sakuye, and Garre convened in Mandera to discuss prospects for peace. The elders agreed to implement the February 2014 treaty.

Following the outbreak of armed violence, the Peace House Social Organization for Fighting Revenge in collaboration with the sheikhs of al-Jada�an, Dahm, Jahm, and Bani Nawf, succeeded in their mediation efforts to make the two tribes reach a fragile 38-day truce in early December 2004.

Negotiations allegedly took place between the conflict parties in 2014, but much is unknown about these negotiations. It is especially unclear whether the negotiations concerned just a ceasefire between the groups or whether it also entailed coordination to join forces against the Syrian Revolutionaries Front (SRF). Moreover, it is known that Abu Khalid al-Suri, one of the founders of al-Nusra was involved in the negotiations, but was killed in a suspected IS suicide bombing.

Tiv, Fulani, Jukun and Hausa leaders from Wukari, Ibi, Donga, and Takum enagaged in peace talks, mediated by Deputy Inspector General of Police Michael Zuokumor, in Jalingo in Taraba State on 5 April 2014. These peace talks led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement that appealed for peace between the four communities.

Representatives of the Jukun, Tiv and Fulani tribes of Bali Local Government Area signed another peace agreement during a peace meeting on 29 April 2014. However, the hostilities resumed in the beginning of May 2014 in that area.

On 30 April 2014, Jukun, Tiv, and Fulani leaders in Wukari Local Government Area held a peace meeting in response to armed clashes in Wukari on 15 April 2014. Taraba State Governor Alhaji Garba Umar and Wukari Paramount Chief Shekarau Angyu acted as mediators during this peace meeting. The meeting led to the signing of a peace agreement. However, the armed fighting resumed in early May 2014. In response, on 16 May 2014, the Governors of Benue State and Taraba State inaugurated a seven-man joint peace committee mandated to ensure the return of peace between the Tiv, Jukun, and Fulani living in the border communities of the two states.

In June 2016, Fulani and Jukun representatives began to participate in an inter-community dialogue process mediated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, along with several other community representatives from South Plateau. This led to the signing of the South Plateau Peace Declaration on 22 December 2016.

Following clashes in May and June 2019, local state authorities mediated a peace meeting between the leaders of the Jukun and Fulani communities in Local Government Areas of Jalingo, Ardo-Kola, and Lau. The meeting took place at the secretariat of the local government of Jalingo. The meeting did not result in an agreement.

On 15 August 2019, after a year of shuttle diplomacy and pre-mediation meetings, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) launched the Benue Mediation Process to find a lasting solution to the farmer-herder conflicts in the region. The meeting took place at the Benue Hotel in Makurdi and brought together representatives of the Agatu, Etulo, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Egede, Jukun, Tiv, and Yoruba communities of Benue State. On this occasion, HD pledged to help the communities achieve lasting peace, while the attending communities pledged to support and actively participate in the mediation process. During this first meeting, it was announced that the mediation process would take place in a joint meeting between tribes from the same senatorial zones.

President Muhammadu Buhari convended a meeting between the leaders of the conflict parties in Abuja on 2 September 2019. In addition to the conflict parties, Governor of Taraba State D.D. Ishaku also attended the peace meeting. The meeting focused on the conflict between the Fulani and the Jukun-Kona in the Local Government Areas of Jalingo and Ardo Kola in Taraba State. The conflict parties did not sign a peace agreement, but both sides agreed to live together peacefully.

HD convened a peace meeting with representatives of the Tiv, Idoma, Igede, Agatu, Etulo, Jukun, Fulani, Igbo, Yoruba, Hausa communities in Makurdi in Benue State in early November 2019. Traditional leaders, religious leaders, civil society groups, and security agencies, and state officials were also involved in the peace meeting. This meeting was part of the ongoing mediation dialogue between the conflict parties in the region. Stakeholders stressed the need for peace, but no written agreement resulted from the meeting.

In June 2014, the Centre for Democracy and Development (CDD) and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) organized a peace meeting in Ekiti State with several political parties, traditional and religious leaders, as well as civil society organizations and security personnel. The mediators tried to reach an agreement on guaranteeing violence free elections, but candidates of the APC, the Labour Party (LP), and the PDP refused to sign the agreement.
third_party: community leaders, UN, traditional leaders, religious leaders, government forces

description: Several peace meetings were held between the presidential candidates in 2015 in view of the upcoming presidential elections. Following a peace meeting on election-related violence, PDP leader President Goodluck Jonathan, APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, and nine other presidential candidates signed the Abuja agreement on 14 January 2015. This agreement committed the political parties and their supporters to peace during the presidential campaigns.

In response to election-related violence in Kaduna State and Niger State, Deputy Inspector General of Police mediated talks between the leaders of several political parties in the region, including the leaders of the PDP and APC. This led to the signing of a peace agreement aimed at preventing further election-related violence on 10 February 2015.

During a peace meeting in Benue State on 4 March 2015, PDP candidate John Ngbede and APC candidate Samuel Ortom reached an agreement to ensure violence-free elections in the region. This agreement was mediated by the Committee of Security Agencies, headed by State Police Commissioner Hycinth Dagala.

General Abdulsalami Abubakar of the National Peace Committee on the 2015 elections mediated a round of peace talks between PDP leader President Goodluck Jonathan and APC leader Muhammadu Buhari in Abuja on 26 March 2015. This led to the conclusion of a peace agreement that committed the parties to holding violence-free elections. However, violence broke out between APC and PDP supporters shortly after the agreement was signed.

The Inter-Agency Consultative Committee on Electoral Security led by the State commissioner of police of Rivers State, Mr. Musa Kimo, mediated between regional leaders of the APC and PDP and their supporters at the Police Officers Mess in Port Harcourt in February 2016. The meeting was held to manage election-related violence ahead of the forthcoming national and state assembly rerun elections. The meeting did not lead to an agreement. The supporters of the APC and PDP clashed again soon after the meeting.

The presidential and National Assembly elections scheduled for February 2019 led to an upsurge in violence between APC and PDP supporters beginning in January 2019. During the month of January 2019, political representatives in several Nigerian states signed peace agreements to guarantee peaceful campaigns. These were most of the time mediated by the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) together with state police officials. The purpose of these agreements was to encourage political leaders to ensure peaceful elections and to communicate to their supporters the importance of peaceful cohabitation with the supporters of rival parties during the campaign and beyond. On 9 January 2019, the political parties of Enugu, including the APC and PDP, signed an agreement at a meeting mediated by the state police command and INEC at the Senior Officers Mess in Agbani Road.

On 18 January 2019, INEC also mediated talks between leaders of the APC, PDP, and of 23 other political parties in Kwara State, which led to the signing of a peace accord guaranteeing violence-free elections. The peace meeting was held at the state headquarters of INEC at Adewole area of Ilorin in Kwara State.

On 18 January 2019, a peace meeting between parties in the region, including the PDP and APC, was held in the Taal Conference Hotel in Lafia in Nasarawa State. This meeting was mediated by the Center for Humanitarian Affairs, in collaboration with INEC, and led to the conclusion of a peace agreement guaranteeing free and fair elections without violence.

Uk�omu Igala, an Igala socio-cultural group, mediated between several political parties, including the PDP and APC, in Anyigba in the Local Government Area of Dekina in Kogi State on 22 January 2019. The meeting led to the conclusion of an agreement that committed the parties to holding elections without violence and to promoting peaceful cohabitation among their supporters.

A peace meeting between 28 party leaders, including the APC and the PDP, took place at the Kano State Government House on 23 January 2019. The meeting was mediated by the Kano State Peace Committee and led to the conclusion of an agreement that stressed the need for peaceful elections and the demilitarization of the supporters of political parties.

INEC, together with the Inter-Agency Consultative Committee on Election Security (ICCES), mediated a peace agreement between 30 political parties in the Gombe State on 24 January 2019. Muhammad Inuwa Yahaya and Usman Bayero Nafada signed for the APC and PDP respectively.

Political party leaders in Bayelsa State, including APC and PDP leaders, gathered for a peace meeting at the police officers� mess in Yenagoa on 24 January 2019. This meeting was mediated by the state police command together with officials of the Inter-Party Advisory Council (IPAC). The meeting led to the signing of a peace agreement that committed the parties to peaceful elections.

A peace meeting mediated by the state police commissioner led to a peace agreement in Anambra State on 30 January 2019. The political leaders attending the meeting were encouraged to convey the call for peace to their supporters.

Armed clashes between the supporters of the APC and the PDP frequently occurred in the run-up to the general elections in several states in spite of the many peace efforts. Consequently, several additional peace efforts were undertaken in early February 2019, just before the elections. On 5 February 2019, PDP and several other party leaders of Akwa Ibom State engaged in talks mediated by INEC at Ibom hall. The meeting was aimed at concluding a peace agreement to mitigate election-related violence, but the APC did not sign the agreement.

On 5 February 2019, the state police command mediated between governor Nasir el-Rufai of the APC and the PDP governorship candidate Isa Ashiru, as well as 20 other political leaders. The meeting led to the signing of a peace agreement that committed the conflict parties to violent-free elections. The meeting took place at the police officers� mess in Kaduna and was mediated by Police Commissioner Alhaji Ahmad Abdurrahman.

The civil society organization Hope Givers Initiative and INEC mediated a peace meeting between five governorship candidates, including the APC and PDP candidates, in Umuahia in Abia State on 12 February 2019. This resulted in the signing of a peace agreement to guarantee peaceful elections.

On 13 February 2019, the two main presidential rivals, Muhammadu Buhari of the APC and Atiku Abubakar of the PDP attended a peace meeting in Abuja, together with 71 other political representatives. The National Peace Committee led by the former military ruler Abdulsalami Abubakar and the Kofi Annan Foundation mediated between the parties. The meeting led to the signing of a peace agreement and all signatories called upon their supporters to wage a peaceful campaign. However, this did not prevent clashes between APC and PDP supporters from occurring in Abuja only one day after the signing of the agreement.

After the reelection of President Buhari of the APC with 56 percent of the votes, violence resumed between the supporters of the APC and PDP in the second half of February 2019. The PDP considered the previously concluded agreements broken. Ahead of state governor elections in Kogi State in November 2019, several political parties, including the PDP and APC, reached a peace agreement that was mediated by the Search for Common Ground, the Kukah Foundation, and the National Peace Committee in Lokoja on 7 November 2019. The signing ceremony was disrupted by thugs who attacked the political candidates. Moreover, attacks resumed between supporters of the two main parties already the next day after the signing of the agreement.
third_party: Search for Common Ground, community leaders, government

description: A peace meeting mediated by police officials and INEC led to the conclusion of an agreement in Yenagoa in Bayelsa State on 7 November 2019. The agreement was signed by 42 parties in the run-up to the state governor�s elections. Senator Douye Diri signed on behalf of the PDP, while David Lyon signed on behalf of the APC.

A police enforcement brought the violence to a pause, after which police officers mediated between the conflict parties. The reconciliation meeting on 3 April 2014, mediated by the police, failed and fighting broke out again.
On 5 April 2014, Prime Minister Ibrahim Mehleb and Minister of Interior Mohamed Ibrahim visited the conflict zone and shuttled between the conflict parties to urge them to end their fighting.
On 7 April 2014, an Aswan peace committee led by Governor Mustapha Yasri and local leaders mediated a round of peace talks, which led to the conclusion of a three-day truce.
third_party: local peace committee, local government, community leaders

description: This ceasefire was re-affirmed and extended for one month during another round of talks mediated by the Aswan peace committee on 9 April 2014.

The Grand Imam of Al-Azhar Ahmed Al-Tayeb mediated a round of peace talks between the conflict parties in Aswan on 12 April 2014. His mediation team included the Minister of Religious Endowment Mokhtar Gomaa, Al-Azhar officials, religious and education leaders. As part of the peace process, the mediation team managed compensation for victims of the communal violence. The mediation effort by the Grand Imam of Al-Azhar led to the extension of the existing ceasefire for three months.

On 3 May 2014, the two tribes expressed their commitment to full reconciliation. However, fighting broke out again on 26 June 2014. On 28 June 2014, the Aswan peace committee mediated a round of peace talks that led to the conclusion of a peace agreement.

UNSMIL mediated a round of negotiations between the conflict parties in March 2013. This led to the signing of a peace agreement, but this agreement failed due to a lack of support from the wider Toubou community.
Another reconciliation meeting in 2013 between the two groups failed and immediately descended into violence an al-Gadaffi-era People�s Hall.
Libyan government officials mediated negotiations between the conflict parties between March and May 2013, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire and the release of prisoners in May 2013.

On 20 April 2013, a group of senior Libyan government officials led by Prime Minister Abdurraheem al-Keib mediated between the conflict parties. This led to the signing of a document on reconciliation, stipulating a ceasefire between the two tribes. However, this did not quell the clashes.

In January 2014, the conflict reignited after the killing of an officer from the Awlad Suleiman tribe that was blamed on the Toubou. Negotiations between tribal leaders led to a ceasefire on 13 January 2014, but this ceasefire soon broke down. The Prime Minister subsequently visited the conflict area on 19 January to promote peace.
Negotiations on 15 January 2014 led to another ceasefire, but this ceasefire failed to last for more than 72 hours.
Another round of negotiations led to the signing of a reconciliation agreement on 25 March 2014.
The Third Force, a Misratan Militia in Southern Libya, mediated another round of negotiations in June 2014. This led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 22 June 2014.
The Community of Sant�Egidio mediated a humanitarian ceasefire � the Fezzan Humanitarian Agreement � between various tribes in Rome on 16 June 2016 in order to provide aid in the Fezzan region.
A round of negotiations mediated by a team of elders and southern local leaders led to a three-day ceasefire between the conflict parties on 22 November 2016.

As conflict persisted, the Community of Sant�Egidio and EU�s Directorate General for International Cooperation and Development, Human Development and Migration met with local representatives to bring them to a negotiating table. These efforts led to a meeting for preliminary talks between the tribal leaders in Rome on 8 December 2016.

In March 2017, 60 tribal representatives engaged in negotiations in Rome mediated by the Libyan Presidency Council, the Italian Interior Minister Marco Minniti, the Ara Pacis Initiative, and the Community of Sant�Egidio. This led to the signing of the Reconciliation and Peace Agreement on 29 March 2017 and a document regarding methods for implementation on 31 March. A faction of the Toubou tribe rejected this agreement on 6 April and fighting resumed.
third_party: government, Italy, Ara Pacis Innitiative, Community of Sant�Egidio

description: The two sides agreed to another ceasefire during another round of negotiations on 29 April.

Negotiations between 15 tribal and state officials from Chad, Libya and Niger in Rome on 21 May 2017 led to the signing of a security and peace framework called The Sahara Triangle: New Perspectives. Italian Interior Minister Marco Minniti acted as the mediator during these negotiations.
Representatives from both tribes also attended a peace conference in Brussels in May 2017 and engaged in dialogue with the Government of National Accord (GNA).
On 6 February 2018, Alwad Suleiman and Toubou tribal leaders met for peace talks in Sabha and signed a ceasefire agreement.
The Awlad Suleiman and Toubou reached another ceasefire accord during another round of negotiations on 27 February 2018.
The Presidency Council mediated between the conflict parties in response to renewed fighting in March 2018, but this did not lead to an agreement.

On 7 April, the Supreme Council of the Tribes and Cities of Fezzan called for a ceasefire for the region. In response, the Toubou announced a unilateral ceasefire on 9 April. Another round of negotiations led to the conclusion of a ceasefire between the conflict parties on 10 April 2018.
The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) successfully mediated a ceasefire between the Awlad Suleiman and Toubou on 9 May 2018, albeit fighting continued.
Local authorities mediated another ceasefire between the conflict parties in Harajah on 13 May 2018.

Negotiations between the tribal leaders led to the signing of a comprehensive peace agreement on 20 May 2018. On 5 July 2018, the Toubou tribe recommitted to its 9 April ceasefire, expressing its support for the ongoing national reconciliation process.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: The United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) mediated negotiations between the conflict parties on 19 November 2014, which led to the conclusion of a humanitarian ceasefire for 12 hours.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: UNSMIL supported local mediation efforts between the conflict parties in 2016. On 10 December 2016, the LNA declared a six-hour unilateral ceasefire for citizen evacuation.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: UNSMIL supported local mediation efforts between the conflict parties in 2017.
The UN mediated a peace agreement in February 2017 between the conflict parties. This agreement did not hold. Violence continued until the end of 2017, but no clashes took place during 2018.

On 19 August 2017, both Hezbollah and the Lebanese army initiated independent assaults against IS in northeast Lebanon. Following a request from IS for negotiations and possible withdrawal on 24 August 2017, Hezbollah engaged in bilateral talks with the group. Those talks led to an agreement on 27 August 2017, the same day as the Lebanon army�s unilateral ceasefire declaration. As part of the agreement, the Islamic State pledged to withdraw its fighters and families, as well as handed over the bodies of five Hezbollah fighters.

Following clashes at the Tripoli International Airport, a local peace council mediated a ceasefire between the conflict parties on 17 July 2014. This ceasefire did not hold. On 23 August, the Libya Dawn successfully expelled the Zintan Military Council from Tripoli. Two days later, the Libya Dawn was absorbed into the General National Congress (GNC) as its de-facto armed forces.
On 20 February 2015, a peace meeting, mediated by religious and tribal leaders, took place in al-Asabea.
A round of bilateral negotiations was initiated following fighting in Warshafana. This led to a ceasefire agreement on 21 April 2015.
The ceasefire of April 2015 did not hold, and another round of negotiations took place in early May 2015.
The two sides met again in Sabratha in late May 2015 for an unsuccessful round of peace talks.

The Zintan Military Council and Libya Dawn forces in Gharyan reached a ceasefire agreement following a round of negotiations on 9 June 2015. Similar agreements were subsequently signed by local military leaders of both sides in the cities of Zuwara, Sabratha, and Zawiya.

New negotiations between the conflict parties took place in the context of negotiations between representatives of the cities of Zintan and Kikla that began in August 2015. While the Libya Dawn controlled Kikla, the Zintan Military Council controlled Zintan. Elders and military officials from both sides entered into negotiations.

The negotiations that had been started in August 2015 finally led to the conclusion of a peace agreement between Zintan and Kikla in January 2016. This agreement was concluded outside the ongoing UN national-level peace process.

In March 2016, a delegation led by Congolese politician Vital Kamhere mediated between Nande and Hutu. With Kamerhe, local representatives of the communities traveled to Kinshasa to speak with the prime minister Augustin Matata Ponyo Mapon about solutions to the rising conflict. This delegation also met with the Special Representative of the UN Secretary-General in the DRC to discuss how to resolve the communal conflict between the Hutu and the Nande.

MONUSCO facilitated a number of high-level visits, including by the Head of State and the Minister of the Interior with representatives of the Hutu and Nade communties in the Buleusa area in July 2016. This resulted in the conclusion of a ceasefire and a reconciliation ceremony on 23 July 2016. On 2 and 3 November 2016, MONUSCO supported awareness-raising activities on peaceful cohabitation in Buleusa to facilitate the return of internally displaced persons and peaceful cohabitation between the Hutu, Kobo and Nande communities. On 29 November 2016, MONUSCO supported the provincial assessment mission led by the Governor of North Kivu following the violent clashes in Luhanga on 27 November 2016.

From 13 to 17 December 2016, MONUSCO facilitated the mediation effort of local authorities between community leaders in Luhanga, Luofu, and in the surrounding areas. The peacemaking efforts to address the conflict between the Hutu and Nande communities in 2016 also involved engagement with the respective Hutu and Nande parliamentary caucuses in Kinshasa in order to support the local reconciliation conferences in Goma, thus bringing together key state-level actors with local ones.

On 20 January 2017, a meeting between Hutu and Nande leaders, facilitated by MONUSCO, put in place a Committee on Peaceful Coexistence between the two communities. The 12-member committee, consisting of artists, church leaders and local authorities, was tasked to lead the reconciliation process.

MONUSCO supported a series of dialogues facilitated by local authorities in order to address rising intercommunal tensions between Nande and Hutu communities in the Rutshuru area between 20 and 27 March 2017.

Following several abductions of Nande by the Hutu throughout mid-July, MONUSCO supported local authorities and civil society in facilitating dialogue between Nande and Hutu leaders in July 2017. This peacemaking effort led to the conclusion of a non-aggression pact, which stipulated an end to the fighting and the return of the abductees. This subsequently led to a reduction in tensions. Only one more armed clash took place between the Nande and the Hutu from this meeting April onwards, namely in December 2017. In mid-March 2018, MONUSCO began to engage with Hutu and Nande communities and the local authorities in order to facilitate the return of Hutu and Nande refugees to their homes.

The provincial government sent officials to the region, while local clan leaders and civil society members organized sensitization meetings between the two sides. On 6 June 2014, the Bafulero on the one side and the Banyamulenge and the Barundi on the other side clashed around Mutarule. The Banyamulenge claimed that a Bafulero militia had attacked Banyamulenge herders � and in revenge Banyamulenge and Barundi youths attacked and killed over 33 Bafulero that had gathered to attend an outdoor church service.

Negotiations between the Banyamulenge and Bafuliruled to the signing of a peace agreement in Kahuna in the Bijombo groupment on 14 December 2017. The negotiations were mediated by the NGO Promotion des Personnes Marginalisees (PROPEM), representatives from the Provincial Government, and MONUSCO.

The Bishop of Uvira in South Kivu, supported by MONUSCO, organized an intercommunity dialogue between the in Uvira town on 18 and 19 September 2018. Representatives of civil society and provincial and local authorities also attended. The dialogue session led to the conclusion of an Acte d�Engagement. A committee composed of two members of each community was set up to follow-up on the commitments, while the bishop traveled to Kinshasa on 21 September 2018 to hand over the detailed dialogue�s report and the Actes D�Engagement to national authorities.

MONUSCO and International Alert organized a three-day intercommunity dialogue between the Banyamulenge, Babembe, Bafuliru, Banyindu, Barundi, and Pygmies in Bijombo between 25 and 28 June 2019. This led to the signing of an Act of Commitment stating necessary conditions for sustainable peace.
MINUSCA helped the armed groups in Bambari reach a weapons-free-zone agreement on 8 September 2015.

On 27 January 2016, Ali Darassa from the UPC and Edouard Nga�ssona from the anti-Balaka signed a non-aggression pact, entitled the Protocole d�accord de nonagression et de bonne cohabitation (English: Memorandum of Understanding on Nonaggression and Coexistence). This agreement was aimed at preventing heavy fighting in the Bambari area, which could disrupt the parliamentary and presidential elections that were held between December 2015 and March 2016. However, the agreement specified that the ceasefire commitments could extend beyond the election period. Darassa and Nga�ssona committed to suspend violent actions, including against the population and the international forces deployed in Bambari, and to allow for the free movement of persons and goods.
agreement_name: Protocole d�accord de nonagression et de bonne cohabitation

description: Another local peace process took place in the Mbr�s sub-prefecture. The MINUSCA field office in Kaga-Bandoro � with the involvement of the Local Peace and Reconciliation Committee (CLPR), religious leaders, and local authorities � mediated between the anti-Balaka on the one hand and the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the other hand in the Mbr�s area. This led to the signing of a non-aggression pact on 8 June 2016.
third_party: MINUSCA, religious leaders, local government, local peace committee

description: In March 2017, the Community of Sant�Egidio started a mediation process, with Andrea Riccardi acting as the chief mediator. UN envoy Parfait Onanga-Anyanga, the European Union, and the Italian Government had an observer status during the negotiations. With peace talks ongoing in Rome, FPRC fighters launched an offensive against anti-Balaka elements in Bakouma on 6 June 2017, following an anti-Balaka attack on Nzako. This persuaded the conflict parties at the negotiations to sign a peace agreement on 19 June 2017, stipulating an immediate ceasefire. This agreement, referred to as the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic, was signed by the RPRC, FPRC, FDPC, UPC, RPRC, RJ BELANGA, UFR-F, UPC, RJ SAYO, UFR-F, FPRC, UFR, RJ SAYO, MPC, SELEKA Renovee, Coordination anti-Balaka, anti-Balaka Mokom, MLJC, RJ Belanga, FDPC, MLJC, and the UFR. The agreement reaffirmed the 2016 elections. In addition, the agreement called for the integration of all �politico-military groups� into the peace process and a restoration of state authority. The agreement also included an immediate countrywide ceasefire. The ceasefire did not hold. Armed clashes between several armed groups already took place in the Bria area already one day after the signing of the ceasefire.
third_party: Community of Sant�Egidio, UN, EU, Italy
agreement_name: Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic

description: On 28 June, President Faustin Archange Touad�ra held meetings with the representatives of the 14 armed groups that had signed a peace agreement in Rome on 19 June.

With it being clear that the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic of June 2017 did not succeed, the AU presented its roadmap for peace in Libreville on 17 July 2017. The roadmap agreement assigns the responsibility for leading peace negotiations in CAR to the AU, while pledging to take into account the achievements of previous peace initiatives including the June 2017 Sant�Egidio Agreement. The Roadmap created an African Panel of Facilitators, with panel members from the AU, ECCAS, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, Angola, Chad, the Republic of Congo, and Gabon. MINUSCA was granted observer status. The African Panel of Facilitators mediated for the first time Bangui between 11 and 12 September 2017.

On 28 August 2018, Russia � which had begun supplying the CAR government with arms and military instructors in February 2018 � and Sudan mediated negotiations between the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the one side and the anti-Balaka (represented by Maxime Mokom) on the other side. These negotiations led to the signing of declaration of understanding and a pledge to support the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation in CAR led by the AU and regional states with the support of the UN. The UPC and MPC expressed they were no longer committed to this declaration in October 2018, but they made it clear that they still supported the African Initiative. Furthermore, the AU, with support from MINUSCA, organized a meeting between 14 armed groups in Bouar between 28 and 30 August. The meeting produced a document with demands to the government, signed by all 14 groups that participated in the meeting. The document was handed over to the government following the meeting.

A local peace process took place in the Basse-Kotto prefecture. Heavy fighting had broken out between anti-Balaka and the UPC in Kongbo, Basse-Kotto prefecture in the previous year, in August 2017. In response, MINUSCA had established a temporary base in the area in August 2017. Local peace actors � including community and religious leaders, local authorities � initiated a mediation effort between the anti-Balaka and the UPC in the Basse-Kotto prefecture in July 2018. This culminated into the conclusion of a peace agreement in Mobaye on 15 October 2018. The agreement stipulates a ceasefire, the free movement of the population, and a commitment to refrain from impeding the restoration of state authority.
third_party: religious leaders, community leaders, local government

description: Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Nga�ssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, S�l�ka R�nov�e, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) and MINUSCA, with support from local officials and traditional and religious leaders, mediated a round of negotiations between the UPC, MPC, RPRC, MLJC, anti-Balaka-Molokom, and FPRC in Bria from 1 to 9 April 2019. This led to the signing of the Bria Accord on 9 April 2019. This local agreement was aimed at reinforcing the implementation of the 6 February 2019 national agreement. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire to end to the violence in Haute-Kotto and Ouaka prefectures, as well as guaranteed the safe and free movement of persons, goods, and humanitarian aid on the main axis.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), MINUSCA, local government, traditional leaders, religious leaders

description: Three days of fighting around Dimsu resulted in the killing of around 150 tribe members. Fighting over cattle-rustling resumed from 13 to 15 August in the Al Nadhif area in Buram and led to 83 fatalities. The conflict parties initiated negotiations in late August, which led to the signing of a peace agreement on 7 September 2015.

On 3 March 2016. Sudanese government soldiers and police forcefully disarmed members of the Salamat and Fulani in Tullus and Buram localities. This led to the detaining of 84 members of both tribes. On 16 May 2016, the conflict parties held a reconciliation conference supported by UNAMID. The violations of the September 2015 peace agreement were discussed, and the parties signed a new reconciliation agreement committed to disarmament and financial compensation for those killed.

However, the conflict parties clashed again on 9 October 2016. In addition to the deployment of government forces, a peace committee was established, comprising the native administrations of both communities and local authorities, which mediated between the conflict parties between October and December 2016.
third_party: traditional leaders, local government, local peace committee

description: Following clashes between Rezeigat and Massalit over access to land in the Graida area on 20 and 27 November, local authorities deployed security personnel and started to mediate between the conflcit parties. This mediation effort led a peace agreement on 11 December 2015.

Tension rose again between the Masalit and Rizeigat Baggara in late 2016, with armed clashes throughout November leaving twelve Massalit and 27 Rizeigat dead in South Darfur. The paramount chief of the Rizeigat living in Ed Daein subsequently visited the conflict area in late November to defuse tensions and prevent the further mobilization of his community. Local authorities, in turn, engaged with the Masalit to defuse tensions. Yet, Masalit farmers killed two Rizeigat nomads who allegedly grazed their cattle on their farm in Dimasoya on 16 November.

The conflict parties held a reconciliation conference in Bielel on 10 December 2016, where they did not sign an agreement, but agreed that all Rizeigat herders would leave the locality until the end of the farming season in mid-January 2017.

location_conflict: United States of America, Yemen (North Yemen)
side_b: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 24 April 2016, Islamic clerics mediated between AQAP and representatives of the Forces of Hadi in Mukalla, which led to AQAP�s withdrawal from the town. This was followed by an offensive of Yemeni and Emirati troops on the city.

In late 2004, during the Ekumomwar � an annual ceremony which gathers the Nyangatom, Hamar and Dassantech from all neighborhoods in the Kibish region � the different communities exchanged gifts as a part of previously adopted peace deals. The primary goal of the ceremony was to discuss conflict resolution options.

On 22 and 24 October 2005, the Ethiopian Pastoralist Research and Development Association (EPARDA) initiated a peace process with district officials in Arbaminch. This process focused on resolving conflicts between the Dassanech, Hamar, and Nyangatom.
The EPARDA subsequently organized a peace conference for the groups and several peace meetings were held throughout 2006.

District and tribal officials from the Nyangatom and the Hamar held a week-long peace conference Kangaten in July 2007. The conflict parties reached an agreement to cease hostilities over grazing land and water.

At the request of district officials, the Peace Centers for Climate and Social Resilience (PCCSR) project organized various peace meetings between the Borana, Hamar, and Arbore in Marmaro between 2014 and 2017.
third_party: local government, Peace Centers for Climate and Social Resilience (PCCSR) project

description: In addition to deploying troops, the state governor mediated between both sides to the conflict in October 2015. This reduced tensions.

In April 2015, a mediation effort was initiated by local chiefs, a county commissioner, and the governor�s peace adviser. UNMISS Civil Affairs provided logistical support by shuttling community leaders from both sides to meetings for discussing their issues. The two communities then appointed representatives who met at a roundtable organized by the NGO ACTED and UNMISS Civil Affairs to find solutions to the underlying problems of resource sharing and road access. The negotiations resulted in the conclusion of a ceasefire, which was celebrated through a series of ceremonial intermarriages between the two clans.
A reconciliation committee with representatives from both communities was set up in January 2018 in response to heavy clashes in December 2017, but this mediation effort did not lead to an agreement.

UNMISS and Oxfam facilitated a peace meeting in Malek County, near Rumbek, on 31 December 2018. This meeting led to conclusion of a peace agreement, which stipulated a ceasefire to end the intercommunal violence, cattle raids, and deadly revenge attacks. It was also agreed that both sides would return stolen cows and promote intercommunal interaction.

While the CMA and Platform were not engaged in direct negotiations during most of the Algiers process, this changed during the final phase of the process. The Government of Mali, the CMA, and Platform entered negotiations in Algiers on 30 May 2015. They signed the Relev� de Conclusions des Consultations Pr�paratoires � la mise en �uvre de l�Accord pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali Issu du Procesus d�Alger (English: Statement of Conclusions of the Preparatory Consultations for the Implementation of the Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation in Mali Arising from the Algiers Process) on 5 June 2015, which addressed stipulated the creation of two regions in Mali, the integration of rebel fighters into the national army, and several arrangements to promote regional economic development. On the same day, the conflict parties also signed another ceasefire agreement, the Arrangement s�curitaire pour une cessation des hostilit�s (English: Security Arrangements for a Cessation of Hostilities).
agreement_name: Relev� de Conclusions des Consultations Pr�paratoires � la mise en �uvre de l�Accord pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali Issu du Procesus d�Alger, Arrangement s�curitaire pour une cessation des hostilit�s

description: This paved the way for the Government of Mali, the CMA, and Platform signing a comprehensive peace agreement in Bamako on 20 June 2015: the Accord Pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali - Issu du Processus d�Alger (English: Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation in Mali - Resulting from the Algiers Process), also referred to as the Bamako Agreement.
agreement_name: Accord Pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali - Issu du Processus d�Alger

description: Another round of negotiations between the members of the monitoring committee � the Comit� du Suivi du present Accord (CSA) � was held in late July 2015 to discuss the implementation process, but the members of the committee disagreed on certain stipulations of the implementation process, such as representation and responsibility sharing. The CSA comprises the Government of Mali, the CMA, Platform, as well as the mediation team chaired by Algeria and further including Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the United Nations, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, the African Union, and the European Union.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: The CSA also met in August 2015.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: A monitoring committee � the Comit� de Suivi du present Accord (CSA) � to oversee the implementation of the agreement was set up under the terms of the Bamako Agreement. The CSA comprises the Government of Mali, the CMA, Platform, as well as the mediation team chaired by Algeria and further including Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the United Nations, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, the African Union, and the European Union. The CSA met for negotiations on the implementation in Bamako between 3 and 5 July 2015. The UN Secretary General�s Special Representative convened this meeting. Under his auspices, the parties concluded another ceasefire and promised to end all incursions into the areas under the other party�s control. The parties also agreed to initiate dialogue in An�fis, with a goal of solving the long-standing intercommunal and intra-communal tensions at the root of the conflict between them.
third_party: Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU

description: The UN Secretary-General�s Special Representative mediated a round of negotiations that led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 23 September 2015.

On 27 and 28 September 2015, a CMA delegation held meetings with President Ibrahim Boubacar Ke�ta and the leaders of the Platform in Bamako. Following the meetings, CMA announced that it would stick to the ceasefire and order its combatants to refrain from using force against the troops of the Government forces and Platform.

Between 27 September and 14 October 2015, CMA and the Platform engaged in direct talks in An�fis. At the end of the talks, the parties endorsed a road map � the Anefis road map � comprising a series of measures, including the cessation of hostilities, joint initiatives for intercommunal and intra-communal reconciliation, the exchange of prisoners, the establishment of interim local administrations and the free movement of people and goods. During and following the An�fis talks, CMA and the Platform mediated a series of intercommunal and intra-communal reconciliation agreements in Gao, Kidal and Timbuktu regions, including between the Ifoghas and Imghad Tuareg communities affiliated with CMA and the Platform, respectively.

The CSA�s efforts to implement the Bamako Peace Agreement continued in 2016. The CMA and Platform were both unhappy with the slow pace of the implementation of the agreement. Hence, the signatories met in Bamako on 19-26 February 2016, but no progress was made. While the Government of Mali presented the measures that it had taken, including the creation of the M�naka and Taoudenni regions and the review of the Code des collectivit�s territoriales, the signatory armed groups, in a joint letter, deplored the lack of progress on the establishment of the interim administrations, reiterating the need for further efforts on institutional issues before moving forward on security and defense aspects.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Another meeting to discuss the implementation of the Bamako Agreement was held in New York on 23 September 2016, on the margins of the general debate of the seventy-first session of the UN General Assembly. The opening session of the meeting was chaired by the UN Secretary-General together with the President of Mali, Ibrahim Boubacar Keita. The goal of the meeting was to mitigate the tensions that had arisen surrounding the implementation of the Bamako Agreement between July and September 2016. Following the opening session, a meeting was co-chaired by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, International Cooperation and African Integration of Mali, Abdoulaye Diop, and the Minister of State, Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation of Algeria, Ramtane Lamamra, together with the UN Under-Secretary-General for Peacekeeping Operations. In the Co-Chairs� summary of the meeting, the signatories of the Bamako Agreement were urged to fully and sincerely maintain their commitments under the agreement and encouraged to take specific steps to swiftly implement the agreement.

Another meeting on the implementation of the agreement took place on 23 October 2016. During this meeting it was decided to start the implementation of the agreement in November 2016, but this did not happen.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Another CSA meeting on the implementation of the agreement took place on 28 November 2016.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: At another CSA meeting on 20 December 2016, the CMA representatives announced the suspension of its participation in the CSA because of a lack of progress in the implementation of the Bamako Agreement. On 16 January 2017, MINUSMA mediated between government representatives and CMA leaders in Kidal to discuss a return of the CMA to the CSA, but Platform representatives did not participate in this meeting. Following a deadly terrorist attack in Gao on 18 January 2017 � which killed 54 members of a mixed patrol including forces from the government, Platform, and the CMA � the mediators tried to prevent a collapse of the peace process. An international mediation team, including ministers from the Governments of Algeria, Mauritania, and the Niger continued to urge CMA to continue its participation in the CSA. While a CSA meeting was held on 30 January 2017 in Bamako, without the presence of CMA, the CMA remained involved in trying to set up mixed patrols in Gao. On 23 February 2017, the signatory parties launched the first mixed patrols in Gao.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: In the context of the stalling implementation process following the Bamako Agreement concluded in 2015, the violence between the CMA and GATIA intensified in early 2016, with both groups competing for territorial control, particularly in the Kidal area. On 2 February 2016, GATIA and CMA concluded an agreement, without the involvement of any third party. The agreement stipulated that both parties would jointly control the city of Kidal. However, CMA and GATIA continued to clash sporadically after the Kidal power-sharing deal was in place. On 6 June 2016, Platform publicly stated that it considered the February power-sharing agreement on Kidal to have led to an inequitable division of power in Kidal between CMA and the Platform. The CMA reacted by stating that CMA remained in charge of the management of the town.

On 14 July 2016, representatives of the CMA and GATIA held discussions in Niamey, at the invitation of the Government of the Niger, to address outstanding political and security issues between them. On 17 July 2016, an agreement was reached by the two groups on the joint management of Kidal and other measures to reduce tensions. Nevertheless, heavy fighting erupted in Kidal two days later, resulting in GATIA being pushed out of the town.

Heavy fighting continued in August 2016. Talks aimed at cessation of hostilities initiated in mid-August by the Government of Niger ended without reaching agreement and talks broke down in September 2016.

A conference for national harmony, the conf�rence d�entente nationale, was held in Bamako from 27 March to 2 April 2017. This conference adopted several recommendations, including, among others, the need to address governance and security issues in the central regions and a lack of inclusiveness in the peace process.

A conference for national harmony, the conf�rence d�entente nationale, was held in Bamako from 27 March to 2 April 2017. This conference adopted several recommendations, including, among others, the need to address governance and security issues in the central regions and a lack of inclusiveness in the peace process.
On 23 August 2017, MINUSMA mediated between the CMA and Platform, which led to the conclusion of a 15-day ceasefire in Kidal. The ceasefire was extended on 6 September 2017.

Another round of negotiations mediated by MINUSMA led to the signing of a definitive ceasefire by the conflict parties in Bamako on 21 September 2017. The ceasefire stipulated an immediate halt to hostilities, the release of prisoners, and the return of the CMA-controlled base in Takalot to Platform.

On 10 October 2017, CMA and GATIA signed yet another agreement that was mediated by MINUSMA, referred to as Anefis II. This agreement specified local security arrangements to keep peace in Kidal region.

On 16 January 2018, a CSA meeting, which was also attended by the CMA, led to the endorsement of a timeline to accelerate the implementation of key provisions of the Bamako Agreement. By September 2018, signatory parties made some progress in the implementation of the agreement, including the nomination of interim authorities at the district level, the creation of municipalities for the M�naka and Taoudenni regions, and the adoption of the national security sector reform strategy.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: In June 2018, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 2423, calling for the signing of a �Pact for Peace� by the Malian parties. At a meeting in October 2018, the Malians parties signed this Pact for Peace, emphasizing the urgency of taking steps to �accelerate the full and inclusive implementation� of the agreement.

In June 2018, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 2423, calling for the signing of a �Pact for Peace� by the Malian parties. At a meeting in October 2018, the Malians parties signed this Pact for Peace, emphasizing the urgency of taking steps to �accelerate the full and inclusive implementation� of the agreement.

On 22 August 2019, the signatories to the 2015 peace agreement held a working session in Bamako. This meeting was chaired by the Minister of Social Cohesion, with support from the Carter Center, to examine in detail the progress made with regard to implementing the peace agreement.

On 22 August 2019, the signatories to the 2015 peace agreement held a working session in Bamako. This meeting was chaired by the Minister of Social Cohesion, with support from the Carter Center, to examine in detail the progress made with regard to implementing the peace agreement.

A political crisis and the COVID-19 pandemic brought the implementation of the 2015 peace agreement to a standstill. The CSA held its first-ever meetings outside of Bamako, namely in Kidal, in February 2021.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Another CSA meeting was held in Kayes in March 2021. However, shortly after this meeting, two specific events further stymied the implementation process during the first half of 2021. First, on 13 April 2021, CMA leader Sidi Brahim Ould Sidat was assassinated. Second, a second coup d��tat took place on 24 May 2021.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: After two days of negotiations taking place in Bamako on 5 and 6 April 2021, CMA and of the Platform agreed on the formation of a Cadre Strat�gique Permanente (CSP) (English: Permanent Strategic Coalition). The CSP was aimed at strengthening the relations between the CMA and the Platform, but was also envisioned as a key security provider in the northern regions.
At another meeting between the CMA and Platform in Rome on 6 May 2021, the leaders of the two groups signed the Rome Declaration, confirming the creation of the CSP.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: According to the Carter Center, which acted as the official observer of the implementation process of the Agreement on Peace and Reconciliation in Mali concluded in 2015, the implementation had reached a state of unprecedented impasse in its seventh year. The CSA met in October 2021, but this meeting ended when intense disagreements broke out among the signatories. After this meeting, the work of the CSA and its various subgroups was suspended.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: According to the Carter Center, which acted as the official observer of the implementation process of the Agreement on Peace and Reconciliation in Mali concluded in 2015, the implementation had reached a state of unprecedented impasse in its seventh year.
