description: From 30 January to 3 February 2022, Ara Pacis Initiatives for Peace, an Italian non-profit organization, mediated peace talks between the CMA, Platform, and representatives from the transitional Government, with the Minister for National Reconciliation being part of the government team. The purpose of these talks was to address ongoing tensions between the signatory parties to the Algiers Accord. The talks also focused on disagreement surrounding the Cadre strat�gique permanent (CSP) (English: Permanent strategic coalition).

The signatories to the 2015 peace agreement held a working session in Bamako on 16-17 February 2022. The working session was chaired by the Minister of Social Cohesion, with support from the Carter Center, to examine in detail the progress made with regard to implementing the peace agreement.

On 16 March 2022, the signatories to the Algiers Accord met in Gao to address their ongoing disagreements, particularly regarding the creation and mission of the Cadre strat�gique permanent (CSP) (English: Permanent strategic coalition), which was formed by the CMA and Platform to strengthen the relations between them, but was also envisioned as a key security provider in the northern regions. The Government of Mali insisted that security matters should remain under the state�s authority and that any concerns raised by the movements should be resolved within the framework of the peace agreement. However, there was no concrete resolution reached.

Although the CSA did no longer meet, the Technical Security Commission (CTS) � tasked with monitoring the ceasefire, investigating potential violations, and monitoring security arrangements � met on 31 March 2022.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Although the CSA did no longer meet, the Technical Security Commission (CTS) � tasked with monitoring the ceasefire, investigating potential violations, and monitoring security arrangements � met on 16 June 2022.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: A high-level decision-making meeting was held in Bamako from 1 to 5 August 2022, attended by the Prime Minister, ministers, the High Representative of the transitional President for the implementation of the Agreement, and leaders of the signatory movements. The members of the international mediation team and the Carter Center acting as the Independent Observer were also present. During this meeting, the Malian parties reached an agreement on the integration of ex-combatants into the national defense and security forces and the public administration in two phases.

description: The CSA, having been inactive since October 2021, restarted by initiating a ministerial meeting on 2 September 2022.

description: Consultations were held among the signatories of the Algiers Accord in Bamako on 9 and 10 January 2023 to discuss the way forward regarding the peace agreement. The former Minister for Foreign Affairs of Algeria, Ramtane Lamamra acted as the mediator.

The international mediation team � including Algeria, the UN, ECOWAS, the AU, the EU, France, and the US � shuttled between the conflict parties in February 2023. On 1 February 2023, the international mediation team met with the CMA leadership in Kidal to discuss the viability of the Algiers Accord concluded in 2015. On 13 February 2023, the international mediation team held discussions with the Platform and the Mouvements de l�inclusivit� in Bamako. The international mediation team conducted a meeting with government officials on 14 February 2023. Following these meetings, the international mediation team called on the parties on 20 February 2023, to demonstrate renewed commitment and to refrain from any statements or actions that could further complicate the situation and efforts for the early holding of a high-level session of the CSA.

description: From 20 February to 3 March 2023, the CMA leadership and Platform visited Algeria for a round of negotiations. The former Minister for Foreign Affairs of Algeria Ramtane Lamamra acted as the mediator at these talks.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs of Algeria, Ahmed Attaf, visited Bamako from 23 to 25 April 2023 to urge the signatory parties to fully adhere to the proposals made by the international mediation team.

The Minister for Reconciliation, Peace, and National Cohesion, Colonel-Major Isma�l Wagu�, met with representatives of the CMA and Platform in Kidal on 12 May 2023 to rebuild confidence and facilitate the resumption of the work of the monitoring mechanisms. The Minister for Foreign Affairs of Algeria, Ahmed Attaf, visited Bamako from 23 to 25 April 2023 to urge the signatory parties to fully adhere to the proposals made by the international mediation team.

On 25 January 2024, Mali�s governing junta announced the abrupt end of the 2015 Algiers Accord. The junta attributed this sudden decision to a �shift in stance among some of the agreement�s signatory groups� and �acts of aggression and manipulation of the accord by the Algerian government.�

The CMA entered into a peace process with the Government of Mali in mid-2014. This peace process, which would become known as the Algiers peace process, was supported by a mediation team led by Algeria, including the UN, ECOWAS, the AU, the OIC, the EU, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, and Chad. The first round of official negotiations in the Algiers peace process took place from 14 to 24 July 2014 in Algiers. The Platform alliance � of which the CM-FPR, GATIA, MAA were members � took also part in the Algiers peace process, but the CMA and Platform refused to sit at the same table of negotiation and talks took place on parallel tracks between the government and the CMA on the one side, and the government and the Platform on the other. The CMA refused to negotiate with the Platform because it saw the alliance as a �government militia,� thereby challenging its legitimacy as a full stakeholder in the process. However, CMA and the Platform alliance met in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, from 25 to 28 August 2014. These talks were mediated by Burkina Faso, whose president was the ECOWAS mediator in the Malian crisis, with support from the UN and the AU. This round of negotiations took place in between the first round of the Algiers process in July 2014 and the second round of negotiations that was planned to be held in Algiers in September 2014. After four days of discussions, the talks in Ouagadougou led to the D�claration finale on 28 August 2014. This peace agreement stipulates a ceasefire, but also describes how the CMA and Platform position themselves in talks with the Government of Mali.

While the CMA and Platform were not engaged in direct negotiations during most of the Algiers process, this changed during the final phase of the process. The Government of Mali, the CMA, and Platform entered negotiations in Algiers on 30 May 2015. They signed the Relev� de Conclusions des Consultations Pr�paratoires � la mise en �uvre de l�Accord pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali Issu du Procesus d�Alger (English: Statement of Conclusions of the Preparatory Consultations for the Implementation of the Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation in Mali Arising from the Algiers Process) on 5 June 2015, which addressed the creation of two regions in Mali, the integration of rebel fighters into the national army, and several arrangements to promote regional economic development. On the same day, the conflict parties also signed another ceasefire agreement, the Arrangement s�curitaire pour une cessation des hostilit�s (English: Security Arrangements for a Cessation of Hostilities).
agreement_name: Relev� de Conclusions des Consultations Pr�paratoires � la mise en �uvre de l�Accord pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali Issu du Procesus d�Alger, Arrangement s�curitaire pour une cessation des hostilit�s

description: This paved the way for the Government of Mali, the CMA, and Platform signing a comprehensive peace agreement in Bamako on 20 June 2015: the Accord Pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali - Issu du Processus d�Alger (English: Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation in Mali - Resulting from the Algiers Process), also referred to as the Bamako Agreement.
agreement_name: Accord Pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali - Issu du Processus d�Alger

description: Another round of negotiations between the members of the monitoring committee � the Comit� du Suivi du present Accord (CSA) � was held in late July 2015 to discuss the implementation process, but the members of the committee disagreed on certain stipulations of the implementation process, such as representation and responsibility sharing. The CSA comprises the Government of Mali, the CMA, Platform, as well as the mediation team chaired by Algeria and further including Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the United Nations, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, the African Union, and the European Union.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: The CSA also met in August 2015.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: A monitoring committee � the Comit� de Suivi du present Accord (CSA) � to oversee the implementation of the agreement was set up under the terms of the Bamako Agreement. The CSA comprises the Government of Mali, the CMA, Platform, as well as the mediation team chaired by Algeria and further including Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the United Nations, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, the African Union, and the European Union. The CSA met for negotiations on the implementation in Bamako between 3 and 5 July 2015. The UN Secretary General�s Special Representative convened this meeting. Under his auspices, the parties concluded another ceasefire and promised to end all incursions into the areas under the other party�s control. The parties also agreed to initiate dialogue in An�fis, with a goal of solving the long-standing intercommunal and intra-communal tensions at the root of the conflict between them.
third_party: Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU

description: The UN Secretary General�s Special Representative mediated a round of negotiations that led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 23 September 2015.

On 27 and 28 September 2015, a CMA delegation held meetings with President Ibrahim Boubacar Ke�ta and the leaders of the Platform in Bamako. Following the meetings, CMA announced that it would stick to the ceasefire and order its combatants to refrain from using force against the troops of the Government forces and Platform.

Between 27 September and 14 October 2015, CMA and the Platform engaged in direct talks in An�fis. At the end of the talks, the parties endorsed a road map � the Anefis road map � comprising a series of measures, including the cessation of hostilities, joint initiatives for intercommunal and intra-communal reconciliation, the exchange of prisoners, the establishment of interim local administrations and the free movement of people and goods. During and following the An�fis talks, CMA and the Platform mediated a series of intercommunal and intra-communal reconciliation agreements in Gao, Kidal and Timbuktu regions, including between the Ifoghas and Imghad Tuareg communities affiliated with CMA and the Platform, respectively.

The CSA�s efforts to implement the Bamako Peace Agreement continued in 2016. The CMA and Platform were both unhappy with the slow pace of the implementation of the agreement. Hence, the signatories met in Bamako on 19-26 February 2016, but no progress was made. While the Government of Mali presented the measures that it had taken, including the creation of the M�naka and Taoudenni regions and the review of the Code des collectivit�s territoriales, the signatory armed groups, in a joint letter, deplored the lack of progress on the establishment of the interim administrations, reiterating the need for further efforts on institutional issues before moving forward on security and defense aspects.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Another meeting to discuss the implementation of the Bamako Agreement was held in New York on 23 September 2016, on the margins of the general debate of the seventy-first session of the UN General Assembly. The opening session of the meeting was chaired by the UN Secretary-General together with the President of Mali, Ibrahim Boubacar Keita. The goal of the meeting was to mitigate the tensions that had arisen surrounding the implementation of the Bamako Agreement between July and September 2016. Following the opening session, a meeting was co-chaired by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, International Cooperation and African Integration of Mali, Abdoulaye Diop, and the Minister of State, Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation of Algeria, Ramtane Lamamra, together with the UN Under-Secretary-General for Peacekeeping Operations. In the Co-Chairs� summary of the meeting, the signatories of the Bamako Agreement were urged to fully and sincerely maintain their commitments under the agreement and encouraged to take specific steps to swiftly implement the agreement.

Another meeting on the implementation of the agreement took place on 23 October 2016. During this meeting it was decided to start implementation of the agreement in November 2016, but this did not happen.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Another CSA meeting on the implementation of the agreement took place on 28 November 2016.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: At another CSA meeting on 20 December 2016, the CMA representatives announced the suspension of its participation in the CSA because of a lack of progress in the implementation of the Bamako Agreement. On 16 January 2017, MINUSMA mediated between government representatives and CMA leaders in Kidal to discuss a return of the CMA to the CSA, but Platform representatives did not participate in this meeting. Following a deadly terrorist attack in Gao on 18 January 2017 � which killed 54 members of a mixed patrol including forces from the government, Platform, and the CMA � the mediators tried to prevent a collapse of the peace process. An international mediation team, including ministers from the Governments of Algeria, Mauritania, and the Niger continued to urge CMA to continue its participation in the CSA. While a CSA meeting was held on 30 January 2017 in Bamako without the presence of CMA, the CMA remained involved in trying to set up mixed patrols in Gao. On 23 February 2017, the signatory parties launched the first mixed patrols in Gao.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

This conference adopted several recommendations, including, among others, the need to address governance and security issues in the central regions and a lack of inclusiveness in the peace process.
On 23 August 2017, MINUSMA mediated between the CMA and Platform, which led to the conclusion of a 15-day ceasefire in Kidal. The ceasefire was extended on 6 September 2017.

third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: On 18 July 2015, tribal leaders participated in a round of negotiations that led to a ceasefire. However, this ceasefire broke down just days later.
Another round of negotiations led to a ceasefire on 25 July 2015.
Qatar began a round of negotiations between the two tribes in Doha on 23 November 2015. The conflict parties signed a ceasefire agreement in Doha on 25 November 2015.
Fighting took place again in January 2016, when tribal leaders met to implement the Doha agreement. Negotiations in February 2016 led to the signing of a comprehensive peace agreement.
The Community of Sant�Egidio mediated a humanitarian accord in Rome on 16 June 2016 between various tribes in the Fezzan region in order to provide aid.

In March 2017, 60 tribal representatives engaged in negotiations in Rome mediated by the Libyan Presidency Council, the Italian Interior Minister Marco Minniti, the Ara Pacis Initiative, and the Community of Sant�Egidio. This led to the signing of the Reconciliation and Peace Agreement on 29 March 2017 and a document regarding methods for implementation on 31 March. A faction of the Toubou tribe rejected this agreement on 6 April and fighting resumed. On 7 April 2018, the Supreme Council of the Tribes and Cities of Fezzan called for a ceasefire for the region. In response, the Toubou announced a unilateral ceasefire on 9 April.
third_party: government, Italy, Ara Pacis Initiative, Community of Sant'Egidio

description: Local leaders mediated a round of negotiations between the two sides, which led to a ceasefire on 19 February 2012. This ceasefire soon broke down.
The government sent an armed force to quell fighting in March and another ceasefire was brokered on 26 March 2012. However, fighting resumed days later.
A round of mediation led by local authorities succeeded in getting the two sides to agree to a ceasefire on 7 July 2012.
The conflict parties reached a truce during a round of bilateral negotiations on 11 May 2013, but this did not prove sustainable.
Negotiations led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 26 July 2015.

UNSMIL mediated a round of peace talks in Tunis from 19 to 20 February 2018. The two conflict parties agreed to a document outlining mechanisms for reconciliation, which was signed by the conflict parties on 21 February.

While several peace committees had been set up in the conflict area in 2014, these committees refrained from mediating. Instead, a peace meeting was facilitated by the Kabarole Research and Resource Centre, Peace and Justice Commission in the Catholic diocese, and the Rwenzori Forum for Peace and Justice in early April 2016.

On 14 April 2016, another round of negotiations, mediated by Ugandan government officials and religious leaders, led to the conclusion of a 4-point communique that included provisions for peace and inter-community dialogue.
In late April 2016, President Yoweri Museveni subsequently mediated another round of peace talks between the leaders of the conflict parties that led to the conclusion of an informal peace agreement.

In March 2017, the Community of Sant�Egidio started a mediation process, with Andrea Riccardi acting as the chief mediator. UN envoy Parfait Onanga-Anyanga, the European Union, and the Italian Government had an observer status during the negotiations. With peace talks ongoing in Rome, FPRC fighters launched an offensive against anti-Balaka elements in Bakouma on 6 June 2017, following an anti-Balaka attack on Nzako. This persuaded the conflict parties at the negotiations to sign a peace agreement on 19 June 2017, stipulating an immediate ceasefire. This agreement, referred to as the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic, was signed by the RPRC, FPRC, FDPC, UPC, RPRC, RJ BELANGA, UFR-F, UPC, RJ SAYO, UFR-F, FPRC, UFR, RJ SAYO, MPC, SELEKA Renovee, Coordination anti-Balaka, anti-Balaka Mokom, MLJC, RJ Belanga, FDPC, MLJC, and the UFR. The agreement reaffirmed the 2016 elections. In addition, the agreement called for the integration of all �politico-military groups� into the peace process and a restoration of state authority. The agreement also included an immediate countrywide ceasefire. The ceasefire did not hold. Armed clashes between several armed groups already took place in the Bria area already one day after the signing of the ceasefire.
third_party: Community of Sant�Egidio, UN, EU, Italy
agreement_name: Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic

description: On 28 June 2017, President Faustin Archange Touad�ra held meetings with the representatives of the 14 armed groups that had signed a peace agreement in Rome on 19 June.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: With it being clear that the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic of June 2017 did not succeed, the AU presented its roadmap for peace in Libreville on 17 July 2017. The roadmap agreement assigns the responsibility for leading peace negotiations in CAR to the AU, while pledging to take into account the achievements of previous peace initiatives including the June 2017 Sant�Egidio Agreement. The Roadmap created an African Panel of Facilitators, with panel members from the AU, ECCAS, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, Angola, Chad, the Republic of Congo, and Gabon. MINUSCA was granted observer status.The African Panel of Facilitators mediated for the first time Bangui between 11 and 12 September 2017.

Active fighting between the coalition of the FPRC, MPC, RPRC, and the Anti-Balaka-Mokom on the one side and the UPC on the other side had started in Bambari in November 2016, greatly decreased from April 2017 onwards. On 27 June 2017, the Prefect of Haute-Kotto set up a local mediation committee to resolve the conflict. MINUSCA pledged to support the committee�s efforts. The UPC and the FPRC entered into negotiations mediated by Christian and Muslim religious leaders in Bria on 17 September 2017. On 21 September 2017, a team of emissaries from Bangui and Birao arrived in Bria to take over the mediation process from the religious leaders. This paved the way for negotiations in Ippy.

On 2 October 2017, Abdoulaye Hissene, leader of a faction of the FPRC, arrived in Ippy to conduct negotiations with anti-Balaka-Mokum and the UPC concerning the conclusion of a ceasefire in the region. While the emissaries from Bangui and Birao mediated between the conflict parties, civil society leaders and a community liaison assistant from MINUSCA civil affairs and representatives of the MINSUCA force also participated in the peace meeting in Ippy. On 6 October 2017, the anti-Balaka-Mokom, UPC, and FPRC signed the Ippy Accord. This agreement led to renewed UPC dominance.
third_party: government, local government, community leaders, MINUSCA

description: In mid-April 2018, the FPRC once more organized a conference to unify the ex-Seleka movement, negotiating with the UPC and the MPC in Kaga Bandoro, but the conference did not lead to an agreement. Russia and Sudan started a national-level mediation effort in August 2018, but instead of making peace between the FPRC and the UPC this mediation effort was aimed at negotiations between the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the one side and the anti-Balaka (represented by Maxime Mokom) on the other side. These negotiations led to the signing of declaration of understanding and a pledge to support the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation in CAR led by the AU and regional states with the support of the UN. Furthermore, the AU, with support from MINUSCA, organized a meeting between 14 armed groups in Bouar between 28 and 30 August. The meeting produced a document with demands to the government, signed by all 14 groups that participated in the meeting. The document was handed over to the government following the meeting.

The Civil Affairs section of the MINUSCA Field Office in Zemio, together with community leaders, supported a peace effort between the UPC and the FPRC, which led to a reconciliation agreement signed in October 2018.

Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Nga�ssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, S�l�ka R�nov�e, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: The Civil Affairs section of the MINUSCA Field Office in Zemio, together with community leaders, supported a peace effort between the UPC and the FPRC, which led to a reconciliation agreement signed on 24 November 2019. The document serves to remind the parties to respect the peace agreements previously signed in Zemio in October 2018.

Following clashes in March 2014, the acting secretary-general of South Sudan�s ruling party � the Sudan People�s Liberation Movement (SPLM) - Anne Itto conducted a surprise visit to talk to local governors and mediate between representatives of the Panyar Dinka and the Waat Dinka in Rumbek. In February 2016 the Panyar Dinka concluded an alliance with the Rek Dinka against the Waat Dinka, with whom they had clashed earlier in 2016.

Vice-President Osinbajo met with the three governors of the states in which the armed conflict took place � namely with Udom Emmanuel of Akwa Ibom State, Ben Ayade of Cross River State, and Dave Umahi of Ebonyi State � at the presidential villa in Abuja on 28 February 2017. The meeting was aimed at planning how to find a way out of the armed conflict between the Ikot-Offiong and Oku Iboku communities. The Governor of Akwa Ibom, Udom Emmanuel, subsequently met with youth and leaders of the fighting community of Oku Iboku in the Itu Local Government Area on 23 April 2017 and called for peace between the two communities.

The federal government convened a peace meeting, mediated by Director General of the National Border Commission Muhammad Ahmad, between the leaders of the conflict parties at the bridge between the Odukpani and Itu Local Government Areas on 11 July 2017. The leaders of the conflict parties expressed their commitment to peace during this meeting.
A delegation led by the Minister of Justice, who originates from the region visited Bouma on 26 March 2016 to mediate between the conflict parties. This mediation effort did not lead to an agreement.
The German development agency, Deutsche Gesellschaft f�r Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ), facilitated a community dialogue between the communities in February 2019.

Following another clash in June 2016, government forces were deployed to the area to end the violence. With support from UNAMID, the conflict parties signed a peace agreement on 22 July 2016. Yet, the Mahadi tribal leadership expressed dissatisfaction with this agreement because it did not include any provisions on compensation (diya) and that the Rizeeigat Abbala continued occupy of their land.

On 6 April, the governors of North and West Kordofan declared the State of Emergency for the period of one month in order to contain the situation. Government forces subsequently managed to separate the warring tribesmen at Um Marahik. A committee was established to investigate the incident and the West Kordofan police were tasked to arrest those that engage in armed violence. On 14 April 2017, the Governor of North Kordofan, Governor Ahmed Haroun, tried to initiate peace negotiations between the leaders of the two tribes. Together with the Chief of the Kababish tribe, he traveled to the territory of the Hamar tribe near En Nahud in West Kordofan.

Deputy Governor of Cross River State Professor Ivara Esu and Senator Ben Ayade mediated between the members of the two communities in early July 2017. The mediators called on the Wanhihem and Wanikade communities to not return to armed conflict and to agree on clear boundaries between them. The conflict parties did not conclude a peace agreement.

Another peace meeting was held in Mfuma in the Yala Local Government Area on 15 July 2017. Wanhihem and Wanikade leaders, as well representatives of other Ukulle people to which both communities belong, signed a communiqu� at this peace meeting. This communiqu� stipulates a ceasefire between the two communities, as well as calls upon the federal government to assist them in resolving the conflict and to establish a Judicial Commission of Inquiry into the conflict and a Truth and Reconciliation Committee.

After the resumption of the conflict between the Kadara and Fulani in Kajuru in Kaduna Stat in February 2019, the Miyetti Allah Cattle Breeders Association of Nigeria (MACBAN) mediated between the conflict parties in March 2019.

A Truth and Reconciliation Committee composed of Fulani and Kadara representatives was set up by the Kajuru government in March 2019. The committee was tasked to find a solution to the ongoing crisis and ensure a ceasefire. This committee was reportedly successful, and fighting ended in the region in August 2019. On the weekend of 19 and 20 October 2019, the Commander of the Nigerian Naval Weapons Technology School in Kachia in Kaduna State), Commodore Tanko Yakubu Pani, mediated between leaders of the Fulani and Kadara communities. The communities, who were given two weeks to surrender their weapons or face sanctions, pledged to contribute to the return of peace in the region. No written agreement was signed on this occasion.

Negotiations between traditional dozo hunters and members of the JNIM in the Niono district in the S�gou region started in October 2020. The negotiations took place in the wake of JNIM militants besieging several villages in the Niono district, accusing the inhabitants of collaborating with the government. Eight emissaries from the High Islamic Council of Mali mediated the talks, which were supported by the junta government in Bamako. After several months of negotiations, the delegates reached an agreement for a ceasefire on 14 March 2021. The meeting took place in the bush near Niono. However, fighting resumed in September 2021, with both sides accusing each other of violating the terms of the agreement.
third_party: High Islamic Council of Mali, Junta Government of Bamako

description: The UCDP records clashes between the MPC and the anti-Balaka for the first time in February 2017, but there were already some mediation efforts between MPC and the anti-Balaka in 2015. A local peace process in Batangafo, with support from the Bossangoa field office of MINUSCA, led to the conclusion of a weapon-free zone agreement in December 2015.

Building on the weapon-free zone agreement that had been concluded in Batangafo in December 2015, MINUSCA mediated a non-aggression pact between the anti-Balaka and the ex-S�l�ka, including the FPRC and MPC, in Batangafo on 29 March 2016.

On 8 March 2016, the MPC and anti-Balaka operating on Kaga Bandoro-Bangui axis signed a Protocole de non agression (English: Non-Aggression Protocol). The agreement was mediated by the MINUSCA field office in Kaga-Bandoro, with involvement from the Local Peace and Reconciliation Committee (CLPR), religious leaders, and local authorities.
third_party: MINUSCA, religious leaders, local government, local peace committee

description: The anti-Balaka on the one hand and the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the other hand signed a non-aggression pact in the sub-prefecture of Mbr�s on 8 June 2016. The agreement was mediated by the MINUSCA field office in Kaga-Bandoro, with involvement from the Local Peace and Reconciliation Committee (CLPR), religious leaders, and local authorities.
third_party: MINUSCA, religious leaders, local government, local peace committee

UN envoy Parfait Onanga-Anyanga, the European Union, and the Italian Government had an observer status during the negotiations. With peace talks ongoing in Rome, FPRC fighters launched an offensive against anti-Balaka elements in Bakouma on 6 June 2017, following an anti-Balaka attack on Nzako. This agreement, referred to as the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic, was signed by the RPRC, FPRC, FDPC, UPC, RPRC, RJ BELANGA, UFR-F, UPC, RJ SAYO, UFR-F, FPRC, UFR, RJ SAYO, MPC, SELEKA Renovee, Coordination anti-Balaka, anti-Balaka Mokom, MLJC, RJ Belanga, FDPC, MLJC, and the UFR. The agreement reaffirmed the 2016 elections. In addition, the agreement called for the integration of all �politico-military groups� into the peace process and a restoration of state authority. The agreement also included an immediate countrywide ceasefire. The ceasefire did not hold. Armed clashes between several armed groups already took place in the Bria area already one day after the signing of the ceasefire.
