description: On 28 June 2017, President Faustin Archange Touad�ra held meetings with the representatives of the 14 armed groups that that had signed a peace agreement in Rome on 19 June.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: With it being clear that the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic of June 2017 did not succeed, the AU presented its roadmap for peace in Libreville on 17 July 2017. The roadmap agreement assigns the responsibility for leading peace negotiations in CAR to the AU, while pledging to take into account the achievements of previous peace initiatives including the June 2017 Sant�Egidio Agreement. The Roadmap created an African Panel of Facilitators, with panel members from the AU, ECCAS, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, Angola, Chad, the Republic of Congo, and Gabon. MINUSCA was granted observer status. The African Panel of Facilitators mediated for the first time Bangui between 11 and 12 September 2017.

Another local peace process took place in early 2018. Mediation by local authorities and MINUSCA led to the conclusion of the Accord entre les Groupes Arm�s de Batangafo on 24 February 2018. The signatories were the anti-Balaka and the ex-S�l�ka, including the FPRC and MPC.
agreement_name: Accord entre les Groupes Arm�s de Batangafo

description: On 28 August 2018, Russia � which had begun supplying the CAR government with arms and military instructors in February 2018 � and Sudan mediated negotiations between the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the one side and the anti-Balaka (represented by Maxime Mokom) on the other side. These negotiations led to the signing of declaration of understanding and a pledge to support the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation in CAR led by the AU and regional states with the support of the UN. The UPC and MPC expressed they were no longer committed to this declaration in October 2018, but they made it clear that they still supported the African Initiative. Furthermore, the AU, with support from MINUSCA, organized a meeting between 14 armed groups in Bouar between 28 and 30 August. The meeting produced a document with demands to the government, signed by all 14 groups that participated in the meeting. The document was handed over to the government following the meeting.

Mediation by local authorities and MINUSCA led to the conclusion of the Accord entre les Groupes Arm�s de Batangafo on 12 January 2019. An agreement with exactly the same name had been signed in February 2018. The second agreement, signed in January 2019, was prompted by the failure of the February 2018 accord following violent incidents in late October 2018. The parties involved in the initial accord � the anti-Balaka and the ex-S�l�ka, including the FPRC and MPC � also signed this subsequent agreement, which encompasses the same provisions. However, notable additions were made, as the new agreement received endorsements from local authorities and representatives of civil society.
agreement_name: Accord entre les Groupes Arm�s de Batangafo

description: Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Nga�ssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, S�l�ka R�nov�e, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) and MINUSCA, with support from local officials and traditional and religious leaders, mediated a round of negotiations between the UPC, MPC, RPRC, MLJC, anti-Balaka-Molokom, and FPRC in Bria from 1 to 9 April 2019. This led to the signing of the Bria Accord on 9 April 2019. This local agreement was aimed at reinforcing the implementation of the 6 February 2019 national agreement. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire to end to the violence in Haute-Kotto and Ouaka prefectures, as well as guaranteed the safe and free movement of persons, goods, and humanitarian aid on the main axis.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), MINUSCA, local government, traditional leaders, religious leaders

description: The Somali government immediately ordered an end to the fighting. In order to reconcile the two communities, a government delegation mediated negotiations attended by 20 individuals from both sides.

Negotiations between representatives of Irigwe, Hausa, and Fulani communities led to the signing of a peace agreement in Bassa in Plateau State on 8 February 2011. The president of the Bassa local council, government representatives, soldiers from the Special Task Force, and police officers acted as mediators during the peace talks.
third_party: local government, government, government forces, police

description: In response to armed clashes in 2017, soldiers from the Special Task Force launched a military operation to create a safe haven in 2017 � dubbed Operation Safe Haven � and convened a series of peace meeting between leaders of the two feuding tribes. However, the violence continued.

The many meetings convened the Special Task Force cumulated in the signing of a ceasefire agreement in early August 2018. Major-General Augustine Chris Agundu, the Commander of the Operation Safe Haven, mediated between the conflict parties at these meetings.

After the alleged attack by an Irigwe man on Fulani people and their livestock in March 2019, the police summoned a peace meeting between the two communities to ensure that such an event would not occur again. However, violence resumed between the two communities in April 2019. On 21 September 2019, on the occasion of the World Peace Day, the Plateau Peace Building Agency (PPBA) facilitated a peace parley between the Irigwe and Fulani leaders in Miango district in the Local Government Area of Bassa in Plateau State. The two leaders of the conflict parties, who had not met in six years, signed a peace agreement and expressed their hope for long-lasting peace in the area. However, attacks resumed only two days later.

On 19 July 2021, the social media peace agreement was signed by youth representatives of the Bache, Fulani and Irigwe ethnic groups in the Bassa local government area of Plateau state. The agreement was facilitated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) and commits the delegates to take actions for reducing harmful behavior online and to serve as ambassadors to promote better online conduct, peaceful co-existence and tolerance among the three communities.

In February 2022, Operation Safe Haven, a multi-security task force aimed at maintaining peace in Plateau and some parts of Bauchi and Kaduna states, organized a peace summit to tackle the lingering crisis between Irigwe and Fulani ethnic groups in Bassa Local Government Area of Plateau State. The peace summit was held in Jos and was organized for youths drawn from the warring parties in Bassa Local Government Area.

In July 2022, a peace accord was signed between the Irigwe and Fulani communities in Plateau State. The agreement was witnessed by various individuals and organizations including the chairman of Bassa local government, Plateau Inter-Religious Council, Kaduna Peace Commission, MACBAN, United States Institute for Peace, among others. The document was produced by a 16-man committee, comprising the two ethnic groups which held a series of consultations, conducted investigations on the causes of the conflicts, and examined modalities for sustainable peace.
third_party: Local government, Plateau Inter-Religious Council, Kaduna Peace Commission, MACBAN, United States Institute for Peace

description: In July 2023, the commander of Plateau State�s Sector 3 Military Command hosted a dialogue to foster peace and unity between the Fulani community in Plateau and leaders of the local Irigwe community. The peace talk was attended by International Christian Concern (ICC), an international NGO, and at least 100 stakeholders from the Fulani and Irigwe communities as well as leaders from other ethnic groups.
third_party: Military Command, International Christian Concern (ICC), local leaders

description: The MINUSCA field office in Bouar town initiated a mediation effort between 3R and anti-Balaka in December 2017. The Prefect of the Nana-Mamb�r� Prefecture and Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) were also involved in this mediation effort. On 15 December 2017, 3R and anti-Balaka signed the Acte d�engagement entre les groupes anti-Balakas de la Nana-Mamb�r� et les 3R. The agreement stipulated a cessation of hostilities, non-use of arms, freedom of movement, and the establishment of information network made up of community leaders, and leaders of the two armed groups. The implementation of the agreement was relatively successful since it contributed to a decrease in violence and direct confrontation between the groups, an improvement in the free movement of people and goods and a considerable decline in livestock theft.
third_party: MINUSCA, local government, Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD)
agreement_name: Acte d�engagement entre les groupes anti-Balakas de la Nana-Mamb�r� et les 3R

description: Another local-level peace procces took place between the anti-Balaka and 3R in Koui-De gaulle between 18 and 20 October 2018. This resulted in the signing of the D�claration de coordination des groupes arm�s � plateforme Rassemblement Centrafricain pour la Paix (English: Declaration of coordination of the armed groups - Central African Rally for Peace Platform). Furthermore, the AU, with support from MINUSCA, organized a meeting between 14 armed groups in Bouar between 28 and 30 August. The meeting produced a document with demands to the government, signed by all 14 groups that participated in the meeting. The document was handed over to the government following the meeting.
agreement_name: D�claration de coordination des groupes arm�s � plateforme Rassemblement Centrafricain pour la Paix

description: Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Nga�ssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, S�l�ka R�nov�e, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: On 11 November 2017, under an alleged authorization of Abdoulaye Hissene, a local mediation team and a MINUSCA Community Liaison Assistant (CLA) mediated an agreement between the rival wings of the FPRC. The FPRC-AK wing subsequently returned to Bria on 27 November 2017.
A mediation team led by FPRC military leader Abdoulaye Hisseine mediated between the rival factions of the FPRC in the locality of Tissi-Fongoro in December 2018.

Immediately after armed clashes between the Bwatiye and Fulani on 4 December 2017, vice-president Yemi Osinbajo held separate talks with both sides, trying to convince the conflict parties to stop fighting.

In mid-December 2017, the Secretary to the Government of the Federation Boss Mustapha visited the leaders of the Bwatyie and Fulani. He called upon the communities to stop fighting, but no agreement was concluded as a result of these shuttle talks.

On 27 July 2017, Jabhat Fateh al-Sham militants part of the HTS alliance raised the white flag and negotiated a ceasefire agreement in the northern Beqaa Valley of Lebanon with Hezbollah. This ceasefire was mediated by the Lebanese General Security Director, Major-General Abbas Ibrahim. The deal called for a cessation of hostilities and the return of captured Hezbollah fighters in exchange for allowing the militants and their families to leave Lebanon for Idlib in Syria.
third_party: Lebanese General Security Director and Major General Abbas Ibrahim

description: Security chiefs from both groups were brought together to discuss the violence in December 2017.

The Pakam Dinka and Rup Dinka attended a two-day peace conference in Greater Lakes on 26 January 2019. This effort was organized by the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS), African Mission Assistance (AMA), and Oxfam. This round of peace talks ended with a peace agreement on 28 January 2019.

The South Sudanese government and the SPLM/A-IO signed a peace agreement in Addis Ababa on 12 September 2018, referred to as the Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan (R-ARCSS). Following the signing of the R-ARCSS, the South Sudanese government and SPLM/A-IO representatives continued engagement to persuade the NAS to sign and implement the agreement. During a meeting in Texas on 23 September 2018, the NAS leader said his group is not committed to the ceasefire in South Sudan even if their group is a signatory to the security arrangements.

In April 2022, the Congolese government and various armed groups attended a peace conference in Nairobi. The peace conference was held under the auspices of the East African Community (EAC). Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta acted as the EAC mediator during the peace conference. Both the CNPSC and the Twiganeho participated in the Nairobi peace process. CNPSC leader Yakutumba sent his spokesperson to Nairobi, while Twirwaneho was represented by a close member of the diaspora based locally in Nairobi.
A second peace conference organized by the EAC was held in Nairobi in June 2022.

A third peace conference organized by the EAC was held in Nairobi between 28 November 2022 and 6 December 2022. Former President of Kenya Uhuru Kenyatta acted as the chief mediator at this peace conference.

side_b: Operations Room Combating Daesh, Shuhada al-Wadi militia
description: Surrounding cities sent peace delegations to mediate an end to the fighting. The United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) urged the parties to cease hostilities in order to allow for citizen to flee the conflict area. Anas al-Dabbashi and Operations Room Combating Daesh subsequently agreed to a three-hour ceasefire on 18 September 2017 to allow residents to leave the conflict area.

side_b: Operations Room Combating Daesh, Shuhada al-Wadi militia
description: Following a diplomatic effort by the Libyan government on 2 October 2017, Anas al-Dabbashi and Operations Room Combating Daesh agreed to another humanitarian ceasefire. The Shuhada al-Wadi militia and Operations Room Combating Daesh managed to defeat Anas al-Dabbashi and Brigade 48 from Sabratha on 6 October 2017.

Negotiations in Miketo, facilitated by MONUSCO, led to the signing of a peace agreement on 20 January. MONUSCO agreed to support the implementation of this agreement. On 22 February 2017, the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of the Interior and Security, Emmanuel Ramazani Shadary, arrived in Kalemie, the capital of Tanganyika, to discuss the recent fighting between the Pygmies and the Bantu. According to a civil society organization which attended the meeting, this meeting did not help to resolve the conflict because no representatives of the conflict parties were invited to participate in the meeting. Fighting continued.

On 24 February, following a mediation effort by the Congolese authorities, the leaders of the communities signed a Peaceful Coexistence pact in Kalemie of the Tanganyika province. The Batabwa on the one side and the Bambuti and the Batwa on the other side did not engage in any armed clashes after the signing of this pact.

In March 2017, the Community of Sant�Egidio started a mediation process, with Andrea Riccardi acting as the chief mediator. UN envoy Parfait Onanga-Anyanga, the European Union, and the Italian Government had an observer status during the negotiations. With peace talks ongoing in Rome, FPRC fighters launched an offensive against anti-Balaka elements in Bakouma on 6 June 2017, following an anti-Balaka attack on Nzako. This persuaded the conflict parties at the negotiations to sign a peace agreement on 19 June 2017, stipulating an immediate ceasefire. This agreement, referred to as the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic, was signed by the RPRC, FPRC, FDPC, UPC, RPRC, RJ BELANGA, UFR-F, UPC, RJ SAYO, UFR-F, FPRC, UFR, RJ SAYO, MPC, SELEKA Renovee, Coordination anti-Balaka, anti-Balaka Mokom, MLJC, RJ Belanga, FDPC, MLJC, and the UFR. The agreement reaffirmed the 2016 elections. In addition, the agreement called for the integration of all �politico-military groups� into the peace process and a restoration of state authority. The agreement also included an immediate countrywide ceasefire. The ceasefire did not hold. Armed clashes between several armed groups already took place in the Bria area already one day after the signing of the ceasefire.
third_party: Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, EU, Italy
agreement_name: Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic

description: On 28 June, President Faustin Archange Touad�ra held meetings with the representatives of the 14 armed groups that had signed a peace agreement in Rome on 19 June.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: With it being clear that the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic of June 2017 did not succeed, the AU presented its roadmap for peace in Libreville on 17 July 2017. The roadmap agreement assigns the responsibility for leading peace negotiations in CAR to the AU, while pledging to take into account the achievements of previous peace initiatives including the June 2017 Sant�Egidio Agreement. The Roadmap created an African Panel of Facilitators, with panel members from the AU, ECCAS, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, Angola, Chad, the Republic of Congo, and Gabon. MINUSCA was granted observer status. The African Panel of Facilitators mediated for the first time Bangui between 11 and 12 September 2017.

On 27 June 2017, the Prefect of Haute-Kotto set up a mediation committee to resolve the conflict. MINUSCA pledged to support the committee�s efforts. The UPC and the FPRC entered into negotiations mediated by Christian and Muslim religious leaders in Bria on 17 September 2017. On 21 September 2017, a team of emissaries from Bangui and Birao arrived in Bria to take over the mediation process from the religious leaders. This paved the way for negotiations in Ippy.

On 2 October 2017, Abdoulaye Hissene, leader of a faction of the FPRC, arrived in Ippy to conduct negotiations with anti-Balaka-Mokum and the UPC concerning the conclusion of a ceasefire in the region. While the emissaries from Bangui and Birao mediated between the conflict parties, civil society leaders and a community liaison assistant from MINUSCA civil affairs and representatives of the MINSUCA force also participated in the peace meeting in Ippy. On 6 October 2017, the anti-Balaka-Mokom, UPC, and FPRC signed the Ippy Accord. This agreement led to renewed UPC dominance. In addition to this local peace process aimed at ending violence between the conflict parties in the Bambari area, the conflict parties were involved in a national-level peace process in 2017.

In mid-April 2018, the FPRC once more organized a conference to unify the ex-Seleka movement, negotiating with the UPC and the MPC in Kaga Bandoro, but the conference did not lead to an agreement. Russia and Sudan started a national-level mediation effort in August 2018, but instead of making peace between the MPC and the UPC, this mediation effort was aimed at negotiations between the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the one side and the anti-Balaka (represented by Maxime Mokom) on the other side. These negotiations led to the signing of declaration of understanding and a pledge to support the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation in CAR led by the AU and regional states with the support of the UN. Furthermore, the AU, with support from MINUSCA, organized a meeting between 14 armed groups in Bouar between 28 and 30 August. The meeting produced a document with demands to the government, signed by all 14 groups that participated in the meeting. The document was handed over to the government following the meeting.

On 28 August 2018, Russia � which had begun supplying the CAR government with arms and military instructors in February 2018 � and Sudan mediated negotiations between the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the one side and the anti-Balaka (represented by Maxime Mokom) on the other side. These negotiations led to the signing of declaration of understanding and a pledge to support the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation in CAR led by the AU and regional states with the support of the UN. The UPC and MPC expressed they were no longer committed to this declaration in October 2018, but they made it clear that they still supported the African Initiative. Furthermore, the AU, with support from MINUSCA, organized a meeting between 14 armed groups in Bouar between 28 and 30 August. The meeting produced a document with demands to the government, signed by all 14 groups that participated in the meeting. The document was handed over to the government following the meeting.

Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Nga�ssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, S�l�ka R�nov�e, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) and MINUSCA, with support from local officials and traditional and religious leaders, mediated a round of negotiations between the UPC, MPC, RPRC, MLJC, anti-Balaka-Molokom, and FPRC in Bria from 1 to 9 April 2019. This led to the signing of the Bria Accord on 9 April 2019. This local agreement was aimed at reinforcing the implementation of the 6 February 2019 national agreement. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire to end to the violence in Haute-Kotto and Ouaka prefectures, as well as guaranteed the safe and free movement of persons, goods, and humanitarian aid on the main axis.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), MINUSCA, local government, traditional leaders, religious leaders

description: Negotiations, mediated by representatives of government forces, led to a reconciliation agreement on 17 August 2013.
On 19 August 2013, local authorities from Regnae arrived to mediate between the conflict parties.

On 21 August 2013, a local peace committee with members from both tribes held a meeting with community members, as well as religious, local, and regional authorities in the town. At this meeting, the Arab Brabich and Idnan signed the Document d�initiation au dialogue pour r�habiliter le calme et cesser l�effusion du sang afin d�atteindre la reconciliation.
third_party: local peace committee, religious leaders, traditional leaders, local government
agreement_name: Document d�initiation au dialogue pour r�habiliter le calme et cesser l�effusion du sang afin d�atteindre la reconciliation

description: In July 2018, the two groups met to negotiate, but no peace accord was concluded.

In January 2019, the CMA represented by Salah Ag Ahmed and Alhousseiny Ag Ahmedou and the MSA represented by Mohamed Ag Kassoum engaged in bilateral negotiations, which led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 20 January 2019. However, fighting resumed the next month.
Another round of bilateral negotiations in Tinfadimata in May 2019 led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 21 May 2019.
The United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) mediated negotiations between the conflict parties on 19 November 2014, which led to the conclusion of a humanitarian ceasefire for 12 hours.
UNSMIL supported local mediation efforts between the conflict parties in 2016. On 10 December 2016, the LNA declared a six-hour unilateral ceasefire for citizen evacuation.
UNSMIL supported local mediation efforts between the conflict parties in 2017.

On 13 March 2020, intercommunity talks were held in Uvira. The talks led to a ceasefire agreement, signed by representatives from various armed groups and local defense forces, such as Biloze Bishambuke, Mai-Mai Mtetezi or FPDC-ML, Twirwaneho, Gumino. Three days after the ceasefire was concluded, violence broke out in Bigaragara.

Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Nga�ssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, S�l�ka R�nov�e, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) and MINUSCA, with support from local officials and traditional and religious leaders, mediated a round of negotiations between the UPC, MPC, RPRC, MLJC, anti-Balaka-Molokom, and FPRC in Bria from 1 to 9 April 2019. This led to the signing of the Bria Accord on 9 April 2019. This local agreement was aimed at reinforcing the implementation of the 6 February 2019 national agreement. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire to end to the violence in Haute-Kotto and Ouaka prefectures, as well as guaranteed the safe and free movement of persons, goods, and humanitarian aid on the main axis.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), MINUSCA, local government, traditional leaders, religious leaders

side_a: Brigade 301, Ghaniwa Brigade, Nawasi Battalion, TRB
description: On 28 August 2018, the parties reached a ceasefire agreement, but this quickly fell apart that same night.

side_a: Brigade 301, Ghaniwa Brigade, Nawasi Battalion, TRB
description: On 29 August 2018, officials from the Libyan government in the form of a Conflict Resolution Committee and the United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) mediated a ceasefire, but this broke down the next day.

side_a: Brigade 301, Ghaniwa Brigade, Nawasi Battalion, TRB
description: The UN mission mediated negotiations that led to another truce on 31 August 2018, but this ceasefire again failed immediately.

side_a: Brigade 301, Ghaniwa Brigade, Nawasi Battalion, TRB
description: The UNSMIL special envoy brokered a ceasefire agreement between the two sides in Zawiyya, on 4 September 2018.

side_a: Brigade 301, Ghaniwa Brigade, Nawasi Battalion, TRB
description: Five days later, on 9 September 2018, the UN representative mediated a more comprehensive agreement referred to as the Zawiyya Agreement that would transfer authority over critical infrastructure to the official forces of the government from the de facto armed forces.

side_a: Brigade 301, Ghaniwa Brigade, Nawasi Battalion, TRB
description: On 21 September 2018, the two sides met in Castelverde with Minister of Interior, Brig. Gen. Abdulsalam Mustafa Ashour sponsoring the meeting. This mediation effort produced a final ceasefire agreement between Kaniyat and the Tripoli Militia Cartel, which was signed on 25 September 2018.

side_a: Brigade 301, Ghaniwa Brigade, Nawasi Battalion, TRB
description: The September 2018 ceasefire held until a brief flare-up in November 2018. However, a ceasefire was re-established quickly on 15 November 2018 by the security committee that produced in the September agreements.
Negotiations led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 25 September 2018. This accord was brokered by the United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL).

Responding to growing tensions, the US company AECOM organized a peace meeting in August 2014 in Boma involving Murle, Jie, Kachipo, and Toposa representatives. Several resolutions on peaceful relations were adopted at the meeting, but animosity between the Jie and the Murle persisted.

The animosity escalated into armed violence on 6 July 2018, when the Murle community attacked the neighboring Jieh community in the border area of Boma and Kapoeta. The Murle attack was in response to a dispute over access to land and water resources. Government officials and army generals in Juba allegedly supported the Murle in their attack on the Jie. Boma State governor David Yau Yau met with the conflict parties in conflict area on 9 July 2018.
A round of bilateral negotiations between the Biide and Sa�ad in Somaliland in November 2019 led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. However, the agreement already broke down in December 2019.

Violence between both communities erupted from November 1997 to March 1998. The police immediately imposed a curfew after the violence of November 1997. In January 1998, as the conflict was still going on, the military administrator of Nasarawa State, Wing Commander Abdullahi Ibrahim, established the committee of inquiry into the communal crisis in the Toto local government area led by Kasimu Idris. Furthermore, the Nasawara State council of Chiefs set up a 7-man Technical committee to broker peace negotiations between the two communities, but there is no evidence that negotiations materialized. In July 2001, the US Agency for Internal Development (USAID) sponsored a conflict resolution workshop in which the conflict parties discussed solutions to their conflict.

When the conflict again erupted in November 2016, Governor Yahaya Bello, accompanied by the state police commissioner Abdullahi Chafe and some state security chiefs, visited the conflict area and encouraged the feuding groups to make peace. The chairman of the city of Ugya, General Malam Musa (Muhammad Ohinoyi), also met with the conflict parties. However, violence between the Bassa Kwomu and Egbura Mozum clans resumed in Kogi State and in the Toto LGA of Nasawara State in 2018. In the week of 9 July 2018, Governor of Nasawara State Umaru Tanko Al-Makura met with stakeholders from the Bassa ethnic group and members of the State Security Council in Abuja to ease tensions. In his statement, Al-Makura promised to create a Bassa Chiefdom before the end of his mandate and set up peace between the two communities. No agreement was reportedly signed during this meeting.

After the two communities clashed from January to March 2019, the Nigerian arm began to disarm the conflict parties. Moreover, the governor of Nasarawa state and Major General Adeyemi Yekini convened a peace meeting at the government house in Lafia on 26 March 2019. The heads of security agencies in the state, political officials, the Chairman of the Toto local government council, and traditional rulers also took part in the meeting. The peace meeting led to the signing of an eleven-point peace agreement in which the conflict parties agreed to a ceasefire and for the army to disarm the groups of their illegal weapons. In addition, the tribes pledged to establish Joint Peace Reconciliation Committees.
third_party: local government, government forces, traditional leaders

description: From 10 to 13 December 2018, the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) convened a peace conference in the Greater Lakes, along with the Disabled Association for Rehabilitation and Development and Oxfam. The Gak and Manuer Dinka attended the conference and they reached a truce on 13 December 2018. When clashes continued in 2019, the UN deployed peacekeeping forces to quell the violence.

Following an armed clash in Akobo on 6 July 2018, the governor of Bieh state, Brigadier General Simon Hoth Duol with the help of local chiefs, mediated between the conflict parties and managed to separate the two groups.

side_a: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: Fighting resumed on 7 August 2019, resulting in STC capturing Aden on 10 August 2019. Saudi Arabia immediately urged the parties to hold peace talks and the two sides announced a ceasefire on the same day.

side_a: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: From 24 September to 24 October 2019, Saudi Arabia held indirect talks between the Government of Hadi and the STC in Jaddah, Saudi Arabia. This eventually led to the signing of the Riyadh Agreement between the STC and the Forces of Hadi in the Saudi capital on 5 November 2019. The agreement stipulated the formation of a new Aden-based government, consisting of 12 southern and 12 northern ministers. Both sides also committed to withdraw their military and security personnel from the southern cities.

side_a: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 9 January 2020, the two sides signed a prisoner exchange deal brokered by the Saudi-led committee resulting from the Riyadh agreement and composed of the warring parties, which was tasked with its implementation.

side_a: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 20 April 2020, the Forces of Hadi and the STC held talks in Aden. These talks were mediated by the implementation committee of the Ryiadh Agreement and were reportedly aimed at the implementation of the security and military annexes of the Riyadh Agreement. Despite these peace efforts, the STC declared self-governance of Yemen�s south on 26 April 2020.

side_a: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 22 June 2020, the forces of Hadi and the STC reached a Saudi-brokered ceasefire agreement in Abyan. The two sides agreed to start discussions on implementing the Riyadh agreement. The Saudi-led coalition promised to send observers to monitor the implementation of the ceasefire. Moreover, on 29 July 2020, Saudi Arabia announced a peace plan to revive the stalled Riyadh Agreement, which was accepted by the two parties. In line with this new peace initiative, the STC announced that it would abandon its declaration of self-administration of the south because of the continuing and deepening strategic partnership of the STC with the Saudi-led coalition. Nevertheless, the armed fighting escalated once more and the STC announced its withdrawal from peace talks on 26 August 2020.

side_a: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: On 10 November 2020, a Saudi military committee made up of two delegations held separate meetings with the leadership of the Forces of Hadi and the STC in Abyan in an attempt to halt the hostilities.

side_a: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: From 8 to 10 December 2020, Saudi Arabia mediated peace talks between the two warring parties in Riyadh. Concluding the talks, the parties agreed on a deal to start implementing the Riyadh Agreement and to form a government of 24 ministers. President Hadi had sworn in 23 of the 24 ministers in Riyadh by 26 December 2020.

side_a: Forces of the Presidential Leadership Council
description: Fighting between the STC and the Forces of Hadi resumed in March 2021 when the cabinet left Aden after STC supporters stormed the Presidential Palace. The two parties participated in a new round of peace talks mediated by Saudi Arabia in Riyadh in the beginning of June 2021. On 14 June 2021, the two warring parties signed a peace agreement following a round of negotiations mediated by Saudi Arabia. The conflict parties committed to halt fighting and to the safe return of the government to the interim capital Aden. Once again, they also pledged to revive the implementation of the Riyadh Agreement.

A peace meeting between the Fulani on the one side and the Yandang and four other ethnic groups on the other side led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in the Lau Local Government Area in Taraba State on 21 July 2018. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire, the withdrawal of all militias, and the formation of a peace and reconciliation committee.

In early November 2018, the Assessment and Reconciliation committee set up by the Governor of Adamawa mediated between the leaders of the Lugunda and Waja. Waja leader Malam Saleh and Lunguda leader John Monsirmi declared their desire to maintain peace between the two communities, though no agreement was concluded.

In May 2021, Governor Muhammadu Inuwa Yahaya convened a peace meeting involving stakeholders from the Lunguda and Waja Communities in Balanga Local Government Area of Gombe State in Nigeria. The primary focus was to address and resolve the communal clashes between the two groups, emphasizing forgiveness, tolerance, and unity for the sake of promoting lasting peace and communal development. Following a five-hour discussion, both parties agreed to reconcile, forgive each other, and work towards restoring the long-standing peace between the communities.

On 18 June 2022, a peace and reconciliation meeting took place in Balanga LGA of Gombe State, following recurring conflicts between Lunguda and Waja communities. The meeting, facilitated by the District Head of Nyuwar and notable individuals from both the Waja and Lunguda ethnic groups, aimed to restore peace to the region.
third_party: District Head of Nyuwar, Local Individuals

description: In May 2022, a peace conference was held in Enijbara town, in the Ahmara region. Representatives from all of Metekel�s woredas and Awi zone participated. This included Gumuz, Sinasha, Oromo, Ahmara and Agaw.

In June 2022, a traditional peace and reconciliation ceremony was held in Wemebera woreda, in the Metekel zone, in which Gumuz, Sinasha, Oromo, Amhara, Agaw cohabitate. Elders from 11 kebeles of Wemebera woreda participated.

In August 2022, elders from Metekel visited Dangur Woreda Aysika Kebel center and held peace discussions. The Metekel region is diverse, with Gumuz, Sinasha, Oromo, Amhara, Agaw cohabitating in this region.

In response to armed clashes between the Ikurav and Shitilet in the town of Katsina-Ala in Benue State in April 2019, the Benue state government imposed a 24-hour curfew on 22 April 2019 as part of peacekeeping efforts in the region. Directly after the resumption of hostilities in August 2019 in Katsina-Ala, the Benue State Police Command mediated negotiations between the communities to resolve the crisis. However, this did not result in any agreement since the two tribes could not agree on the causes of the attacks.
Negotiations between the Beni Amir and Nuba led to a peace agreement in El Gedaref in May 2019.

In response to armed clashes between the conflict parties, the Sudanese government, in the form of the Sovereignty Council of Sudan, mediated between the conflict parties on 22 August 2019. These talks did not lead to an agreement.

The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) and MINUSCA, with support from local officials and traditional and religious leaders, mediated a round of negotiations between the UPC, MPC, RPRC, MLJC, anti-Balaka-Molokom, and FPRC in Bria from 1 to 9 April 2019. This led to the signing of the Bria Accord on 9 April 2019. This local agreement was aimed at reinforcing the implementation of the 6 February 2019 national agreement. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire to end to the violence in Haute-Kotto and Ouaka prefectures, as well as guaranteed the safe and free movement of persons, goods, and humanitarian aid on the main axis.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), MINUSCA, local government, traditional leaders, religious leaders

description: The Sudan-based Arab Mediation and Reconciliation Committee, comprised by 17 Taish, Salamate and Missiria community leaders, mediated a temporary ceasefire between the MLCJ/Kara and the FPRC/Rounga in Am-Dafock in December 2019.
Goula elders mediated between the MLCJ/Kara and the FPRC/Rounga in December 2019.

On 26 and 27 January 2020, MINUSCA supported the Prefect of Haute Kotto and the MPC leader to mediate between MLCJ and FPRC. The Parti du rassemblement de la nation centrafricaine (PRNC) (English: Party of the Rally of the Central African Nation) was also involved in the dialogue. The PRNC had been formed as a split faction from the Rassemblement patriotique pour le renouveau de la Centrafrique (RPRC) (English: Assembly for the Renaissance of Central Africa) RPRC in May 2019, while the RPRC, in turn, had split from the FPRC in November 2014. The parties concluded a ceasefire agreement concerning three areas in the city of Bria (Ndrou, Gbakoundji, and Mande) on 26 January 2020. On 27 January 2020, it twas agreed to withdraw all armed elements from the three affected quarters and to work on an agreement with the assistance of religious leaders.

In April 2022, the Congolese government and various armed groups attended a peace conference in Nairobi. The peace conference was held under the auspices of the East African Community (EAC). Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta acted as the EAC mediator during the peace conference. Both the CNPSC and the Twiganeho participated in the Nairobi peace process. CNPSC leader Yakutumba sent his spokesperson to Nairobi, while Twirwaneho was represented by a close member of the diaspora based locally in Nairobi.
A second peace conference organized by the EAC was held in Nairobi in June 2022.

A third peace conference organized by the EAC was held in Nairobi between 28 November 2022 and 6 December 2022. Former President of Kenya Uhuru Kenyatta acted as the chief mediator at this peace conference.

In September 2019, the United Arab Emirates (UAE) flew in Mohammed Adam Lino of the Toubou group to prepare him for mediation between the two communities, but this mediation effort never materialized. In October 2019, the Ara Pacis Initiative and the Italian government jointly mediated between the conflict parties. The series of negotiations, referred to as the Murzuq Peace Dialogues, took place in Rome and led to the signing of the Agreement in Principle on 17 October 2019. This agreement outlined steps for a more comprehensive peace agreement.

To this purpose, a follow-up commission of representatives of the conflict parties convened in Rome from 12 to 14 November 2019. The Ara Parcs Initiative mediated this meeting, which was aimed at determining how to move forward with implementation of the previous agreement.
A follow-up meeting took place in Ubari December 2019.
On 16 June 2020, a reconciliation agreement between the Mouro and Dadjo communities was signed in Kerfi, almost a year after deadly clashes that claimed many lives.

The Abugbe and Agbaduma engaged in bilateral negotiations in June 2019 in response to armed clashes between the two tribes in the Local Government Area of Agatu in Benue State. This led to a peace agreement on 29 June 2019. However, fighting resumed directly after the signing of the agreement.

On 29 August 2019, the two rival communities reached a peace agreement during a peace meeting mediated by the deputy Governor of Benue State, Benson Abounou, in Makurdi. This agreement partially resolved the land dispute between the parties. The agreement built on the efforts of a peace committee that had previously been set up by the state government to discuss the chieftaincy title in Aila, ownership of the Ohebu fish pond, the agricultural land surrounding the pond, Ashukwu, and Adagole. The Abugbe community agreed to renounce its claim to ownership of the Ohebu fishpond in favor of the Aigocheigwu family in Agbaduma. In addition, it was agreed that all the people farming around the Ohebu pond should continue to have unhindered access until the dry season, when the committee will visit the area and solve the problems concerning the farmland.

On 22 February 2022, a peace conference, attended by over 20 clans from the Agatu community in North Central Nigeria, led to the signing of an agreement aiming to put an end to long-standing conflicts over water and land. The agreement primarily focused on the fair sharing of resources, allowing unrestricted movement in the area, and ensuring the safe return of numerous displaced individuals. The peace deal was facilitated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) and is known as the Natural Resource Peace Agreement in the Agatu Local Government Area.
agreement_name: Natural Resource Peace Agreement in the Agatu Local Government Area

description: In 2014, the Ministry of Federal and Pastoral Development Affairs mediated between the Afar and the Somali regional states. The parties reached a peace agreement, which included the redrawing of borders and kebeles-assignation. However, the Somali regional state later withdrew from the agreement.
third_party: Ministry of Federal and Pastoral Development Affairs

description: On 8 April 2021, the Ministry of Peace mediated between the Afar and Somali regional presidents during a round of peace talks. The parties agreed to put an end to violence. Despite the agreement, armed clashes have subsequently been registered between the two regions.

Between 26 May and 1 June 2023, several armed groups took part in an inter-armed group dialogue in the locality of Aru. The provincial government was led by Lieutenant-General Johny Luboya and MONUSCO acted as mediators. The primary objective of the dialogue was to reconcile differences among the participating armed groups and to ensure adherence to prior agreements concerning the cessation of hostilities in Ituri. Each militia faction accused the others of violating previous peace accords, leading to violent confrontations. The overarching aim of the discussions was to prepare the armed groups for their inclusion in the Disarmament, Demobilisation, Community Rehabilitation, and Stabilisation Programme. The dialogue concluded with a memorandum of understanding, which included a commitment to cease hostilities, as well as committed the leaders of the armed groups to facilitate the free movement of people and their property throughout Ituri province, to stop carrying weapons, and to stop wearing military or police uniforms. The memorandum also included a roadmap for peace. The memorandum was signed by the FPIC and the FRPI, the Coop�rative pour le d�veloppement du Congo (CODECO) (English: Cooperative for the development of Congo), the Zaire self-defense group, and the Mouvement d�auto-d�fense populaire de l�Ituri (MAPI) (English: Ituri Popular Self-Defence Movement).

On 27 August 2020, MINUSCA and local mediators � including Francois Dieudonne Bata Wapi Yepi, the President of the Prefectural Implementation Committee (CMOP) set up by the CAR Government to implement the peace accord signed on 6 February 2019, and Ibrahim Senoussi, the Common Sultan-Mayor of Dar-El-Kouti � mediated between the conflict parties. This led to the signing of the Non-Aggression and Peaceful Cohabitation Pact Between the Disputing Parties From Bamingui-Bangoran. This local agreement reaffirmed the commitment of the armed groups to the Political Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation.
third_party: MINUSCA, President of the Prefectural Implementation Committee
agreement_name: Non-Aggression and Peaceful Cohabitation Pact Between the Disputing Parties From Bamingui-Bangoran

description: On 27 August 2020, MINUSCA and local mediators � including Francois Dieudonne Bata Wapi Yepi, the President of the Prefectural Implementation Committee (CMOP) set up by the CAR Government to implement the peace accord signed on 6 February 2019, and Ibrahim Senoussi, the Common Sultan-Mayor of Dar-El-Kouti � mediated between the conflict parties. This led to the signing of the Non-aggression and peaceful cohabitation pact between the disputing parties from Bamingui-Bangoran. This local agreement reaffirmed the commitment of the armed groups to the Political Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation.
third_party: MINUSCA, President of the Prefectural Implementation Committee
agreement_name: Non-Aggression and Peaceful Cohabitation Pact Between the Disputing Parties From Bamingui-Bangoran

description: In September 2020, UNMISS hosted a peace conference to address the prolonged violence in the Jonglei region involving Dinka, Nuer, and Murle groups. The meeting involved political leaders at national and state levels, community elders, civil society representatives, and other stakeholders engaging in peace talks. The conference led to the signing of the Bor Communiqu� on 9 September 2020, which highlighted a commitment to a bottom-up approach for peace involving youth and local leaders in conflict areas.

From 15 to 25 March 2021, delegates from Dinka Bor, Murle, and Lou Nuer communities � including women, youth leaders, and traditional leaders � met in Pieri. The negotiations were mediated by the NGO Peace Canal, a NGO financed by UK Aid. Peace Canal worked with a local mediator in each of the three communities. UNMISS provided some logistical support to the process, but UNMISS staff were not present at the conference. The conference was held under the guidance of Nuer Spiritual Leader Gok Deng Dak Kueth. The participants discussed the conflict�s impact and practical steps forward, focusing on issues such as abductions, cattle raiding, and civilian killings, aiming to build confidence in the peace process. The conference led to the signing of the Pieri Agreement by all parties. In this agreement, the communities pledged to support peace efforts, and develop modalities for punishment of perpetrators, return of abducted women and children, and return of stolen cattle.
A Jonglei-GPAA Inter-Communal Governance Structures meeting was held in December 2021 to follow up on the Pieri Agreement.
A Jonglei-GPAA Inter-Communal Governance Structures meeting was held in Juba in late July 2023 to follow up on the Pieri Agreement.
A Jonglei-GPAA Inter-Communal Governance Structures meeting was held Ayod from 2-6 November 2023 to follow up on the Pieri Agreement.

A peace conference attended by participants Bor Dinka, Murle, and Lou Nuer leaders from Bor County from Jonglei State and Gumuruk County from GPAA took place in Juba from 14 to 15 November 2022. The NGO Peace Canal and UNMISS Civil Affairs supported the conference. The conference led to the signing of the Agreement of Peace Dialogue. However, soon after the signing of this agreement, the Lou Nuer and Bor Dinka mobilized to conduct a large-scale attack on the Murle in the GPAA over the course of December 2022 and January 2023. This attack was allegedly in retaliation for the Murle raids into Lou Nuer and Dinka territory, which the Pieri process had failed to stop.

On 2 October 2020, at the palace of Agwatyap Dominic Yahaya, the paramount ruler of Atyap (also Kataf) Chiefdom, a Peace and Security Partnership Committee (ACPSPC) of the Atyap Chiefdom was established. This initiative emerged after a peace summit convened by the chief in August to urgently address escalating violence. During this period, armed individuals, reportedly identified as ethnic Fulani, were engaging in severe retaliatory actions, prompting concern from surviving victims, government, and security sources due to the conflict�s increasingly intense nature. The next year, in October 2021, a meeting between Fulani leaders and the Peace and Security Partnership Committee (ACPSPC) of the Atyap Chiefdom was held in Kafanchan. The meeting was intended to hear the Fulani perspective on the way forward concerning the ongoing crisis in the chiefdom. Leaders of Fulani communities in Atyap chiefdom of Zangon Kataf Local Government Area of Kaduna State demanded that their members, who fled various villages in the area due to insecurity, would be allowed to return in order to end the lingering crisis in the chiefdom.

In October 2022, the Atyap, Hausa and Fulani communities in Atyap Chiefdom of Southern Kaduna engaged in peace dialogue. The dialogue was mediated by Victor Abarshi, a program officer of the Kaduna State Peace Commission. The dialogue took place separately in Zonzon, Agwan Gaiya, Gora and Zango Urban districts of the Chiefdom in Zango Kataf Local Government Area.

On 12 May 2023, leaders of the Atyap, Hausa and Fulani communities in Zangon Kataf Local Government Area (LGA) of Kaduna State signed an agreement. During the meeting a peace and reconciliation committee was set up with representatives of the three communities as members.

In April 2022, the Congolese government and various armed groups attended a peace conference in Nairobi. The peace conference was held under the auspices of the East African Community (EAC). Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta acted as the EAC mediator during the peace conference. Both the CNPSC and the Twiganeho participated in the Nairobi peace process. CNPSC leader Yakutumba sent his spokesperson to Nairobi, while Twirwaneho was represented by a close member of the diaspora based locally in Nairobi.
A second peace conference organized by the EAC was held in Nairobi in June 2022.

A third peace conference organized by the EAC was held in Nairobi between 28 November 2022 and 6 December 2022. Former President of Kenya Uhuru Kenyatta acted as the chief mediator at this peace conference.

In May 2022, a peace conference was held in Enijbara town, in the Ahmara region. Representatives from all of Metekel�s woredas and Awi zone participated. This included Gumuz, Sinasha, Oromo, Ahmara and Agaw.

In June 2022, a traditional peace and reconciliation ceremony was held in Wemebera woreda, in the Metekel zone, in which Gumuz, Sinasha, Oromo, Amhara, Agaw cohabitate. Elders from 11 kebeles of Wemebera woreda participated.

In August 2022, elders from Metekel visited Dangur Woreda Aysika Kebel center and held peace discussions. The Metekel region is diverse, with Gumuz, Sinasha, Oromo, Amhara, Agaw cohabitating in this region.

In September 2020, UNMISS hosted a peace conference to address the prolonged violence in the Jonglei region involving Dinka, Nuer, and Murle groups. The meeting involved political leaders at national and state levels, community elders, civil society representatives, and other stakeholders engaging in peace talks. The conference led to the signing of the Bor Communiqu� on 9 September 2020, which highlighted a commitment to a bottom-up approach for peace involving youth and local leaders in conflict areas.

On 10 December 2020, Lou Nuer and Murle armed youth leaders met in Pieri. They engaged in peace talks and made a resolution for peace, as well as engaged in a spear ceremony guided by Spiritual Leader Gok Deng Dak Kueth.

From 14 to 18 January 2021, Murle and Bor Dinka armed youth leaders from Jonglei State met in Rumbek in Lakes State for a peace meeting. Galweng leaders acted as mediators during this peace meeting. The meeting led to the signing of a mutual commitment to peace witnessed by galweng leaders.

From 15 to 25 March 2021, delegates from Dinka Bor, Murle, and Lou Nuer communities � including women, youth leaders, and traditional leaders � met in Pieri. The negotiations were mediated by the NGO Peace Canal, a NGO financed by UK Aid. Peace Canal worked with a local mediator in each of the three communities. UNMISS provided some logistical support to the process, but UNMISS staff were not present at the conference. The conference was held under the guidance of Nuer Spiritual Leader Gok Deng Dak Kueth. The participants discussed the conflict�s impact and practical steps forward, focusing on issues such as abductions, cattle raiding, and civilian killings, aiming to build confidence in the peace process. The conference led to the signing of the Pieri Agreement by all parties. In this agreement, the communities pledged to support peace efforts, and develop modalities for punishment of perpetrators, return of abducted women and children, and return of stolen cattle.
A Jonglei-GPAA Inter-Communal Governance Structures meeting was held in December 2021 to follow up on the Pieri Agreement.
A Jonglei-GPAA Inter-Communal Governance Structures meeting was held in Juba in late July 2023 to follow up on the Pieri Agreement.
A Jonglei-GPAA Inter-Communal Governance Structures meeting was held Ayod from 2-6 November 2023 to follow up on the Pieri Agreement.

A peace conference attended by participants Bor Dinka, Murle, and Lou Nuer leaders from Bor County from Jonglei State and Gumuruk County from GPAA took place in Juba from 14 to 15 November 2022. The NGO Peace Canal and UNMISS Civil Affairs supported the conference. The conference led to the signing of the Agreement of Peace Dialogue. However, soon after the signing of this agreement, the Lou Nuer and Bor Dinka mobilized to conduct a large-scale attack on the Murle in the GPAA over the course of December 2022 and January 2023. This attack was allegedly in retaliation for the Murle raids into Lou Nuer and Dinka territory, which the Pieri process had failed to stop.

In Jubbaland, reconciliation talks, facilitated by the state administration and the Soransoor clan, took place between the Majerten and Awramale clans. From 10 May to 4 June 2020, the two clans agreed to withdraw armed militia from the affected areas. A meeting of Hawadle clan elders was convened in Beledweyne on 11 June 2020 by the President of Hirshabelle, Mr. Ware, with a view to minimize conflict over district council formation processes.

In May 2022, a peace conference was held in Enijbara town, in the Ahmara region. Representatives from all of Metekel�s woredas and Awi zone participated. This included Gumuz, Sinasha, Oromo, Ahmara and Agaw.

In June 2022, a traditional peace and reconciliation ceremony was held in Wemebera woreda, in the Metekel zone, in which Gumuz, Sinasha, Oromo, Amhara, Agaw cohabitate. Elders from 11 kebeles of Wemebera woreda participated.

In August 2022, elders from Metekel visited Dangur Woreda Aysika Kebel center and held peace discussions. The Metekel region is diverse, with Gumuz, Sinasha, Oromo, Amhara, Agaw cohabitating in this region.

On 10 October 2023, the Fulani and Mwaghavul communities in Mangu Local Government Area of Plateau State, convened by the paramount ruler of Mangu, Da. John Hirse. The meeting aimed to address the ongoing conflict between the Fulani and Mwaghavul communities that had been escalating since April. The primary objective was to find lasting solutions and restore peace in the area by appealing for a cessation of hostilities and promoting reconciliation between the conflicting groups.

Between 26 May and 1 June 2023, several armed groups took part in an inter-armed group dialogue in the locality of Aru. The provincial government was led by Lieutenant-General Johny Luboya and MONUSCO acted as mediators. The primary objective of the dialogue was to reconcile differences among the participating armed groups and to ensure adherence to prior agreements concerning the cessation of hostilities in Ituri. Each militia faction accused the others of violating previous peace accords, leading to violent confrontations. The overarching aim of the discussions was to prepare the armed groups for their inclusion in the Disarmament, Demobilisation, Community Rehabilitation, and Stabilisation Programme. The dialogue concluded with a memorandum of understanding, which included a commitment to cease hostilities, as well as committed the leaders of the armed groups to facilitate the free movement of people and their property throughout Ituri province, to stop carrying weapons, and to stop wearing military or police uniforms. The memorandum also included a roadmap for peace. The memorandum was signed by the FPIC and the FRPI, the Coop�rative pour le d�veloppement du Congo (CODECO) (English: Cooperative for the development of Congo), the Zaire self-defense group, and the Mouvement d�auto-d�fense populaire de l�Ituri (MAPI) (English: Ituri Popular Self-Defence Movement).

On 19 May 2022, during a meeting in Bunia, the militia leaders of Ituri, including FPIC, ARDPC/CODECO, FDBC, and FRPI, expressed readiness to participate in a round of consultations in Nairobi, Kenya. The meeting, held under the auspices of MONUSCO and attended by representatives from the Congolese presidency and the Kenyan embassy, aimed to advance peace efforts in the region. The militia leaders demonstrated their commitment to peace by signing a unilateral agreement to cease hostilities and mobilizing their troops for pre-cantonment.

MINUSCA shuttled between the CPC and the Azande Ani Kpi Gbe militia in late May 2023. A meeting with the spokesperson of the Azande Ani Kpi Gbe militia was conducted on 31 May 2023. The primary focus of the discussions revolved around the threats and abuses perpetrated by the group, but also related to the need to avoid stirring up communal tensions. During the meeting, the spokesperson offered apologies and reiterated that the militia�s principle was not to target the civilian population.

On 22 July 2022, following a closed-door security meeting chaired by the state's deputy governor, Haruna Manu, leaders of the Fulani and Kuteb ethnic groups agreed to a ceasefire to allow for a peaceful coexistence among the people.
